title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey

The toddler, Georgia Kent, died at Cooper University Hospital in Camden at 6:43 p.m., about eight hours after she was hit by the tree, according to Sgt. Kevin Rehmann of the state police. The toddler was playing in the yard while her father, Edward Kent, was cutting down the tree.   (AP)

title: Europe's Union to Grow by 10
description: On May 1, 2004, the European Union officially expands to 25 members, adding 10 countries in Eastern Europe and the Mediterranean -- the Czech Republic, Cyprus, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia. In one broad sweep, the union will grow to 450 million people and an economy rivaling the United States in size. There are predictions of chaos. Decision-making, not exactly easy even among the core countries of what has been called old Europe, will get more cumbersome. A flood of migrants could swamp the sluggish Western European job markets. But there is also optimism. The low wages of the East may force countries like Germany and France to overhaul their own economies and loosen up labor rules. That could make Europe more competitive and give it a much-needed shot of self-confidence.

title: Factoring in Politics
description: Advertising spending, watched closely as an indicator of economic vigor or malaise, has grown steadily in 2003 -- by 3.3 percent through September when compared with the period last year, according to Nielsen Monitor-Plus. The biggest gain in ad spending through the third quarter came from the auto sector -- with spending by car dealer associations up 67 percent and by automakers up 14 percent. Pharmaceutical ad spending continued to come on strong, with a 15 percent increase.

title: Microsoft's European Test
description: Microsoft's antitrust troubles are mostly behind it in the United States. The Bush administration's settlement of the federal antitrust suit left the company intact and its business practices little changed. Microsoft is now engaged in mopping up private suits, including a $750 million settlement with Time Warner last May. But in Europe, Microsoft still faces a severe test. The European Commission accuses it of antitrust transgressions that warrant tougher remedies. The sanctions under consideration include forcing Microsoft to remove its media player software from the Windows operating system. Such a sanction would outlaw the essence of Microsoft's business strategy -- bundling new kinds of software into Windows. A settlement or sanctions is expected early in 2004.

title: Has the Time Come to Settle?
description: Every few months, American or Canadian trade negotiators put out word that a deal is near in the long dispute over imports of Canadian softwood lumber. Used mainly for building houses, the lumber has about a third of the United States market. The United States imposed punitive duties totaling 29 percent last year after concluding that Canadian mills had flouted international trade rules through unfair subsidies and by pricing timber below production costs. Canada responded with complaints through the North American Free Trade Agreement and the World Trade Organization. Relations between the two nations have been somewhat cool since Canada's prime minister, Jean Chrtien, declined to back the war in Iraq. Mr. Chrtien is to retire on Dec. 12, and his successor, Paul Martin, has said he will give high priority to improving Canada's relations with Washington.

title: Informal Peace Plan for Mideast Is Unveiled in Geneva

title: Brazil to Weigh Modified Crops
description: The fate of genetically modified crops in Brazil, one of the world's fastest-growing agricultural superpowers, will hang in the balance in 2004. Permanent legislation on whether Brazil should commercialize transgenic crops is set to go before lawmakers. Opponents of the technology contend such crops present a potential long-term threat to public health and the country's rich biodiversity. Yet Brazil's increasingly powerful farming lobby, which says transgenic crops will generate 20 percent more revenue, looks likely to gain the upper hand. In 2003, agriculture generated nearly 30 percent of Brazil's growth, and Brazil overtook the United States as the biggest soy exporter.

title: Editorial Observer; Turning Northeast Wyoming Upside Down in the Hunt for Coal-Bed Methane
description: In its own quiet way, there is hardly a landscape in America lovelier than the hills of northeastern Wyoming. The drama of that countryside is understated, except when the weather bears down hard. Pockets of low brush on the hillsides burn as bright as sugar maples when October comes. After half a decade of drought, the pasture grasses by mid-November seem utterly bleached, as if they had been reduced to silica. Angus mother cows wander along the irrigation ditches, and when the sun catches the herd through a break in the clouds, the contrast between the black cattle and the blond light rising from the grass seems to define the limits of the visible spectrum.

Schick denied that charge and sued Gillette, saying that Quattro is unique and contending that Gillette's slogan ''The world's best shave'' is tantamount to false advertising. Gillette has asked for a preliminary injunction against Schick, and Judge Patti B. Saris of the United States District Court in Massachusetts is expected to rule soon.

They said the woman tried to catch a northbound No. 5 train as it left the station about 1:15 p.m., and her jacket became lodged in the door. A passenger freed the jacket, and the woman, whose name was not released, was treated at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital. title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MORE POSSIBLE BIAS INCIDENTS REPORTED Several incidents of possible anti-Semitic vandalism were reported on Saturday and yesterday in Brooklyn and Queens, including the defacing of buildings with swastikas, the police said. The police are investigating the incidents as bias crimes, but investigators said yesterday that there did not appear to be any direct connection to the vandalism in the largely Jewish neighborhood of Borough Park on Thanksgiving, when scores of tires were slashed. On Saturday morning, a swastika was found carved on the front door of the Congregation Sons of Israel synagogue in Astoria, the police said. Swastikas have also been found painted or written on buildings on Avenue V, Ocean Parkway and Shore Parkway in Brooklyn, and anti-Semitic statements were found painted on the walls and floors of a building on 114th Street in Queens, the police said.

title: Quiet Times in the Mideast Encourage Official and Unofficial Efforts for a Cease-Fire
description: Israel's security chiefs say that these relatively quiet times for Israelis are deceptive, that Palestinian suicide bombers are merely being foiled.

title: Radio ID Tag Deadline
description: With Jan. 1, 2005, set by Wal-Mart and the Defense Department as the date they expect to see tiny radio identification tags on much of what enters their warehouses, makers of thousands of products will be scrambling throughout 2004 to meet the deadline. R.F.I.D., as the technology is known, can handle much more product data than standard bar codes. Moreover, because radio signals travel through many materials, an R.F.I.D. reader does not need a direct line-of-sight contact to capture a tag's data, and large numbers of tags can be read almost simultaneously. Initially, the tags will be largely limited to cartons and pallets of products because the tags are still too expensive to use on most individual items.

title: The Challenge for Sony
description: The economy is on the mend in Japan, but the turnaround has not included the country's most famous company, Sony. The electronics and entertainment giant is going through a difficult period. Its marquee electronic products have been overtaken and undercut by low-cost rivals like Dell and Samsung. Sony's movie studio has failed to repeat its record run in 2002, and its music unit is trying to overcome hurdles to merge with Bertelsmann's BMG division. Even sales of its once enormously popular PlayStation 2 video game console are slowing. In October, Sony's chairman, Nobuyuki Idei, announced a broad three-year plan to improve profits that involves cutting about 10 percent of the work force. That could mean more pain in 2004, or the long-awaited revival of Japan's best-known brand.

title: In Brooklyn, a Grand Temple of Government, Without Much Governing Going On

He would break down the season into digestible units, just as he had last season. In 2002, the mandate to turn a 2-5 start to .500 worked for the Jets. They reached .500, then made the playoffs.

description: SCHWARTZ--Hortense M. On November 28, 2003, at age 96. Graveside service Tuesday, 1 pm, at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

title: Economy & Business; With Change in Consumer Confidence, So Goes the Presidency
description: A CHICKEN in every pot. A New Deal. The inflation-era ''misery index.''

title: Stinging Criticism
description: To the Editor:

title: Economy & Business; Selling to 45-Plus Generation: That's Where the Money Is
description: AMERICA is aging, and some people suggest that marketers are going to have to change their ways and start trying to appeal to the older set.

title: INSIDE
description: Steel Tariffs May Be Lifted

title: TALKING SHOP WITH: Zoe Lazarus and Richard Welch; Hunting for the Next Cool in Advertising
description: THE question haunting Madison Avenue these days is, to paraphrase Sigmund Freud, ''What do consumers want?'' As changes in demographics and lifestyles accelerate, consumer behavior is becoming increasingly difficult to predict. More people are surfing the Web, fewer are watching the tube. And a many are becoming more skeptical toward advertising in general.

title: Mississippi St. Hires S.E.C.s First Black Head Coach
description: Sylvester Croom, an assistant coach for the Green Bay Packers, accepted Mississippi State's offer today to be its head football coach, becoming the first black to hold such a position in the 71-year history of the Southeastern Conference.

title: Illegal Immigrants and Auto Licenses (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: More Medicine Is Not Better Medicine
description: No one in Washington is completely satisfied with the Medicare legislation that Congress approved last week. For many conservatives, the shift toward private health plans is too limited; for many liberals, the new prescription-drug benefit is too stingy. Yet almost everyone agrees that the current bill worsens the program's long-term financial stability.

title: Technology & Media; To Grab Young Readers, Newspapers Print Free, Jazzy Editions
description: WHEN he was hired by The Dallas Morning News two years ago, Bill Tanner's chief qualification was not that he had ever written for a newspaper, or sold advertisements for one. It was that he had spent two decades asking children as young as age 6 for their reactions to various Coca-Cola products, including Minute Maid juices and Hi-C fruit drinks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKEZIN, JAMES G.
description: MARKEZIN--James G. On November 28, 2003. Beloved husband of Ida. Loving father of Elaine, Ernest and the late Dean. Also survived by four grandchildren. Religious service on Tuesday, 10 am, at the Cathedral of St. Paul, Hempstead. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Beiderbecke Reimagined, With an Eclectic Approach
description: Slithering through the cracks that separate musical genres has long been a way of life for Geoff Muldaur. Over the years his albums have blended gospel and bluegrass, country blues and modern jazz, Tin Pan Alley and R&B. But however eclectic his approach, those who prefer their music in neatly labeled boxes have tended to agree that he belongs in the one marked ''folk singer.'' His new album should put an end to that idea.

title: New Yorkers Love to Complain, And Hot Line Takes Advantage
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that the city was adopting a 311 hot line for public complaints, he promoted it as a way to help New Yorkers navigate the hurdle-strewn path to city services.

title: Illegal Immigrants And Auto Licenses
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Heisman Trophy, An Open and Shut Case
description: Usually at this time of year, a debate rages about a certain bronze statue presented by the Downtown Athletic Club. It centers on what turns into a bedeviling question: is the Heisman Trophy awarded to the best college football player in the nation, period, or to the best player on the best team?

title: Girl, 12, Is Hit By a Gunshot In Brooklyn
description: Residents say nighttime gunshots are all too familiar at the Marlboro Houses in Gravesend, Brooklyn. But Judith Holmes still froze in terror when she and her two granddaughters encountered gunfire as they left one of the project's buildings about 1:30 a.m. yesterday.

title: Fight Over F.C.C. Deregulation
description: The battle over the rules that determine the reach of the nation's largest media conglomerates moves early next year to a court that has already indicated that it is skeptical of further deregulation of the industry. In February, lawyers representing consumer groups, industry and the government will present arguments in a lawsuit before a federal appeals court in Philadelphia. The court, which has temporarily blocked new rules set by the Federal Communications Commission under Chairman Michael K. Powell, will decide whether to overturn them entirely. They include one that would permit the same company to own newspapers and broadcast stations in the same city and others that would allow a company to own as many as three television stations and eight radio stations in the largest markets.

title: The Bills Wish More Games Worked Out Like This One
description: The frustrations kept piling up for the Buffalo Bills.

title: Gertrude Ederle, the First Woman to Swim Across the English Channel, Dies at 98
description: Gertrude Ederle, who was called ''America's best girl'' by President Calvin Coolidge in 1926 after she became the first woman to swim across the English Channel, died yesterday at a nursing home in Wyckoff, N.J. She was 98.

title: UAL Aims to End Bankruptcy
description: UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, is aiming to emerge from bankruptcy court in late spring, after having made the largest filing for Chapter 11 protection in aviation history in December 2002. Until last August, when it gave a new schedule to a bankruptcy court judge in Chicago, the company had been saying it would emerge from bankruptcy protection as early as this month. United, the second-largest airline, behind American, has said it will start operating a low-fare airline called Ted in February. In the third quarter of 2003, UAL reported an operating profit of $19 million, its first since the spring of 2000.

title: Venezuelans Flock to Sign Petitions for Chvez's Ouster
description: Sunday morning opened up with long lines at schools, plazas and churches, as thousands of antigovernment Venezuelans enthusiastically signed petitions seeking a recall referendum on the country's mercurial leader, President Hugo Chvez.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on July 10 about the Tour de France misstated the rules of the team time trial that helped put Lance Armstrong in position to win his fifth consecutive title. In a team time trial, teams are sent off at five-minute intervals, not five-mile intervals. (This correction was delayed by an editing oversight.)

title: Economy & Business; Biotech Industry Banks on Medicare Law for Help on Drug Bills
description: IN the year since Dr. Mark B. McClellan became head of the Food and Drug Administration, the biotechnology industry's complaints about how difficult it was to get drugs approved by the F.D.A. have eased. Now the industry has a new worry -- getting people to pay for its drugs after they are approved.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about Anthony Wright, a quarterback with the Baltimore Ravens, misstated the score of the overtime game in which he started on Nov. 16 against the Miami Dolphins. The Dolphins won, 9-6, not the Ravens by 10-9.

title: Technology & Media; Rampant Epidemics of Powerful Malicious Software
description: THERE is a kind of software that has consistently gotten faster and more powerful, and is available free worldwide. Unfortunately, it is ''malicious software,'' the insidious purveyor of viruses and other threats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINK, N. JOHN ''JACK.''
description: FINK--N. John ''Jack.'' 78, formerly of New York, passed away peacefully on November 28, 2003, surrounded by his family in Boca Raton, FL. For information, contact Babione Funeral Home (561395-8787).

title: Favored Group Has the Lead On Final Day in New Orleans
description: The Fall Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League began the final day Sunday with a favored group leading in the Reisinger Board-a-Match Team Championship. George Jacobs and Ralph Katz of Hinsdale, Ill., and Norberto Bocchi, Giorgio Duboin, Alfredo Versace and Lorenzo Lauria, who won Open Board-a-Match Teams a week ago, headed a powerful field after two days of qualifying and semifinal play. The four Italians have won many international titles, and missed capturing the Bermuda Bowl in Monaco earlier this month by a single imp.

title: Cheating in School, Cheating in Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaving Board, a Disney Heir Assails Eisner
description: Roy E. Disney, a nephew of Walt Disney, said on Sunday that he was leaving the Disney board of directors and called for the resignation of the chairman and chief executive, Michael D. Eisner.

title: Raymond J. Pettine, 91, Judge in Rhode Island Prison Case
description: Judge Raymond J. Pettine, a federal judge in Rhode Island whose rulings in several prominent cases included ordering an overhaul of the Rhode Island prison system and banning a Nativity scene on public property, died on Nov. 17 in Dallas. He was 91.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: More Possible Bias Incidents Reported
description: Several incidents of possible anti-Semitic vandalism were reported on Saturday and yesterday in Brooklyn and Queens, including the defacing of buildings with swastikas, the police said. The police are investigating the incidents as bias crimes, but investigators said yesterday that there did not appear to be any direct connection to the vandalism in the largely Jewish neighborhood of Borough Park on Thanksgiving, when scores of tires were slashed. On Saturday morning, a swastika was found carved on the front door of the Congregation Sons of Israel synagogue in Astoria, the police said. Swastikas have also been found painted or written on buildings on Avenue V, Ocean Parkway and Shore Parkway in Brooklyn, and anti-Semitic statements were found painted on the walls and floors of a building on 114th Street in Queens, the police said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Economy & Business; Only One Life to Spend and Spend
description: FOR as long as I can remember, I have thought of myself as a consumer first, a human being second. Instilled with the belief that all disposable cash must be disposed of quickly, I have long been an implacable adversary of the penny-pincher, the coupon clipper and the tightwad. In my view, buying appliances I do not need, gadgets I cannot operate, DVD's I may never watch and clothes that do not even look good on me is not only a birthright, but a sacred, patriotic duty.

title: The Patriots and McGinest Draw a Line in the Turf
description: The Colts' offense is often strokes of beauty. In the RCA Dome on Sunday, it singed the New England defense for four touchdown passes by Peyton Manning, 26 first downs, 370 total yards and 24 points in the second half.

title: Cheating in School, Cheating in Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 3 Stabbed In Bensonhurst
description: A man suspected in the stabbing of three men in a Bensonhurst apartment jumped out a window, breaking his leg, when officers arrived at the scene, the police said. The suspect, whose name and age were not released, was arrested and taken to Kings County Hospital Center for treatment, the police said. Another suspect escaped. The police arrived at the scene, at 1601 West Second Street, about 1 a.m. and found the two suspects and the three victims, ages 21, 26 and 31. An officer fired one shot, but police spokesmen said they did not know if he had hit the other suspect or why the officer had fired. The three stabbing victims were in stable condition yesterday, the police said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: SPECIAL TODAY: Outlook
description: A special issue of Business Day examines the prospects for the economy as it is dominated today by consumers. Their spending supports growth, and their likes and dislikes help to shape myriad industries. SECTION C

title: Steel Industry Expects Bush To Drop Tariffs
description: President Bush is expected to announce this week that he will immediately lift most of the tariffs he placed on foreign steel in an effort to protect American industry, bowing to a ruling by the World Trade Organization that his administration had violated global trading rules, industry officials who have been in negotiations with the White House said on Sunday.

title: The U.N.'s Challenge in Iraq
description: The United Nations has had a terrible year in Iraq. First it was marginalized by the misconceived unilateralism of the Bush White House. Then it was all but driven out of the country by the deliberate terrorist targeting of relief agencies. Yet with Washington now eager to get out of the occupation business and move more quickly toward restoring Iraq's sovereignty, it may become easier to revitalize the U.N.'s role. A meeting in New York today, convened by Secretary General Kofi Annan and bringing together Iraq's neighbors and leading members of the Security Council, could be an important first step.

title: SYRIAN PRESSING FOR ISRAEL TALKS
description: President Bashar al-Assad called Sunday for the United States to use its influence to revive negotiations between his country and Israel, portraying their absence as a gaping hole in the Bush administration's strategy for the Middle East.

title: Boeings Chief Steps Down a Week After Firings Over Ethics
description: Facing challenges from abroad and in Washington, the Boeing Company announced this morning that Phil Condit, the company's chairman and chief executive, had tendered his resignation, effective immediately.

title: Technology & Media; In Fight Between Cable and Satellite, Customers Gain an Edge
description: AS cable operators and satellite companies vie for customers next year, consumers could be the beneficiaries.

title: Technology & Media; TV's 'Pay More for Less' Pattern Is Under Pressure
description: FOR years, a strange but highly effective equation -- which might be called the failure model -- has worked wonders for the network television business: fewer viewers plus fewer hit shows equals more advertising revenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NORDLINGER, MILDRED
description: NORDLINGER--Mildred. On Friday, November 28, 2003, at age 88. Abounding in an infinity of energy and ingenuity, Milly was the first woman member of the Automotive Advertising Council. A creative and inventive toy and gift advertising executive, she later began her own agency. Focused her energies after retirement on issues that she had always found most important. As Chapter President of NOW and an avid worker for equal rights, pro-choice and healthcare for all, Milly fought passionately. Admired friend to so many. Much loved partner of William Silverman. Loving sister of Jay. Beloved Mom to Steve, Joan and James. Mother-in-law of Carol, Steven and Michelle. Adored grandmother of Alex, Jacob and Sam. We miss you.

title: Outsiders Bond in a South of Roiling Change
description: The plot hinges on the division of small amounts of pocket money -- nickles, dimes, even pennies. But there is nothing cheap or loose about ''Caroline, or Change,'' the carefully wrought chamber opera by Tony Kushner and Jeanine Tesori.

title: 2004: The Year of the Breakup
description: if (document.layers) { document.write(" "); } else { document.write(" "); } 2004: The Year of the Breakup var google_hints = "";

title: International Business; Consumerism Grows in China, With Beijing's Blessing
description: THE cellphone market extends block after block in this commercial hub in the southeast corner of the country. The ground floors of a string of buildings are filled with hundreds of small, fluorescent-lighted stalls, many with as little as eight feet of counter space.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 437 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Saturday:

title: Rangers Unable to Stop Toronto Winning Streak
description: When Rangers right wing Matthew Barnaby saw Toronto's Owen Nolan elbow and punch defenseman Darius Kasparaitis last night, he decided he had to do something.

title: The State of Health Care, in One Easy Number
description: Surrounding last week's Congressional debate over Medicare was a blizzard of budget figures, insurance statistics and cost projections -- an illustration of how deeply and confusingly intertwined economics and medicine have become. However, economic measures can clarify the health care picture as well as cloud it. One way for Americans to judge more easily the effectiveness of the new legislation, and of our health care system as a whole, is to adapt a leading tool of political economics: the misery index.

title: Anton Burg, 99; Developed New Compounds
description: Anton Burg, an expert on the nonmetallic element boron who developed compounds used as building blocks in the creation of synthetic materials, died on Nov. 19 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 99.

title: Economy & Business; I.R.S. Set To Resolve Disputes Online
description: FINDING a notice from the Internal Revenue Service in the mail is enough to ruin the day for many people, and the ensuing headache can last for weeks or months, as a taxpayer deals with clerk after clerk trying to get the information needed to resolve the issue. Next year, though, the ordeal will be much briefer for millions of taxpayers who rely on professionals to prepare their tax returns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRANT, FRANCES
description: GRANT--Frances. Beloved wife of William for 67 years. Wonderful mother of Edward Grant (wife Jane) and Alice Brofman. Also survived by grandchildren Michael (wife Penny) Grant, Gregory (wife Elisabetta) Grant and Ben Brofman, and a great-granddaughter, Antonia LewinsGrant. Best friend and sister to Shirley Brown and Anita Moss. Loving aunt to many nieces and nephews. She was special to all who knew her and will be sorely missed. Funeral service Monday, 11:30 am, at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Rd in Mamaroneck, 914381-1809, followed by an interment at King David Cemetery in Putnam Valley, NY.

title: Economy & Business; For the Influential, Time Savers Top Holiday Gift Lists
description: WHAT do people with busy lives and influential jobs value in their purchases? Reporters asked several such people to name their favorite purchase this year and something they looked forward to buying in 2004. Thoughts on holiday giving and receiving were also sought.

title: International Business; Thailand, a Retail Paradise
description: CHILDREN this time of year may dream of sugarplum fairies, but auto executives must fantasize about going to sleep and waking up in Thailand.

title: Economy & Business; Hotels to Flaunt Brands and Add Amenities
description: MORE than ever, hotel chains will emphasize their brands next year as they try to appeal to business and leisure travelers who are bargain hunters on some trips and free spenders on others.

title: Markets Shaped by Consumers
description: THAT consumers shape markets is a truism, but their influence is probably understated and certainly not fully understood. Eric von Hippel, a professor at the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, argues that a huge swath of innovation can be traced to elite consumers whom he calls lead users. These imaginative and technically adept consumers spot a need and invent a solution, often changing whole industries, from sports to software.

title: Turkish Engineer Released in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 30  Suspected Taliban fighters have released a Turkish road engineer whom they kidnapped a month ago in southern Afghanistan, threatening to kill him if the government did not release six Taliban prisoners.

title: Veteran Teaches Rookie From Seats on the Bench
description: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 30  By the end of this season, Robert Pack might even be speaking a little Croatian.

title: U.S. in Talks To Return Scores Held At Cuba Site
description: Senior Defense Department officials said Sunday that the military may soon release to their home countries scores of detainees, perhaps more than 100, who are being held in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RILEY, JOHN (JACK) DANIEL
description: RILEY--John (Jack) Daniel. Age 82. December 22, 1920 November 24, 2003. Baseball aficionado, loving father of Tricia, Monica, Sheila, and Dede, beloved brother of Dede Scovell and beloved friend of Paula. You are ''Unforgettable.'' See ya' pal.

title: A REGION INFLAMED: Baghdad Politics, Then and Now; In Dispute: The Caucus Plan
description: With the Iraqi Governing Council voting Sunday to support the principle of direct elections, the American plan for caucus-style elections is in doubt. But council members say direct elections may not be feasible because of such problems as the lack of voter rolls and the continuing violence. A council panel is studying ways to select a provisional government by spring, and may adapt a version of the caucus plan. The American proposal is shown here, according to the text of the agreement of Nov. 15 between the Coalition Provisional Authority and the Governing Council. ARCHIE TSE

title: China Frees 3 'Cyber Dissidents' (as a Diplomatic Visit Nears)
description: The Chinese government has released three jailed ''cyber dissidents,'' including a young college student nicknamed Stainless Steel Mouse whose arrest a year ago had brought international condemnation, a Hong Kong human rights group said Sunday.

title: An Accord to Remember
description: Today, civic leaders from across the Israeli and Palestinian political spectrum are gathering here to publicize what has become known as the Geneva Accord -- a negotiated but unofficial framework for reaching a permanent peace between our two peoples after years of bloodshed and lost and shattered lives.

title: U.N. Report Says Lack of Resolve Hinders Terror Effort
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 1  A lack of international cooperation and political resolve in many countries is undermining attempts to stem the flow of money and weapons to Al Qaeda and is allowing the group's influence to spread, a special committee of the Security Council said today.

title: Hewitt Achieves His Goal
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 30  It was a good week for Lleyton Hewitt. First he donned his "golden fleece," then he picked up the holy grail of tennis. In both cases, his name will be inscribed alongside the legends of his sport, which had been his goal much of this unusual season.

title: Economy & Business; Competition Keeps Up as Air Travel Returns
description: GETTING from Point A to Point B this holiday season is likely to take more time than usual, and that situation will probably not improve much in 2004, travel industry experts say.

title: You Can Go Home Again, but a Farmer's Sons Find It's Not So Profitable
description: On the eve of World War II, John Shields bought a 160-acre farm here with a handshake and a pledge to make cash payments whenever he could.

title: Jamaica Fire Ruins 2 Stores And Displaces 9 Tenants
description: A fire tore through a two-story brick building in southeast Queens early yesterday, injuring no one but gutting two stores on the first floor and displacing nine men who rented rooms on the second floor.

title: Losses in Iraq Won't Alter Spain's Policy, Leader Says
description: Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar said Sunday that Spain's course with regard to Iraq was unchanged and its determination unbroken, and that Spain would keep its troops in Iraq ''with loyalty and serenity,'' despite the killing of seven Spanish intelligence agents on Saturday.

title: Come On, Valiant Toys. Let's Fight Evil Mice.
description: What may be ballet's most beloved party has gotten under way, complete with swirling Snowflakes and sparkling Sugarplums.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNOPF, KATE (WEISS)
description: KNOPF--Kate (Weiss). Beloved wife of the late Alex Knopf. Beloved mother to Carole Stutzel and mother-inlaw to Dr. William Stutzel. Beloved sister of Harriet Moresh. Beloved sister of the late Yetta Cohen, Isidore and Edward Weiss and Blanche Wind. She devoted her life to helping others. She will be greatly missed by her relatives and friends. Services Monday, December 1, 2003, at 10:30 am, Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 Second Ave (near E. 10th St), NYC.

title: Pakistan to Lift Flight Ban
description: The president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, announced Sunday that as a good-will gesture, he would end a ban on Indian flights over Pakistani airspace.

title: A Holiday In a Haze, Until News Breaks Out
description: Ever since President John F. Kennedy's assassination, Americans have learned not to count too much on tranquil television viewing during the Thanksgiving season, yet Macy's parades and college football games still have a narcotic effect. By Thursday morning even 24-hour cable news had taken a deep breath and swung over to features about soup kitchen volunteers and the latest research on L-tryptophan.

title: Economy & Business; Some Businesses Take Initiative to Voluntarily Reduce Emissions
description: WHEN the Bush administration and the Republican leadership in Congress oppose capping emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases implicated in global warming, they argue that doing so would damage the economy. Major business lobbies in Washington like the National Association of Manufacturers support that stand.

title: Islanders Godard Injured
description: The Islanders placed Eric Godard on injured reserve yesterday with a strained right shoulder and used their roster space to shore up their offense by calling up Jeff Hamilton, who leads the American Hockey League in goals with 17. The Islanders also called up Mattias Weinhandl from their affiliate in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: MCI Tries for a Comeback
description: Welcome back MCI? It was taken over in 1999 by WorldCom, became tangled in a historic accounting fraud and was restructured in bankruptcy. Now, MCI is looking for a 2004 that is calm by comparison. But MCI, the nation's second-largest long-distance carrier, after AT&T, faces a tough challenge in rebuilding profits as revenue from its long-distance telephone business erodes. It would not surprise many analysts if MCI once again disappeared as an independent entity before the year is over. SBC Communications, Verizon and BellSouth are seen as potential acquirers.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Bengals Continue Their Turnaround
description: Cincinnati's huddle was silent late Sunday afternoon, but not for the same reason that Bengals huddles were silent in the old days.

title: Nebraska Explains the Firing of Solich
description: Nebraska's athletic director, Steve Pederson, said yesterday that he fired Coach Frank Solich after a 9-3 season and a six-year record of 58-19 because he felt the Cornhuskers were slipping into mediocrity.

title: White House Letter; A Trusted Aide Relishes Trailer-Park Life in Texas
description: Sometimes working for the president of the United States is as glamorous as living in a double-wide trailer on a dry stretch of prairie.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DOUGHERTY, JAMES W.
description: DOUGHERTY--James W. 11/25/40-12/1/95. How long is forever? Miss you, Tish

title: Music at Your Fingertips, but a Battle Among Those Selling It to You
description: COMING to a music download store in 2004: Yo-Yo Ma's Shostakovich Quartet No.15 and Bob Dylan's second show at Amsterdam.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Universal Vibe From South America
description: These records carry new sounds from South America -- folk-electronica, rock and jazz. They're the opposite of regional: they reflect the country of their origin to various degrees, but basically this is all universal music.

title: Economy & Business; The Teenage Market: Young, Hip and Looking for a Bargain
description: AH, the teenager: grown up enough to work part time, but not too old for birthday money or that weekly allowance.

title: Key Passages From Interview With Syria's President
description: Following are key passages from an interview on Sunday with President Bashar al-Assad of Syria. The president's office transcribed and translated the interview, in which Mr. Assad spoke in English and Arabic. A full transcript is available at www.nytimes.com/international.

title: Fresh Produce, the Downside
description: Americans are eating more fresh fruits and vegetables, and that is a healthy development. But a recent outbreak of hepatitis in western Pennsylvania is a reminder that in order to ensure the safety of our food supply chain, changes in our eating patterns require similar adjustments in our vigilance.

title: Drew Falters In Division III Men's Final
description: It was early in the second half and Drew University, which had not allowed a goal in 17 straight games before this weekend, was trailing Trinity (Tex.) by two goals in the N.C.A.A. Division III men's soccer final.

title: Technology & Media; Marketers Adjust as Spam Clogs the Arteries of E-Commerce
description: AFTER two decades in the garment business in New York, Allan Levy started an Internet company. His first idea -- gifts delivered with custom greeting cards -- did not catch on. So he tried selling gifts without the cards. Still no home run. But that led to a crucial insight: the real money on the Internet was in gathering e-mail addresses and using them to sell products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAHANER, LEAH
description: KAHANER -- Leah. Loving wife of the late Dr. Jack Richard Kahaner. Caring mother of Susan and Robert Caine, Helen and Donald Kahaner. Devoted grandmother of Stacey and Robert Marotta, Vicki Kahaner, Cecil and Karen Caine, Marc and Stacy Caine. Adoring great-grandmother of Alexander, Brian, Max, Isabelle, and Natalie Caine, and Alyssa and Samantha Marotta. Sister of Lewis Slaff. Greatly loved and sadly missed. Passed away November 28, 2003.

title: Technology & Media; Newsstands Beckon the Ink-Stained Entrepreneur
description: INDEPENDENT magazine publishers lack the distribution, bundled ad sales and marketing muscles of major media companies, but they seem to possess one thing the behemoths do not: courage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEUMANN, GERARD ANTHONY
description: NEUMANN--Gerard Anthony. 1928-2003. Gerard ''Rod'' Neumann of Saddle River, NJ, and Mattituck, NY, died at home on November 28, surrounded by his loving family. While he had much to be proud of in his professional life, he counted his family as his crowning achievement. He is survived by his wife of 43 years, Kathleen, his six children, Cecilia, James, Denise, Michael, Margaret and Patricia, their spouses, and eleven granchildren (with a twelfth expected in March). He loved boating, tennis and golf, The New York Times crossword puzzle, pruning trees beyond recognition, and writing songs for family occasions. Visitation at Van Emburgh Funeral Home in Ridgewood, NJ. Mass at Our Lady of Ostrabrama, Cutchogue, NY, at 11 am, on December 3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUMKIN, WALTON, ELAINE
description: BLUMKIN - WALTON -- Elaine. Died on September 14, 2003, in Merrick, L.I. Elaine was one of the first persons advanced to Director from the Clerical Staff of The Human Resources Department of New York City. Her approach to life was joyous, her positive liveliness attracted many friends. She is survived by her husband, Terry, her daughter, Shani McNamara, her son Jay Martin, and Ben and Danny Herman, Alex Martin, and Katie McNamara, her grandchildren, and Bea Abbe Allen, her step daughter.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants Need to Check Their Downward Spiral
description: THERE'S a thin line between a bad team and a bad franchise. The Giants, a bad team, are hovering perilously close to that line. This has nothing to do with yesterday's embarrassing 24-7 loss to the Buffalo Bills, but with how an organization recognizes signs of deterioration and how it takes action.

title: Waiting in Silicon Valley
description: In Silicon Valley, the Realtors can't wait. The nation's high-technology region has become obsessed with the impending initial public offering of Google, the leading Internet search engine. A flurry of press reports suggest that the company will go public some time between January and April of 2004, and prospects for the company's valuation have been reported as high as $25 billion. Google executives would not comment, but the company, according to reports, is considering a so-called Dutch auction, bypassing Wall Street and selling shares directly to investors, a route that would distance it from the investment bank scandals of the dot-com era. The second question on everyone's minds is whether Google will become the next Netscape, another highflying Silicon Valley Internet company whose business was undermined when Microsoft added a browser to its operating system.

title: Eisner's 19 Years At Walt Disney
description: 1984 -- Michael D. Eisner, 42, becomes chairman and chief executive of the Walt Disney Company. He enters with a wellspring of support; Steven Spielberg and Jim Henson were among those in Hollywood who lobbied for him to get the job, and Roy E. Disney, a board member and Walt Disney's nephew, played a crucial role in his recruitment. Mr. Eisner had recently been passed over for the top job at Paramount Pictures. He appoints Jeffrey Katzenberg to run the studio.

title: Canadian Groups Agree to Conserve Woodlands
description: An unlikely coalition of energy and forestry companies, Native Canadian tribes and environmental groups have come to a sweeping agreement to conserve at least 50 percent of Canada's vast sub-Arctic, or boreal, forests, one of the largest unspoiled woodlands in the world.

title: PRO FOOTBALL

title: Shifts in States May Give Bush Electoral Edge
description: Beyond issues like Iraq and the economy is one political reality that both the White House and Democrats say is already shaping next year's presidential race: If President Bush carries the same states in 2004 that he won in 2000, he will win seven more electoral votes.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: Russians To Join Peacekeepers
description: President Vladimir V. Putin ordered a contingent of about 40 Russian communications officers and military observers to join the United Nations peacekeepers in Liberia, who now number 4,500. Earlier this year Russia withdrew peacekeeping troops from the Balkans, citing the strains of extended deployments, but it has sent 100 troops and transport helicopters to the peacekeeping mission in Sierra Leone. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Dean Defends Sealing His Papers as Governor
description: Howard Dean yesterday defended a decision he made when he left office as governor of Vermont to keep nearly half of his official papers secret for a decade, saying that doing so was routine.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDONESIA: MILITANT'S CONVICTION REVERSED An appeals court has overturned the treason conviction of Abu Bakar Bashir and reduced his prison sentence to three years, from four, a critical victory for the prominent Islamic militant. Mr. Bashir was arrested shortly after the bombings in Bali in 2002, which killed 202 people. A court convicted him of treason in September but he was cleared of the main charge of leading Jemaah Islamiyah, a Qaeda-linked terror group.

title: President in a Political Vise Over Steel Tariff Decision
description: With the White House signaling that President Bush would abide by a ruling of the World Trade Organization and lift the tariffs he placed last year on foreign steel, American steel makers angrily declared on Monday that he should resist doing so rather than give in to threats of retaliation from Europe.

title: MEMO PAD
description: DIRE warnings of holiday backups notwithstanding, airport passenger traffic flow actually went very smoothly over the Thanksgiving travel period, according to Travelocity, the online booking company.

title: Out of Retirement and Into the Boardroom; 'New' Chief at Boeing Has Been There Before
description: Four years ago, as the Boeing Company was struggling to remain profitable amid production problems, Philip M. Condit insisted in a side-by-side interview with Harry C. Stonecipher that the two were precisely the right team to lead the company.

title: Insurance Company Chairman Steps Down
description: The chairman of the Skandia Insurance Company of Sweden stepped down on Monday after a seven-month investigation found that the company's previous top management had broken rules, ignored board recommendations and possibly acted illegally.

title: Defense of Primaries Said to Cost $800,000
description: The opponents of a ballot measure to end political primaries reported yesterday that they had spent about $800,000 in their hugely successful effort to defeat the referendum last month. Just last week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced that he had spent $7.5 million of his personal fortune to urge voters to approve the measure.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: TACKLING A PAYROLL GLITCH A payroll-system glitch that left hundreds of state employees with incorrect paychecks should be fixed in two weeks, the state comptroller, Nancy Wyman, said yesterday. That is when workers are scheduled to get their next checks. About 700 of the 70,000 checks issued biweekly by the state were incorrect. Some had payments of $0, while others were for more than the worker should have received. The mixup is being attributed to problems with a new software system. The comptroller's office began using a new financial system called CORE-CT for payroll two weeks ago. (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Student Arrested In Gun Possession
description: A 12-year-old student was arrested yesterday after he brandished a .38-caliber semiautomatic pistol in the schoolyard of Middle School 180 on Beach 104th Street in the Rockaways, the police said. The boy, a seventh grader whose identity was not disclosed, was charged with criminal possession of a weapon. Investigators said that other students told the school's principal that the boy was threatening classmates with a gun, and that when officers arrived on the scene about 2 p.m., the boy tossed the gun on the ground and walked away. Detectives questioned the boy and his parents, and other charges were pending last night, the police said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Barber B. Conable, 81, Dies; Congressman and Bank Chief
description: Barber B. Conable Jr., an influential Republican congressman from western New York who as president of the World Bank steered it through a turbulent period of defaults and restructuring, died on Sunday at his winter home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 81 and lived in Alexander, in Genesee County.

title: Corrections

title: Corrections

title: ICAD TO BUY PARENT OF CADX FOR $30.6 MILLION
description: Icad Inc., a maker of computer-assisted medical tests, said that it would buy CADx Systems Inc. and its parent, Qualia Computing Inc., for about $30.6 million to expand its business. Icad, which is based in Nashua, N.H., said it would issue 4.3 million shares of its common stock, representing 16 percent of the outstanding shares after the merger. The company will also pay $1.55 million in cash and issue a $4.5 million promissory note to buy Qualia shares held by two institutional investors. The companies have collectively installed more than 300 systems that detect breast cancer in early stages, Icad said. CADx is based in Beavercreek, Ohio.

title: A Fine, Unofficial Mideast Peace Deal
description: To nitpick at the alternative blueprint for Middle East peace presented yesterday in Geneva is to miss the importance of the exercise. Sure, there are elements that require more work, more elaboration, more debate. What is truly momentous is that Israelis and Palestinians of good will have done what their current leaders have shown themselves incapable of doing, and what the United States has long urged the two sides to do: declaring in concrete terms how their conflict can end. This courageous feat by Yossi Beilin and Yasir Abed Rabbo should be welcomed, and built on.

title: AT&T President Resigns
description: Betsy J. Bernard, who was named president of AT&T a little over a year ago, resigned today, saying she wants the chance to run her own company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ORZACK, LOUIS
description: ORZACK--Louis, of Newton formerly of New York, passed away November 27, 2003. He was the beloved husband of Maressa (Hecht). Dear son of the late Morris and Jennie Orzack. Devoted father of Deborah of Worcester, Steven Orzack and Ariane Cherbuliez of Cambridge, Elizabeth and Joshua Friedman of Connecticut. Loving brother of the late Everett, Alvyn, and Beatrice. Cherished grandfather of Margot and Jacob Friedman and, Nora Cherbuliez-Orzack. A proud graduate of Townsend Harris High School, City College, Columbia University, and Indiana University. He was a professor of sociology at Rutgers University. Memorial service will be held at a time and date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Townsend Harris High School Alumni Association, 149-11 Melbourne Ave., Flushing, New York 11367.

title: Hack The Vote
description: Inviting Bush supporters to a fund-raiser, the host wrote, ''I am committed to helping Ohio deliver its electoral votes to the president next year.'' No surprise there. But Walden O'Dell -- who says that he wasn't talking about his business operations -- happens to be the chief executive of Diebold Inc., whose touch-screen voting machines are in increasingly widespread use across the United States.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Winemaker Sold
description: An Irish beverage and snack food conglomerate, Cantrell & Cochrane, will sell Barbero 1891, its Italian wine and spirits manufacturer, to Campari of Milan, for 220 million euros ($264 million). The deal includes Barbero's 70 million euro ($84 million) cash reserves, its Mondoro brand of wine and an aperitif known as Aperol, but not the popular Frangelico brand of liqueur. Campari also owns Campari and Skyy Blue vodka; it has become the world's sixth-largest spirits company through recent acquisitions. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Britain Discusses Talks
description: The secretary of state for Northern Ireland, Paul Murphy, discussed the next stage in the province's stalled political process with the Democratic Unionists, a hard-line Protestant group that became the largest party in the provincial Assembly in elections last week. The Unionists' refusal to work with Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, makes it unlikely that the Assembly will begin functioning again for at least a year, leaving Northern Ireland governed directly from London. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Nonperforming Loans Sold

A student who was training to become a Christian cleric has charged that his First Amendment rights were violated. His claim should be rejected.

title: Correction: Chagas Disease
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 18 about the rare blood infection known as Chagas disease included an imprecise summary of the views of Dr. Hira Nakhasi, director of transfusion-transmitted diseases at the Food and Drug Administration, about the lack of a screening test for the disease. While Dr. Nakhasi said the absence of ''public and media'' pressure might have contributed to the inaction, he did not say he agreed that the agency and blood industry had not been very aggressive in pursuing a test.

description: Now that her husband is back from Baghdad, Laura Bush is thinking of taking her own trip -- to Kabul.

title: Small, Bespectacled and Polite, But a Wiseguy Just the Same

Played by David Paymer, Jonah Malloy is small, bald, bespectacled and looks like an accountant or a lawyer. He nevertheless controls, with polite ruthlessness, the biggest crime syndicate in Richmond, Va.

title: Clark Kerr, Leading Public Educator and Former Head of California's Universities, Dies at 92
description: Clark Kerr, who created the blueprint for public higher education in the United States while president of the University of California system in the 1950's and 60's, died yesterday afternoon in El Cerrito, Calif. He was 92.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Powerwave To Acquire LGP Allgon
description: The wireless equipment maker Powerwave Technologies said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire LGP Allgon Holding of Sweden in a $407 million deal to create a company that can offer customers a broader range of wireless infrastructure gear. The transaction is expected to add to Powerwave's earnings per share in the first full quarter after its completion and to result in savings of at least $15 million a year, according to a news release. The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2004. Shares of Powerwave, which makes power amplifiers used in wireless communications networks, fell 17 cents, or 2.3 percent, to $7.28. Trading in shares of LGP Allgon, which makes products to improve radio coverage, capacity and data speed in mobile communications networks and employs 1,400 people, was suspended on the Stockholm stock exchange.

title: Israelis Kill 3 Hamas Militants And a Young Boy in Ramallah

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Say Abandoned Baby Was Killed
description: The police said yesterday that a baby found dead in a shopping bag on the steps of a church on Sunday had been killed. The medical examiner's office said that the baby girl, who was found at Resurrection Roman Catholic Church in Gerritsen Beach, was a newborn, not a fetus. Under a 2000 law intended to prevent the death of abandoned infants, newborns can be left in a place where they are ''safe from physical injury'' with no questions asked of parents. The Brooklyn district attorney's office has specified hospitals and firehouses as ''safe havens,'' and when the baby was thought to be abandoned, the fact that she was left at a church on Sunday morning, when parishioners could be expected, was a factor in favor of the person who left her. That has changed with the police ruling of homicide. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

description: An article in The Arts yesterday about Geoff Muldaur and his new album celebrating the music of Bix Beiderbecke misidentified the instrument played by Frankie Trumbauer, a colleague of Beiderbecke. It was the saxophone, not the clarinet.

title: Reviewing Foreigners' Use of Federal Courts
description: Urged by the Bush administration to curb the growing recourse to United States courts as forums for international human rights cases, the Supreme Court agreed on Monday to review the use of a once-obscure 18th-century law as the jurisdictional basis for such lawsuits.

title: Sports of The Times; Jets Provide Respite from New York's Disarray in Duplicate
description: IT could be worse, and it has been. But as an entry, New York's two pro football teams, even with the Jets' 24-17 upset of the Tennessee Titans last night, have been more of a double disappointment to their frustrated followers this season than ever before.

description: ALMOST every morning, Ruth Lacey takes a brisk walk from her apartment on West 107th Street to 79th Street. She stops just a few blocks shy of Beacon High School, the public school she helped to found 10 years ago at a turning point in her life as a teacher and a mother.

description: BAGHDAD, Dec. 2  They stand as monuments to megalomania, four massive heads of Saddam Hussein, each three stories high, sitting atop the Republican Palace, which serves as home for L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator of Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Qantas Chooses Airbus
description: Australia's leading airline, Qantas, said it would buy 23 planes from Airbus for its low-cost domestic carrier, Jetstar, which will begin service in May. Qantas has 70 percent of the Australian market but faces competition from Virgin Blue, a budget carrier controlled by the Virgin Group, which has gained 30 percent of Australian traffic in the last three years. Qantas's chief executive, Geoff Dixon, said the new aircraft would cost $1.15 billion. John Shaw (NYT)

title: A CONVERSATION WITH: Steffie Woolhandler; Heal Health Care System? Start Anew
description: Dr. Steffie Woolhandler, 52, an associate professor at Harvard Medical School and an internist at Cambridge Hospital, wants to change the health care system. Soon, and not in the way Congress just did.

title: That Ounce Of Prevention Grew Too Big
description: Is being a doctor becoming too hard? I used to think so when I was an intern, when being a doctor was too hard. Back then I remember wandering the hospital wards, wondering how I was going to get through another night on call, until I realized that my patients were helping me.

title: Front Row
description: Los Angeles Discovers a New Talent

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Arrested In Officer's Stabbing
description: Two teenagers were arrested yesterday in the stabbing of an off-duty police officer during a robbery in Prospect Heights, the police said. The officer, whose name was not released, was approached from behind early yesterday morning on Prospect Place near Vanderbilt Avenue by two people, one of whom threatened him with a knife while the other went through his pockets, the police said. When the officer resisted, he was stabbed, and the suspects fled. The police arrested Michael Gregory, 16, and a 15-year-old, on charges of attempted murder, robbery and criminal possession of a weapon. The officer was reported in stable condition at New York Methodist Hospital. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Medical Students Go Beyond Books to Learn About Activism
description: She already knows how to read an EKG. And she was taught to measure blood pressure three years ago. But in her fourth year of medical school, Hilda Fernandez is learning how to quantify hope.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Irish Newspapers Sold
description: The largest newspaper publisher in Britain, Trinity Mirror, sold its seven Irish titles to 3i, a venture capital group based in London, for 46.3 million ($79.6 million), to focus on domestic businesses like its flagship Daily Mirror. The Irish titles include the Belfast Newsletter, which first published in 1737 and is one of the world's longest-running English- language newspapers, as well as smaller regional papers like the Donegal Democrat. The venture capital group will also repay 600,000 ($1 million) of Trinity Mirror's debt. Robin Marsha, a 3i director, said that the Irish newspaper industry would probably undergo a round of consolidation soon. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLAPP, EDWIN J.
description: CLAPP--Edwin J. Peacefully, on November 29, 2003, in Washington, DC. Yale ('36), Yale Law School ('40). Honorary Wiffenpoof; Tenor, LPRVBS. Foreign service officer; counsel to AID Missions in Taiwan, Korea, and Thailand. After retiring, for 20 years a Volunteer Attorney with Legal Counsel to the Elderly. ABA 1998 Pro Bono Lawyer of the Year. Married 60 years to the late Jeanne Thayer Clapp. Survivors include three sons, Peter, John, and Nelson, and three granddaughters, Becky, Mary, and Libby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AARONS, MORRIS
description: AARONS--Morris, a New York City attorney who was elevated to the judiciary in 1969 died on December 1, 2003 at age 96. Judge Aarons graduated from Fordham University School of Pharmacy in 1927 and received a law degree from Saint John's University in 1931. He became trial counsel for Prudential Life Insurance. In 1960 was named general counsel to the National association of Pharmaceutical Manufacturers. He labored successfully to influence Congress and state legislatures to license generic drugs for public use. A lifelong Republican active in politics, Judge Aarons ran for the United States Congress in 1960. Judge Aarons served respectively as a judge in civil court, criminal term of the Supreme Court, Surrogate's Court of New York County and the Court of Claims. Subsequently he served as a judicial hearing officer until he was 92 years of age. He continued to practice law during that period as well. He is survived by his wife, Miriam, of Scarsdale, New York, their children, Marjorie, Paul, Stanley, Gail and Joseph, seven grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York on Wednesday, December 3, 2003 at 12:00 P.M. Visitation will take place on Tuesday, December 2, 2003 from 7-9 PM.

title: Child Sex Abuse Foe Says L.I. Bishop Should Resign
description: A national advocate against child sex abuse is calling for the Roman Catholic bishop of Long Island to resign, charging that he wants to cover up scandals and help molesters rather than protect children.

title: Suit Challenges Bear Hunt in Federal Park
description: A coalition of animal-welfare groups and individuals filed a lawsuit yesterday in federal court in Washington seeking to exclude a national park along the Delaware River from New Jersey's six-day bear hunt next week.

title: Cincinnati Officials Try to Forestall Tension After Beating
description: Cincinnati police and city officials today continued to investigate an incident this weekend in which a man died after being clubbed repeatedly by officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, HORTENSE M.
description: SCHWARTZ--Hortense M. On November 28, 2003, at age 96. Graveside service Tuesday, 1 pm, at Mount Carmel Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

description: Stocks Hit Recent Highs On Surge in Manufacturing

title: U.S. Forces Search for Hussein Ally
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 2  American forces mounted a series of raids today intended to kill or capture a top member of Saddam Hussein's government, but denied reports afterward that they had succeeded.

title: Same Book, New Look
description: A study recently released by Senator Charles E. Schumer found that the average New York college freshman spends more than $900 a year on textbooks. Considering that most full-time students take about eight courses per year, that averages to more than $100 per course for books. Publishers say that college textbook prices are so high because they have to cover production costs. That's true, but it doesn't have to be. Good textbooks can be produced and published for a reasonable price.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in The Arts yesterday about movies' box-office earnings over the weekend included an erroneous estimate from Universal Pictures for ''Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat.'' Its figure was $25.6 million (not $24.7 million), making it the No. 1 movie of the weekend, not No. 2 behind ''The Haunted Mansion.'' A brief article about the weekend's box-office earnings appears today, on Page C8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOOD, CAROLYN
description: WOOD -- Carolyn, former Assistant Dean of Columbia University Law School, patron of the Metropolitan Opera, member of the Friends of Mostly Mozart, Lincoln Center, and Metropolitan Museum of Art, died November 27, 2003 in Lewiston, ME. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Morningside Retirement and Health Service, 100 LaSalle St, NY, NY 10027 or to Bates College, c/o the Frank S. and Gladys P. Hoy Scholarship Fund, 2 Andrews Road, Lewiston, ME 04240-6028. Celebration of her life will be held Sunday, December 7th, 3 PM, at the Baptist Church of Greene, 102 Main Street, Greene, ME. A gathering will follow in the church's Fellowship Hall. Burial will be private. For further information contact Dillingham & Son Memorial Chapel, 62 Spring Street, Auburn, ME, 207784-6449.

title: Actors in All-Latino Cast Savor a 'Historic Moment'
description: When Victor Argo began his acting career in the 1950's, he found that to get work he had to drop Jimnez, his real surname. Priscilla Lopez stuck to her name a decade later and found it easier to land jobs, achieving early success as Diana Morales in ''A Chorus Line.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 18 about a rare blood infection, Chagas disease, included an imprecise summary of the views of an official with the Food and Drug Administration about the lack of a screening test. The article and a chart referred incorrectly to Red Cross estimates of the chance of contracting the disease from a blood transfusion. The chart also misstated estimates for the rates of blood donations in Los Angeles with antibodies to the disease. A detailed correction appears today on Page F2.

title: Cubans on Trial in Case That Led to Crackdown by Castro
description: Federal prosecutors outlined a meticulous yearlong plot by six Cubans accused as hijackers as their trial started here on Monday. The case involves the first of several such incidents that heightened tensions between the White House and Cubans in both Havana and Miami.

title: A Gentler Type of Colonoscopy Is Found Effective
description: A new study finds that virtual colonoscopy, a method that uses a C.T. scanner for colon cancer screening, can be just as effective as traditional colonoscopy in finding polyps, the mushroomlike growths from which most cancers arise.

title: Dissenting From Disaster in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Year's Last Major Bridge Title Is Won in Tourney's Final Deals
description: Five Americans won the final major bridge title of the year at the end of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here on Sunday night.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend on Friday about Simon Gray's ''Butley'' at the Huntington Theater Company in Boston misstated the closing date. It was Sunday; it is not next Sunday.

title: S.E.C. Has a Black Football Coach
description: Sylvester Croom became the first African-American head football coach in the 71-year history of the Southeastern Conference yesterday, accepting the position at Mississippi State.

description: OfficeMax, the office products retailer, said yesterday that sales this quarter would exceed its expectations after a one-day record of more than $40 million on Friday.

title: Trading Favors
description: Presidents subordinate economic and trade policy to electoral pandering at their own peril. That should now be abundantly clear to George Bush as he tries to decide what to do -- and when to announce it -- in response to a World Trade Organization ruling that his 2002 steel tariffs are illegal.

title: FIRST COMMUNITY TO BUY HARBOR NATIONAL BANK
description: First Community Bancorp, the holding company for Pacific Western National Bank and First National Bank, agreed to buy Harbor National Bank for $35.5 million to add customers in Orange County, Calif. First Community, based in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., said it would pay about $13.28 a share for Harbor National after all outstanding stock options were cashed out. That is 8.4 percent less than Harbor National's closing price of $14.50 on Wednesday, when the shares last traded. Harbor National is based in Newport Beach, Calif.. First Community had 32 branches and $2.4 billion in assets as of Sept. 30.

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: OREGON: SENTENCE IN TALIBAN CASE The lone woman among a group of American Muslims who tried to ally themselves with the Taliban was sentenced in Portland to three years in prison. The woman, October Martinique Lewis, 26, was convicted of wiring money to her former husband and a group of men who were trying to get to Afghanistan in 2001 to help the Taliban fight American soldiers. The group made it only as far as China. Last week, Ms. Lewis's former husband, Jeffrey L. Battle, and another man, Patrice Lumumba Ford, were sentenced to 18 years in prison for conspiracy to levy war against the United States.

description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Urges Syria to Discourage Attacks
description: Israel's president, Moshe Katsav, said Monday that Syria must stop supporting armed factions that attack Israel if it is serious about restarting negotiations with Israel over the Golan Heights.

title: Split Verdicts in Texas Trial Of Professor and the Plague
description: A Texas Tech University professor was found guilty yesterday of 47 of the 69 charges that federal prosecutors filed against him after a bioterrorism scare in January when he reported 30 vials of plague bacteria missing from his laboratory.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Chief Justice Quits
description: W. H. Arnold will resign as chief justice of the State Supreme Court, effective Jan. 1. Chief Justice Arnold, 68, a Democrat who was elected in 1996, said he needed a career change. But he also indicated that he might eventually seek another elective office. Gov. Mike Huckabee, a Republican, will name a replacement to fill in until the general election in November, when voters will choose a successor to serve the three years left in the chief justice's term. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: The Two Terrorisms
description: One salutary effect of the rise of Al Qaeda is that it has given terrorism an even worse name than it had before the Sept. 11 attacks. For the ''new'' terrorists of Al Qaeda and its affiliates, apocalyptic terrorism is an indispensable means to a total, violent victory for radical Islam over the West.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Ex-Police Commissioner Arrested
description: Bombay's former police commissioner, Ranjit Singh Sharma, was arrested in a widening corruption inquiry. Mr. Sharma is accused of hampering, or failing to pursue, an investigation of Abdul Karim Telgi, a forger who accumulated millions of dollars by selling fake revenue paper, which is used to collect fees for legal documents. Mr. Sharma, whose official retirement was scheduled for Sunday, quit last month when news of the scheme broke. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Bitter Parting Words From a Disney
description: Roy Disney's parting words to the company his uncle built were harsh, but few resonated more painfully than the charge that the Walt Disney Company has ''lost its focus, its creative energy and its heritage.''

title: Just How Low Can You Go? A Cholesterol Challenge
description: New research and studies that are under way are leading many heart disease experts to say they expect that the current guidelines for lowering cholesterol may not be stringent enough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAIDMAN, ANNE
description: MAIDMAN--Anne. Died at home December 1 at age 86. Devoted wife, mother, and grandmother, we will miss your compassion, your sharp mind, your steadying presence, and your strong spirit. Service on Wednesday at 11:30AM, Collins Funeral Home, 92 East Avenue, Norwalk, CT.

title: Bobbing Aloof From the Apple
description: New York's landlubbers find it more ludicrous than insulting that Tom DeLay, the majority leader of the House of Representatives, may offer to house hundreds of solons, fat-cat donors and lobbyists in a luxury cruise ship off the Manhattan shore during next summer's Republican National Convention. If he prevails over growing G.O.P. embarrassment at such a floating symbol of gated plutocracy, we urge Mr. DeLay to forgo any ''Master and Commander'' regalia he may have in mind. Instead, the flinty Texan should borrow Nathan Detroit's double-breasted pinstripes to come ashore from the newest established permanent floating avoidance game in New York.

title: Pardon Me, Sir, but Your Auricular Instrument Is Flat
description: Every concert hall and opera house has found a way to remind audience members to please turn off all cellphones, pagers and beepers before a performance. At Avery Fisher Hall a message is projected on the back wall of the stage. At the Metropolitan Opera it is posted on each seat's Met Titles screen, the first thing to greet people as they settle into their seats. Broadway theaters use amusing recorded announcements that list an assortment of mood disturbers, including crackling candy wrappers and crinkling plastic shopping bags.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Land Prices Fall
description: Land prices in Japan's six largest cities fell 4.2 percent from April to September compared with the preceding half year, continuing a 12-year slide in property prices, according to the Japan Real Estate Institute. Prices for commercial land slid 3.7 percent, while residential land prices fell 3.4 percent. Industrial property prices declined 5.6 percent. Property prices over all are now at 22-year lows. There was at least one exception. The average land price in Tokyo's most expensive districts rose 0.3 percent, the first growth in 13 years. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEEDS, DR. LEONARD W.
description: LEEDS--Dr. Leonard W., 90, of Monroe Township, N.J., on November 30, 2003. He was predeceased by his wife of 58 years, Sylvia (Tenenbaum). Father of Ronald and his wife Judith, Richard and his wife Linda and Andrea Eisenberg and her husband Michael. Brother of Morton and Joseph Leeds. Grandfather of six. Funeral Tuesday, 9:45AM, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, Cranbury Rd at Evergreen Blvd, East Brunswick, NJ. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge.

title: For a Good Time, Well, Don't Call Dad
description: Sir Walter Scott was an author, not an evolutionary theorist. He wrote his poems and historical novels 40 years before Charles Darwin described the process of evolution -- and well over a century before scientists began in earnest to apply principles of natural selection to the study of human nature.

title: INSIDE
description: Electoral Map Tilts to G.O.P.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Site Of Anthrax Deaths Reopening
description: More than two years after two workers at the Brentwood postal center in Washington were killed by anthrax and two others were sickened, some employees will return to the building this week, officials said. A spokeswoman for the Postal Service, Deborah Yackley, said about 100 employees would report to work there by Friday, with others coming back over the next few months. Postal workers and neighbors of the mail sorting center had expressed skepticism that the building, where about 2,000 people worked, could be made safe. John Files (NYT)

title: With a Rich Girl Here And a Rich Girl There
description: ''The Simple Life,'' the new Fox reality show that follows two pampered celebutantes -- Paris Hilton and Nicole Richie -- as they trade Beverly Hills for an Arkansas barnyard, is not so simple.

title: Expos May Play in Monterrey
description: Officials from Major League Baseball have told promoters who tried to take the Montreal Expos to Monterrey, Mexico, for 22 regular-season games in 2004 that the team will return to San Juan, P.R., for part of the season instead.

title: Antidotes for Poisons Are Just a Phone Call Away
description: In recent years, ''tried and true'' remedies for children have fallen like autumn leaves when medical scientists discovered that the treatment was either worthless or worse than the disease. Hence the passing of Merthiolate and Mercurochrome for cuts and abrasions, aspirin for fever, boric acid for diaper rash and now syrup of ipecac for ingested poisons.

title: Corrections
description: A thumbnail biography on Sunday with a profile of Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who is seeking the presidential nomination, misspelled the name of the military hospital in Denver where he was born. It is Fitzsimons, not Fitzsimmons.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Judge Clears Health Insurance Law
description: A state judge has ruled that a new law requiring employers to provide contraception to women as part of health insurance coverage does not violate the free-exercise-of-religion clauses in the state and federal Constitutions. Church groups had challenged the law, saying it forced them to violate their beliefs by providing birth control to employees at hospitals and other institutions with religious affiliations. Dennis Poust, a spokesman for the New York State Catholic Conference, said the plaintiffs would appeal. Justice Dan Lamont of State Supreme Court ruled on Friday that state precedent going back to 1911 held that compelling government interests can permit some infringement on religious practice. The state's interest in providing necessary health care to women, Justice Lamont ruled, outweighed whatever First Amendment burden affected the religious charities. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: A Few Words From Mara Go a Long Way
description: The look in Giants receiver Amani Toomer's eyes said it all when the subject turned to Wellington Mara, the team's co-owner.
