title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: State Tries New Slogan
description: Officials announced that they were changing the state slogan from ''Things Look Different Here'' to ''Oregon. We Love Dreamers.'' Officials said the new slogan reflected the sense of opportunity and idealism in Oregon and was part of an aggressive campaign to make the state, which has struggled with a severe budget crisis in the past several years, more attractive to tourists. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHALFIN, ADELE
description: CHALFIN--Adele. On November 30, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Victor. Devoted mother of Ronni Fink and Marjorie Feinstein. Cherished grandmother of Scott, Alexander, Samantha and Jeffrey. Loving sister of Murray, Selma and Morty. Funeral services today, 12 noon, at Gutterman's Inc, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sony Selling Eurobonds
description: The Sony Corporation will raise up to 250 billion yen ($2.3 billion) by selling zero-coupon Euroyen convertible bonds to help pay for the development of semiconductors and other devices. The bonds, which will come due in 2008, will be issued on Dec. 18. The bonds will have a face value of 5 million yen and will pay no interest, but can be converted to stock if Sony's shares meet certain benchmarks. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Heart Disease: The Focus Narrows
description: As parents and doctors struggle with an epidemic of childhood obesity in America, Anne Youngquist worries about a subtler menace that may not threaten her three children for decades: heart disease.

title: ARCHIPELAGO PLANS INITIAL OFFERING NEXT YEAR
description: Archipelago Holdings, the parent of the all-electronic Archipelago Exchange, said it planned to sell shares to the public for the first time next year. The company, which is based in Chicago, expects to file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the next several months, a spokeswoman, Margaret Nagle, said. Archipelago began in 1997 after the Securities and Exchange Commission approved it as one of the first four electronic communications networks, or all-electronic trade-matching and order-routing systems. Goldman Sachs has the biggest stake among 14 Wall Street firms that invested in Archipelago.

title: Israel Raps U.S. on Plans to Meet Geneva Authors
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 2  In a rare Israeli criticism of the United States, a senior official said today it would be a mistake for Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to meet Israeli and Palestinian politicians who negotiated a symbolic Mideast peace plan.

description: After several years of reduced support because of government corruption, the World Bank has decided to increase its loans to Indonesia, even though the bank says corruption is still rampant.

title: Walter J. Fried, 99, Lawyer Involved in Co-op Conversions
description: Walter J. Fried, a real estate lawyer who handled the conversion of prime Manhattan apartment buildings like the Beresford and the Ritz Tower into cooperatives, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 99 and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You can be a social conservative in the U.S. without being a wacko. Not in Canada.''

title: After a Hard-Won Success in New York, Time Out Is Heading West to Chicago
description: When Time Out New York made its debut in 1995, few in the media business thought a paid weekly calendar of oh-so-current events could make its way in a city awash with publications offering entertainment listings, many of them free. Eight years later, ones much tougher and more expensive than anticipated, the New York version of Time Out London has carved out a profitable niche. So to celebrate, the Time Out Group has decided to fight the odds once again, this time in Chicago.

title: Zapping Germs From Office Air
description: Millions of cases of illness among office workers each year could be prevented by installing germ-killing lights in ventilation systems, researchers say.

title: Set of Wheels, Driven Around, Comes Around
description: It was with a certain sense of the expected that Thomas Jacobellis, a retired police officer from the Bronx, learned that his 1968 Mercury Cougar -- stolen from his driveway on a warm spring day 20 years ago -- had been found.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Assembly Elections In 4 States
description: Voters in Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Chattisgarh and Delhi went to the polls to elect assemblies. The average turnout among the 93 million eligible voters was more than 55 percent, according to the Election Commission. Results are expected Thursday. The Congress Party currently controls the four assemblies, and the Bharatiya Janata Party, which leads the national coalition government, is hoping to make gains in advance of parliamentary elections next year. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Starwood Hotels Hires Financial Chief
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, owner of the Sheraton and Westin chains, hired Vasant Prabhu away from the grocer Safeway to fill the job of chief financial officer being vacated in a management reorganization.

title: Wear a Holiday Shrug And an Open Mind
description: The little black dress is pass, the cocktail suit is a bore, and don't even think about getting cute with a reindeer sweater. Holiday dressing, like just about everything else in fashion, demands more finesse than excess, more polish than glitter. And a little bit of mistletoe provocation doesn't hurt either.

title: A Memorial to Evoke the Horror of That Day
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Drug Rights Acquired
description: The British biotechnology company Celltech Group said that it would retain the full rights to an antibody treatment, CDP 870, after refusing to renegotiate terms of a 2001 agreement with Pfizer. The drug, used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, is also being used in clinical trials to treat Crohn's disease and could be effective against psoriasis. Pfizer inherited the rights to the treatment when it purchased Pharmacia this year, and was hoping to capture a larger share of the profits. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EDERLE, GERTRUDE
description: EDERLE--Gertrude. The Officers and Trustees of the New York Sports Museum & Hall of Fame regret the passing of a member of the New York Sports Hall of Fame on November 30, in Wyckoff, NJ. Bill Shannon, President Jordan Sprechman, Secretary

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Asbestos Workers Reach Agreement
description: The union representing 2,500 workers who remove asbestos, lead and hazardous waste in New York City and on Long Island announced a new contract yesterday that raises compensation by 22 percent over four years. Under the accord signed by more than 80 contractors, the workers will get increases in wages and benefits totaling $6.75 an hour on top of the $30.27 they were earning in the contract that expired yesterday, union officials said. The union, Local 78 of the Laborers International Union of North America, had threatened to strike unless an accord was reached yesterday. Workers will receive a $2.25 increase per hour in wages and benefits in the first year and a $1.50 increase in each of the next three years. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Some Agree to Quit HealthSouth's Board
description: The board of HealthSouth, the embattled chain of hospitals and clinics, agreed under pressure last night to the removal of a number of board members who served when company executives were committing extensive securities fraud, according to people briefed on the board decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENBERG, HERBERT JE ROME
description: EISENBERG -- Herbert Je rome. Born June 3, 1928, left us reluctantly on December 1, 2003. Beloved and cherished husband of 52 years to Beverly Bruh Eisenberg. Devoted and adored father to Elyse and Richard Coleman, Shari and Steven Sitkoff, Lori and Jay Eisenberg and Risa and David Milbauer. His grandchildren, the lights of his life, worshipped, loved, and greatest Grandfather to Matthew and Amy Coleman, Caroline and Ilana Sitkoff, Beth, Scott and Jake Eisenberg and Samantha and Michael Milbauer. Devoted son of the late Mary and Samuel Eisenberg and the brother of the late Ruth Cohen. Graduate of the Georgia Institute of Technology, class of 1949. Proud member of Alpha Epsilon Pi Fraternity, Zeta Chapter. We will miss you forever, miss that beautiful smile, the great jokes, your guidance and cherished words of wisdom and the great stories. We'll always remember ''back home on the farm''. Rest well and we know that your shining smile will always be upon us. Funeral services on Wednesday, December 3, 2003 at 12 Noon at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, NY. No flowers please. Donations can be made to M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Development Office, Eisenberg Endowed Fellowship, 1515 Holcombe Blvd-Unit 541, Houston, TX. 77030. The Eisenberg, Coleman, Sitkoff & Milbauer Families

title: Colorado Court Rejects Redistricting Plan
description: The Colorado Supreme Court on Monday rejected a Republican effort to redraw the state's Congressional map to the party's advantage, handing Democrats a victory in the first of a series of legal fights that could help determine control of the House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DESANTO, ANNE MCALLISTER
description: DeSANTO--Anne McAllister. On November 30, 2003 at age 99. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Ernest Paul DeSanto. title: MANUFACTURING AT HIGHEST LEVEL IN TWO DECADES
description: American manufacturing activity rose to its highest level in nearly 20 years last month as factories raced to keep up with demand and indicated a readiness to expand their work forces for the first time in three years, according to a survey published on Monday.

title: A Big Professional Headache
description: Neurologists suffer many more migraines than the general population, researchers have found, and for those neurologists who specialize in treating headaches, the incidence is even higher.

title: Christianity and Islam Battle Fervently for African Souls
description: Add Africa to the list of dangerous arenas where Christianity and Islam are clashing. Anyone charting global hot spots may know as much, but viewers of ''Battle for Souls,'' on the Discovery Times Channel tonight, can get a lesson in compounded pain. The continent is already gasping through pandemics of poverty and AIDS, so bloodshed among true believers seems to inflict new lacerations on broken limbs.

title: Putin Aide Rules Out Russian Approval of Kyoto Protocol
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 2 — A senior Kremlin official declared today that Russia would not ratify the international treaty requiring cuts in the emissions of gases linked to global warming, delivering what could be a fatal blow to years of diplomatic efforts.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: JUDGE CLEARS HEALTH INSURANCE LAW A state judge has ruled that a new law requiring employers to provide contraception to women as part of health insurance coverage does not violate the free-exercise-of-religion clauses in the state and federal Constitutions. Church groups had challenged the law, saying it forced them to violate their beliefs by providing birth control to employees at hospitals and other institutions with religious affiliations. Dennis Poust, a spokesman for the New York State Catholic Conference, said the plaintiffs would appeal. Justice Dan Lamont of State Supreme Court ruled on Friday that state precedent going back to 1911 held that compelling government interests can permit some infringement on religious practice. The state's interest in providing necessary health care to women, Justice Lamont ruled, outweighed whatever First Amendment burden affected the religious charities.   James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Move To Speed Ouster Of Whites
description: The government proposed to accelerate seizures of white-owned commercial farms by abolishing the legal requirement that owners be personally notified of an impending confiscation, the state-run Herald newspaper reported. The proposed change would require only that farms be listed in newspapers before seizures began. About 5,000 white farmers once owned four-fifths of the commercial farmland in Zimbabwe; experts say about 600 working farms remain in white hands. The farmers are not compensated for their losses, which the government says redresses decades of racial injustice. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Funds Still Flow To Al Qaeda, Panel Says
description: A lack of international cooperation and political resolve in many countries undermines attempts to stem the flow of money and weapons to Al Qaeda and allows the group's influence to spread, a special committee of the Security Council said. Iraq in particular has become ''a fertile ground'' for Al Qaeda and ''is readily accessible to Al Qaeda followers anxious to take up the battle against the coalition forces and other 'Crusaders,' '' the committee said. The committee was set up by the Security Council to monitor measures against Al Qaeda, the Taliban and their associates. Only 83 of the 191 member countries have submitted fourth-quarter reports to the committee. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: Supreme Court Weighs Case on State Spending and Religion
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 2  An argument by religious conservatives in a church-state case they embraced as a vehicle for expanding their recent Supreme Court victories met resistance from a deeply divided court on Tuesday. A majority of the justices expressed concern about the implications of requiring states to subsidize religious training if they choose to provide college scholarships for other kinds of study.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Agnes Audier was named to the new post of chief performance officer at Havas, Paris. She had been director at Vivendi Universal Internet, Paris, part of Vivendi Universal.

title: Scientists Unearth Urban Center More Ancient Than Plato
description: Digging on a coastal plain at the Gulf of Corinth three years ago, archaeologists came upon some ruins of Helike, a Greek city destroyed by earthquake in Plato's time. A search for the rest of Helike has now turned up something even more ancient, rare and inviting.

title: Amnesty Criticizes U.S. Military In Deaths of 2 Afghan Prisoners
description: A leading human rights group criticized the United States military on Monday for not disclosing the status of an investigation into the deaths of two prisoners at an American base in Afghanistan last year. Initial inquiries by military investigators deemed the deaths homicides that involved ''blunt force injuries,'' according to the group.

title: U.S. Coach Hopes to Surprise
description: A draw or a victory today against Germany in the United Arab Emirates would send the United States under-20 men's national team into the second round of the world youth championships.

title: U.S. SEES LESSON FOR INSURGENTS IN AN IRAQ BATTLE
description: American commanders vowed Monday that the killing of as many as 54 insurgents in this central Iraqi town would serve as a lesson to those fighting the United States, but Iraqis disputed the death toll and said anger against America would only rise.

Adored grandmother of Joshua, Joanna, Rob, Julia and Alex. Retired English teacher at Samuel J. Tilden HS, Bklyn, NY. Loved and admired by family and friends. He enjoyed an active life including extensive traveling, music, theatre, photography and driving his Model 'A' Fords. In his practice of psychoanalysis for over 50 years, he was a compassionate and deeply concerned physician. He touched many lives and he will be deeply missed. Services Tuesday 11:30AM at Riverside-Nassau North chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, N.Y.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: United Nations: Guard Found Dead
description: A United Nations security guard was found dead yesterday morning with a gunshot wound to the head, officials said. The guard, Michael Halton, 41, was slumped in a chair in a lounge used by General Assembly delegates and United Nations staff members, his handgun beside him, the chief of security for the United Nations said at a news conference. Colleagues had been sent to find Mr. Halton when he did not return to his post from a scheduled hourlong break, said the chief, Michael McCann. Investigators from the New York Police Department did not immediately announce the cause of death, though United Nations officials said it appeared to be suicide. Mr. Halton left no note, Mr. McCann said. Kirk Semple (NYT)

title: New Findings on Breast-Feeding
description: A new study finds little evidence, despite some earlier reports, that breast-feeding reduces a child's risk of high blood pressure in adulthood.

description: JONES--Philip. 15 years without you. Beatric

description: The Islanders placed Eric Godard on injured reserve yesterday with a strained right shoulder and used their roster space to shore up their offense by calling up Jeff Hamilton, who leads the American Hockey League in goals with 17. The Islanders also called up Mattias Weinhandl from their affiliate in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: No Muhammad Testimony
description: John A. Muhammad, who has been sentenced to death for his role in the sniper attacks in the Washington area last year, will not testify at the trial of Lee Malvo, the other person charged in the shootings. Mr. Malvo's lawyers, who sought the testimony, told a judge that Mr. Muhammad had invoked his right against self-incrimination. The lawyers said they would still ask Mr. Muhammad to appear in court so jurors could assess the sizes of the two men. Judge Jane Marum Roush indicated that she was skeptical about that request. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Marlins, Not Mets, For Castillo
description: When the world champion Florida Marlins traded first baseman Derrek Lee to the Chicago Cubs last week, they evoked memories of 1997, when another championship Marlins team had its roster disassembled in order to cut payroll.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Settlement In Trade Center Dispute
description: Silverstein Properties settled a long-running dispute yesterday that had threatened to hold up the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site. Under the terms of the agreement, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will spend $563 million to buy out the GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation, Silverstein's lender in the company's 2001 winning bid for control of the trade center. In a statement, Larry A. Silverstein, the president and chief executive of Silverstein Properties, said he was ''pleased that we have reached a full agreement with the Port Authority on terms for repaying GMAC.'' The authority will also buy out Westfield America, the Australia-based mall operator that held the retail leases at the trade center, for $140 million. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRALJIC, NIKICA ANN
description: KRALJIC--Nikica Ann. On November 30, 2003 in New York City. Niki passed on a beautiful Sunday afternoon surrounded by the ones who loved her most. She was 69 years old. She lived a very active life and was best known for her brilliant spirit and remarkable elegance. A tremendously intelligent, caring individual, Niki dedicated her life to her friends and family. Known for her generosity, Niki always had a small gift, card or kind gesture for the ones she loved. Niki's personality and attention to detail made her truly distinct. Her remarkable ability to focus and concentrate allowed her to achieve great things that separated her from most. She was an excellent student, earning a Bachelor's degree from Fordham University and a Master's degree from NYU. After completing her studies, Niki spent 40 years as an Economist and Assistant Vice President at New York Life Insurance company. She leaves behind her sisters Frances and Helen, nephew Michael and niece Elizabeth. To our best friend, sister and aunt Didi, no words will ever explain what you mean to us, nor characterize how good you are. You lived a model life and everyone who knew you benefited from your kindess and generosity. You are the best friend and person we have ever known. Without you, our lives are not complete. Now you are in heaven and can rest with Mima and Papa. We will remember you always and lovingly, recall all the good times and adventures we had together. This world has lost a tremendously wonderful person. Our only comfort is that the next world has gained someone truly extraordinary. You will never be forgotten. We love you so much. Family will receive friends 2-5 and 7-9 on Wednesday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral Mass Thursday at the Guardian Angel R.C. Church, 10th Ave at 21 St. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery. XOXO, The Currans, Illijics and Harts

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Bailout Promised
description: Chinese banking regu-lators have raised the percentage of a Chinese bank that can be owned by a foreign investor to 20 percent from 15 percent, as planned. They have also confirmed recent hints that they would conduct another bailout of the country's four main state-owned banks. Liu Mingkang, the chairman of the China Banking Regulatory Commission, said that one or two of the banks would be chosen for an experimental effort to reduce their number of nonperforming loans. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Powell Trip Seeks to Bolster Support
description: TUNIS, Dec. 2  Secretary of State Colin L. Powell embarked on a five-nation, four-day tour today, hoping to mend fences with Europeans upset by the American strategy in Iraq and to stiffen the resolve of North African nations rattled by terror attacks to continue to fight Islamic extremism.

description: Frank D'Alessandro moved to Fort Myers, Fla., from New Jersey in 1980 because he smelled the heady brew of a real estate boom. description: Japanese regulators formally took control of the Ashikaga Bank on Monday, the first regional bank Tokyo has nationalized. The step appeared to be an acknowledgement by the government that the longtime policy of nearly endless leniency and patience with deeply troubled financial institutions was not going to save them.

title: Yankees Sign Gordon, Meet With Sheffield
description: The slugging outfielder Gary Sheffield met with George Steinbrenner in Tampa, Fla., yesterday, bringing him one step closer to the Bronx. At the same time, Steinbrenner's busy general manager, Brian Cashman, continued his efforts to retool a bullpen that often struggled last season, completing a two-year, $7.25 million deal with Tom Gordon, who will become a right-handed setup man for Mariano Rivera.

title: Sales Rise for Jos. A. Bank
description: HAMPSTEAD, Md., Dec. 1 (Dow Jones/AP) - The men's clothing retailer Jos. A. Bank Clothiers posted a 53 percent increase in earnings for its latest quarter, helped by a 24 percent rise in sales.

description: The leaders of three secessionist regions in Georgia have been meeting with Russian officials in Moscow, raising questions here about Russia's intentions and concerns about possible instability.

title: French Diplomats Go on Strike To Protest Planned Budget Cuts
description: Thousands of French diplomats and Foreign Ministry staff members went on strike on Monday, slowing work at the country's far-flung foreign services and even shutting down some embassies and consulates in protest over proposed budget cuts.

title: Income Rises 14% At Thor for Quarter
description: Thor Industries said on Monday that its net income rose 14 percent in its latest quarter, a result of higher sales of its recreational vehicles and buses.

description: MANILA:  While AIDS prevalence in the Philippines is relatively low, AIDS experts and monitors are concerned that the situation could worsen if nothing is done about the increasing number of overseas Filipino workers who are carrying the disease back home.

description: To prove that Middle East peacemaking is possible, self-appointed Israeli and Palestinian negotiators came together on Monday to celebrate a sweeping shadow agreement that would create a Palestinian state and resolve other contentious issues that have thwarted peace negotiators over the years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 1 about Mahathir Mohammad, who stepped down as prime minister of Malaysia on Oct. 31 after 22 years, misstated his country's projected 2003 economic growth rate and its comparative ranking among Southeast Asian nations. According to the Asian Development Bank, the Malaysian rate is 4.1 percent, not 4.5; it is behind that of Thailand (6.0 percent), Vietnam (6.9 percent), Laos (5.5 percent) and Cambodia (5.0 percent), not just that of Thailand.

title: Bush Aides Say Attacks Won't Scare Allies Into Leaving Iraq
description: Bush administration officials said Monday that a recent wave of attacks on Spanish, Japanese and South Korean personnel in Iraq appeared intended to drive apart those seeking to secure the country. But the officials insisted that the campaign would not succeed in scaring anyone away from the job.

title: Spitzer Warns Lobby Panel About Its Chief
description: ALBANY, Dec. 1  Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's office is trying to get the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying to stop its executive director from airing his concerns about litigation strategy.

title: McDonald's Expands OMD's Assignment
description: The McDonald's Corporation in Oak Brook, Ill., said yesterday that it would expand its relationship with OMD Worldwide in New York by naming the agency to handle nearly all its media planning and buying assignments. The assignments, with total billings estimated at $1 billion to $1.3 billion, had been divided among OMD and five other agencies.

title: PROTEIN DESIGN SETTLES PAYMENT DISPUTE WITH GENENTECH
description: Protein Design Labs Inc. settled a dispute with Genentech Inc. over payments for an experimental cancer treatment, Avastin, the companies said. Protein Design shares rose 23 percent. Genentech will license Avastin if the product wins regulatory approval, paying lower royalties than called for in a broader agreement signed earlier, the companies said. Protein Design will receive payments based on combined sales of Avastin and three other medicines. Terms of the accord were not disclosed. Protein Design is based in Fremont, Calif., and Genentech is based in San Francisco.

Mr. Rowland said that he had made no such arrangement and had paid a fair price for all the renovations.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Recalling Flashlights That Pose Burn Risk
description: Two California companies have recalled nearly a half-million small flashlights because they overheat, posing a burn risk, federal officials said. The companies, SCI Promotion Group of Ontario and the Scripto-Tokai Corporation of Rancho Cucamonga, said the recall involved flashlights that were included as free gifts with the purchase of Aim N Flame II multipurpose lighters. The black plastic flashlights are about five inches long. The companies, which announced the recall along with the Consumer Product Safety Commission, said the flashlights should be discarded. John Files (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Airtrain Set To Run Dec. 17
description: The AirTrain, a light rail system connecting Kennedy International Airport to the city's mass transit system, will open to the public on Dec. 17, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the airport's parent, said yesterday. In September 2002, the elevated train derailed on a curve during a test run, killing its operator. An investigation said the crash was unrelated to the design and construction of the system. The eight-mile system will connect airport terminals and the airport itself to the transportation hub in downtown Jamaica. The train will operate 24 hours a day and leave every four minutes during peak travel periods. It will also run to the A train at the Howard Beach subway station and to a new terminal in downtown Jamaica. The Howard Beach and Jamaica trips will cost $5 each way. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Her Personal Ad ReadsBorn Too Late for Torquemada
description: The blonde in the black micro-mini, cocktail thin, was ANN COULTER, the conservative author. When we saw her at the American Songbook gala at Lincoln Center on Monday night, we asked her about her new book. She told us it was about "liberals." The tone she brought to that one word was one you might use after months of living in a deeply carpeted apartment with a dog that cannot be house-trained. "Top secret, they're no good," Ms. Coulter said. "That's the seminal insight of the book."

title: The Food of India, From Top to Bottom
description: INDIA is a big country, but Amma manages to cover most of it. Its menu is a whirlwind tour that extends geographically from the northwestern frontier to Goa, and stylistically from refined Mogul cooking to lunchbox fare and street snacks. Suvir Saran, one of Amma's owners as well as one of its two chefs, is the travel agent for this culinary adventure, and he has a not-so-secret educational agenda. For years he has taught a popular course on Indian cooking at New York University. Amma is his opportunity to reach a different kind of audience, in a different way, and he has jumped for it.

title: In Dumbo, Remaking a White Elephant; Brooklyn Waterfront Landmark, Long Abandoned, Awaits New Life
description: It is called the Empire Stores, and for more than 50 years the cavernous, forbidding warehouse has been abandoned, a magnificent ruin between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges along the East River.

title: Our Towns; In School and Out, Lessons About Becoming American
description: HIS class numbered all of eight pupils, so when L. Joachin Mendez's fellow teachers asked him if there was a real need to continue offering English as a Second Language courses in Southampton's schools he could only shrug.

title: Earnings Rise at Movado
description: The Movado Group, the watchmaker, reported on Tuesday that it had a 14 percent increase in earnings in its most recent quarter as new products drove comparable sales up more than 19 percent at its boutiques.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about medical school courses on social activism misstated the specialty of Dr. Bertrand Bell, a professor at Albert Einstein College who led a successful campaign to limit residents' hours in New York State. He is an internist, not a surgeon.

title: Sanitation Dept. to Rehire Last of Workers It Laid Off
description: The New York City Sanitation Department announced yesterday that before Christmas, it would rehire the last of the 508 agency workers laid off this year as part of the Bloomberg administration's attempt to resolve the city's budget deficit.

title: Picking Pinots That Don't Pick Pockets
description: TWICE a year, I get in the car and drive 200 miles or so for half a dozen bottles of wine. It's always pinot noir, and, frankly, I doubt if I'd go to that much effort for any other grape.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Delay In Hearing For Guantnamo Chaplain
description: The military said it had postponed a preliminary hearing for Capt. James J. Yee, former Muslim chaplain at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, because it had inadvertently distributed a classified document to the defense lawyers. The hearing at Fort Benning, Ga., was rescheduled for Monday. Eugene R. Fidell, Captain Yee's civilian defense lawyer, said military officials retrieved 15 pages of a document he had been given last week. Mr. Fidell said the mistaken release of the document demonstrated how difficult it would be for the prosecution to prove one of its charges, that his client knowingly mishandled classified materials. Neil A. Lewis (NYT)

title: Philippine presidency / That movie-star allure: In search of a political action hero
description: MANILA  When Efren Lacorte lost his job as a welder three years ago, it crossed his mind that having voted for Joseph Estrada, his favorite movie actor, who was president of the Philippines at the time, might not have been a great idea.

title: Swearing Fealty to Ethanol
description: The sound you hear wafting across the nation from Iowa these days is Democratic presidential candidates in full pander mode. Ambitious politicians seem incapable of setting foot in the state without genuflecting before the altar of ethanol, a corn-based gasoline additive.

title: Republicans on the Hudson, and a Bronx Cheer
description: To the Editor:

title: Charity Begins at Home, and You Live in the World
description: RAMBAM'S LADDER

title: Boy's Talk of His Gay Mothers Sets Off Furor at His School
description: A 7-year-old Louisiana boy has been disciplined by his elementary school for telling a second-grade classmate that he had two mothers and explaining that gay meant ''when a girl likes a girl,'' the American Civil Liberties Union says.

title: Tape of Beating Is Released in Cincinnati
description: In an era when video recordings of police beatings have sparked riots and brought down chiefs, officials in this racially polarized city are actually urging people to watch a seven-minute video showing officers in a fatal brawl with a black man, asserting that the tape proves they behaved correctly.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Altiris Buys Wise Solutions For $43 Million
description: Altiris, a software company based in Lindon, Utah, bought Wise Solutions yesterday for $43 million in cash and stock to expand its business software product line. Altiris paid $31.5 million in cash and issued 348,797 common shares for all of Wise's stock outstanding. The purchase closed on Monday. Wise Solutions is based in Plymouth, Mich.

title: For Mideast, Blueprint or Illusion?
description: To the Editor:

title: Clothing Retailers Struggle to Size Up Teenagers
description: They ran, they giggled, and occasionally, they shopped. They tried on knit hats -- too expensive. They tried on lightweight chino pants -- too tight. They pointed to glitter and big logos emblazoned across the front of T-shirts -- too pass.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: SUNY Trustees Back Tuition Increase
description: The trustees of the State University of New York have approved a 2004-05 budget proposal calling for no increase in state financing but seeking a modest but unspecified tuition increase. SUNY's chancellor, Robert L. King, left, said he also wanted to develop a long-range plan to raise tuition automatically each year by an amount linked to an as yet unspecified price index. Yesterday, two SUNY trustees opposed the budget plan: the student trustee, Stephanie Gross, and Candace de Russy, a former educator. SUNY, after eight years without tuition increases, raised tuition 28 percent this year to $4,350 for state students at its senior college. The City University of New York, which also went eight years without a tuition increase, raised tuition this year by 25 percent, to $4,000. On Monday, the CUNY board approved a budget plan seeking $139 million in increased state aid but no tuition increase. CUNY's chancellor, Matthew Goldstein, said yesterday that he backs tuition indexing, but only if tuition increases are accompanied by higher state financing. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Foreign Investors Hit One Into a Japanese Ballpark
description: It is not the House That Ruth Built, but foreign investors have agreed to buy one of the best-known baseball stadiums in Japan: the home of the current champions, the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks. An American real estate investment firm, Colony Capital of Los Angeles, has agreed to buy the stadium, the Fukuoka Dome, as well as the nearby Sea Hawk Hotel and Resort from Daiei Inc., Japan's third-largest retailer.

title: People
description: Kent Holland, executive vice president at Plesser Associates, New York, was named to lead a new Washington office.

title: Glossary: How to Speak Chocolatese
description: BALLOTIN The traditional long, deep box used for packing chocolates in Europe.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: The Bank of Canada left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 2.75 percent, citing expectations that the exceptional growth of the American economy will soon translate into higher Canadian exports and robust domestic growth. The decision was in line with expectations. Canada's growth rate has slowed since spring, and the bank held out the possibility of lowering interest rates if business and consumer spending failed to rebound, or if the recent surge in the Canadian dollar offset stronger demand for exports. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: New York Harbor Fuel Spill Fouls Sea Gate
description: A fuel spill yesterday from a freighter anchored off Staten Island sent tarlike balls of heavy-grade oil washing ashore in Sea Gate, Brooklyn, a residential enclave west of Coney Island, the authorities said.

title: Automakers Agree to Make S.U.V.s Safer in Car Crashes
description: DETROIT, Dec. 3  The auto industry, which for years has disputed the extent of safety problems associated with sport utility vehicles, agreed today to make design changes to S.U.V.'s and pickup trucks sold in the United States so they become less dangerous to the occupants of passenger cars.

title: THE CHEF: Jamie Oliver; He's Young, Famous, And He's Got Plans
description: WHEN you dine at the River Cafe in Hammersmith, on the outskirts of this city, you begin to see, and taste, where Jamie Oliver, now a celebrity and the star of ''Jamie's Kitchen'' on the Food Network, developed what he calls his ''Tuscan globe-trotting'' style of cooking. He worked at the restaurant from 1996 to 1999. His cooking now is less rigid, more cluttered, in a jovial way, than the casual riffs on Italian food that you find at the River Cafe. But that probably has more to do with his personality. His mind bubbles with ideas, he is instantly bored and often laughing. His cooking shares similar verve.

title: Republicans on the Hudson, and a Bronx Cheer
description: To the Editor:

title: Simon and Garfunkel, Together Again, but Worn by Time
description: In 1968, Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel sang about two old friends at 70 ''sharing a park bench silently.'' Simon and Garfunkel, now both 62, opened a sold-out three-night stand at Madison Square Garden last night, singing ''Old Friends.'' They are on a reunion tour -- doing their first shows together since 1993 -- that's likely to sell more than $50 million worth of tickets.

title: The Secrets Behind Many Chefs' Not-So-Secret Ingredient
description: TODAY's sexiest fruit, the darling of chefs, is the yuzu, a rare, expensive Japanese citrus of mysterious provenance. Few diners have seen this rough-skinned oddity the size of a golf ball or know what it is, but many have encountered its distinctive flavor and aroma, a complex blend of lime, lemon and grapefruit.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Marion Cunningham; A Grande Dame Of Home Cooking Is Still at the Stove
description: MARION CUNNINGHAM is a woman of conviction, with twinkling cornflower blue eyes, white hair slicked back in a tiny ponytail and a handsome, grandmotherly face. She also has a keen sense of the ridiculous, delivering her zingers in the style of a practiced comedian.

title: KELLWOOD, A CLOTHING COMPANY, NAMES A PRESIDENT
description: Robert C. Skinner Jr. was named president of the Kellwood company, a clothing company that reached licensing agreements with Calvin Klein and Russell Simmons earlier this year. Mr. Skinner, 49, will succeed Hal J. Upbin, who will keep the titles of chairman and chief executive until at least January 2006, when he has said he would retire. Mr. Skinner is credited with efforts to update Kellwood's stodgy image with licensing agreements to create Def Jam University clothes in a preppy/rap style and Def Run Athletics, a line of sports-oriented clothes named after Mr. Simmons' brother, the rapper Reverend Run. Tracie Rozhon (NYT)

title: In Seattle, a New Life for a Once-Derelict Lakefront
description: Final touches are being put on the interiors of some 500,000 square feet of office, laboratory and apartment buildings here that are to receive their first tenants in a few months.

title: Dean Says He's Now Considering Unsealing Vermont Files
description: Facing criticism for another day over his decision on leaving office as governor of Vermont to keep many of his official papers secret for a decade, Howard Dean said on Tuesday that he was now considering unsealing some of the records.

title: A Ruling for Democratic Principles
description: The Colorado Supreme Court took a stand for electoral fairness this week when it struck down a partisan redrawing of the state's Congressional district lines. It held that districts should be drawn once after the census, not whenever a party sees a chance to pick up seats. The alternative would mean constant redistricting, and interference with state Congressional delegations, whenever one party got the upper hand at the state level.

title: Hevesi Says Subway Fares Could Rise In Two Years
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's financial problems could be much worse than projected by the agency, meaning another fare and toll increase may be needed in just two years, according to a report by the state comptroller's office.

title: The Search for the Perfect Gift: Just a Click, Not a Drive, Away
description: When someone types ''Christmas light sets'' into the Web search engine Google, the second listing, after a government recall notice, is the site for Aubuchon Hardware, a family-run chain of New England hardware stores. As a result, Aubuchon is now selling more light sets in California than in Massachusetts, its home state.

title: It's Hofstra's Turn to Dominate St. John's
description: The jeers, the cries of disbelief and the calls for Mike Jarvis's head started sooner than normal last night at Alumni Hall. Midway through the first half, it was apparent that St. John's was in deep trouble against another team that it used to beat regularly.

title: New Accusations At Tyco Fraud Trial
description: Tyco International reimbursed its former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, and its former chief financial officer, Mark H. Swartz, for their investment in a New Hampshire restaurant, a former Tyco employee testified yesterday.

title: The Syrian Leader's Curious World
description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria understands that he no longer lives in his father's Middle East, where brutal repression at home, the refusal to deal with Israel and cozy relations with terrorist groups and rogue regimes were enough to ensure decades of unchallenged power. That much comes across in an interview with our colleague Neil MacFarquhar in The Times on Monday. What is less clear is whether Mr. Assad, the son and successor of Hafez al-Assad, fully grasps the magnitude of the challenge he has inherited, and so far failed to meet.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Chip Maker Raises Outlook
description: Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing, Singapore's biggest chip maker, said its fourth-quarter loss would be narrower than forecast on increased orders for chips used in devices like cellphones and modems. The loss will be about $44 million, or 18 cents an American depository share. In October, the company forecast a loss of about $50 million, or 20 cents. The fourth-quarter loss in 2002 was about $109 million.

title: City Detective And Ex-Officer Charged in Theft Of Drug Cash
description: When members of the elite El Dorado Task Force set up surveillance of a drug operation last week in Queens, they were looking for criminals. They did not anticipate catching an on-duty detective from another elite unit shaking down a courier for $169,000.

title: Republicans on the Hudson, and a Bronx Cheer
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about Mary Caryl Fairbank and other grandparents who raise their grandchildren and receive help through donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of three of her grandchildren. They are Rachel, Michael and Garry Mayes III, not Mays.

title: Lost Jewelry Returned After Suspicious Bag Is Reported on Train
description: When Grace Colangelo left a bag full of jewelry on the B train on Monday night, she thought she would never get it back.

title: Edwards Tries Personal Touch to Gain in Iowa
description: Senator John Edwards of North Carolina barnstormed across Iowa on Tuesday at speeds topping 80 miles an hour, making eight stops in about 11 hours in a concerted effort to claim third place in the Democratic caucuses next month.

title: Isles Lose Again, Making a Run at Being the Worst
description: The Islanders are reaching into their dark recent past, when defeats were matter-of-fact and a sleepy Nassau Coliseum was livened up only by scattered booing.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the Metropolitan Opera's decision to take a two-week midseason break in January 2005 misstated the length of the Met's current and 2004-5 seasons. The current one is 32 weeks, not 36; next season will be 32 weeks plus a partial week after the break, not 36.

title: Muhammad Looms Over Sniper Trial Of Teenager
description: A striking photograph of John A. Muhammad, who has been sentenced to die for his role in last fall's sniper attacks, from time to time literally looms over the trial of Lee Malvo, the other man charged in the shootings.

title: There's Just Last Stands Remaining For the Jets
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards saw the beauty in the ugliness of the victory over the Jacksonville Jaguars.

title: JONES APPAREL REVISES ITS FORECAST UPWARD
description: The Jones Apparel Group raised its profit forecast for next year after completing the purchase of Kasper A.S.L. The acquisition, completed Monday, will increase earnings in 2004 by about 15 cents a share, the company said. Jones had forecast profit of $2.25 to $2.50 a share. The purchase of Kasper, the owner of the Anne Klein and Albert Nipon brands, is expected to add $415 million to $435 million to revenue next year. Jones had forecast sales of $4 billion. Kasper, which is based in Secaucus, N.J., filed for bankruptcy protection in February 2002. Jones is based in Bristol, Pa.

title: Revived Economy Helped Lift Automakers' November Sales
description: Sales at General Motors, BMW and Honda's luxury division, Acura, all surged last month, largely because of the rebounding economy, automakers said Tuesday. DaimlerChrysler said its sales rose slightly in November from the month a year ago, while the Ford Motor Company's sales showed a decline.

title: Pentagon Delays $20 Billion Boeing Deal
description: The Pentagon has delayed a $20 billion contract from the Air Force to the Boeing Company and directed its inspector general to determine whether there is any reason the deal should not go forward, Defense Department officials said on Tuesday.

title: The Mediterranean, Lapping at Midtown
description: Think you know your beers? How about Keo, a lightly bitter citrus-sharp lager from Cyprus that is terrific with cheese? Or Castelain, a fruity ale from France; or the robust Layla Dirty Blonde lager from Israel; or Casablanca, a spicy and rich lager from Morocco?

title: On ABC, Sears Pays to Be Star Of New Series
description: The ABC television network is making its biggest branded-entertainment deal to date, signing Sears, Roebuck & Company as the centerpiece sponsor of a reality series, ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,'' that will have its premiere as an hourlong special tonight at 10.

title: National Briefing: Plains
description: NORTH DAKOTA: ARREST OF SEX OFFENDER IN KIDNAPPING A man described as a predatory sex offender was arrested and charged with kidnapping in the disappearance of a college student in Grand Forks, but the authorities said they had not found the young woman. Alfonso Rodriguez Jr., 50, was arrested on Monday in Crookston, Minn., about 30 miles from Grand Forks, where he lives, the police said. Court documents in the case were sealed. The University of North Dakota student, Dru Sjodin, 22, of Pequot Lakes, Minn., vanished on Nov. 22 after leaving her job at a Victoria's Secret store in a Grand Forks mall.   (AP)

title: They'll Take Manhattan: Republicans Drop Ship Idea
description: Representative Tom DeLay of Texas will not go ahead with his plan to use a luxury cruise liner as a floating entertainment center for members of Congress, lobbyists and contributors during the Republican National Convention next summer, an aide said yesterday.

title: Off the Menu
description: With BAR JAMN, 125 East 17th Street, MARIO BATALI, left, and JOSEPH BASTIANICH have turned their attention to Spain. Diners at tall counter-style tables can choose from a menu of about two dozen tapas, like tender calamari on a toasted baguette, two kinds of Spanish ham (jamn) and anchovies on a bed of chorizo-flavored bread crumbs. Mr. Batali and Mr. Bastianich, both of Babbo and Otto fame, have the chef ANDY NUSSER preparing the dishes next door at CASA MONO, another new spot of theirs that is opening in a week or so at 52 Irving Place. Casa Mono will have a more elaborate menu of small plates, and seats at 20 tables and 2 bars. Unlike Bar Jamn, it will eventually accept reservations.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a lawsuit to block a bear hunt in a federal park in New Jersey misstated the date of the anti-hunting protest shown. It was Nov. 1, not this Monday.

title: Julian Hirsch, 81, an Engineer Who Wrote About Audio Gear
description: Julian Hirsch, an electrical engineer and writer who was among the first to help a growing audience of audiophiles sort through the good, the bad and the indifferent in electronic sound equipment, died on Nov. 24 in the Bronx. He was 81 and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: PARLIAMENT APPROVES MEDIA LAW Parliament passed a law that will permit Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi to increase his expansive media holdings. Supporters of the bill said that was not its intention, adding that the law mirrored those elsewhere that liberalized media markets in the hope of modernizing them. But Mr. Berlusconi's opponents noted that it would enable his family holding company, starting in 2009, to purchase newspapers and radio stations. Mr. Berlusconi has direct control or indirect influence over six of the seven national television stations. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: Devils' Offense Disappears, and Coyotes Dictate the Pace
description: Phoenix defenseman Ossi Vaananen had disposed of Devils right wing Brian Gionta by shoving him into the goal. Gionta is 9 inches shorter and 52 pounds lighter than Vaananen, but he came up snarling.

title: The Neediest Cases; An Illness Alters a Family's Life Forever
description: Alfred Ferrer, 9, is a little like a one-man band, heavy on the percussion. He smacks his thighs, stomach, cheeks and head, producing a steady beat. He shakes a nearly empty soda bottle, adding a sloshing counterpoint. His vocals are delicate: gulps of air, fluttering lips and sing-song calls, punctuated with shouts.

title: FAO to File for Bankruptcy And Break Up Toy Empire
description: In the season of Santa Claus and peak toy shopping, FAO, owner of the F.A.O. Schwarz toy stores, said yesterday that it would file for bankruptcy protection and intended to break up an empire known not just for toys but also for a certain retail fantasy and style in selling them.

title: Market Place; For This Chief, a Loss Would Be a Big Gain
description: If the impending stock offering by Orbitz, the online travel agency, stumbles out of the gate, virtually all shareholders could suffer. But one, Jeffrey G. Katz, the chairman and chief executive, would not necessarily feel their pain.

title: Wisconsin Is Looking Up
description: Wisconsin had five victories and nine losses on Dec. 1 last year and was on its way to its worst season in 27 years. This year, the Badgers are 8-3-3 and giving every indication a turnaround is in progress.

title: Memorializing 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweet Life After Bitter Start
description: ALL chocolate starts as a ripe cacao pod, about the size and shape of a football, growing on a tree somewhere within 20 degrees of the equator, mainly in Ivory Coast, Ghana and Venezuela. Within the pods are sweet white fruits; within each fruit is a dusty brown cacao bean; within each bean is a fingertip-size, inedibly bitter nib of pure chocolate. (In the unrefined state, the pod and beans are called cacao. Once processing begins, the word cocoa is used instead.)

title: Republicans on the Hudson, and a Bronx Cheer
description: To the Editor:

title: For Mideast, Blueprint or Illusion?
description: To the Editor:

title: His Jury Sees Rep. Janklow Placing Blame
description: A few hours after his car accident killed a motorcyclist at a rural intersection, Representative Bill Janklow, one of the most powerful men in South Dakota, found himself in a state trooper's squad car, anxiously returning, again and again, to the seconds just before the wreck.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: New Bond Issue
description: Argentina will sell three-year peso-denominated bonds, the longest maturity auctioned since 2001, in a bid to rebuild the domestic market two years after the government defaulted on $95 billion of debt. By selling the bonds, the central bank will help open the domestic market for companies and individuals to borrow and finance investments and purchases, said Rodrigo Sacca, an economist at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Buenos Aires. The government is trying to sustain a recovery as it forecasts that gross domestic product will grow 7 percent this year, the fastest expansion in six years.

title: Longevity In Coaching Worries Scott
description: Maurice Cheeks was sitting in his office with his feet propped on the sofa when he saw a picture of Coach Larry Brown of the Pistons flash on the television screen.

title: Born to State Office, or at Least Reared on It
description: WHEN the New Jersey Republican Party found itself having to choose a minority leader in the State Senate, it sought someone who was not, in polite political slang, ''ethically challenged.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Powell Avoids Human Rights Concerns in Africa
description: ALGIERS, Dec. 3  Ending a two-day sweep across North Africa today, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell offered praise and rewards for allies that he acknowledged were still moving toward full democracy, while avoiding any pointed remarks about human rights concerns.

title: RUSSIA TO REJECT PACT ON CLIMATE, PUTIN AIDE SAYS
description: A senior Kremlin official declared Tuesday that Russia would not ratify the international treaty requiring cuts in the emissions of gases linked to global warming, delivering what could be a fatal blow to years of diplomatic efforts.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Saturday about the effectiveness of the death penalty law signed by Gov. George E. Pataki in 1995 referred incorrectly to the previous position of Judge Victoria A. Graffeo, a Pataki appointee who dissented from a recent Court of Appeals ruling setting aside a death sentence. As solicitor general, she served under Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco; it was not a senior legal position in Mr. Pataki's administration.

title: Turkish Reports Cite Qaeda Order in Bombings
description: Turkish news organizations reported Tuesday that two suspects in the suicide bombings that rocked Istanbul last month took direct orders from a senior Qaeda leader, Dr. Ayman al-Zawahiri, after meeting him earlier this year.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: IVORY COAST: POLICE BREAK UP SIEGE OF FRENCH Riot police officers dispersed protesters outside a French base in Abidjan who had demonstrated through the night to urge the soldiers to leave the country. The protests followed clashes over the weekend between Ivoirian soldiers and French forces policing a cease-fire line through the center of the country. The French Foreign Ministry said a pullout was "out of the question." French troops were sent to Ivory Coast in November 2002, two months after a rebellion boiled over into civil war, to police a cease-fire. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Rangers Feel Cheated As Leafs Keep Rolling
description: Rangers Coach Glen Sather often sounds as if he believes the referees are out to get his team. On Tuesday night, Sather and his players felt that way more than ever after the Toronto Maple Leafs squeaked past the Rangers, 5-4.

title: Man Calls Childrens Shooting an Accident
description: Aman arrested in the shooting of two children at a playground has told the police the gunshot was an accident.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Harlem; Buildings Can Be Higher; Prices, It Seems, Follow Suit
description: Spurred in part by the prospect of zoning changes that would allow construction of taller residential buildings, the price of empty lots in Harlem has almost doubled in the last year or so, according to a study by Massey Knakal Realty Services.

title: Whisk and Baster With Quirks, But They Work
description: A couple of kitchen stocking stuffers:

title: 42 A-Plants Found to Lack Enough Cash For Cleanup
description: The owners of nearly half the nuclear power reactors in the United States are not reserving enough money to decommission them on retirement, according to Congressional auditors, who also say the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is not tracking the money carefully.

title: A Hard Case From the Streets Makes Good
description: The first time Rick Carlisle saw Jack Ryan, he was less than impressed. It was 13 years ago, in 1990, at a Nets rookie camp, when Carlisle, now head coach of the Indiana Pacers, was an assistant to Bill Fitch.

title: St. John's Expanding On Future
description: St. John's will build a field house with practice courts for its men's and women's basketball teams and explore a major renovation of Alumni Hall, university officials said yesterday.

title: Making A Nation More Equal
description: Women in Afghanistan have only a short time to influence the new draft constitution to be considered by the Constitutional Loya Jirga scheduled for next week. Although the new draft upholds the principle of human rights, there is no explicit guarantee of women's equality. This is not a matter of semantics. Rather, it raises serious questions about the document's commitment to protect women's rights.

title: Iraq's Hidden Treasure
description: Iraq has many capable women ready to lead the country toward democracy. Yet women are severely underrepresented in the leadership established for the transition. As plans for a new governing structure are developed, the Iraqi Governing Council and the Coalition Provisional Authority should ensure women their rightful place at the decision-making table.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about plans by the Time Out Group to start a magazine in Chicago, misstated the life span of 7 Days, a magazine that closed in 1990. It was two years, not two months.

title: Con Edison Customers To Receive Small Rebate
description: Consolidated Edison has agreed to refund nearly $45.5 million to its customers and forgo $89.5 million in rate increases as part of a settlement over shutdowns at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, New York State officials announced yesterday.

title: A MIRACLE REVISITED: Measuring Success; Gains in Houston Schools: How Real Are They?
description: As a student at Jefferson Davis High here, Rosa Arevelo seemed the ''Texas miracle'' in motion. After years of classroom drills, she passed the high school exam required for graduation on her first try. A program of college prep courses earned her the designation ''Texas scholar.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Outlook For Bank
description: The British bank Barclays said that 2003 pretax profit would beat analysts' estimates of 3.69 billion ($6.4 billion), which was a 15 percent increase from a year earlier. Growth in the bank's private client, corporate and investment banking unit was stronger in the third quarter, the bank said, while credit quality improved. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Health Industry Bidding to Hire Medicare Chief
description: The federal official who runs Medicare and was intimately involved in drafting legislation to overhaul the program is the object of a bidding war among five firms hoping to hire him to advise clients affected by the measure.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Veritas To Hire 300 In India
description: The Veritas Software Corporation, one of the world's largest independent makers of data-storage products, will hire 300 people in India over the next 12 months to expand research and development in the country. Veritas, based in Mountain View, Calif., employs 500 people in India. They represent almost a quarter of the company's engineering work force, the company said yesterday. Veritas and companies like Microsoft and Oracle have centers in India to develop the country's pool of technical workers and to save costs. The country produces 167,000 engineering graduates annually, according to an industry group, the National Association of Software and Service Companies. Programmers in India can cost companies as little as one-sixth as much as employees in the United States.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Interest In Soccer Club
description: Sheik Abdul Rahman bin Mubarak al-Khalifa, a member of the Bahrain royal family, said he might buy the English soccer club Leeds United. The Leeds club is deep in debt, and the team has performed poorly. The sheik is exploring options for the club, according to a statement to the London Stock Exchange. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Disney Board Names an Independent Director
description: The Walt Disney Company announced on Tuesday that John S. Chen, chief executive of Sybase Inc., the computer software company, would join its board as an independent director in January.

title: Powell Begins Trip to Europe and Africa, Seeking Cooperation
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell embarked on a five-nation, four-day tour on Tuesday, hoping to mend fences with Europeans upset by the American strategy in Iraq and to stiffen the resolve of North African nations rattled by terror attacks to continue to fight Islamic militants.

title: Beware 'Animal Spirits'
description: You cannot accuse The Times of throwing a wet blanket on good economic news.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the decision by the Bush administration to cancel $289.5 million in American-backed loan guarantees for Israel referred incorrectly to West Bank construction activities that prompted it. Although federal law requires revoking loan guarantees to penalize certain construction deemed contrary to American policy, the United States does not define the activities as illegal.

title: LIBERTY MEDIA ACQUIRES SHARES IN TP INVESTMENT
description: The Liberty Media Corporation said it had acquired the outstanding shares of TP Investment, a private investment vehicle run by Liberty's chairman, John C. Malone, for Liberty stock valued at $60.7 million. Liberty paid 5.28 million of its Class B shares valued at $11.50 each in exchange for TP Investment stock, according to a regulatory filing. Liberty also said it was in talks with the family of Robert J. Magness, who founded the predecessor company to Liberty, Tele-Communications Inc., to acquire the 96 million Class B shares of Liberty held by the family. The combined transactions would reduce Mr. Malone's voting power in Liberty to about 28 percent of the total from 42 percent, the company said in the filing. Mr. Malone controls Liberty, a media investment company whose holdings include the Starz Encore cable networks, through his ownership of Class A and Class B shares.

title: NATO Should Beef Up Its Force in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Chinatown Stores Raided In Counterfeit-Goods Sweep
description: Not only was a raid in Chinatown yesterday timed to grab the attention of tourists and holiday shoppers, but it also involved enough fake Louis Vuitton clutch bags, bogus Kate Spade calfskin totes and faux Fendis to keep hundreds of low-rent supermodels happy through all 12 days of Christmas.

title: New Test for Colorectal Cancer
description: It sounds too good to be true, and perhaps it is. Researchers announced this week that an X-ray screening technique had proved just as effective in detecting colorectal cancer as the widely dreaded colonoscopy, in which a long tube is inserted into the colon so a doctor can view its walls. An editorial in The New England Journal of Medicine suggested that the less invasive X-ray technique -- using a C.T. scanner and new software -- might ultimately be headed for ''prime time.'' Yet there are reasons to go slow in registering our applause.

title: Three Are Indicted in Fake A.T.M. Scheme
description: The men set up a fake automated teller machine in a small grocery on First Avenue in Manhattan, and then, according to prosecutors, used it to skim personal information from credit and bank cards.

title: Justices Resist Religious Study Using Subsidies
description: An argument by religious conservatives in a church-state case they embraced as a vehicle for expanding their recent Supreme Court victories met resistance from a deeply divided court on Tuesday. A majority of the justices expressed concern about the implications of requiring states to subsidize religious training if they choose to provide college scholarships for other kinds of study.

title: Meaty Role Pulls Actor Beyond Beefcake; Film About Immigrants Is a Step to Stardom For Djimon Hounsou
description: The first thing one noticed about the actor Djimon Hounsou on a recent afternoon was not his towering build or startling good looks: flawless dark skin, dimples and a smile worthy of a White Strips commercial. Rather it was his navy-blue baseball cap. Pulled low over his brow, it featured a glorious rooster that looked poised to deliver a mighty crow. When asked about his curious choice in headgear, Mr. Hounsou chuckled mischievously. ''Today,'' he said, ''I am monsieur le coq.''

title: Addenda VW Unit in Spain Shifts To Grey Worldwide
description: Seat, the Spanish operation of Volkswagen, has named Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group, to handle the creative and media duties on its account, which had been handled by Bates Worldwide.

title: Rights, Religion And Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Parliament Approves Media Law
description: Parliament passed a law that will permit Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi to increase his expansive media holdings. Supporters of the bill said that was not its intention, adding that the law mirrored those elsewhere that liberalized media markets in the hope of modernizing them. But Mr. Berlusconi's opponents noted that it would enable his family holding company, starting in 2009, to purchase newspapers and radio stations. Mr. Berlusconi has direct control or indirect influence over six of the seven national television stations. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: Judge Strikes Down Colorados School Voucher Law
description: ADenver judge struck down Colorado's new school voucher law today, ruling that it violated the state constitution by stripping local school boards of their control over education.

title: Court Finds Rwanda Media Executives Guilty of Genocide
description: ARUSHA, Tanzania Dec. 3  In the first verdict of its kind since the Nuremberg trials, an international court today convicted three Rwandan news media executives of genocide for helping to incite a killing spree by machete-wielding gangs who slaughtered about 800,000 Tutsis in neighboring Rwanda in early 1994.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 3Com Makes Distribution Deal
description: The 3Com Corporation, one of the world's biggest makers of computer networking gear, said yesterday that the Electronic Data Systems Corporation had agreed to distribute 3Com's switches, routers and other equipment. Terms were not disclosed. Electronic Data will resell 3Com gear, including products for Internet-based phone calling, in the United States and Britain, the companies said. The accord is aimed at helping 3Com, which is based in Marlborough, Mass., add business clients and regain sales from a bigger rival, Cisco Systems. In March, 3Com formed a joint venture with Huawei Technologies, a competitor of Cisco in China. Electronic Data Systems shares rose 68 cents, or 3 percent, to $22.88.

title: Researchers Are Split on Case of Plague Expert
description: A day after after a federal jury in Texas convicted a respected plague researcher on 47 counts but cleared him of the most serious charges of research misconduct, scientists and lawyers were as divided in their opinions yesterday as the verdict itself.

title: No Resolution in U.S. Case Against French Bank
description: Discussions between the United States and France on an agreement to avoid criminal charges related to the Crdit Lyonnais purchase of assets from a California insurance company have broken down, both sides said Tuesday.

title: PepsiCo Plans to Cut 750 Jobs and Close Several Plants
description: To streamline its operations, PepsiCo said yesterday that it would cut 750 jobs in its beverage and snack businesses, close a Frito-Lay plant in Kentucky and relocate the headquarters of its Tropicana unit from Florida to Chicago, which will become the hub for the company's juice and Gatorade business.

title: She Teases Brains Into Joy of Learning
description: THERE'S lots of excitement when a new young teacher like Ashley Jones comes to a rural school. Here in Beaufort County, in eastern North Carolina, where the cotton fields meet the saltwater marshes of Pamlico Sound, it is hard to find young teachers. Four months into the school year, the high school still cannot fill a math teaching position. Those who apply are often middle-aged men and women changing careers after a farm goes broke or a textile mill closes.

title: Listen Up! Insights From A Quirky Music Tutor
description: In the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, Robert Kapilow was leading 200 audience members in a boisterous singalong of Beethoven's piano sonata ''Les Adieux,'' written after the departure of his patron, Archduke Rudolph, as the French Army advanced on Vienna.

title: Bubbles With a Little Twist
description: At a dinner in Paris a year ago, the host poured Dom Prignon into narrow little crystal tumblers with thick bottoms that he said he had bought on sale at Baccarat. I loved their feel, and they were fun for Champagne: the unusual shape didn't get in the way of the bubbles. Now similar glasses, after a style by the late Austrian designer Alfred Loos, are being sold in the gift catalog of Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue (86th Street), (212) 628-6200. They are four and a half inches high, hold six ounces (about the same as a typical flute) and, at $80 each, make a lovely holiday indulgence or gift.

title: For Mideast, Blueprint or Illusion?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dayne Accepts Idleness And Fassel Reaffirms It
description: In the middle of a team in chaos, Giants running back Ron Dayne has stayed nearly silent. He quietly comes to work every day. He stands on the sideline at games, never in uniform, encouraging his teammates.

title: Pound Wont Call Payments Bribes
description: Dick Pound of Canada, an International Olympic Committee member for the last quarter-century, said yesterday that he would not apply the term "bribes" to the payments made by the indicted Olympic bid leaders Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson to I.O.C. members before the selection of Salt Lake City to stage the 2002 Olympic Winter Games.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a television review of ''The Tracy Morgan Show'' reversed the surnames of the star and the character he plays. The picture showed Tracy Morgan with other cast members; Tracy Mitchell is the character's name.

title: Saudis Arrest Suspect in Bombing of Compound
description: Authorities in Saudi Arabia said today that they had arrested a suspect in the November bombing attack that killed 18 people in the capital of Riyadh, and that they had seized a cache of weapons and explosives.

title: Would-Be Marciano Faces Test
description: They've waited for a long time for a heavyweight like him, and Joe Mesi seems to have all the right ingredients. The boyish, clean-cut face. The punches that knock people out. The story that began in the middle-class suburbs of Buffalo when Mesi was overweight and bartending in college and wanted to be a schoolteacher.

title: Upper East Side Rents
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. SPEEDS UP REVIEW OF A CANCER DRUG
description: Pharmacyclics, an unprofitable developer of heart and cancer drugs, said federal regulators had agreed to a speedier review of its experimental brain-cancer medicine. Shares of the company surged 25 percent. The Food and Drug Administration granted a so-called fast-track review for the medicine, Xcytrin, which treats patients with lung cancer that has spread to the brain, the company said. The status allows Pharmacyclics to file data on drug studies as it is collected for faster processing by the agency. Pharmacyclics, which has not yet filed an application for F.D.A. approval, is conducting trials comparing patients treated using radiation with or without Xcytrin. Shares of Pharmacyclics rose $1.62, to $8.17.

title: INSIDE
description: Boeing Contract Delayed

title: Recipe: Brandied Custard
description: Time 15 minutes

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Republican Lawmaker To Retire
description: Representative Cass Ballenger, a Republican known for controversial remarks, said he would not seek a 10th term next year. Mr. Ballenger, who turns 77 on Saturday, is tired of the constant travel to and from Washington, a spokesman said. Last December, Mr. Ballenger, who represents the 10th Congressional District, northwest of Charlotte, apologized for saying that Representative Cynthia McKinney, a black Democrat from Georgia known for her abrasive style, had stirred in him ''a little bit of a segregationist feeling.'' Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: China Tells Its Public Of Enormity Of AIDS Toll
description: With China taking its first real steps toward a full-scale public awareness campaign about AIDS this week, the degree of ignorance caused by past government denial is evident in the dazed expression of Zhao Pingyuan.

title: In Search of the Perfect Baked Apple
description: MY grandmother Ella had the right idea when it came to baked apples. She made them on Friday afternoons before the Jewish Sabbath, filling the centers with red jam and roasting them along with the chicken or brisket. Come dessert, she arranged the apples on a platter, pouring on top the sugary sauce studded with raisins and nuts from the pan. Then she set the platter on her white lace tablecloth next to the strudel or rugelach or chocolate cake and watched as we devoured the pastries and left the fruit.

title: Bush Is Urged To Maintain Import Tariffs For Steel
description: President Bush got a taste of the treacherous nature of trade politics on Tuesday, hearing last-ditch pleas from some of his own supporters not to proceed with plans to lift tariffs protecting the steel industry from international competition.

title: S.E.C. Proposes Strict Rule to End Late Mutual Fund Trading
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  In response to an industry in crisis, the Securities and Exchange Commission proposed its first set of new mutual fund regulations today and announced an ambitious schedule to issue more rules in the next two months.

title: In a Shaky Present, Boeing Weighs Risks of Building a Jet of the Future
description: The future of the Boeing Company, no matter its tumultuous present, rests in large part on the wings of its next-generation jet.

title: Sports of The Times; Important Barrier Falls in the Deep South
description: THE story begins in the mid-60's in northeast Tuscaloosa County, Ala., where the sons of the Rev. Sylvester Croom Sr. and his wife, Louise, were taught to look beyond the bigotry, to ignore the ignorance, and to seek a place of solid standing for themselves in a world of racial polarization.

title: Wartorn Fledgling Hides, Until a Friend Finds Him
description: ''Birdy,'' a play by Naomi Wallace that has been intelligently adapted from a 1978 novel by William Wharton, is about the aftershock of war and two boyhood friends who coax each other out of it.

title: British Universities Increasingly Look Abroad for Leadership
description: When she left the University of California at Berkeley to become dean of the London Business School nearly two years ago, Laura D'Andrea Tyson was struck by her new colleagues' penchant for meetings.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: ECHINACEA FAILS IN STUDY Echinacea, trumpeted as an herbal remedy for the common cold, did nothing to ease symptoms in children, a study has found. "There was no difference in both the length of cold symptoms and severity of cold symptoms in children who received either echinacea or placebo for their colds," said James Taylor of the University of Washington, who led the study of 407 children. The results contrasted with earlier, less reliable studies that have shown echinacea to be somewhat effective in helping adults stricken with colds to recover, said the report, published in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association.   (Reuters)

title: Critic of Ideas For Memorial Is New Adviser On Rebuilding
description: An architectural and planning coalition that has criticized the World Trade Center memorial competition was named yesterday to help prepare design guidelines for the overall trade center site.

title: U.S. Proposes Easing Rules On Emissions Of Mercury
description: The Bush administration is proposing that mercury emissions from coal-burning power plants should not be regulated in the same way as some of the most toxic air pollutants, reversing a stance on air pollution control taken by the Clinton administration in 2000.

title: Ferry Official Is Investigated In S.I. Crash
description: Federal prosecutors and the New York Police Department are examining the performance of at least one senior Staten Island Ferry official as part of their expanding criminal investigation into the October crash of the Andrew J. Barberi, several law enforcement officials said.

title: Chinese Officers Warn That Taiwan Referendum Could Lead to War
description: BEIJING, Dec. 3  Chinese military officers said today that Taiwan's leadership had pushed the island toward the "abyss of war" with its independence drive, making clear that China would consider a popular vote on Taiwan's political status as cause for war.
