title: Rumsfeld Says Allied Nations Are Undeterred By Iraq Losses
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, wrapping up a two-day meeting of NATO defense ministers here, said Tuesday that despite attacks that had taken the lives of allies, he had received assurances from many governments that they would not withdraw troops from Iraq.

title: Fine Dining in New Jersey, Sauced With Puns
description: ''Sophisticated'' may not be the first word that comes to mind in describing many New Jersey restaurants, but Vicki J. Caparulo and her husband, Steve, make a strong case that it should in their new book, ''Great Dishes From New Jersey's Favorite Restaurants'' (Rutgers University Press, $32.95). The book, a survey of 52 restaurants from Weehawken and points north down to Cape May, includes recipes and tempting photographs taken by Mr. Caparulo. The list tilts toward formal places like the Ryland Inn and the Dining Room at the Short Hills Hilton. Ms. Caparulo, a cooking teacher, has a jokey, exclamatory writing style, calling a chef who likes seafood ''a real afishianado.'' But the recipes are clear and often include chefs' tricks. Many are on the complicated side, requiring special equipment and unusual ingredients like caul fat. But if an appealing dish seems intimidating, the restaurants' phone numbers are provided: you could always make a reservation. ROBERTA ZEFF

title: A Big Deal? The Yankees Still Aren't There Yet
description: The Yankees remained active yesterday, continuing efforts to collect arms for what will be a very expensive bullpen and making other minor moves. But they have yet to make a big deal, certainly not one that would rival Boston's acquisition of Curt Schilling, and the one headline-generating move that seemed closest to completion has encountered at least a little bit of turbulence.

title: Iraqis Say U.S. Agrees to Formation of a Multiparty Militia
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 3  The American-led administration in Iraq has agreed with leaders of the country's top political parties to create a militia group made up of troops picked in equal numbers by the parties, party officials and members of the Iraqi Governing Council said today.

title: Casting a Fresh Eye on China With Computer, Not Ink Brush
description: Yang Fudong, a 32-year-old Chinese video artist, is in high demand on the international art circuit. The Venice Biennale and the Georges Pompidou Center showed his work this year. He travels to Florida to exhibit at the Art Basel Miami Beach show, which opens on Dec. 4. In January he plans to visit Manhattan when the Museum of Modern Art shows his work at the Gramercy Theater. He will also be included in an exhibition organized by the International Center of Photography that opens in June.

title: U.S. Appeals Ban on Death Penalty in Moussaoui Case
description: International Herald Tribune

title: Pilot Is Unhurt in a Suffolk County Crash
description: The downed pilot wore business attire under his flight suit. He was dazed, slightly bloodied and covered in debris. But as he wrenched open the cockpit of the small plane, he seemed to Jeff Colon to be in remarkably good condition for a man who had just fallen from the sky and crash-landed into two houses.

title: The Greeks Had Many Words for Sex, and Here They Are
description: Ribaldry presides over the Jean Cocteau Repertory's production of ''Lysistrata'' by Aristophanes, as translated and adapted by David Lee Jiranek. The original's chorus of men is replaced here by a pair of depleted war veterans, and the desire and scorn of Aristophanes' chorus of women is shared among the female characters and a couple of Scythian women invented by Mr. Jiranek.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Being Pretty Didn't Help

title: New Woe for Troubled Cemetery
description: After years of mismanagement and controversy, Cypress Hills Cemetery, one of the city's largest, is out of receivership and emerging from bankruptcy. But new charges arose yesterday as one of its former court-appointed guardians accused another of trying to seize control through stealth and self-dealing.

title: First Snowstorm Dazzles and Fades, Leaving Only the Chills
description: If you weren't outside or near a window yesterday morning, you might have missed it.

title: Productivity Grew at Fastest Rate Since 1983
description: American workers churned out goods and services in the third quarter at the strongest pace in 20 years, the government reported today, but economists noted that the sharp gains were unsustainable.

title: Duck's Day In the Pan
description: PRODUCING the type of roast duck you see hanging in the windows of many Chinese restaurants is nearly impossible at home. I've tried, believe me, and it is about as far from the minimalist ideal as making vegetable pt.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Sought In Fatal Shooting Of Wife
description: A 32-year-old woman was shot dead on the street in Flatbush yesterday morning, and the police were looking last night to question her husband, a spokesman for the Police Department said. The woman, Sonja Farrier, had recently moved from Suffolk County, where she had an order of protection against the husband, which expired last month, the police said. The police did not identify the husband. At about 9 a.m., Ms. Farrier was shot at close range outside the building where she lived, near the intersection of 38th Street and Glenwood Road, the police said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: YES-Cablevision Arbitration to Begin Soon
description: The binding arbitration that will decide the long-term contract between YES and Cablevision will start soon, said Stanley Sporkin, a retired federal judge on the three-man arbitration panel. Sporkin was chosen by YES, and Richard Aurelio, a former president of the Time Warner City Cable Group, was selected by Cablevision. A third arbitrator remains to be chosen.

title: Mets View All Options As Market Changes
description: Curt Schilling buoyed the hopes of the Red Sox last week by accepting a trade to Boston from Arizona. The Yankees, seeking a major deal of their own, have been hoping to sign the slugger Gary Sheffield, although negotiations have stalled this week. Second baseman Luis Castillo re-signed with the World Series champion Marlins Monday night, rejecting the Mets.

title: G.M. SAYS IT WILL NOT SELL MORTGAGE UNIT
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it had decided not to sell its commercial mortgage business because the company could not get the price it sought and had found ways to pay for the unit's growth. The unit, the General Motors Commercial Holding Corporation, had been up for sale since March. General Motors wanted to raise money to pay for its auto and home finance businesses and ensure that the commercial-mortgage unit had access to cheaper capital. General Motors Commercial Holding had assets of about $14.6 billion as of the end of September. The unit increased net income 60 percent, to $243 million, in this year's first three quarters from the year-earlier period, a spokeswoman, Toni Simonetti, said.

title: How to Say Simplicity in Turkish
description: A COMPLICATED plate of food, with its sauces, squiggles and garnishes, can conceal many faults. But simple, elemental food has nowhere to hide. If the food is not prepared skillfully, it will be painfully obvious to the diner.

title: Residents Protest Plan To Rebuild Newark Area
description: Three weeks ago, Mayor Sharpe James and other Newark officials unveiled a $550 million redevelopment plan to create an ''urban village'' on 13 downtown acres to attract new residents. But on Tuesday, many of the people who already live and work there called the plan a ''land grab'' that excluded them and hinged on an impractical vision of the area's future.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: SUNY TRUSTEES BACK TUITION INCREASE The trustees of the State University of New York have approved a 2004-05 budget proposal calling for no increase in state financing but seeking a modest but unspecified tuition increase. SUNY's chancellor, Robert L. King, said he also wanted to develop a long-range plan to raise tuition automatically each year by an amount linked to an as yet unspecified price index. Yesterday, two SUNY trustees opposed the budget plan: the student trustee, Stephanie Gross, and Candace de Russy, a former educator. SUNY, after eight years without tuition increases, raised tuition 28 percent this year to $4,350 for state students at its senior college. The City University of New York, which also went eight years without a tuition increase, raised tuition this year by 25 percent, to $4,000. On Monday, the CUNY board approved a budget plan seeking $139 million in increased state aid but no tuition increase. CUNY's chancellor, Matthew Goldstein, said yesterday that he backs tuition indexing, but only if tuition increases are accompanied by higher state financing.    Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Meyer Kupferman, Composer In Many Forms, Is Dead at 77
description: Meyer Kupferman, a prolific composer whose music embraced both jazz and 12-tone techniques, died on Wednesday near Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 77 and lived in Rhinebeck.

title: Recipe: Spiced Baked Apples With Maple Caramel Sauce
description: Time: 1 hour 10 minutes

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Man Faces Assault Charge In Child's Death
description: The police charged a Bronx man yesterday with first-degree assault in connection with the death of his 5-week-old son on Monday. Officers answered a call from the home of the man, Michael Williams, 23, of Seneca Avenue, reporting that the baby, also named Michael Williams, had stopped breathing. After a preliminary investigation, the police said the infant, who was pronounced dead on arrival at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, had injuries to his skull, ribcage and leg. Mr. Williams was also charged with endangering the welfare of a child. A spokesman for the Bronx district attorney said the case was under review. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun To Introduce New Products
description: In an attempt to illustrate that its investment in research and development has a payoff, Sun Microsystems is scheduled today to introduce nearly 20 products the company says are intended to help corporate customers keep their network costs down. The new products include servers for technical computing, accelerator boards for existing servers and a new computing system for telecommunications. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., made the announcements at its annual SunNetwork conference in Berlin. Sun executives also said that in January, the company would release its first servers based on Advanced Micro Devices' Opteron processor, which were announced in November as part of its joint development relationship with Advanced Micro. In addition, Sun said it would update its Solaris operating system for Advanced Micro chips. Separately, the company announced plans to open a radio frequency identification test center in Scotland, aimed at helping retail businesses use networks to inventory their product lines. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Australia Promoting Its Natural Gas in U.S.
description: Geoff Gallop, the state premier of Western Australia, is visiting the United States to help ChevronTexaco sell Australia's natural gas. Between meetings with oil executives in California and energy officials in Washington, he visited Baja California, Mexico, where ChevronTexaco hopes to build a terminal to receive liquefied natural gas shipped from a huge $7.9 billion gas project off the coast of Western Australia called Gorgon.

title: Rights, Religion And Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the start of an article about the Jets' 24-17 victory over the Tennessee Titans was omitted from the first sports page in some copies yesterday. (The continuation appeared on Page D3.) The complete article is online at nytimes.com/sports. It can also be obtained by mail or by fax from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@ nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Mayor Proposes Zoning Changes
description: Home builders on Staten Island would have to provide more parking spaces, larger yards and greater distance between houses, under new zoning regulations proposed yesterday. The proposals were put forward by a task force appointed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to examine complaints about crowded, haphazard development. The proposals require City Council approval. Staten Island's population has increased by nearly 20 percent since 1990. ''You cannot continue to destroy neighborhoods and change their character overnight, and that's what was happening,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Wanted: A Good Home For a Space-Starved Art
description: A New York season was once a must for dance companies. But in recent years some major troupes have bypassed the city, among them the Royal Danish Ballet and the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago. One reason is familiar in crowded New York: a lack of space.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Antiterrorist Squads Arrest 14
description: The police arrested 12 men and 2 women in London, Cambridge and the West Midlands under the Terrorism Act, but released few details. Britain has been on its second highest alert for two weeks, since officials said they had received an intelligence warning of a probable attack by Al Qaeda. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Inquiry on Aluminum Sales
description: The Tongaat-Hulett Group, an aluminum processor in South Africa, said yesterday that the United States International Trade Commission was investigating accusations by Alcoa that Tongaat-Hulett was dumping aluminum in America.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Rivalry Threatens Major Party
description: The biggest political party is set to oust its congressional leader, Elba Esther Gordillo, in an internal battle over economic reforms proposed by President Vicente Fox. The party, the PRI, ruled Mexico from 1929 until 2000, when Mr. Fox was elected. It still commands a plurality in Congress. Ms. Gordillo, above, has supported some of President Fox's plans, which the PRI has blocked, and has called her party's president, Roberto Madrazo, a liar. Her dismissal would further dim the chances for congressional approval of Mr. Fox's economic agenda. It also threatens a deeper divide in the PRI as it fights to regain national control. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Anglican Talks Suspended
description: The Vatican suspended plans for a meeting in February at which Roman Catholic and Anglican leaders were to work on a joint statement of faith. In a statement, the Vatican said the reason was ''recent developments within the life of the Anglican Communion,'' a reference to the selection of a gay man as Episcopal bishop for New Hampshire. The Vatican says homosexual acts ''go against the natural moral law.'' Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: Sources: For Candy Machine Graduates
description: SOME of the best chocolate sources in New York and on the Internet:

title: Lawyer Allowed For Man in Brig
description: The Defense Department said on Tuesday that an American citizen of Saudi descent who is being held in a South Carolina naval brig as an enemy combatant will be allowed access to a lawyer.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: ELECTION SPENDING BREAKS RECORD Spending by all candidates in New Jersey's general election last month reached $41.3 million, according to campaign finance reports released yesterday, bringing total spending in the legislative races this year to $58 million. The total spending was 40 percent higher than the record set two years ago, when there was also a campaign for governor. This year, Democrats raised more than Republicans, 61 percent to 39 percent.    Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: The Smell of the Greasepaint, the Roar of Those Third Graders
description: Beneath the blazing lights of the Broadway revival of ''Gypsy,'' Patrick Garner, playing a weary theater owner, snarled at Bernadette Peters: ''I told you this morning, I told you this afternoon, and I'm telling you now. If there's anything I hate worse than kids, it's kids on stage!''

title: Funds Scandal Hits Invesco And Founder Of Strong
description: Richard S. Strong gave up control yesterday of the mutual fund company he founded, and regulators filed suits accusing the Invesco Funds Group and its chief executive of securities fraud in the rapidly expanding investigation of improper trading.

title: Ohio Study Finds Flaws in Electronic Voting
description: Electronic voting machines from the four biggest companies in the field have serious security flaws, but they can -- and must -- be fixed, a new report for the State of Ohio says.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Brewer's Profit Falls
description: The British brewer Scottish and Newcastle reported a 17 percent decline in net income to 105.3 million ($182.2 million) for the six months ended Oct. 26. Sales increased 17 percent, to 3.03 billion, in part because of the purchase of Bulmer Holdings. The company's shares rose. Results were hampered by higher distribution costs in some areas and write-offs of good will related to acquisitions. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Microsoft to Allow More Licensing of Its Technology
description: Microsoft announced today that it would open the doors to its storehouse of patents, copyright and trade secrets to outsiders with a more liberal policy for licensing the big software maker's intellectual property.

title: A Joyful Palace Event: Four Heads Roll in Baghdad, and All of Them Are Hussein's
description: They stand as monuments to megalomania, four massive heads of Saddam Hussein, each three stories high, sitting atop the Republican Palace, which serves as home for L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator of Iraq.

title: School Wars in New York City
description: With more than a million students and 80,000 teachers spread over more than 1,100 buildings, the New York City school system is more complex than most cities. Retooling this gargantuan system to meet the new standards laid out by both the state and the federal governments would be difficult in the best of times. It will be impossible if the city and the teachers' union succumb to the hostility that has been building in their relationship in recent months.

title: New Evidence Is Reported That Floors Failed on 9/11
description: Federal investigators said here Tuesday that new evidence supported earlier suggestions that the floor supports in the World Trade Center began failing in the minutes before the towers fell and might have played a major role in their collapse.

title: Pioneer Sees A Coach First And Foremost
description: Sylvester Croom arrived exactly on time for his news conference, if years late as the first African-American head football coach in the Southeastern Conference. He strode into a room packed with reporters and several hundred fans, hugged and kissed his mother, Louise, then sat down while the overflow crowd stood and cheered.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Airplane Strike Ends
description: Workers at Shorts, a subsidiary of the Canadian airplane manufacturer Bombardier, agreed to end a week-old strike after the company promised not to cut any jobs before next March and to change a new shift arrangement that pays less overtime. Shorts is Ulster's biggest manufacturing employer, and the walkout by nearly all its 4,500 workers was the company's first in 20 years. Its two major unions rejected a four-year deal last summer, and after that management said it would cut 1,000 jobs to remain competitive. Employees then said they deserved a better deal because Shorts had performed better than Bombardier's other operations. Workers will now reconsider the earlier offer. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: For Mideast, Blueprint or Illusion?
description: To the Editor:

title: Knock, Wait 15 Seconds, Then Break In, Justices Rule
description: The police need not wait more than 15 or 20 seconds after knocking before they break down a door to search a residence for drugs, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Tuesday.

title: Neighborly Interests
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: For Everybody, A Little Something
description: Small indulgences, small price tags.

title: For City Dwellers, Street-Smart Gifts
description: New York is an attitude. And when it comes to New Yorkers have lots of it.

title: Gifts for Greener Pastures
description: Some New Yorkers dream of more rural surroundings.

title: An 18-Hour Day
description: For a cadet football player at West Point, a typical day is rough yet rewarding.

title: Smart Toys for Kids
FirstEnergy to Invest More in '04 on Improvements
description: The FirstEnergy Corporation, the utility owner blamed for lapses that contributed to the blackout in the Northeast in August, said yesterday that it would increase capital spending on power lines by 36 percent, to $465 million next year to improve reliability. Computer systems and operator training also will be expanded, and the company will adopt a policy of zero tolerance for transmission-line failures caused by trees, the senior vice president for energy delivery, Charles Jones, said at an investor meeting in New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Morristown: Group Seeks Bear-Hunt Halt
description: An environmental group yesterday sought to prevent New Jersey's black-bear hunt, which is set to begin on Monday, from including state parks and forests. The group, Saving Our Resources Today, filed its motion in a state appeals court, arguing that hunting bear on those lands was illegal because the State Division of Parks and Forestry had given insufficient public notice. The group also said that the agency had failed to conduct a required environmental impact report. It was the second such legal challenge to the bear hunt, the first sanctioned hunt since 1970. On Monday, animal-welfare groups and others made similar arguments in federal court seeking to exclude a national park along the Delaware River from the hunt. The state's environmental commissioner, Bradley M. Campbell, said that the disputed land was only about 10 percent of the area open to hunters, and that any court action would have minimal impact on the hunt. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: In the Capital of the Car, Nature Stakes a Claim
description: PAUL WEERTZ lives less than 10 minutes from downtown, but the view from his window is anything but urban. On a warm day this fall, the air was ripe with the smell of fresh-cut hay and manure. In the alley behind his house, bales of hay teetered and listed where garbage cans once stood. Chickens scratched in the yard, near a garage that had been turned into a barn. Mr. Weertz drives a Ford -- not a sleek sedan but a rebuilt 1960 tractor.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article last Thursday about the rebroadcast of the November 1966 football game between Notre Dame and Michigan State misstated the comparison of the original broadcast's Nielsen ratings with those of the first Super Bowl, shown two months later. The Notre Dame-Michigan State game drew a 22.5 rating; the Super Bowl, which was shown on two networks, drew 40.8 -- 23.0 on CBS and 17.8 on NBC.

title: His Dream, to Be the Light at the End of the Israeli-Palestinian Tunnel
description: The faux-peace agreement between Israelis and Palestinians celebrated with much fanfare here on Monday might never have happened had it not been for an obscure Swiss academic -- and close to a million dollars from his father.

title: LUXURY IN A COLD CLIMATE: Brands turn on to senses
description: PARIS  The luxury world is awash with logos and powerful visual images. But for the 21st century, there is a revolution in store. Let's call it "emotional" branding, the use of scent, touch, sound and even taste in marketing.

title: Accountability; In Running Down Rogue Charges, Persistence Is Crucial
description: Vigilance in avoiding stealth inflation requires you (or someone else in your household) to act as an accounts payable department, looking over every bill, every month. Some companies will not correct an error if you catch it more than 90 days after the statement date.

title: Sudden Shift On Detainee
description: When the Pentagon said this week that it would let an American being held as an enemy combatant meet a lawyer, which it had refused to do for months, it appeared on the surface to be a major concession to the critics of the policy of detaining terrorism suspects.

title: Economic Scene; Are open markets threatened more by a pro-business or by an antibusiness ideology?
description: IN the good old days, your local bankers knew you. You saw them in person, and maybe played golf with them or attended the same church. They didn't need a credit report to decide whether to give you a loan. Your character wasn't reduced to a numerical score. Trust didn't require computers or background checks.

title: After Scandals, State Panel Offers Plan to Revamp Judges' Elections
description: An expert panel appointed by New York State's chief judge called yesterday for significant changes in the way judges across the state are elected, and proposed that lawyers be required to disclose in court any campaign contributions they have made to judges presiding over their cases.

title: Bush Set to Lift Tariffs on Steel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 3  The Bush administration plans to announce on Thursday that it will rescind tariffs it imposed last year on imported steel, administration and industry officials said on Wednesday. The administration will argue that the temporary trade protection allowed American steel makers to get themselves in shape to survive against intense global competition.

title: McDyess Adds Zest, But Knicks Drop Ball
description: Antonio McDyess was giving his teammates an infusion of energy Wednesday night in his second game back on the court. Suddenly, the Knicks were back in the game, trailing by 5 points to Seattle early in the fourth quarter.

title: Gifts for Greener Pastures
description: SOME New Yorkers dream of more rustic surroundings, regardless of where they live, be it a Central Park West penthouse or a basement studio in Greenwich Village. And there are gifts for them all, home accessories that suit the country soul, whether departing the town for a weekend or forever. These gifts can go both ways, adding a country touch for those who prefer to stay in the city. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: A Little New York, at Any Address
description: IF New York is an attitude, you don't have to live here to have it. You can have Bronx chutzpah in Boise as well as on the Grand Concourse. For those who live in Brooklyn Heights, Ohio, or Harlem, N.D., there are plenty of things for the home to help keep in touch with big city sights. With lamps and throw pillows decorated with photographs of New York landmarks and an inflatable model of Yankee Stadium, the big city is never far away. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: How Well Are We Doing?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Triple Crown Jockey's Grandson, Title for St. John's Will Do
description: Grandfathers have been known to sit with young grandsons and spin tales of youthful daring. Sometimes the stories are even true.

title: Stretching the Rainbow With New Paper and Inks
description: Pantone, the company whose color-matching system is the standard in industries from printing to design, is releasing a line of premium printer paper and inkjet cartridges that it says will be less expensive than replacements supplied by the printer makers.

title: A Harder Road to Irish Peace
description: Confrontational parties outpolled conciliatory ones on both sides of Northern Ireland's sectarian divide in provincial elections last week. In the largely Protestant unionist community, the Democratic Unionist Party, led by a fiery Protestant preacher, the Rev. Ian Paisley, triumphed over the more moderate Ulster Unionists. Among the mostly Catholic nationalists, Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, displaced the Social Democratic and Labor Party.

title: Breastfeeding Ads Delayed By a Dispute Over Content
description: Federal officials have softened a national advertising campaign to promote breastfeeding after complaints from two companies that make infant formula, according to several doctors and nurses who are helping the government with the effort.

title: With a Click and a Smile
description: Forums highlights, including readers' stories of online shopping – for cars and for love.

title: S.E.C. Proposes Rules to End Late Trading In Mutual Funds
description: Responding to an industry in crisis, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday proposed a new set of mutual fund regulations and announced an ambitious schedule to issue additional fund-trading and governance rules over the next two months.

title: Productive, but Tired
description: To the Editor:

title: Saudi Arsenal Is Found
description: A vast arsenal, including surface-to-air missiles, has been found in the hands of a suspect in the bombing of a residential compound in Riyadh on Nov. 8, which killed 17 people, the Saudi News Agency reported on Wednesday, quoting an Interior Ministry official.

title: Liberias Ex-Leader Is Put on Interpols Most Wanted List
description: The international police organization Interpol issued a notice today for the arrest of the former president of Liberia, Charles G. Taylor, who has been indicted on war crimes charges by a special tribunal in Sierra Leone.

title: National Briefing | Politics: Suit Over Dean's Sealed Records
description: A conservative watchdog group filed a lawsuit in Montpelier seeking access to sealed records from Howard Dean's 11-year tenure as governor of Vermont, arguing that he had improperly invoked executive privilege. The Washington group Judicial Watch contends that Dr. Dean pushed to keep the papers secret for 10 years because of his presidential ambitions. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: In Eastern Germany, the Auto Plant as Showplace
description: The largest construction project in Europe is rising on a windswept plain north of this eastern German trading city. Here, BMW is building a vast new assembly plant to produce the next generation of its perennially popular entry-level car, the 3-Series.

title: A Billionaire Wants to Be Moscow's Mayor
description: In a bulging metropolis peopled by the elite and the destitute, a billionaire businessman is waging a come-from-behind campaign for mayor. Running against a wildly popular incumbent, the challenger is calling for an end to corruption and saying he will run the city as a transparent business and end the chokehold of bureaucracy.

title: Ways to Coax Sound From Silent Audio Files
description: Q. I am repeatedly seeing a message that says Windows Media Player cannot play a file in a certain audio file format, even though it has played similar files before. What happened?

title: The Air We Breathe In Lower Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Armstead Sympathizes With Fassel's Situation
description: The Giants were going through the motions of their practice Wednesday, and it was probably looser than Jim Fassel would have liked. When a penalty on an offensive drill drew laughter from some players, Fassel barked, ''It ain't funny.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Grenade Attack Wounds 2 G.I.'S
description: In a bold daylight attack, a former Taliban fighter hurled a grenade at two American soldiers in central Kandahar, wounding the Americans. The attacker hurled another grenade at policemen pursuing him, wounding one before being captured. Afghan officials identified him as a former Taliban fighter from Helmand Province. The attack came a week before the United States is to establish a military reconstruction team in Kandahar to provide aid and to combat a slowly growing Taliban insurgency. David Rohde (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Politics: Dean Taps Web For Congressman
description: Howard Dean raised at least $50,000 for Representative Leonard L. Boswell, an Iowa Democrat, in a single day. Sending e-mail messages to more than 500,000 people, Dr. Dean tapped the small-donor base that had made him the best-financed Democrat in the presidential race. Glen Justice (NYT)

title: Europe's Vision of Unity Meets Headwinds
description: The grand, even historic vision shared by all of the 25 current and imminent members of the European Union is that the organization, begun as a simple customs union several decades ago, will move to ever higher levels of integration, able to forge common European positions on defense and foreign policy as well.

title: S.U.V.'s to Be Redesigned to Reduce Risk to Cars
description: The auto industry agreed on Wednesday to make design changes to sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks sold in the United States so they are less dangerous to the occupants of passenger cars.

title: How Hard Is It to Control the Vendors?
description: The clogged sidewalks of Manhattan this season offer an excellent example of how things don't get done in Albany. Herald Square is chockablock with peddlers. Canal Street is practically impassable on weekends, as is Fifth Avenue and most of Midtown. All over Manhattan, vendors selling T-shirts and pink Yankees hats crowd one another out of the busiest spots. Pedestrians have to detour into the traffic, never a path for long-term survival in New York City.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bombardier Job Cuts
description: The Canadian aircraft and railcar manufacturer Bombardier said that it would close some European plants and cut management jobs to improve the profitability of its rail unit. The company, based in Montreal, reported net income of 184.8 million Canadian dollars ($142 million) in the three months to Oct. 31, up from 181 million Canadian dollars a year earlier. Revenue fell 4 percent, to 4.7 billion Canadian dollars ($3.6 billion). The improved profit was attributed to the aerospace division, which benefited from cost cutting and the sale of a military flight services business. Earnings at the railcar unit declined 11 percent before interest and taxes. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column yesterday about feature films that will be in competition at the Sundance Film Festival next year misspelled the given name of the star of ''November.'' She is Courteney Cox Arquette, not Courtney.

title: For Little Fingers, an Array of Digital Tutors
description: BACK in the days of the first I.B.M. PC's or the Apple II, it was easy to find optimistic educators who dreamed of a golden age of learning in which smart interactive technologies would deliver top-rate instruction to schoolchildren.

title: Market Place; Governance Issues Raised on Sprint-Boeing Pact
description: After its top two executives resigned over their use of tax shelters early this year, the Sprint Corporation took several steps to create a stronger, more independent board. One move was naming Michael Sears, the chief financial officer of Boeing, to the board as an independent director.

title: Mock-Up Is Burned In Effort for Clues To Nightclub Fire
description: In a burning mock-up of the Rhode Island nightclub where 100 people were killed last February, fire and searing gases spread quickly from the stage across the ceiling and, within 70 seconds, caused nylon carpeting near the dance floor to burst into flame, federal investigators said here today.

title: For Everybody, a Little Something
description: 1. Egyptian glass candlesticks are $12, $14 and $18 at Anthropologie, www.anthropologie.com or (800) 309-2500.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERSHENSON, MILTON GABRIEL
description: GERSHENSON--Milton Gabriel. Professor of Law for 57 years at Brooklyn Law School. Beloved husband of Paula nee Dubson for 58 years. Adored father of Suzette A. Gray. Cherished grandfather of Colette S. Gray. Former Lieutenant Colonel U.S. Army retired, Judge Advocate General. Services private.

title: Metro Matters; Just a Few Miles, And Hours, From Home
description: THERE'S a saying in this business that news is what happens to an editor. Well, why not? News is also what happens to a writer, especially if the same thing is happening to thousands of others in this allegedly world-class city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDQUIST, WARREN T. ''LINDY''
description: LINDQUIST--Warren T. ''Lindy''. My dear friend Lindy Lindquist died November 15, 2003 at his home in Seal Harbor, ME. He was 84. From the time Lindy and I served together in Paris during WWII, he was my trusted associate in the fields of banking and urban affairs. As Executive Director of the Downtown Lower Manhattan Association, he helped conceive of the idea of the World Trade Center. He served as the first CEO of the New York City Community Preservation Corporation, played a key role in organizing Morningside Gardens, and in establishing the New York State Housing Finance Agency and the Urban Development Corporation. He served with distinction under President Reagan as the first General Manager of the New Community Development Corporation in the Department of Housing and Urban Development and as the first Assistant Secretary for Public and Indian Housing. He was a principal associate in the development of L'Enfant Plaza in Washington, and Embarcadero Center in San Francisco. I offer my most heartfelt sympathy to his wife Muriel, his ten children, twelve grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Lindy was a great person and a wonderful friend, who I will miss for the rest of my life. David Rockefeller, New York, N.Y.

title: Kerry Denounces 'Inept' Bush Foreign Policy
description: Senator John Kerry attacked President Bush yesterday for an ''arrogant, inept, reckless'' foreign policy and laid out a detailed plan for prosecuting the war on terrorism far differently while ''building bridges to the Islamic world.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POWELL, EDITH HARLAN
description: POWELL--Edith Harlan. On December 2, 2003. Beloved mother of Edith De Montebello. Also survived by four stepchildren and three grandchildren. Funeral private.

title: When Technology Is Heartwarming
description: Itook last Thursday off from writing this column, and you took last Thursday off from reading it. But I have a Thanksgiving thought to share, even though it's about something that happened two weeks ago.

title: LUXURY IN A COLD CLIMATE: Off-Bond Street jewelers
description: LONDON  Bond Street has never had it so good as host to London's finest jewelers. In addition to Cartier, Graff, Tiffany, Bulgari, Chanel Fine Jewellery and David Morris, London has been given extra sparkle by a new generation of designers: Jade Jagger at Garrard, Solange Azagury-Partridge at Boucheron and Reema Pachachi at DeBeers. The imminent comeback of Asprey and the survival of Wartski and Bentley & Skinner ensure that important historical jewel houses retain their prominence.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: $2 Billion Bond Set For Durst
description: A Galveston, Tex., jury may have acquitted Robert A. Durst last month of murdering his neighbor, but that does not mean that the authorities are eager to let go of the New York real estate heir. Yesterday, Judge Susan Criss set a bond of $2 billion on Mr. Durst's remaining charges of bail jumping. Lawyers on both sides said they had not heard of a higher bond anywhere in the country. Mr. Durst would face up to 10 years in prison if convicted. He has acknowledged fleeing in October 2001, after he was originally arrested and released on $300,000 bail. ''The biggest problem with bond for him is the risk of flight because he's never not flown,'' Judge Criss said yesterday. Mr. Durst's lawyers vowed to appeal. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Linen Supplier Pleads Guilty In Conspiracy To Fix Prices
description: The president of a Westchester County company pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy in connection with a continuing investigation into price fixing in the linen supply business.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BARR LABORATORIES INC., Pomona, N.Y., the third-largest maker of birth-control pills in the United States, said it had agreed to buy almost all of the assets of Endeavor Pharmaceuticals for about $35 million.

title: Lucent Is Paying Workers Cash Bonus
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it plans to pay a bonus to all its workers for the first time since 1999 after the company returned to profit and met other financial goals. Cash bonuses will be paid to about 35,000 Lucent workers on Dec. 12, a spokeswoman, Kathleen Fitzgerald, said. She declined to say how much the bonuses would cost Lucent, the nation's largest maker of telephone equipment. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., returned to profit earlier than forecast by its chief executive, Patricia F. Russo, who received a 37 percent pay raise this year.

title: Kerry on the Mideast
description: Senator John Kerry accused President Bush of having an ''arrogant, inept, reckless'' foreign policy and laid out a detailed plan for fighting terrorism while ''building bridges to the Islamic world.'' Mr. Kerry, a Democratic presidential candidate from Massachusetts, also said the administration was considering a ''cut and run strategy'' in Iraq that would speed up the withdrawal of troops to win votes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEAVER, WILLIAM M., JR.
description: WEAVER--William M., Jr., of New York City, died on November 28, 2003 at the age of 91. He is survived by his wife, Rosemary, and four daughters, Marcia Campbell and Patricia Wurts, both of Philadelphia, PA, Wendy Chaix of New York City, and Alison Weaver of Easton, CT; six grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Saint Bartholomew's Church, 50th Street and Park Avenue, New York, NY on Tuesday, December 9, 2003 at 4pm.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Wireless Sells Stake In BPL
description: AT&T Wireless Services, the nation's third-largest cellphone company, sold its 49 percent stake in India's BPL Mobile Cellular to the BPL Mobile Group. Terms were not disclosed. AT&T Wireless and its predecessors invested more than $150 million in BPL Mobile Cellular in the last six years, the company, based in Bangalore, India, said yesterday. AT&T Wireless said it had sold the stake as part of its strategy to focus on the North American market. The acquisition makes BPL Mobile Cellular a wholly owned unit of the BPL Mobile Group. It gives the group freedom to seek investment to improve its services in India, said the chief executive, Sandip Basu.

title: Jets' Pass Rushers Hoping To Put Bills Under Pressure
description: Bryan Thomas stood on his stool in the Jets' locker room after practice Wednesday, holding up his defensive-player-of-the-game plaque from the Jets' victory two weeks ago over Jacksonville.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Seeking Restroom Parity
description: City Council members proposed a bill yesterday intended to reduce long restroom lines for women by requiring theaters, stadiums, meeting halls and other public venues to provide two women's restrooms for every one for men. The legislation, named the Restroom Equity Bill, would require newly constructed or renovated public buildings to adhere to the 2-to-1 ratio, and existing buildings to redesignate restrooms whenever possible. Councilwoman Yvette D. Clarke said, ''Whether at a concert venue or a movie theater, women are routinely inconvenienced by the insufficient number of restroom facilities available to them.'' Similar legislation has been adopted in at least a dozen states, city officials said. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Reducing Traffic Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Charged With Illegal Drug Sales Online
description: Federal prosecutors have indicted 10 people and 3 companies that they say made $125 million from illegally selling controlled substances over the Internet.

title: For City Dwellers, Street-Smart Gifts With an Edge of Luxe
description: NEW YORK is an attitude. And when it comes to shopping, New Yorkers have lots of it. They know what they want, and what they want is often what other people don't have or can't find. For example, for many years decorators and designers have drawn from a cache of wallpapers hand-painted in Jaipur, India; now these papers are being digitally reproduced in Paris and can be ordered online -- if you know where. And what young girl wouldn't want to be seen in Central Park, riding on a replica of a pink 1936 tricycle?

title: Merrill Will Reimburse Fund Buyers $11 Million
description: Merrill Lynch, the nation's largest brokerage firm, plans to make amends for overcharging buyers of mutual funds by reimbursing about $11 million to them before the end of the year, people at the firm said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCPARTLAND, ANTHONY
description: McPARTLAND--Anthony, on December 1, 2003, after a long illness. Son of Rose Lally McPartland and brother of Mary Ann, Eugene, James and Pamela. A wake will be held on December 4 from 3-5 and 7-9PM at Castle Hill Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Avenue, Bronx, New York. The funeral service will be on December 5 at 12 noon at St. Philip Church, Norwalk, CT. 06851. Contributions in memory of Tony may be sent to St. Philip Church.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Interest Rate Rises
description: The Reserve Bank of Australia increased its benchmark interest rate by 0.25 percent, to 5.25 percent, the second increase in a month. Analysts said the central bank's action reflected its concern about the inflationary risks of a three-year boom in housing loans, starts and prices fueled by historically low mortgage rates. The country's annual rate of economic growth is 2.6 percent. John Shaw (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Politics: Edwards Would Restrict Lobbyists
description: Senator John Edwards of North Carolina proposed prohibiting registered lobbyists from donating to the campaigns of members of Congress and the president and called for a ban on lobbyists taking jobs in the administration related to their field for at least a year after leaving their companies. Top administration officials, Mr. Edwards said, should be barred from lobbying for at least five years after leaving office. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: So, You Were Expecting a Pigeon?; In City Bustle, Herons, Egrets and Ibises Find a Sanctuary
description: The spot was in the heart of an urban bedlam, surrounded by the hurtling traffic of the Triborough Bridge, the smokestacks of Con Edison, the grim warrens of Rikers Island, the roar of La Guardia jets and three sewage treatment plants.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Airline Replaces Routes
description: Ryanair, the low-budget Irish airline, will replace nine of its routes from Stansted Airport in London and its hubs outside Stockholm, Frankfurt and Brussels, with alternative destinations because of insufficient customer demand. The chief executive, Michael O'Leary, warned last month that such changes were likely. In a statement, Mr. O'Leary said that a new route to Valladolid in Spain would bring 400,000 additional passengers through the government-owned Charleroi Airport near Brussels, where Ryanair pays discounted landing charges that are subject to an investigation by the European Commission. In another case heard by the Irish Supreme Court, Ryanair won the right to see documents owned by the government-owned airport authority, Aer Rianta, which Ryanair says gave it unfavorable treatment in allocating space at check-in desks and in baggage carousels. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Colorado's New Voucher Law Is Struck Down in State Court
description: A Denver judge struck down Colorado's new school voucher law yesterday, ruling that it violated the state's Constitution by stripping local school boards of their control over education.

title: Birmingham Journal; Britain's No. 2 City Gets Respect (After All These Years)
description: It has long been fashionable to scorn Birmingham, the second city of Britain.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toyota To Investigate Leak
description: Fujio Cho, the president of Toyota Motor, left, said the company would investigate why vehicle inspectors at its dealerships obtained in advance questions for a national licensing examination. In apologizing, Mr. Cho said three employees were involved and the company would install preventive measures. The government said Toyota employees obtained the questions before the exam and made them available to mechanics who were trying to win special certification. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Election Scandals, Past and Future
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Stock Offer Withdrawn
description: Dometic International, a Swedish refrigerator maker owned by the Wallenberg family's buyout firm, scrapped a 4.3 billion kronor ($580 million) initial public offering that would have been Sweden's first in 18 months. ''At the end of the day it turned out to be a price issue,'' said Haakan Johansson, a partner at the Stockholm-based EQT Partners, the buyout firm of the Wallenbergs' Investor AB. Dometic had offered to sell the shares at 190 kronor to 240 kronor each, valuing the company at as much as 7.4 billion kronor.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 441 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAGOV, DUNJA
description: SAGOV--Dunja. Our beloved Dunja, who left so soon. We'll miss her always. Rest in peace. Memorial service Saturday, December 6th at 680 West End Avenue, 2:30PM

title: U.S. Pressing Industry On Technology Security
description: Federal officials made clear Wednesday that private industry must make progress in voluntarily complying with the Bush administration's national cybersecurity plan or face new legislation requiring compliance.

title: On Eve of Trade Talks, Group Reports Salvador Labor Abuses
description: A study by a prominent human rights organization has found widespread abuse of labor rights in El Salvador just as final negotiations are to begin for that country and four Central American neighbors to create a free trade agreement with the United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 23 about unrelated incidents of violence the previous weekend gave an incorrect address from the police for the fatal shooting of an unidentified man on a Queens street. It was at 62-05 30th Avenue in Woodside, not 82-05 30th Avenue in Astoria.

title: Inventing Her Life As She Goes Along
description: Of all the peculiar entries in the Broadway derby this fall, perhaps the most peculiar is Doug Wright's fascinating one-actor play starring Jefferson Mays, ''I Am My Own Wife.'' A critical success in its limited run earlier this year Off Broadway at Playwrights Horizons, it has now moved to the Lyceum Theater, where it opened last night amid all kinds of doubts that such a work might find enough of a mainstream audience to sustain it.

title: Election Scandals, Past and Future (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alcatel To Cut Jobs
description: Alcatel, the world's biggest maker of broadband Internet equipment, said it would cut 470 jobs in France at its fixed-line communications and optical systems units and redeploy 900 others in 2004. Jobs will be cut at units at which demand has declined, the company said. Alcatel CIT, which employs 7,600 people, will offer early retirement to employees who volunteer. The company, which is based in Paris, said it would reorganize its teams so that more people work on the mobile unit where demand is growing.

title: Gift Aims To Keep Met Opera On the Air
description: The Annenberg Foundation has given $3.5 million to the Metropolitan Opera to help keep its treasured Saturday afternoon live radio broadcasts on the air next season, the opera company said yesterday. The money, it said, is the largest gift ever made to the Met's annual-giving fund.

title: Spare Change? Good. Old Miles? Better.
description: ONE day last week my three daughters searched the house as methodically -- and as stealthily -- as pirates who had unearthed an ancient treasure map.

title: Duke Routs Michigan St. In Less Than Big Game
description: In a place where Michigan State usually makes its opponents do so many things wrong, Duke did almost everything right Wednesday night.

title: Remembering 'Nutcracker' Ballets Past; An Onstage Reunion for a Half Century of Mice, Toys, Fairies and Princes
description: The Christmas tree in the first New York City Ballet production of ''The Nutcracker'' threatened to catch fire at any moment from the sparking, smoking bulbs that simulated candles. The production cost twice as much as its allocated budget of $40,000. The costumes were still being sewn three hours before opening night.

title: Blazers Trade Wells
description: The Portland Trail Blazers traded Bonzi Wells to the Memphis Grizzlies yesterday for Wesley Person and a conditional first-round choice in the 2004 draft. But this trade was less about what they received than what they sent away. Although Wells has averaged 13.3 points and 4.7 rebounds in his six-year career, he was suspended last month for cursing his coach during a game and fined for making an obscene gesture at a fan at the Rose Garden. As a result, he was stripped of his captaincy.

title: Profits Fall for Big Board's Market Makers
description: The combined profit of market makers at the New York Stock Exchange dropped 66 percent in the third quarter as the Big Board and the Securities and Exchange Commission investigated whether the firms traded at the expense of their customers.

title: Giving 100 Percent, Just Like His All-Star Patient
description: DR. GERALD APPEL shows a framed photograph of himself with Alonzo Mourning, the N.B.A. All-Star who was forced to say goodbye to the Nets and professional basketball because of a chronic kidney disease. A smiling Dr. Appel stands, all of 5-foot-6, while Mr. Mourning hovers at 6-foot-10.

title: Corrections

title: Boeing Lags In Building Spy Satellites

He served the Society as President, 1973-1977, Chairman, 1977-1978, and Honorary Life Director. In February 2000 the Society honored Mr. Brown for a lifetime of extraordinary service and achievement, and announced that its Information Resource Center would bear his name, due to his many years as an advocate for the timely and widespread dissemination of information about MS. Mr. Brown was President Emeritus of L. P. Brown & Co. in Memphis, TN, was praised as one of Memphis' strongest community pillars for much of the past century, and was named Outstanding Citizen of Memphis in 1960. Mr. Brown is survived by a daughter, Axson B. Morgan, a sister, Kathryn B. Butler, and four grandchildren. The family requests that memorials be sent to the Church Health Center, the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, Rhodes College, St. John's United Methodist Church, or charity of choice. Edward A. Kangas Chairman of the Board Mike Dugan President and CEO

title: A Meteoric View of Life
description: One of the great advantages of being short-lived by geological standards is that life seems relatively stable to us. In the span of time that we humans have been fully ourselves as a species -- the oldest human fossils are only 160,000 years old -- life on this planet has gone on essentially uninterrupted, no matter how cataclysmic our own history has been. We live in the midst of one of the great extinctions, largely caused by humans, and yet we've experienced nothing like the meteor that crashed into the earth 65 million years ago and destroyed the dinosaurs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINDMULLER, JOHN PHILIP
description: WINDMULLER--John Philip. The Martin P. Catherwood Professor of Industrial and Labor Relations Emeritus at Cornell University, died on December 2, 2003 at Kendal in Ithaca, NY following a long illness. John Windmuller was born on December 4, 1923 in Dortmund, Germany, son of Solomon and Bertha (nee Kahn) Windmuller. He left Germany on a children's transport in December 1938 after having been held for four days by the Gestapo. He was a passenger on the ill-fated voyage of the St. Louis and came to the United States in 1942. He served in the U.S. Army from 1943 to 1946, was active in postwar relief work on behalf of children in war-devastated European countries, and graduated with a B.A. degree from the University of Illinois in 1948. He then undertook graduate work in the School of Industrial and Labor Relations at Cornell University, receiving a doctoral degree in 1951 when he was appointed to the Cornell faculty. In 1983 he became the first holder of the Martin P. Catherwood Chair in Industrial and Labor Relations, and in 1987 he was named Professor-emeritus. He continued to teach for several years after his retirement. As a teacher, he had the satisfaction of seeing several of his students embark on careers in international industrial relations. Throughout his academic career Professor Windmuller was actively engaged in research, usually on subjects with a significant international or comparative aspect. He took a special interest in the operation of labor organizations, employers associations and collective bargaining systems. He also served on several editorial boards of academic journals and the Cornell University Press. For a book on Labor Relations in the Netherlands (1969) the Dutch government awarded him a medal. For many years, Professor Windmuller contributed to the development of international programs and activities in Cornell's School of Industrial and Labor Relations, and from 1961 to 1964 he served as its Director of International Activities. He also served as Associate Dean of the School from 1975 to 1977. On two occasions he held senior positions in the International Labor Organization in Geneva, Switzerland, chiefly to prepare a study of Collective Bargaining in Industrialized Market Economies. John Windmuller is survived by Ruth, his wife of 56 years; a daughter Betsey Roberts (Neil) of Los Angeles; a son, Thomas (Cathy Overly) of Geneva, Switzerland; and a grandson (Jonathan) also of Geneva.

description: MURPHY -- George Arthur, age 97, former Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of the Irving Trust Company (now the Bank of New York) and former Chairman of the Board of NYU, died December 2, 2003 at his home in Washington, CT. His banking career spanned 39 years as a corporate director in New York banking and business institutions. His business institutional service included the presidency of the New York State Banker's Association, the chairmanship of the Better Business Bureau of New York, the presidency of the Advisory Council of the Federal Reserve system and the management, and ultimately the chairmanship of the multi-billion dollar UN Pension Fund. He was a former Chairman and Life Trustee of the New York University Board of Trustees. In his retirement, he was an inspirational leader at St. John's Episcopal Church and the Steep Rock Land Trust in Washington, CT. Mr. Murphy is survived by his wife, Ruth Bybee Murphy of Indianapolis, IN, two daughters, Louise M. Johnson of Concord, MA and Jean M. Smith of Cambridge, MA, two sons-in-law, seven grandchildren, and five great grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, December 19, 2003 at 11:00 a.m. at St. John's Episcopal Church, Washington, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Mr. Murphy's memory may be made to St. John's Episcopal Church, PO Box 1278, Washington, CT 06793 or to the Steep Rock Association, Inc., PO Box 279, Washington Depot, CT 06794

description: Annual percentage yields, in percent, on money market accounts, three-month certificates of deposit and six-month C.D.'s expected at selected institutions on Wednesday, December 3, 2003. Yields are based on the method of compounding the interest rate stated for the lowest minimum to open an account, but minimums may vary. Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only. Rates subject to change without notice.

title: Study Suggests Switching Drugs Could Aid Breast Cancer Patients
description: In a study comparing two drugs designed to prevent a recurrence of breast cancer, women who switched from the standard drug tamoxifen to a newer type of treatment fared better than those who continued to take tamoxifen.

title: Hot-Shooting Rutgers Beats Temple Again
description: Temple Coach John Chaney's famed matchup zone has confused and befuddled far better teams than Rutgers over the years, but there remains one sure-fire way to defeat the Owls and their zone: shoot the lights out, particularly from behind the 3-point line.

title: Preschool Teacher in Queens Is Shot to Death
description: A popular nursery school teacher described as a mother to her Queens neighborhood was shot repeatedly and killed yesterday morning just after opening her school in Richmond Hill.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Collegiate School Departure
description: The headmaster of the Collegiate School, the boys' school on the Upper West Side, has announced that he will leave next summer to become headmaster of Roxbury Latin School in West Roxbury, Mass. The headmaster, Kerry P. Brennan, 48, is in his fourth year at Collegiate. In a message posted on Tuesday on the Roxbury Latin School Web site, the president of the school's board of trustees, Harry R. Lewis, explained that Mr. Brennan had started his teaching career at Roxbury Latin, ''so his return here is a homecoming.'' In a letter sent on Monday to parents of current Collegiate students and to alumni, Mr. Brennan wrote that he would not have left Collegiate for any other role or any other school, but that ''Roxbury Latin occupies a special corner of my heart.'' Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Pushing For Capital Punishment
description: Gov. Tim Pawlenty, citing the arrest of a sex offender in the disappearance of a college student in North Dakota, said he would call for the return of the death penalty. Minnesota abolished capital punishment more than 90 years ago. Alfonso Rodriguez Jr., 50, of Pequot Lakes, was charged on Monday with kidnapping Dru Sjodin, a student at the University of North Dakota. She has not been found. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: City Campaign Finance Board Irks Mayor With Proposals
description: The Campaign Finance Board proposed a major package of changes yesterday that included at least one aimed at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, immediately drawing harsh words from him and setting off a round of partisan sniping in and out of City Hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAURA, ERIN S.
description: LAURA--Erin S. The Browning School mourns the loss of Erin S. Laura, Class of 1994, who died December 1st after a long illness. Visitation Thursday and Friday, 6-8PM at Metropolitan Funeral Home, 191 Avenue A (11th St.). Funeral will be Saturday, 10 AM at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, 14th St between 1st and Avenue A.

title: Amid Muck, Officials Seek Answers in Oil Spill at Coney Island Peninsula
description: Men in buoyant insulated jumpsuits laid barriers over the boulders and sand along the Coney Island peninsula yesterday as federal investigators sought to assign responsibility for an oil spill in New York Bay.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Solectron To Sell Businesses
description: The Solectron Corporation, which makes electronics for other companies, is selling seven or eight businesses under a plan started this year as the company seeks to return to profitability. The divestitures will be completed by the end of the 2004 fiscal year, the treasurer, Perry Hayes, said yesterday. Solectron, based in Milpitas, Calif., sold or closed four businesses in the quarter ended in August and said it would sell its Dy 4 unit for $110 million to the Curtiss-Wright Corporation. Solectron, which is forecast to report an 11th straight quarterly net loss this month, expects proceeds of $500 million to $600 million from the sales, the chief executive, Michael Cannon, has said. Shares of Solectron rose 8 cents, to $5.73.

title: Times Square Jam
description: To the Editor:

title: $2.85 Billion for 3 Transit Sites, With Strings
description: Substituting discreet electronic transfers for the poster-size checks that politicians like to hand out whenever cameras are near, the federal Transportation Department sent New York State $1.15 billion yesterday for two Lower Manhattan projects.

title: The 6-Month Makeover, 36 Years Later
description: WHEN Clem and Claire Labine bought an 1883 brownstone on Berkeley Place in Park Slope in 1967, they had no idea that the renovation would create a new career for Mr. Labine (who founded Old House Journal), nor that they would carry out one of the longest-running brownstone restorations in Brooklyn.

title: LUXURY IN A COLD CLIMATE: In Italy, paying cost of past ambitions
description: MILAN  The difficult financial situation of some Italian luxury-goods groups has highlighted how the boom at the end of the '90's led to excessive ambition, optimism and, most of all, a mountain of debt.

title: On the Other End of the Phone, Workers Stripped of Their Identities
description: Silent movies always make me envy the thrill audiences have when form is new. The Georges Mlis spectacles in which everything -- cabinets, teapots, planets in the galaxy -- had a life of its own. The dark, ruthless machines of ''Metropolis.'' The acting of great performers -- Buster Keaton, Harold Lloyd, Mary Pickford, Clara Bow -- that makes each gesture true to life but the whole bigger than life.

title: Head Out (Wirelessly) on the Highway
description: LIKE many business travelers, Lance Tindall enjoys using the wireless technology called Wi-Fi to connect to the Internet when he is on the road. But Mr. Tindall, who works for Crete Carrier of Lincoln, Neb., does not travel with a briefcase. Nor does he log on from an airport lounge. Parked at a truck stop, he browses the Internet from his 18-wheeler.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: And Usually, They Are So Straight With Us

title: Top Editor Returns To Random
description: Phyllis Grann, who oversaw a virtual assembly line of blockbuster books as chief executive of Penguin Putnam but later lasted just six months as the vice chairwoman of Random House Inc., is returning to Random House in a new capacity.

title: Katharine Sergava, the Star Of 'Oklahoma!' Ballet, Dies
description: Katharine Sergava, the dancer and actress who portrayed the dream-ballet version of Laurey, the heroine, in the original production of ''Oklahoma!,'' died on Nov. 11 in Palm Springs, Calif., where she had settled in the mid-1960's.

title: Absence of Formal Charges Against Michael Jackson May Point to a Weakening of the Case
description: Two weeks after the arrest of Michael Jackson on felony child molesting charges, the case against him may have hit some snags.

title: Fun Stirs At Resorts Without Snowfalls
description: It is not easy being the mythical Norse god of winter. Among other things, try as you might through the centuries, you can't be everywhere.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: MINNESOTA: PUSHING FOR CAPITAL PUNISHMENT Gov. Tim Pawlenty, citing the arrest of a sex offender in the disappearance of a college student in North Dakota, said he would call for the return of the death penalty. Minnesota abolished capital punishment more than 90 years ago. Alfonso Rodriguez Jr., 50, of Pequot Lakes, was charged on Monday with kidnapping Dru Sjodin, a student at the University of North Dakota. She has not been found. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Neiman Marcus Profit Up
description: The Neiman Marcus Group said yesterday that first-quarter profit almost doubled and sales showed their best increase in three years as shoppers bought more designer handbags, dresses and jewelry.

title: With Much Blame to Go Around, Nets Point at the Game Officials
description: For the past month, the Nets have berated themselves for every rebound they could not gather, every open shot they could not make and every game they could not win.

title: Bid to Limit Ferry Liability Hits Raw Nerve
description: The city's decision this week to try to invoke an obscure, century-old maritime law to cap the amount of damages for which it is liable in the Staten Island ferry disaster is a striking example of City Hall's effort to change the way it pays damages. The move reflects a broader effort by the Bloomberg administration to blunt the rising cost of settlements and judgments in liability cases, which last year alone cost the city $500 million.

title: Microsoft Eases Policy on Licensing Its Technology
description: Microsoft announced yesterday that it would adopt a more liberal policy for licensing its intellectual property, opening the doors to its storehouse of patents and copyrights to outsiders.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the arrest of two men in connection with a fatal shooting last week on a subway platform in Far Rockaway, Queens, gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the given name of the victim. He was Shamel Garrett, not Shamal. A picture caption gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a cousin of the victim. He is Levar Jiggetts, not Jiggets.

title: Bishop Criticized for Letting Suspended Monsignor Say Masses
description: A group of Roman Catholics on Long Island is criticizing their bishop for allowing a few Masses to be celebrated by a former high church official who was suspended from the ministry because of child-molestation complaints.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAREL, EZRA
description: HAREL--Ezra. To the Ezra Harel Family: May the love of friends and family be a source of comfort to you. Our deepest sympathy. The Law Firm of McLaughlin & Stern, LLP

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Flat Panel Fallout
description: The country's second-largest electronics maker, LG Electronics, plans to take a 380 billion won ($318 million) charge as consumers abandon cathode-ray tube televisions and computer monitors for flat-panel models. The fourth-quarter charge will be taken by its LG Philips displays unit, the world's largest cathode-ray tube maker, to reflect a sudden decline in demand, LG Electronics said. The company, which is based in Seoul, has been closing cathode-ray tube plants and channeling investment to production of liquid crystal displays.
