description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DESANTO, ANNE MCALLISTER
description: DeSANTO--Anne McAllister. On November 30, 2003 at age 99. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Ernest Paul DeSanto. Twenty year volunteer at Roosevelt Hospital and longtime member of the Colony Club. Memorial service at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71 Street Thursday December 4th, 1PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Roosevelt Hospital Volunteer committee.

title: Offspring of Genius
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Rejects Iraqi Plan To Hold Census by Summer
description: Iraqi census officials devised a detailed plan to count the country's entire population next summer and prepare a voter roll that would open the way to national elections in September. But American officials say they rejected the idea, and the Iraqi Governing Council members say they never saw the plan to consider it.

title: If Geology Is Destiny, Then Russia Is in Trouble
description: Russia's future will be defined as much by geology as by ideology. Unfortunately, while leaders can pick their ideology, they don't have much of a choice when it comes to geology.

title: Rich in Oil, Poor in Everything Else; Making Sure The Money Goes Where It's Supposed To
description: America has always lusted after a secure energy supply. Against a background of deteriorating relations with the Arab world, which holds the largest oil reserves, the United States is casting about for new sources of oil in countries like Venezuela, Nigeria, So Tom and Azerbaijan. With Saddam Hussein gone, Iraq could also become a major supplier.

title: Chinese Officers Say Taiwan's Leaders Are Near 'Abyss of War'
description: Chinese military officers said Wednesday that Taiwan's leadership had pushed the island toward an ''abyss of war'' with its talk of independence. They made it clear that China would consider a popular vote on Taiwan's political status -- which a faction of Taiwan's governing party recently urged -- as a cause for war.

title: Experiments in Jazz-Inspired Tangles, Some Only a Minute Long
description: Jazz dance may be an acquired taste. But there was an off-putting sameness to the repertory and performing by Les Ballets jazz de Montral on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. The dancers are terrific, with lithe bodies, appealing verve and pleasantly distinctive presences. But that came through only in Mia Michaels's piquant ''No Strings Attached,'' a company staple danced to music by Albert Sterling Menendez, and in several episodes from Crystal Pite's ''Short Works:24,'' a gimmicky, generally repetitive suite of 24 one-minute dances set to music by Owen Belton.

title: Mets, in Shift, Bid for Infielder Matsui
description: Earlier this week, the Mets were dropping hints that they would be taking a modest approach to this year's free-agent market. But now they have turned bold, making a multiyear contract offer to the Japanese infielder Kazuo Matsui and assuring him that he would be the team's starting shortstop, with Jos Reyes moving to second base to accommodate him.

title: With Oil Prices High, OPEC Is Ready to Defer Supply Cut
description: Delegates to a gathering here of OPEC nations signaled on Wednesday that they might consider reducing oil production again by early next year, even though they did not see much justification for an immediate cut in light of current demand and prices.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actor Art Carney on Nov. 12 listed four film credits erroneously. Mr. Carney did not appear in ''The Greatest Show on Earth,'' ''The Silencers,'' ''Gambit'' or ''The Venetian Affair.'' Those listings, as well as mistaken television credits corrected in this space on Nov. 18, came from an unrelated entry that adjoined his in a biographical reference.

title: Academics and Athletics, Army's Way
description: It was two minutes past 8 in the morning when Rob Davis, a sophomore Army football player, put down his pencil next to his physics exam. The test had asked him, for bonus points, to calculate the terminal speed of an object of a certain mass and cross-sectional area moving through a precise fluid of density due to a constant force of a specific magnitude.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: 2 Reports Indicate Recovery Is Taking Hold
description: The growing American economy has produced two statistics reinforcing the impression that a typical recovery is finally taking hold two years after the last recession.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Xerox To Dismiss 800 More
description: Xerox said yesterday that it would lay off about 800 more employees in the next 10 days, or 2.2 percent of its work force in the United States, to reduce costs after 14 consecutive quarters of declining sales. About 200 of the workers are in the Rochester region, a company spokeswoman, Christa Carone, said. They include engineering, administrative and clerical employees, she said. Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., had 36,700 employees in the United States and 62,800 workers worldwide at the end of September. The chief executive, Anne M. Mulcahy, has spent about $1.1 billion since 2001 to cut costs. That included the elimination of about 20,500 jobs, Ms. Carone said. Xerox shares rose 21 cents, to $12.21.

title: Record Label Drops Murder, Keeps Inc.
description: The hip-hop record label Murder Inc., saddled by a federal investigation and a volatile public feud between two leading rappers, is looking to clean up its image. The label's founder, Irv Gotti, said at a news conference yesterday that the company was dropping murder from its name.

title: Testing Expert to Leave Post At Turbulent Time for Regents
description: Gerald E. DeMauro, the testing expert in charge of developing and administering the New York State Regents exams, is leaving his post, just as the state is trying to stabilize the testing program after significant scoring problems.

title: INSIDE
description: Boeing Lags in Satellite Deal

title: Choreography That Comes With a Voice
description: Kenneth King's dance performance at St. Mark's Church on Tuesday night eventually became a book signing. During the metamorphosis, words danced and movements seemed kinetic messages. The event was tied to Mr. King's book, ''Writing in Motion: Body-Language-Technology,'' which has just been published by Wesleyan University Press.

title: It Did Happen Here: The Lynching That a City Forgot
description: On an afternoon when a howling wind and early dusk gave promise of the northern Minnesota winter to come, two yellow buses pulled up to an empty downtown intersection and a swarm of bundled seventh and eighth graders poured out.

title: Catching Up On the Classics? Bring Tissues.
description: MY wife and I are victims of Netflix, and it is our own fault.

title: Court Casts Doubt on Parts of Antiterrorism Law
description: A federal appeals court panel ruled on Wednesday that crucial parts of an antiterrorism law were unconstitutional because the law, which the Bush administration relies on heavily, risks ensnaring innocent humanitarians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENHAUS, LAWRENCE R.
description: GREENHAUS--Lawrence R. Age 83, died peacefully in Doylestown, Pa., December 3. He was a retired Vice President of Joy Mfg Company. He is loved and mourned by his wife of 56 years Gwen Davies, by sons James and Michael, daughter Jody, and grandchildren Matthew, Jeffrey, Samantha and Vanessa.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the World Health Organization's plan to begin delivering antiretroviral drugs to three million AIDS patients by the end of 2005 misidentified a drug in two of the agency's recommended combinations for treatment. It is nevirapine, not nelfinavir.

title: The Silicon-Paved Road to No. 1
description: THIS weekend will mark the end of the regular season in college football, and barring upsets of the top-ranked teams, there will be a tight race for the No. 2 spot in the nation.

title: Indias Leading Hindu Party Makes Gains in State
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 4  The Hindu nationalist party that leads India's coalition government won three out of four key state elections held on Monday, according to vote totals that were released today.

title: With Roadside Data, Better Forecast for Snow Removal
description: IOWA, like many states, once had a system for dispatching highway snowplows and salt trucks that had an obvious shortcoming.

title: Pound Won't Call Payments Bribes
description: Dick Pound of Canada, an International Olympic Committee member for the last quarter-century, said yesterday that he would not apply the term ''bribes'' to the payments made by the indicted Olympic bid leaders Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson to I.O.C. members before the selection of Salt Lake City to stage the 2002 Olympic Winter Games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENRY, MIRIAM GLICKSMAN
description: HENRY--Miriam Glicksman, of Boca Raton, FL and formerly White Plains, NY, died at age 85. Wife of the late Alan Henry. Survived by her son, Richard Henry, daughter, Jill Viuker and five loving grandchildren, Tim, Claire, Matthew, Alex and Jordana.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Automakers to Redesign S.U.V.'s and Trucks

title: The Far-From-Perfect Red Storm Puts Jarvis's Future in Jeopardy
description: After the final buzzer had mercifully sounded, Mike Jarvis called it awful. He could have called Tuesday's 81-64 loss to Hofstra embarrassing or devastating. He could have mentioned how the game's bad taste had 4,164 fans stewing inside the building before they left in disgust. It really didn't matter how he described the game, because the play on the court left nothing unsaid.

title: European Court Overturns Antitrust Ruling Against VW
description: Europe's second-highest court has overturned a 2001 decision by the European Commission to fine Volkswagen for price fixing, a ruling that is expected to complicate antitrust cases in Europe.

title: Times Square Jam
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about the 113th birthday of Fred Hale Sr., who is regarded as the oldest man in the United States, misidentified the great-great-granddaughter who helped blow out the candles. She is Claire Vredenburg; her sister Cara was in the background, on the lap of Jerry Vredenburg, their grandfather.

title: Put Your Life on the Record, 30 Seconds at a Time
description: If you yearn to videotape whatever you look at, now you have a new option -- provided you are willing to put up with a camera clipped to your eyeglasses or the brim of your baseball cap.

title: Coroner in Cincinnati Rules Man's Struggle Led to Death
description: Nathaniel Jones, a black man whose death in police custody has incited new racial tensions here, died primarily because of his violent struggle with the police, a coroner said on Wednesday. But he cautioned that his ruling did not imply wrongdoing or excessive use of force by the police.

title: A Karaoke Assist For the Budding Top 40 Star
description: If you can tolerate the idea of your young children singing ''Bibbidi-Bobbidi-Boo'' over and over in a questionable key, you might want to buy them a Disney Karaoke Microphone.

title: Yankees Get Vazquez From Expos for Johnson, Two Others
description: To the Yankees, armed with cash and riddled with pitching questions, the decision was easy. They had a chance to trade a 25-year-old first baseman for a 27-year-old starting pitcher, and they did not pass it up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASER, LEON
description: GLASER -- Leon. DOROT mourns the loss of our visionary friend at the J.E. and Z.B. Butler Foundation, whose heartfelt compassion for the aged made him an effective champion of our work--to the benefit of thousands of frail elders. Our hearts go out to Evelyn, Janet, Naomi, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Vivian Fenster Ehrlich Executive Director Joel D. Kazis, President

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Government Departments Spread Out
description: Nine government departments, with 10,300 state employees and their families, will move from the capital to 53 regional locations under a plan announced by the finance minister, Charlie McCreevy. ''No longer will policy be made entirely in Dublin on the basis of a Dublin mindset,'' he said in presenting his national budget for 2004 to Parliament. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHICK, ALEXANDER
description: SCHICK--Alexander. Age 92 of Pawling, New York. Died on November 26, 2003 in Paris, France. He leaves two devoted stepchildren, Janine Luke and Anthony Evnin, two step-grandchildren, Luke and Timothy Evnin, and four step-great-grandchildren.

title: Seeking to Block Terrorist Route, Rumsfeld Asks Help in Azerbaijan
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived at this Caspian Sea port on Wednesday to warn that the inland ocean, which produces oil as well as caviar, is also a transit route for terrorists, unconventional weapons and narcotics.

title: Justices Hear Case on Using Death Photos Of Official
description: Although Vincent W. Foster Jr., the Clinton administration's deputy White House counsel, killed himself more than 10 years ago, the controversy provoked by his death has yet to run its course. The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday on whether the Freedom of Information Act obliges the government to make public the graphic photographs that the police took of the death scene in Fort Marcy Park in McLean, Va.

title: Empty Feeling for the Devils at Home
description: The Devils just went on a four-game Western trip. Befitting defending Stanley Cup champions, they generated a box-office rush in all four places. Two games sold out. Only 1,753 tickets went unsold for the other two.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bigger Chip Investment
description: The Toshiba Corporation will spend an additional 50 billion yen ($462 million), or 33 percent more, to expand its production of NAND flash memory chips. Toshiba will invest 200 billion yen in its new 300-millimeter wafer fabrication plant in Yokkaichi. Toshiba will get help building the plant from the SanDisk Corporation of California. NAND flash memory chips are used in camera cellphones, digital still cameras and other consumer devices. Toshiba has about half of the world market for the chips.

title: Kyoto Protocol in Peril
description: The news from Moscow on Tuesday was not good -- Russia, a senior official said, had decided not to ratify the Kyoto Protocol on climate change. Combined with President Bush's decision two years ago to abandon the pact, Russia's rejection would have effectively killed it. Then yesterday came word that it might have been a false alarm, a negotiating tactic to strengthen Moscow's leverage in economic talks with the European Union, and that Russia was indeed ''moving toward'' ratification.

title: Iraqi Political Parties Will Form Militia to Work With American Forces
description: The American-led administration in Iraq has agreed with leaders of the country's top political parties to create a militia group made up of troops picked in equal numbers by the parties, party officials and members of the Iraqi Governing Council said Wednesday.

title: Election Scandals, Past and Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Deal Provides Final Approval For Complex In Meadowlands
description: New Jersey will receive $160 million from developers for the rights to develop a mammoth entertainment complex that will transform the New Jersey Meadowlands, under the terms of an agreement approved on Wednesday.

title: Sheffield All but Signed With Yanks
description: The Yankees and Gary Sheffield have seemed for weeks to be an inevitable match, and their union is now all but assured. The sides have resolved their differences in contract negotiations, according to a baseball official, and Sheffield will soon join the Yankees with a three-year contract worth $11 million to $12 million a season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARRAGAN, BEATRICE ''BIBI''
description: BARRAGAN--Beatrice ''Bibi'' on December 2, 2003. Born June 8, 1976 she left this world much too soon. Bibi brought joy and light and love and will be sadly mourned by all. She was the beloved daughter of Kay and Napoleon Barragan, founder of 1-800-Mattress; sister of Kay Massell (Paul), Luis Barragan (Leslie), Edward Barragan and Angela Barragan; granddaughter of Grizelda Herrera and Otillia Barragan; nieces and nephews are Mary, Paul, Sarah, Emily, Michael, Hannah and Maximillian Massell, and Luke, Logan and Lily Barragan. Bibi was much loved by everyone in the 1-800-Mattress family and will be sadly missed. Contributions in her honor should be made to Salud y Vida and sent c/o ''Bibi'', 1-800-Mattress, 31-10 48th Ave, LIC, NY 11101.

title: Left Jab! Right Hook! Step Into the Ring on Your Cellphone Screen
description: Two new products from Sorrent, a company that develops video games for wireless devices, are not the first real-time multiplayer games for head-to-head action on cellphones. But the games, Fox Sport Boxing and Fox Sport Racing, may be the most sophisticated.

title: McDonald's and A&W Award New Contracts
description: Big fast-food advertisers have made decisions on two new assignments.

title: The Neediest Cases; Life Seen Through a Lens, First Darkly, Now Brightly
description: Jesus Perez's first real experience taking photographs was a flop. ''I didn't know how to use the camera,'' he said. But those photos, taken about eight years ago with a disposable camera, only made him want to take more.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actor Art Carney on Nov. 12 listed four film credits erroneously. Mr. Carney did not appear in ''The Greatest Show on Earth,'' ''The Silencers,'' ''Gambit'' or ''The Venetian Affair.'' Those listings, as well as mistaken television credits corrected in this space on Nov. 18, came from an unrelated entry that adjoined his in a biographical reference.

title: Offspring of Genius
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Religion: Pressing For Mideast Peace Plan
description: In an unusual alliance, 32 prominent Christian, Jewish and Muslim leaders have started lobbying the Bush administration and Congress to intervene more actively in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by pressing the peace plan known as the ''road map.'' The alliance includes the leaders of the Methodist, Lutheran, Presbyterian, Episcopal, Disciples of Christ and United Church of Christ churches; the Roman Catholic cardinals of Washington and Baltimore; the Greek Orthodox primate in the United States; three prominent evangelical ministers; rabbis who head the Conservative, Reform and Reconstructionist associations; and eight heads of major Muslim organizations. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: New Archbishop For St. Louis
description: Pope John Paul II has appointed Bishop Raymond L. Burke of La Crosse, Wis., as archbishop of the St. Louis Archdiocese, home to 550,000 Roman Catholics. He succeeds Cardinal Justin F. Rigali, who became archbishop of Philadelphia in October. Archbishop-elect Burke, 55, a conservative canon lawyer, warned Catholic students last year not to read Harry Potter books. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Fight For Council Leadership
description: Councilmen Bill de Blasio and Albert Vann announced yesterday that they had enough support to wrest control of the 17-member Brooklyn delegation of the City Council from Councilman Lewis Fidler. No date has been set for a vote by the delegation, but Mr. Fidler said yesterday that he would fight any attempted ouster. The councilmen produced a petition signed by 12 delegation members endorsing Mr. de Blasio and Mr. Vann as co-chairmen for the 2004 term. ''We didn't achieve as much as we think we were capable of doing,'' Mr. Vann, a Democrat, said. ''The overriding issue is, members really want to see new leadership every so often.'' The move would also place Mr. de Blasio in a better position to fill the speaker's job in 2005, when Gifford Miller must give up the post because of term limits. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Quiet Push to Build Two Power Plants on L.I. Brings Criticism
description: A proposal to build two power plants on Long Island has galvanized critics of the Long Island Power Authority, who said on Wednesday that the giant power provider was exploiting loopholes in state law to quietly build costly, inefficient plants.

title: Northwest Chief Rules Out Starting a Low-Cost Airline
description: As traditional airlines obsess over the threat posed by low-cost carriers like Southwest Airlines and JetBlue, the chief executive of Northwest Airlines, Richard H. Anderson, has ruled out starting one.

title: Into Thin Air: Kyoto Accord May Not Die (Or Matter)
description: Since it was negotiated in Japan in 1997, the Kyoto Protocol, the first treaty that would require countries to curb emissions linked to global warming, has lingered in an indeterminate state, between enactment and outright rejection.

title: Police Are Looking for Husband After His Wife's Disappearance
description: The police said yesterday that they suspected foul play in the disappearance of a 36-year-old woman from Hillside, N.J., who has been missing since Monday, and were looking for her estranged husband in connection with the investigation.

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; THE FREE DESIGN:
description: ''Kites Are Fun'' and ''Heaven/Earth'' (Light in the Attic). The year was 1967. Jimi Hendrix was setting his guitar aflame at Monterey, the Rolling Stones had Satan on their mind and the Doors were singing about killing their fathers. Suddenly, out of the counter-cultural hotbed of New York City came the Free Design: three siblings in turtleneck sweaters singing about how much they loved flying kites and watching umbrellas open and close. Yet as out-of-step as their soft rock may have been with the spirit of the time, their baroque arrangements, pop-perfect production and candy-coated psychedelia somehow still sound innovative and genre-defining. Finally, their two most lovable CD's are available domestically (with plenty of bonus tracks). At least one track from these, like ''2002: A Hit Song'' or ''Kites Are Fun,'' is a must for anyone making an eclectic mix tape. NEIL STRAUSS

title: The Body in All Its Mortal Urgency
description: SUMMERS in high school and into college, I worked as an orderly in a small urban hospital where my father was a doctor, often in the emergency room, often all night. For a bookish, daydreamy kid, into Emily Dickinson and Italian opera, it was an experience. Fairly quickly, I think, it started to loosen up my view of the world, adding something large, and also something concrete and acute, a sense of life as a we're-all-in-it-together sharing, but also as solitary and unromantically finite.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Canary Wharf Deal
description: The Canary Wharf Group accepted a 1.6 billion ($2.7 billion) takeover offer from an investment group led by Morgan Stanley after a six-month battle for control of the company. The group, which includes the investor Simon Glick, raised its offer to 265 pence a share ($4.58) after an earlier bid was rejected. Canary Wharf shares closed at 248.75 pence. The Brascan Corporation of Toronto and the investor Paul Reichmann have also been trying to buy the company. The latest offer includes 220 pence a share in cash and 45 pence a share in stock of a new company that will control Canary Wharf.

title: Bomb Kills U.S. Soldier and 2 Iraqis in Baghdad

title: With a Load of New Albums Aboard, the Holiday Bandwagon Rolls
description: CHRISTMAS albums don't discriminate  not by age, sex, race, chart position, genre or even religious affiliation. Sooner or later, it seems, every famous musician and countless unknowns have the urge to celebrate and/or capitalize on the holiday season. On most of the albums, chestnuts are roasted one more time, although a few songwriters try to come up with new seasonal sentiments. Perhaps it's the public-spirited urge to provide some variety as holiday songs take over sound systems and radio stations for the next few weeks. And perhaps it's the dream of joining the Christmas perennials.

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''LOOKING FOR MY BABY! SOUL TREASURES FROM THE VAULTS OF AMY-MALA-BELL''
description: (Sundazed). Digging well beyond the usual 1960's soul oldies, this two-CD collection turns up material from three labels that were based in New York City but that also had pipelines to soul centers like New Orleans, Memphis, Chicago and Detroit. This collection offers obscure soul singles along with lesser-known songs from Gladys Knight and the Pips and Aaron Neville. Teenage romance is the main subject, and not all the songs are knockouts, but there are plenty of voices, among them Jimmy Jones, Lou Johnson, Oscar Mack, Ben and Spence, the Four Sonics, Chuck Brooks, Sam Hutchins, that deserve to be reissued, particularly on the set's second disc. JON PARELES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUPFERMAN, MEYER
description: KUPFERMAN--Meyer. Sarah Lawrence College notes with sorrow the death of Meyer Kupferman, emeritus member of the music faculty. From 1951 until his retirement in 1993, he was a central figure in the development of the Sarah Lawrence music program, introducing generations of students to music theory and composition and especially to the world of new music improvisation. He was a prolific composer whose work ranged across many genres. His love of music, his spirit, and his intelligence enriched the lives of his students and colleagues. It was a privilege to work with him. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Michele Tolela Myers, President Barbara Kaplan, Dean of the College

title: Holiday Albums; ''YULE BE MISERABLE''
description: (Verve). Twelve sad-sack Christmas songs, most of them (roasted) chestnuts. In any case, it seems only fair that a younger generation of revelers should be given the chance to wear out Louis Armstrong's '' 'Zat You, Santa Claus?'' It's no surprise to hear Billy Eckstine's lugubrious ''Blue Christmas,'' but ''Baby, It's Cold Outside,'' the playful Ella Fitzgerald-Louis Jordan duet, is a more unexpected choice; it's Christmasy, to be sure, but not at all miserable. KELEFA SANNEH

description: Early last year Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld disbanded the Pentagon's Office of Strategic Influence after it became known that the office was considering plans to provide false news items to unwitting foreign journalists to influence policymakers and public sentiment abroad.

title: Car Kills Boy, 5, as His Mother Takes Him to School
description: A 5-year-old boy was killed outside a Queens elementary school yesterday morning when a car being driven by another child's parent spun out of control and crushed him against the school's front gate.

title: Holiday Albums; ''A VERY SPECIAL ACOUSTIC CHRISTMAS''
description: (Lost Highway). An omnium-gatherum of country and Americana artists, pulled together by a fashionable new label intended for the discriminating middle-aged listener. Willie Nelson's ''Please Come Home for Christmas'' is a mellow high point, as is Alison Krauss's ''Only You Can Bring Me Cheer,'' with a kind of pop-R&B groove, uncharacteristic for her and well-produced. Ralph Stanley's ''Christmas Is Near'' transmits rawboned charm, and Norah Jones contributes a winning solo-piano and vocals version of Horace Silver's ''Peace.'' BEN RATLIFF

title: Holiday Albums; ERIC REED:
description: ''Merry Magic'' (MaxJazz). A lot of Christmas albums are recorded by well-known bandleaders with pulled-together, second-tier bands; the sessions are accomplished while the A-list accompaniment is on holiday. So it's good to hear the jazz pianist Eric Reed play Christmas music with three members of his primo septet: the vibraphonist Steve Nelson, the bassist Barak Mori and the drummer Rodney Green. Mr. Reed doesn't preserve the sanctity of the songs; he puts them through the jazz process. The singers Paula West and Erin Bode make guest appearances; the smart song selections include Frank Loesser's ''What Are You Doing New Year's Eve?'' and Sammy Cahn and David Jack Holt's ''Christmas Blues.'' BEN RATLIFF

title: Officials Make an Appeal for Tips on Rule-Breakers
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., Dec. 4  Tipsters invited.

title: Holiday Albums; ''MAYBE THIS CHRISTMAS TOO?''
description: (Nettwerk). The second installment of this alternative-rock compilation brings to the world something more ambivalent than joy. No one does this better than Rufus Wainwright, whose ''Spotlight on Christmas'' spares some sympathy for poor little rich girls and boys, singing ''You can measure it in blood/You can measure it in myrrh/Let us say, for these 12 days/Put the measuring away/'Cause it's Christmas.'' Elsewhere, the Dave Matthews Band sings ''Christmas Song,'' the Flaming Lips do a spooky ''White Christmas'' and Rilo Kiley contributes a lament called ''Xmas Cake,'' as in, ''Cry into my . . .'' KELEFA SANNEH

But capital spending in the quarter rose 1.5 percent compared with the period a year earlier, slower than figures released in the report on gross domestic product several weeks ago. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Holiday Albums; WHITNEY HOUSTON:
description: ''One Wish'' (Arista). Momentarily freed from the pressure to choose the right pop pose, Whitney Houston can simply bestow her vocal gifts on the familiar songs (plus two inoffensive new ones) that fill her Christmas album. The lavish swoops, the sultry whispers, the gospelly asides and the meteoric crescendos are all applied to songs that are usually arranged with the burnished keyboards and subdued percussion of current R&B. The ballads are impressive, though they can verge on soupy; turning ecumenical, she adds Hanukkah and Kwanzaa to Mel Torm's ''Christmas Song.'' A medley of ''Deck the Halls'' and ''Silent Night'' shows a frisky side, and ''O Come O Come Emmanuel'' is the tour de force: Ms. Houston sailing above an unaccompanied male choir, harmonizing like Take 6, that's actually the multitracked voice of her producer, Mervyn Warren. It's enough to make a listener forgive Ms. Houston for pushing her daughter forward on ''Little Drummer Boy.'' JON PARELES

title: When a Woman's Car Breaks Down, Good Samaritans May Not Be What They Seem
description: ''What Alice Found,'' a small, finely wrought drama about a nave young woman who gets lost on the American highway, gives that wonderfully salty New York stage actress Judith Ivey one of the chewiest roles of her career as a weatherbeaten truck-stop prostitute. The true profession of her character, Sandra, who cruises the interstate in a recreational vehicle driven by her older husband and business partner, Bill (Bill Raymond), a former marine, isn't revealed until midway in the film, which takes a sudden, sinister left turn once the beans are spilled.

title: A Tale of War: Iraqi Describes Battling G.I.'s
description: The man was in the car for less than two minutes Thursday when he pulled out a hand grenade. He had been carrying it, like an apple, in a little red shopping bag. He smiled. The other passengers winced.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Posts Income Increase
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said yesterday that its net income rose sharply during its second quarter, citing improved sales of notebook computers, wireless handsets and PC's, and successful cost-cutting measures. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., reported net income of $65.8 million, or 34 cents a share, for the quarter ended Nov. 23, up from $6.2 million, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding certain charges, the company's earnings were $71.1 million, or 36 cents a share. Global bookings in the quarter increased 36 percent over the second quarter last year, making it National's strongest bookings quarter in three years, Brian L. Halla, the chief executive and president of National, said. Sales rose 12 percent over the year-earlier period, to $473.5 million, while gross margins improved 2.9 percentage points. The company's guidance for the third quarter, typically its slowest, is for revenue to grow 3 percent to 5 percent. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Design Applicant Loses
description: Justice William A. Wetzel of State Supreme Court yesterday upheld the elimination of a plan called Twin Piers from the World Trade Center memorial competition on the ground that its creator, Fred A. Bernstein, ''had for all practical purposes two horses in this race,'' in violation of the rules. While the proposal for a pair of piers at Battery Park that would be as long as the trade center was tall, was Mr. Bernstein's, it was entered by his domestic partner, Charles Upchurch. Mr. Bernstein submitted a separate proposal in his own name. The Twin Piers entry survived until very late in the judging process but was eliminated after Mr. Bernstein's involvement was discovered by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. Mr. Upchurch then sued for reinstatement. Mr. Bernstein said yesterday, ''It would have been good for everyone -- including the jury -- to be able to consider the Twin Piers on their artistic merit, but the L.M.D.C. had other ideas.''

description: The Del Monte Foods Company, the maker of canned fruits and vegetables, said yesterday that quarterly earnings fell 23 percent because the purchase of businesses from the H.J. Heinz Company raised costs.

description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said Wednesday night in an interview here that all European countries should rally to American efforts in Iraq and described the intervention there as an important, necessary example of the West exporting freedom.

Survivors: Father and stepmother Alan and Margaret Zlotkowski; mother and stepfather Mary Ann and Edward Castagnetta; brother Michael Alan Zlotkowski; and maternal grandmother Nella Del Prete. title: G.M. IN BID FOR SOUTH KOREAN AUTOMAKER
description: General Motors, the biggest foreign automaker in South Korea, was preparing to join the auction for the Ssangyong Motor Company with a bid for a controlling stake worth about $550 million. General Motors submitted a letter to creditors who are selling 55.4 percent of Ssangyong, saying it plans to make an offer, said Kim Sung Soo, a spokesman for the G.M.-Daewoo Auto and Technology Company, which is based in Seoul. Ssangyong's shares rose 5.4 percent; a merger with G.M.-Daewoo is seen as helping both companies close the gap with the market leaders.

description: Snapple got a sweetheart deal when it was given exclusive rights to place vending machines in city schools and to sell iced tea and bottled water on city property, representatives of several competing beverage companies told the City Council yesterday.

title: Fleeing Cuba, Hoping to Soar On New Stage
description: Before dawn on Oct. 12, Cervilio Amador and Gema Daz, Cuban ballet dancers on tour, grabbed their backpacks and walked briskly through the lobby of their Daytona Beach hotel. Between them, they carried 16 pairs of ballet shoes, several videos of their work and $1,000.

title: Holiday Albums; ''CHRISTMAS REMIXED: HOLIDAY CLASSICS REGROOVED''
description: (Six Degrees). The label that brought you Bebel Gilberto and a lot of other soign dance music from around the world presents 12 familiar holiday tunes turned inside out. There's a nice disjunction in hearing Andy Williams's croon over syncopated beat-box rhythm supplied by Shrift, or Dean Martin's ''Jingle Bells'' sliced up and rearranged by Dan the Automator. description: A retired detective who was arrested last week with an 18-year police veteran on charges that they took $169,000 from a drug money courier is cooperating with prosecutors and Internal Affairs investigators, several law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Liver Transplant Thwarted by Blackout Succeeds on 2nd Try
description: Since the middle of August, every time the telephone rang, Delyla Torres hoped it would be Mount Sinai Hospital, calling to tell her a liver was on the way and it was time for her transplant.

title: Whatever He Felt for Women, Sargent Loved to Paint Them
description: Was John Singer Sargent a feminist? You could get that impression from ''Sargent's Women,'' an exhibition of paintings at Adelson Galleries. Including more than 50 paintings, watercolors and drawings in varying degrees of quality and finish, the show shifts attention away from the professional work that made Sargent one of the most successful high-society portrait painters of his day. It focuses instead on more personal things from early in his career (the 1870's and 80's): pictures of his mother and sisters, friends from family and artistic circles and beautiful young women of the lower classes whom he encountered on trips to Venice, Capri, Spain and Africa.

title: Holiday Albums; ''CLASSIC COUNTRY CHRISTMAS''
description: (Time Life Music/BMG). A pretty straightforward Christmas compilation, and an effective one. The first half includes Dolly Parton's deliciously whiny ''Hard Candy Christmas,'' from 1982, as well as Johnny Cash's unremittingly grim version of ''The Little Drummer Boy''; backup singers try to brighten things up, but they can't overpower Cash's stern voice and that sad, ceaseless beating. Soon comes the antidote: a slew of cheerful songs, including Chet Atkins's instrumental trot through ''Jingle Bells.'' And the disc ends on a serene note, with Jim Reeves singing ''Silent Night.'' KELEFA SANNEH

title: World Briefing | The Environment: Kremlin Seems To Reverse Itself Again On Kyoto
description: A top Kremlin official reaffirmed that President Vladimir V. Putin had decided not to ratify the Kyoto Protocol, the first climate treaty that would require countries to curb emissions linked to global warming. On Tuesday the official, Andrei N. Illarionov, quoted Mr. Putin as telling a European group, ''In its present form, this protocol cannot be ratified.'' Backing for the treaty is weighted, and with Washington still refusing to ratify it, the pact needs Russian approval to be enacted. On Wednesday, a deputy economics minister denied the Kremlin had decided to back away, but on Thursday, according to news agencies, Mr. Illarionov, Mr. Putin's top economic adviser, said the original statement was precisely what Mr. Putin had said. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: From the Wild West To the Honorable East
description: There is probably no director more obsessed with the complexity of patriotism -- an unusual subject to plumb in mainstream films -- than Edward Zwick, who is driven to question the imperatives of an America that his protagonists both love and detest. His latest movie, ''The Last Samurai,'' falls squarely into the realm of the previous Zwick bedeviled-hero films, ''Glory,'' ''Courage Under Fire'' and ''The Siege.''

title: Knicks Let Games Slip Through The Fingers
description: Thirty seconds into the Knicks' eventual loss in Seattle on Wednesday, Howard Eisley zipped a pass -- right to Seattle's Vladimir Radmanovic. Thirty-four seconds later, Keith Van Horn lost the ball and Antonio Daniels turned it into a fast-break layup.

title: Rumsfeld Visits Georgias New Leaders
description: TBILISI, Georgia, Dec. 5  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, the first senior administration official to visit here since a peaceful, popular revolt forced out the government of Eduard A. Shevardnadze, expressed strong support today for Georgia's territorial integrity in the face of rising secessionist sentiment and the presence of Russian troops on its territory.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Inquiry on Steroid Use Gets Bonds Testimony
description: The Giants slugger Barry Bonds, a six-time most valuable player in the National League and baseball's single-season home run champion, appeared yesterday before a federal grand jury in San Francisco that is investigating a company accused of being at the center of a scandal involving anabolic steroids.

title: Foes Overturn Veto by South Korea's Leader
description: President Roh Moo Hyun, in office less than a year, received a powerful blow from his political opponents Thursday when the opposition-dominated National Assembly voted to overturn his veto of an independent investigation into corruption charges involving some of his former aides.

title: At Least 41 Killed in Suicide Bombing on Russian Train
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 5 — A suicide bomber triggered a devastating explosion inside a crowded commuter train in southern Russia today, killing at least 41 passengers, officials said. President Vladimir V. Putin denounced it as a terrorist act intended to disrupt parliamentary elections here this weekend.

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''CRUNK AND DISORDERLY''
description: (TVT). This new compilation of Southern hip-hop includes a few of the year's rowdiest Christmas songs. Atlanta's Ying Yang Twins contribute a merry, foul-mouthed track called ''Ho! Ho!,'' and their fellow Atlantan Killer Mike snarls through ''A Christmas Grind,'' his tribute to ''Carol of the Bells.''

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''NOW THAT'S WHAT I CALL MUSIC, VOL. 14''
description: (Sony). Another diabolical collection of the most impossible-to-get-out-of-your-head songs of the year, crashing across radio playlists to encourage you into the position that R&B and rock are all really one music. It includes Chingy's ''Right Thurr,'' R. Kelly's ''Thoia Thoing,'' Ginuwine's ''In Those Jeans'' and-arguably the song of the year, Beyonc's ''Crazy in Love.'' BEN RATLIFF

title: Rap Rules Among the Grammy Award Nominations
description: Rappers and the recently deceased dominated the nominations for the 46th Annual Grammy Awards, which were announced this morning at the Beverly Hilton Hotel in Beverly Hills. Unlike recent years, when artists like Santana and Lauryn Hill stood out with 10 nominations, this year there was no clear-cut leader. The awards will be presented on Feb. 8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STALLWORTH, SAMUEL S.
description: STALLWORTH--Samuel S. Jr. 57, of Tampa, died peacefully Monday, December 1, 2003 at Tampa General Hospital surrounded by his family. He was diagnosed with lung cancer in October. Mr. Stallworth had been Vice President and General Manager of WFTS/ABC-TV since 2000. He was very active in the Tampa community and served on the board of the Champions Fund. He was also instrumental in raising the public awareness and fundraising opportunities for numerous Tampa civic organizations including Academy Prep, Tampa Bay Performing Arts, and MDA. Stallworth is survived by his wife, Shelley; daughters Shannon Hesse (Andrew) of Louisville, KY and Regan Deering (Brian) of Chicago, IL; son Eric Andreas of Decatur, IL; parents Beverly and Samuel S Stallworth Sr. of Manchester, NH; granddaughters Claire and Sara Evelyn Hesse; and beloved pets Lily and Hannah. Visitation will be at Blount & Curry Funeral Home, MacDill Avenue Chapel, 605 S. MacDill, in Tampa on Saturday from 6-8 pm. A memorial celebration will be held at Old Memorial Golf Club in Tampa on Sunday at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to: The Moffitt Foundation PO Box 550985 Tampa, FL 33655 Please specify the donation is for lung cancer research in memory of Sam Stallworth. Tampa General Hospital C/O Lea Shappee Director of Development Projects P.O. Box 1289 Tampa, FL 33601-1289. Please specify the donation is in memory of Sam Stallworth. Out of town friends are invited to sign the family's guestbook at www.blountcurry.com. For information contact Blount & Curry Funeral Home, MacDill Avenue Chapel, Tampa, FL. (813) 876-2421

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Guilty Plea In Corruption Investigation
description: A woman who was a top aide to the chief of staff to former Gov. George Ryan pleaded guilty on Wednesday to perjury, admitting that she had lied during a grand jury investigation of Mr. Ryan's tenure as secretary of state. The plea by the woman, Alexandra Coutretsis, is a major victory for federal prosecutors, who have convicted dozens of state employees in the investigation. Ms. Coutretsis worked with Mr. Ryan's chief of staff, Scott Fawell, who has been sentenced to more than six years in prison for racketeering. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Khannouchi Withdraws From the Olympic Trials
description: Khalid Khannouchi is one of history's greatest marathon runners, a former world record-holder, an immigrant from Morocco who worked as a dishwasher in Brooklyn, determined to become an American citizen and to repay his gratitude by winning an Olympic gold medal for the United States.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, Page A3 in some copies on Wednesday was a reprint from the previous day. The Wednesday page would have carried an article about an Israeli warning to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell on the so-called Geneva accord, backed by Israeli and Arab peace groups. That article remains online at nytimes.com/corrections.html. It can also be obtained by mail or by fax from Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@ nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Exports Rise
description: Led by rising shipments of semiconductors to Japan, Philippine exports rose 6.2 percent in October, to $3.2 billion, compared with the month a year ago, according to government data. It was the second month of export growth, but the Philippines still lagged other Asian countries as businesses readied for instability ahead of presidential elections next May. Economists said the recovery in exports was probably not enough to push growth up to the government's goal of 5 percent. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''THE FOLD''
description: (Credit Records). Most small and infamous rock clubs in major cities present the same touring bands. The only identity they tend to have is in the local bands they discover before the acts graduate to college radio and major labels. Thus, the boon of this compilation of alternative-rockers who have performed at the well-booked Fold at the Silverlake Lounge in Los Angeles is not in its songs by Black Rebel Motorcycle Club, Patrick Park and Polyphonic Spree. It's in allowing the rest of the country to discover quality unsigned SoCal acts like Midnight Movies, Trespassers William, Silversun Pickups, Gwendolyn, and Eleni Mandell. NEIL STRAUSS

title: The Mistaken Arab Experience
description: Even before the ink dried on the Geneva Accord, signed on Monday by self-appointed Israeli and Palestinian negotiators, enemies on both sides of the regional divide were united in their antipathy toward what is, after all, just a virtual agreement.

title: Investor Fight To Control Air Canada Goes to Court
description: One of Asia's wealthiest families has locked horns with a New York investment fund over Air Canada, in a dispute that is as much a clash of Canadian and American business styles as a disagreement over a deal.

title: Taiwan Referendum to Focus on Missiles, Not Independence
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Dec. 5  President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan said in an interview here today that he planned a referendum next March calling on China to withdraw ballistic missiles aimed at Taiwan and demanding that China renounce the use of force against the island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAPPUCCI, RUTH F.
description: CAPPUCCI--Ruth F., on December 4, 2003. Beloved wife of Joseph R. Funeral visitation Sunday, December 7, 2003, 2-4 and 7-9PM, at Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Road, Katonah, New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Publisher Cuts Outlook
description: The Reed Elsevier Group, which publishes Variety and LexisNexis, said that earnings growth would slow in 2004 in part because of a flat outlook for ad revenue. The company, which also publishes textbooks, said that it expected profit, excluding one-time items, to increase 5 to 10 percent next year, down from more than 10 percent in 2003. It said it expected to increase spending to improve some services. The group is owned by Reed Elsevier of London and Reed Elsevier of the Netherlands. Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Conclude Hamas Has Suspended Its Suicide Attacks
description: Israeli officials have concluded that the Islamic movement Hamas has suspended its suicide bombing campaign in recent months, a senior Israeli military officer said Thursday, citing that as one reason Israel has not suffered any deadly bombings in the past two months.

title: AES+F -- 'King of the Forest, New York'
description: Claire Oliver Fine Art

title: Giving Voice To an Act Of Terror
description: All those entering the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night had to empty their pockets and pass through metal detectors set up right inside the four doors to the spacious lobby. The reason behind the heightened security was the opening-night performance of John Adams's opera ''The Death of Klinghoffer,'' which had its United States premiere in 1991 at the academy, six months after its world premiere in Brussels. The opera has come back to the academy in an arresting new production, with Robert Spano conducting the Brooklyn Philharmonic, that will be repeated tonight and tomorrow night at the Howard Gilman Opera House.

title: A Fossil, Decidedly Male, and Old as the Hills
description: A 425-million-year-old fossil found in Herefordshire, England, may be the oldest record of an animal that is unarguably male. Scientists report Friday in the journal Science that the tiny crustacean, only two-tenths of an inch long, had an unmistakable penis. In their paper, the scientists name the creature Colymbosathon ecplecticos, which they say means swimmer with a large penis.

title: Houses With Stained Glass: Adding Color and Light
description: WHO -- Stephen Fields, 61, a family physician in Wichita, Kan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEAVER, WILLIAM M., JR.
description: WEAVER--William M., Jr., of New York City, died on November 28, 2003 at the age of 91. He is survived by his wife, Rosemary, and four daughters, Marcia Campbell and Patricia Wurts, both of Philadelphia, PA, Wendy Chaix of New York City, and Alison Weaver of Easton, CT; six grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Saint Bartholomew's Church, 50th Street and Park Avenue, New York, NY on Tuesday, December 9, 2003 at 4pm.

title: Panel to Analyze Brewers' Books
description: In response to the public outcry over their plan to cut payroll, the financially troubled Milwaukee Brewers have agreed to let an independent panel of business leaders analyze the team's finances dating from 1994.

title: Alan Davidson, 79, an Envoy Who Loved the Kitchen, Dies
description: Alan Davidson, a diplomat whose passion for food and its history led him to write indispensable works on seafood and to edit the comprehensive Oxford Companion to Food, died on Tuesday in London. He was 79.

title: Euro Rises as Central Bank Stands Pat
description: The euro traded at another record high against the dollar on Thursday. Yet the currency's guardian, the European Central Bank, signaled that it was not alarmed by the recent surge, leaving its benchmark interest rate unchanged and dampening speculation of a radical change in policy to curb the appreciation of the euro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDQUIST, WARREN T.
description: LINDQUIST--Warren T. ''Lindy''. My dear friend Lindy Lindquist died November 15, 2003 at his home in Seal Harbor, ME. He was 84. From the time Lindy and I served together in Paris during WWII, he was my trusted associate in the fields of banking and urban affairs. As Executive Director of the Downtown Lower Manhattan Association, he helped conceive of the idea of the World Trade Center. He served as the first CEO of the New York City Community Preservation Corporation, played a key role in organizing Morningside Gardens, and in establishing the New York State Housing Finance Agency and the Urban Development Corporation. He served with distinction under President Reagan as the first General Manager of the New Community Development Corporation in the Department of Housing and Urban Development and as the first Assistant Secretary for Public and Indian Housing. He was a principal associate in the development of L'Enfant Plaza in Washington, and Embarcadero Center in San Francisco. I offer my most heartfelt sympathy to his wife Muriel, his ten children, twelve grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Lindy was a great person and a wonderful friend, who I will miss for the rest of my life. David Rockefeller, New York, N.Y.

title: It's Modern No Longer, But Precious
description: As we begin the 21st century, we find we cannot escape the 20th. Midcentury Modern design is everywhere: in fashion and shelter magazines, Target commercials and new books like ''Objects of Design From the Museum of Modern Art,'' and at specialized Manhattan antiques shows, gallery exhibitions and, of course, the auction houses.

description: In percent

title: Qaeda Trainee Is Sentenced To 8-Year Term
description: A man who admitted attending a terrorist training camp in Afghanistan was sentenced on Thursday to eight years in prison, moments after he apologized in Federal District Court for his actions.

title: A Blink From the Bush Administration
description: President Bush had little choice on Thursday when he reversed himself and lifted the tariffs on imported steel that he imposed last year.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Aid In Bank Case
description: Japan's top banking regulator, Heizo Takenaka, said the government would explore ways to help shareholders of the insolvent Ashikaga Bank, which has been nationalized. Speaking in Parliament, Mr. Takenaka, left, said regulators would try to minimize the impact on shareholders, whose stock fell to zero after the government took over the bank on Monday. Many of the shareholders are businesses in Tochigi Prefecture, where Ashikaga is based. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: LIPA Plans Higher Surcharge And $150 Million Budget Cut
description: The Long Island Power Authority will cut $150 million in costs and increase a surcharge to consumers' bills to deal with financial troubles brought on by rising fuel prices and the cost of building new power plants, LIPA officials said on Thursday.

title: Powell, in Brussels, Calls for Increased NATO and U.N. Roles in Iraq
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell on Thursday urged NATO to consider expanding its activities in Iraq, in the Bush administration's most pointed appeal for international help since it went to war in the spring. He also called for more involvement from the United Nations.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: BEAR STEARNS BUYS PARENT OF BALDUCCI'S FOR $50 MILLION
description: The merchant banking unit of the Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that it would pay $50 million to buy and expand the operations of the Sutton Place Group, owner of 11 upscale food stores including Balducci's and Hay Day Country Farm Markets. Bear Stearns paid cash to a group of investors led by two private equity firms, AEA Investors and Catterton Partners, said David King, senior managing director at Bear Stearns Merchant Banking. More than 50 percent of the purchase price will be used to pay debt and improve the stores and for capital expenses. Mr. King said he expected to have as many as 50 stores, mostly under the Balducci's brand, in five years in Manhattan and the surrounding area. Sutton Place operates stores in New York, Connecticut and the Washington area. The oldest, Balducci's, was started in Manhattan in 1916 and has an outlet on the Upper West Side.

title: At Hearing on Blackout, Critics Focus on Report
description: Independent experts called on Thursday for big changes in the electric grid at a hearing here, the first opportunity for public comment on the report on the Aug. 14 blackout, and some criticized the report itself.

title: Correction: Phone Subscribers in China And Central Bank Interest Rates
description: Because of a production error, two charts on Monday in the special Outlook issue of Business Day -- one showing the number of cellphone and fixed-line subscribers in China and the other showing central bank interest rates for Britain, the European Union and the United States -- carried incorrect scales. Corrected versions appear below.

title: Sports of The Times; In Nets' World, Even Kidd Is Vulnerable
description: THE deathwatch begins now for a lame duck coach, Byron Scott, his Nets stumbling through the first quarter of the N.B.A. season with the body language of a team waiting for that proverbial other shoe to drop. Scott's vulnerability will dominate the dialogue for the two-time finalists, but it may be remembered as a footnote compared with the franchise upheaval likely to come.

title: Players Threatened, F.B.I. Says
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is analyzing several hate-mail letters received by prominent African-American men, including N.F.L. players, civic leaders and entertainers, The Palm Beach Post reported yesterday. The contents of the article were confirmed yesterday in an interview with a special agent from the Cleveland office of the F.B.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULLANE, CESIAH TORO
description: MULLANE--Cesiah Toro. We mourn the loss of an irreplaceable community activist and tireless President of the Board of Directors of the Cypress Hills Local Development Corporation. We extend our condolences to Cesi's beloved husband Michael, and all her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. Cesi will be sorely missed by those whose lives she touched and enriched. Cypress Hills has lost its greatest friend and advocate Board of Directors and Staff Cypress Hills Local Development Corporation

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Hires Executives
description: The banking company HSBC said it had hired two executives in its investment banking division as part of a strategy to increase business in that area. Rupert Robson will become co-head of its financial institution group on Dec. 8 from Citigroup, where he was a managing director in the financial institutions group. In addition, Anthony Bernbaum, a former Goldman Sachs managing director, became HSBC's European head of insurance, corporate finance and advisory services on Monday. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: North Carolina Women Seek 17th Soccer Title
description: The North Carolina women's soccer team has gone two years without a national championship trophy to put in its showcase, an unprecedented slump for a program that has won 16 titles in 21 years.

title: Couture Motorcycles
description: IN a cluttered and paint-splattered studio in Dumbo, the Brooklyn neighborhood where he spends most nights working, Scott Chester is designing a motorcycle for Spider-Man. Not the Spider-Man who climbs bridges to fight the Green Goblin, but the one who fortifies city structures against terrorist attacks for the New York City Department of Transportation and whose real name is John Jones.

title: Mary Pinkett, First Black Councilwoman, 72
description: Mary Pinkett, a labor advocate from Brooklyn who became the first African-American woman elected to the New York City Council, died yesterday. She was 72.

description: A Brooklyn Home For Feminist Art

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Bias Inquiry In Beating
description: A group of white and Hispanic men punched and kicked two teenagers in Queens yesterday, an attack that the police said was being investigated as a possible bias crime. About 11 a.m., four or five men approached a black youth, who is 17, and a 15-year-old Hispanic boy and attacked them while shouting racial slurs, according to investigators. The victims suffered minor injuries, the police said. No arrests have been made. The incident followed two cases of vandalism in a predominantly Jewish neighborhood in Brooklyn, which the police said were possible bias crimes. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Islanders Owner Withdraws Bid to Buy the Nets
description: Exhausted by delays in the proposed sale of the Nets, Charles B. Wang dropped his $265 million bid to acquire the team and move it to Long Island yesterday.

title: Holiday Albums; ''HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS''
description: (Om Records). It's generally an exciting event when a label with an alternative vision releases a Christmas CD. This disc from the San Francisco electronic dance label Om collects Christmas classics and originals and sets them to a down-tempo dance beat. Though this compilation is not as interesting or original as one might hope, it makes head-bobbing funky background music, especially if you're spending Christmas at a plush, hip lounge. Colossus's turntable cut-up of Peanuts records and the songs that add the lush vocals of Becky Williams are highlights. NEIL STRAUSS

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Magnetic-Field Gaps Found To Stay Open For Hours
description: Gaping holes in Earth's magnetic field can remain open for hours at a time, allowing solar storms to slip through and disrupt satellites, radio communication and power grids, according to a study published in the journal Nature. Scientists have known about the cracks for some time but thought they lasted only minutes, said Dr. Harald Frey, a physicist at the University of California at Berkeley and co-author of the study. Instead, the holes, caused by a southward pointing magnetic field carried by the solar wind, can last at least nine hours.

title: Cellphone Number Transfer Hits a Snag
description: Hundreds of thousands of consumers have switched mobile phone providers in the last 10 days since new federal rules went into effect allowing them to keep their cellphone numbers when they change carriers. But mobile phone users looking for improved phone reception and service have discovered a new problem: technical glitches and delays in making the number transfers.

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; WYCLEF JEAN:
description: ''Greatest Hits'' (Sony Urban/Columbia). The jury is still out on Wyclef Jean. While his former band, the Fugees, certainly made their mark, it remains to be seen whether his solo career is worth a remark. While his last album, ''The Preacher's Son'' (R.C.A.) demonstrated that he still had something to say musically and lyrically, his ''Greatest Hits'' album certainly doesn't make a case for his having had many great hits. If Wyclef ever gets close to the caliber of his musical ideals, perhaps this disc will be reissued and updated. Then it may be worth buying. NEIL STRAUSS

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Share Buyback
description: The wireless company Vodafone Group said it bought 20 million of its shares on Dec. 3 at a price of 136 to 137 pence ($2.34 to $2.36) a share, or about 27.3 million ($47.2 million). Vodafone said in November that it had allocated 2.5 billion for buying back shares. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Unemployment Rate Slides, but Job Creation Slower Than Hoped
description: The nation's unemployment rate ticked down in November, the Labor Department reported today, but employers added just 57,000 jobs, far less than Wall Street's expectations.

title: Shopping List | Laundry Room
description: THERE'S a reason some people spend precious weekend hours washing clothes: the swishing, dripping and tumbling rhythms of the laundry room can be oddly soothing and relaxing. Today's high-tech machines can be programmed to remove different stains and to remember favorite cycles of each family member. But when it comes to the basics -- irons, soap tins, clothes baskets and more -- the classics still rule. NANCY M. BETTER

title: Iraq, Through the Soldiers Eyes (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:
