description: Bush Avoids a Trade War By Lifting Steel Tariffs

title: Alcohol Marketer Agrees to Ad Review
description: Another large marketer of alcoholic beverages has agreed to having its advertising reviewed by outsiders as part of efforts to defuse the growing criticism of the industry's sales tactics.

title: Bush and Jordanian King Confer on Palestinian Plan
description: President Bush and King Abdullah of Jordan discussed a Palestinian proposal on Thursday in which Israel would refrain from killing terrorist suspects and stop construction of its barrier in the West Bank in return for a cease-fire by militants, Arab diplomats said.

title: Washington Post Selects Writer for 'Reliable Source'
description: ''The Reliable Source,'' the gossip column in The Washington Post that has been on hiatus since the end of July, will return in the new year with a new byline attached.

title: When Marimekko Was In Flower
description: Clothing from the late 1960's, right, with the dynamic patterns so reminiscent of Pop Art, are part of ''Marimekko'' at the Bard Graduate Center in Manhattan. The show examines the fabrics, fashion and architecture produced by the Finnish design company from its early years through today.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Kill Devil Hills, N.C.

title: FOR FAO, A SECOND BANKRUPTCY FILING
description: FAO Inc., owner of the 141-year-old F.A.O. Schwarz toy store chain, sought bankruptcy protection yesterday for the second time this year and said it would shut down unless it received a rescue offer within 11 days. FAO would close its Zany Brainy chain and seek buyers for its F.A.O. Schwarz and Right Start stores by Dec. 15. FAO, based in King of Prussia, Pa., reorganized in April after closing 111 stores and agreeing to pay suppliers and other creditors as much as 38 percent of what they were owed. The company now operates 142 stores. FAO listed assets of $102 million and debts of $85.9 million in its Chapter 11 petition filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del.

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''LIGHT OF DAY: A TRIBUTE TO BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN''
description: (Schoolhouse Records). Some unpolished clunkers complicate this 37-track, two-disc tribute to the Boss, but the scope of it is nice. New folk singers (Mike Rimbaud), old rock singers (Dion), and representatives of the new wave era (Elvis Costello, Graham Parker), neo-country (Joe Ely, Rosie Flores) and so forth bring their own perspectives to Mr. Springsteen's best songs. BEN RATLIFF

title: Elusive Helping Hands in the City
description: It's a fact of life for many in the city: even a regular paycheck is no guarantee that there will be enough money for food. And as the number of working poor in the city has grown, so has the need for food stamp assistance. From the time Mayor Michael Bloomberg took office through last August, total rolls in the federal food stamp program have risen nearly 12 percent, with more than 900,000 city residents receiving assistance. That would be impressive -- if national enrollment had not risen by more than 18 percent. With New York leading the nation in absorbing economic hardship, there is something wrong here.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the return of Phyllis Grann to Random House as a senior editor misidentified the executive to whom she will report. He is Stephen Rubin, president and publisher of the Doubleday Broadway group, not Peter Olson, chairman of Random House Inc.

title: Weekender | Washington, Conn.
description: WASHINGTON is the kind of place where you start chatting with a retired gent at the library only to find he has lived in four countries and helped build a well-known Bahamas hotel. Or where the couple you meet at the local bar turn out to be best friends with a famous film director.

title: 2nd Move in 5 Months For Creative Director
description: After five months, Eric Silver has decided to leave Saatchi & Saatchi in New York to become an executive vice president and executive creative director at BBDO Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: Residential Real Estate; In Queens, High-End Living In Less-Than-Upscale Area
description: The phrase ''gated community'' is not usually associated with Ozone Park, Queens. Nor, in this densely developed and solidly middle-class neighborhood, is the term ''luxury housing'' much used. And a less-than-three-acre lot on North Conduit Avenue, with its unobstructed view of the Belt Parkway, is not what one would think of as a site for upscale development.

title: L.I. Bishop Will Meet 400 Priests in Effort to Heal Rift Over Abuse Scandal
description: Bishop William F. Murphy, the leader of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, has agreed to meet with the 400 priests he oversees, a move that some Roman Catholics on Long Island are hailing as one of the first positive moves the bishop has made to deal with the church sex-abuse scandal.

title: Israeli Deputy Sees Israel Acting Alone to Secure Peace
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 5  Israel's deputy prime minister predicted in remarks published today that Israelis and Palestinians would not reach a peace agreement but that Israel would unilaterally have to cede territory and permit the creation of a Palestinian state.

title: At Many Stores, a Disappointing November
description: Retail sales in November, including the bellwether Thanksgiving weekend, failed to rise to analysts' expectations, suggesting that the Christmas season may not be as good as some retailers hoped a month or two ago.

title: Holiday Albums; ''THE AMERICAN SONG-POEM CHRISTMAS: DADDY, IS SANTA REALLY SIX FOOT FOUR?''
description: (Bar/None). This collection is just one crucial step removed from other Christmas novelty albums: all of its lyrics were written by amateurs, who sent them in to companies that would set them to music, record them and press them on extremely limited-edition albums. These impersonal collaborations for hire, from the 1960's and 70's, yielded Christmas songs about a cheating mom (the album's title song), fear (''Santa Came on a Nuclear Missile''), strange free associations (''Ole Year Christmas''), would-be crazes (disco and polka Christmases), lusty new years (''Baby, It's a Cold Night in December''), obsessions with peppermint and endless mismatched rhyme schemes. They're all delivered by the hired hacks with straight faces and surprising geniality. JON PARELES

title: Holiday Albums; HARRY CONNICK JR.
description: ''Harry for the Holidays'' (Columbia). Mr. Connick is the singer, pianist and -- most of all -- arranger for this album, which works the secular end of the Christmas repertory and wisely plays up his New Orleans roots. From the rhythm-and-blues ''Frosty the Snowman'' to the brass-band ''Santa Claus Is Coming to Town'' to his own cheerfully swinging ''Happy Elf'' to modal jazz versions of ''I Wonder as I Wander'' and ''Nature Boy,'' Mr. Connick is best when he's uptempo, since the string-laden ballads tend to droop. But one of them, the lonesome ''Nothin' New for New Year,'' turns into a country song and features none other than George Jones. JON PARELES

title: As the Flu Spreads Early and Quickly, Colorado Expands Its Vaccination Campaign
description: Phillip Shnaider, 10, glanced with horror at the long needle in the nurse's hand on Thursday. There was no way he was going to be stung with that thing, he said.

title: People
description: Gina Goss, executive director for agency services at Coyne Communications, Morristown, N.J., was promoted to president, succeeding Thomas J. Coyne III, who continues as chief executive.

title: Test May Aid Chemotherapy Decisions
description: A new genetic test can help predict whether breast cancer will recur, providing a way to help women decide whether they need chemotherapy, researchers here said on Thursday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bottled Water Entry
description: The Coca-Cola Company said it would enter the French bottled water market with its Dasani brand in the spring. Coca-Cola will compete with Nestl, Danone and Neptune, which control 70 percent of the French bottled water market. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINBERG, MEYER
description: STEINBERG--Meyer. The Officers, Governors and Members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Friar Meyer Steinberg. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. Service on Sunday, December 7, 1 PM, at Park Avenue Synagogue. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Sharpton Runs for Presidency, and Influence
description: In the world of politics, the Rev. Al Sharpton sees himself as a sort of D.J., working alone behind a console, grabbing old hits and spinning them into a contemporary beat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASER, LEON
description: GLASER--Leon. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Leon Glaser, treasurer of the J.E. and Z.B. Butler Foundation, a cherished friend and generous supporter of UJAFederation. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Glaser family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column on Tuesday about Lyle Stuart, the president of Barricade Books, misspelled the surname of a tall entertainer whose divorce from a midget figured in an anecdote from Mr. Stuart's days as a press agent. She is Lois de Fee, not de Faye. (Her recollection appears in the column today, on Page B2.)

title: Jack Smith
description: Mitchell Algus Gallery

title: Holiday Albums; RHODA SCOTT:
description: ''The Hammond Organ of Christmas'' (Sunnyside). Ms. Scott, the jazz Hammond-organ player, recorded some of these pieces in 1977, with only spare percussive background, and the rest in the mid-90's, with a small band including the likable tenor saxophonist Houston Person. They're restrained versions of church repertory (''There Is a Balm in Gilead,'' ''Every Time I Feel the Spirit'') as well as stock holiday songs like ''The Little Drummer Boy.'' The album is parked at a lovely midway point between jazz and classical music. BEN RATLIFF

title: MARATHON OIL NAMES CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: The Marathon Oil Corporation appointed an executive of the Nuevo Energy Company, Janet F. Clark, as chief financial officer and senior vice president. Ms. Clark, 48, will start Jan. 5, Marathon said, succeeding John T. Mills, 56, who retired on Monday. Ms. Clark has been chief financial officer at Nuevo, an oil and natural gas producer, since 2001. Both companies are based in Houston.

title: Holiday Albums; ''COOL DECEMBER,'' ''YULESVILLE'' AND ''UNDER THE MISTLETOE''
description: (Shout! Factory). These three CD's, produced and compiled by Brad Benedict for the Wonderland series, are among the year's best in toasty-warm Christmas classics. Nicely packaged, and loosely organized thematically (there's one about the weather outside, a second about the warmth inside and finally a third of Christmas icons), they mix the regular Christmas crooners with less obvious choices that should be classics. What results is a CD not just for arch-eyebrowed purveyors of cocktail music but also for Christmas-pop traditionalists looking to expand their horizons. Included are Rosemary Clooney, Ella Fitzgerald, Artie Shaw, Sergio Mendes, Booker T. and the MG's, and Claudine Longet, whose fantastic ''Snow'' makes me wonder why I've never seen a collection of 1960's French Christmas chansons. Maybe next Christmas. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOULK, DAVID G.
description: FOULK--David G., 83, of Dobbs Ferry, New York on December 3, 2003. Devoted brother of Charlotte L., the late Thomas J. and the late Richard N. Foulk. Funeral Mass Saturday, December 6, 2003, 11:00 AM, St. Matthew's R.C. Church, Hastings-onHudson, New York.

title: Yankees Add Vazquez and Get Younger on Mound
description: To the Yankees, armed with cash and riddled with pitching questions, the decision was easy. They had a chance to trade a 25-year-old first baseman for a 27-year-old starting pitcher, and they did not pass it up.

title: A Look Ahead
description: A.F.C. Division Title Pictures Coming Into Focus

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Companies Affected By Shortages
description: Flextronics International, which makes electronics for other companies, said yesterday that a shortage of parts would prevent it from filling all its cellphone orders this quarter, the company's third, which ends this month. Flextronics, based in Singapore, and competing cellphone makers will probably not be able to fill all their orders, a senior vice president, Tom Smach, said. Motorola said yesterday that it was not getting parts fast enough, delaying shipments of some camera phones. Demand in North America, Europe and Asia for camera phones is outstripping the company's ability to ship some models, Motorola said. The company, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., did not say whether the delays would affect revenue or earnings in the fourth quarter. Short supplies of camera parts are an industrywide problem, Motorola said.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: So, It's Like A Sci-Fi Movie?

title: The Neediest Cases; Blind Liberian Immigrant Is Undaunted by Challenges
description: When warring factions staged a devastating battle in his hometown in Liberia in 1993, Zayzay Mulbah was forced to leave. When he left, he was frightened and weary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELTZER, BERNICE BOLOKER
description: SELTZER--Bernice Boloker. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Boloker and the late Mac Seltzer. Loving mother of Susan and Mark Koppelman and Michael and Judith Boloker. Adoring grandmother of Heidi and Matthew Resnick, Libby Koppelman, Judd and Laurie Boloker. Cherished great-grandmother of Myles. Devoted sister of Beverly Silverman. Dear aunt of Francine. Past Grand Officer, Eastern Star State of New York, Secretary of Heritage Chapter, volunteer extraordinaire at Methodist Hospital. Services Sunday, 10 AM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Ave. (Ave J), Bklyn. Visiting Saturday 7:30-9:30PM.

title: Hug a Japanese Banker? Nah! Lay on the Tough Love
description: A decade of financial turmoil appears to have taught Japanese policy makers the value of tough love: the surest way to restore a failing bank to health may be to let it collapse, not prop it up.

title: Holiday Albums; CHRISTINE LAVIN AND THE MISTLETONES:
description: ''The Runaway Christmas Tree: Favorite Holiday Songs and Bedtime Stories'' (Appleseed Recordings). Finally, it's been composed: the ultimate all-inclusive holiday song.

title: Red Sox' Checklist: Manager (Yes), Rodriguez (Maybe)
description: Ten years after he managed Michael Jordan with the Class AA Birmingham Barons, Terry Francona will manage the Boston Red Sox next season and be surrounded by star power again. Just who those stars are is the question.

title: Iraq, Through the Soldiers' Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAGOV, DUNJA
description: SAGOV--Dunja. Our beloved Dunja, who left so soon. We'll miss her always. Rest in peace. Memorial service Saturday, December 6th at 680 West End Avenue, 2:30PM

title: Tapping Toward Love In Celebrated Slippers
description: There was a time -- long, long ago, my children -- when Hollywood was the place where good musicals went to veg out. A racy, vivacious Broadway show like ''Pal Joey'' or ''Kiss Me, Kate'' would rush to California for a glamorous big-screen makeover and wind up with a lobotomy. Sure, there were exceptions. But more often than not, what finally lumbered into movie theaters resembled the neutered, empty-eyed Jack Nicholson at the end of ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.''

title: Reducing Abortions
description: To the Editor:

title: Antitax Group Starts Ad Effort Against Dean
description: Eleven months before Election Day, a conservative antitax group began television advertisements in Iowa and New Hampshire on Thursday that accuse of Howard Dean, a leading Democratic presidential hopeful, of planning to raise taxes on average families by $1,933.

title: AFTER 21 MONTHS, BUSH LIFTS TARIFF ON STEEL IMPORTS
description: Citing an improving economy and cost-cutting efforts by domestic steel makers, President Bush lifted tariffs on imported steel on Thursday, averting a trade war with Europe but risking a political backlash in some industrial states heading into the 2004 election.

title: Bush Sending Baker to Iraq to Deal With Its Debt Problem
description: President Bush named James A. Baker III, the former secretary of state, as his personal envoy to Iraq today to help the country grapple with its debt problem.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Five Fire Companies Expanded
description: The Fire Department said yesterday that it had increased the staffs of five engine companies, including one in Harlem near an engine company that was closed earlier this year. Staffing levels are a factor in how quickly a fire can be attacked. The city has 197 engine companies; a majority are operated by four firefighters. But the following engine companies will now work with five firefighters: Engine Company 35 in East Harlem, which is near Engine Company 36, which closed earlier this year; Engine Company 68 in Highbridge, the Bronx; Engine Company 84 in Washington Heights; Engine Company 257 in Canarsie; and Engine Company 275 in Jamaica. In June, the city agreed to reduce the number of firefighters on certain engine companies, but to restore the additional firefighter if the percentage of firefighters out on sick leave fell below an agreed-upon level. In November, sick leave fell to 7.9 percent, below the specified level of 8 percent. Stephen Cassidy, the president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, praised the department for the restorations.

title: Manufacturing Leap: Good News for Jobs, but Maybe Not for Investors
description: THE stock market came alive just over a year ago, and now its virtue as a forecasting tool is being confirmed by a surge in American manufacturing.

title: 36 Hours | Laguna Beach, Calif.
description: FOX'S ''The O.C.'' may make all of Orange County look like a vast and arrogant suburb by the sea, but there are still idyllic islands amid the sprawl and bulldozed billion-dollar hillsides. The county's crown jewel is tiny Laguna Beach, set on striking verdant slopes that plunge to the Pacific. Laguna, which started as an artists' colony in the early 1900's, has long been expensive, but the recently opened Montage Resort & Spa, with 262 rooms that start at $450 a night, has upped the luxury quotient considerably. Still, surfers, artists and a large cast of resident eccentrics give Laguna a bohemian edge. CHRIS DIXON

title: Hindu Nationalist Party Makes Unexpected Gains in India Vote
description: The Hindu nationalist party that leads India's coalition government decisively won three of four key state elections held on Monday, according to votes that were counted Thursday.

title: Picture Windows
description: STAINED glass, a hallmark of Victorian-era houses, is found today in homes of all architectural styles, whether a beach scene at an oceanfront condo or animals at a getaway lodge. Houses for sale include one to be auctioned and others priced from $144,000 to $1.2 million. Page 6.

title: Concert Policy: Three Coughs and You're Out
description: To the Editor:

title: A Young Jew, an Elderly Muslim and a Sentimental Bond
description: Before striking out for the hills of Anatolia near the end, ''Monsieur Ibrahim,'' which opens today in New York and Los Angeles, confines its attention to the Rue Bleue, a narrow, slightly shabby street in a working-class section of Paris. Adapted from Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt's novel (which was also made into a play), this modest, sentimental film looks nostalgically back on Paris in the mid-1960's and casts a loving, oblique glance at the French movies of that era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, WILLIAM F.
description: BAKER--William F., of Troy N.Y. on December 1, 2003 at age 90 at home in Londonderry, VT. Devoted husband of Helen (nee Foley). Beloved father of Ellen Thorner, Susan Carlucci, and Edward T. Also survived by six grandchildren, two great grandchildren, a brother Edward of Alabama and many nieces and nephews. Mr. Baker graduated from Manhattan College in 1933. He was the Controller and Director of Corporate Development for Cluett Peabody & Co. He retired in 1976. Memorials may be made to the Mountain Valley Medical Center in Londonderry and the Vermont Visiting Nurses Association of Chester whose care and devotion was vital in helping us provide a loving and peaceful environment for him over these past few years.

title: With a Load of New Albums Aboard, the Holiday Bandwagon Rolls
description: CHRISTMAS albums don't discriminate -- not by age, sex, race, chart position, genre or even religious affiliation. Sooner or later, it seems, every famous musician and countless unknowns have the urge to celebrate and/or capitalize on the holiday season. On most of the albums, chestnuts are roasted one more time, although a few songwriters try to come up with new seasonal sentiments. Perhaps it's the public-spirited urge to provide some variety as holiday songs take over sound systems and radio stations for the next few weeks. And perhaps it's the dream of joining the Christmas perennials.

title: One Top Political Figure Testifies for Another in South Dakota
description: For a few moments on Thursday, most of South Dakota's delegation to Washington occupied an unlikely space: a cramped, baby-blue courtroom in this isolated farming town of 2,376.

title: Sisters Make Most of N.Y.U.'s Welcome
description: Jennifer Gardikas did not stick around long enough in 2001 to accurately assess the promise or potential of the New York University women's volleyball team.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, two charts on Monday in the special Outlook issue of Business Day -- one showing the number of cellphone and fixed-line subscribers in China and the other showing central bank interest rates for Britain, the European Union and the United States -- carried incorrect scales. Corrected versions appear today, on Page C4.

title: Defense Asks Judge To Rule for Acquittal
description: The government rested its case on Thursday in the Olympic bribery trial.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Lawyer For Terror Suspect Tells Of Threat
description: A lawyer in Toronto representing a former terror suspect once held by the United States in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, said he would withdraw from all terror-related cases after finding a death threat on his telephone-answering machine. The lawyer, Rocco Galati, received the message after he held a news conference this week where his client, Abdurahman Khadr, admitted he had trained at a ''Qaeda-related camp'' in Afghanistan. Mr. Galati helped secure Mr. Khadr's return to Canada after he was released in Afghanistan last fall. An emotional Mr. Galati played the coarse message for reporters and said the voice was familiar. He said he believed the source to be an American or Canadian intelligence agency. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Mayor and Council Speaker Clash on Campaign Finance
description: The battle over a proposal to revamp the city's campaign finance laws escalated yesterday into one of the fiercest yet between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Gifford Miller, who is likely to challenge the mayor in 2005.

title: Holiday Albums; ''ASHANTI'S CHRISTMAS''
description: (The Inc./Island Def Jam). Half an hour of Christmas music from the unapologetically lightweight singer who was known, until recently, as the first lady of Murder Inc. (These days the record company is known by its less bloodthirsty abbreviation.) The six standards drift by pleasantly enough, and of the four new songs ''Christmas Time Again'' is probably the best; near the end, Ashanti tells a charming story about an understocked party. Still, you sometimes wish she were brave enough to ignore the unwritten law that requires every Christmas song to repeat the word Christmas as often as possible. KELEFA SANNEH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDNER, CORINNE
description: GARDNER -- Corinne. Of Great Neck, N.Y., at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Joan Roland and the late Wendy Parichy. Adored grandmother of David Parichy and Tika and Ari Roland. Dear sister of Ruth Frank. Services private. Contributions in her memory may be made to PBS Channel 13.

title: Yonkers Dodges Latest Cliffhanger Crisis Involving School District Cuts
description: Capping days of intense negotiations, city and state officials announced on Thursday that they had worked out a deal to avert hundreds of layoffs in the public schools, as well as the threatened cancellation of all athletic and extracurricular programs.

title: Interpol Puts Liberian Ex-Chief On World's Most-Wanted List
description: Interpol called Thursday for the arrest of the former Liberian president, Charles Taylor, for his suspected role in atrocities committed during Sierra Leone's 10-year civil war. Interpol put Mr. Taylor on its most wanted list by posting a ''red notice'' on its Web site, alerting police forces around the world to an arrest warrant issued by Sierra Leone in June.

title: ROCKWELL AUTOMATION SELECTS A CHIEF
description: Rockwell Automation, the world's largest maker of factory controls, promoted Keith Nosbusch to president and chief executive. Mr. Nosbusch, 52, has run Rockwell's control-systems business, its biggest unit, since 1998. He will succeed Don Davis, who will remain chairman, the company said. The appointment is effective Feb. 4. Mr. Davis, who turns 64 this month, has been chief executive since 1997 and chairman since 1998. His resignation is part of a succession plan the company has been working on for the last year, a spokesman, Steve Smith, said. Rockwell, which is based in Milwaukee, last month hired the treasurer of Honeywell, James Gelly, to succeed Michael Bless as chief financial officer.

title: Partisan Hacking in Congress
description: It sounds like a Beltway episode of ''The Pink Panther'': Congressional detectives have seized computers from the Senate Judiciary Committee in an investigation of how suspected Republican mischief-makers leaked minority Democrats' confidential memos to sympathetic media outlets. The sergeant-at-arms has called in espionage experts to help in grilling dozens of Capitol staff members. But the affair is hardly comical; in fact, it is further sad evidence -- as if any were needed -- of the blood-sport level of partisanship in Washington.

title: Iraq, Through the Soldiers' Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REBOLLEDO, RICHARD
description: REBOLLEDO--Richard. Died on December 2nd, 2003. He was born on July 12, 1923. He is survived by wife Ilse, daughters Stephanie Levy and Sandra Gwinn, sons Stephen Rebolledo and Richard Rebolledo Jr., granddaughters Maritza Kelesis and Tatiana Rebolledo, grandsons Alexander Zaro, Justin Gwinn, Alexander Rebolledo and Nicholas Rebolledo, and brother Alvaro.

title: Looting The Future
description: One thing you have to say about George W. Bush: he's got a great sense of humor. At a recent fund-raiser, according to The Associated Press, he described eliminating weapons of mass destruction from Iraq and ensuring the solvency of Medicare as some of his administration's accomplishments.

title: The Eagles' Formula: Three Backs, No Losing
description: The Philadelphia Eagles have three running backs who are sharing the ball, and sharing success.

title: Rio Journal; An American Family Abroad: Horror Strikes in the Night
description: The detectives at Rio de Janeiro's homicide division are a world-weary bunch, inured to the horrors of violent crime by their daily hunting down of killers in one of the world's most dangerous cities.

title: Chain Limits Drugs by Mail
description: The Walgreen Company said yesterday that it would not join any more insurance plans that force consumers to get 90-day prescription refills by mail, a practice that threatens sales at its 4,291 pharmacies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALPERIN, DAVID A.
description: HALPERIN--David A., 69, of New York City and Camden, ME, dedicated psychiatrist, cult expert, esteemed professor, author and editor of numerous publications including ''Psychodynamic Perspectives on Religion Sect and Cult'', published poet, loving husband, father, brother and uncle died peacefully Wednesday, December 3, 2003. Graduate of Stuyvesant H.S., Harvard University magna cum laude, University of Virginia Medical School. Services 11:30 AM Sunday, December 7, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Bush Avoids a Trade War by Lifting Steel Tariffs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 4  Citing an improving economy and cost-cutting efforts by domestic steel makers, President Bush lifted tariffs on imported steel on Thursday, averting a trade war with Europe but risking a political backlash in some industrial states heading into the 2004 election.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article in some copies on Sunday about the tennis doubles victory of Todd Woodbridge and Wayne Arthurs of Australia that put their country ahead by 2-1 in the Davis Cup final misstated the given name of the player whose record of 28 Cup appearances Woodbridge broke. He is Adrian Quist, not Arthur.

title: Priscilla C. Kidder, 86, Outfitter To Brides as Priscilla of Boston
description: Priscilla Comins Kidder, who rose to prominence as Priscilla of Boston, outfitting young brides as their numbers soared after World War II in embellished dresses that became synonymous with American matrimonial style, died on Sunday at her home in Winchester, Mass. She was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAVAGE, JOHN
description: SAVAGE--John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Savage associated with The Times from July 1983 until retiring in November 2001

title: School System Performance Getting New Measuring Sticks
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that his office was developing new ways to measure performance in the school system that would offer a far more sophisticated analysis than is currently gleaned from standardized test results.

title: Kyoto Treaty: The Future Is Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; TELEVISION:
description: ''Live at the Old Waldorf San Francisco, 6/28/78'' (Rhino Handmade/Elektra). Television, the band that put CBGB on the map in the mid-1970's, was less a punk band than what would now be called a jam band. But it was a New York jam band, barbed and dark and deliberately astringent. Its late-1970's studio albums were showcases for Tom Verlaine's songs and were constrained by the length of the LP. Now that Television's first albums have been reissued, this live set reveals what was missing: the constant, peripatetic interplay of Mr. Verlaine and Richard Lloyd on guitar and the dynamics of a rhythm section that brought jazz subtlety to basic, two-chord rock. The sound is pristine, illuminating each quietly picked harmonic or distorted squall from a band whose improvisations were tightrope-walking marathons. JON PARELES

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; PEARL JAM:
description: ''Lost Dogs'' (Epic). Pearl Jam's two-disc collection of unreleased songs and collectors' items is downright bipolar. The first disc lets the band have fun, with rowdy, straightforward rockers that are as close to garage-rock and punk as to the band's grunge; it includes one B-side, ''Yellow Ledbetter,'' that has often turned up in concert sets. The second disc turns inward, with longer, quieter songs that meditate over private and existential troubles, along with a few references to Christmas. Then it switches to goofy rap experiments. Either way, it's Pearl Jam taking a break from its sometimes overwhelming ambitions to let the songs emerge unadorned. JON PARELES

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; AARON CARTER:
description: ''Most Requested Hits'' (Jive). If you think those recordings of yourself singing as a child are embarrassing now, imagine how the teenage boy pictured on the front of this CD must feel. He is almost 16 and looks like a reasonably cool adolescent. And, as such, the squeaky pre-teenybopper hits that dominated Radio Disney like ''Aaron's Party (Come Get It)'' and ''That's How I Beat Shaq'' must make him cringe. I know they make me cringe. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Rumsfeld Confers With Afghan Leader and Warlords
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld returned on Thursday to Afghanistan, the opening front in America's campaign against terrorism, and urged Afghan warlords to surrender heavy weapons, discussed plans for quelling a lingering insurgency and pressed for economic development.

title: Who's Who on the Grammy List
description: OutKast (left), Beyonc, Jay-Z and Pharrell Williams led the list of Grammy Awards nominees announced yesterday. They received six nominations each. The awards ceremony is set for Feb. 8 in Los Angeles.

title: The Doctor and His Documents
description: There is no good explanation for why Howard Dean's office sought to have nearly half of his gubernatorial records sealed away in Vermont. In a compromise worked out last year with the state archivist, Dr. Dean, his eye on a presidential run, succeeded in having documents he considered sensitive sealed for 10 years. (His attorney, inexplicably, originally wanted 24 years.) His period of concealment, a decade, is four years longer than his most wary predecessors', and safely beyond the reach of the two presidential terms he covets. ''We didn't want anything embarrassing appearing in the papers at a critical time in any future endeavor,'' Dr. Dean explained at the time.

title: Timothy Egan
description: The Times reporter answered readers' questions about the Vanishing Point series on life in the emptying Great Plains.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Lawmakers Oust Leader
description: The City Council's Brooklyn members voted overwhelming yesterday to oust Councilman Lewis A. Fidler, left, as the chairman of their delegation. The vote was 15 to 0 in the 17-member delegation, with Mr. Fidler and James Oddo, another member, absent. Mr. Fidler will be replaced by Councilmen Bill de Blasio and Albert Vann as co-chairmen.

title: Holiday Albums; THE BLIND BOYS OF ALABAMA:
description: ''Go Tell It on the Mountain'' (Real World). The Blind Boys of Alabama, a gospel group founded in 1939, invites all sorts of guests for its Christmas album. It modestly turns itself into a richly harmonizing backup chorale for Aaron Neville, and it joins in hearty call-and-response with Tom Waits, George Clinton, Solomon Burke and Mavis Staples. Clarence Fountain, the Blind Boys' patriarch, gets cozy with Shelby Lynne in ''The Christmas Song,'' and the group even tries to accommodate recitations from Michael Franti and Meshell Ndegeocello. And when the Blind Boys perform a bluesy ''Silent Night'' on their own, they show they don't need any help. JON PARELES

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''MTV 2 HEADBANGERS BALL''
description: (Roadrunner). The old, long-abandoned MTV show for new metal videos was smartly re-energized this year with a focus wide enough to alter the market and broaden teenagers' tastes. This two-disc set, representing the artists shown on the program, includes some obvious big-name bands of the late 90's, like Marilyn Manson and Staind, but it also has bands like Lamb of God, Mastodon, Eighteen Visions and Meshuggah, excellent (if more hardbitten) underground groups that for once aren't being ignored by commercial interests. BEN RATLIFF

title: Brooklyn Murder Trial Is Shadowed by Fear and a Witness's Death
description: One witness to the killing refused to come to court at all. Another ran from the Brooklyn courthouse on Wednesday only to be forced to take the stand yesterday. A third testified at first that a man in the audience was the one she saw menacing the victim, but then, after a tearful admission that she had been threatened, she said it was the defendant.

title: Holiday Albums; ''WINTER KOLEDNICA: SEASONAL CAROLS FROM SLOVENIA''
description: (Naxos World). Slovenia, in central Europe, has held on to two kinds of unaccompanied seasonal songs: narrative songs so rhythmic they could be Slovene hip-hop, and choral songs declaimed in major-key harmonies, both originally sung by groups of English carolers. This collection intersperses the songs with ebullient instrumentals -- for bells, wooden flute, accordion, hammered dulcimer or zither -- that add variety. All that's missing is translations of lyrics, which could have been interesting: ''Probelelo Pole z Ovcama'' is described as a solstice song about three women who tear out a young man's heart. JON PARELES

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONAGRA FOODS, Omaha, Neb., the maker of Peter Pan peanut butter and Hebrew National hot dogs, said its board authorized the repurchase of up to $1 billion worth of common stock, equal to about 40 million shares.

title: Fanning Rwanda's Genocide
description: The butchering of more than half a million Rwandan Tutsis, roughly 70 percent of Rwanda's entire Tutsi population, during the spring of 1994 is one of the clearest cases of genocide since World War II. Regrettably, the international community did little to stop it. Now, belatedly, it has taken an important and welcome step, with Wednesday's conviction by a special international court of three leading organizers of that slaughter.

title: Holiday Albums; KENNY CHESNEY:
description: ''All I Want for Christmas Is a Real Good Tan'' (BNA). With all the songwriters in Nashville, one would think there'd be more original Christmas fare coming from country artists. Mr. Chesney's holiday CD is a centerpiece for the title song, about getting away from the snow and to the Caribbean. It's enough to make Jimmy Buffett jealous. There's plenty of filler, throwaways and sap here, and many of the elements that make Mr. Chesney stand out from his contemporaries are neutered. But there are two worthwhile duets, ''Christmas in Dixie'' with Randy Owen and ''Pretty Paper'' with Willie Nelson. NEIL STRAUSS

title: If Price Is No Object, the Roof's the Limit
description: THERE'S no such thing as over the top in hedonistic, self-indulgent Miami Beach. But the decadently appointed penthouses atop opulent hotels, bathed in sunlight and overlooking turquoise pools, pink sand and a glistening ocean, come close to being too much. Rented primarily for parties or business functions, they provide rich fantasy fodder for someone planning a weekend getaway and willing to drop a few thousand dollars a night for the experience.

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''SAVOY ON CENTRAL AVE.''
description: (Savoy Jazz). This glorious music has appeared in many forms over the years, but these two discs encapsulate the time and energy well: the sounds of the bands who played the clubs on Central Avenue in Los Angeles in the 1940's and 50's as recorded in the studio by the Savoy label. The discs contain some of the best jazz and R&B of the time, including Johnny Otis and his Orchestra, Slim Gaillard, Charlie Parker, Erroll Garner, Helen Humes and Big Jay McNeely; the purview of the label incorporated bebop's subtleties but tended more toward frantic good times. BEN RATLIFF

title: She's Aiming for the Stars, With Feet Planted in the Bronx
description: ''Honey,'' an upbeat little hip-hop fable that opens today nationwide, is not the kind of movie that will impress anyone with its originality. It may remind you, at various times, of ''Flashdance,'' ''Fame,'' ''8 Mile'' and ''Drumline,'' a list that could be expanded to include dozens of other movies about plucky young artists striving to make it big while remaining true to themselves and connected to the people around them. In this case the heroine is a cheerful, driven young dancer named Honey Daniels (Jessica Alba), who longs to break out of the hip-hop club scene into the world of music videos (from which the movie's director, Bille Woodruff, has emerged to make his feature-film debut).

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''THE BIGGEST RAGGA DANCEHALL ANTHEMS 2003''
description: (Greensleeves). Thanks mainly to Sean Paul, dancehall reggae is more popular in America than ever, but that doesn't make the world documented on these two CD's seem any less mysterious. Still, casual listeners may be surprised at how quickly these brusque electronic beats and pithy patois refrains become lodged in the brain. A few days after listening to Kid Kurrupt's ''Pride'' (which uses one of the year's best riddims, ''Coolie Dance,'' although the liner notes won't tell you that), you may find -- with horror, perhaps -- that the not-quite-feminist chorus is stuck in your head: ''Me a gal yuh take pride inna yuh pantie/And yuh never borrow none from yuh auntie/Independent!'' KELEFA SANNEH

title: Clark Says He Has Plan for Iraq, but Will Not Offer Details
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark assured a crowd at a college campus here on Thursday that he had a strategy to secure Iraq and bring American soldiers home, criticizing the Bush administration for not producing a timeline to withdraw troops.

title: At U.S. Meeting, Iraq Appears Open for Business
description: The room had the feel of a souk, a constant buzz, chatter in lots of languages, display tables showing off wares.

title: Foreman Resigns From HBO
description: George Foreman announced his resignation as a boxing analyst for HBO Sports yesterday after a 12-year run that began when he was still fighting. His last assignment will be in February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHICK, ALEXANDER
description: SCHICK--Alexander. Age 92 of Pawling, New York. Died on November 26, 2003 in Paris, France. He leaves two devoted stepchildren, Janine Luke and Anthony Evnin, two step-grandchildren, Luke and Timothy Evnin, and four step-great-grandchildren.

title: Devils Opt to Shoot More, Then Shut Down Capitals
description: After holding the Washington Capitals to one shot in the first period Thursday night, the Devils gathered to discuss staying alert against an opponent that was bad on offense and even worse on defense.

title: Ex-Chairman Of Chrysler Testifies in Suit
description: The former chairman of Chrysler, Robert J. Eaton, testified yesterday that Chrysler was never taken over in its 1998 transaction with Daimler-Benz, disputing a principal contention of the plaintiff in the suit, the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian.

title: Despite New Violence, Prosecutor Presses His Investigation Into Mexico's 'Dirty War'
description: Thirty years ago, Horacio Zacaras Barrientos, a peasant who lived not far from the tourist resort of Acapulco, was kidnapped by the Mexican Army as it swept through the state of Guerrero in hot pursuit of a handful of leftist guerrillas.

title: New Deal Is Not What Bothers Scott
description: Before the preseason, Nets Coach Byron Scott was asked what it would be like having to confront a three-game losing streak amid speculation about whether the Nets would extend his contract, which expires at the end of the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAREL, EZRA
description: HAREL--Ezra. To the Ezra Harel Family: May the love of friends and family be a source of comfort to you. Our deepest sympathy. The Law Firm of McLaughlin & Stern, LLP

title: Ailey Starts Its New Season by Remembering Its Founder
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opened its 45th anniversary season on Wednesday night at City Center with all the required glamour. The beautiful people were out in force -- fur coats and cashmere gleaming. Judith Jamison, artistic director of the company, was her usual slyly ebullient self as she welcomed the audience, taking a second bow as she entered the stage in order to show off her sweeping red evening coat, designed, she announced, by Geoffrey Holder. There was a full panoply of onstage board members, and Star Jones made a well-informed curtain speech. But the real star of the evening was Ailey himself, appropriately enough.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: EVENTS

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''TEDDY PENDERGRASS ANTHOLOGY''
description: (The Right Stuff/Capitol). This anthology focuses on the exquisite soul songs Mr. Pendergrass recorded for Philadelphia International Records from 1976, when he left Harold Melvin and the Blue Notes, to 1982, when his career was interrupted by a car crash. On these recordings, Mr. Pendergrass sounds equally smooth (and, when necessary, gruff) whether accompanied by an orchestra, a funk band or a synthesizer, and sometimes, as on ''I Can't Win for Losing,'' he's accompanied by all three. On ''Close the Door,'' a silky Gamble and Huff production, Mr. Pendergrass punctuates his pleadings with a shouted invitaion: ''Come here, woman!'' This is singleminded music, but it's also surprisingly versatile: some listeners will hear a great singer navigating the transition from soul to disco to 1980's R&B; others, no doubt, will be content merely to act out the lyrics. KELEFA SANNEH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROGOVIN, SANDRA L.
description: ROGOVIN--Sandra L. of West Orange, NJ. Beloved wife of Arthur. Devoted mother of Bari Lewart and Scott Rogovin. Beloved sister of Jean Diamond. Precious grandmother of Jacob and Benjamin. Services at BernheimApter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, NJ, Friday 2PM (1-800-938-6372).

title: Guantnamo Chaplain and His Wife Speak Out
description: At noon last Sept. 11, Huda Yee arrived at the Seattle-Tacoma airport for a long-awaited reunion with her husband, Capt. James J. Yee, a Muslim chaplain who was supposed to return home from Guantnamo Bay for a one-week leave.

title: Celebrating the Flesh: Its Fullness, Its Frailties, Its Forbidden Secrets
description: Whatever else can be said about ''Corporal Identity -- Body Language'' at the Museum of Arts and Design, it can't be viewed as scanting its subject. Skin, hair, orifices, veins, organs, face, feet, sex, birth, disease, plastic surgery, mind-body connections, human cloning and so on come under the relentless scrutiny of the 200-odd participating artists in this no-holds-barred anthology of attitudes toward the body and its relationship with the self.

title: After Taking Knee, Rangers Take Game
description: With criticism and trade talk swirling about him, Michael Peca, the Islanders' captain, did everything he could to make his presence felt against the Rangers on Thursday night at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Shrugging Off Pain and Age, Martin Runs At Milestones
description: After watching Curtis Martin shrug off injuries for nearly three seasons, his Jets teammate LaMont Jordan had to come to terms with his own limitations.

description: Fig is big.

description: Panel to Review Campaign for Alcohol

title: Inquiry on Steroid Use Gets Bonds Testimony
description: The Giants slugger Barry Bonds, a six-time most valuable player in the National League and baseball's single-season home run champion, appeared yesterday before a federal grand jury in San Francisco that is investigating a company accused of being at the center of a scandal involving anabolic steroids.

title: Going Beyond 'Carmina Burana,' and Beyond Orff's Stigma
description: Tonight at Avery Fisher Hall the National Chorale is opening its season with Carl Orff's ''Carmina Burana.'' Nothing special about that: the National Chorale and several other local amateur choruses, not to speak of hundreds or thousands more around the country and world, sing ''Carmina Burana'' most every year.

title: Knee Ligament In a Transplant Leads to Illness
description: Two years after a young Minnesota man died from an infection brought on by routine knee surgery, a Colorado teenager has become severely ill under similar circumstances, federal health officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALDMAN, ELVIRA HELFGOTT
description: WALDMAN--Elvira Helfgott. Of Easton, PA, on November 25, 2003. Beloved wife of Herman B. Devoted mother of Jessica, Bruce and Mark. Cherished grandmother of 11 grandchildren and best friend of her sister Lorraine Wishner. Elvira, a lady of class and style.

title: EQUITY FIRM BUYS PREPARER OF MILITARY FOOD RATIONS
description: Veritas Capital, a private equity firm based in New York, agreed to buy the Wornick Company, a maker of military food rations, for about $155 million. Wornick produces food used by American troops overseas, as well as ready-to-eat meals for humanitarian operations andHomestyle Express meals sold in convenience stores. Wornick, with 840 employees nationwide, expects to have $305 million in sales in 2003. ''Our plan is to grow the company organically as well as through acquisitions with the goal of reaching $1 billion in revenue in five years,'' Robert McKeon, president of Veritas Capital, said in a statement. The company, which is based in Cincinnati, will continue to be led by its existing management team, Mr. McKeon said.

title: Steinbrenner Aide Decides It's Time to Move On
description: As George Steinbrenner asserts more influence over the Yankees' organization, his inner circle is closing ever tighter. Gordon Blakeley, Steinbrenner's highest-ranking baseball operations official in Tampa, Fla., said last night that he and the Yankees are negotiating a buyout of his contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTIN, ELIZABETH ZAK
description: MARTIN--Elizabeth Zak. Our beloved aunt died December 2, 2003. Survived by John Zak III, MD of Daytona Beach, FL, Kristine Zak Zimmer of East Burne, NY, and Gerald F. Machacek Jr. of Flushing, NY. Viewing at Quinn's Funeral Home, Astoria, NY, 2-5 & 7-9.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: BIAS INQUIRY IN BEATING A group of white and Hispanic men punched and kicked two teenagers in Queens yesterday, an attack that the police said was being investigated as a possible bias crime. About 11 a.m., four or five men approached a black youth, who is 17, and a 15-year-old Hispanic boy and attacked them while shouting racial slurs, according to investigators. The victims suffered minor injuries, the police said. No arrests have been made. The incident followed two cases of vandalism in a predominantly Jewish neighborhood in Brooklyn, which the police said were possible bias crimes. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about Russia's likely rejection of the Kyoto treaty intended to curb global warming misidentified a cause of the warming. It is the emission of heat-trapping gases including carbon dioxide, not industrial toxic dust. The caption also referred incorrectly to 1990 data that were used to formulate the treaty. The data showed that Russia generated 17.4 percent of the heat-trapping gases released by industrialized countries, not 17.4 percent of the world's pollution.

title: When Stripes and Flowers Ruled, and Smocks Were All the Rage
description: If you missed the original Marimekko moment, which was at its international zenith in the 1960's and 70's, you probably weren't alive. In those days, it was hard to be unaware of the bright, boldly patterned fabrics, fashions and furnishings produced by the small but influential Finnish design company whose American power base was the legendary Design Research store on 57th Street in Manhattan. (It occupied a brownstone where the Four Seasons Hotel now stands.)

title: A soymilk maker hopes a creator of the 'Got milk?' campaign can do for soy what he did for dairy.
description: AN executive who helped develop the successful ''Got milk?'' campaign can now answer that question by replying: ''No. Got soymilk?''

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''THE CHEMICAL BROTHERS SINGLES 93-03''
description: (Virgin/Astralwerks). An endlessly exuberant disc sketching the decadelong career of the Chemical Brothers, the British duo that perfected the art of combining thumping breakbeats with blaring midrange. This is dance music for rock fans, or vice versa. The two members, Tom Rowlands and Ed Simons, find clever ways to keep ratcheting up the energy in their tracks: ''Hey Boy Hey Girl'' creates the illusion of five minutes of perpetual increase. This disc also includes two new tracks: ''Get Yourself High,'' a relatively pedestrian collaboration with the Canadian rapper K-OA, and ''The Golden Path,'' a suitably spaced-out track featuring the Flaming Lips. KELEFA SANNEH

title: Mary Tyler Moore, Chided by Neil Simon, Quits His Play
description: Hurt by harsh criticism from the playwright Neil Simon, Mary Tyler Moore has withdrawn from his latest comedy, ''Rose's Dilemma,'' which was to open at the Manhattan Theater Club on Dec. 18.

title: New Unemployment Claims Rise, but Slightly
description: The number of Americans filing first-time applications for state unemployment benefits rose to 365,000 last week, the government said yesterday, holding close to an almost three-year low.

title: Born in Iraq, Living in Israel, Pondering Issues of Identity
description: In the opening moments of ''Forget Baghdad,'' a fascinating but disorganized documentary that has double vision in more ways than one, its director, writer and narrator, Samir, states that what inspired this portrait of four Iraqi-born Jews living in Israel was his desire to explore what it's like to change your country, forget your culture and language, and ''become the enemy of your own past.'' Samir has compelling personal reasons for wanting to know. Born in Iraq but raised in Switzerland, he is the son of a Shiite Muslim who was also an ardent Communist.

title: Dean Organizers Take Lesson From Labor
description: The sun was setting over the wooded hills of western New Hampshire as David Steinberg, 22, a Columbia University student from Baltimore, asked 12 local Democrats to gather their chairs in a circle. Mr. Steinberg proceeded to tell his story -- of how he deferred law school to come here to work for Howard Dean -- and asked the others to ''share a little bit.''

title: National Briefing | Politics: Lieberman Seeks Junk-Food Investigation
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut called for a federal investigation into how companies market junk food to children. The announcement capped a week of family-oriented proposals from Mr. Lieberman. Campaigning in New Hampshire for the Democratic presidential nomination, he also said the government should create standards for food sold in public schools and for new nutritional labels to appear on food products and on menus and wrappers at national chain restaurants.

title: Returned To Life
description: ''I'm an educator,'' said David Protess. ''I try to teach my students to be better reporters, and a few times we've gotten lucky.''

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: MAN ARRESTED IN DEATH A man suspected in the killing of his aunt, the operator of a popular nursery school in Queens, was charged with murder yesterday. The suspect, Raymond M. Smith, 32, was arrested on Wednesday night after a car chase in Queens that ended with Mr. Smith crashing and being surrounded by the police. He was charged with second-degree murder in the death of Effie Lee Roseborough, 57, who for 27 years ran a nursery school in Richmond Hill. Mr. Smith was raised mostly by his aunt and helped her run the school for many years, and lived in an apartment above it. The police said Mr. Smith shot her at 7 a.m. Wednesday at the school. Mr. Smith was scheduled to be arraigned in Criminal Court in Queens this morning. Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: Delta and Pilots Start Talks on Concessions
description: Delta Air Lines and its pilots union have begun negotiating on wage and benefit concessions, and analysts are optimistic that an agreement can eventually be reached because of new leadership on both sides.

title: Deal to Indict N.Y.R.A. in the Works
description: The New York Racing Association will be indicted -- perhaps as early as today -- on charges of conspiracy, tax evasion and fraud, but in a deal with federal prosecutors it would be allowed to continue to operate Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga racetracks, according to a person familiar with the negotiations.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday erroneously reported the death of Katharine Sergava, a dancer and actress who portrayed the dream-ballet version of Laurey, the heroine, in the original production of ''Oklahoma!'' Details appear today on Page C11.

title: Greatest Hits, Live Albums And Compilations; ''TALES OF A LIBRARIAN: A TORI AMOS COLLECTION''
description: (Atlantic). This two-disc set includes a disc of greatest hits, plus four new songs, alongside a disappointing DVD with performances taken from a recent pre-concert soundcheck. Still, her greatest hits sound both dreamy and dangerous: on ''Silent All These Years,'' she sneers, ''So you found a girl who thinks really deep thoughts/What's so amazing about really deep thoughts?/Boy, you best pray that I bleed real soon.'' But here's the best part: every song is catalogued according to its Dewey Decimal Classification number. So ''Sweet Dreams,'' a new song that sounds a lot like an anti-Bush protest, is 973.938: History of North America -- Politics of Illusion. KELEFA SANNEH

title: Sports of The Times; In the U.S., It's the Law: Unintended Consequences
description: BARRY BONDS showed up at the federal courthouse here at 11 o'clock yesterday morning and didn't leave until roughly 4 p.m. He made two statements to the throng of reporters that staked out the courthouse during his appearance before a federal grand jury investigating a company that is accused of being central to a scandal involving anabolic steroids.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Mob Associate Faces Charges
description: Ronald Trucchio, who pleaded guilty in April to attempted racketeering in connection with a gambling operation that prosecutors said was run for the Gambino crime family, faces new charges, this time in Florida. Mr. Trucchio and nine other men were charged with racketeering in a federal indictment in the Southern District of Florida. Prosecutors linked the men to two unsolved New York crimes -- a 1995 bank robbery in Howard Beach and, in the same year, the robbery of an armored car company in Queens Village. The group was also connected to a stolen-automobile operation in Maspeth, the prosecutors charged. Four of the defendants were arrested yesterday in New York, and the other six, including Mr. Trucchio, were already in custody.

title: Holiday Albums; ''GENUINE HOUSEROCKIN' CHRISTMAS''
description: (Alligator Records). Holiday cheer and the blues have always been uneasy bedfellows. That is one reason blues Christmas classics are far rarer than the legendary jazz, rock and pop carols. And though zydeco Christmas favorites may be even rarer on holiday hearths, at least the energy of the music makes a more festive match. There is a little of both worlds here, with Koko Taylor, C. J. Chenier, the Holmes Brothers, Marcia Ball and Shemekia Copeland contributing mostly originals on a worthy hit-and-miss collection. In the end, Cephas and Wiggins contribute the best blues Christmas song of the moment. And yes, their baby left them on Christmas day. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Complaint Made Against Paroled Killer Is Dismissed
description: The woman whose assault charges a month ago led to the arrest of Thomas Trantino, the paroled killer of two New Jersey police officers, testified in court on Thursday that her accusations were lies.

title: South Beach: From Hot to Cold, Back to Hot Again
description: FOR the past few years, the word has gone out among the fashionable set: South Beach is so over. The litany of complaints piled up as this high-profile strip of Miami Beach seemingly fell victim to its own success. The place was too crowded. The traffic impossible. The hotel service inept. Ocean Drive now a fraternity-house nightmare of sports bars, fuzzy navels and hot body contests -- a ''South Street Seaport for tourists,'' in the words of Brett Sokol, a columnist for New Times, a Miami weekly.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Ex-Editor To Receive Award
description: The White House said President Bush would award the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian award, to Robert L. Bartley, a former editor for The Wall Street Journal. Mr. Bartley, 66, spent three decades overseeing the newspaper's editorial page, making it a leading voice among conservatives. The White House said the citation for the award would identify him as ''one of the most influential journalists in American history.''

title: Feeding the Well-Heeled Hearth
description: WHEN Dennis Paget and his wife, Nancy, went to a wedding in Ireland several years ago, the bridal couple put them up in a cottage that was heated by peat. ''And I fell in love with the aroma,'' said Mr. Paget, founder of Language American Style, a company that teaches business English and culture to foreign executives. ''It's hard to describe, but it smells like what you think an Irish cottage should smell like.''

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: PROSECUTORS SEIZE LIMBAUGH RECORDS Rush Limbaugh told listeners of his radio show that prosecutors in Palm Beach County had seized medical records from four of his doctors, but he called the investigation a "fishing expedition." Mr. Limbaugh, reading from a statement, denied any wrongdoing and said the medical records would clear him. The conservative commentator, who lives in West Palm Beach, was absent from his show for five weeks recently while spending time at a drug rehabilitation program because of his addiction to prescription painkillers. (AP)

title: Filmmaker Who Gravitates Toward Rising Stars
description: THE otherworldly intrusion of primal howls, human ones, no longer waft upstairs to the photographer/documentarian George T. Butler's Upper East Side pied--terre from the landlord's first-floor office. His genial landlord of two decades, a therapist devoted to the primal scream methodology, recently died, and the brownstone's exotic soundtrack went with him. Mr. Butler admits to calling the police the first time he heard yelps from down below, but lately he almost misses the aural stimuli. While he doesn't peg himself as much of a screamer, he regrets that he never let the therapist hypnotize him; in other ways, Mr. Butler's seems a life lived too close to the hilt to permit many regrets.

title: TV Weekend; What Did You Do In the War, Daddy?
description: ''Word of Honor,'' tomorrow night on TNT, revisits the Vietnam War to raise weighty questions about combat, truth and whether the two can coexist. Such questions, however, quickly prove too heavy for this wimp of a movie. Instead of confronting life's painful ambiguities, especially at a time when American soldiers are enduring another foreign crucible, it squanders its opportunity, taking refuge in platitudes and plot contrivances. You may not guess the ending, but by that point you may not care.

Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: There's a new view in town, on the 35th floor of the Mandarin Oriental Hotel, and Asiate, the hotel's restaurant, takes full advantage. The lucky few get to sit along the perimeter of the dining room, suspended over Columbus Circle and perfectly positioned to take in the panoramic sight of Central Park and beyond to the Upper East Side. Because the window tables are a few feet below dining-room level, everyone else gets a clear view as well. Noriyuki Sugie, Asiate's chef, has his work cut out for him to hold the attention of his diners.

Smith, 32, was arrested on Wednesday night after a car chase in Queens that ended with Mr. Smith crashing and being surrounded by the police. He was charged with second-degree murder in the death of Effie Lee Roseborough, 57, who for 27 years ran a nursery school in Richmond Hill. Mr. Smith was raised mostly by his aunt and helped her run the school for many years, and lived in an apartment above it. The police said Mr. Smith shot her at 7 a.m. Wednesday at the school. description: The Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday proposed designating all of New Jersey and Connecticut as being out of compliance with tougher anti-smog standards adopted several years ago. It also classified the rapidly growing counties west and north of New York City in such a way that could bring tougher emissions controls to these areas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMILTON, REVEREND MONSIGNORE LAMONT R.
description: HAMILTON--Reverend Monsignore Lamont R. Died December 3, 2003 at age 50. Born June 2, 1953 in Manhattan to Morris and Margaret E. (nee Coker) Hamilton. He was Ordained November 3, 1979 and was later named a Prelate of Honor by His Holiness, Pope John Paul II, November 25, 1999. He graduated from Fiorello LaGuardia High School for Music and Arts and did his Graduate Studies at the Juilliard School. Rev. Msgr. Hamilton was an Associate Pastor at the Church of Sts. Philip and James in the Bronx, Faculty Member at Cardinal Spellman High School in the Bronx, Director of the Office of Black Ministry for the Archdiocese of NY, Pastor of the Holy Rosary Church in the Bronx, Associate Pastor for Church of St. John the Evangelist White Plains and currently Associate Pastor at the Church of Sts. John and Paul in Larchmont. He was also a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. Survived by his loving brother Duane Hamilton, many cherished Aunts and Uncles, devoted Cousins and dearest friends The Shoemaker and Valentin Families. Visitation Saturday 7-9 and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 at Coxe and Graziano Funeral Home, 767 E. Boston Post Rd in Mamaroneck 914-698-5968. He will lay in state at Sts. John and Paul Church on Monday starting at 2pm. This will conclude with a Mass of the High Priest Monday night at 7:30pm. All are welcome to attend. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated by His Eminence Cardinal Egan, Archbishop of New York, Tuesday 10:30 am at Sts. John and Paul Church followed by an interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne.

title: A Lynching Memorial Unveiled in Duluth
description: Nations deal with nightmares the same way people do -- by trying to forget them. Among the nightmares that had faded from public memory in the United States until recently, none are more ghastly than the campaign of racial terror that gripped this country from the 1880's to the 1930's, when thousands of black Americans were hanged, mutilated, burned alive or dragged to death while huge crowds looked on.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Single Malt Distinction:
description: The liquor maker Diageo agreed to change the packaging of its Cardhu Pure Malt whiskey after rivals threatened to sue because they said it too closely resembled the packaging of Cardhu, a single malt whiskey. An industry group, the Scotch Whisky Association, was asked to rule on the packaging because of the distinction between single malt whiskeys, which are produced at individual distilleries, and Cardhu Pure Malt, which is a successor to Diageo's Cardhu single malt and contains whiskeys from different distilleries. Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: Two groups working to limit money in politics have asked the Internal Revenue Service to deny tax-free status to a charity that offers donors a chance to spend time with Representative Tom DeLay of Texas at the Republican National Convention and to have part of their donations help abused children.

I applaud the instinct, but I think that a moon shot alone seems more like reaching for past glory than striving for new triumphs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LABRAN, DOROTHY
description: LaBRAN--Dorothy. On December 4, 2003. Born in New York, March 13, 1914, she grew up and raised her family in her home town until she and her late husband Leo retired to Margate, Fla in 1975. title: Too Few Hires, Still
description: America's gross domestic product grew at a China-like 8.2 percent rate in the third quarter. The productivity growth and manufacturing activity numbers released this week were the best in two decades. Corporate profits are at record highs, consumer confidence is rising, and interest rates remain low. All of which makes November's anemic jobs report, released yesterday, so disappointing. It was, to be fair, the fourth-consecutive month of added jobs, and the unemployment rate dropped to 5.9 percent. Still, the 57,000 jobs created in the month were far below expectations, and fell short of the 200,000-plus needed per month, on average, to reduce the unemployment rate substantially.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Nokia Slips
description: Nokia, the world's largest mobile phone maker, lost market share in the third quarter to rivals including Motorola and Samsung, according to a Strategy Analytics study. Nokia, which is based in Finland, has been slower than its competition to introduce clam-shell shaped mobile phones that have been popular with consumers. Nokia's global market share dropped to 33.8 percent in the third quarter of 2003 from 36 percent in the second quarter, the study said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Moratorium On Executions Ends
description: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo reinstated capital punishment after an outcry from supporters of the death penalty, who blamed the moratorium for a rise in crime. ''Much as I am averse, as a matter of moral principle, to the taking of human lives in this manner, the president must yield to the higher public interest when dictated by extraordinary circumstances,'' Mrs. Arroyo said in a statement. Her reversal drew criticism from human rights groups. The death penalty was removed from the Constitution in 1987 but a series of sensational crimes in 1992 prompted Congress to reinstate it in 1993. Executions started in 1998, but President Joseph Estrada stopped executions in January 2001. By then, only seven of more than a thousand convicts on death row had been executed. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Exports Rise

Shipments to the United States rose to their highest level since July 2002, according to the data. After posting what economists said was weak export data in August and September, Malaysia's latest export figures have helped allay fears that the country was being left behind by Asia's export recovery. title: Taking a Spin In the Old Monkmobile

They are the texts that every jazz musician can live by, with worldbeating melodies, streaks of chilly irony and ocher-colored, down-home beauty, and -- this is important -- their dance impulse. No other jazz translates directly through the body better than Monk's. He had access to some eternally fresh code of rhythm.

title: That Turkey You Ate

title: The Rural Life; Over the Fence
description: By 2:30 the other morning, the moon had dropped well down in the west, behind the birches. Just enough snow had fallen to reflect the moon's light. The stars overhead were washed out by the vaporous glow. It was almost as light as it is on a dark December noon, when the clouds look like snow. There aren't enough lamps in the house -- in the world -- to offset the darkness outside in the country at this time of year, so my day contracts with the natural light. I become just one of the animals. By early afternoon, our two turkeys, Tom and Pearl, have fluttered up to their high roost above the chicken-yard fence. The chickens are roosting in their houses, and the horses are giving me significant looks over the pasture gate. The ducks have laid a trail of cuneiform footprints back to the duck pen through the snow.

title: Going Wholesale in Iowa
description: For more than three decades, the Iowa presidential caucuses and the New Hampshire primary have been hailed as the last hopes for keeping the candidates focused on human-scale retail politicking. Iowa and New Hampshire have a right to lead the primary pack, the theory goes, because they are small down-home venues where contenders are forced off the TV-commercial treadmill to mingle directly with ordinary voters posing plain questions about real life. This plebeian notion is epitomized by the ''Our Town'' image of Jimmy Carter carrying his own garment bag in 1976 to Iowa, where he scored his political breakthrough by finishing second to ''undecided'' in the caucus tallies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMILTON, REVEREND MONSIGNORE LAMONT R.
description: HAMILTON--Reverend Monsignore Lamont R. Died December 3, 2003 at age 50. Born June 2, 1953 in Manhattan to Morris and Margaret E. (nee Coker) Hamilton. He was Ordained November 3, 1979 and was later named a Prelate of Honor by His Holiness, Pope John Paul II, November 25, 1999. He graduated from Fiorello LaGuardia High School for Music and Arts and did his Graduate Studies at the Juilliard School. Rev. Msgr. Hamilton was an Associate Pastor at the Church of Sts. Philip and James in the Bronx, Faculty Member at Cardinal Spellman High School in the Bronx, Director of the Office of Black Ministry for the Archdiocese of NY, Pastor of the Holy Rosary Church in the Bronx, Associate Pastor for Church of St. John the Evangelist White Plains and currently Associate Pastor at the Church of Sts. John and Paul in Larchmont. He was also a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. Survived by his loving brother Duane Hamilton, many cherished Aunts and Uncles, devoted Cousins and dearest friends The Shoemaker and Valentin Families. Visitation Saturday 7-9 and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 at Coxe and Graziano Funeral Home, 767 E. Boston Post Rd in Mamaroneck 914-698-5968. He will lay in state at Sts. John and Paul Church on Monday starting at 2pm. This will conclude with a Mass of the High Priest Monday night at 7:30pm. All are welcome to attend. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated by His Eminence Cardinal Egan, Archbishop of New York, Tuesday 10:30 am at Sts. John and Paul Church followed by an interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Increase In Employment
description: Employment in Canada grew during November for the third month in a row, the national statistics agency said, confirming signs of an economic rebound. The unemployment rate dipped to 7.5 percent, from 7.6 percent in October and 8 percent in September. The 54,000 jobs created last month brought the total since August to 168,000, more than three times the number created in the first eight months of the year. With business activity quickening in the United States, analysts have recently lifted their estimates for growth north of the border in 2004. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: WEST VIRGINIA: RELIEF FOR DUPONT The State Supreme Court overturned an order for DuPont to pay for blood tests for 50,000 people in Wood County who say a chemical used to make Teflon, C-8, has contaminated their water supply. In a 4-to-1 ruling, the court said DuPont had not been given proper notice that the residents were seeking an injunction. The residents said using ammonium perfluorooctanoate at the lone Teflon plant in the United States, in Washington, just west of Parkersburg, had affected their health.    (AP)

title: AMR CORP. APPOINTS CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, said yesterday that James Beer, its vice president for Europe and Asia, would become its chief financial officer. Mr. Beer, 42, succeeds Jeffrey Campbell, who said last month that he was leaving to become chief financial officer at the McKesson Corporation. Mr. Campbell replaced Tom Horton, who left in June 2002 to go to AT&T. Mr. Beer joined American in 1991 as a financial analyst and had held the overseas post since June 2002. Craig S. Kreeger, 44, a vice president and general sales manager, will succeed Mr. Beer in the Europe-Asia job, AMR said.

title: Unneeded Quarrel Over Taiwan
description: The ambiguous relationship between mainland China and Taiwan clearly serves both sides. Taiwan's 23 million people enjoy one of Asia's liveliest democracies and highest living standards. Despite living in the shadow of a much larger nuclear power that claims ultimate sovereignty over their island, the Taiwanese run their own affairs. Meanwhile, most of the world officially recognizes Beijing's claim to be the government of all China. The highly nationalistic Communists can claim that Taiwan has not broken away and that the dream of reunification remains intact. China also benefits from billions of dollars in Taiwanese investments.

title: The Farrellys' Double Vision
description: TWO boys in pajamas lie sleeping in the quiet bedroom of their big Rhode Island house. Suddenly, downstairs -- boom! -- the front door slams. Their eyes pop open and their hearts start thumping. ''Oh, geez, what did we do?'' they wonder. And then, as the angry stomping starts up the steps, they remember. The label gun. As their mother left for a regional bridge championship that evening, they'd patted her on the back, saying how nice she looked, while surreptitiously sticking a little embossed piece of tape on her dress. Toward the end of the tournament, a friend finally took her aside, and now Mariann flies into their room in a fury, brandishing a fly swatter. ''This will never, ever be funny!'' she cries, swatting -- and it isn't the first time; at 11 and 9, the boys are already screw-ups, wastrels, layabouts, inveterate practical jokers. But if she's right that it's unforgivable to have sent her out to a dressy event with a label on her back that says ''I Just Pooped,'' she's wrong about its not being funny -- and, despite the boys' chagrin and their mother's mortification, they all know it. Or will soon. A mere decade or two later she will be able to laugh about the experience.

Democratic legislators then suggested making the increase more palatable to commuters by using part of the proceeds to eliminate the parkway tolls. But opposition appears to be mounting. Jon Orcutt of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign called the idea ''a revenue shell game, taking a significant part of new revenue to replace existing revenue.''
