title: GARDENING
description: As a genre, gardening books must surely outdo any other in terms of shape, size and weight. This consignment ranges from a neat paperback that could comfortably be read in bed to an encyclopedia so hefty that I needed help to carry it up a flight of stairs. Several others are of such dimensions that they would overflow the average bookshelf by many inches -- designed as a flat slab flaunting the dramatic cover photograph of a perfect rose or apple. All very well for point-of-sale display, but a confounded nuisance when you get the thing home and are faced with the problem of where to put it; some of these would swamp the average coffee table, let alone bookshelf. And of course the reason for this gigantism is illustration: luscious full/page state-of-the-art photography, eclipsing the text entirely. Many of these books are for looking at quite as much as for reading. Frankly, there are moments when one yearns for those sober, text-heavy Victorian and Edwardian manuals, with just a sprinkling of chaste diagrams and few decorous watercolors.

title: School Away From School
description: Andy Markishtum's hair reaches past his shoulders, thick and shining. He speaks in a low monotone, a rocker growl, and his favorite band is Cradle of Filth. As a student at McKay High School in Salem, Ore., Andy was part of the stoner crowd -- a self-described slacker with a backpack full of half-finished assignments. ''I'd get too distracted,'' he says. ''There would be kids sitting right next to me talking or something, and instead of paying attention to the teacher, I would drift off. Someone would drop a book, and I'd have to look.'' Attention-deficit disorder was diagnosed; for a while, Andy took Ritalin, but it gave him migraines. His mom decided he needed to get out of McKay and leave behind his old scene, his old messed-up self. Andy enrolled in Salem-Keizer Online high school, and he says, ''Now I can really concentrate.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARON, HERMAN THEODORE (H.T.B.)
description: BARON--Herman Theodore (H.T.B.), age 89, born in Yonkers, NY, passed away on November 29, 2003. He lived and worked in Riverdale, NY for most of his adult life. A stellar husband to his late wife, artist Hannelore (nee Alexander) Baron. Always the most generous and loving father to Julie Delyannis and Mark Baron. A cherished grandfather to Tara Ryan and Evan Shenkman. Great-grandfather to Sedona and Elliot Ryan, who he would have so enjoyed knowing. Father-in-law to David Delyannis and Elise Boisante. A devoted son to Henry and Fannie (nee Levine) Baradinsky and, until his death, the last surviving brother to five siblings he loved so much, Murray, Oscar, Harry, Charlie and Celia Schnapper. Loving uncle to Kal Schnapper and to many other nieces and nephews. Herman served proudly in the US Air Corps during WWII and was stationed in Iceland. He was honored with numerous awards for exemplary service. He owned and operated Baron's Book Shop in Riverdale, NY for many years, and then managed the bookstore at Horace Mann Prep and the Union Theological Seminary before retiring in the 1970s. All through his life Herman took real joy in making people laugh. He was a jokester of the most loving sort, and used his natural optimism to uplift the spirits of those around him. He did everything he could for those whose lives touched his, never accepting anything in return. A brilliant man, yet simple things made him happy--classical music, The New York Times, a beautiful day, a hot cup of coffee and a bun. Everyone who knew H.T. Baron--even those who knew him briefly--loved him immensely. He will never be forgotten and will be missed forever.

title: Climb to Conquer
description: John Jennings, a twenty-one-year-old infantryman with the 87th Regiment of the 10th Mountain Division, steadied his ski and slipped one leather boot between the toe irons. In the darkness, he felt for the cable loop and positioned it around his heel. Then he snapped the forward throw closed - a familiar, comforting sound - locking his boot to the ski. Kneeling, he repeated the process with the other boot and binding. It was January 1945. Snow coated the cobblestone streets of Vidiciatico, a medieval farming village in Italy's Northern Apennine Mountains. A few miles to the north, the German army had dug in for the winter along a series of high ridges, forming a defensive shield that U.S. Army mapmakers dubbed the Winter Line.

title: FINAL ACCORD AT MEADOWLANDS

Not exactly an enticing offer -- and hardly one you would expect from a man who was the Russell Stover Candy salesman of the year in 1981 and, four years later, the designer of a ticket-sale computer system that led to the formation of Ticketmaster.

title: The Disability Gulag
description: I've been in the disability service system for 37 years -- since the birth of a child with multiple disabilities who, I was advised by doctors, would be ''better off'' in an institution. My child died when she was 7, and I was fortunate that I never had to follow that advice. I was also fortunate to have been involved in the efforts to close New Hampshire's single institution for people with disabilities, Laconia State School and Training Center. In fact, I spent some time at that institution monitoring (for the court that mandated its closure) the plans to move residents back to their communities. Unlike Johnson, I wasn't using a wheelchair, nor was I at risk of being mistaken for ''the new girl.'' But I observed the same things she did -- especially the overwhelming waste of the lives of people who, like Johnson and my friends with disabilities, could have had a free and productive life.

title: TRAVEL
description: THERE'S no use pretending that the travel book of the season is anything other than Jan Morris's omnibus THE WORLD: Travels 1950-2000 (Norton, $27.95), though I've never been a fan of Morris's myself. The tweediness, the jauntiness and those overstuffed sentences -- that endless pileup of adjectives and adverbs! Morris might be E. B. White's idea of hell. Bathos battles cuteness: ''Russia in winter is a dread and dreary country, clogged alike with sludge and dogma; but fly into Leningrad as I did, and your very glands will be rejuvenated.'' ''When, sitting on a San Francisco bench, I see another ruined and ravaged victim of the 60's shambling by, I think: O City, City, I can sometimes hear, your siren song of Haight and Ashbury!'' I set about plowing through 50 years' worth of her travel journalism with the sensation of hacking my way through underbrush.

title: For Parents, the Fear Factor Grows
description: IF you grew up having your engine stoked by horror films like ''Night of the Living Dead'' or ''Jaws'' or ''The Last House on the Left,'' not to mention ''The Texas Chainsaw Massacre,'' ''Halloween'' and ''Nightmare on Elm Street,'' you learned that fear was close to home. Such movies dispensed with the dreamy, faraway mythology of Dracula and the Wolf Man and Frankenstein; they placed the terror in the audiences' own backyards, or at least on the local beach. These moviegoers also had tabloids packed with back-alley stories about cannibalism, gunplay and entertainingly lurid crimes -- too good to be true but too good to put down. Where can this audience, now parents and grandparents, find its chills these days?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADELSON, HOWARD L.
description: ADELSON--Howard L. The American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Howard L. Adelson, a distinguished professor of Medieval Studies and History at City College and the Graduate Center of the City of New York. A great humanitarian and advocate of Israel, Howard provided years of service to The Hebrew University, chairing the Academic Advisory Committee for the Rothberg International School. As President of The Anna Sobol Levy Foundation, which enables young officers from the U.S. armed services to study at Hebrew University, Howard strengthened the relationship between the US and Israel. Howard was a longstanding member of AFHU's Board and Executive Committee and an honorary vice president. He received an honorary fellowship from Hebrew University in 1985 in recognition of his tireless efforts to enhance the University's growth and global reputation. We extend our deepest sympathies to Howard's beloved children, Mark and Sara, his grandchild and the entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew Unversity Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Peter T. title: The Perfect Prince
description: The beginnings of his story, as he told it, lay deep in the turmoil of the recent history of England. For three decades, to the astonishment of foreigners, the crown had been wrestled back and forth between the Houses of Lancaster and York. Henry V, the glory of Lancaster and the victor of Agincourt, had been followed in 1422 by a child-king, Henry VI, who grew into a saintly fool at the mercy of his scheming lords. England quickly descended into factional warfare, with extraordinary slaughter of the nobility on both sides. In 1460 Richard, Duke of York, claiming descent from Edward III, tried to proclaim himself king but was rebuffed and, in short order, killed. The next year, his son defeated Henry in battle and was crowned as Edward IV at Westminster.

description: Kathryn Lynne Saurack, the daughter of Carole and Walter Saurack of Clifton Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Axel Ashworth Barcroft, a son of Birgitta Barcroft of Dublin and Stephen Barcroft of Puckane, Ireland. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Keeping It Together by Living in Public
description: INVARIABLY dressed rather primly, rational and affable in her manner, Sophie Calle resembles neither a voyeur nor an exhibitionist. Yet over the last 25 years, through a ceremonial exploration of hidden lives and emotions, she has emerged as one of France's most unusual artists. She might be called a conceptual artist, but in reality her work is best defined by what she does: she studies the world and her place in it, and she examines others' views of the world and their places in it.

description: Vitali Klitschko left only one question unanswered last night as heavyweight boxing returned to Madison Square Garden for the first time in three years: Will Lennox Lewis come back to fight him again?

title: Love in the Time of No Time
description: I can't remember ever being so embarrassed at working in the dating/personals industry as I was reading about ''Greg'' in Jennifer Egan's article. Here's a guy who, although he's got a pretty appealing girlfriend in ''Sam,'' preps for a trip to San Francisco by making pre-arranged dates with two women he's never met and preparing ''a list of 19 bars he was interested in checking out.'' It's no wonder he needs the power of online personals to provide him with a steady stream of women. And it's no surprise that the growing dating sites are the ones that work hard to eliminate ''players'' rather than allowing ''Gregs'' to browse for their next anonymous score.

title: Once Again at the Garden, Theres Room to Rumble
description: On most Saturday nights, Kendall Holt works the floor at the Target department store stocking yoga mats and sports bras near his apartment in Paterson, N.J. But last night, Holt took the night off. Along with a dozen or so other talents and hopefuls, Holt, a 22-year-old light welterweight, fought on the undercard in the place where fight dreams are supposed to come true, Madison Square Garden.

title: Money Manager Resigns at Janus
description: The Janus Capital Group , a mutual fund company that is being investigated for improper trading, said yesterday that Michael Buchanan, who runs the $768 million Janus High-Yield fund, is resigning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, JEANETTE H.
description: ADLER--Jeanette H. Beloved mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother and sister, but, first and foremost, Jeanette was the loving wife, partner and soulmate of the late Edward. Together, Jeanette and Ed mastered duplicate bridge and shared their enthusiasm with countless bridge players in the New York City area at their Lefrak City and Kissena Bridge Clubs and in many regional tournaments. In lieu of flowers, contribution to the Alzheimer's Disease Association, The American Kidney Fund or the Hole in the Wall Camps will help make a difference. Funeral service on Sunday, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Archaeology of Maleness Reaches Back ... and Back Again
description: THE emperor Elagabalus appointed ministers in Rome through a competitive appraisal that Edward Gibbon, the 18th century historian of the Roman empire, described delicately as one based on ''enormitate membrorum.''

title: As Iranian Elections Approach, Voters Lose Faith in the Reformers
description: In 1997 Lida Salehi enthusiastically worked on the presidential campaign of Mohammad Khatami, the reformist candidate. She even talked her parents, who had not cast a ballot since the referendum in 1979 that turned Iran into an Islamic Republic, into voting for him.

title: ART
description: THERE was a time when catalogs for art exhibitions were small enough to carry around from picture to picture, giving gallerygoers a handy source of information beyond what wall panels could convey. Headphones provide that service now, and catalogs have swollen to the size of encyclopedias. In the meantime, government and university subsidies for the specialized art monograph have all but dried up. As a consequence of these developments, you will now find some of the liveliest current writing on art in these often unwieldy exhibition guides, and some of the most vivid reproductions. Spectacular shows were mounted this year, on a scale many thought impossible in our time of wary travelers and warier insurers, with equally eye-opening books in their wake. Leonardo! The First Cities! Romare Bearden! Opening now at a bookstore near you.

title: Maybe It's the Orange Roof: Bronx Scoffs at Howard Johnson Inn
description: Political and business leaders in the Bronx have long lamented that the borough does not have a real hotel to accommodate executives, tourists and relatives visiting overcrowded apartments. So one would think that the construction of a Howard Johnson Express Inn in West Farms, practically in the center of the borough, would bring universal cheers.

description: Best Bet

description: WHILE General Motors is counting on the GTO to put some excitement back into Pontiac, the company reserved a trick or two for its full-size Bonneville sedan.

description: THE contrast is so New York: on one block on a recent sunny Saturday, restrained crowds of grown-ups in dark glasses waited for outdoor tables at Pastis, a hot see-and-be-seen restaurant in the ultra-hip Gansevoort Market meatpacking district. On another, at the Bleecker Playground, howling children in colorful clothing cavorted excitedly under a shimmering canopy of bright yellow ginkgo and maple leaves.

description: Ron Artest was about to put in a breakaway layup when Derrick Coleman clocked him, sending him sprawling, chipping his tooth and bloodying his mouth. Last season, someone or something would have had to pay, be it Coleman, a referee or an object in or around the Indiana Pacers' locker room.

description: ON one side of the postcard is a picture of a solemn Windsor Castle guard playing a drum in his wooly fur hat and bright red tunic. On the flip side is a hand-scrawled message: ''You are the greatest drummer in the world. Really.''

description: Allison Charlene Bonner, a daughter of Charles W. Bonner Sr. of Fayetteville, N.C., and the late Alice Morgan Bonner was married yesterday on the island of St. Thomas to Clinton Kenneth Shillingford, the son of Cora Shillingford of Brooklyn and Clinton Keith Shillingford of Charlotte Amalie, V.I. The Rev. Allan S. Jones, a nondenominational Christian minister, officiated at the Akwaaba Mansion, a bed-and-breakfast in Brooklyn.

title: Margaret Singer, a Leading Brainwashing Expert, Dies at 82
description: Dr. Margaret Singer, a leading expert on brainwashing who testified in several high-profile cases contending that various groups inappropriately manipulated their members to control their behavior, died on Nov. 23 in Berkeley, Calif. She was 82.

title: Pucker Up and Chow Down
description: Inspired by her childhood love of lemons, Andrea Honan opened the charming Lemon Lounge in downtown Basking Ridge. Inside the cozy one-room establishment, her salute to citrus is unmistakable, with ornately framed paintings of lemons positioned on deep blue walls, sparkling lemon slices hanging on strings from a chandelier and yellow tabletops decorated with pictures of lemons and lemon recipes.

title: Q and A; Visiting Farms in Europe
description: Q. We are small-scale farmers interested in visiting farms of our European counterparts. Aside from the usual agritourism, are there any organized tours that visit farmers and their operations in Italy or France? -- Leo Sances, Berlin, Wis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEEN, RENEE
description: GEEN--Renee. The Barnard College community grieves for the loss of its long time faculty member, Professor Renee Geen, an inspiring and generous teacher of French for nearly 50 years. Professor Geen was an admired and devoted member of our community who will be greatly missed. In addition to her dedication to teaching, she joined three colleagues as an author of a key French grammar and literary text, which was adopted by leading colleges in the country. A memorial service will be held on the Barnard campus in the Spring semester. We extend our condolences to her husband, Stanley Geen, her children, and other family members and friends. Elizabeth S. Boylan Provost and Dean of the Faculty Barnard College

title: When Films Started Talking, He Taught Them to Sing
description: THE camera pulls back from a shuttered feed and grain shop, then cuts to various angles on an empty street, litter blowing along it. A stray dog snarlingly attacks a crumpled poster advertising ''Kitty Darling and Her Gaiety Girls.'' In the distance a band plays ''Alexander's Ragtime Band.'' Another cut and we see a crowd hurrying toward a parade, followed by an overhead shot of Kitty (played by the legendary Helen Morgan) in a horse-drawn carriage throwing flowers to the rubes. The camera moves in on a bass drum. It is match-cut to another drum, this one in a theater's orchestra pit. Shots of bored musicians, then up-angles on meaty chorus-girl legs in sagging tights. They are doing a sad little kick chorus, not always in unison. Shots of their somber, affectless, unpretty faces -- they are not trying to sell their number; they're just trying to get through it. Kitty enters. She may be the star of the show, but her performance is only marginally less desultory than the chorines.

title: 'Caroline,' Kennedy And Change
description: THE Kennedy assassination has been shoved back into cold storage for another decade. Two-thirds of the population had not yet been born on Nov. 22, 1963, and so the 40th anniversary quickly gave way to the bulletins from Neverland. TV had struck up the usual medley of tarnished Camelot, ''what if'' scenarios and Where They Were When They Heard the News nostalgia -- all set to the well-worn forensic percussion of conspiracy, with its bullet trajectories and grassy knoll. But even Zapruder had lost its zing.

description: The Nobel Prizes will be awarded on Wednesday in Oslo and Stockholm, including the Peace Prize to Shirin Ebadi, the Iranian human rights activist and women's rights lawyer.

description: THE climax of the new film ''The Last Samurai'' is no ordinary fight scene: It is a coda to Japan's medieval past and a nod to its enduring fighting spirit.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about photographic images that come to define a war referred incorrectly to the iconic picture of a helicopter evacuation at the end of the Vietnam War. The site was an apartment building in Saigon, not the American Embassy.

title: Funds for Iraq Are Far Short Of Pledges, Figures Show
description: Six weeks after organizers of an international donors conference in Madrid said that more than $3 billion in grants had been pledged to help Iraq with immediate needs, a new World Bank tally verifies grants of only $685 million for 2004.

description: BY 11:15 a.m. on a recent Friday, Wendell Bowman had been on patrol for several hours. He had taken a trapped skunk from a resident's yard and released it in Blue Mountain Reservation.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: BOOKSHELF
description: THE STONE LAMP: Eight Stories of Hanukkah Through History. By Karen Hesse. Illustrated by Brian Pinkney. Hyperion. $18.99. (Ages 9 and up) As the midwinter holiday extends over eight nights, there is time enough and reason for family conversation about Jewish history. Here, the author of ''Out of the Dust'' briefly tells of historic incidents, and accompanies them with free-verse commentary, from the burning of Clifford's Tower in England in 1190 to book burning in Paris in the 13th century to the 20th century and Kristallnacht in 1938.

title: Metrosexual
description: 'The promotion of metrosexuality was left to the men's style press,'' wrote Mark Simpson in the British newspaper The Independent in 1994, coining a term that has made a home for itself in the vocabulary of the new millennium. ''They filled their magazines with images of narcissistic young men sporting fashionable clothes and accessories. And they persuaded other young men to study them with a mixture of envy and desire.''

The future Fed chairman praised the institution's managers for building it up ''to a vibrant and healthy state, with a strong net worth position.''

description: When Antonio McDyess was at his lowest point last year, when he thought his knee would never heal and his career was over, Nick Van Exel would reach out to him by phone. He would tell McDyess to be quiet.

title: Support Pledged For Spano Tax Plan
description: Westchester's mayors and supervisors have agreed to support County Executive Andrew J. Spano's latest proposal to raise the sales tax by one percentage point in exchange for receiving a portion of the income such a tax would generate, said Larry S. Schwartz, deputy county executive and a spokesman for Mr. Spano. Municipalities - including the cities of Rye and Peekskill - would receive about 20 percent of the $87 million such an increase would generate the first year, and one-fourth of the $105 million it would earn in the next 12 months.

title: An Advocate for Times Readers Introduces Himself
description: WHEN The New York Times invites you to be the first person charged with publicly evaluating, criticizing and otherwise commenting on the paper's integrity, it's hard to say no: this is a pretty invigorating challenge. It's also hard to say yes: there are easier ways to make friends.

title: Mary Jane Russell, 50s Fashion Model, Is Dead at 77
description: Mary Jane Russell, a leading fashion model of the 1940's and 50's who was a favorite of the photographers Louise Dahl-Wolfe and Irving Penn, died on Nov. 20 in Charleston, S.C. She was 77.

description: PAT Sheridan is the kind of volunteer any PTA would love to have -- an advocate for children who is a head of the playground committee, lobbies the school board, works at the book fair and visits the first-grade classroom at the Post Road Elementary School in White Plains to help with the reading program

title: A Sad Coda To 20 Years Of Singing
description: IN a stark illustration of how precarious life is for cultural organizations outside a major city, the Opera Festival of New Jersey, based in Princeton, recently closed operation, after 20 years of building itself into a respected regional institution.

title: Habitats/Larchmont, N.Y.; A Former Texan Immortalizes Life in a Ranch
description: KATHERINE ANN SAMON comes from solid Texas ranch stock. Her Aunts Stella, Lorraine and Ruby Lee lived in ranches; so did her grandmother Amelia, and her Aunt Harriet and Uncle Bill. Her parents still live in the ranch she grew up in. With its cathedral ceiling and limestone exterior, it is as American as her family's red Rambler station wagon, born not on a wind-blown plain but in an Austin subdivision, Levitt-style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LABRAN, DOROTHY
description: LaBRAN--Dorothy. On December 4, 2003. Born in New York, March 13, 1914, she grew up and raised her family in her home town until she and her late husband Leo retired to Margate, Fla in 1975. She is survived by her two daughters, Elinor Oertell and Roslyn Cohen, her son-in-law Harold Oertell, four devoted grandchildren Ingrid, Ronald, Stacy and Allison, their spouses and five wonderful great-grandchildren Arianna, Gabriel, Adam, Solomon and Benjamin, a sister and a brother, nieces and nephews. She will be greatly missed but never forgotten. Funeral service at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsteredam Ave, Sunday 11:15AM. In lieu of flowers donations to Hebrew Union College, 1 W. 4th St, NY, NY 10012.

title: Islanders' Streak Ends With Convincing Victory
description: The Islanders were called quitters last week by General Manager Mike Milbury, who threatened to exile any player who underperformed. The team's morale sank so low that defenseman Janne Niinimaa described the losing as a snowball rolling downhill that could not be stopped.

title: Winter of Building Set for Mormon Temple
description: Construction on the Mormon chapel to be built in New Rochelle is expected to begin this winter, while church officials are still trying to obtain sewer service for the larger temple in Harrison, city officials said.

title: E-Trips
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Web Merchants Go Global'' by Bob Tedeschi: Last year when we were traveling to Europe, we discovered e-vacations .com. Besides having some great travel deals -- we saved more than $6,000 while expanding our vacation by five days -- the site offered other benefits. First, it provided one-stop shopping, including air fare, hotels, tours and rental cars. Even more important, when we were ready to complete our plans, it let us work with a live person via an 800 number to make certain that everything was just as we wanted it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, LINDA
description: HOROWITZ--Linda. Truly beloved wife of Richard. Devoted and caring mother of Jill and Jeff Libshutz. Loving sister of Bruce and Randi Pergament, and the late Sherri Pergament Koeppel. Devoted daughter of the late Murray and Irene Pergament. Loving daughter-in-law of Grace and Sidney Horowitz, and sister-in-law of Joanne Horowitz. Your beauty, elegance, kind heart and wisdom touched the lives of your adoring family and every one else who knew you. Your courage and devotion has been an inspiration to your family and so many others. You will be in our hearts forever and always. Services will be held Monday, December 8, at 11 am, at Temple Beth El of Great Neck. Richard Horowitz, Jill and Jeff Libshutz

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLENBOGEN, ROBERT, PH.D.
description: ELLENBOGEN -- Robert, Ph.D. On December 1, 2003. Devoted father of Joshua and Benjamin, and father-inlaw of Sarah. Services were held Friday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to the Alfred Adler Institute of New York, 594 Bway, Suite 1213, NYC 10012.

title: Marriott Promises Lowest Available Rate
description: Beginning Jan. 1, Marriott International will guarantee that customers receive the best available rate on rooms whether they book through Marriott's Web site (www .marriott.com), its telephone reservation centers or directly through a hotel.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 16, about the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center, a new Smithsonian flight museum in Chantilly, Va., misstated the purpose of a design feature of the F-4U Corsair, which will be displayed there. Its dihedral (or angled) wings allow more ground clearance for the propeller, not for the wingtips.

title: Red 'n' White All Over
description: Wine bars are popular not only because they offer a broad selection -- by the bottle and the glass -- but also because of their casual, unpressured atmosphere. Here are some popular choices.

title: Page Two: Nov. 30-Dec. 6; DON'T SAY SNIPER
description: Washington had its sniper case last year, as did West Virginia in August. Now, someone is shooting into vehicles and, in one case, a school near Interstate 270 in Columbus, Ohio. One woman is dead and people are frightened. But the police are not ready to call the shooter a sniper.

title: Honoring Ailey With a Dance Set Between Anger and Jubilation
description: Walking hand in hand, four dancers strode across a studio recently at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on West 61st Street, rehearsing Robert Battle's explosive new work, ''Juba.'' Within moments they broke apart and, as if propelled by the wind, spun wildly in all directions. Stopping abruptly, they then beat their fists against their thighs. The music clanged and crashed, underlining the frustration they embodied.

title: The Disability Gulag
description: Johnson criticizes institutional long-term care and discusses long-term care only in terms of its relation to the government through the prism of Medicaid and the bureaucracy. It's important for all involved in this growing, necessary public-policy debate to keep the ultimate delivery of quality care as the paramount focal point.

title: Rooms on the Lagoon
description: JUST a century ago, you had to be a bit mad to stay on the Venetian island of San Clemente. The behemoth of a building astride this speck of land, a monastery in the 17th century, eventually became an insane asylum and most Venetians and tourists did not bother with it.

title: The Week Ahead; EUROPE
description: After more than five months of testing his fellow European leaders' tempers and stoking their outrage, Silvio Berlusconi, Italy's prime minister, heads to Brussels late this week for a summit at which lingering disagreements over a first European constitution are supposed to be resolved.

title: Michael Leavitt's Baptism
description: The White House called the shots when Christie Whitman was running the Environmental Protection Agency, and from the looks of things, the White House is still calling the shots. Michael Leavitt's first major action as E.P.A. administrator last week was to rescind a Clinton-era proposal to reduce mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants. The reversal came right out of the Karl Rove playbook, a long-promised payoff to President Bush's big contributors in the utility industry. Nobody blamed Mr. Leavitt personally. Still, the ruckus surrounding the announcement got his tenure off to a wobbly start, while overshadowing two positive initiatives on smog and acid rain.

title: Hospital to Build Center To Treat Cancer Patients
description: Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco is about to begin construction of a $20 million cancer treatment and wellness center, part of which is expected to open late next year, said Joel Seligman, the institution's president and chief executive officer.

title: Cutting the Cord
description: Now that the Internet addiction has gripped much of the population, tourist spots are teeming with people exhibiting signs of either e-mail withdrawal or vacation denial. Internet cafes, airports and hotel rooms are increasingly filled with vacationers gazing into their notebook computers, alongside other travelers who are itching to get a look at their own in-boxes or favorite Web sites.

title: Hotels Prepare For Emergencies
description: JUST before noon on the day Hurricane Fabian blew into Bermuda in September, 300 guests and local people at the Fairmont Hamilton Princess hotel in the island's capital, Hamilton, were shepherded into a large windowless meeting room deemed by the management the safest place in the building. For the next 12 hours, as 125-mile-an-hour winds raged outside, they watched movies, played board games and visited buffet tables replenished regularly by the kitchen staff. Pillows and blankets were available so children could nap. Smoking was prohibited, but late in the evening about 30 people were led to the basement for a cigarette.

title: Clearing Yorktown's Roads, and a Political Path, With an Innovative De-Icing Process
description: While many roads in the metropolitan area were slippery and treacherous on Saturday, the roads in the Town of Yorktown, in northern Westchester County, had but a thin layer of blue slush, thanks to an innovative method of spraying roadways before a storm with a solution of liquefied salt.

title: Art meets tech at Le Meridien, in a mix of the cool and the comfy
description: Minneapolis, adhering to the Scandinavian ethos of jantelagen (don't show off), has always been uncomfortable being first. So why would Le Meridien, the luxury chain, pick the city to test its Art + Tech design, a hybrid of postmodern sparseness tempered with actual comfort that would provide the template for future hotels?

title: Removing a Co-op Board Member
description: Q. Two board members recently engaged in conduct that I believe should result in their removal. One was reportedly inebriated in the lobby, used foul language with a guard, threatened her and had to be helped to his apartment. The other reportedly walked into the co-op office screaming and using foul language at the women working there. The board received the report on both incidents, but basically took no action. Can these board members be removed for the co-op's good? . . . Florence Most, Rego Park, Queens.

title: If the Shoe Ties, They Don't Wear It
description: A FEW times a year, Stuart Cohen and his son, Will, visit the Niketown store near them in Beaverton, Ore., which is also the corporate hometown of Nike, the athletic-shoe giant. On these shopping trips, Mr. Cohen notes, the 5-year-old Will makes one insistent demand: ''No laces.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Church Council Pulls Chaplains From Jail
description: FRUSTRATED by Nassau County's failure to approve a bare-bones $40,000 contract for jail chaplains 11 months after the old contract expired, the Long Island Council of Churches has yanked its five part-time Protestant chaplains from the county jail in East Meadow.

title: Syosset Board Was Right On Student's Violent Novel
description: Dylan Finkle's school is to be faulted for not doing more. The responsibility of school officials is not only to protect other students by isolating and punishing problem children, but also to help those very children.

title: Oaxaca
description: Few places in the world have the magic of Oaxaca. Its deep roots reach back 2,600 years to the settlement of Monte Albn, the Zapotec capital, about as old as the Tree of El Tule, a cypress outside town, nearly 180 feet in circumference, that is one of the largest living things on earth. The life, the art and the food of the colonial city of Oaxaca, first laid out by Spanish conquerors in 1529, draw visitors from around the world, and the power of the attraction is never stronger than when the new year nears.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Fabiola Bertolini de Moura and Kathia Bellevue, Saks Fifth Avenue, New York, Nov. 20, 2003

title: Women on Ice
description: Title IX has produced a generation of women who have participated in collegiate sports and want to continue to compete in their sport after college. Hockey players who fill that bill in New Jersey have the opportunity to suit up for about 20 teams at four women's hockey clubs. One of them is the Bridgewater Wings Women's Ice Hockey Club, based at the Bridgewater Sports Arena.

title: Serenading a Tree via AT&T
description: Millions of American television watchers, it seems safe to say, have enjoyed an odd bit of Handel opera recently, though few may have realized it. It comes in a fetching television commercial for AT&T Wireless. A woman is seen on a bus trapped in city traffic. As a boy -- her son, it becomes obvious -- performs at a piano recital, her husband transmits the sound to her cell phone. She beams with pride.

title: The Poise and Enthusiasm of Pennington Are Impressing Other Coaches
description: When left tackle Jason Fabini was caught up in the excitement of Monday night's game against Tennessee, he head-butted Chad Pennington as he knelt in the Jets' huddle early in the fourth quarter and accomplished something few opponents have figured out how to do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEXTER, ROBERT GRANT
description: DEXTER--Robert Grant, 73, died on November 25th, 2003 in Portland, ME while traveling from his home in Summerville Centre, Nova Scotia. The son of Dr. Joseph H. Dexter, longtime professor of physics at City College of New York, and Frances Clifford Tupper, formerly of Nova Scotia and Englewood, NJ. After serving his country honorably in the U.S. Air Force, Dr. Dexter was graduated from the University of Maryland with a BS degree in Journalism and Public Relations and the Master's of Education degree. In 1976 he was awarded the Ed.D from Nova University. Dr. Dexter, associated with Maryland State Teachers Association for 22 years, was the Director of Public Relations and Assistant Executive Director before retiring in 1985. Dr. Dexter served two terms as president of the National Public Relations Council of the National School Council of State Educational Associations and in 1980 was honored as the Public Relations Person of the year. Dr. Dexter is survived by his three children, daughters, Jennifer Scott Dexter, Marmora, NJ, Hilary Harris Dexter, Glenview, IL, son, Timothy Joseph Dexter, Huntingtown, MD, their families and ten grandchildren, his brother, Edwin M. Dexter, Tumbling Shoals, AK.

title: Football Player Is 2nd in Season-Opening Moguls Race
description: Jeremy Bloom, who plays football at Colorado, was second in the season-opening men's moguls race yesterday to the Olympic champion, Janne Lahtela of Finland.

title: Ideas & Trends; How Low Can DVD Players Go?
description: WHEN a Florida woman claimed to have been trampled in a holiday mob of Wal-Mart shoppers trying to get DVD players for $29.87, people across America were shocked -- not at man's inhumanity to man, but by the price. DVD players cost hundreds of dollars just a few years ago.

title: A Bit of New Haven Line Is Resurrected
description: THE department store where my parents bought everything from drapes to electric trains, G. Fox, is long gone. So are the Hartford Whalers and dozens of insurance companies and banks that once had their headquarters in Connecticut.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Jersey Footlights column last Sunday about two exhibitions on the Holocaust, at the Bergen County Y.M.C.A./Y.W.C.A., misstated the closing date. It is Dec. 19, not this Wednesday.

title: M.T.A. Urged Not to Cut Elevator Jobs At 5 Stations
description: Snow and howling winds did not deter than 150 Manhattan residents from marching up and down the hills of Washington Heights yesterday to protest the elimination of elevator operators at subway stations there.

title: In a Homeland Far From Home
description: The devastation in the mid-70's of Cambodia is so complex an experience that it proves difficult for people to fully understand (Deborah Sontag, Nov. 16). The only experience we Americans have to compare with such destruction is the collapse of the twin towers and the tragic death of some 2,750 people within them. But to understand Cambodia's loss, we must multiply that number by at least 365 (more than one million lost) or 1,091 (three million lost -- estimates vary). Repatriating men like Loeun Lun and Many Uch (and further emotionally damaging the women who brought them to freedom) smacks of being penny-wise and pound-foolish. Such actions can only further damage an already severely tarnished image of America.

title: A Player's Coach Who Knows How to Win
description: Because he is sentimental, Dick Vermeil often pauses when he tells a story. Sometimes, he will walk over to a photograph on the wall of his office at Arrowhead Stadium that helps him tell it a little better.

A year later, man is wiped out, grappling with debt and deep depression, and now he sees an idiot every time he shaves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENNEY, STEPHEN G.
description: KENNEY--Stephen G., known to his friends and family as Stevek, died Thursday, November 27, 2003 in New York City. Stevek is survived by his parents Dorothy & Mike Mitchell of Norwalk, CT, his sister Gabriella Pellinger of Savannah, GA and his sister Kathy Kenney-Baskin of Menlo Park, CA. Stevek had a successful career at New York Life in partnership with his mother Dorothy and was the originator of the Allegro freestyle ski program at Stratton Mountain, VT. In over 30 years of instruction Stevek produced both US Ski Team members and US National freestyle champions. A memorial service, unfortunately by invitation only, is planned for Wednesday, December 10th, 2003 at 5 P.M. in Zankel Hall of Carnegie Hall, NYC. In lieu of flowers, gifts can be made to the Stevek Foundation c/o Cramer & Anderson LLP, 51 Main Street, New Milford, CT 06776 for the benefit of deserving Stratton youth athletes.

title: The Only Underrated Member Of N'Sync
description: JC CHASEZ -- First Justin Timberlake proved himself with a series of sublime R & B songs. And now the most -- all right, the only -- underrated member of 'N Sync seems to have found his niche, too. Late last year, Mr. Chasez released ''Blowin' Me Up (With Her Love),'' from the ''Drumline'' soundtrack; it sounded like a marching band trapped in a dance club. Next came ''Plug It In,'' a feverish collaboration with the Basement Jaxx, and ''Some Girls (Dance With Women)'' (Jive), another uncategorizable rhythmic adventure. His multitracked voice wraps around a seductive conga-drum beat, and then Dirt McGirt (a k a Ol' Dirty Bastard) shows up out of nowhere, bellowing about a ''sexual whirlwind.'' Mr. Chasez's solo album is due out in January; here's hoping it's more of the same.

Nine children died here Saturday morning in a United States air strike, and were still lying in the dust when American soldiers flew in by helicopter to investigate the consequences three hours later, villagers and U.S. soldiers at the scene said today.

title: Love in the Time of No Time
description: I posted my first profile on Match.com two days before I read Jennifer Egan's article (Nov. 23). As a 22-year-old who sees the Internet as the most convenient venue to meet potential dates, I am still wary of contacting any of my ''matches.'' Why would I want to go out with a guy who can't get a date in real life and is using the Internet as a last resort? And then I realized that I'm doing the same thing!

title: In Central London, Four Hotels for Less
description: FEW people really like the idea of a cheap hotel. For the budget-minded, bed-and-breakfasts are cute and cozy, and hostels have a kind of scruffy glamour. The cheap hotel seems undignified by contrast. It conjures mysterious, Hollywood-inspired images of solitary business trips, anonymous trysts, the barebones room where a film's young hero stays when he first comes to the big city.

title: Spoiling (Carefully) for A Fight
description: Matt Bai demonstrates why more and more voters are tuning out politics. He points out, ''It's not the 10 things you say in a debate that matter; it's the one that leads the evening news and the next day's paper.''

title: One Degree of Separation
description: I was an only child. I was born in 1932 in Little Rock, Ark., and we lived nearby in a town called Park Hill. My father spent a lot of time with me; he was outgoing, very masculine, a handsome man. He was an officer at the Federal Reserve Bank in Little Rock and had played basketball in a semipro league. The times I really remember were the times we went on vacation either to Hot Springs or to Paron, Ark., where Aunt Jewel and Uncle Alonzo Dodson had a cabin. We fished a lot; my father taught me how to handle a gun.

title: Business; Who Wins and Who Loses as Jobs Move Overseas?
description: The outsourcing of jobs to China and India is not new, but lately it has earned a chilling new adjective: professional. Advances in communications technology have enabled white-collar jobs to be shipped from the United States and Europe as never before, and the outcry from workers who once considered themselves invulnerable is creating a potent political force.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: There's a theological bent to this season's books of and about photographs, as some of the titles reviewed below attest: ''Revelation'' (singular), ''Revelations'' (plural), ''The Passions,'' ''The Devil's Playground.'' But big biblical themes like temptation, renunciation, redemption and grace can also be found in unexpected places, like ''One Big Self,'' a startling collection of portraits of convicted felons in a Louisiana prison, and ''What Remains,'' Sally Mann's new book of freighted landscapes and portraits of the dead. (These, too, are reviewed below.) Another sign of the times is a wealth of photographic literature, from collections of essays by the curator David Travis (''At the Edge of the Light,'' published by David R. Godine) and the critic David Levi Strauss (''Between the Eyes,'' published by Aperture) to attempts to write the recent history of photography as an art (David Campany's ''Art and Photography,'' from Phaidon, and the Tate Modern's catalog to last summer's mega-show, ''Cruel and Tender''). Equally literary, though less easy to pigeonhole, is ''The Montesi Scandal'' (University of Chicago), Karen Pinkus's captivating account -- in quasi-screenplay form -- of the moment in postwar Italy when politics, cinema and paparazzi photography coalesced into a single culture. Could moths, too, be a trend? Two books take the unassuming creatures as their subject: Mike and Doug Starn's ''Attracted to Light,'' reviewed below, and Joseph Scheer's ''Night Visions: The Secret Designs of Moths,'' published by Prestel (Scheer makes his color pictures by placing moths directly on a high-resolution scanner). And for those whose photography libraries lack a classic heft, there are major collections of the work of Henri Cartier-Bresson (Thames and Hudson), Jacques Henri Lartigue (Abrams) and Julia Margaret Cameron (Getty).

title: Corrections

title: After Snowstorm's Raging Glory, Now Comes the Great Slush Shove

The award is the most prestigious in Britain for contemporary art.

It was the height of futility -- a play the officials should have blown dead on a delay-of-game penalty -- and the lowest point of a Giants season full of lows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RANSOM, DAVID MICHAEL
description: RANSOM--David Michael, of Washington, DC, died December 4, 2003, of a heart attack in New York City. Born in St. Louis, MO, in 1938, he was U.S. Ambassador to Bahrain, a career U.S. diplomat and Arabist, a beloved father and successful businessman. He is survived by his wife of 38 years, Marjorie, his three daughters, Elizabeth, Katherine and Sarah, his brother, Clifford, a son-in-law, Craig, and two grandsons, Ransom and Gabriel. The family will receive visitors at home on Wednesday, December 10, from 5 pm to 9 pm. Due to limited parking, public transportation is recommended. The memorial service will be Saturday, December 13, 11 am, at St. Margaret's Episcopal Church, 1820 Connecticut Ave., in Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Arabic program, Rock Creek International School, 1550 Foxhall Rd., NW, Washington, DC 20007, 202-965-8700 (http://www.rcis.org/)

title: Jump-Starting Winter
description: Were you ready for this? You may have had the car winterized and your snow boots waterproofed and a new snowblower or snow shovel waiting in the garage or the basement, but the question still obtains: Were you ready for this? By midday yesterday, a map of the storm that buried the Northeast and the mid-Atlantic states over the weekend -- setting snowfall records along the way -- showed a blob of precipitation that reached from mid-Illinois to the Atlantic shoreline. Much of New England won't be free of the storm till sometime today. In the wake of the snowfall itself came strong winds that abruptly resculpted the landscape, undoing in an hour or two all the hard work of snow clearing that many people undertook too early. On Saturday night the winds sounded like snowplows on the highway, but they were plowing us in, not out.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Ithaca: Cornell Names Law Dean
description: Cornell University named Stewart J. Schwab, a labor and employment law expert who clerked for Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, as its law school dean. In an announcement Friday, the university said he would succeed Lee Teitelbaum, who served as dean from July 1999 to June 2003. Mr. Schwab earned a Ph.D. in economics and a law degree from the University of Michigan, and also clerked for Judge J. Dickson Phillips Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit before joining Cornell's law school faculty in 1983. He has consulted for the World Bank on the reform of labor and employment laws in parts of the former Yugoslavia and Soviet Union. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Don't Hang Up, That's My Mom Calling
description: The next time an annoying sales call interrupts your dinner, think of my 71-year-old mother, LaVerne, who works as a part-time telemarketer to supplement her Social Security income. To those Americans who have signed up for the new national do-not-call list, my mother is a pest, a nuisance, an invader of privacy. To others, she's just another anonymous voice on the other end of the line. But to those who know her, she's someone struggling to make a buck, to feed herself and pay her utilities -- someone who personifies the great American way.

The mayor said the money would be used to expand programs that help libraries serve as learning places for children during nonschool hours. title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: 3 CONVICTED IN JOGGER ATTACK TO SUE CITY Three men whose convictions in the 1989 beating and rape of a jogger in Central Park were overturned last year will file a federal lawsuit today, their lawyer said yesterday. The suit, to be filed in Manhattan Federal Court, will name the city, the New York Police Department, current and former police officers and the Manhattan district attorney's office, said the lawyer, Jonathan Moore. The three men — Kevin Richardson, Raymond Santana and Antron McCray, who are seeking $50 million in damages each — were among five men convicted in the near-fatal attack on the 28-year-old jogger on April 19, 1989, and lawyers for all the men said in March that the men would sue over their convictions. Their convictions were overturned by a State Supreme Court judge last year after DNA evidence pointed to another man, Matias Reyes, who had stepped forward to say he was the sole attacker. A spokeswoman for New York City law officials, Kate O'Brien Ahlers, said the city had not seen the legal papers and would evaluate them once they were filed.   (AP)

title: Russians Inch Toward Democracy

Heartening as it was to see Russians voting freely on Sunday to fill all 450 seats of the Duma, the lower house of the Russian Parliament, the dominant impression is that Russia's democracy is a long way from any Western model. In some worrisome ways, it is moving farther away. The horrendous terror bombing in southern Russia on Friday cast a shadow over the elections. It seemed likely to produce more votes for President Vladimir Putin's supporters, as Russians rallied in anger behind their leader's unyielding stance toward Chechen rebels, who were blamed for the blast. Early results showed that Mr. Putin's party had more than double the votes of any other party.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Conjoined Twins Develop Infection
description: For the second time in a month, Clarence and Carl Aguirre, the 19-month-old Filipino twins joined at the head, have developed an infection that led doctors to remove a tissue expander inserted under their scalps. The infection was not life-threatening, doctors said. The expander was inserted on Nov. 24 to stretch the skin enough to cover both skulls later, when the boys' skulls are separated. Doctors removed the expander yesterday at the Children's Hospital at Montefiore in the Bronx, and will implant new ones later. Carl and Clarence are neurologically healthy and normal, according to a hospital spokesman. In the months ahead, the boys are expected to undergo a series of operations that will ultimately separate them.

title: City Settles Sharpton Suit Over Stabbing
description: New York City agreed yesterday to pay the Rev. Al Sharpton $200,000 to settle his 12-year-old lawsuit stemming from his 1991 stabbing before a rally in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn.

title: Revenge of Old Europe / Czech policy under fire : Nobility seeks to win back seized property
description: VIENNA  New Europe is facing a challenge from the most unlikely of sources: Old Europe  extremely Old Europe, that is. Just ask the prince.

title: Unknown Harrison Ford With No Future
description: In an uncrowded week, an unhurried retrospective. Picking up the tempo, boys will be boys behind the wheel, and Ben Stiller tries network television.

title: U.N. Assembly Puts Off Action on Human Cloning Ban
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 9 — The General Assembly today ducked for a year a polarizing debate over human cloning that has set the Bush administration against allies like Britain and large parts of the world's scientific community.
