Paid Notice: Deaths   PELL, FRANCESCA H. (HINCKLEY)
description: PELL--Francesca H. (Hinckley), on December 7, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Clarence C. Pell. Loving mother of Kina King, Anita K. Wilson and Helen K. Woodhouse. Stepmother of Eve Pell, Peter Pell and Haven Pell. Beloved sister of Elizabeth H. Milburn. Member and past president of Westbury Garden Club, Member of Piping Rock Club and The Colony Club. Volunteer at Abilities. A memorial service will be Saturday, December 13, 1:00pm in St. Peters Episcopal Church, 72 Central St, Narragansett, RI. For information, Avery-Storti Funeral Home.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The American Foundation for AIDS Research, New York, introduced a pro bono print campaign designed by Kenneth Cole , vice chairman, who also is president and chief executive of the shoe company Kenneth Cole Productions. The campaign, focused on women's sexual health, H.I.V. and AIDS, was timed to coincide with the 15th annual World AIDS Day last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERSHENSON, MILTON G.
description: GERSHENSON -- Milton G. The Brooklyn Law School Community notes with sorrow the loss of a distinguished graduate, esteemed teacher and beloved colleague. In more than a halfcentury of service on the Law School Faculty, he touched the lives of thousands of students. In addition to teaching, he served as a Special Hearing Officer for the United States Department of Justice, as Advisor to the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Family Law, and as Chief Reporter for the Criminal Jury Instructions Project of the State of New York. Although his presence will be missed, he legacy will be long enduring. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Paula and daughter Suzette. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean

title: Job Cuts Follow Recovery in South Korea
description: Employment worries are growing in South Korea as signs proliferate that lifetime jobs are now a luxury of the past.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Kidnappers Seize Tourists
description: Three tourists -- two Germans and an Irish citizen -- were kidnapped along with their Iranian guide in the southeastern province of Sistan-Baluchestan, near the border with Pakistan and Afghanistan. The Iranian Student News Agency quoted an unidentified official from the province as saying the kidnappers had demanded a ransom of $6 million. The German Embassy refused comment, but reports said the kidnapping took place a few days ago. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: COURT TAKES ON IMMUNITY ISSUE The country's Constitutional Court will begin today to assess an immunity law for top government officials that stopped a corruption trial of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi after his allies pushed it through the Italian Parliament in June. A decision on the law's constitutionality could take three to four weeks.

title: Letters
description: Cads and Dads

title: Japan Approves Deployment of Troops to Aid U.S. in Iraq
description: TOKYO, Dec. 9  Japan decided today to deploy ground troops to join the American-led war in Iraq, in what will be its most ambitious military operation since its surrender to the United States at the end of World War II.

title: People
description: Brian P. Tierney resigned as chairman at the agency he founded in 1989, now called Tierney Communications, Philadelphia, to open the T2 Group, Philadelphia, which will initially focus on public relations. Tierney, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said there were no immediate plans to fill the post of chairman; Scott Franks continues as chief executive and Mary Stengel Austen as president.

title: Mars Mission's Invisible Enemy: Radiation
description: As the United States considers new goals for NASA after the loss of the Columbia, some space enthusiasts have renewed calls for a mission to Mars.

title: Mars Is Our Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: Pocket of Opposition to Vaccine Threatens Polio Eradication
description: Opposition to vaccinations against polio by some Islamic leaders in northern Nigeria has led to the spread of the disease to neighboring West African countries, jeopardizing the World Health Organization plan to eradicate it by the end of 2005.

title: In Ethiopia's Malaria War, Weapons Are the Issue
description: With a major malaria outbreak sweeping Ethiopia, an international doctors' group working there contends that outdated drugs are being used to fight it and may even worsen the epidemic.

title: Advice to the G.O.P., From New Yorkers
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports Briefing
description: PRO FOOTBALL

title: The Boom on Outer Karada Street
description: A survey by The New York Times of 85 stores along a half-mile stretch of Outer Karada Street in Baghdad provides a snapshot of the recent boom in appliance sales. The street is one of the largest markets for appliances in the city. Boxes of televisions, stereos, washers, dryers and satellite dishes are left stacked on the sidewalk all day long. Along the section of road studied, 53 stores are selling appliances. Nine of those stores were selling other goods before the war and have since switched. Another 12 are new appliance stores that opened since the war began. ARCHIE TSE

title: Internal Police Investigation Widens, to 5 Suspects From 2
description: Federal prosecutors and police Internal Affairs Bureau investigators who are looking into the activities of a retired police detective and an 18-year veteran arrested two weeks ago have expanded their inquiry to include a retired lieutenant and two current detectives, according to several law enforcement officials.

title: More Than a 'Scream': A Blast Felt Round the World
description: Against a lurid sky, vividly streaked with waves of red and yellow, a grotesque figure cowers, his mouth and eyes wide open, his hands clasped to his ears. This familiar painting, ''The Scream,'' is Edvard Munch's most famous work. Yet for more than a century, the event that inspired it has eluded identification.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAMER, NOEL
description: KRAMER -- Noel. Untimely demise, on December 1, 2003, was felt by many. He is survived by his brother Eugene, niece Rosanne, nephews Michael, Lane and Rod. Noel accomplished much in his lifetime. He was altruistic and charitable. His departing will be perceived by family and friends. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Wednesday, December 10th, 1:30PM.

title: GORE TO ENDORSE DEAN, REMAKING DEMOCRATIC RACE
description: Al Gore has decided to endorse Howard Dean for president, aides to the men said Monday, a move that rocked the Democratic presidential field and hastened Dr. Dean's evolution from a long-shot maverick to a leading candidate of the Democratic establishment.

title: Patriots Climb Back to Top After Falling
description: There are still doubters left over from Feb. 3, 2002, when New England quarterback Tom Brady and an underappreciated defense walked over the St. Louis Rams and danced on a carpet drenched in confetti.

title: Only a Move Will Prevent Bankruptcy, Barnes Says
description: The Barnes Foundation, with its multibillion-dollar art collection, will be forced to go bankrupt unless a judge permits it to move from the cozy suburb of Merion, Pa., to downtown Philadelphia, Barnes officials testified in court on Monday.

title: Miscellany
description: Local and national advertising revenue for radio networks and stations fell 1 percent in October, the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York reported, compared with October 2002. For the first 10 months, combined ad revenue is up 2 percent compared with the period a year earlier, the bureau reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BREAKSTONE, JOSEPH
description: BREAKSTONE--Joseph. Died Sunday, December 7, 2003. He is survived by his sister Jane. For information, 212-628-1847.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LARSEN, JAMES A.
description: LARSEN--James A. Age 33. On December 7, 2003. Adoring husband to Joanne Kolker. Loving son of Fredrick and the late Patricia Larsen. Devoted brother to Christopher and Joseph. Son-in-law to Nadine and Thomas Kolker. Brother-in-law to Amy Kolker. Friend and humanitarian to all. Services will be held Thursday, December 11th at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64 St., N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the James Larsen Foundation for Esophageal Cancer, 310 E. 75 St., Suite 4B, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Roosevelt: 13 Arrested Outside High School
description: The police arrested 13 young people outside a high school in Roosevelt last night, and charged them with trespassing and disorderly conduct, Officer Thomas Brussell of the Nassau County Police Department said. The young people, aged 16 to 22, had gathered in two groups on the grounds outside Roosevelt High School around 7 p.m. They were preparing to fight when police officers stopped them, Officer Brussell said. Several of the young people suffered minor injuries, though none required hospitalization. Officer Brussell described the groups as rival gangs. He did not have details on whether any of the young people were students at the school. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: With Playoffs Dashed, Jets' Only Hope Is .500
description: In the days leading up to the Jets' game against the Tennessee Titans last Monday, Coach Herman Edwards deployed all of his considerable motivational skills, speaking to players individually and in groups, tweaking their confidence and their egos, bringing them to an emotional pitch that propelled them to an unexpected victory over the Titans.

title: 7 of 8 Researchers Rescued in Antarctic
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, Dec. 9 (AP)  Seven of eight South Korean polar researchers who disappeared at sea off Antarctica were rescued, but the eighth was found dead, officials said Tuesday.

title: General Aviation Security Concerns
description: Moving to address concerns about security in general aviation, a field that ranges from single-occupant personal aircraft to fleets of multimillion-dollar corporate jets, the Transportation Security Administration plans to issue formal guidelines early next year for improving security at more than 18,000 airports and landing strips used by about 214,000 general aviation aircraft.

title: Accounts
description: J.P. Morgan Chase, New York, to the Martin Agency, Richmond, Va., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle creative and media duties on the account of the retail banking division, Chase Consumer Financial Services. Spending has not been determined. Those duties had been handled by another Interpublic agency, Foote Cone & Belding, New York, which continues as agency of record, handling assignments like credit cards.

title: What Does Keep Them Up There?
description: TO those who fear flying, it is probably disconcerting that physicists and aeronautical engineers still passionately debate the fundamental issue underlying this endeavor: what keeps planes in the air?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLIANCE GAMING CORP., Las Vegas, said it planned to sell its Rail City Casino in Nevada to Sands Regent, Reno, Calif., for $38 million in cash and debt as it concentrates on supplying casinos with gambling machines.

title: U.S. Bars Iraq Contracts for Nations That Opposed War
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  The Pentagon has barred French, German and Russian companies from competing for $18.6 billion in contracts for the reconstruction of Iraq, saying the step "is necessary for the protection of the essential security interests of the United States."

title: Timeline: Space
Yes, They Can! No, They Can't: Charges Fly in Nanobot Debate
description: It wasn't quite Dan Aykroyd and Jane Curtin tossing insults at each other while ostensibly debating a serious political issue. But an exchange between a Nobel laureate and a nanotechnology visionary last week was reminiscent of that old ''Saturday Night Live'' sketch.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Stop Using Army To Fight Crime, U.N. Says
description: A United Nations human rights commission issued a report calling on Mexico to keep the military out of the criminal justice system. The government has relied on soldiers to perform the work of police officers, including carrying out drug investigations. The report, requested by President Vicente Fox after he took office three years ago, recommends changes in the Constitution to strengthen the rule of law, among them the presumption of innocence for criminal defendants. The report also says Mexico needs to protect the rights of workers, including their right to join unions, and needs to create equal opportunities for women and a juvenile-justice system. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Rebels wary over Sudan talks
description: RUMBEK, Sudan:  The thunder of a thousand-horse charge by a cavalry wielding AK-47's still seems more real to Elias Waya, a rebel commander, than the prospect of peace in Sudan.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: Oil Privatization Rejected
description: A government move toward partial privatization of the oil sector was rejected by voters in a defeat for the country's already unpopular government. More than 60 percent of the votes favored cancellation of a law passed in 2001 that would have allowed the government oil company, Ancap, to form alliances with private oil companies. The referendum result was viewed as a blow to President Jorge Batlle. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Saving the Village
description: ''With a heavy dose of fear and violence, and a lot of money for projects, I think we can convince these people that we are here to help them,'' an American battalion commander in Iraq said recently. He was speaking from a village that had been virtually wrapped in razor wire after a series of attacks on U.S. troops. ''This fence is here for your protection. Do not approach or try to cross, or you will be shot,'' a sign reads.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Lending Executive Resigns
description: Yasuo Takei, the founder and chairman of a consumer loan company, the Takefuji Corporation, resigned almost a week after his arrest on suspicion of illegal wiretapping. Mr. Takei, who founded Takefuji in 1966, has been accused of ordering employees to tap the phones of a freelance journalist who wrote articles critical of the company. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Sale of Nuclear Plant to China Puts German Aide on the Spot
description: A little over 10 years ago, when Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, was the minister for the environment in the state of Hesse, he was one of the most visible leaders in a successful fight against a nuclear enrichment plant built by the industrial giant Siemens and almost ready for operation.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: King Undergoes Cancer Surgery
description: King Harald V, 66, underwent surgery to remove a cancerous bladder and will remain hospitalized for two to three weeks, his doctors said. His son, Crown Prince Haakon, 30, will stand in. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: Ex-Government Officials Recommend Intelligence Overhaul
description: In the two years since the Sept. 11 attacks, a group of veterans of the Central Intelligence Agency, Federal Bureau of Investigation and Pentagon has been quietly trying to figure out how to help shape the debate over intelligence reform in the wake of the attacks. They say the place to start is a drastic realignment of the way the United States conducts intelligence and counterterrorism operations within its borders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLHISER, ROSS
description: MILLHISER -- Ross. Altria Group, Inc. (formerly Philip Morris Companies Inc.) notes with great sorrow the death of Ross R. Millhiser, the former Vice Chairman of Philip Morris Incorporated and a former director of Philip Morris Companies Inc. An energetic and passionate businessperson with broad-ranging interests, Mr. Millhiser played a central role in the growth and development of our companies during a 40year career. In extending their deepest sympathy to his family, the Altria Board and employees of the Altria companies pay warm tribute to Mr. Millhiser's memory, his many accomplishments, and his service to his country. Mr. Millhiser is survived by his brother, four children and eight grandchildren. A graveside service will be held at Hollywood Cemetery, 412 South Cherry Street, Richmond, VA., Wednesday, Dec. 10, at 3:00 p.m. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Greater Richmond chapter of the American Red Cross, P.O. Box 655, Richmond, Va., 23205

title: Tagging Sharks? No Problem. They're Big Babies. Really.
description: When Ramon Bonfil fishes for great white sharks off the coast of South Africa, he does not take any chances with his tackle. Two hooks tied together and attached to a chain ensure that the shark will not break the hook or line. The chain is attached to a rope that is attached to an oversize buoy that quickly tires out the shark as it dives.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Victory Against Rustbuckets
description: Environmental campaigners won a court battle to prevent a British company from dismantling old United States Navy vessels that crossed the Atlantic to be scrapped in the northeastern port of Hartlepool. The British government initially approved the plan to scrap them, but the decision was challenged by Friends of the Earth, an environmental group that called the ships ''toxic.'' A High Court judge said the government's decision ''cannot stand.'' The British company, Able UK, must now reapply for a license and submit to an environmental review before work can begin on breaking up the ships. Four ships are in Hartlepool and nine more are waiting to leave the United States. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENNEY, STEPHEN G.
description: KENNEY--Stephen G. Stevek made everyone in his life feel like they were his best friend. His limitless devotion to his Stratton Freestyle Team and Allegro Family was truly inspirational. He was our coach, confidante, guardian, enforcer, teacher, organizer, joke teller, a trainer of young minds, and giver of the world's greatest hugs-our loss is profound. To honor Stevek, we will keep his dreams alive, ski through our tears, and remember a unique soul who will live in our hearts forever. Debbie, Shelly, Alexis, Brent & Jared Palmer

title: Electronic Eyes for What Man Can't See
description: THE Wright brothers can take credit for designing the first airplane and its engine, but they could not have envisioned how their invention would change after electronics were added to the package. Early airplanes relied entirely on pilots who could see where they were going, but today's pilots monitor electronic systems that do the flying for them. The airplane has taken a century to evolve, but it has reached full flower -- thanks, mostly, to the development of equipment that frees it from the limitations of human senses.

title: With Childbirth, Now It's What the Mother Orders
description: When my twin sons were born 34 years ago, the goal of every woman I knew, myself included, was a vaginal delivery.

title: Stirred by Movie, Brothers Win in Science
description: In the 1999 movie ''October Sky,'' the teenage sons of coal mine workers in rural West Virginia build rockets and improbably wind up winning a national science contest.

title: Shoes to Die For (or at Least to Suffer For)
description: To the Editor:

title: Raid at High School Leads to Racial Divide, Not Drugs
description: It was partly a tip from an informant, partly the activity he saw on the Stratford High School surveillance cameras that led the school's principal to call in the police for an early morning drug sweep here on Nov. 5.

title: An End Run Around Miranda
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments today in a case that could greatly undermine Miranda warnings, among the best known of all constitutional protections. Not long ago, opponents of Miranda v. Arizona had hopes of overturning it, but the Supreme Court reaffirmed the ruling in 2000. Now the justices are considering interrogation tactics that sneak around it. If Miranda is to retain its vitality, the court must reject these underhanded tactics.

title: Global Crossing Discloses Its Past Losses
description: Global Crossing, which is about to emerge from bankruptcy protection, revealed that it had losses of $25.7 billion in 2000 and 2001 after writing down the value of its fiber-optic network.

title: Mets and Matsui All Smiles as He Arrives in New York
description: Kazuo Matsui hit the ground at Kennedy Airport last night, starting his new life as the shortstop for a beleaguered Mets franchise that hopes the abundant talent he displayed in Japan will hold up well in Queens.

title: Spiegel Seeks to Close Stores After Holidays
description: Spiegel Inc., a bankrupt chain store and catalog retailer, has asked a federal judge for permission to close 30 Eddie Bauer stores and to hire companies to sell inventory at the locations after the holidays.

title: Smoldering Daughter of Delft; A Film Fleshes Out Vermeer's Anonymous Model and the Artist Himself
description: With great portraits it is usually the painter, not the painted, who is remembered: even emperors, kings and popes take second place when Titian, Rubens or Velzquez portray them. Yet a few unidentified models, Leonardo's Mona Lisa or Goya's Maja among them, have become icons. And now, thanks to a best-selling novel and a new movie, Vermeer's ''Girl With a Pearl Earring'' may be joining them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAADJ, ABDEL GHANI, M.D.
description: BAADJ--Abdel Ghani, M.D., age 77, after a brief illness on December 1st, 2003, leaving behind a beloved friend, Jane Agola of New York. Services and burial were on December 5th at Crown Cemetery, Indianapolis, IN.

title: Secondhand Smoke May Harm Family Pets, Too
description: Susan Kilgore smokes outside now.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: 'Cab Elvis' Can Keep Sequins
description: In a victory for a cabdriver who dresses as Elvis Presley, the Seattle City Council voted to amend an ordinance that requires cabbies to wear shirts with collars and black pants and prohibits costumes. The cabdriver, David Groh, who was fined last spring for violating the dress code, sued the city, saying the fine was a violation of his constitutional rights. The ordinance was changed to allow costumes, and Mr. Groh, who is known as Cab Elvis, agreed to drop his lawsuit. The City Council is expected to take up the larger issue of the dress code early next year. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EPSTEIN, ALLEN
description: EPSTEIN--Allen of Clifton, NJ, on Sunday, December 7. Beloved husband of Felice (nee Victor). Devoted father of Dr. Steven Allen Epstein and Gail Eckstein. Loving grandfather of four grandchildren. Services at Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ on Wednesday at 12:30 PM.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Prison Guard Faces Sex Charge
description: A city correction officer has been arrested on charges that he tried to receive sexual favors from a female inmate at the Queens criminal court building, officials said. The officer, Robert Roach, of Jamaica, Queens, confessed last week to trying to receive oral sex for $20 from the inmate, who was in a cell in the prearraignment section of the Queens Court Pens, according to officials with the city's Department of Investigation. When the inmate tried to acquiesce, investigators said, Officer Roach became nervous, told her to stop and left the cell. Officer Roach, who joined the Department of Correction in 1989, resigned from his $54,000-a-year job on Friday. He is being charged with a criminal sexual act and other offenses and if convicted will face up to four years in prison.

title: U.S. STEEL TO CLOSE DISTRIBUTION UNIT AND RECORD CHARGE
description: The U.S. Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would close its Straightline Source steel distribution unit and take a pretax charge of about $25 million in the fourth quarter. The unit, which has been losing money, will close on Dec. 31, U.S. Steel said. Straightline, which was started in October 2001 with about 100 employees to increase sales to smaller customers, never turned a profit. It reported a third-quarter loss of $15 million, according to company earnings statements. U.S. Steel is based in Pittsburgh.

title: National Briefing | Labor: Rail Union Merges With Teamsters
description: Members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers have voted overwhelmingly to merge with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, union officials said. The engineers' union has 36,000 members in the United States and Canada. It becomes the first railroad union to join the Teamsters, which has 1.4 million members, as part of the Teamsters' goal of uniting rail workers and truck drivers. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for a concert tomorrow by the Dessoff Choirs misstated the site. It is the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue at 59th Street, not the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew.

title: No Increase in Gasoline Tax for Now, McGreevey Says
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Dec. 9  Gov. James E. McGreevey said today that he would not support a move to increase the state's gasoline tax, essentially killing an effort to raise the tax.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Introduces Premium Net Services
description: Yahoo yesterday introduced its long-delayed premium service for users of high-speed, or broadband, Internet connections, apparently using a strategy of less is more. Its new Yahoo Plus service costs $5.95 a month. It competes with America Online's AOL for Broadband, which costs $14.95 a month, and a similar service from Microsoft's MSN at $9.95 a month. All of these services are meant to offer a package of features, like upgraded e-mail, virus protection and video clips, that may not be available from a cable system or telephone company providing broadband service. Yahoo is offering 10 e-mail accounts, each with more storage and some other features not included in its free service. The premium service includes software to protect against viruses and Internet intrusions and to limit the online activities of children. And it includes access to some services Yahoo has tried to sell on a stand-alone basis: premium Internet radio, telephone access to e-mail and news, and extra online storage for photos and files. Yahoo said the service would be available by the end of the month. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Takeoff! How the Wright Brothers Did What No One Else Could
description: ONE hundred years ago, on Dec. 17, 1903, two brothers from Ohio took flight in a machine of their own creation. They were men of simple tastes and soaring ambition, skilled where it counted and resolute. Their machine was a fragile piece of minimalist engineering, an insubstantial butterfly compared with the eagles of technology that later took to the air.

title: Timeline: Engineering
Memo Shows MFS Funds Let Favored Clients Trade When Others Couldn't
description: MFS Investment Management, the oldest mutual fund company in the country, allowed privileged clients to trade quickly in and out of its biggest funds while saying it restricted the practice for the vast majority of its shareholders, according to a memorandum from a senior company executive.

title: Shoes to Die For (or at Least to Suffer For)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCDERMOTT, FRANK A. JR.
description: McDERMOTT--Frank A. Jr., 85, of Bronxville, NY, Stuart, FL and Barrington, RI died on December 7, 2003 after a long illness. Mr. McDermott retired from New York Telephone in 1983, after serving 47 years beginning as a messenger and retiring as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. He was a trustee of New York Telephone, Orange and Rockland Utilities, The Dime Savings Bank, Tele Sciences Inc., Ayco, The Merger Fund, New York Medical College, Our Lady of Mercy Medical Center, Fordham University, The College of New Rochelle, Frances Schervier Home and Hospital, Holy Family Church, President of the Telephone Pioneers of America and President of JFM Associates. Mr. McDermott was inducted into the Knights of Malta and remained an active participant. He was a decorated Military Officer in WW II receiving the Bronze Star, American M/E European, American Campaign, American Defense, World War II Victory, Good Conduct and two battle stars and other military honors. He served in North Africa and Europe and retired as a Lieutenant Colonel. In addition to his beloved wife Jeanne, he leaves four daughters and three sons. Jeanne Cohane of Nantucket, MA., Joan McDermott and Jane Bogue of Simsbury, CT and Sheila Sutton of Barrington, RI. His sons; Frank McDermott of New Rochelle, NY, Stephen McDermott of Irvington, NY, John McDermott of Chatham, NJ and 23 grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Viewing will be held at Fred H. McGrath Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY on Wednesday, December 10, 2003 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. The Funeral mass will be held at St. Joseph's Catholic Church, 15 Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY at 10 am Thursday, December 11, 2003. The family would prefer donations to a non-profit charity in lieu of flowers. Details to follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RANSOM, DAVID MICHAEL
description: RANSOM--David Michael, of Washington, DC, died December 4, 2003, of a heart attack in New York City. Born in St. Louis, MO, in 1938, he was U.S. Ambassador to Bahrain, a career U.S. diplomat and Arabist, a beloved father and successful businessman. He is survived by his wife of 38 years, Marjorie, his three daughters, Elizabeth, Katherine and Sarah, his brother, Clifford, a son-in-law, Craig, and two grandsons, Ransom and Gabriel. The family will receive visitors at home on Wednesday, December 10, from 5 pm to 9 pm. Due to limited parking, public transportation is recommended. The memorial service will be Saturday, December 13, 11 am, at St. Margaret's Episcopal Church, 1820 Connecticut Ave., in Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Arabic program, Rock Creek International School, 1550 Foxhall Rd., NW, Washington, DC 20007, 202-965-8700 (http://www.rcis.org/)

title: Political Memo; Opponents Focus on a Mayor With Deep Pockets
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent $7.5 million of his own fortune to campaign in favor of a measure to bring nonpartisan primaries to New York City, laying out $52 a vote to his opponents' $2.40 a vote. Yet the proposal was defeated in a lopsided 70-30 vote.

title: Washington Mutual Cuts Forecast as Mortgage Lending Slips
description: Reflecting the sharp slowdown in home mortgage and refinancing activity, Washington Mutual Inc. , one of the nation's biggest mortgage lenders, cut its earnings forecast for 2003 and said today that it planned to cut costs by $1 billion in costs over the next year and a half, beginning in the first quarter of 2004.

title: In Him, Storyteller Meets Architect
description: IT is hard to impress children. They have seen and heard it all: the special effects, the racy and gruesome images and the strident trash talk that seems destined to poison our discourse. Pop-up books would hardly, it would seem, be able to compete.

title: Insurer's Stock Is Big Draw in Hong Kong
description: Hundreds of investors lined up at banks on Monday for an opportunity to buy shares of the China Life Insurance Company, the world's biggest initial public offering this year.

title: In a Made-for-Television Romance, the Most Telegenic Man Wins
description: Melana chose pretty Jason over homely Adam. And that decision, dragged out over the six weeks of NBC's reality show ''Average Joe,'' was an affirmation of sorts. It suggested that beneath all the artifice and selective editing that make up a reality show, there is still a tinge of realism left.

title: A Shortage of Jobs in China
description: As American leaders in both parties complain about lost manufacturing jobs and push for China to revalue its currency, China has its own serious jobs problem. Page A18.

title: Is Dean a McGovern, or a Dean?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Raid in Afghanistan May Have Missed Target

title: FONTERRA SIGNS $380 MILLION CONTRACT WITH E.D.S.
description: The Fonterra Cooperative Group Ltd., the biggest exporter of dairy products in the world, said yesterday that it had signed a seven-year, $380 million contract with the Electronic Data Systems Corporation to manage its computer systems as it strives to cut costs. Fonterra, which is based in Auckland, New Zealand, was formed two years ago in a merger of the country's two biggest dairy cooperatives and the industry's national export agency. Beginning in March, 127 Fonterra employees will shift to E.D.S., Fonterra said. E.D.S. will own and manage Fonterra's voice and data networks, e-mail systems, servers and desktop computers.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: CMGI Reports Income Of $29.9 Million
description: CMGI, an Internet venture company whose shares have more than doubled this year, had first-quarter net income of $29.9 million because it sold stock in Overture Services, now a part of Yahoo. Net income for the period that ended on Oct. 31 was 7 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $93.6 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said yesterday. Revenue fell 16 percent, to $94.9 million from $113.2 million. CMGI, based in Andover, Mass., had a gain of about $40.5 million by selling 3.2 million Overture shares received when Overture bought the AltaVista unit of CMGI in April. The AltaVista sale gave CMGI net income of $76.9 million in last year's third quarter. Yahoo completed the Overture purchase on Oct. 7. CMGI has posted net losses in 7 of the last 10 quarters. First-quarter results were announced after markets closed yesterday. CMGI shares rose 2 cents, to $2.08.

title: CONOCOPHILLIPS TO PROCEED WITH GAS PROJECT IN QATAR
description: ConocoPhillips agreed to proceed with a $5 billion project in Qatar to convert natural gas to diesel and other fuels, expanding its presence in a country that has the world's third-largest gas reserves. ''We are looking forward to a more definite agreement in 2004,'' ConocoPhillips's chief executive. James J. Mulva, said at a news conference in Doha, Qatar, where he signed a statement of intent for the plant with the Qatari oil minister, Abdullah bin Hamad al-Attiyah. The first phase of the project would start as early as 2009 and would produce half of the plant's full output target of 160,000 barrels of fuel a day, Mr. Mulva said. ConocoPhillips is based in Houston.

title: National Briefing: Northwest
description: WASHINGTON: `CAB ELVIS' CAN KEEP SEQUINS In a victory for a cabdriver who dresses as Elvis Presley, the Seattle City Council voted to amend an ordinance that requires cabbies to wear shirts with collars and black pants and prohibits costumes. The cabdriver, David Groh, who was fined last spring for violating the dress code, sued the city, saying the fine was a violation of his constitutional rights. The ordinance was changed to allow costumes, and Mr. Groh, who is known as Cab Elvis, agreed to drop his lawsuit. The City Council is expected to take up the larger issue of the dress code early next year. Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Court Upholds 1955 Hanging
description: Court of Appeal judges dismissed a challenge to the death sentence imposed 48 years ago on Ruth Ellis, the last woman to be hanged in Britain. Her relatives had appealed her conviction on the grounds that she should have been tried for manslaughter, not murder, and that she was suffering from battered woman syndrome. The court said Ellis, 28, a nightclub hostess, was properly convicted for shooting her lover, the racing driver David Blakely, under the laws that prevailed in 1955. Her case was turned into a movie, ''Dance With a Stranger'' released in 1985 and starring Miranda Richardson. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: National Briefing: South
description: OKLAHOMA: NEW FEDERAL BUILDING OPENS A new federal office building opened in Oklahoma City a block from where the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building was destroyed by a bomb in 1995, killing 168 people. The building, which has not yet been named, is to be dedicated next year. Antiterrorism features include three-quarter-inch steel plates at the entrance level and shatter-resistant glass, and the structure is set well back from the street. Timothy J. McVeigh, who was convicted of planting the bomb that destroyed the Murrah building, was executed in 2001. A co-defendant, Terry L. Nichols, was convicted and given a life sentence on federal charges in the case, but state prosecutors are seeking the death penalty. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: Astronomers announced yesterday that they had found the remains of an ancient cosmic car wreck.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Retire Some Products
description: Microsoft will retire several products next week, including Windows 98 and SQL Server 7, to comply with a court order related to its dispute with Sun Microsystems over Java. In a posting to its developer Web site, MSDN, Microsoft lists several older products that are being phased out and that will not be available to customers as of Dec. 15. The products to be dropped include SQL Server 7, Office XP Developer, Windows 98 and a number of Office 2000-related tools and patches. Microsoft said it would update Java-compliant versions of some products by the end of December, including Office XP Professional with FrontPage, Publisher 2002, Windows NT 4.0 and Small Business Server 2000. In the posting, dated Thursday, the company said the shift was ''due to a settlement agreement reached in January 2001'' related to Java licensing. According to an agreement reached with Sun over the distribution of the Java virtual machine, Microsoft's software has to run Java programs. Microsoft has the right to modify its Java software to fix critical bugs or security holes through Jan. 2, 2004. While Microsoft will no longer distribute the products listed, many will continue to be supported. The company plans to offer SQL Server 7 support until the end of 2007, for instance. Windows 98 support will be available, for a fee, until next month.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mine Stake Raised
description: The mining company Anglo American said it now owned a 66.6 percent stake in Kumba Resources, a South African iron ore producer. Anglo owned 35 percent of the company before making an offer that closed Friday, and said it would accept partial sales. Anglo was compelled to make the offer by stock exchange rules even though it had previously agreed with the South African government that it would not exceed a 49 percent holding. The company said it would discuss a resolution with the government.

title: The New Bear in Town
description: One day soon we will be reading about a bear sighting in New York City. A Manhattan bear is a distinct possibility, should the prospective rogue prove to be as venturesome as those coyotes who have been observed crossing various bridges into Gotham and dodging late-night taxis on their way toward Central Park. Nor can one rule out an ursine visit to Brooklyn, although this would require a rare Two-Bridge or Bridge-and-Tunnel Bear. No, the initial encounter is most likely to occur in the Bronx, that borough being contiguous with the mainland's Eastern corridor, where the black bear has staged such a remarkable comeback -- some biologists estimate the bear population to be as high as 3,300 in northwest New Jersey alone -- that the state yesterday opened its first sanctioned bear hunt in 33 years.

title: National Briefing: Plains
description: WOMAN SUES SCHWARZENEGGER A woman who said she had been sexually harassed by Arnold Schwarzenegger filed a libel lawsuit on against him, saying his staff had falsely suggested in an e-mail message that she was a convicted felon. The woman, Rhonda Miller, accused Mr. Schwarzenegger, California's new governor, of groping her when she was working as a stunt woman and he was an actor. She said that she had never been arrested and that false information implying such an arrest had been broadcast on national television reports. (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Ex-Official Indicted
description: A former senior official of District Council 1707, the union that represents employees working for nonprofit agencies, was indicted yesterday on charges of accepting more than $80,000 in kickbacks from a computer consultant who also worked for the union. The official, Robert McMillan, 63, was the union's director for fiscal affairs and was charged by the state with grand larceny, commercial bribe-receiving and a scheme to defraud. He pleaded not guilty. The computer consultant, David Tart, 41, was charged with the same crimes and also pleaded not guilty. According to the indictment, Mr. McMillan approved $300,000 in ''extra work'' invoices that Mr. Tart had submitted. The indictment also alleges that from 1996 to 2002 Mr. Tart wrote checks for more than $82,000, made payable to cash for Mr. McMillan. Bail for both men was set at $10,000 yesterday evening. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 2nd Guilty Plea In Rape Case
description: A second man pleaded guilty yesterday in the gang rape and robbery of a woman in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park last December, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said. The man, Luis Carmona, 20, pleaded guilty to attacking and beating the 42-year-old woman and her male companion on Dec. 19, dragging the woman into a makeshift shelter near the park and, along with a group of other attackers, raping and robbing her. Last Friday, Victor Cruz, 22, pleaded guilty to the same charges before the same judge, Justice Randall T. Eng of State Supreme Court in Queens. Both men have agreed to testify for the prosecution. Three other defendants, Jose Hernandez, 18; Armando Juvenal, 20; and Carlos Rodriguez, 22, await trial in the attack. Each would face up to 25 years in prison if convicted. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Labor

State party officials blame poor accounting and lack of oversight for a debt they put at $400,000 and for expected sanctions by the Federal Election Commission that are likely to include substantial fines. Mr. Rockefeller's father, Winthrop, served two terms as governor of Arkansas in the 1960's.    Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: One Killed, 14 Hurt In Theater Collapse

Rescue workers were searching the rubble for one other person. Firefighters removed chunks of debris by hand to free people in the school, the Yorkville English Academy, which teaches English as a second language. The collapse of the 83-year-old Uptown Theater is under investigation. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: No Cheer for the Unemployed
description: With a perverse sense of holiday timing, President Bush and the Republican leaders of Congress are blithely accepting the expiration of emergency benefits badly needed by the nation's long-term unemployed. This vital program ends on Dec. 21, crushing the hopes of an estimated 80,000 or more jobless Americans each week who will find their state benefits expiring. The emergency benefits, which provide 13 extra weeks of help, were approved by Congress early last year as hard-core unemployment became entrenched. The problem continues today as the economic recovery shows only a meager turnaround in job creation.

Galileo will continue to provide ticket information to travel agents and a network for the agents to make reservations with the airline. A United spokeswoman, Jean Medina, declined to reveal the value of the contract or estimate the dollar amount of the savings, which the carrier said would be 20 percent to 30 percent. title: Frequent Flier; Join a Business, Travel the Globe, Eat a Sheep's Eye
description: I want to tell you about eating a sheep's eye in Saudi Arabia. I was the guest of honor at a client's weekend retreat outside Jidda. About 30 men in traditional Arab robes and headgear sat on a beautiful Persian carpet under the stars. The servants brought in a roasted sheep. The host plucked out the eyeball and said, ''The first serving is for you; it's a tradition and an honor that you receive the eyeball.'' I was thinking, ''I don't want to lose my job; it's a huge account; do I put it down my shirt?'' Everybody was watching. I think it was an unspoken test to see if I would respect their culture. It tasted like a round, firm gooey oyster. The only thing that got rid of the taste was the hookah that they passed around afterward.

McVeigh, who was convicted of planting the bomb that destroyed the Murrah building, was executed in 2001. A co-defendant, Terry L. Get-There tallied the cost of flying 100 people -- two from each of the 50 biggest metropolitan areas -- to cities that had at least 25 three-star or four-star hotels offering business services and putting them up for a four-day meeting. The cabdriver, David Groh, who was fined last spring for violating the dress code, sued the city, saying the fine was a violation of his constitutional rights. The ordinance was changed to allow costumes, and Mr. Groh, who is known as Cab Elvis, agreed to drop his lawsuit. The City Council is expected to take up the larger issue of the dress code early next year.    Sarah Kershaw (NYT)

title: PROVIDENCE: LIBRARY CHIEF QUITS
description: The executive director of the Providence Athenaeum has resigned amid a furor over the proposed sale of the library's prize possession, a copy of John James Audubon's masterpiece ''Birds of America.'' The 250-year-old library, in Providence, had expected to raise as much as $7 million from the sale, but dozens of people who use the library protested and took the matter to court. The suit delayed the sale until February, when the case is scheduled to be heard. Jonathan Bengtson, a specialist in medieval history who became the library's executive director late in 2001, sent a letter of resignation to the board on Nov. 23, and the board accepted it on Friday. In his letter Mr. Bengtson cited ''lingering elitism among a small, but active, group of individuals'' whose ''disdain for those who seek to secure the institution's survival seems to know no bounds.'' He pledged to stay on through mid-February to help with the litigation and said that he intended then to take a job as chief librarian of St. Michael's College at the University of Toronto. ALISON LEIGH COWAN

title: How Not to Pick a Flu Vaccine
description: The nation needs a faster and better way to design and produce influenza vaccines. Experts knew back in March that a new, potentially formidable strain of the virus was circulating, yet practical difficulties forced them to stick with an obsolescent vaccine rather than press for a better formulation. There was simply not enough time to prepare the new strain for manufacturing and then produce vaccine in vast quantities. Thus we are entering what looks like a severe flu season with less than optimal protection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDERSON, CINDY
description: SANDERSON -- Cindy, died peacefully on November 28th, 2003 after a 12-year battle with breast cancer. She was the beloved partner of Marcia Landsman, mother of Emma Ying and sister of Sara Sanderson. She was born in Arkansas and raised in Kentucky where she received a Ph.D. in psychology. Cindy was an expert and talented clinical psychologist, serving much of her career at New York Presbyterian Hospital in White Plains. Most recently, she was the Director of Training of Behavioral Tech, LLC. She was an avid reader of science and religion, an outstanding teacher, writer and mentor. She was kind, generous, extremely funny and had a fierce will. Cindy is survived by her partner and daughter, sisters Sara and Connie, brothers David and Herb, nieces Sara, Emma, Rachel, Leslie and Hannah, nephews Jesse, Lane and Austin. She was grateful for the compassion and devotion of her doctors and all those who helped her through all of the medical and personal struggles in her life. She lived a vital life filled with great love for her daughter, family and friends. Some months before Cindy's death, she wrote to a friend, ''I stood out on the back porch this afternoon and I prayed for the peace and grace to accept this life on its own terms...to have the courage and the will to do just that.'' In the end, she was able to find peace in this strife. She will be loved and missed forevermore. In lieu of flowers, you can make a donation to Emma Ying/Sanderson Family Education Fund, Florence Savings Bank, Williamsburg, MA 01096.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHERNICK, ARTHUR
description: CHERNICK -- Arthur. The Board and Staff of the New York Association for New Americans (NYANA) are deeply saddened by the loss of our esteemed Board member and great friend Arthur Chernick. Arthur Chernick was involved in Jewish civic and philanthropic life over a period of 38 years. Arthur served on the NYANA Board of Directors since 1967, he served as its President from 1980-1983 and chaired its Executive Committee from 1983-1987. His private life was as exemplary as his public service. Arthur served as captain in the Armored Force Commission Infantry in the Second World War. His decorations include the Bronze Star, the Belgium Fouragere and European Theatre Medal-5 battle stars. Arthur has served not only his country well, but the Jewish community with distinction. He will truly be missed. We express our sincere condolences to the entire Chernick family. Michael Loeb Chairman of the Board Mark Handelman, President & CEO

Mr. Manzi, the former chairman, president and chief executive of the Lotus Development Corporation, will succeed Richard F. Syron, who resigned to become the chairman and chief executive of Freddie Mac, the mortgage lender, Thermo Electron said. Mr. Manzi, 51, led Lotus from 1984 until it was bought in 1995 by I.B.M. Since leaving Lotus, Mr. Manzi has been involved with several technology start-up ventures, including Interwise Inc., which arranges online meetings and conferences, and Flooz.com, a seller of online currency used as electronic gift certificates. Dimitri Pauli, at right in photo, whose father, Hans, opened Sant Ambroeus in 1982, owns it with Gherardo Guarducci, left. This troupe of dancers under age 20 serves as the second company of American Ballet Theater and, under John Meehan's direction, it seeks to give talented young performers experience in ballets of many styles. title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: WHITE PLAINS: WESTCHESTER APPROVES A BUDGET The Westchester County Legislature has restored all the jobs and most of the social services programs that were cut in the county executive's proposed 2004 budget, making the budget even more reliant on a sales tax increase that is anything but certain. The Legislature voted Monday night along party lines — 11 Democrats to 6 Republicans — to approve a $1.4 billion budget that assumes the State Legislature will permit a penny-on-the-dollar sales tax rise in the county. They acted despite a warning from Assemblyman Richard Brodsky, who told them before they voted that the sales tax was "off the table." The budget, which County Executive Andrew Spano said he would sign, would raise property taxes by about 8.5 percent. To protect the county from financial problems that would occur by mid-February if the sales tax failed, nine of the Democrats signed a letter promising to raise property taxes an additional 12.4 percent and cut spending by $20.6 million — bringing back the layoffs Mr. Spano had proposed.   (AP)

title: Anaheim Signs Coln For 4 Years

title: Time to Draw the Line

The case, a challenge of district lines in Pennsylvania, raises the question of whether Congressional districts can ever be drawn in such a politically partisan way that they are unconstitutional. The court should reaffirm that they can be.

Each CCBT share will be exchanged for 1.084 shares of Banknorth, a rate that values CCBT shares at $35.52 each, 38 percent more than CCBT's closing price on Monday. The purchase will shift 26 branches to Banknorth, which is based in Portland, Me. CCBT, which is based in South Yarmouth, Mass,. has $1.4 billion in assets.
