description: The oldest of three teenagers arrested on charges that they planned a shooting spree last summer pleaded guilty to a single charge of carjacking here on Tuesday.

title: The Homeless and the Meatless; A Deer Hunt to Aid the Hungry Brings a Vegan Response
description: When a deer hunt was proposed on 285 acres of pristine open land here owned by the Audubon center, it was not surprising that hunters, animal rights activists and bird lovers found themselves locked in battle.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investor Confidence Rises
description: Investor confidence in Germany rose to its highest in two and a half years last month, according to a survey. The index compiled by the ZEW Center for European Economic Research found that investor confidence rose to 73.4 percent in November from 67.2 percent in October. The institute said a Europewide index showed a similar increase. Economists said the optimism was based on faster economic growth in Germany, helped by the recovery in the United States. Another German research institute, DIW, raised its forecast for economic growth in the fourth quarter to 0.5 percent from 0.25 percent a day earlier. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: A Signpost of Greece, A Cloak of Italy
description: AS far as I'm concerned, there are two major kinds of cooking, and the distinction I make is not between types of foods but the approach to preparing them.

title: Lewis M. Allen, 81, Tony-Winning Producer
description: Lewis M. Allen, the producer of hit Broadway shows that included ''Annie'' and ''Master Class,'' died on Monday in New York. He was 81.

title: Justices Hear New Arguments About Meaning of Miranda
description: Three years after the Supreme Court reaffirmed its landmark Miranda decision as having ''announced a constitutional rule,'' it was apparent during arguments at the court in two cases on Tuesday that the practical meaning of Miranda and the continued utility of its famous warnings for criminal suspects remain very much in question.

title: Ruben Gonzalez, 84, Buena Vista Club Pianist
description: Ruben Gonzalez, the Cuban pianist who came out of retirement in his late 70's and unexpectedly rose to international fame, died on Monday in Havana. He was 84.

title: Experts Say Greek Verdicts Don't Dispel Olympic Threat
description: Now that 15 members of a Greek radical group are behind bars and facing long sentences after being convicted Monday of a nearly three-decade rampage of bombings and assassinations, Greece is assuring the world that the Olympic Games here next summer will be safe.

title: Singapore Airlines to Create Low-Cost Carrier Next Year
description: Surrounded by an increasing number of no-frills upstarts, the full-service stalwart Singapore Airlines said on Tuesday that it planned to create a budget airline called Tiger Airways here next year with the help of the people who started the Irish discount airline Ryanair.

title: After Dinner, the Sweetest Note
description: SWEET wines are sometimes considered an acquired taste. If so, I acquired it long ago. Few things are as pleasing after a meal as a good sweet wine, one that balances sugar with a bracing acidity that leaves you with a clean, refreshed feeling in your mouth. I'm especially drawn to sweet wines in the holiday season, when a glass poured after a meal with some good cheese can add just the right festive touch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCH, GRETA P. (SIMON)
description: HIRSCH--Greta P. (Simon) of Lexington, MA, formerly of New York City. Beloved wife of the late Salli Hirsch. Loving mother of Susan H. & Dr. Paul A. Menitoff of Lexington, MA. Services at the Levine Chapel, 470 Harvard Street, Brookline, MA, on Thursday, December 11 at 9:30 AM. Burial at Beth El Cemetery, Township of Washington, NJ on Friday, December 12 at 10:30am. Memorial observance at the home of Susan and Paul Menitoff Saturday evening, and Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, beginning at 2PM each day. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to a charity of one's choice.

title: Report Says China is Returning Refugees to North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 9 - On the heels of a Russian offer to take in able-bodied North Korean refugees, a leading South Korean human rights group has released a report estimating that China is forcibly repatriating 100 refugees to North Korea each week.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Cheeseburger Lawsuit
description: A Chicago hamburger restaurant famously parodied in the ''cheeseburger, cheeseburger'' sketches on ''Saturday Night Live'' is suing a Florida company called Cheeburger Cheeburger Restaurants Inc. The Chicago restaurant, the Billy Goat Tavern and Grill, a long-time newspaper hangout underneath Michigan Avenue, filed the trademark infringement lawsuit after learning that the Florida chain planned to open a restaurant in a Chicago suburb. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Learning Arabic
description: To the Editor:

title: For Live Langoustines, Atlantic Below, Restaurants Ahead
description: Langoustines are highly perishable creatures. Until now, imports were cooked before being shipped or were sent frozen. Either way, the tail meat, the only part eaten, was often mushy and lacked sweet succulence. Live langoustines from Scotland are now being imported by Andrew Hamilton, a Scottish chef who formerly ran Caswell-Massey, one of New York's oldest pharmacies. He has founded a new company, Wild Scottish Harvest.

title: Secretary to Leave Before Drug Benefit Begins
description: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said Tuesday that he would stay in office through the 2004 elections but would resign before the new Medicare drug benefit becomes available in January 2006.

title: SoHo Fixture Sends a Satellite To the East Side: An Open Kitchen Beckons at Front
description: Dean & DeLuca has opened its first market on the Upper East Side, at 1150 Madison Avenue (85th Street), replacing a Gristede's supermarket.

title: Israeli and Egyptian Officials Discuss Renewing Peace Efforts
description: Israeli officials met Egyptian and Palestinian leaders in separate talks today as part of efforts to renew peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians to end more than three years of violence.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: News Rack Owners Criticize City
description: News rack owners and newspaper publishers, smarting from thousands of city summonses, complained yesterday that a city law was being arbitrarily enforced against them. They also told a committee of the City Council that they were assessed heavy fines without being given adequate time to resolve violations. A new law regulates the placement and maintenance of news racks on city sidewalks. Councilman John C. Liu, the chairman of the transportation committee, questioned why news racks had been cited more frequently for excessive dirt and graffiti rather than for public safety. Iris Weinshall, the transportation commissioner, testified that her inspectors mainly responded to complaints from the public. Since April, her office has inspected 4,735 news racks and issued 2,073 summonses, she said. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: America Online To Trim 2% Of Work Force
description: The America Online unit of Time Warner will eliminate 400 jobs, or 2 percent of its work force. Most of the workers are software engineers, with about 375 of them at the Mountain View, Calif., campus.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egyptian President And Israeli Minister To Meet
description: Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, and the Israeli foreign minister, Silvan Shalom, plan to meet in Geneva today in the first such high-level contact in more than a year. They agreed to meet as part of an effort to repair strained relations, an official with the Israeli Foreign Ministry said. In Israel, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said he was considering moving some Jewish settlement outposts, most of which consist of a small number of mobile homes, as a way of easing tensions with the Palestinians, according to a spokesman. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: It's Early, But Arizona Serves Notice
description: Early-season matchups may mean nothing by the time March rolls around, but they give a team a good idea of where it stands and what it needs to do. Arizona can leave the Jimmy V Classic at Madison Square Garden feeling pretty good about itself. Texas, on the other hand, must still prove it can defeat an elite team.

title: Iraq, the West Bank and Vietnam
description: To the Editor:

title: SLAP SHOTS
description: Detroit defenseman CHRIS CHELIOS will miss three to four weeks because of a sprained right knee, and he was placed on injured reserve yesterday. Chelios was hurt Monday when he was checked by Los Angeles's MIKE CAMMALLERI in the Red Wings' 3-2 overtime victory.

title: Sideline Style In the Color Of Money
description: Take a look at National Football League coaches. Dressed down. Every game is Casual -- or Sloppy -- Sunday, time to don the caps, turtlenecks, windbreakers, jackets, sweatshirts, golf shirts, parkas and knit hats provided by the fashion arm of the league and made by Reebok.

title: Snow for the Holidays
description: To the Editor:

title: Abercrombie & Fitch to End Its Racy Magazine
description: Abercrombie & Fitch, the apparel retailer, said yesterday that it would no longer publish its provocative quarterly magazine, which included photographs of nude and nearly nude young models.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC TO COMBINE UNITS IN COST-CUTTING MOVE
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, a leading maker of plywood, will combine its industrial wood products business with its panel and lumber operations on Jan. 1 to cut costs. The new unit will be part of Georgia-Pacific's building-products group, according to a memo distributed by David J. Paterson, president of the group. The number of jobs affected by the combination is not known yet, a spokesman, Greg Guest, said. Georgia-Pacific has been combining sales and production responsibilities as part of a plan to reduce administrative costs by more than $200 million over two years.

title: Corrections
description: The Wine Talk column last Wednesday, about moderately priced American pinot noirs, misstated the location of Oregon's prime pinot noir vineyards. They are in the western part of the state, not eastern.

title: Supreme Court Backs Virginia In Rift Over Potomac Water
description: The Supreme Court handed Virginia a decisive victory on Tuesday in that state's battle with Maryland over the right to draw drinking water from the Potomac River, which forms most of the boundary between the two states.

title: Mixed Signals Over Fate of Gifted-and-Talented Programs
description: Depending on who is asked, the city's Department of Education may or may not be planning big changes for gifted-and-talented programs in schools citywide.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 446 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEON, SOL
description: LEON--Sol of Beverly Hills, CA formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Died at age 90 on December 5th. Executive Vice President of the William Morris Agency, his beloved 2nd home and family of 65 years. Most cherished husband of the late Lee Leon, dear father of Steven Leon and Susan Leon, devoted father-in-law of Andrew Fredman, cherished grandfather of Joshua and Alison Fredman. A gentleman and a legend in living. Services Friday 11:45 AM Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam at 76th St. In lieu of flowers donations memorial gifts may be made to The Lymphoma Research Foundation, 8800 Venice Blvd, Suite 207, Los Angeles, CA 90034.

title: High Payments To Halliburton For Fuel in Iraq
description: The United States government is paying the Halliburton Company an average of $2.64 a gallon to import gasoline and other fuel to Iraq from Kuwait, more than twice what others are paying to truck in Kuwaiti fuel, government documents show.

title: Fidelity Narrows Review to 4 Agencies
description: Fidelity Investments in Boston, part of the FMR Corporation, has narrowed a review for an agency to handle the creative duties on its account to four finalists. Billings were estimated at $75 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALVA, JEAN
description: DALVA--Jean. The Dalva family mourns the loss of their matriarch, the doyenne of Dalva Brothers. Mother of David II, Leon, Jr., and Robert; aunt of Barbara Ann Bricker; grandmother of nine, great grandmother of five. Mass of Christian Burial at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89 St., N.Y.C., on Wednesday, December 10th at 9:30am.

title: Japan Commits Itself to Sending Up to 600 Ground Troops to Iraq
description: Japan decided on Tuesday to send ground troops to join the American-led forces in Iraq in what will be its most ambitious military operation since World War II.

title: Gore's Endorsement Was Won Over Time and Under the Radar
description: Al Gore was in Tokyo on Friday and Howard Dean was in a van in Iowa, and for 45 minutes, their cellphone conversation was not particularly extraordinary, people close to both politicians said.

title: Iraqi Governing Council Sets Up Its Own Court for War Crimes
description: With the painful discoveries of suspected mass graves this spring still in mind, Iraq's transitional Governing Council voted Tuesday to create its own tribunal to judge Saddam Hussein's aides and functionaries on charges of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.

title: With BT, Internet calls join the mainstream
description: Bringing a powerful consumer name to an obscure technology, BT Group of Britain on Tuesday said it would market a service that transmits phone calls over the same Internet lanes traveled by e-mail, digital music and Web pages.

title: PENTAGON BARS THREE NATIONS FROM IRAQ BIDS
description: The Pentagon has barred French, German and Russian companies from competing for $18.6 billion in contracts for the reconstruction of Iraq, saying it was acting to protect ''the essential security interests of the United States.''

title: Nascar May Change Race for Points Title
description: A dull finish to this season's Nascar Winston Cup points race might have suited the champion, Matt Kenseth, but it has inspired officials to consider a major overhaul of the system that determines who wins the annual title.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an effort to create a new accountability system in New York City's public schools misstated part of the federal term for the measure of a school's performance on reading and math tests. It is ''adequate'' yearly progress, not ''annual.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCDERMOTT, FRANK A.
description: McDERMOTT--Frank A. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of Frank A. McDermott, devoted friend of long standing and past Trustee. A Christian gentleman passionate about the College, he generously shared himself with us and we are stronger for it. We mourn his loss and celebrate his life. Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D. President Jean Baptiste Nicholson, OSU Chair, Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LERNER, GENEVIEVE EDNA NEWICK ALBERS
description: LERNER--Genevieve Edna Newick Albers, clinical psychologist and wife of Max Lerner, on December 2. A memorial service will be held in the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's, 50th St and Park Ave, Monday, December 22, 2PM.

title: In This Case, a Two-China Policy for U.S.
description: After the opening speeches, the 50 or so American executives gathered at the Hotel Pennsylvania in Manhattan were invited to divide up. Those interested in investing in China -- putting an operation there and hiring Chinese workers -- were to go across the hall to the Penntop North conference room. Those who wanted help in exporting to China were to stay seated in Penntop South.

title: A Bittersweet Transition From Chamber Piece to Full Orchestra
description: The thrill and the immediacy of chamber music owe much to its small proportions, its intimate give-and-take and the fact that there is but one instrument on a single part. It is always therefore bittersweet to hear one's favorite chamber works played by a full string orchestra. The tension of the harmonies, the urgency of the phrasing, the clarity of the lines can never be quite the same. And forget about the intimacy; a bustling musical convention has convened on a site where secrets were once shared.

title: Cooks' Gifts, With Shelf Life
description: THERE are three kinds of cookbooks: those that go immediately into my kitchen, those that get piled on the bedside table and those that are so inviting that they beg to be gift-wrapped.

title: Fatal Nightclub Fire Brings 3 Indictments
description: The owners of a Warwick, R.I., nightclub and the tour manager of a heavy-metal band were indicted on charges of involuntary manslaughter in a fire at the nightclub that killed 100 people and injured nearly 200 last February. Each was charged with 200 counts of involuntary manslaughter, two for each death.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Sunday about a gathering of people who submitted losing entries for the design of the World Trade Center memorial misspelled the surname of the entrant who also invented the first artificial heart. He is Robert Jarvik, not Jarvick.

title: Matsui Officially Joins the Mets
description: The Mets called on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg today to introduce the biggest foreign import in the team's history. The mayor obliged, firing off one-liners, as only a politician can. But it was the newest Met, who stole the show with 11 simple words: "Hello everyone. My name is Kazuo Matsui. I love New York."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, RABBI SIMON
description: COHEN--Rabbi Simon. Beloved brother of Rabbi Morris A. Cohen, Rabbi Harry Cohen and Rabbi Sol Cohen. Devoted son of Rabbi Ben-Zion and Nechama Cohen. Cherished uncle. Interment in Israel. You will always be in our hearts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the use of an odor, SkunkShot, in vacant Los Angeles buildings that are magnets for crime gave a misspelled surname in some copies for a sheriff's deputy who used it in Compton. He is Dan Drysol, not Brysol.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Industrial Output Rises
description: Industrial production in Malaysia rose 11.3 percent in October compared with the month a year earlier, its strongest increase since the end of 2000, according to government statistics. Year-end demand is driving Asia's export-focused economies. Tuesday's production figures followed data released last week showing that Malaysian exports in October rose 7.2 percent, to their highest level since September 2000. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: After the Gold Rush: Parsons on the Future of Time Warner
description: In the windowsill of Dick Parsons' office, high above Rockefeller Centre in central Manhattan, there is a framed magazine. In large letters it says: "The Path to Wealth - How to Succeed in 2004". The front cover from Money magazine - one of Time Warner 's many properties - neatly sums up the challenge facing the chairman and chief executive of the US media group that many say has lost its way during the internet boom.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Dec. 3 about Julian Hirsch, an engineer who tested audio equipment for consumer magazines, referred imprecisely to his reports in the late 1950's, when he and Gladden Houck formed Hirsch-Houck Laboratories. Mr. Hirsch indeed wrote the lab reports personally.

title: F.T.C. Offers Guide To Weight-Loss Ads
description: The Federal Trade Commission yesterday published an 18-page reference guide for TV stations, magazines, newspapers and other media outlets to use voluntarily to help identify and reject advertisements for diet pills, weight-loss plans and other such products that are false or deceptive.

title: Ad Pages Declined For a Sixth Month
description: Magazine advertising pages declined in November for a sixth consecutive month, the Publishers Information Bureau in New York reported yesterday. Ad pages last month fell 2.8 percent compared with a year earlier, bureau data showed. For the first 11 months of 2003, ad pages have fallen 0.5 percent compared with the period in 2002.

title: Military Says 6 Children Died in U.S. Raid in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 10  The United States military acknowledged today that six more children have been killed in a bombing raid in operations against suspected Taliban members in eastern Afghanistan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lender's Revenue Rises
description: HSBC, the bank based in London, said that third-quarter revenue grew as consumer lending expanded in the United States and Britain, offsetting low interest rates. The company did not provide specific figures but said part of the growth was a result of its $15 billion acquisition of Household International, a lender based in Prospect Heights, Ill.; that deal was completed in March. The bank also said defaults on consumer loans declined. HSBC plans to release its annual results on March 1. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: An Insurgent Gains Status
description: Al Gore's endorsement confirms the status of Howard Dean as that rarest of animals in the jungle of presidential nominating politics: an insurgent front-runner. It gives him the legitimacy he has been seeking, but it also presents him with problems of self-definition.

title: WHITE MOUNTAINS INSURANCE TO EXPAND IN EUROPE
description: The White Mountains Insurance Group agreed to buy the insurance unit of ABB Ltd. for 3.22 billion Swedish kronor ($440 million), in the company's biggest expansion into Europe. Investors in White Mountains include Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the holding company controlled by Warren E. Buffett. ABB, which is Europe's largest electrical engineering company, will take a $150 million loss on the sale, said Wolfram Eberhardt, a company spokesman. The unit, called Sirius International Insurance, is based in Stockholm and sells reinsurance to other underwriters. It is the fourth acquisition this year for White Mountains, which is based in Hanover, N.H., and will gain offices in Zurich, London, Hamburg and Stockholm. The acquired company includes Sirius America Insurance Company, a primary insurer in the United States, which wrote $96 million of net premiums in 2002.

title: Cards for Fun, And for Deals
description: O.K., smarty-pants, answer this true or false question: In the Bible, Noah gets drunk on wine. And how about this one: is tempura originally Japanese, Chinese, Portuguese or Italian?

title: Senate Won't Vote on Spending Until 2004
description: Senate leaders brushed aside White House objections on Tuesday and chose not to vote on a huge spending bill until late January, deferring dozens of major federal programs and projects for the better part of two months.

title: Off the Menu
description: DAVID BURKE & DONATELLA may sound like a lounge act, but it is the name of the restaurant that Mr. Burke, a chef formerly of the Smith & Wollensky Group, and his partner, DONATELLA ARPAIA , who owns Bellini, are opening at 133 East 61st Street. The two, below, have turned the dark interior of what was Il Valetto into a bright space accented with chocolate brown and chili red.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with the continuation of an article about the movie ''Girl With a Pearl Earring'' misidentified the actor shown with the director, Peter Webber. He was Colin Firth, not Cillian Murphy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARKSDALE, SALLY
description: BARKSDALE--Sally. MS philanthropist and education advocate, Sally McDonnell Barksdale, has died in Jackson, MS at the age of 60. She is survived by her husband of 38 years, Internet pioneer and former Netscape CEO, James (Jim) Love Barksdale. She is also survived by her children: Susan Barksdale Howorth and husband, Judge Andrew K. Howorth and grandchildren Marian and Stewart of Oxford; Betsy Barksdale Pokorny and husband, John Pokorny and grandchildren, Max, James and Sarah of Winter Park, Florida; and John David Barksdale of New York City. In January of 2000, Sally and Jim Barksdale created a $100 million dollar endowment to establish the successful Barksdale Reading Institute. Their generosity focused solely on improving the literacy skills of under-resourced Mississippi children in the third grade and below. It remains the largest private gift to early childhood literacy in this nation's history. Among Sally and Jim's philanthropic gifts, they also established the McDonnell - Barksdale Honors College endowment at The University of MS, as well as the Two Sisters Scholarship Fund at Goodwill Industries of MS. They also created at the University of MS Medical Center full medical scholarships for African American students. Sally was also on the Board of The University of Mississippi Foundation and The Jackson State University Development Board. She was a founding member of the Ole Miss Women's Council. She was awarded an honorary Doctorate of Public Service Degree from Millsaps College, The University of MS Humanitarian Award; the Friends of Education Award by the Mississippi Association of School Administrators, and the Phi Beta Kappa Certificate of Appreciation. A celebration of Sally's life will be held at St. James Episcopal Church at 3921 Oak Ridge Drive, Jackson, MS at 2:00 P.M. on Thursday, December 11, 2003. Visitation with the family will begin at 12 noon in the church parish hall. The Barksdale family requests that in lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the charity of their choice or to the Ole Miss Women's Council (Sally McDonnell Barksdale Memorial) of the University of Mississippi Foundation, P.O. Box 249, University, MS 38677.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Governor Drops Investigation
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said in interviews with CNN and Fox News that he would not hire a private investigator to look into accusations of sexual misconduct against him. In his campaign for governor, Mr. Schwarzenegger said he would have the accusations investigated after the election. Last month, his spokesman said an investigator had been chosen and would soon begin work. But Mr. Schwarzenegger said on CNN, ''I have been elected by the people to come up here and do a job, and that is what I am doing now.'' Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Tom Valenti; For Grandma, With Amore
description: BEFORE Tom Valenti started his first restaurant job, in Ithaca, N.Y., the chef told him to spend three months reading the ''Escoffier Cook Book.'' ''I was 18 and it was totally foreign to me,'' Mr. Valenti recalled last week at his apartment in Washington Heights. ''From the top of the recipe to the bottom I didn't know what they were talking about. I didn't know what truffles or foie gras were. And I have to say, when I pick that book up now I still don't understand it.''

title: U.S.C. Still Controls Its Fate In One Poll
description: The fate of Southern California, still hoping for a piece of the national football championship, depends on how it fares in the Rose Bowl against Michigan on Jan. 1 and the mood of the 65 writers and broadcasters who vote in the Associated Press poll.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Businessman To Become Yale Officer
description: John Pepper, left, who retired last year as chairman of the Procter & Gamble Company, has been named vice president for finance and administration at Yale University, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Robert L. Culver, who left the university in August. Mr. Pepper said he would use his 40 years of experience in business to ''bring greater quality and effectiveness and lower cost to support services.'' He said he expected to serve in the post for no more than two years. Mr. Pepper, 65, graduated from Yale in 1960 with a bachelor's degree in history. Kimetris N. Baltrip (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are the owners of the jungle. We have always rejected the petroleum companies. We do not accept them.''

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Apology Accepted, But Let's Not Shake Hands

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STARR, ROGER
description: STARR--Roger. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Roger Starr, associated with The Times from 1977 until retiring in 1988.

title: Divided Court Says Government Can Ban Soft Money
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 - By a narrow vote and with a broadly pragmatic rationale, the Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld all the major provisions of the campaign finance law that Congress passed last year to try to curb a flood of money into national politics that had all but swamped a previous generation's effort at regulation.

title: Musicians Urge Board To Keep Maazel
description: After months of speculation about whether the New York Philharmonic would replace Lorin Maazel as its music director or extend his contract, the orchestra's board has begun to confront the question, and the musicians are rallying around him.

title: New York Man in Qaeda Case Will Serve 8 Years
description: A Lackawanna, N.Y., man who left a camp run by Al Qaeda in Afghanistan before completing training and said he had declined an offer to meet with Osama bin Laden received an eight-year prison sentence on Tuesday.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Killer Of 17 Teenagers Sentenced To Death
description: A man who kidnapped, tortured, killed and then buried 17 teenage boys beneath his home in central China was sentenced to death after a short, emotional trial, Chinese news media reported. An estimated 1,000 people gathered outside the courthouse in Henan Province to listen on loudspeakers to the three-hour trial of Huang Yong, 29. The serial killings attracted widespread media attention as parents blamed the police for refusing pleas to investigate after the youths began disappearing in 2001. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAVAGE, JOHN PATRICK
description: SAVAGE--John Patrick, of Woodside, died on November 28, 2003, at age 57. Loving father of John Moore. Loving brother of Michael. Dear brother-in-law of Margaret Hanczyk, Peter J. Choray, Sonya Savage and the late Robert Choray. Beloved Uncle Johnny of Meghan, Michael, Sarah, Emily, Elizabeth, Victoria, Peter James and Kiera. Beloved former husband of Barbara. Dear son of the late Elizabeth McGourty and John. Beloved son-in-law of the late Peter Choray. Also survived by family and friends here and in County Leitrim, Ireland. Retired from the New York Times. Retired member I.U.O.E., Local 30. U.S. Army Veteran. Member of the Leitrim Society. Funeral December 1, 2003.

title: A Village Renaissance for Sant Ambroeus
description: Sant Ambroeus, the coffee bar and restaurant that was a fixture on the Upper East Side until two years ago, has reopened in Greenwich Village, at 259 West Fourth Street (Perry Street). The room is a sleek wood, marble and mosaic retreat for excellent espresso, gelati in a dozen flavors and fine pastries. But it lacks the show window filled with special-occasion cakes that stopped shoppers on Madison Avenue. Dimitri Pauli, whose father, Hans, opened Sant Ambroeus in 1982, owns it with Gherardo Guarducci. They have Mario Danieli preparing the same breakfast, lunch and dinner dishes that he made uptown.

title: Gap Chairman Will Resign; His Son Will Be His Successor
description: Donald G. Fisher, the real estate entrepreneur who founded Gap Inc. in 1969 because he could not find jeans that fit, said yesterday that he would step down as chairman of the company, effective in May. He will be succeeded by his son Robert J. Fisher, 49.

title: Our Towns; 'Volunteer' Versus 'Firefighter'
description: IT has probably been equal parts skill and luck that have carried George M. Xylas -- lawyer by day, volunteer fire captain any other time -- through a dozen successful years of putting out blazes across this waterside city as a member of the Springdale Fire Company.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: VIRGINIA: PSYCHOLOGIST TESTIFIES IN SNIPER CASE Lee Malvo, the younger defendant in the Washington-area sniper shootings, told a court-appointed psychologist that he had shot and killed a 21-year-old woman in Tacoma, Wash., about eight months before the sniper spree began, the psychologist testified. The psychologist, Dewey G. Cornell, told jurors that Mr. Malvo considered the shooting a test of his commitment to the violent "mission" of John A. Muhammad, the convicted mastermind of the shootings. The woman, Keenya Cook, was the niece of a close friend of Mr. Muhammad's former wife. James Dao (NYT)

title: Pataki Vows No Increases In State Taxes
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said he would not raise taxes to balance the budget next year and would do all he can to make sure that the Legislature holds to a timetable to start rolling back some of the taxes that were increased this year.

title: Bush warns Taiwan to keep status quo: China welcomes U.S. stance
description: WASHINGTON:  President George W. Bush, in comments welcomed Tuesday by the visiting Chinese prime minister, Wen Jiabao, said that the United States strongly opposed a move in Taiwan to stage a referendum favored by those who support independence from the mainland.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett-Packard Merging 2 Units
description: Hewlett-Packard will merge its services and business-computer divisions to avoid duplicating sales work, the chief executive, Carleton S. Fiorina, said. The new business, technology solutions, cuts the company's operating units to three from four, Ms. Fiorina told an analysts' conference in New York yesterday. The chief financial officer, Robert P. Wayman, said that profit would be $1.43 a share on sales of $77.3 billion in the year ending next October, matching analysts' estimates.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: AMP Breakup Approved
description: Shareholders in AMP, Australia's largest funds manager, voted overwhelmingly to separate the group's profitable Australian division from its failed British unit, which incurred losses of about $1 billion in life insurance and in the stock market in recent years. The British operation will be listed on the London exchange after refinancing. The AMP chairman, Peter Willcox, warned that a write-down of the value of the British unit, HHG, could be higher than the previously expected 2.5 billion Austrian dollars ($1.85 billion) if HHG initially trades below its valuation. John Shaw (NYT)

title: U.N. to Keep Its Staff Out of Iraq for Security Concerns
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 10  Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that the dangerous situation in Iraq had caused him to rule out a swift resumption of a United Nations presence inside Iraq.

title: Music With the Passion Polished Out
description: Near the beginning of his concert at Hammerstein Ballroom on Monday night, Seal looked out at the audience and saw a world beyond race and beyond racism, a place where people could transcend their differences and come together through music. (His music, of course.)

title: Costco Reports 9.9% Profit Rise in Quarter
description: ISSAQUAH, Wash., Dec. 9 (Dow Jones/AP) - The Costco Wholesale Corporation said on Tuesday that it had a 9.9 percent rise in profit on surging revenue in its latest quarter.

title: Sweet, Fat and Salty: Three Food Groups Make Music Together
description: LIKE Fred and Ginger, Roquefort and Sauternes are a classic pair, the pungent saltiness of the cheese standing toe to toe with the intense sweetness of the wine. But does that paradigm apply to other blue-veined cheeses and to other sweet white wines? In this tasting, rieslings generously endowed with residual sugar proved largely in harmony with the blues.

title: Brand Names Are Paying the Price For a Change in Shopping Trends
description: Have brands become a blur for American shoppers?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: The Bottom Line Misses Rent Deadline
description: New York University has moved a step closer to the eviction of the Bottom Line nightclub from an N.Y.U.-owned building after the nightclub's owners missed a Monday deadline to pay in full about $190,000 in back rent. A judge had given the club five days to pay, but the club responded with an offer of partial payment, about 20 percent of the sum over the next two weeks, said Josh Taylor, a university spokesman. Mr. Taylor said the club's rent has been in arrears for three years. In a statement, the Bottom Line's owners said that N.Y.U.'s lawyers had made it clear that the school ''was not interested in any way, shape or form in entertaining this proposal or any proposal, and in fact had no desire to have any communication with the Bottom Line at all.'' The statement did not indicate whether the owners would resist eviction. Kimetris N. Baltrip (NYT)

title: Restaurant Hiring May Lead the Way To Wider Job Gains
description: The restaurant industry has gone on a hiring spree over the last four months, suggesting that broader gains in the job market could be on the way.

title: Ex-Senator Kerrey Is Named To Federal 9/11 Commission
description: Bob Kerrey, the former Democratic senator from Nebraska, was appointed on Tuesday to the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, a panel he will join with six months left in its inquiry.

title: Democrat Wins San Francisco Mayor's Race
description: In a contest that the Democratic Party considered a must win, a Democratic businessman, Gavin Newsom, was elected mayor of San Francisco on Tuesday, fending off a strong challenge from a member of the Green Party.

Devoted grandfather of Alexandra, Claudia, Gregory, Douglas and Katherine. Great-grandfather of Pearce, Gioia and Crosby. Family will receive friends Tuesday 6-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. Funeral services Wednesday, 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Putin Tries to Dismiss Any Talk Of Urging Constitutional Change
description: President Vladimir V. Putin spoke out pre-emptively on Tuesday against those who, he said, hoped to turn the results of the parliamentary elections on Sunday into a mandate to amend Russia's still young Constitution.

description: In the summer of 2001, the once-lofty stock price of SBC Communications was coming down, but the company still appeared strong.

title: France and Germany Flex Muscles on Charter
description: In a sign that Europe's grand experiment with a constitution could unravel, France and Germany threatened Tuesday to reject it if smaller countries continued to insist on negotiating changes intended to enhance their power.

title: Bad News for New Jersey Bears
description: New Jersey is in the midst of its first black bear hunt in 33 years. That the state has enough bears to make them fair game is a miracle of conservation, considering that the population had dwindled to fewer than 100 when hunts were suspended. While estimates of current numbers vary from about 1,000 to 3,000, there is no question that the black bear is back. What makes the bears a target is not just their proliferation, but their aggressiveness in seeking food. Uninvited bears have entered homes, frightened children and attacked pets.

title: SUICIDE BOMBER KILLS 5 IN MOSCOW NEAR RED SQUARE
description: A suicide bomber blew herself up outside a historic hotel in the center of Moscow on Tuesday, officials said, killing at least 5 others and seriously wounding 13 several hundred feet from the Kremlin, Red Square and Parliament.

title: Aye, Hal, Such Commotion as if 'Twere the Globe
description: The lobby buzz at the first intermission was positive.

title: Parmalat Moves to Allay Concerns About Its Debts
description: Parmalat, the embattled Italian dairy giant, tried to calm investors Tuesday by hiring a well-known turnaround specialist and announcing that it would make good on 150 million euros ($183 million) of debt that came due on Monday.

title: Corrections

title: U.S. Considers Importing Influenza Vaccine
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday that they were exploring ways to import influenza vaccine from Europe and redistribute supplies to meet any shortages in this country.

title: Call by Gore Does Little to Soothe Lieberman
description: Stung by Al Gore's endorsement of Howard Dean for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman on Tuesday dismissed a telephone call he received from Mr. Gore earlier in the day as ''too late.''

title: A Braised Winter
description: BRAISED dishes like beef stew may feature green, orange, yellow or red vegetables but their most appetizing color is brown, the shade of brown whose glossy darkness shouts intensity and richness.

title: Drugs Cited as N.Y.U. Leap Is Ruled Accident, Not Suicide
description: A New York University student was high on drugs when he jumped to his death from a floor in Elmer Holmes Bobst Library at the university in October, the New York City medical examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the court verdicts against 15 members of a Greek radical group known as November 17 misstated the relationship between relatives of two of the group's American victims. Stephanie Tsantes is a daughter of Capt. George Tsantes, who was killed in 1983, and a sister of Chip Tsantes. (She is not related to Tim or Nicholas Welch, or their sister Molly Welch Ball, who are the children of Richard Welch, the C.I.A. station chief in Athens slain by the group in 1975.)

title: WYETH EXPECTS LOWER 4TH-QUARTER EARNINGS
description: Wyeth, the maker of Advil painkillers, said earnings in the fourth quarter would be reduced by as much as $517.5 million as it repays debt, writes down the value of assets and reorganizes operations. Net income in the three-month period will be reduced by as much as 39 cents a share, the company said. Wyeth is closing a plant in Singapore because of slowing sales of the Premarin hormone-replacement therapies, which have been linked to cancer and heart diseases. The company is also repaying $1 billion in notes due in 2006 and will offer to buy back the rest of its $1 billion in notes due in 2005, it said. The announcement was made after markets closed.

title: Lender Sees Weaker Profit As Mortgage Boom Eases
description: Washington Mutual, a big mortgage lender, said yesterday that its earnings for the year would fall well short of forecasts, reflecting the sharp slowdown in home mortgage and refinancing activity.

title: Fed Keeps Rates Steady but Paves Way for Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 - The Federal Reserve kept its benchmark short-term interest rate at 1 percent on Tuesday, the lowest level in 45 years, but it laid the groundwork for a gradual tightening of monetary policy next year.

title: Reyes Will Get to Keep Number
description: Kazuo Matsui is taking Jos Reyes's position but stopped short of taking the number off his back. Matsui will be introduced as a Met today at a news conference in Manhattan and will unveil his new uniform, but the number will not be Reyes's. Reyes will keep No. 7, three people involved in Matsui's negotiations with the Mets said yesterday.

title: Attackers Kill 2 U.S. Soldiers and Wound 4 Others in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 10 — Two American soldiers were killed and four wounded in the northern city of Mosul in separate attacks today, one day after a suicide bomber injured dozens of soldiers by driving a car laden with explosives into a military base near the same city, military officials said.

title: Suicide Bombers Strike at 2 U.S. Bases, Wounding Dozens of G.I.'s
description: Two suicide bombers set off explosions at United States military bases on Tuesday, killing only themselves but wounding several dozen American soldiers on a day that saw a sharp increase in violence around Iraq.

title: Fed Keeps Rates Steady But Paves Way for Rise
description: The Federal Reserve kept its benchmark short-term interest rate at 1 percent on Tuesday, the lowest level in 45 years, but it laid the groundwork for a gradual tightening of monetary policy next year.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon To Take Up To $3.7 Billion In Charges
description: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it would have expenses of as much as $3.7 billion through March for pension costs and early retirements of 21,260 employees. The $2.8 billion expense for the early retirements announced last month is equivalent to 99 cents a share in the fourth quarter after taxes, the company said. The pension charges of $700 million to $900 million will be recorded mostly in the first quarter.

title: Paul Simon, Former Senator From Illinois, Is Dead at 75
description: Paul Simon, a five-term Democratic congressman and two-term senator from Illinois who ran unsuccessfully for his party's presidential nomination in 1988 and retired from politics seven years ago, died on Tuesday in Springfield, Ill. He was 75.

title: The Powering Up of the Power Lunch
description: LAST week, the Composite Index of Leading Economic Indicators rose, the Dow was close to 10,000 for the first time in 18 months, and Julian Niccolini, an owner of the Four Seasons restaurant, added three tables in front of the matre d'htel's stand in the Grill Room.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUMENTHAL, ISIDOR
description: BLUMENTHAL--Isidor of Far Rockaway, NY, passed away on the eve of his 94th birthday on December 9th, 2003. Devoted husband of 67 years to Ann (Chanchy). Beloved father of Reuben and Beth, Deborah and Rabbi Marvin Bash, David and Barbara, as well as seven grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Beloved brother of Bernard and May Blumenthal, Sam and Melanie Blumenthal, George (z'l) and Rose Blumenthal, Murray(z'l), Molly (z'l) Levine, Solomon (z'l) and Rosalind (z'l) Elbaum. Born in 1909 in Ansonia, Connecticut, he exemplified a life that combined Orthodox Jewish traditions and Yankee charm. He was active in many Jewish causes including serving in leadership roles at Congregation Sons of Israel, Yeshiva Ohel Moshe and the Jewish Community House in Bensonhurst, Congregation Kneseth Israel, Congregation Shaare Tfilah and Yeshiva B'nai Torah of Far Rockaway, and the Atlantic and Long Beach Jewish Center. He was a tireless fundraiser for Shaare Tzedek Hospital in Jerusalem. But the gift he leaves with us was his love of family and his determination to keep his evergrowing extended family in close touch. His favorite adage, among many, was ''Family is life and life is family.'' Services will be today, Wednesday, December 10th 11:30 A.M. at The BoulevardRiverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Nursing Homes Face Challenge As the Young Fill the Beds
description: When two residents of the state's largest nursing home were arrested this weekend on drug charges, their case illuminated more than a bizarre tale of heroin abuse and sales amid the wheelchairs and linoleum hallways at the home, the A. Holly Patterson Geriatric Center.

Rada III and Sean Thomas Rada. Dear father-in-law of Kathryn. Former Captain in the U.S. Army, George was a realist painter who worked and exhibited in NYC. description: The French police arrested a suspected military leader of the Basque separatist group ETA in the southwest village of Lons. The Spanish police said the suspect, Gorka Palacios Alday, 29, was responsible for a series of attacks in Spain in 2000. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Clinton Urges More Housing Loans
description: Criticizing the Bush administration for having ''dropped the ball'' on housing policy, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed yesterday to make it easier for residents of New York State to take out federal loans to purchase homes. Senator Clinton said she would introduce legislation to increase the ceiling for Federal Housing Authority loans to match an area's median home price, which in New York State is about $310,000, as opposed to the current limit of about $290,000. If Congress adopts the legislation, she said, nearly 900,000 more people will be eligible for the loans. Mrs. Clinton made her remarks during a speech on housing policy marking the 30th anniversary of the New York Housing Conference, a coalition of nonprofit and private developers, bankers and community groups. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: Judge Lifts Bear-Hunt Ban On Delaware Gap Parkland
description: As New Jersey's black bear hunt entered a second day in the snowy woods of the state's northwestern corner, judges in Washington and Trenton dismissed all pending challenges by animal welfare organizations on Tuesday. The decisions mean that no federal or state-owned park in the hunting zone is closed to hunters.

description: A federal appeals court in Manhattan overturned a decision yesterday that had allowed judges in New York State to attend campaign events and to endorse candidates.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Conference Threat
description: American officials warned that the Taliban and Al Qaeda were planning attacks either to disrupt a meeting in Kabul on Saturday of the grand council, or loya jirga, as it convenes to finalize a constitution or to terrorize the main highway to the city to prevent delegates from reaching it. At a briefing, the United States ambassador, Zalmay Khalilzad, said an operation involving 2,000 soldiers in the south and east of the country that started a week ago was part of an effort to knock the insurgents off balance ahead of the conference. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Democrats Wrestle With the Gore Factor
description: He is not running for president in 2004. But Al Gore was a dominant figure in the final Democratic presidential debate of the year here on Tuesday, as the candidates questioned -- and tried to minimize -- the impact Mr. Gore would have on the battle for the Democratic nomination with his surprise endorsement of Howard Dean earlier in the day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENNEY, STEPHEN G.
description: KENNEY--Stephen G. The Stratton Community mourns the loss of Stephen ''Stevek'' Kenney, a longtime member of the Stratton family. Stevek was the inspiration and energy behind our Allegro and Freestyle programs, sharing his passion for the sport of freestyle skiing and enriching the lives of hundreds of young people. He was coach, mentor and so much more. In his 30 years at Stratton, Stevek was at the heart of an extended family that transcends time and distance. Stevek personified those values we hold deeply and that we hope to pass on to our children, friends, and family. We are blessed for the opportunity to have had Stevek in our lives. Our thoughts and prayers are with all his family and friends in this most difficult time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHERNICK, ARTHUR
description: CHERNICK--Arthur. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Arthur Chernick, a cherished friend and longtime leader at UJA-Federation and our beneficiary agencies. We extend our deepest sympathies to his entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: American Know-How Can't Prevail Nohow
description: ''Power Trip,'' Paul Devlin's superbly balanced and organized documentary about the politics of electricity in the former Soviet Republic of Georgia, offers a cautionary reminder that the basic services we take for granted in the United States are often luxuries elsewhere. It also underscores what became painfully evident at the height of the Enron scandal: political power and the distribution of energy are intimately connected.

description: TORPEY--William L. Of Staten Island, on December 9, 2003. Beloved husband of Pauline. Loving father of William, Eugene, John and Daniel. Also survived and loved by six grandchildren. A private cremation from Hanley Funeral Home, 60 New Dorp Lane, Staten Island.

Pisani, M.D. Loving stepmother of B. Michael; Anthony J.; John and Christopher Pisani. Devoted aunt of Glenavie Norton; Barry D. McMullan; William G. McMullan; Gail F. Kelly; W. Ross Fillippone. Holle Funeral Home, 2122 Millburn Ave., Maplewood, NJ on Saturday, December 13, 3 PM.

title: Where Sushi Is a High-Energy Meal
description: OUTSIDE of Christian Science reading rooms, Japanese restaurants tend to be the quietest public places in the city. By tradition, the cuisine calls for a contemplative setting that encourages the full appreciation of dishes designed to please the eye and the mind, as well as the taste buds.

title: Brave face of the Maryinsky
description: ST. PETERSBURG  The world outside Russia got a distorted impression of the severity of a September fire in a Maryinsky Theater warehouse, when news reports estimated the damage at only $225,000. In fact, about 30 productions suffered various degrees of damage, imperiling the theater's 2003-04 St. Petersburg season and tours to Germany, Japan and the United States.

title: Scientist Links Man to Climate Over the Ages
description: Humans have altered the world's climate by generating heat-trapping gases since almost the beginning of civilization and even prevented the start of an ice age several thousand years ago, a scientist said on Tuesday.

title: Pressure on Pennington Underscores Weak Spots
description: It was, until last Sunday, the most comforting of statistics: the Jets had yielded 18 sacks in their first 12 games, an indicator of the premium they placed on protecting their most precious assets. But that figure was deceptive and it figures to shape part of the Jets' off-season plans.

title: 2 Would-Be Robbers Shot Dead at Pet Store
description: Two men who were attempting to rob a Brooklyn pet store were shot and killed in a confrontation with the store's owner and an employee last night, the police and residents said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: 70's Terrorist Freed
description: The authorities freed Rolf Clemens Wagner, 59, the longest-jailed member of the Red Army Faction, a far-left terrorist group of the 1970's. Pardoned last month by President Johannes Rau, he had been serving a life sentence since 1979 for charges including the killing of an industrialist. Just 4 of the 26 members of the group, also known as Baader-Meinhof, sentenced to life remain in prison. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Al Gore Places an Early Bet
description: Wearing the mantle of Al Gore's newly minted endorsement, Howard Dean has completed his ascent from political nowhere to the front-runner's spot in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. Yesterday's surprising endorsement highlighted one of the unintended consequences of the Democrats' vaunted nomination reforms more than a generation ago. Having abolished the smoke-filled convention free-for-all, the party has created an ethereal system in which a candidate's job is to conjure an early sense of a steamroller while the nation mutely watches. For the Dean campaign, Mr. Gore's blessing was just what the doctor ordered.

title: Florida Court Orders New Trial for Boy Serving Life Sentence
description: MIAMI, Dec. 10  A Florida appeals court panel ordered a new trial on Wednesday for Lionel Tate, whose life prison sentence for murdering a playmate when he was 12 became an international rallying point against treating juvenile offenders as harshly as adults.

title: Pentagon Rules on Iraq Contracts Draw Criticism Abroad
description: PARIS, Dec. 10  France, Germany, Russia and Canada today assailed the Pentagon's decision to bar them from competing for $18.6 billion in contracts for rebuilding Iraq. The European Union vowed to investigate the legality of Washington's move.

description: The owners of a Rhode Island nightclub and the tour manager of a heavy-metal band were indicted on Tuesday on charges of involuntary manslaughter in a fire at the nightclub that killed 100 people and injured nearly 200 last February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAHN, ERIC LAWRENCE VALENTINE
description: GRAHN -- Eric Lawrence Valentine, 72. Returned to his Lord on December 8, 2003 after a long battle with lung disease and cancer. Predeceased earlier this year by his wife, Juliet. Beloved father of Rebecka and Dominick Russo, Lawrence and Christine Grahn, Christina and Gregory. Loving MorFar to Justina, Maribeatta and Quinn Russo and FarFar to Corinne and Lilianna Grahn. He began his seafaring career at 15 as a galley boy and later attended the Kings Point USMM Academy. He received a commission in the US Navy as Lt. and was chief engineer on the USS ''Rankin''. Retired owner of Weber & Grahn Conditioning Corp. and W&G Service, HVAC companies serving the ''East End''. Mentor to many, generous of his time, talent and spirit to those he met along his travels, he left a unique and indelible mark on this world. His whistle and easygoing way will be missed. The family will receive friends at the WhiteVoltz Funeral Home, 364 E. Main St., Bay Shore, N.Y. Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Funeral service on Saturday 11am at St Luke's Lutheran Church, Bay Shore. Donations in his memory can be made to the Philanthropic Arm of the American College of Chest Physicians: 330 Dundee Rd., Northbrook, IL 60062 or via the internet @ chestfoundation.org

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: KING OF THE ROAD NO MORE Shanghai plans to ban bicycles from its major roads next year, banishing China's most popular form of transportation from its congested streets to make more room for cars, official newspapers said. (AP)

title: Pressure on Canada's Online Drug Sellers
description: Neither Mark Rzepka's colleagues nor his competitors were amused when The Winnipeg Free Press published a two-part series recently about the lavish way Mr. Rzepka and his wife had decorated their new 6,800-square-foot house in this prairie city.

title: Debate on Human Cloning Is Put Off by U.N. for a Year
description: The General Assembly on Tuesday ducked for a year a polarizing debate over human cloning that has set the Bush administration against some allies like Britain and much of the world's scientific community.

title: AMERICA WEST PILOTS LET STAND A CONTRACT DEFEAT
description: America West Airlines' pilots union decided not to vote again on a proposed contract that was rejected last week by a five-vote margin. America West, a unit of the America West Holdings Corporation of Phoenix, said it would not object if the union representing its 1,700 pilots wanted to vote again because of the narrow loss. The proposal was the second turned down since March; the two sides have been in talks since February 2000. The rejected $30 million proposal would have increased pay 14 percent over its three-year term, provided a bonus when signed and created a new retirement plan.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page profile on Nov. 30 about Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts misidentified the college attended by George Butler, a friend who is making a movie about him. (The error was repeated in some copies on Friday in the Public Lives profile of Mr. Butler.) He attended the University of North Carolina, not Yale.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts Briefing column on Monday about a new jazz series at Merkin Concert Hall in Manhattan included an erroneous reference from the hall to the educational background of the pianist Andrew Hill. He does not have a doctorate from Colgate University, according to university officials.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: More Guilty Pleas In Rape Case
description: The remaining three defendants in the rape, beating and robbery of a woman in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park last December pleaded guilty yesterday to taking part in the attack, prosecutors said. The men -- Jose Hernandez, 29; Armando Juvenal, 21; and Carlos Rodriguez, 23 -- made their pleas before Justice Randall T. Eng of State Supreme Court in Queens, who has said he will impose a sentence of 20 to 23 years. Two other men, Victor Cruz and Luis Carmona, pleaded guilty over the past week in the attack, which took place on Dec. 19, 2002. The five men had faced charges of rape, kidnapping, robbery and other crimes, and penalties of up to 50 years in prison if convicted, said the Queens district attorney Richard A. Brown. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Makers of AIDS Drugs Easing Costs in Southern Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 10  Two major makers of anti-AIDS drugs agreed today to expand the licensing of the drugs in southern Africa to a host of generic manufacturers, potentially making both existing and new, more powerful AIDS treatments available at drastically lower prices.

title: Democrats Wrestle With the Gore Factor in Debate
description: DURHAM, N.H., Dec. 9  He is not running for president in 2004. But Al Gore was a dominant figure in the final Democratic presidential debate of the year here on Tuesday, as the candidates questioned  and tried to minimize  the impact Mr. Gore would have on the battle for the Democratic nomination with his surprise endorsement of Howard Dean earlier in the day.

title: That Old College Try At Being Sophisticated
description: In ''Juvenilia,'' a new play by Wendy MacLeod at Playwrights Horizons, the sexual mores of the young get a frantic but ultimately sympathetic airing. The play is about the struggles of college seniors to parse the co-mysteries of love and lust. And like hormonally fueled 20-year-olds everywhere, the four characters are eager to experiment with one another, to hypothesize beforehand about their experiments and analyze them endlessly afterward.

title: High-Stakes Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Baby-Faced Little Rascals Who Pack Saturday Night Specials in Baggy Pants
description: Bearing a 2000 copyright, Adam Davidson's ''Way Past Cool'' opens today at the Two Boots Pioneer Theater in the East Village. It is not hard to see why this small, sympathetic but ultimately unsatisfying movie spent so much time on the shelf. ''Way Past Cool'' awkwardly straddles two genres, the violent urban thriller and the sentimental recollection of childhood, a little as if ''Boyz N the Hood'' had been crossbred with ''Stand by Me.''

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Rebels Renege On Promise To Free Tourists
description: The Marxist rebel group National Liberation Army said it would not free four Israelis and a Briton before Christmas, as it had pledged after releasing two backpackers from Spain and Germany last month. The group said government military operations in the northern mountains made it too risky for them to release the hostages, who were kidnapped Sept. 12. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Growth Estimate Lowered
description: Japan's gross domestic product in the July-September period fell more than a third as capital spending grew less than first announced, according to a government report. Japan's economy grew at an annualized rate of 1.4 percent in the period compared with the previous three months, rather than the 2.2 percent growth announced in mid-November, the report said. The revision resulted mostly from a smaller increase in corporate capital investment and a larger decline in public works spending. The government also reduced its growth estimates for three of the last four quarters. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Plans Reveal World's Tallest Tower, But Only 70 Stories Will Be Inhabited
description: The nearly completed design for the signature tower at the World Trade Center site would recapture the title of world's tallest building for New York City without forcing anyone to work higher than 70 stories in the sky.

title: Iowa and Harlem Rallies Set Scene for Gore's Endorsement
description: The scene in the ballroom on Tuesday resembled 100 other Howard Dean rallies, a blanket of blue ''Doctor Is In'' placards dotted with the green, black and purple of the unions backing him. But instead of a phalanx of youngsters in Dean for America T-shirts, the stage held just Dr. Dean and Al Gore, their fists flung skyward in the traditional politicians' pose of triumph.

title: Fed Statement on Interest Rates
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged:

title: Knicks Are Going Downhill Out West
description: The Knicks were depleted and deflated.

title: Inventories Up in October
description: Wholesale inventories rose 0.5 percent in October, the Commerce Department said yesterday, the biggest increase this year, as companies tried to keep enough goods on hand to meet improving sales.

title: Freddie Mac to Pay $125 Million Fine
description: Freddie Mac , the nation's second-largest source of home mortgage financing, said today it had reached a settlement with its federal regulator on charges it manipulated earnings over the past three years. As part of the settlement, the company agreed to pay a $125 million fine.

(The error was repeated in some copies on Friday in the Public Lives profile of Mr. Butler.) He attended the University of North Carolina, not Yale.

title: About New York; Ed Koch's Opinion? Don't Ask. He'll Tell.
description: IN his role as movie critic, he thinks that Sean Penn is an O.K. actor with less-than-classic features: ''A Brad Pitt he's not.'' In his role as political commentator, he thinks that Madeleine Albright, the former secretary of state, should be shunned for criticizing American foreign policy while promoting her memoir in France: ''Albright: Not very bright.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PINKETT, MARY
description: PINKETT--Mary. The City University of New York deeply mourns the death of former City Councilwoman, Mary Pinkett, a Brooklyn College Alumna, the first African-American woman elected to the New York City Council. She was an excellent and dedicated supporter of CUNY and educational oppotunity during her three decades of service in the Council. She will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her family. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr., Chairman Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

title: Gay Ex-Officers Say 'Don't Ask' Doesn't Work
description: Three retired military officers, two generals and an admiral who have been among the most senior uniformed officers to criticize the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy for homosexuals in the military, disclosed on Tuesday that they are gay.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suit Against Spraying Can Continue
description: A federal appeals court panel ruled yesterday that environmental groups could continue their legal challenge to New York City's use of pesticides against West Nile virus. The groups argue that such spraying violates the federal Clean Water Act because of its possible effect on the water supply. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit overturned a trial court ruling that had thrown out the groups' lawsuit. In the decision, the judges said they found no basis for the district court's interpretation of the clean-water act, the foundation on which the lawsuit was dismissed. The judges stated that ''any citizen'' might bring a suit to enforce the act's requirements. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Wireless To Respond To F.C.C.
description: AT&T Wireless said yesterday that it planned to send a letter today to federal regulators explaining that it had made ''significant progress'' in enabling customers to switch their phone numbers more quickly to and from other cellphone companies. It is sending the letter in response to an inquiry made last week by the Federal Communications Commission, which received complaints that AT&T Wireless customers were facing delays when they tried to change cellular carriers. On Nov. 24, new rules went into effect that allow consumers to take their numbers when they switch mobile carriers. But thousands of customers of the six major mobile carriers have faced days of delays in getting their numbers. AT&T Wireless said it made improvements to its software and was now on par with competitors in helping customers take numbers with them. Still, the company said it was telling customers it could take three to five days to switch their numbers. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Hook, Line and Sinker: A Life of Telling Tall Tales
description: Tim Burton -- who made ''Pee-Wee's Big Adventure,'' ''Edward Scissorhands'' and the first two ''Batman'' movies, among others -- is surely one of the most prodigiously imaginative filmmakers around. His best movies glide effortlessly from devilish whimsy to startling perversity, and even when his storytelling falters his inimitably strange visual sensibility leaves its haunting, humorous traces on the memory.

title: Come-From-Behind Victory Creates a Two-Game Streak
description: Islanders Coach Steve Stirling spoke in measured tones Tuesday night, indicating neither victory nor defeat. The music piped into the Islanders' locker room was good-time Jimmy Buffett, but played at a meditation-friendly volume.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KESTNER, ZENIR, KIM
description: KESTNER-ZENIR--Kim. The Executive Board and members of The Mount Sinai Alumni, are deeply saddened by the untimely death of our beloved staff member. She will be sorely missed. Our most sincere condolences are extended to her entire family.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
description: Orders for machinery from private-sector companies, a crucial gauge of corporate investment, rose 17.4 percent in October, compared with September, according to a government report. The figure, which was three times what economists had expected, more than erased declines of the last three months. The number suggested that companies were optimistic enough to use profits from exports to invest in factories and offices. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A Documentary Records a Fierce Struggle for Power, Electric and Otherwise
description: When the filmmaker Paul Devlin was looking for financial help with a project he described as ''a movie about the electrical sector in the former Soviet Republic of Georgia,'' people yawned. But when he told them he was making ''a nonfiction narrative about corruption, assassination and street rioting over electricity,'' they paid attention, even if they still did not give him any money.

description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Chrysler Deal Was a Merger, Executive Tells Court
description: The chairman of DaimlerChrysler, Jrgen E. Schrempp, testified in federal court here on Tuesday that Daimler-Benz executives deceived no one about the terms of the company's 1998 merger with Chrysler.

title: All Bets Off as Yankees Reconsider Right Field
description: In this madcap Yankees off-season, even the sure things are not so sure anymore. It had seemed for weeks to be a foregone conclusion that Gary Sheffield would sign on to be the Yankees' right fielder. Now, it could be Vladimir Guerrero. With the principal owner, George Steinbrenner, in complete control of personnel moves, even club officials have no idea what will happen from day to day.

title: Backers See Free-Speech Issue In Hostos College Student's Trial
description: A Hostos Community College student is on trial in the Bronx on charges of assaulting a campus security officer two years ago during a protest against cuts in the college's English-as-a-second-language program.

title: The Dow Breaks Through 10,000 Before Falling Back
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose briefly above 10,000 yesterday, the first time the average has been above this psychologically important level in more than 18 months.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the court verdicts against 15 members of a Greek radical group known as November 17 misstated the relationship between relatives of two of the group's American victims. Stephanie Tsantes is a daughter of Capt. George Tsantes, who was killed in 1983, and a sister of Chip Tsantes. (She is not related to Tim or Nicholas Welch, or their sister Molly Welch Ball, who are the children of Richard Welch, the C.I.A. station chief in Athens slain by the group in 1975.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, LINDA
description: HOROWITZ--Linda. Your untimely death leaves a void in our family's lives forever. We shall truly miss you, along with our parents, the late Murray and Irene Pergament, who both died within the past year, and our late sister, Sherri Koeppel. We grieve together with Richard, Jill and Jeff, and Kyle, Max, and Sam Koeppel who will never again have the pleasure to enjoy your company. Linda, your courage and strength was truly unimaginable. Your positive focus towards life was at all times inspiring. May we be blessed by your spirited and cherished memories all the days of our lives and may you find rest and peace throughout eternity. Randi and Bruce Scott, Cole, and Wesley

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Elin's Relatives Sue
description: The Miami relatives of Elin Gonzlez filed a federal lawsuit saying federal agents used excessive force when they seized the boy in a raid in April 2000. The suit seeks unspecified compensatory and punitive damages from the agents, whose names were filed under seal. Elin was found clinging to an inner tube on Thanksgiving Day, 1999, after his mother drowned while trying to escape with him from Cuba to Florida. He returned to Cuba to live with his father after the raid. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: A Festival of Light and Shapes
description: The Hanukkah menorah can come in many forms and materials, from traditional silver to unusual forms made by contemporary artists.

description: FOR SALE: Weekend house, Chicago area; 2 bedrooms; 2 baths; 2,233 sq. ft.; newly renovated; furnished; asking $6 million; will consider any reasonable offer above $4.5 million.

title: German Judge Frees 9/11 Suspect, Citing New Evidence
description: BERLIN, Dec. 11  A judge surprised a Hamburg courtroom today by ordering the release of a Moroccan man accused of aiding the Sept. 11 hijackers, after the German police said they had seen evidence that a witness had testified to American interrogators that only four people from the Hamburg cell knew of the attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLENN, WILLIAM LOVE
description: GLENN--William Love, husband, father, grandfather, uncle, dear friend, retired company president and avid sailor, died unexpectedly in the early morning hours of Sunday, December 7, in St. Petersburg, Florida. He was 59. In addition to his wife, Maxine, and son, William, Mr. Glenn is survived by three grandchildren, Claire Elise, John Alden Grice, and Emma Grace Glenn; two brothers, Joseph Wooderson ''Woody'' Glenn III and Lawrence ''Larry'' Randolph Glenn; and a sister, Sarah Glenn Meyer. A public viewing will be held at DeVine Funeral Home, 293 South Street, Oyster Bay, Long Island, NY, from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m. and 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. on Friday, December 12. A public funeral service will be held at Christ Episcopal Church, 61 East Main Street, Oyster Bay, NY, on Saturday, December 13 at 9:30 a.m. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the ''Will Glenn fund for the love of sailing'' c/o Oyster Bay Sailing Foundation, PO Box 720 Oyster Bay, NY 11771.

title: If the Kitchen's Warm, It May Be the PC
description: WHEN Lyman and Suzanne Chapin built their house in Hopkinton, Mass., in 1987, the networking they had in mind was of the human variety. They kept the layout of the kitchen area open to create an atmosphere that would foster frequent interaction among the four family members.

title: Fumes From 2 Utility Fires Force Evacuations in Brooklyn
description: Homes on two blocks in Brooklyn were evacuated late Tuesday and yesterday after carbon monoxide seeped from electrical fires under the streets, the authorities said. Last night, authorities evacuated a set of houses in Queens. The fires were linked to rock salt spread over the weekend to melt snow and ice.

title: JUSTICES, IN A 5-TO-4 DECISION, BACK CAMPAIGN FINANCE LAW THAT CURBS CONTRIBUTIONS
description: By a narrow vote and with a broadly pragmatic rationale, the Supreme Court on Wednesday upheld all the major provisions of the campaign finance law that Congress passed last year to try to curb a flood of money into national politics that had all but swamped a previous generation's effort at regulation.

description: ALTERBAUM--Beatrice, on December 9, 2003. Beloved wife of the late George Alterbaum, M.D. Loving mother of Caryl Alterbaum Brief, Robert Alterbaum, M.D., and Ralph Alterbaum.

description: When Gov. Craig Benson announced on Tuesday that New Hampshire would start buying prescription drugs from Canada, the move seemed at once bold and careful.

description: THE City of Indianapolis, it has been reported, is reeling after United Airlines closed a maintenance center last spring that cost the government $320 million in subsidies. Do cities that offer generous subsidies to recruit businesses routinely get taken to the cleaners?

title: A New Prime Minister Is Ready to Take the Reins in Canada
description: Former Finance Minister Paul Martin takes over as prime Minister on Friday after a prolonged transition in which he threw bouquets of promises to liberals and conservatives, business and environmental groups, Westerners and urban dwellers.

title: PRESIDENT OF ST. JUDE MEDICAL TO BECOME CHAIRMAN
description: St. Jude Medical said its chairman and chief executive, Terry L. Shepherd, would retire, effective with the company's annual meeting in May. Mr. Shepherd, 50, became chief executive in May 1999 and was elected chairman three years later. St. Jude's president and chief operating officer, Daniel J. Starks, 49, will succeed Mr. Shepherd as chief executive and chairman, the company said. Mr. Shepherd, who had open-heart surgery in July, has worked to regain investor confidence after St. Jude fell behind Medtronic and Guidant in the development of heart-regulating devices.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: AOL Introduces Online Personals
description: America Online introduced a preview of its Love.com Web personals service yesterday, aiming to ride its success with instant-messaging software into the lucrative Internet dating sector. The company announced last month that it was building what it called a real-time personals site by pairing up the functionality and widespread distribution of its AOL Instant Messenger program with the growing popularity of online personals. Web-based dating networks have proven increasingly profitable as businesses including InterActiveCorp's Match.com and Yahoo have persuaded millions of people to look for potential mates online. Match.com, the current leader of the Web personals industry, reported $48.3 million in revenue last quarter, up 44 percent from a year earlier. AOL said Love.com would allow subscribers to browse other users' profiles, see who is online, and communicate through instant messaging.

title: After Firing by Falcons, Reeves Takes Early Exit
description: Dan Reeves, the sixth-winningest coach in National Football League history, became the first one to lose his job this season when he was fired by the Atlanta Falcons.
