description: McQUILLAN--William L. 85, retired advertising writer and creative director, died September 14, 2003 at his home in Gulfport, MS after a long illness. He is survived by family in NY, MS and MI. He will begreatly missed by colleagues, family and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'GRADY, WILLIAM JOHN
description: O'GRADY--William John, 83, of 59 Winthrop Rd, Guilford, CT, died Saturday, December 6, 2003 at Middlesex Hospice in Middletown, CT. Mr. O'Grady was born February 3, 1920 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of John and Helen (Barry) O'Grady, originally from County Kilkenny, Ireland. He graduated from St. John's Prep in Brooklyn. In 1942 he enlisted in the US Navy and served with the Joint Intelligence Collection Agency during World War II. Mr. O'Grady earned a bachelor's of science degree from Mount St. Mary's College in Emmitsburg, MD, in 1949. On September 29, 1951 he married Anne Hayes of Brooklyn. Mr. O'Grady was international marketing director for the Echlin Manufacturing Company in Branford, CT for 28 years, retiring in 1995. He is survived by seven sons and two daughters William M. of Ada, MI, Michael of Woodinville, WA, John of Lyme, CT, Patrick of Claremont, NH, Jim of Sherborn, MA, Thomas of Guilford, and Barry of South Windsor, CT, Mary A. O'Grady of Brooklyn, NY, and Anne L. O'Grady of London, England; a sister, Anastasia Thoelen of Waldwick, NJ, 15 grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his wife and four brothers: Michael O'Grady, Jack O'Grady, the Rev. James O'Grady and Thomas O'Grady. A Mass of Christian burial will be at St. Therese's Church, Branford, December 12 at 11AM. Friends may call Thursday, December 11 from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Guilford Funeral Home. Burial in St. Agnes Cemetery, Branford. Memorial contributions in Mr. O'Grady's memory may be made to Huntington's Disease Society of America, Research, 158 West 29th St, 7th Floor, NY, NY 10001-5300.

title: French Panel Recommends Banning Head Scarves in Schools
description: PARIS, Dec. 11 — As Europe struggles with the integration of its rising Muslim population and a new wave of anti-Semitism, a long-awaited official report on church-state relations in France is recommending sweeping changes in the way the country balances its fierce commitment to secularism with the demands of its religious minorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLUMENTHAL, ISIDOR
description: BLUMENTHAL--Isidor. The constituency of the Fashion Institute of Technology notes with sadness the passing of Isidor Blumenthal, president of Orchard Yarn & Thread Co., Inc. and Lion Brand Yarn Company since 1958. Mr. Blumenthal's enthusiasm for and support of FIT will be commemorated by naming an academic space in his honor, through a generous gift from his son, David Blumenthal, senior vice president and COO of Lion Brand Yarn Company. We extend our condolences to his family and colleagues. Dr. Joyce F. Brown, President, FIT CEO Educational Foundation For the Fashion Industries John J. Pomerantz, Chairman, Educational Foundation For the Fashion Industries

title: Sony Chooses an Outsider To Lead Entertainment Unit
description: The Sony Corporation of America has again turned to an industry outsider to help shore up its entertainment assets in the United States. On Wednesday, it named Michael Lynton, the chief executive of AOL Europe, to lead its entertainment arm in Hollywood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, CHARLES J,
description: WEISS--Charles J, a life long resident of North Stamford and Greenwich, died Saturday, December 6th, over the Pacific, enroute to Hong Kong. Cause of death is thought to be heart failure. He was 61. Mr. Weiss graduated from the Brunswick School in Greenwich, The Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, and the New York University School of Law. In 1965, Mr. Weiss was awarded a Fulbright Scholarship to study international law in Chile. Spending the majority of his career with Citizens Communications in Stamford, CT, Mr. Weiss retired in 2000 as Corporate Secretary. Since his retirement, he has been active in town government and currently sits on the Planning and Zoning Commission, the Selectman's Committee on Traffic & Transportation, and on the Charter Review Commission. He was also an active member at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Mr. Weiss is survived by his wife, Susan Adams Weiss, of Greenwich and his mother, Sylvia B. Weiss of Stamford, as well as two nieces and a nephew, who played an important role in his life. Funeral services will be held Friday December 12th, at 2:30PM at the Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Mr. Weiss' memory to the Greenwich Hospital Capital Campaign for the Watson Pavilion or The Greenwich Land Trust.

title: Metro Matters; A Whistle Still Ringing In Wall St. Ears
description: ANOTHER one. Another whistle-blowing woman. Turns out that the growing mutual fund scandal began with one woman's phone call to Eliot Spitzer, New York's attorney general.

title: Thoroughly House-Trained, Does Not Shed
description: Department stores like Bergdorf Goodman use artificial foliage because, among other things, it remains presentable through the holidays. And increasingly, fake greenery stands up to close scrutiny, said Mimi Rasamee of Pany Silk Flowers, a boutique in the New York flower district that sells to individuals as well as to stores, restaurants and flower shops. ''The market is expanding every year,'' Ms. Rasamee said. Three of her flexible plastic ''ice branches'' ($2.75 each) quickly and easily twist into a festive ring (shown). The 24-inch branches also add sparkle to her artificial Christmas tree, inspired by the perennial ''Peanuts'' television special ''A Charlie Brown Christmas.'' The trees are four feet tall and have bare branches but come wired with miniature white lights under a dusting of fire-resistant synthetic snow; $87 at Pany, 146 West 28th Street (Seventh Avenue); (212) 645-9526. At the Center of Floral Design and Supply, lifelike fronds called Japan Cedar, inset, inspired by floppy Norfolk Island pines, are about three feet tall and cost $14.95 each. Fake long-needle pine sprays are $9.95, and sprays of plastic cedar are $3.95. The Center of Floral Design and Supply is at 145 West 28th Street; (212) 279-5044.

title: The Neediest Cases; Despite Physical Problems, an Indomitable Will to Work
description: Terrence Murrain, 46, pointed to a swollen area on the right side of his forehead, the very spot where a shunt was inserted in 1990 to drain fluid from a benign cyst on his brain. The cyst had caused him to collapse one day in Harlem Park, and he woke up in Harlem Hospital Center.

title: Allies Angered at Exclusion From Bidding
description: Russia, France, Germany, Canada and other countries barred by the Pentagon from bidding for $18.6 billion worth of prime reconstruction contracts in Iraq reacted angrily Wednesday, saying that the move was all the more astonishing given recent appeals by Washington for help in postwar Iraq.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Plans To Combine 2 Units
description: Intel, the world's biggest maker of computer processors, said yesterday that it would combine its two communications businesses as it struggles to win customers for mobile-phone chips. It said Ron Smith, 53, a senior vice president who was head of its wireless business, would retire early next year. His unit will be merged with one that builds chips for networking and communications gear, Intel said. Sean Maloney, 47, who runs the communications group, will lead the new unit. Intel needs to cut costs in the wireless business and to persuade cellphone clients to switch from chips by the industry leader Texas Instruments. Intel said last week that it would write down a wireless acquisition by $600 million, prompting concern that Intel was missing out as the cellphone market surges. In the company's most recent quarter, sales in the wireless unit fell 23 percent to $450 million, while revenue from communications chips increased 13 percent to $544 million. Mr. Smith has been with Intel 26 years and helped develop its early processors and its effort in flash-memory chips. He has no specific career plans once he leaves Intel and will assist in the transition, a spokesman, Bill Calder, said.

title: Daimler Leader Explains Why He Called Deal Merger of Equals
description: The chairman of DaimlerChrysler, Jrgen E. Schrempp, resumed testifying in federal court here on Wednesday and gave his first in-depth explanation of a 2000 interview that demoralized Chrysler workers and enraged its former top shareholder.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Guilty Plea In Organ Trafficking
description: A South African man who was charged last Thursday with participating in a trans-Atlantic organ-trafficking network pleaded guilty in Durban to 38 counts of violating the South African law prohibiting the sale of human tissues. The man, Roderick F. Kimberly, had been identified as a potentially key figure in the ring, which linked poor Brazilians willing to sell their kidneys through middlemen to wealthy but desperately sick recipients in South African hospitals. Fourteen people, four of them Israelis, were arrested last week in South Africa and Brazil and charged with trafficking in human organs. The police have suggested that more arrests are imminent. Mr. Kimberly, 58, was fined $40,000 and given a six-year suspended prison sentence for his role in the ring. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: WASHINGTON: CULTURE GRANTS
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities announced yesterday that it would distribute $9.1 million in challenge grants to 27 cultural institutions in 16 states. The institutions must raise a total of $29.7 million themselves. In an effort to strengthen education and public programs in local history, grants went for the first time to local historical initiatives, including the Fort Apache (Ariz.) Heritage Foundation ; the Hanover (Va.) Tavern Foundation; and the Oberlin (Ohio) Heritage Center. Most of the institutions have more than four years to raise the matching monies. ELIZABETH OLSON

title: A Grand Plan in Brooklyn For the Nets' Arena Complex
description: The developer Bruce Ratner unveiled his plans yesterday to build a Frank Gehry-designed arena for the Nets basketball team near Downtown Brooklyn. He detailed his ambitious $2.5 billion commercial and residential project at a theatrical presentation attended by the mayor, a former basketball star and a best-selling rapper.

description: PARIS, Dec. 11  Negotiators from France and the United States have reached a $760 million settlement in principle with United States prosecutors over charges related to the failed California insurer Executive Life, French officials and lawyers involved in the negotiations said today

title: Doctors See Increase in Demand for Flu Vaccine for Children
description: Mohammed Sajid, 1 year old, fought having a mask strapped to his face. But exhausted by two days of coughing and fever, he quickly gave in, inhaled the medicinal vapor and, in minutes, fell asleep in his mother's arms.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cost Rise For Rail Link
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's ambitious plan to connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal will cost nearly 20 percent, or $1 billion, more than originally expected. The revised estimate, by Mysore Nagaraja, president of the authority's Capital Construction Company, put the price tag for the project at $6.3 billion yesterday, up from an Army Corps of Engineers estimate of $5.3 billion. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: A Campaign Finance Triumph
description: The Supreme Court delivered a stunning victory for political reform yesterday, upholding the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law virtually in its entirety. The court rejected claims that the law violates the First Amendment, making it clear that Congress has broad authority in acting against the corrupting power of money in politics. The ruling is cause for celebration, but it should also spur Congress to do more to clean up our political system.

title: For Rugged Conditions, A Laptop That Endures
description: Q. My wife and I hope to rejoin the Peace Corps in Africa, and we are wondering what type of laptop would be tough enough to take with us. And is it possible to power a laptop with car battery?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit Warning
description: The Dutch telecommunications company Royal KPN warned investors that its pretax profit next year would most likely decline and that overall sales might fall as much as 2 percent. The report set off a decline of 9 percent in the company's stock price. The company said it expected to earn a pretax profit in 2004 of 1.4 billion euros ($1.7 billion), down 100 million euros from the projected 1.5 billion euros it hoped to earn this year. KPN also expects no improvement in its sales performance in 2005. KPN lowered the sales forecast for its fixed-line division, saying revenue would decline 5 to 7 percent in 2004 and 3 to 5 percent in 2005. The company is contending with price cuts, some of them required by regulators. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Pentagon Finds Halliburton Overcharged on Iraq Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 — A Pentagon investigation has found evidence of overcharging and other violations in billions of dollars worth of reconstruction contracts for Iraq that were awarded to Vice President Dick Cheney's former company, military officials said today.

title: Customer-Service Representatives Explain Themselves
description: Ay-yi-yi, what a hornet's nest! The mail continues to pour in, dozens per hour, about my e-column three weeks ago, in which I described a weird little quirk of phone companies, insurance companies, and others: they make enormous numbers of errors on our bills-almost always in their favor.

title: Youngster Given Life Term For Killing Gets New Trial
description: A Florida appeals court panel ordered a new trial on Wednesday for Lionel Tate, whose life prison sentence for murdering a playmate when he was 12 became an international rallying point against treating juvenile offenders as harshly as adults.

title: Schools Report Gun Incidents And Assaults
description: In a series of separate incidents in New York City schools yesterday, two students took guns into elementary schools in Brooklyn and the Bronx, a student at Washington Irving High School in Manhattan was arrested and charged with assaulting a school safety agent, and a student and a teacher at a Bronx middle school were removed by ambulance after a fistfight.

title: People
description: Heide Peper was named media director, a new post, at McClain Finlon, Denver. She had been vice president and group media director at Cramer-Krasselt, Chicago.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article in some copies on Nov. 30 about Florida State's 38-24 football victory against Florida misidentified the Florida player who fumbled the ball, resulting in a touchdown that enabled Florida State to tie the score at 24-24. He was Ciatrick Fason, not Ran Carthon.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Investment Abroad Grows
description: Investment by Japanese companies overseas grew 19 percent in the six months that ended in September as manufacturers built more factories in China, the United States and elsewhere. Foreign direct investment grew to 2.5 trillion yen ($23.4 billion) and included a new Nissan Motor Company factory in Mississippi. Japanese investment in the United States grew 128 percent. New investments by foreign businesses in Japan increased 55 percent, to 981 billion yen ($9.2 billion). Ken Belson (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Canon And Ricoh Upgraded
description: Moody's Investors Service raised the credit ratings of Japan's two largest office equipment makers, Canon Inc. and the Ricoh Company, because of their profitability and strong finances. Canon, which was raised to Aa3 from A1, was also credited for strength globally and for strength in the digital camera market. Moody's increased Ricoh's rating to A2 from A3, citing its digital copiers. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Marines Intend to Avoid Get-Tough Tactics in Iraq
description: CAMP PENDLETON, California, Dec. 10 -- No force has a tougher reputation than the United States Marines. But the marines who are headed to Iraq this spring say they intend to avoid the get-tough tactics that have been used in recent weeks by Army units.

title: Two Chances for Elias, One Too Many for Isles
description: As he slowly skated away from Islanders goaltender Garth Snow, Patrik Elias shook his head. He had shoved a penalty shot -- a penalty shot in overtime -- into Snow's left leg pad. A wonderful chance, gone forever.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about criticism of Michael D. Eisner, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, misstated the performance of its stock. The price has risen more than 60 percent since its recent low in August 2002. It has not nearly doubled in the last year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Identify Two Dead Men
description: Two Bronx men who were shot dead while apparently trying to rob a pet store on Tuesday night have been identified by the police. The men, Michael Live, 48, of Jackson Avenue, and Hector Perez, 33, of Trinity Avenue, were fatally shot by the owner of Quality Canines on Stillwell Avenue in Gravesend. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said the investigation indicated that the owner of the store, who has not been identified, took a gun from one of the men during a robbery attempt and shot both of them. ''On a preliminary basis, it looks like a justified shooting,'' he said. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Attacks in Iraq Kill 2 G.I.'s, and a Bank Is Robbed of $800,000
description: Two American soldiers were killed and four wounded in the northern city of Mosul on Wednesday in two attacks, a day after a suicide bomber injured dozens of soldiers at a base west of the city, military officials said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Hefty Sentences Asked For Terror Group
description: An Athens prosecutor asked for record sentences for the leader of the radical group November 17, its chief assassin and other members found guilty this week of a series of assassinations, car bombings and rocket attacks since the 1970's. The prosecutor, Christos Lambrou, urged the court to sentence Alexandros Yiotopoulos, the leader, to 21 life terms plus 2,440 years in prison. For the assassin, Dimitris Koufodinas, 13 life terms plus 2,446 years were asked. Sentencing may come by the end of next week. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Shopping for a Sofa, And Some Baubles To Wear With It
description: Monica Melhem often wears colorful Perfectos Dragones rubber jewelry, which resembles diced Jell-O, and sells it from a table just inside her new SoHo home-furnishings store, M at Mercer. The jewelry ($20 to $235) is made in Argentina, where she is an architect and where the houses she designs are furnished with some of the same pieces that she sells in her store in New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Widens
description: Japan's current account surplus grew 39 percent in October from a year earlier, helped by rising exports and declines in the services deficit. The surplus in the account, the widest measure of goods and services going in and out of Japan, was 1.26 trillion yen ($11.5 billion), slightly below estimates by private economists. The increase, the fourth in a row, suggests that the yen's gains against the dollar are not hurting Japan's exporters. Ken Belson (NYT)

description: ELKUS--Jonathan H. Age 55. Died on December 7, 2003, of a heart attack, in Geneva, Switzerland. Graduate of St Paul's School, Yale and Harvard Business School. He is survived by his twin sister, Peggy of Pittsburgh, PA., his brother, Christopher of Ligonier, PA. and New York and a nephew, James, of Barcelona. Contributions may be made to WQED, 4802 Fifth Ave, Pittsburgh, PA. 15213.

title: Wooing Nets, McGreevey Plans Rail Spur to Meadowlands
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey stepped up his efforts to keep the New Jersey Nets in the state by announcing on Wednesday that a $150 million rail spur would be built into the Meadowlands site of a planned family entertainment complex that will surround the Continental Airlines Arena, where the Nets play.

title: Payments By Managers Of Drug Plans Face Scrutiny
description: The pharmacy benefit companies that manage drug coverage for most working Americans commonly offer millions of dollars in payments to important customers when contracts with them are signed, according to industry executives and consultants.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bird Flu Case
description: A 5-year-old boy spent two days in a hospital late last month with a case of influenza known as H9N2, only the third case documented in people, although the virus is found in many birds. The two previous cases, which also affected children in Hong Kong who recovered, were in 1999.

title: Fed May Wait Longer Than Expected to Increase Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11  Federal Reserve officials concluded in October that inflation could remain low until some time in 2005 and that they should wait for concrete signs of inflation before raising interest rates, according to minutes released today of Fed's policy-making meeting on Oct. 28.

title: Robert L. Bartley, 66, Dies; Led Journal Editorial Page
description: Robert L. Bartley, who led the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal for three decades, championing the supply-side economics of the Reagan era and fashioning a showcase of conservative thought that became required reading for liberals and conservatives alike, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 66 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: On a Hunt for Ways to Put Sex in the City
description: ON a Tuesday night at a downtown lounge here, Ryan Flickinger, 30, was preaching the economics of hip. Specifically, he was talking about young professionals, the most mobile class in American history, who are choosing not to come to this river city despite what seem attractive amenities: cheap housing, good music, excellent barbecue and a major employer, FedEx, with 30,000 jobs in the area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GENNARELLI, VALENTINO J.
description: GENNARELLI--Valentino J., 94, of Dallas, TX and Yorktown Heights, NY, died December 7, 2003. Born in Casalciprano, Italy, he immigrated to New York in 1929 and married Mary LeChase in 1935. They had two sons, Charles and Louis, respectively from Greenwich, CT and Dallas, TX. In 1948 Gennarelli, started a business in New York that designed and manufactured clerical robes and vestments for the Catholic Church. He would become one of the largest suppliers of garments in North America with a reputation for quality that extended to the Vatican. A mass in his honor was performed at St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Catholic Church by his Eminence Bishop Edwin Broderick of New York.

title: Police Superintendent Resigns in Maryland After Indictment
description: Edward T. Norris, who became Maryland police superintendent after a celebrated crime-fighting record in New York City and Baltimore, resigned on Wednesday after he was indicted on charges of using a Baltimore Police Department charity fund to pay for gifts, private travel and visits with girlfriends.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FAO INC., King of Prussia, Pa., owner of the F.A.O. Schwarz toy store chain, said it hired DJM Asset Management, Melville, N.Y., to dispose of leases for 89 Zany Brainy stores as part of its bankruptcy filing last week.

title: Dow Closes Above 10,000 for the First Time in 18 Months
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 10,000 for the first time in more than 18 months today.

title: Marsalis, Clinton and Others Dissect Jazz at Symposium
description: Wynton Marsalis, the artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, has talked for some years about his desire to gather an intellectual community around jazz.

title: A Dream Comes True, Even if It's 4-9
description: An hour after he had led the Giants in practice on Wednesday for the first time in his career, quarterback Jesse Palmer still glowed, a player realizing his dream.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ruling In Credit Suit
description: Leo Kirch, founder of the KirchMedia Group, based in Munich, is entitled to damages from Deutsche Bank for violation of secrecy rules, a Munich court ruled. Kirch sued Deutsche Bank and its supervisory board chairman, Rolf Breuer, for compensation of at least 100 million euros ($122 million) after Mr. Breuer made a statement in an interview in February 2002 that was unfavorable to Kirch's credit standing. Mr. Kirch said the statement was untrue but contributed to the collapse of his media company in April 2002. KirchMedia's $5.7 billion debt burden included more than $855 million in loans from Deutsche Bank. While the ruling held Deutsche Bank responsible for its chairman's remarks, it cleared Mr. Breuer of personal liability. The compensation payment still has to be determined. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Man Charged In Wife's Murder
description: A 67-year-old manwas arrested last night and charged with the murder of his 65-year-old wife, according to the police. The man, John Stiehler, was charged several hours after the body of his wife, Catherine, was found in a chair in the kitchen of the couple's house on Rensselaer Avenue. She died of a gunshot wound, the police said. Neighbors said Mrs. Stiehler had been a singer in her church choir. They described Mr. Stiehler as aloof. One neighbor, Joseph Spinale, said Mr. Stiehler had been detained by the authorities about a year ago for shooting three pets, a dog and two cats. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Former NewCom Officer Is Acquitted
description: The former chief financial officer of NewCom Inc. has been acquitted of criminal charges that he lied in filings and testimony to the Securities and Exchange Commission, his lawyer, Marc Harris, said yesterday.

title: Jailed Man Accused of Having Ties to Al Qaeda
description: The federal authorities in Minnesota have arrested a man who is accused of having ties to the terrorist network of Al Qaeda and to Zacarias Moussaoui, law enforcement officials said on Wednesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Borrowing Outlook
description: Gordon Brown, the chan-cellor of the exchequer, said in a semiannual budget update to Parliament that the government would need to borrow 34 billion ($59 billion) over the next five years, 10 billion more than was expected in April. "It is right and prudent that, as in America, Japan and Germany, we borrow at this, the right time of the economic cycle," he said. Mr. Brown assumed the economy would grow 3 percent to 3.5 percent next year and in 2005, up from 2.1 percent this year. The faster pace could help pay off the debt. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: San Francisco Democrats Survive a Scare
description: The Democratic Party avoided an embarrassing defeat on Tuesday, winning election of a Democratic businessman, Gavin Newsom, as mayor of San Francisco by having played to the party's organizational strengths in a city it has long dominated.

description: MANDELBAUM -- Richard Marc. Suddenly at age 49, beloved son of Roslyn and Muzzy. Father of Alyssa, Jamie, and Julia, whom he adored. Brother of Don, Cindy and Carol. Nephew of Edith and Henry Everett.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAIMS, JUDITH FELLER
description: HAIMS--Judith Feller, age 90, a devoted wife to her late husband, Sam, loving mother to Wendy Handler of Pound Ridge, NY, Bruce Haims of NYC. Passed away December 10, 2003 at her home in Stamford, CT. She was a cherished grandmother to Amy Bender, Barrie Klein, the late Randi Klein, Daniel Lythcott-Haims and Nolan Haims and a loved greatgrandmother to Rebecca and Sarah Bender and Sawyer and Avery Lythcott-Haims. Besides her children and great-grandchildren she is survived by her daughter-inlaw Judy Jackson, her son-inlaw Sid Handler, sister-in-law Evelyn Feller, niece Lori Lonczak and great-nieces Jenna and Kate Lonczak. Services will be at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT, at 1PM on Friday, December 12, 2003. Call 203-327-1313 for information. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Child Protection Center, Montefiore Medical Center, 3314 Steuben Avenue, Bronx, NY 10417, or Visiting Nurse and Hospice Care of Southwestern, CT, 1029 E. Main St., Stamford, CT. 06902-4108.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARTHUR, ROBERT S.
description: ARTHUR--Robert S. Northfield, MN. Died December 3, 2003. Attended Keble College, Oxford; Haverford and Princeton. Survived by wife Martha, daughter Evelyn Richer, sons Andrew and Jon, nine grandchildren.

title: For Hearing Aids, a Lesson From a Fly on the Wall
description: CARRYING on a conversation in a busy restaurant can be a challenge for anyone who wears a hearing aid. The devices amplify speech, but they amplify the general racket in the room, too.

title: French Close 2 Islamic Day Care Centers; Cite Scarf on Girl, 3
description: The police shut down a day care center and a kindergarten last week that were being run by Islamic militants, Interior Minister Nicolas Sarkozy told the National Assembly on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRODSKY, HILDA
description: BRODSKY--Hilda. On December 10, 2003. Loving wife of Arthur. Dear mother of Iris and Sean Burnsworth. Grandmother of Jeremy Wood. Everyone who knew her loved her. You will be greatly missed and in our hearts forever. Rest peacefully. Arthur and Iris

title: Astros' Bid for Pettitte Puts Yanks in a Bind
description: All along, the Yankees have known there was one thing they could never offer Andy Pettitte: the opportunity to pitch near his home in Deer Park, Tex. The Yankees still had a chance to retain him last night, but in what would be the most stinging blow of a chaotic off-season, Pettitte may be slipping away to the Houston Astros.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAGIN, ALEX
description: FAGIN--Alex. The City University of New York extends deepest sympathies to the family of Alex Fagin, beloved father of Assemblywoman Audrey I. Pheffer. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr., Chairman Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

title: Taking Down a Bear Is Hard. Standing It Back Up Is Harder.
description: After the protesters protested and the hunters hunted, people like John Person got down to work on the spoils of New Jersey's first bear hunt in 33 years.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Right-Wing Leader In Government
description: Christoph Blocher, a nationalist intent on moving his country away from the European Union and curbing foreigners, won a seat on the country's seven-member executive council, shifting the political alignment to the right for the first time in more than 40 years. The Parliament chose Mr. Blocher, a 62-year-old chemicals tycoon, in a narrow vote, increasing his Swiss People's Party's representation on the Federal Council to a second seat. The ballot effectively averted a potentially bruising confrontation between other parties and Mr. Blocher, who had threatened to lead his party into opposition if denied a place in the government. The party emerged as the largest in Parliament after elections last month. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Still in High School, Certified Celebrities Look Toward N.B.A.
description: In the old days of, say, the late 1990's, it would have been a whale of a coming-out party: a nationwide television audience, a highly touted opponent, a grand opportunity to put his name, game and face into the national psyche. But when Sebastian Telfair leads Lincoln High School of Brooklyn against Edgewater High of Orlando, Fla., tonight in a game televised on ESPN2, he will do so not as a rising star but as a bona fide 18-year-old celebrity.

title: Building Ties With North Korea
description: While the Bush administration wants to freeze economic ties with North Korea until the country puts its nuclear program under international controls, Russia's Far East is aggressively repairing and expanding its relationship with North Korea.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: RIGHT-WING LEADER IN GOVERNMENT Christoph Blocher, a nationalist intent on moving his country away from the European Union and curbing foreigners, won a seat on the country's seven-member executive council, shifting the political alignment to the right for the first time in more than 40 years. The Parliament chose Mr. Blocher, a 62-year-old chemicals tycoon, in a narrow vote, increasing his Swiss People's Party's representation on the Federal Council to a second seat. The ballot effectively averted a potentially bruising confrontation between other parties and Mr. Blocher, who had threatened to lead his party into opposition if denied a place in the government. The party emerged as the largest in Parliament after elections last month.

title: After Gore Endorsement, Attacks on Dean Are Sharper
description: Faced with a presidential race suddenly recast by Al Gore's endorsement of Howard Dean, Senators Joseph I. Lieberman and John Kerry sharpened their attacks against Dr. Dean, with Mr. Kerry accusing him of inconsistency on the Iraq war and Mr. Lieberman saying Dr. Dean represented the party's past.

title: Events to Be Described For Advertising Week
description: Ambitious efforts to create an event called Advertising Week in New York City, patterned after the annual Fashion Week, are moving ahead with a series of programs for Sept. 20-24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARWIN, MIRIAM J.
description: HARWIN--Miriam J. Age 82. Of Naples, FL. Died Tuesday, December 9, 2003. Born in Brooklyn, N.Y., Mrs. Harwin lived in Westbury, N.Y. most of her life. She graduated with honors from Wheaton College in Norton, MA. While living in Westbury, she was a member of the Hadassah and ORT. Miriam was the wonderful wife of 61 years to Martin Harwin, M.D., She is also survived by three sons, Robert Harwin and his wife Anna of San Antonio, TX., Richard Harwin and his wife Bonnie of River Vale, N.J. and William Harwin, M.D. and his wife Marilyn of Fort Meyers, FL. She is also survived by eight grandchildren, Alexandra, Michael, Alison, Melissa, Daniel, Kristen, Jeffrey and Peter, and a sister-in-law, Evelyn Hartman.

title: In Midtown, Minimalism Meets British Luxe
description: THE black and white lacquered exterior of the Asprey store on Fifth Avenue offers a whiff of Audrey Hepburn swearing at Ascot in ''My Fair Lady.'' But the interiors of this British luxury goods store is entirely Rex Harrison, a handsome space of subdued elegance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALVA, JEAN
description: DALVA--Jean. The Art and Antique Dealers League of America is saddened by the passing of Mrs. Jean Dalva, mother of past League presidents, David Dalva II and Leon Dalva, and grandmother of David Dalva III, all principals in the firm Dalva Brothers, Inc. Anthony Blumka, President James Frankel, Secretary

title: U.S. Opens Firearms Charge Against Iraq-U.S. Contact
description: A Lebanese-American businessman who acted as an intermediary between Baghdad and Washington before the war in Iraq has been charged with violating a firearms regulation. His lawyer contends that the case represents retribution by the Bush administration.

title: Annan Rules Out the Quick Return of a U.N. Presence in Iraq
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said Wednesday that the dangerous situation in Iraq had caused him to rule out a swift resumption of a United Nations presence there.

title: Miscellany
description: The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, Beverly Hills, Calif., named divisions of Daniel J. Edelman Inc. to create a campaign to discourage the illegal downloading of music over the Internet. The campaign will be developed by Edelman, for public relations; Blue Worldwide, advertising; and StrategyOne, for research. The campaign is to include commercials, which may first appear on Feb. 8, during the broadcast on CBS of the 46th annual Grammy Awards, which the academy oversees.

title: New York Regents to Propose Overhaul in School Financing
description: The New York State Board of Regents will announce today what a spokesman described as a ''proposal for major reform in state aid for schools,'' refining a plan adopted last month to overhaul how state money is allocated to school districts.

title: Rate Change Widens Pool Of Credit In China
description: China's central bank has sharply raised the maximum interest rates that banks can charge for commercial loans, a step that, paradoxically, is likely to make credit more widely available to private enterprises and speed China's transformation into a capitalist economy.

title: New Jersey Proposes Measures to Reduce Mercury Emissions
description: TRENTON, Dec. 10  New Jersey will propose new controls to limit emissions of mercury, a toxic substance that is particularly harmful to fetuses and young children. The new rules on power plants and other sources would cut emissions by 75 percent in three years.

title: The Coal in the Sock Is Fine, As Long as They Get a Whipping
description: 'Lesbian Pulp-O-Rama in ''A Very Pulpy Christmas'' '

title: In Speech, Nobel Winner Rebukes the U.S.
description: Shirin Ebadi, an Iranian lawyer, received the 2003 Nobel Peace Prize here Wednesday, declaring that the prize would inspire women across the Muslim world to fight for equality in oppressive, patriarchal societies.

title: Pettitte Goes Home, Choosing Astros Over the Yankees
description: Andy Pettitte's locker at Yankee Stadium was covered with photos of his children wearing football uniforms or frolicking in a swimming pool. Pettitte routinely flew home to Houston see them on Yankee off days, and when Major League Baseball filmed a commercial last season with Pettitte instructing young players, he put his sons in the ad.

title: Judge in Clarett Case Will Get N.F.L. Education
description: Baseball was her first crush. As a shy, bright girl growing up in Detroit, she memorized the batting averages of all the Tigers. Years later, after discovering the law, Shira A. Scheindlin shed her baseball card collection for a robe and gavel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARENA, GLORIA THERESA
description: ARENA--Gloria Theresa, December 8, 2003, age 75. Beloved and devoted mother of Paul and Colette. Our mother touched so many lives through her compassionate and loving nature as mother, aunt, teacher, friend, fitness enthusiast and wellness advocate. Family will receive friends for a memorial gathering Friday, December 12, 25 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral services Saturday, 10:30am at St. Joseph's Church, 404 East 87th Street. The family would prefer donations to the American Lung Association, Youth Education Programs in lieu of flowers.

description: A few years ago P.O.D.'s tendency toward rap-metal probably seemed to be the band's biggest selling point, and the members' Christianity probably seemed its biggest liability.

description: Whether governments should support open-source software like Linux over commercial software like Microsoft's Windows was debated on Wednesday at a United Nations conference on closing the so-called digital divide between rich and poor countries.

Rada III and Sean Thomas Rada. Dear father-in-law of Kathryn. Former Captain in the U.S. Army, George was a realist painter who worked and exhibited in NYC. title: Mixing Up the Marriages at the Highest Level
description: Memorable bridge weddings are rare. Four decades ago Edgar Kaplan and Betty Sheinwold married, and their partnership seemed to suggest the celebrated Kaplan-Sheinwold system, which he had invented with Alfred Sheinwold, Betty's previous husband. About that time Kaplan's longtime bridge partner, Norman Kay, also married, and he and Judy Kay remained together 37 years, until his death nearly two years ago.

title: Ambition And Ethics Wage War At a Paper
description: Journalism has had a rough time of it lately, and ''The Story,'' a conscientious and absorbing new drama by Tracey Scott Wilson, feels almost like a year-end review of the profession's troubles. The play, at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, explores newsroom politics, race relations and personal ambition at a fictional metropolitan daily newspaper and offers a close-to-credible scenario for how one reckless reporter can unmoor an entire institution.

title: Tradition With A Flourish
description: Hanukkah, the eight-day festival of lights, begins at sundown on Dec. 19. The menorah, the holiday's special candelabrum, must have room for nine candles, one for each night, plus a master candle in the center. But it can come in many forms and materials, from traditional silver to unusual forms made by contemporary artists.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Wednesday about the Pentagon's decision to bar French, German and Russian companies from competing for reconstruction contracts in Iraq referred incorrectly to Germany's role on the United Nations Security Council. It is a temporary member, not a permanent one.

title: AT&T Joins Fray For Cheaper Calls Through the Web
description: The battle over the future of telephone service will break wide open today with an announcement from AT&T that it plans to offer unlimited long-distance and local calling using Internet technology at a lower cost than conventional phone service.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 3 about the videotaped beating of a black man by Cincinnati police referred incorrectly to a 2001 shooting death that led to three days of unrest in the city. It was the 15th death of a black man in confrontations with the police or during an arrest -- not the 15th in police custody.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the Pentagon's decision to bar French, German and Russian companies from competing for reconstruction contracts in Iraq referred incorrectly to Germany's role on the United Nations Security Council. It is a temporary member, not a permanent one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROMEO, ANTHONY
description: ROMEO--Anthony. Planned Parenthood Hudson Peconic notes with deep sorrow the death of Anthony Romeo, father of our esteemed board member, Daphne Philipson. Heartfelt condolences to the Philipson and Romeo families. Carol Stix, Chair of the Board Reina Schiffrin, Pres./CEO

title: Hold It Right There, And Drop That Camera
description: ''WHAT grabbed my attention,'' said Alderman Edward M. Burke, ''was that TV commercial when the guy is eating the pasta like a slob, and the girl sends a photo of him acting like a slob to the fiance.''

title: Nightmares On Mold Street
description: FOR 32 days, William Wessling, a 44-year-old chef in Pineville, N.C., was forced to stay out of his condominium because of a sore throat, pains in his fingers and neck and other ailments that his doctors attributed to mold behind his baseboards and kitchen cabinets.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Mercury Emission Controls
description: New Jersey will propose new controls to limit emissions of mercury, a toxic substance that is particularly harmful to fetuses and young children. The new rules on power plants and other sources would cut emissions by 75 percent in three years. Bradley M. Campbell, the commissioner of environmental protection, announced yesterday that if the department adopts the proposal, 24 coal-fired power plants, municipal waste incinerators and iron smelters will have to adopt measures to cut the state's mercury emissions of 2,000 pounds per year to 500 pounds. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: As Donations Fall, U.N. Plans to Reduce North Korea's Food Aid
description: As winter grips North Korea, 2.2 million people, or 10 percent of the population, will no longer receive food rations provided by the World Food Program, agency officials said Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the awarding of the Turner Prize, Britain's most prestigious award for contemporary art, misstated the titles of two works by Jake and Dinos Chapman, who were nominated. The set of 83 Goya etchings they doctored is ''Insult to Injury,'' not ''Death.'' Their bronze version of plastic blowup dolls engaged in oral sex is ''Death.'' (''Sex'' is the title of their three-dimensional representation of one of the Goyas.)

Our heartfelt condolences go out to his wife Jay Presson Allen and daughter Brooke. Tom Dillon, President Joe Benincasa, Exec Dir.

title: Panel Votes to Give Snapple Citywide Marketing Rights
description: A franchise review panel dominated by Bloomberg administration officials brushed aside objections from critics yesterday and approved a citywide marketing contract with Snapple, potentially setting the stage for a legal battle with the city comptroller.

title: Metro Briefing: New York City
description: BROOKLYN: POLICE IDENTIFY TWO DEAD MEN Two Bronx men who were shot dead while apparently trying to rob a pet store on Tuesday night have been identified by the police. The men, Michael Live, 48, of Jackson Avenue, and Hector Perez, 33, of Trinity Avenue, were fatally shot by the owner of Quality Canines on Stillwell Avenue in Gravesend. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said the investigation indicated that the owner of the store, who has not been identified, took a gun from one of the men during a robbery attempt and shot both of them. "On a preliminary basis, it looks like a justified shooting," he said.

title: Easing the Wait for Early College Admissions
description: Laurence Neron-Bancel is prepared for good news or bad with a bottle of Champagne chilling in the refrigerator. At the appointed hour, her son Timothee will sign on to the Cornell University Web site and find out if he has been accepted, rejected or deferred as an early-decision applicant. Whatever the result, the cork will pop.

title: Why Settle for Concrete When You Can Have a Jardin?
description: When the five-story Lyce Franais complex opened in Manhattan this fall, students found a hidden park. One of the designers, Susan T. Rodriguez of Polshek Partnership Architects, inserted a ''floating'' lawn between the school's two towers, which are connected by a ground-level cafeteria, below. Zoning rules required construction of a courtyard between the towers, and though shrubs or even concrete would have been allowed, Ms. Rodriguez said, ''we realized a beautiful lawn would be simple and unifying.''

title: New York's Amazing Police Story
description: The number of homicides in the United States fell by about 34 percent over the last decade, according to the most recent statistics from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. But the drop in New York has been nearly twice that, and now the number of homicides in the city is hovering at a 40-year low. Over all, serious crime in New York is continuing to drop despite the enormous new burden placed on the Police Department by the fight against terrorism and by skyrocketing unemployment, which many expected to translate into more robberies, burglaries and drug trafficking.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Nov. 22 about a lecture at the New York Public Library by J. M. Coetzee, winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, referred imprecisely to his actions after the lecture. While his books were being sold and he was signing copies, Mr. Coetzee was not himself selling them.

title: Reaching for a Last-Minute Lifeline
description: ONE morning last week, I congratulated myself on having the holiday shopping under control.

title: Toronto Journal; Comedians in the Rough: Canada's Very Special School
description: Most Canadians like to be thought of as civil people, apt to shy away from overt confrontation, loud behavior and brash idiosyncrasy. Then there are the 130 students who attend the comedy school at the Humber School of Creative and Performing Arts, appropriately located on the campus of an old mental hospital where ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' was filmed.

title: Facing Execution, Convict Refuses Help
description: A man facing the death penalty after his federal murder conviction, has barred his lawyers from presenting a social and psychological assessment of him that might help avoid a death sentence, his lawyers said yesterday.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: PARTIES PICK FILM ACTOR A coalition of opposition parties formally declared a former action-film star, Fernando Poe, as their candidate to challenge President Gloria Arroyo in next May's elections. Juan Ponce Enrile, a former senator who headed the candidate selection committee, said the coalition chose Mr. Poe, 64, a high-school drop-out with no experience in public service, because of "his patriotism and humanity, his sterling leadership and success in the movie industry." He also cited Mr. Poe's showing in recent opinion polls in which he led Ms. Arroyo.

title: Arafat Seeks to Restore His Mideast Status
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, has released a statement saying that he recognizes and respects ''the Jewish religion and the Jewish historical attachment to Palestine,'' in a bid to restore his standing as an advocate of peace after more than three years of conflict.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Report On 1974 Bombing
description: After a four-year investigation into possible official collusion in four car bombings in Dublin and in the border town of Monaghan on May 17, 1974, that killed 33 people, an Irish judge stopped short of finding that Protestant paramilitaries received help from the Northern Irish police force or military reserve, though some officers may have known of the plan. No one was ever charged in the attacks. ''If one accepts that some people were involved, they may well have been acting on their own initiative,'' the judge, Henry Barron, wrote in a 300-page report that criticized the rapid closure of the case and left open the possibility that further information might prove collusion.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Friday about the withdrawal of Khalid Khannouchi from the United States Olympic Marathon Trials in February misstated his place among the fastest marathon runners. He has run the third-fastest race, not the second. Paul Tergat of Kenya broke his record in September at the Berlin Marathon with a time of 2 hours 4 minutes 55 seconds. In that race, another Kenyan, Sammy Korir, ran 2:04:56. Khannouchi's best time is 2:05:38.

title: Bouncing From Start-Up to Start-Up, and Loving It
description: Howard Yellen has recently found what promises to be his dream company: a business with a life span of no more than two years. The company, Settlement Recovery Center in San Francisco, helps small and medium-size businesses in California recover money owed them by Microsoft as part of a $1.1 billion antitrust settlement. When the funds have been distributed, Mr. Yellen will be out of business -- an outcome that suits him just fine.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Legal Clarity Sought On Civil Unions
description: The State Senate is expected to ask the state's highest court whether a bill authorizing civil unions for gay men and lesbians complies with the court's ruling last month that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry. The bill would grant same-sex couples in civil unions the same rights and benefits as married couples and would bar discrimination against them. The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court gave the Legislature 180 days to act on its Nov. 18 ruling. On Feb. 11 lawmakers will vote on a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage, but such an amendment could not be in place until 2006. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: End Taylor's Refuge, Groups Urge
description: A coalition of West African civil rights groups called on Nigeria to revoke asylum for the former Liberian president, Charles G. Taylor, arguing that harboring an indicted war criminal violates the Nigerian Constitution. The coalition, which includes Nigerian, Liberian and Sierra Leonean organizations, called on Nigeria to turn over Mr. Taylor to the Special Court for Sierra Leone, a United Nations-backed tribunal that has charged the him with crimes against humanity. Nigeria offered Mr. Taylor asylum when he agreed to leave office in August.

description: Federal regulators released a scathing report Wednesday on the corporate culture that fostered improper accounting at Freddie Mac, the same day that they announced that the company had agreed to pay a $125 million penalty and to take measures to prevent future misconduct.

title: As Befits An Old Villa, Restoration And Rumor
description: VIEWED from the back terraces of the Villa La Pietra, the changeless Montughi Hills of Florence, rolling gently in a blue haze toward the buoyant dome of the cathedral, seem cultivated in grace and suspended in time. Within this Tuscan landscape, La Pietra occupies its own unique pocket of eternity, from the alle of stately cypress marching through the olive grove at the front, to the princely three-story ocher mansion. It seems that the original owner, Francesco Sassetti, might appear at any moment on the forecourt to greet his elderly banking colleague, Cosimo de' Medici. Or that its last owner, Sir Harold Acton, the British-American scholar and writer, could step out to receive his chum, Princess Margaret, a regular here, or the Prince and Princess of Wales, who visited in the happier years.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SOUTH AFRICA: GUILTY PLEA IN ORGAN TRAFFICKING A South African man who was charged last Thursday with participating in a trans-Atlantic organ-trafficking network pleaded guilty in Durban to 38 counts of violating the South African law prohibiting the sale of human tissues. The man, Roderick F. Kimberly, had been identified as a potentially key figure in the ring, which linked poor Brazilians willing to sell their kidneys through middlemen to wealthy but desperately sick recipients in South African hospitals. Fourteen people, four of them Israelis, were arrested last week in South Africa and Brazil and charged with trafficking in human organs. The police have suggested that more arrests are imminent. Mr. Kimberly, 58, was fined $40,000 and given a six-year suspended prison sentence for his role in the ring.

Wearing a sleeveless black cocktail dress and a come-hither smile, the star of ''All My Children'' seems poised to seduce the White House pastry chef or at the very least steal a souvenir ashtray.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MADSEN, NIELS BO
description: MADSEN--Niels Bo, 79, formerly of New Canaan, CT. and London, England. Died at his home in Vero Beach, FL. on December 3, 2003. Mr. Madsen came to the US from his native Denmark in 1949. In 1968 he became CEO of Anglo-Nordic Shipping Ltd, one of the largest independent ship owning companies at the time. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITEHILL, JENNIE LEVY
description: WHITEHILL--Jennie Levy. 96, a philanthropist and pioneer in the field of family and child welfare, died on November 28, 2003. She was a longtime resident of Scarsdale, New York. Mrs. Whitehill was born and raised in Henderson, Kentucky. A graduate of Goucher College, Baltimore, Maryland, she was honored by her alma mater 60 years later with its Award for Excellence in Public Service. Mrs. Whitehill's life-long interest in child development led to her tenure for more than two decades as President and Chairman of the Board of the Child Study Association of America, an innovator of programs for child development. An early supporter and Board member of Scarsdale Family and Community Services, she had a strong influence in expanding SFCS's counseling services in Westchester County. As Chairman of Westchester Day Care Centers, she presided over the establishment of 21 child day care centers in the county. Earlier she had served as President of Stuyvesant Neighborhood House. She was also the founding director and a long-time member of the Board of the Westchester Jewish Community Services where she established the Clarence K. Whitehill Counseling Service in memory of her late husband. In the 1960s, Mrs. Whitehill was chairman of the Women's Division of the New York Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. She also served on the Board of the Federation's Distribution Committee for more than 20 years. Her husband, Clarence K. Whitehill, founder of the Whitehill Insurance Agency, at one time the largest privately owned casualty insurance agency in New York City, died in 1958. The company was later sold to Eagle Star Insurance Company in the U.K. Surviving are her three children: Jane Whitehill Silberman of Dallas, Texas, Carol Whitehill Moses of McLean, Virginia, and Dr. Richard P. Whitehill of Evergreen, Colorado; a sister, Babette Newman, of Los Angeles, California; 11 grandchildren and 23 great - grandchildren. Funeral arrangements are private.
