title: W.U.S.A. to Return in 2004
description: John Langel, the lawyer who represents the players from the defunct Women's United Soccer Association, said yesterday that plans would soon be announced for a series of doubleheaders to be played in 2004. ''There seems to be a level of excitement from sponsors,'' Langel said in a telephone interview, confirming some of the details that first appeared in an article in USA Today yesterday. ''We will have something in 2004.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Terror Suspects To Indonesia
description: Government officials handed over six Indonesian students accused of having links to terrorism to a delegation from Jakarta, the state-run media reported. One student is the younger brother of Riduan Ismauddin, commonly known as Hambali, who is thought to be the main link between Al Qaeda and Jemaah Islamiyah, the radical Islamic organization based in Indonesia. The suspects were studying in Karachi when the police arrested them in September. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: For a Jolly and Very Green Client
description: A six-inch pavilion made of paperboard by Robert A. M. Stern Architects is among the Christmas ornaments being auctioned tomorrow to benefit the Institute of Classical Architecture and Classical America. Mr. Stern used a robotic laser to do the chinoiserie fretwork. ''That's the freedom of being modern,'' he said. Bids for the silent auction will be taken on the telephone or at a $75 gala tomorrow night at the Racquet and Tennis Club, 370 Park Avenue (52nd Street). For tickets or to place a bid, (212) 924-9686; information is available at www.classicist.org.

title: More Documents Seized From Yukos Oil
description: Government investigators seized more documents from the Yukos oil company Wednesday.

title: Bush's Advisers Focus on Dean As Likely Opponent Next Year
description: President Bush's political advisers are now all but certain that Howard Dean will be the Democratic presidential nominee and they are planning a campaign that takes account of what they see as Dr. Dean's strengths and weaknesses, Republicans with ties to the White House said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Transit Union Chief Re-Elected
description: In a closer vote than expected, Roger Toussaint, the incumbent president of the city's principal transit workers' union, has won re-election. The union, Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, announced last night that Mr. Toussaint had received 60.2 percent of the vote to 39.8 percent for the challenger, Noel Acevedo, the union's recording secretary. Mr. Toussaint will now serve his second three-year term as head of the local, which represents 34,000 subway and bus drivers. One of the main election issues was rank-and-file discontent with the one-year pay freeze in the three-year contract negotiated last December. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: A New Charge Called 'Oops': Readers Recount Misadventures; Senile and Vulnerable
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILIPS ELECTRONICS PICKS PRESIDENT OF U.S. UNIT
description: The Dutch health care and technology concern Royal Philips Electronics has appointed a president of its struggling consumer electronics division in the United States. Reinier Jens, 46, currently managing director of the company's northern European consumer electronics division, will assume his new job Jan. 1. He succeeds Larry Blanford. Philips is struggling to figure out how to make its United States consumer electronics division profitable in the face of intense price competition, some of it from Asian-based competitors. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBINSTEIN, IRVING
description: RUBINSTEIN -- Irving. The Board of Governors and members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member Irving Rubinstein. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife, Florence, and his entire family. Paul Levy, President Monty Davis, Secretary

title: Judge Questions Sentence in Al Qaeda Case
description: A man described as the leader of a group of Yemenite-Americans from Lackawanna, N.Y., who attended a training camp run by Al Qaeda was sentenced to 10 years in prison by a federal judge who questioned the term's adequacy.

title: Jolting the Democrats: The Gore-Dean Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: No Corks Popping Yet, but Signs Point to End of Recession in City
description: More tourists and business travelers are flying into the city. Some Wall Street firms are starting to hire again, at least modestly. City tax revenues are rising. Hotels are filling up. New restaurants are opening. Unemployment is dropping.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Former Executives Indicted
description: Former executives of a Nicor and Dynegy joint venture, Nicor Energy L.L.C., were indicted on criminal charges of manipulating financial results and were accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of inflating income by $11 million in 2001.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-27

title: Fassel Says He's Sticking It Out
description: Jim Fassel's Giants have lost five straight games and have heard the chants and seen the signs saying ''Fire Fassel'' at Giants Stadium.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Knicks' Trip To the West Is a Washout
description: In each stop of this ill-fated trip, the Knicks left empty-handed simply because they watched loose balls skirt out of their reach and into the grasp of their on-rushing opponents. Other times, they never saw it coming.

title: Bidding for Isolation
description: Just when it looked as if there was a chance to expand international involvement in Iraq, President Bush has reversed field again and left the European allies angry, the secretary of state looking out of step, and the rest of us wondering exactly what his policy really is.

title: One Hunter Got No Bear, But Swamp Nearly Got Him
description: Scott Seelagy and a friend eagerly set out about sunrise Tuesday on their second day of bear hunting. After lunch, the two men were separated on Hamburg Mountain in Sussex County, N.J. As night fell, Mr. Seelagy found himself trapped in icy, waist-deep water in a swamp next to a golf course named -- irony of ironies -- Black Bear Golf Club.

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Ruling on McCain-Feingold Campaign Finance Law
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision on Wednesday upholding the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law. The vote in McConnell v. F.E.C. was 5 to 4. The majority opinion was written by Justices John Paul Stevens and Sandra Day O'Connor. Justices Antonin Scalia, Clarence Thomas, Anthony M. Kennedy and Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote dissents. The full ruling is online at nytimes.com/washington.

title: A $200 PC (but Don't Expect Bells, Whistles or a Monitor)
description: In ''The First $20 Million Is the Hardest: A Novel,'' a 1997 comedy set in Silicon Valley, a group of techies set out to do the seemingly impossible: create a personal computer that sells for under $300. It's a testament to the pace of change in the PC industry that just a few years later, such a product exists.

title: Jolting the Democrats: The Gore-Dean Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: South
description: SOUTH CAROLINA: JUVENILE JUSTICE OVERSIGHT ENDS Judge Joseph F. Anderson of Federal District Court in Columbia ended eight years of federal oversight of the State Department of Juvenile Justice that began as a result of a lawsuit against the department in 1990. The suit said juveniles in state prisons suffered overcrowding and abuse, and poor health care, food and education. Since the federal government began oversight in 1995, the department has built new wilderness camps for nonviolent offenders, focused on education and job skills, started sports leagues and hired more guards, partly thanks to $7 million in new financing from the Legislature this year, said the department's director, Bill Byars. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Jolting the Democrats: The Gore-Dean Connection
description: To the Editor:

title: S.&P. Declines on Concerns About Rising Interest Rates
description: The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell for a third day in four yesterday as mortgage lenders like Washington Mutual and home builders including Toll Brothers declined amid speculation that interest rates will rise, hurting their business.

title: A Russian Poet Steeped In America
description: With a bright patchwork jacket from Guatemala covering his broad shoulders, the graying lion of Russian letters, Yevgeny Yevtushenko, paced and shouted as he read some of his poems that once shook the world. Between verses he tossed off advice and opinion about life, love and literature.

title: Credit Rating of Parmalat Cut Sharply on Fear of Default
description: Standard & Poor's sharply cut its credit rating on Parmalat, the Italian dairy giant, by four notches on Wednesday, just a day after announcing a similar cut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VOLNER, VERA LEVINSON
description: VOLNER -- Vera Levinson. Age 93, died peacefully of old age December 6, 2003 in Bethesda, MD. She was predeceased by her husband of 48 years, Kelly Volner. Surviving are her son, Ian (Martha) Volner, daughter Kelcy (Richard) Roth, and five grandchildren, Mandy, Loren, and Glen Roth and Davey and Matt Volner. Instead of flowers, please make memorial contributions to House of Ruth, 5 Thomas Circle, Washington, DC 20005.

title: Editorial Observer; Just as Mexican Movies Become Chic Again, the Government Pulls Its Support
description: Mexican movies and moviemakers -- are hot. Hollywood borrowed Alfonso Cuarn, who made the breathtaking ''Y Tu Mam Tambin,'' to direct the third Harry Potter film. Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu, whose 2000 debut movie, ''Amores Perros,'' was nominated for an Oscar for best foreign film, has won more acclaim with the just-released ''21 Grams.'' The once-great Mexican film industry is again enjoying boom years.

title: Martin Continues to Play With the Same Abandon
description: As the Nets were rolling to victory over Seattle in the fourth quarter on Tuesday, Richard Jefferson stroked a 3-pointer to push his point total to 28. The next trip upcourt, with the five hopeful substitutes already lined alongside the scorer's table, Jefferson fed Kenyon Martin for what he thought would be his final turn in a superb performance. But Martin deferred, firing the ball back to Jefferson, who then hit another 3-pointer before heading to the bench.

title: Baseball Analysis; And Exactly What Were They Thinking?
description: Andy Pettitte recently asked his father, Tom, whether he should sign his next contract with the Yankees or with the Houston Astros.

title: Mets Give Matsui His First Taste Of the Bright Lights in the Big City
description: The Mets called on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday to announce their first player acquisition of this off-season and unveil the biggest foreign import in the team's history. Bloomberg fired off one-liners selling the city and setting the stage for the newest Met, who stole the show with 11 English words: ''Hello everyone. My name is Kazuo Matsui. I love New York.''

title: Serb Policeman Describes Massacre in Kosovo
description: For the first time since the end of the 1990's wars that broke up Yugoslavia, a former Serbian policeman went before a local court on Wednesday and described how his police reserve unit had taken part in the massacre of at least 14 people, including 7 children.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Pro-Beijing Party Chooses Leader
description: The main pro-Beijing party, the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong, has chosen Ma Lik, who has sometimes criticized the local government, as its new chairman. He succeeds Tsang Yok-sing, who resigned after the party suffered a sharp decline in support in local elections on Nov. 23. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: A Phone Chat, Warts and All
description: People who demand more than sound from their telephones now have another option: the Beamer TV Videophone Station from Vialta.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Male Judge Files Sex Bias Suit
description: A State Supreme Court justice on Staten Island has filed a lawsuit against the state's chief judge, Judith S. Kaye, charging her and other officials with falsely branding him sexist and replacing him with a female justice. The justice, Frank V. Ponterio, is seeking $3 million in damages against Judge Kaye and other administrators, accusing them of sex discrimination and of retaliating against his complaints by refusing to recertify him for another term. Justice Ponterio, 72, who as a retiree must be recertified every two years to remain on the bench, claims that to facilitate his removal he was falsely branded with a reputation of discriminating against women in his rulings. David Bookstaver, spokesman for the Office of Court Administration, said, ''At the time of the appointments, the decisions were made solely on the basis of merit and the need for judicial resources.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Agreement Expands Generic Drugs in South Africa to Fight AIDS
description: Two major makers of anti-AIDS drugs agreed Wednesday to expand licensing of the drugs in southern Africa to generic manufacturers, potentially making both existing and new, more powerful AIDS treatments available at drastically lower prices.

title: When the Garon Gets Snooty, A Fluent Palmtop Takes Charge
description: Tongue-tied travelers who fear mispronouncing even ''bonjour'' can now safely keep their mouths shut, literally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERGER, MARCUS
description: BERGER--Marcus. Devoted husband of Rachel. Beloved father of Joseph and Joshua, and Evelyn Hartman. Adored zayde of Jakey, Annie, Danny, Alisa, David, Benji and Renee. Died December 10. Funeral today at Hebrew Institute of Riverdale, 3700 Henry Hudson Parkway, at 10AM

title: George Marshall's World, And Ours
description: In early December 1953, Gen. George C. Marshall was en route to Oslo to receive the Nobel Peace Prize for his role in reconstructing Europe. The five-day passage aboard the Andrea Doria was a rough one, and the general had a terrible cold. Marshall had intended to use the voyage to draft his acceptance speech, but his illness prevented him from doing so. He landed in Europe with a few central ideas in his head but nothing on paper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, PAUL
description: SIMON--Paul. The Institute of International Education Board of Trustees and staff deeply mourn the death of our distinguished Trustee, Senator Paul Simon, who was known for the great depth of his honor and integrity throughout his 40 year career in public service and his leadership in public policy. We are grateful to have been touched by his extraordinary vision and commitment. We were honored by his service on our board, and privileged to have been working with him on his most recent initiative, the proposed Abraham Lincoln Study Abroad Fellowship Program. We hope to see this program realized, and to see his legacy include the far reaching benefits that it offers our country and the world. We express our deepest sympathy to the Simon family. Allan Goodman, President Thomas S. Johnson, Chairman

title: Accounts
description: Sanofi-Synthelabo, Paris, consolidated its worldwide advertising for drug brands like Ambien and Plavix, with billing estimated at $235 million to $245 million, at agencies owned by the Publicis Groupe, Paris. The decision came after a review that had been narrowed to agencies owned by Publicis; Havas, Paris; and the WPP Group, London.

title: The Short and Squat Keep Cocktails Upright
description: Elementary physics suggests that short, heavy glasses are harder to tip over than tall, lightweight ones. The new Kampai collection by Lena Bergstrom for Orrefors includes a 17.6-ounce iced-beverage glass ($40), left, and dwarf martini glasses, right, which are just 4 1/2 inches tall yet able to hold a generous 10 ounces ($70 for a pair). The collection will be available next spring from the Orrefors shop, 685 Madison Avenue (61st Street); (212) 752-1095. A similar cocktail glass, with a stubby black stem, called Viva ($3.50), holds 8 ounces and is now at Crate & Barrel, 611 Broadway (Houston Street); (212) 780-0004 or www.crateandbarrel.com.

title: Afghanistan's Tragedy Through a Teenager's Eyes
description: The first hint that Hyder Akbar is not Afghanistan's most seasoned radio reporter is his sign-on. ''Hello?'' he says. ''Hello?''

title: It's 3 a.m. on Dec. 25: Got Wrapping Paper?
description: Looking for the right wrapping paper? Look no farther than your color printer. At www.epson.com, click on ''USA,'' then ''craft projects,'' then ''patterned pages.'' Now look for ''ornaments, ribbons and fabrics.'' (Above, the pattern known as Ornaments.) Hewlett-Packard offers its own wrapping papers at www.homeandoffice.hp.com; type ''wrap'' into the search box. Offerings include ''dove,'' ''star'' and ''lights.'' Granted, these papers will be only as large as the printer allows, but good things come in small packages. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: West Texans Sizzle Over a Plan to Sell Their Water
description: Angry West Texans and some state officials are demanding a halt to a deal that allows a group of politically well-connected Midland oilmen to tap the desert and sell billions of gallons of water from the state's public reserves.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Juvenile Justice Oversight Ends
description: Judge Joseph F. Anderson of Federal District Court in Columbia ended eight years of federal oversight of the State Department of Juvenile Justice that began as a result of a lawsuit against the department in 1990. The suit said juveniles in state prisons suffered overcrowding and abuse, and poor health care, food and education. Since the federal government began oversight in 1995, the department has built new wilderness camps for nonviolent offenders, focused on education and job skills, started sports leagues and hired more guards, partly thanks to $7 million in new financing from the Legislature this year, said the department's director, Bill Byars. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: The New Look at Ground Zero May Be the Oldest
description: THERE is, as the public will learn next week, a difference between a plan and a design, a design and a design concept. All the difference in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VELEZ, HENRY
description: VELEZ -- Henry. Veteran Broadway stage manager and director died December 9, 2003 after a short illness. Mr. Velez stage managed such Broadway plays as ''Inherit the Wind,'' starring Paul Muni, ''Foxy,'' starring Bert Lahr, ''How Now Dow Jones,'' ''Promises, Promises,'' and ''Sugar,'' produced by David Merrick, ''The Wiz,'' ''Sly Fox'' ''The Corn is Green'' with Cicely Tyson, and ''The Poison Tree,'' ''Biloxi Blues,'' and ''Broadway Bound,'' for Emanuel Azenberg. In addition, he produced and directed summer seasons for the Mt. Gretna Playhouse and the Woodstock Theatre. He also directed for Oslo Theatre in Oslo, Norway.

title: Jets Ponder Abraham At Outside Linebacker
description: With the their defense mired near the bottom of the National Football League ranking, the inevitable personnel overhaul looms for the Jets. But one of the most significant changes could involve one of their best players.

title: Sports of The Times; The Knicks May Need To Watch Their Turf
description: ONE day, in about four years, James L. Dolan may be stirred from his narcoleptic leadership as Knicks chairman by a hired jostler on retainer at Madison Square Garden.

title: For Doodlers and Pack Rats, a Multimedia Binder
description: THIRTY-FIVE years ago, the first planned experiment for the forerunner of today's Internet was to offer remote access to a software tool designed to let researchers create, capture, organize and retrieve digital information.

title: Fund Compliance Plans Ignored Trade Timing
description: The numbers seemed almost incredible: more than 25,000 letters and e-mail messages were sent by 68 mutual fund companies over 12 months to Prudential Securities, all complaining about a small group of Prudential brokers in Boston.

title: When Your Mom Calls to Sell Me Something
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Charge Called Oops: Readers Recount Misadventures
description: ACorporate Game

title: When It Comes to Surgery, He's a Minimalist
description: PHYSICAL size is pretty much an unavoidable topic around Dr. Butch Rosser.

title: In New Landscape of Campaign Finance, Big Donations Flow to Groups, Not Parties
description: The Supreme Court's decision to uphold most of last year's campaign finance law quashed any final hopes politicians and their parties had about returning to the days when unlimited contributions flowed freely into their hands.

title: BUSH SEEKS HELP OF ALLIES BARRED FROM IRAQ DEALS
description: President Bush found himself in the awkward position on Wednesday of calling the leaders of France, Germany and Russia to ask them to forgive Iraq's debts, just a day after the Pentagon excluded those countries and others from $18 billion in American-financed Iraqi reconstruction projects.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Sweet and Low

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Plum Island: Animal Lab Gets New Director
description: The Plum Island Animal Research Center, which has been criticized by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and others for security problems and for its handling of a labor dispute, will get a new director and a change in its security operations, officials said yesterday. The Department of Homeland Security said it had hired Dr. Elizabeth A. Lautner, a veterinarian and the National Pork Board's science director, to head the laboratory. At the same time, the Arctic Slope Regional Corporation's Field Support Services is taking over the ferries, security, power plant and other operations, except for scientific and administrative functions. Under the departing contractor, LB&B, security breaches had occurred that involved the disappearance of two computers, the firing and reinstatement of a whistle-blower and a strike-lockout dispute with Operating Engineers Local 30 that has lasted more than a year. Senator Clinton praised the changes. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Serving Up Reality
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Design Firm's Classic Icons
Italy steps up hunt for source of bottled-water tampering
description: MILAN:  Investigators have intensified their efforts to track down the so-called Acquabomber, who for the past month has been injecting small quantities of toxic substances into plastic bottles of mineral water with a syringe, sickening several people.

title: DANAHER BIDS $720 MILLION FOR DANISH EQUIPMENT MAKER
description: Danaher , the maker of Craftsman tools, said yesterday that it had offered to buy Radiometer of Denmark for 4.4 billion kroner ($720 million) to gain access to technology used in treating the SARS virus. Danaher's DH Denmark Holding unit bid 460 kroner a share for Radiometer, 6.2 percent more than its closing price on Wednesday. Danaher is making its bid after Radiometer's chief executive, Johan Schroeder, indicated that an investment company he controls wished to sell its 33.9 percent stake. Danaher also said that it had agreed to pay $102.5 million in cash for the Gendex dental-imaging-equipment business of Dentsply International.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREIMAN, DR. DAVID G.
description: FREIMAN--Dr. David G. Of Newton, MA, on Wednesday, December 10th, 2003. Beloved husband for 54 years to Ruth (Schein). Loving father of Nancy F. Docken and Leonard H. and Marjorie R. Freiman. Adored grandfather of Emily Webster, Nathan and Eli Freiman. Dear brother of the late Carlyn Hausman. For further information, please call the Levine Chapel at 617277-8300.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: LITHUANIA: IMPEACHMENT APPEARS CLOSER Lawmakers said they had collected enough signatures to begin impeachment proceedings against President Rolandas Paksas, who has been accused of links to criminal groups. "We have 36 signatures and are looking for more" said Eligijus Masiulis, a legislator. The support of 36 lawmakers is required to start impeachment proceedings in the 141-seat Parliament; 85 votes are needed to remove the president. (Agence France-Presse)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Man Dies In Synagogue Blast
description: A car exploded near a synagogue in the central city of Modena, killing its Jordanian driver in an apparent suicide that the police and government officials insisted was not a terrorist attack. The police said that the man was emotionally unstable and that he set fire to a flammable liquid in the car, which was parked beside a wall surrounding the synagogue. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Rapid-Result H.I.V. Testing Will Be Offered in City Jails
description: The city Health Department next month will begin offering rapid H.I.V. tests, which provide results in minutes, to any of the nearly 14,000 inmates in New York City jails who request it, officials said yesterday.

title: US Airways' Stock Hurt By Southwest's Route Plans
description: Shares of US Airways fell yesterday, as Southwest Airlines, the largest low-cost carrier, said it would serve six cities from Philadelphia, one of US Airways' hubs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOSKOWITZ, LEAH
description: MOSKOWITZ--Leah. Beloved wife of the late Moses. Devoted mother of Howard and Arlene, Judith and Larry Kunstatd. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. An Eishes Chayrl. Services Friday 9:30AM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave, Yonkers, NY.

title: National Briefing: Mid-Atlantic
description: PENNSYLVANIA: MISSING MUSEUM PIECES Hundreds of items are missing from the Barnes Foundation, including a piece by Matisse and a Renoir vase, the foundation's chief executive, Kimberly Camp, testified at a trial to determine whether the Barnes can move its multibillion-dollar art collection to downtown Philadelphia from the suburbs. The foundation learned of the missing items beginning to catalog the 9,000 items in its collection. (AP)

title: Technology Makes Comeback in Realigning of Nasdaq Index
description: The Nasdaq 100, on its way to a very good year, is bringing in technology stocks again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, LOUIS
description: MILLER--Louis. Age 95. Retired business executive and community leader in Manchester, NH, died of influenza on November 26, 2003 in Scottsdale, AZ, his second home. He was married for 57 years to the late Helene Chase Miller, whom he met when both were English majors at Brown University in the late 20s. He is survived by his children, Devra Miller Breslow and her husband Dr. Lester Breslow of Los Angeles and Professor Linda B. Miller of S. Wellfleet and Wellesley, MA, by his wife of seven years, Meredith Weiss Miller, and his sister Sally Miller Brash of Tucson, nephews and cousins. Services were held in Scottsdale, November 30. Services and committal will be held Sunday, December 14, 12 Noon, at Temple Adath Yeshurun in Manchester. Contributions in his memory: Louis Miller Fund, Temple Adath Yeshurun, 152 Prospect Street, Manchester, NH 03104. Devra M. Breslow Lester Breslow Linda B. Miller

title: Hey, Little Cobra
description: IN the early 1960's, the innovative designs of Carroll Shelby, a racecar driver from rural Texas, forced Europhiles to take American sports cars seriously. An exhibition of his most famous works, ''A Life in the Fast Lane,'' is now at the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles. Page 7.

title: Taking Supplies to the Troops, 'Coming In High and Fast'
description: From the darkened cockpit of this giant Air Force cargo plane, Capt. J. J. Grindrod peered early Monday through his night vision goggles at the Iraqi airstrip ahead and prepared to make a steep, high-speed landing, a tactic used to thwart surface-to-air missile attacks.

title: Shock Over Arrests in Children's Deaths
description: A day after an Illinois woman and her boyfriend were accused of murder in the drowning deaths of the woman's three children, the farming community where she lived was grappling Thursday with the charges.

title: A Geeky Guy, a Popular Girl And a Fortuitous Car Wreck
description: ''Love Don't Cost a Thing,'' proclaims the title of Troy Beyer's film, but affection is a little more expensive. The going rate here is $1,500 for two weeks, which is what Alvin Johnson (Nick Cannon), a geeky high school student, indirectly pays Paris Morgan (Christina Milian), the most popular girl in his Long Beach, Calif., high school class, to pretend to be his girlfriend for two weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIED, MAURICE
description: FRIED -- Maurice. Beloved husband of the late Jeanne, devoted father of Lynn, dear brother of Herbert and the late Leah Resnick and Julius Fried, loving uncle and dear friend. Services Friday, 11:45AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, N.Y.

title: 2 American Journalists Wounded in Iraq
description: Two journalists covering the Iraq conflict for Time magazine were wounded Wednesday night in Baghdad, when a grenade was thrown into the Humvee they were riding in while accompanying United States military personnel, representatives of the magazine said Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about President Bush's meeting with King Abdullah of Jordan misstated the effect that an unofficial peace plan drafted by Israelis and Palestinians, known as the Geneva plan, would have on Israeli settlements. Under that plan, Israel would give up most of the settlements in the West Bank, not keep them. But since the 400,000 Israelis in the West Bank and Jerusalem are concentrated in a few settlements and neighborhoods that Israel would keep under the plan, about 300,000 settlers would remain where they live.

title: One Hungers for Fame, One's Along for the Ride
description: It's probably fitting that portions of the new Farrelly Brothers' chewy but minor comedy, ''Stuck on You,'' are set during the winter in a resort town -- Martha's Vineyard -- like their first picture out of the toboggan chute, ''Dumb and Dumber.'' Both movies seem to come out of a taste-free zone partially inspired by Rankin/Bass, the animation studio responsible for the holiday stop-motion, self-pity classics like ''Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer.''

title: Goldman Asks For Grants Downtown
description: Three years ago, Goldman Sachs decided to build the tallest and most expensive skyscraper in Jersey City -- a development that left New York officials fuming over the snub.

title: 6 Cubans Are Found Guilty in Hijacking Case
description: A jury on Thursday found six Cuban men guilty of hijacking a passenger flight from their country to South Florida last March, in what federal prosecutors called an unequivocal rebuke of using violence to reach the United States.

title: In the Master's Voice, Old Books Live Again
description: In the age of talk shows and national publicity tours, it's easy to see that every writer has at least two voices -- the one on the page and the one that comes out of his mouth -- but that was true long before Oprah got into the act. When J. R. R. Tolkien reads from ''The Hobbit,'' he gives the sinister Gollum a hissing, whispery voice, full of sibilant menace, and makes a choking sound as he says of his creature, ''He made a horrible swallowing noise in his throat. That is how he got his name, though he always called himself 'my precious.' ''

title: New 'Immortal' for France, But Some Would Wish It Otherwise
description: Former President Valry Giscard d'Estaing of France became immortal on Thursday, according to a French conceit, after France's high-flown lexicographers committee, the Acadmie Franaise, accepted him as a member. The academicians are known in France as ''immortals.''

title: Clark Call to Clinton Follows Gore Move
description: Gen. Wesley K. Clark said yesterday that he had called former President Bill Clinton immediately after learning that Al Gore had endorsed Howard Dean in the race for president, ''just to call and say 'hello.' ''

title: 3 Killed in Israel Blast Linked To Crime Figure, Not to Terror
description: A powerful bomb exploded at the entrance to a currency exchange shop on a busy street here at lunchtime on Thursday, killing 3 men and wounding more than 20 other people. The police called it the latest attempt to kill a reputed underworld figure who has now survived six assassination attempts.

title: Lilly Cuts Off 5 Wholesalers
description: By Bloomberg News

title: TBS Superstation Hires Two Agencies
description: The TBS Superstation cable television network, part of the Turner Broadcasting System, will formally announce today that it is hiring two agencies to handle creative assignments.

title: Regents Propose New Plan for Calculating and Increasing Education Aid
description: The New York State Board of Regents unveiled a plan on Thursday to scrap the byzantine formulas the state has used to deliver education aid and proposed increasing basic aid to schools by $5.98 billion over the next seven years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDINER, JAMES BRONSON II.
description: GARDINER--James Bronson II. Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York Inc. marks with great sadness the death on December 11, 2003 of James Bronson Gardiner II, its esteemed member of the Board of Managers, and Life Member. In addition to serving on the Board of Managers at various times during the past 20 years, he rendered valuable service as chairman and member of several committees. In his memory, the Society's flag at Fraunces Tavern will be flown at half-staff for 30 days. We extend our deep sympathy to his family. Kevin F. Hansley, President Eric Kramer, Secretary

title: Remnants of Military Tradition Remain for Clark, the Candidate
description: Donors who show up for Gen. Wesley K. Clark's fund-raisers these days are personally greeted by General Clark as new enlistees to ''C Company.'' The V.I.P. supporters can be spotted by the lapel buttons adorned with four military stars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DALY, JOSEPH R.
description: DALY--Joseph R., of Jupiter, FL, age 85. Dear father of Dottie Mull, Suzanne Herbers, Peter, Timothy, Mark, Andrew and Jennifer Daly. Loving brother of Steve, John, Paul Daly, Theresa Siller, Winifred Madigan and Peggy McGee. Also survived by 15 grandchildren, one greatgranddaughter. Memorial Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral, NYC (Lady Chapel), Monday, December 29, 10:30am. Donations in lieu of flowers to Joseph R. Daly Foundation, c/o Mark Daly, PO Box 43350, Cincinnati, OH 45243.

description: To the Editor:

title: Calling 'Candid Camera'
description: Not all that long ago, the tools Americans owned were relatively simple, single-purpose tools. No one expected the black, rotary-dial Ma Bell telephone in the hallway to take photographs. That was not its job. Even if it could have taken photos, it could have taken ones only of the hallway because the phone was tethered to the wall by a cord. And if you wanted to send those hallway photos to someone, you had to have them developed at the photo shop and had to send prints in the mail.

title: The Study of Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: No Will To Win?
description: Ready, aim. . . .

title: Rights Group Faults U.S. Over Cluster Bombs
description: The American and British armies could have prevented hundreds of civilian injuries or deaths during the war in Iraq by eliminating the use of cluster munitions in populated areas, according to a study by a leading human rights group.

title: Martin Is Close to Joining Some Exclusive Company
description: When Curtis Martin was a senior at the University of Pittsburgh, he was sitting in a restaurant one day just before he began training for the N.F.L. draft. He was talking to a man, a friend of his mother's, who flew planes and it occurred to Martin that he might go to aviation school.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ALABAMA: PLANS TO SEEK DEATH IN CLINIC BOMBING United States Attorney Alice Martin said she would seek the death penalty for Eric R. Rudolph in an explosion at a Birmingham abortion clinic in 1998 that killed a police officer. He is also accused in the 1996 Olympic bombing in Atlanta that killed one woman, and two bombings in Atlanta in 1997. (AP)

title: Under Pressure, a Mutual Fund May Lower Fees
description: Eliot Spitzer's campaign to lower fees in the mutual fund industry may be making some headway, even though pricing is normally the domain of federal regulators.

title: Sharpton Smarts as Others Get Local Support
description: On Saturday, he pulled in big ratings as host of ''Saturday Night Live.'' On Tuesday, he drew both applause and laughs in a nationally televised debate. On Wednesday, the day after a rival was endorsed by a former vice president, Al Gore, he sat down in Harlem for a private meeting with a former president, Bill Clinton.

title: Yankees Are Embarking on Life After Pettitte
description: George Steinbrenner craves superstars, big-name performers with track records and attitude on the Yankees. The Los Angeles Dodgers right-hander Kevin Brown, with a nasty sinking fastball and a surly -- if not nasty -- mien, is a Steinbrenner kind of guy.

title: John Sidgmore, 52, Dies; Headed WorldCom
description: John W. Sidgmore, a leading Internet entrepreneur who became chairman and chief executive of the scandal-ridden WorldCom last year when its founder, Bernard J. Ebbers, was forced to resign, died yesterday of kidney failure, according to a statement issued by his family. He was 52 and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: Last-Minute Damage to the Environment
description: The Senate's failure this week to complete work on its omnibus spending bill gives it a month to review some damaging last-minute legislative riders that should be killed when Congress returns to work in January. Of particular concern are two amendments involving environmental issues. One would weaken air pollution rules. The other would weaken protections for dwindling fish species. These riders would not only serve special interests in the familiar manner of the pork-barrel riders that lard the bill, but also undercut basic law.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KLAUSNER, MORRIS
description: KLAUSNER--Morris. December 12, 1903-December 10, 1968. On what would have been his 100th birthday, we honor the memory of our beloved father, grandfather and great grandfather. Vivienne, Lynn and Jay and children.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Portland, Ore.

title: Those Dinosaurs Weren't Even as Sweet as They Looked
description: Why are history's actual monsters -- ''unblinking killers,'' in the words of a new show -- so often depicted as adorable?

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Applauding Mr. Andersen

title: A Bush Aide Criticizes Israel for Not Doing More to Foster Peace
description: In an unusually blunt criticism of a close ally, a Bush administration envoy on the Middle East said Thursday that Israel had ''done too little for far too long'' to foster peace negotiations with the Palestinian Authority.

title: INSIDE ART
description: Gagosian Adds To London Space

title: Pakistan Holds Scientists for Questioning
description: Government officials confirmed Thursday that they were questioning two Pakistani nuclear scientists who were reported missing on Sunday. But they denied newspaper reports that the scientists were under investigation for sharing nuclear weapons technology with Iran.

title: The Real Dean, And the Real Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: A Candidate Captures a Vote, if Not a Heart
description: Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio, the Democratic presidential candidate who declared in a debate last month that he was in the market for an ''outspoken woman,'' may have met his Mrs. Right on Thursday morning: a 34-year-old New Jersey resident who won breakfast with him by entering an Internet contest entitled ''Who Wants to Be a First Lady?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITEHILL, JENNIE LEVY
description: WHITEHILL--Jennie Levy. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Jennie Whitehill, a cherished friend of the Jewish community. Jennie's accomplishments will help those in need for generations to come. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Turmoil Poses Danger to Government Case on Detroit Terror Cell
description: The government's case against an accused terror cell here appears to be at risk of falling apart amid turmoil in the prosecutor's office and a dispute between the Senate Finance Committee and the Justice Department.

title: Making the Medical Care System Fair for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Lover Boys Woo the Ladies With Rhythm, Roses and Raunch
description: It's not easy to be a rhythm-and-blues love man in the hip-hop era. But Gerald Levert and Will Downing have made careers singing what women want to hear, and when they shared a bill at the Beacon Theater on Sunday night grown women rushed the stage to get a kiss or a rose. Both singers are figuring out just how raunchy they are supposed to be. With hip-hop pushing toward the explicit, they now dispense sweet nothings as a thin cover for lubricity.

title: Yankees Lose Part of Their Core As Pettitte Signs With Houston
description: He has been through nine years in the playoffs, six American League pennants, four World Series titles, all with one team. Andy Pettitte was that rare modern player, a career Yankee in the mold of Whitey Ford and Ron Guidry, a reliable left-hander who seemed as if he would wear pinstripes forever.

title: Virginia Indicts 2 Under Antispam Law
description: Virginia announced yesterday the indictments of two people on criminal charges involving unsolicited e-mail, the first case to be brought under an antispam law that took effect in June. Virginia is one of the few states with laws that include criminal penalties for sending unsolicited bulk e-mail, or spam.

title: U.S. General Says Coalition Is Choking Funds to Insurgency
description: TIKRIT, Iraq, Dec. 11  The United States general commanding operations in Saddam Hussein's ancestral homeland says that American forces have dealt a damaging blow to the insurgency in this pivotal region of Iraq in the past 30 days by choking off much of the guerrillas' financing and arms supplies. But he also acknowledges that the occupation still faces huge challenges, including suicide bombings and the training and equipping of new Iraqi police officers and militia.

title: Painting Interiors of the Heart, With Eros in Restrained Hues
description: At the start of ''Girl With a Pearl Earring,'' Griet (Scarlett Johansson) is shown peeling an onion, an image as metaphor rarely seen outside first-semester filmmaking classes. The determination visible in such an effort communicates Importance Writ Large. And the film, adapted by Olivia Hetreed from Tracy Chevalier's novel, does have a great subject: the story surrounding an artwork shrouded in mystery and a project that ruins a woman's reputation yet ensures her a place in history.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Kerry Promises to Crack Down On Crime in Corporate Offices
description: Senator John Kerry said on Thursday that he would crack down on abuses in the mutual fund industry if elected president and called for expanding the antiracketeering laws to fight a ''new age of organized crime that comes from corporate offices.''

title: Korean Art, Serenely Unconcerned, Finally Gets a Chance to Shine
description: Apart from jade-green celadons, which everyone adores, there was no such thing as Korean art for most Americans before 1979. That was the year the exhibition ''5,000 Years of Korean Art, '' organized by the Asian Art Museum here, traveled the country and was a hit.

title: Shakespeare's Lovers, Lost in a Musical Forest
description: The opera departments at both the Juilliard School and the Manhattan School of Music present only a handful of productions every year, but they are often among the most vital stagings of the season. Both schools tend to favor unusual or contemporary works over standard fare, and although there are differences in budgets and facilities (Juilliard is the better endowed), both offer productions that are fully staged and costumed, thoughtfully lighted and directed by experienced hands. Although the singers and orchestral musicians are students, no excuses need be made for them.

title: Magic Tries to Climb Out of a Deep Hole
description: The mood has been so funereal in the land of neon theme parks that John Gabriel, the general manager of the most disappointing team in the N.B.A., the Orlando Magic, hardly raises his voice above a whisper in these hangdog days.

title: Alcan Weighs South African Smelter
description: Ever since the Alcan aluminum and packaging group of Canada began pursuing its French rival Pechiney last summer, Alcan's chief executive, Travis Engen, has been bombarded with e-mail, faxes and phone calls from South Africa.

title: This Management Wants Investors' Money, Not Their Opinions
description: CALL it shareholder democracy, Chinese style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, RUTH (SPECTOR)
description: SHAPIRO -- Ruth (Spector). On December 11, 2003. Beloved wife of Norman for 62 years. Devoted mother of Merrill and the late Steven. Dear sister of Isabel and the late Marjorie. Adored grandmother of Jenai and Kiera. Cherished aunt. Beloved sister-in-law. Devoted friend and neighbor. Ruth was wise and compassionate dedicating her life to making this world a better place. Her loving spirit will live on. Services Sunday 12 noon ''Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 114-03 Queens Blvd in Forest Hills, NY. Donations to God's Love We Deliver.

title: 'Will & Grace' Creators Sue Over Rights
description: The creators of the hit comedy series ''Will & Grace'' sued NBC on Thursday, accusing the network of selling the rights to the show at ''tens of millions of dollars'' below fair value.

title: Ross R. Millhiser, 83, Marketer Of Top-Selling Marlboro Brand
description: Ross R. Millhiser, the Philip Morris executive who enlisted a rugged cowboy image and innovative packaging to make Marlboro America's best-selling cigarette, died on Saturday in Richmond, Va. He was 83.

title: Who's Scarier: The Hunter or the Hunted?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fed Minutes Suggest Rates Could Stay Low Until 2005
description: Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their October meeting that inflation could remain low until 2005 and that they should not raise interest rates until they saw concrete signs of rising prices, according to minutes of the meeting released on Thursday.

title: Dow Closes Above 10,000 for First Time in 18 Months
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 10,000 yesterday for the first time in more than 18 months, adding its own ratification to this year's economic rebound.

title: Master Planner or Master Builder?
description: As Gov. George E. Pataki prepares to unveil the latest design of the ''Freedom Tower'' at ground zero, the long-simmering dispute between Daniel Libeskind, the master planner for the site, and David M. Childs, the architect chosen by Larry Silverstein, the commercial leaseholder at the site, to design the tower has come to a boil. Although this is unfortunate and unprofessional, it will probably pale in comparison to the struggle for symbolic control of the rebuilding after the designer of the World Trade Center memorial is chosen next week. That is the way things will go if certain crucial points are not clarified now.

title: The Business of Rebuilding Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Armies, Without Rifles, From Japan
description: THE major story out of Tokyo this week was Japan's decision to send up to 600 soldiers to Iraq. For a country that since World War II has had a profound aversion to military entanglements -- not to mention to potential military defeats -- this qualified as a very big deal.

title: In Reversal, U.S. May Send Additional Food Aid to North Korea
description: The United States is considering releasing roughly 66,000 tons in additional food aid to North Korea this year as that country faces a winter famine, administration officials said Thursday.

title: Collins Questions Hit By Washington's Smith
description: Kerry Collins threw himself into film sessions and meetings this week to help prepare Jesse Palmer, his replacement as the Giants' starting quarterback. But Collins also took time to watch the tape of the hit by Washington's Bruce Smith last Sunday that resulted in the high sprain of his left ankle. What Collins saw was unsettling, not for the severity of the injury but for the intent.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Doctors Urged To Save Vaccine For Those Most Vulnerable To Flu
description: As the demand for flu shots threatens to overtake dwindling supplies, New York City's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene urged doctors yesterday to administer the vaccine to patients who are the highest risk first. Those most at risk of becoming seriously ill from flu-related complications are the elderly and children, said Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, commissioner of the department. People over the age of 65 are particularly vulnerable to pneumonia, which can develop from the flu. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Comparing Genomes Shows Split Between Chimps and People
description: By comparing the human genome with that of chimpanzees, people's closest living relative, scientists have identified a partial list of the genes that make people human.

title: Legislators Focus on Lesser Issues After Failing to Increase Gas Tax
description: New Jersey legislators voted on Thursday on measures that would prohibit drivers from using hand-held cellphones, lower the legal threshold for drunken driving and guarantee same-sex couples access to a wider range of medical insurance and legal protections.

title: Closer Look at Deductions For Donations to Charity
description: Charitable donations of everything from mittens and food to property and planes is coming under Congressional scrutiny, thanks to research raising questions about the real value of donated vehicles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, GEORGE
description: GOLDBERG--George, 78, of Great Neck and East Moriches, retired publisher of SCAN Newsletter and President of GGX Assoc., on December 10, 2003. Devoted husband of Teddy and beloved father of Jeff of Washington, DC; Robbi of East Moriches; and David and wife Nanci of Port Washington; grandfather of Jonathan; brother of Leon and wife Brana of Tamarac, FL; and many nieces and nephews. Services at the RiversideNassau North Chapels, Great Neck, Friday at 1:15 PM. In our hearts forever.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption yesterday with an article about child victims of recent American airstrikes in Afghanistan referred incorrectly in some copies to the deaths of nine children last Saturday in the village of Hutala, whose graves were shown. They were killed by weapons fired from an American warplane, not by the collapse of a wall.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chip Sales Rising
description: The world's largest supplier of made-to-order chips, the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, said it might post record sales in the fourth quarter, as analysts forecast strong cellphone demand. Sales in the first two months of this quarter rose to 38.8 billion Taiwan dollars ($1.14 billion), or 30 percent, from 29.8 billion Taiwan dollars a year earlier, based on monthly reports from Taiwan Semiconductor. Third-quarter sales were 54.9 billion Taiwan dollars.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Vietnamese cuisine, it seems to me, is well suited to American culture at the present time. The food is low in fat and endlessly varied, with lots going on even in small, bite-size dishes. What could be better for a nation with a short attention span and a firm grip on the channel changer?

title: Cost of Rutgers Merger Is Put at $1.25 Billion Over a Decade
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey's plan to merge the state's top three research universities would cost $1.25 billion in the first 10 years, a consultant hired to study the matter said on Wednesday. The preliminary cost estimate came just before the governor's self-imposed Jan. 1 deadline to get the three universities to agree to the merger to create what he hopes will become a more prestigious unified state university system.

title: Furnished Houses: Moving In Means Taking Your Toothbrush
description: WHO -- Susan Castellanos, 54, a homemaker in Alexandria, Va., shown with her son, Alexander, far right, and his friends Mike Soul, far left, and Ryan Brady.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the retirement of Gordon Conway, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, included an erroneous reference from the organization to his role in establishing offices in Nairobi and Bangkok. Both offices were opened in 1963; Mr. Conway joined the foundation in 1998.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sports of The Times; A Different End If the Red Sox Were Involved
description: In the end, the bottom line on Andy Pettitte's startling departure to the Houston Astros was that George Steinbrenner, who usually keeps adjusting the bottom line of the Yankee payroll higher and higher toward $200 million, thought the team's best pitcher was not worth the last-minute, four-year, $52 million counterproposal from Pettitte's agents as long as he was joining a National League team. And not the rival Red Sox.

title: Dean at Yale Is Named President of Duke
description: Duke University announced today that its next president would be Richard H. Brodhead, a 56-year-old Yale English professor and dean of Yale College. He will succeed Nannerl O. Keohane, 63, who will step down on July 1 after 11 years.

title: Lieberman Is Working To Capitalize On Sympathy
description: On Tuesday morning, as Al Gore announced his endorsement of Howard Dean, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut was at Logan International Airport in Boston, surrounded by aides still working out the details of their response to the setback. As he passed through the terminal, a man shouted, ''Give them hell, Joe!'' Two more people offered their support as well.

description: Virginia Indicts Two Men Under New Spam Law

title: For Those Daring Young Men In Their Flying Machines
description: On Dec. 17, 1903, Wilbur and Orville Wright, who were natives of Ohio, first took flight in a machine of their invention. On Tuesday night the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company, one of Ohio's finest dance troupes, landed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music as the final attraction of this year's Next Wave Festival.

title: Sullivan County Woman Denies She Killed 3 Infants
description: The voice on the police audiotape played on Thursday in the Sullivan County Courthouse was Diane Odell's, who is accused of murdering three of her children in the 1980's and transporting the infants' corpses around the country for a decade or more before abandoning them in an Arizona storage shed.

title: Terry Winters
description: Matthew Marks Gallery

title: Thomas Nozkowski
description: Max Protetch Gallery

title: A Home Away From Home
description: SO long dorm rooms. Real estate agents in college towns across the country report that more parents are buying places for their children to live in while they are in school. Page 3.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Port Authority Budget Is Approved on Schedule
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, still hindered by a less-than-robust regional economy and the demands of rebuilding and heightened security after the Sept. 11 terror attack, approved a $4.5 billion budget yesterday that board members said was little changed from spending levels last year and the year before.

title: When an Artist's Eye Guides a Museum Show
description: Museums should make a habit of inviting artists to sift through their permanent collections and organize exhibitions. Such shows cast collections in new and sometimes strange lights. They show artists thinking outside the box of their own work; that is, being more overt and demonstrative. And they usually provide valuable antidotes to the academic tendencies that too often hobble exhibitions of contemporary art.

title: Stringer Estate Must Repay Vikings
description: The estate of Korey Stringer, the offensive tackle for the Minnesota Vikings who collapsed and died two years ago from the heat during a training camp practice, must repay the team and other defendants about $47,000 in legal expenses, Hennepin County District Judge Gary Larson ruled this week.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Dec. 3 about the television and film director Earl Bellamy included one credit erroneously. The assistant director of the movie ''The Talk of the Town'' was Norman Deming. The obituary also misidentified the star of ''Seminole Uprising,'' the first feature film Mr. Bellamy directed. It was George Montgomery, not George Raft.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: AMTRAK WALKOUT GETS LEGAL NOD A federal judge ruled that Amtrak's unions could legally halt work for one day to press for improved financing for the railroad. But the unions have not decided if they will strike. Six unions had planned to strike on Oct. 3, but agreed with management to delay until the decision. In November, House and Senate negotiators agreed on spending of $1.2 billion for one year for the railroad. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Haunted by War Crimes
description: Charlotte Rampling and Michael Caine, left, star in ''The Statement,'' a thriller in which Mr. Caine plays a former French Vichy officer on the run for war crimes. The film, writes Stephen Holden, ''gives character development a distant back seat'' to the ''mechanics of its formulaic plot.''

title: St. John's Expects Tough Semifinal Match
description: The losers get to sleep in. The winners have to wake up early.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Police Arrest 13 In Outlawed Islamic Group
description: The police arrested 13 members of the banned political Islamic group, the Muslim Brotherhood. Their lawyer, Abdel Monaem Abdel Maqsoud, said that they were arrested from different parts of the country and were doctors, engineers and teachers. It was the second such sweep in a week. On Tuesday 23 members, 12 of them were university students, were arrested in Fayoum, southwest of Cairo. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: As Election Nears, Another Actor Woos Filipinos
description: When Efren Lacorte lost his job as a welder in a machine shop three years ago, he had second thoughts about having voted for Joseph Estrada, his favorite movie actor, as president.

title: Afghan President Confident About Keeping Taliban at Bay
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Dec. 12  President Hamid Karzai, appearing relaxed on the eve of a historic constitutional convention here, dismissed the gradually intensifying Taliban insurgency in southern and eastern Afghanistan in an interview today at his American-guarded presidential palace.

title: A Deliberate Debacle
description: James Baker sets off to negotiate Iraqi debt forgiveness with our estranged allies. And at that very moment the deputy secretary of defense releases a ''Determination and Findings'' on reconstruction contracts that not only excludes those allies from bidding, but does so with highly offensive language. What's going on?

title: Osijek Journal; A Homeless Veteran's Sad Plight in Near-Feudal Croatia
description: With a cigarette in one hand and a plastic bag containing his possessions in the other, Branko Markan stares at what used to be his ramshackle home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOLCES, DAVID JAY
description: TOLCES--David Jay. A retired dentist and avid photographer, died on December 6, 2003. He was 72. Survived by his sister, Bette Lane. A private memorial gathering will be held in January. Condolences can be sent to: www.simpsongaus.com

title: Bush Defends Barring Nations From Iraq Deals
description: President Bush on Thursday defended his policy of barring France, Germany, Russia and other nations from $18.6 billion in American-financed Iraqi reconstruction projects. But despite the anger the policy has aroused in foreign capitals, he said his personal envoy, James A. Baker III, would still meet with the leaders of several of those nations to ask that they forgive debts they are owed by Iraq.

title: Jackson Hole Grows Up
description: THE Jackson Hole Mountain Resort in Wyoming long prided itself as the dominatrix of North America's ski areas. By day the resort in the shadow of the Grand Tetons thrilled and bruised its devotees with bucking bronco-rides down runs like the Paintbrush. It dared them to try the mine shaft drop into Corbet's Couloir and cajoled them to doing one more lap on the ski area's 4,139-foot vertical aerial tram.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Pleads Guilty To Internet Indecency
description: A man who was accused of tricking children into logging on to pornographic Web sites pleaded guilty on Wednesday in federal court to 49 counts of using misleading domain names. The man, John Zuccarini, 53, faces up to four years in prison and fines when he is sentenced on Feb. 20. Prosecutors said he registered misspellings or slight variations of 3,000 popular domain names -- www.dinseyland.com, for example -- to entice minors onto pornographic sites. Mr. Zuccarini also pleaded guilty to one count of possessing child pornography, which carries a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOUTHERLAND, ARNOLD
description: SOUTHERLAND -- Arnold. The Trustees, Clergy and staff of The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine mourn the untimely death of Arnold Southerland, longtime Cathedral Security Director. Half of his life was spent at The Cathedral, and he was a treasured member of our family. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Louvenia, his children and the family. Public viewing 9-10AM, funeral service is on Wednesday, December 17, 10:30AM, at The Cathedral. The Rt. Rev. Mark S. Sisk, Episcopal Bishop of NY The Very Rev. Dr. James A. Kowalski, Dean Henry L. King, Esq., Pres.

description: The Frames, Too, Can Be Valuable

title: Who's Scarier: The Hunter or the Hunted?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Evaluating a Conductor, Do the Musicians Know Best?
description: This is not a column about Lorin Maazel. The esteemed music director of the New York Philharmonic has been much written about; that's part of his job description. Some love him; some don't love him quite so much. I myself want to hear more Philharmonic concerts before coming grandly to judgment.

title: Carroll Shelby: Dr. Go-Fast at 80
description: CARROLL SHELBY is excited about the new engine that his company, Carroll Shelby International, is manufacturing, and he wants to hear it hum. The eight-cylinder monster in question, which is called the OX2, is cordoned off in a glass booth at the company's headquarters in Gardena, south of Los Angeles, and is controlled by a console in an adjacent room.

title: Stepping Into Someone's Shoes (Very Expensive Ones, at That)
description: Duncan Roy's ''A K A,'' a British film that opens today in New York, might look at first like a transposition of Patricia Highsmith's ''Talented Mr. Ripley'' to Margaret Thatcher's England.

title: U.S. Soldiers Kill 4 Men in Afghanistan Raid
description: American soldiers killed four men in the eastern town of Jalalabad on Thursday when they raided a house and arrested a powerful commander allied to the government, local officials said. At least two others were wounded.

title: The Real Dean, And the Real Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: Nevada and Part of California May Face Water Shortages
description: Even with the landmark federal agreement in October on use of the Colorado River, millions of residents in Southern California and Nevada face the possibility of sharp cuts in water supplies in about a year, the Bush administration said on Thursday.

title: Residents Help Banish a Blinking Billboard
description: Across a busy intersection, they startle and distract, and that is the point: 30-by-60-inch electronic billboards, essentially big-screen televisions, that sit above subway entrances and blink, flash and zoom through computer-animated ads.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Cleric Sentenced For Currency Violation
description: A Muslim cleric who prosecutors said was a fund-raiser for an Islamic charity that financed terrorism, was sentenced yesterday to five years and three months in prison. The cleric, Alaa Al-Saadawi of Jersey City, was convicted in July of conspiring to smuggle $659,000 to Egypt in violation of currency-declaration laws. In Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. Al-Saadawi said he had preached that the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks were a crime. Federal prosecutors did not claim during the trial that the cleric had terrorism ties, but said later that he helped terrorists. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Putting a Smiley Face on a Nazi Camp
description: The Holocaust documentary ''Prisoner of Paradise'' is built around a shocking piece of information: that a performer was so consumed by the need to express himself before an audience that he participated in a horrifying lie.

title: Flu Illnesses Are Widespread in 24 States, Official Says
description: Influenza is now causing widespread illness in 24 states, up from 13 a week ago, but may have reached its peak in some states with a high number of cases, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday.

title: Philip Guston
description: David McKee Gallery

title: Europe Creates Military Planning Unit Separate From NATO
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 12 — The leaders of the 15-nation European Union approved a common security strategy on Friday that they said would enable Europe to "share in the responsibility for global security, and in building a better world."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROBERTS, FLORA
description: ROBERTS--Flora December 12, 1998 All of us who miss you, and there are many, find it hard to believe it has been five years. Your vivid presence has not dimmed nor the memories of laughter, adventure, learning, and wisdom you gave us in your unique blend of friend and mentor. There is no one like you, no one to take your place in our minds and hearts, our beloved Flora. Hele

title: Metro Briefing: New York

The powerful labor movement in Quebec is challenging a variety of government proposals, including legislation that would allow for more subcontracting of work to the private sector and the forced merging of some health care unions. Andina, which has halted production because of the strike, accounts for 1.8 percent of global copper output. Antonio Varas, a spokesman for the mine, said he could not confirm the offer but talks were scheduled.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Report Says City Debt Is High But Below Limit
description: New York City's debt burden is twice that of other large cities in the United States, and the cost of repaying it accounts for 15 cents of every dollar the city collects, according to a report released yesterday by Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. Nonetheless, the report said that the city's level of indebtedness, although high, is still $8.5 billion below the legal limit of $40 billion. Municipal debt in New York, which pays for capital projects like school construction and bridge repairs, totaled $5,645 per resident in the fiscal year that ended in June, a 127 percent increase since 1990, the report said. By comparison, per capita debt was $3,600 in Chicago, $1,700 in Los Angeles and $1,400 in Boston.

Comcast also agreed to show Tribune's Superstation WGN in more homes. Comcast now owns 99 percent of the Golf Channel and is investing more in networks to run on its cable systems, which serve 21 million subscribers.

title: Rebels Who Saw the World As Being Too Full of Objects
description: Superstudio was the name not of a 60's rock band but of a group of five young architects based in Florence, Italy, who joined together in 1966 to practice ''radical architecture,'' a trend that bloomed internationally in the decade of youthful rebellion. Ant Farm in the United States, Archigram in England, and in Italy, where the movement found particularly fertile ground, Gruppo 9999 and Archizoom: these and other collectives drew variously on Dada, Pop Art, hippie culture, science fiction and utopian traditions in the interest of shaking up, if not totally razing, established architectural theories and practices. Few actual buildings were realized, but the ideas generated about the politics, economics and environmental impact of architecture still reverberate.

title: PENNIE & EDMONDS SAYS IT IS BEING ACQUIRED BY JONES DAY
description: Most of the lawyers at Pennie & Edmonds, a 120-year-old New York firm that specializes in intellectual property law, will soon join Jones Day, a 2,000-lawyer firm that has its largest offices in Cleveland and Washington. ''We are very far down the road on consummating a transaction with Jones Day,'' John J. Normile, the managing partner of Pennie & Edmonds, said yesterday. ''When the transaction is done, Pennie & Edmonds will be closing its doors in the sense that we will be becoming Jones Day attorneys.'' The transaction was reported yesterday in The New York Law Journal. Pennie & Edmonds has about 200 lawyers in offices in New York; Palo Alto, Calif.; San Diego; and Washington, according to the firm's Web site. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Says Profit More Than Doubles
description: Adobe Systems, the maker of Photoshop and Illustrator graphic-design software, said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit more than doubled as designers and businesses bought more of its software. Net income climbed to $83.3 million, or 34 cents a share, in the period ended Nov. 28. This compares with $40.1 million, or 17 cents, in the year-earlier period. Sales rose 22 percent to $358.6 million from $294.7 million, the company reported after markets closed yesterday. Sales have climbed for five consecutive quarters, and net income has increased for six. Advertising companies, who use Adobe's software to design their campaigns, said ad spending might increase 6.9 percent in 2004, spurred in part by marketing related to the Summer Olympics; that would be the biggest jump since 2001. In last year's fourth quarter, Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., said advertisers spent no money on new software. In after-hours trading, shares of Adobe rose as much as $2.31, to $42.09. The stock ended the regular trading session at $39.78. In October, Adobe shipped a new set of software programs for the design and publishing fields called Creative Suite. Analysts have said users will wait to examine the new products before buying, which could slow the rate of sales growth.

title: Cutting James Baker's Ties
description: Last week, the White House summoned James Baker III, the Bush family's persuader of last resort, back to public service. His new portfolio is the diplomatically ticklish and economically crucial problem of restructuring Iraq's currently unpayable official debts. As a former secretary of both the State and Treasury Departments and a public and private Middle East deal maker, he is in many ways a supremely qualified choice. Yet as it stands right now, Mr. Baker is far too tangled in a matrix of lucrative private business relationships that leave him looking like a potentially interested party in any debt-restructuring formula. The obvious solution is for him to sever his ties to all firms doing work directly or indirectly related to Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Fund Proposed
description: The ruling Liberal Democratic Party is considering a proposal for setting aside 2 trillion yen ($18.5 billion) to help ailing banks before they fail. The funds would be used to help banks that are still meeting a minimum capital standard but are in need of help strengthening their balance sheets. The proposal comes on the heels of the nationalization of Ashikaga Bank, one of the nation's biggest regional lenders, and would allow the government to inject funds into banks in return for preferred shares.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Standard Chartered Outlook
description: The British banking group Standard Chartered said that 2003 pretax profit would beat analysts' expectations of $1.45 billion. Growth in earnings per share for the year is expected to be 15 to 20 percent. An economic turnaround in Hong Kong, growth in consumer banking and improving returns in wholesale banking are contributing to the improved profits, the bank said. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Ruling On Governor's Power Over Budget
description: The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, lost the latest round yesterday in a long-running legal battle over how much power the governor should have over the state budget. A five-judge Appellate Division panel ruled that the Legislature had illegally tried to limit how the governor could spend money appropriated in the 1998 budget. Mr. Silver said he would appeal the decision to the state's highest court, while Gov. George E. Pataki hailed the decision as an affirmation of his powers. At issue is the governor's practice of inserting changes to current law into descriptions of appropriations, which the state's Constitution says the Legislature cannot change. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Blacks Buy Newsprint Stake
description: Anglo American, the mining company, plans to sell half of its 1.1 billion rand ($170 million) South African newsprint unit to black investors, mostly a group led by a former politician, Cyril Ramaphosa. The unit's 322 employees produce 220,000 metric tons of paper a year at a mill in Merebank, near Durban. Andrew Thompson, chief executive of the unit that holds the newsprint business, Mondi South Africa, said the unit supplied 60 percent of South Africa's newsprint and ran plantations to supply the mill. The newsprint business represents about 10 percent of Mondi South Africa. MCI Resources Ltd., controlled by Mr. Ramaphosa, will buy 42 percent of the unit and a further 8 percent is set aside for other black investors like employees and local communities. Mr. Ramaphosa, above, founded South Africa's biggest labor union, the National Union of Mineworkers, and helped negotiate South Africa's first all-race elections in 1994.
