title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RYAN, EILEEN B. (NEE SULLIVAN)
description: RYAN--Eileen B. (nee Sullivan), died Tuesday, December 10, 2003 at her home in Millbrook, New York, from complications related to lung cancer. She was 89. Fondly referred to by her grandchildren, nieces and nephews as ''Zsa Zsa'', she was well known for her wit and humor. When she was asked by hospice what music she would like played at her funeral, she said, ''A Good Man Is Hard To Find.'' She was born, raised and a long-time resident of the Bronx. She leaves behind a legacy of unwavering love and support, generosity and humor. She will be deeply missed by her son, Robert, of Orangesburg, N.Y., daughter, Regina, of Boston, MA, and three grandchildren. Visiting hours are Friday, 2-4 and 79PM at the Moritz Funeral Home, 98 Rte 303, Tappan, N.Y. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Saturday, 9:15AM, at St. Catharine's R.C. Church, Blauvelt, N.Y. She will be buried next to Roger, her beloved husband of 61 years at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-the-Hudson, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to Seavey Joyce S.J. Community Service Award, 936 Nantasket Avenue, Hull, MA 02045

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Kidnapped Boy Freed After Three Years
description: Dzhamal Gamidov, an 11-year-old boy who was held captive for three and a half years and now weighs just 33 pounds, was found by chance in Dagestan, a republic in southern Russia, by police officers who were searching for killers in an unrelated case. Television broadcast harrowing images of the boy in captivity, crying for his mother. A police official who heads the antikidnapping unit was arrested in the case, the Interfax news agency reported. The kidnappers had demanded more than $1 million in ransom, Dagestan's interior minister told The Associated Press. The boy's father, Gamid, was Dagestan's finance minister in 1977 when he was killed when a bomb exploded in his ministry. Dagestan, which borders Chechnya, has been plagued with kidnappings in recent years. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: A Cacophony of Arty Funk, Drawn Together by a Dance Beat
description: The first rule for an arty funk band is that the funk comes first, and the Rapture knows it. Its songs are built on the splintered sounds that post-punks and minimalists selected to parry rock's opulence as the 1970's ended: high, hollow guitar chords or isolated notes; two-finger keyboard fragments; discordant trills or nagging repeated notes for saxophone; tinny, deliberately artificial drum-machine sounds. The Rapture's two singers, Luke Jenner on guitar and Mattie Safer on bass, have high, pinched voices that are pretty only with an effort.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about President Bush's meeting with King Abdullah of Jordan misstated the effect that an unofficial peace plan drafted by Israelis and Palestinians, known as the Geneva plan, would have on Israeli settlements. Under that plan, Israel would give up most of the settlements in the West Bank, not keep them. But since the 400,000 Israelis in the West Bank and Jerusalem are concentrated in a few settlements and neighborhoods that Israel would keep under the plan, about 300,000 settlers would remain where they live.

title: The Shortage of Flu Vaccines
description: The United States is in the opening stages of what looks like a severe flu season this winter, yet it has far less vaccine on hand than was available last year to combat a relatively mild epidemic. The manufacturers misjudged how many doses they would be able to sell and thus found themselves short when a variety of factors conspired to drive up demand beyond expectations. As federal officials scramble to find additional supplies, they must also find ways to avoid a repeat of this year's shortfalls.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Nov. 26 about David Stern III, a newspaper publisher who wrote the novel ''Francis, the Talking Mule,'' misidentified the star of ''Francis in the Haunted House,'' the last movie inspired by the book. He was Mickey Rooney. (Donald O'Connor starred in the earlier ''Francis'' movies.)

title: Leathernecks Plan to Use A Velvet Glove in Iraq
description: No force has a tougher reputation than the United States Marines. But the marines who are headed to Iraq this spring say they intend to avoid the get-tough tactics that have been used in recent weeks by Army units.

title: Chief of State Parole Board Is Reassigned
description: The chairman of the New York State Board of Parole was assigned to a different job in the state government yesterday, according to a Parole Board spokesman.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a report by federal regulators on improper accounting at Freddie Mac included a Wall Street firm erroneously among those linked to improper transactions. While J. P. Morgan Chase participated in deals with Freddie Mac, the report did not say those transactions were part of the improper accounting.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Verisity To Acquire Axis Systems For $80 Million
description: Verisity, which makes software used to design computer chips, agreed to buy Axis Systems yesterday for about $80 million in cash and stock to improve the performance of its products. Axis has 90 employees and revenue was more than $20 million for the year ended July 31. The purchase will be completed in the first quarter, according to Verisity, which is based in Mountain View, Calif. Axis Systems, which is closely held and based in Sunnyvale, Calif., counts Sun Microsystems and I.B.M. among its customers. Axis Systems' ReConfigurable Computing technology simulates hardware and software to test for potential problems. Verisity's customers include Avaya and National Semiconductor. The Axis Systems purchase was announced after markets closed yesterday. Earlier in the day, Verisity shares fell 10 cents, to $12.50.

title: A Pragmatic Eye on the Downtown Site Plan
description: FAME is what Daniel Libeskind, the big winner in the urban reality sweepstakes to anoint a lead architect for the resurrection of the World Trade Center, is basking in or suffering through, depending on his appetite for cutting a high-profile swath by creating world-class architecture from a disaster. Resignation is almost what Bruce S. Fowle, a prominent yet low-key peer -- no kooky glasses, no silly scarf, no gel on the cranium or speckled beard -- is feeling as the towers grow taller and clunkier and the planning ordeal crawls on. But not quite.

title: Shift by China Might Not Aid U.S. Industry, Fed Chief Says
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said on Thursday that American manufacturers may not benefit much if China permits its currency to rise in value against the dollar.

description: Gregor Schneider

title: Injured Devils Are Hoping To Be Healthy for Flyers
description: Devils center John Madden was hit in the face with a puck Wednesday night. He had stitches under his right eye and on his nose. The flesh around his right eye was swollen and purplish. He peered from a slit.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in the Vital Signs column of Science Times on Tuesday about a British study finding that few people with severe allergies know how to use the injectable epinephrine devices found in many public places misstated a Web address with instructions. It is www.foodallergy.org (not .com).

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Nov. 27 about the use of computer scanners in a survey to develop new standard apparel sizes misstated the percentage of women who met the definition of misses' size 8, and it described the criterion incompletely. The survey found that fewer than 10 percent of those with a size 8 bust, not 10 percent of all the women surveyed, fitted the existing size 8 standard -- that is, corresponded in all three measurements (bust, waist and hips).

title: A Pampered Day on the Slopes
description: THE regular season at the Jackson Hole Mountain Resort begins on Dec. 20. Lift tickets are $64 a day, with discounts for multiple days. One-day adult ski rentals start at $26.50 for skis, boots and poles. One of the best times to go is late February or early March, when the snow is more likely to be good and high temperatures are usually in the 30's.

title: A Frenchman on the Run From His Vichy Past
description: A cat-and-mouse thriller with delusions of grandeur, ''The Statement'' arrives wrapped in an intimidating mystique of high-minded solemnity that makes its vagueness and incoherence all the more disappointing when the pieces don't add up. Adapted by Ronald Harwood (the screenwriter for ''The Pianist'') from Brian Moore's best-selling novel and directed by Norman Jewison (''The Hurricane''), the movie has a blue-ribbon cast led by Michael Caine, Tilda Swinton and Jeremy Northam. Charlotte Rampling and Alan Bates put in cameo appearances.

title: Weep, and the World Laughs Hysterically
description: About two-thirds of the way through ''Something's Gotta Give,'' Diane Keaton bursts into tears. Her character, a divorced, middle-aged playwright named Erica Barry, has seen her quiet life of professional fulfillment and romantic disappointment unexpectedly disrupted by love and then, in short order, by heartbreak. Erica's sobs, sniffles and wails seem endless and uncontrollable, expressing every conceivable combination of hurt, humiliation and anger. Her crying jag, which seems to last for several months, continues without interruption through a half-dozen cuts and scene changes, carrying Erica through nearly every room in her large, airy East Hampton beach house.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm like a fish out of water. They've never run across anything like me. I mean, a guy like me running for the presidency? I've never run for anything.''

title: A Perennial Coaching Candidate Warms to L.S.U.
description: While the plane was idling at Teterboro Airport on Tuesday, Nick Saban looked around at the weather he has not missed for a minute in his four Sunbelt seasons as football coach at Louisiana State. He peered out at the aftermath of the weekend's snowstorm, growing more and more impatient as the plane was forced to wait for an available gate. An hour passed. Saban's cellphone died.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Emigrant Bank In Buyout Deal
description: Consolidating its control of one of the largest privately owned banks in the country, the family of Paul Milstein paid $811 million on Wednesday to buy out its minority partners in Emigrant Savings Bank. The deal was the final step in an agreement resolving a bitter, long-running dispute within the Milstein family. Howard P. Milstein, Paul's son, will remain as chairman of the $10 billion institution, which has 36 branches in the New York area. The minority partners -- who included Max Fisher, Oded Aboodi, David Wallace and the family of Seymour Milstein -- had owned a 45 percent stake. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

description: MILENBACH -- Burton. The most wonderful man in the world has just died in his sleep. Burton Milenbach, PhD, has been a lifelong resident of NYC and a clinical psychologist all his adult life. He will be terribly missed by his beloved companion of 11 years, Abbe Franklin, as well as by his daughter Rachel, his son Julian, Julian's wife Ann and her son Ben. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Sunday, December 14.

title: Ban Religious Attire in School, French Panel Says
description: A report delivered to President Jacques Chirac on Thursday called for a new law banning the wearing of ''conspicuous'' religious symbols in French public schools -- large crosses for Christians, head scarves for Muslim girls, or skullcaps for Jewish boys.

title: U.S. General Says Coalition Is Choking Funds to Insurgency
description: TIKRIT, Iraq, Dec. 11  The United States general commanding operations in Saddam Hussein's ancestral homeland says that American forces have dealt a damaging blow to the insurgency in this pivotal region of Iraq in the past 30 days by choking off much of the guerrillas' financing and arms supplies. But he also acknowledges that the occupation still faces huge challenges, including suicide bombings and the training and equipping of new Iraqi police officers and militia.

title: NASA Plans Wing Sensors for Shuttle to Detect Hits by Debris
description: NASA intends to line the wings of its space shuttles with sensors to detect hits by debris or other objects during flights, an agency advisory committee said on Thursday.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Running Mate
description: President Chen Shui-bian said that his vice president, Annette Lu, would again be his running mate in the March 20 election. A group of moderate lawmakers from Mr. Chen's Democratic Progressive Party had urged him to choose someone else, contending that he would lose votes in a close race by retaining Ms. Lu, an outspoken advocate of greater independence from China. But some analysts have suggested that Mr. Chen may feel less need to adopt pro-independence positions himself as long as Ms. Lu's presence reassures hard-liners in his party. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Creatures In Torment Seek Their True Nature
description: Nowadays the choreographer Marie Chouinard from Montreal is apt to garner international prizes, including a Performing Arts Award from the Governor General of Canada. Gone are her images of early revolt: no more retching or urinating before an audience or, as in her brilliant gloss on Nijinsky's ''Afternoon of a Faun,'' pasting a phallus onto a female body.

description: The Bush administration has been considering a plan to change how certain duties on steel imports are calculated, which would give new protection to American steel makers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIGLER, LLOYD E.
description: RIGLER--Lloyd E. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society are deeply saddened by the loss of Lloyd E. Rigler of Burbank, CA. A generous and steadfast friend, he became a Technion Guardian, achieving the highest level of commitment to the American Technion Society, the Technion and Israel. He established the Lloyd Rigler Sleep Research Fund, which supports the work of the Technion's world-renowned sleep research scientist, Prof. Peretz Lavie. A successful entrepreneur, he and his business partner Lawrence E. Deutsch made their fortune as founders of Adolf's Meat Tenderizer. They provided major support for the arts, including institutions such as the New York City Opera and Carnegie Hall, and created the Classic Arts Showcase, a public television program to stimulate interest in the arts, through the Lloyd Rigler and Lawrence E. Deutsch Foundation. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mr. Rigler's nephew, Jamie Rigler, sister Audre Estrin and the entire Rigler family. title: In Too-Tall Grass, Huntington Sees a Law Violated
description: Over seven decades, Robert Vance slogged through Korea as a machine gunner and sniper, sold Christmas trees and saw the world, but he said he had never been arrested until he ran afoul of his town's littering codes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Mistrial In Hostos Student Case
description: The trial of a Bronx college student charged with assault was declared a mistrial on Wednesday as the student's lawyer announced in court that he was not competent to represent his client. The student, Miguel Malo, 33, was on trial in Bronx Criminal Court for assaulting two security officers at Hostos Community College in August 2001 in a case that many professors at Hostos and the City University of New York, its umbrella institution, have said reflects a ''police state'' atmosphere at the college. Ronald B. McGuire, Mr. Malo's lawyer, asked for a mistrial, and Justice Robert Torres agreed. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Shootings Upset Sniper Suspect, Jury Is Told
description: After shooting one young woman in the face at point-blank range last year in Tacoma, Wash., Lee Malvo was so upset that he defecated in his pants, a psychiatrist told the jury this week at Mr. Malvo's trial on charges related to the sniper attacks around Washington, D.C.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Amtrak Walkout Gets Legal Nod
description: A federal judge ruled that Amtrak's unions could legally halt work for one day to press for improved financing for the railroad. But the unions have not decided if they will strike. Six unions had planned to strike on Oct. 3, but agreed with management to delay until the decision. In November, House and Senate negotiators agreed on spending of $1.2 billion for one year for the railroad. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Investor Money Still Flowing Into Russia
description: Russia's foreign currency and reserves rose last week to $70.6 billion, the Russian central bank said on Thursday, the fourth consecutive weekly gain and a sign that investor confidence in the country remains high despite the turmoil surrounding Yukos, the country's largest oil company.

title: Tracking American Christmas
description: THERE was a time before Bratz dolls, maxed-out credit cards and criminal background checks for mall Santas, when Christmas was celebrated more gently. In fact, the roots of Christmas traditions in the United States are to be found in New York, in the towns of the Hudson Valley, where early the Dutch and English settlers brought with them their native holiday customs, and what developed was an amalgam of heritages, which ultimately formed distinctly American traditions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHPEARL, ROCHELLE
description: ROTHPEARL--Rochelle. Age 92, musician, beloved mother and grandmother, died in her home on Wednesday, December 10, 2003 in Floral Park, NY. She was born on September 9, 1911 in Zaparosia, Ukraine/Russia, to the late Bessie and Elias Kritchmar. She emigrated to the USA in her pre-teen years with her parents and spent her early adult years as a featured pianist with Phil Spitalny's All Girl Orchestra, before marrying and having four children. She was the last survivor of her immediate family of two sisters and one brother Rose, Toni, and Irving, and leaves behind four children Sandra, Elliot, Susan and Allen, 10 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. She died peacefully surrounded by loved ones and her music. Funeral services Friday December 12, 2003 at 12 Noon at Riverside--Nassau North Chapels, 55 No. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. The family asks that donations be made to Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590.

description: BRONITSKY--Frances. April 28, 1909-November 27, 2003. Of Forest Hills, NY. Adored wife of sixty years of Jesse. Beloved mother of Gerald, Leonard (Debbie) and Madelyn (Sam Gelbtuch). Dear grandmother of Molly and Max Bronitsky, Daniel, Ruth, and Gabriel Gelbtuch. Sister of Rose Baumgarten. Admired kindergarten teacher, PS 196, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: In Milwaukee, a Bookkeeping Brouhaha
description: The sign on West Bluemound Road advertises the place as ''Milwaukee's Oldest Custard Stand, Since 1938.'' For decades, the unpretentious Gilles Frozen Custard has been the favorite lunch stop for baseball's commissioner, Bud Selig, a place where he can grab a hot dog and gab about the team closest to his heart, the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Partying Like It's 1750
description: A TRIP up the Hudson Valley to the towns of the early settlers is a step back in time to the birthplace of the American Christmas. Early arrivals, particularly the Dutch and the English, brought with them their native holiday customs, and what developed was an amalgam of heritages, which ultimately formed new and distinct traditions. Several historic homesteads are decorated for the holidays and open to the public. Page 2.

description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi and his counterparts from Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines agreed to start separate bilateral talks on free trade agreements. Japan is trying to form its own relationships with the countries to counteract deals made by China, India and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Korean Art Finally Gets To Shine
description: The 15-inch-high Avalokiteshvara, right, a gilt bronze figure from 14th-century Korea, is in ''Goryeo Dynasty'' at the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco. The show, with an accompanying one of contemporary Korean art, inaugurates the museum's new home.

title: 36 Hours | Amelia Island, Fla.
description: VISITORS to Amelia Island, just north of Jacksonville, can easily spend a long weekend sitting around the pool or playing tennis and golf at one of the island's high-end resorts. But that would mean missing out on the island's history: Europeans first settled there in the 1500's, and by the early 1800's it had become what President James Monroe called a ''festering fleshpot'' filled with pirates, smugglers and illegal slave traders. A more licit golden age in the 1870's, when it first became a tourist destination, left the island's main town, Fernandina Beach, filled with Victorian houses with gabled roofs, elaborate verandas and widow's walks. Oh, and then there are the 13 miles of white sand beach. AMY VIRSHUP

But tomorrow, when the Jets meet the Pittsburgh Steelers at Giants Stadium, Glenn will start for the first time in his three-year N.F.L. career, filling in for the injured linebacker Sam Cowart.

There were general managers, managers, assistant general managers, scouts, trainers, traveling secretaries and public-relations officials walking, talking and happily participating in one of the routine off-season events in the baseball business.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Section Of Berlin Wall Is Sold
description: A 33-yard-long, grafitti-marked stretch of the Berlin Wall, one of the last remaining sections of the wall that once divided the city, was sold at auction to an anonymous buyer for $212,000. The section is set on a 7,000-square-foot vacant plot near the Nordbahnhof train station that comes with building permission. But under the terms of the sale, the wall cannot be painted, moved or torn down. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: City Council Moves Forward With Lead Paint Legislation

description: Even as they celebrate their victory in the Supreme Court on campaign finance, lawmakers and advocacy groups are pressing for more changes in election law like updating the presidential public financing system and revamping the Federal Election Commission.

description: Over-the-top business parties may just now be making a comeback in New York, but in Houston, the trial lawyer W. Mark Lanier's holiday gala has never missed a beat.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Fishermen Indicted For Fraud
description: A grand jury has indicted four fishermen for defrauding a lobster restoration program developed after a 1996 oil spill that killed nearly eight million lobsters in Rhode Island Sound. Each lobsterman is accused of making more than $500 by falsely claiming he protected female lobsters. Under the program, which ended in June, lobstermen returned to the sea more than one million female lobsters, allowing them time to produce more eggs. Fishermen were paid for the number of lobsters they returned to the sea under an honor system. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: AMERITRADE IS EXPECTING RECORD EARNINGS
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation, the discount broker, said it expected record earnings this quarter and next fiscal year as new accounts, trading and commissions climb beyond its previous forecast. Ameritrade, based in Omaha, said it would earn 14 cents to 17 cents a share this quarter, revising its earlier forecast of 8 cents to 15 cents a share. Ameritrade said customer trades rose 6 percent in November from October to an average of 180,000 a day while it added 15,000 net new accounts. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial estimated before today's announcement that Ameritrade would earn 14 cents a share this quarter. Shares of Ameritrade rose 73 cents, or 6 percent, to $12.97 a share.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Salmon Set Record At Dam
description: This year a record number of chinook salmon passed through the Bonneville Dam on their way up the Columbia River to spawn, federal fishery officials say. While the majority of the fish, about 80 percent, were hatchery-reared as opposed to endangered wild fish, the 920,000 chinook were more than twice the 10-year average. Increased salmon runs in the Columbia are generally attributed to ocean conditions. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO CLIMBS. The dollar hit a new low against the euro on comments from Treasury Secretary John W. Snow that the market should set the value of the dollar. In New York, the euro settled at $1.2288 from $1.2189 on Thurday.

title: Iranian Rebels Urge Pentagon Not to Let Iraq Expel Them

title: Sports of The Times; LeBron's Legacy? Tune In To Find Out
description: SEBASTIAN TELFAIR stepped up at Fordham University on Thursday night while Rick Pitino dropped in. With a controlled but blinding quickness, Telfair, the point guard from Brooklyn's Lincoln High School, had fewer points but more polish than his rival, Darius Washington, of Edgewater High School of Orlando, Fla. Resplendent in a dark, pinstriped suit, Pitino got to see what opponents of his Louisville program might be in store for and got to be seen by all those viewers dreaming of their very own ESPN time slot,  la LeBron.

description: The Dusan Tynek Dance Theater made a pleasant debut with "Debut" on Dec. 6 at the Kitchen. This first full-scale program by a young Czech-born choreographer had its weaknesses, but it remained strong enough to arouse curiosity about what Mr. Tynek will create next.

But he also acknowledges that the occupation still faces huge challenges, from suicide bombings to training and equipping new Iraqi police officers and militia members.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: New Premier Takes Over
description: Paul Martin, a former finance minister, was sworn in as prime minister, replacing Jean Chrtien, who retired after 10 years in office. A moderate member of Parliament from Montreal, Mr. Martin has pledged to improve the government's ethical conduct and be more responsive to the public will. He has also pledged to improve the tone of relations with the United States. Mr. Martin has reshuffled the cabinet, putting an unusual number of Westerners in top positions. Former Health Minister Anne McLellan, from Alberta, will serve as deputy prime minister. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

Rowland's admission that he gave a false account of the financing of work done on his private cottage may not put him in immediate criminal jeopardy, but coming after years of mounting scandal, the incident has left an indelible stain on his governorship and may make it impossible for him to accomplish anything in his third term, if he completes it, Connecticut politicians and political observers said Friday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Insurer Sells Shares

Investors placed orders for about $80 billion of stock, said bankers who arranged the sale. China Life, which controls about 45 percent of the country's life insurance market, sells policies through a network of 650,000 agents, 8,000 branches and through 78,000 commercial bank branches and post offices.

The company said in a regulatory filing that it had planned to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Monday, using a recovery plan backed by creditors. title: Expat adviser : Ways to acquire a U.S. work visa
description: [Q.]I am a U.S. citizen and have lived and worked in England for about 18 years. My husband is a British citizen. It now appears that we will be moving to the United States within the next year  following a new job for me. I believe that if my husband has a job offer before he moves, his employer-to-be would do some of the work of filing for a work visa. If he comes as a trailing spouse and job hunts after arrival, what happens with his visa status? How long would it likely take for him to obtain a work visa while applying from within the United States, or from Britain before going? Is there anything we can do to make the process simpler or quicker?

title: Sir Mick
description: Given the course of British knighthood, it's probably no surprise to learn that Mick Jagger has been newly dubbed Sir Mick Jagger. But it does provoke a certain sadness. There was a ''sir-ness'' to Sir Paul McCartney long before it became official, an acknowledgment of how much music hall, as well as Beatle, there was in him. Even if there was never as much difference between the Beatles and the Rolling Stones as we liked to believe, they at least stood for different tensions within rock 'n' roll: the difference between the rebellion implicit in a kind of musical ecstasy and rebellion as actual insurrection. The premise of the Rolling Stones was that you couldn't contain them. That has long since ceased to be true, and ''Sir Mick'' proves it.

title: H&R BLOCK SAYS S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING REFUND LOANS
description: H&R Block Inc., the tax preparation company, said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating the company's disclosure of lawsuits stemming from its tax-refund loans. The S.E.C. has begun a formal investigation into company filings before December 2002, said Bob Schneider, an H&R Block spokesman. H&R Block reported a $41.7 million charge in November 2002 to settle a Texas lawsuit over its loans, which advance money to clients while they await a tax refund. The company had not disclosed the case in its previous quarterly filings, and less than three weeks before the settlement said in a statement that it did not expect a material impact from any pending litigation.

title: FIRST COMMONWEALTH TO BUY GA FINANCIAL
description: The First Commonwealth Financial Corporation, which owns banks in western and central Pennsylvania, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy GA Financial in a stock-and-cash transaction valued at $183.2 million, to expand in the Pittsburgh area. Shareholders in GA Financial can receive $35 cash a share or an equivalent amount of First Commonwealth stock, First Commonwealth said. The offer is 22 percent higher than the closing share price of GA on Thursday. First Commonwealth's chief executive, Joseph O'Dell, said in a statement that the purchase was a second step in the company's growth plans for the Pittsburgh area. First Commonwealth completed a $28.5 million acquisition of the Pittsburgh Financial Corporation and its BankPittsburgh branches this week.

COCA-COLA PLANS TO BUY BACK $2 BILLION IN STOCK
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that it planned to buy back at least $2 billion in stock next year, increasing its share repurchase plan by a third as rising sales and a falling dollar help profit. Coca-Cola still expects to increase earnings per share at least 11 percent a year, the company said, without giving a specific forecast. The company said in October that it planned to repurchase $1.5 billion in stock this year. Next year's $2 billion plan would allow Coca-Cola to buy more than 41 million shares at the current price, representing almost 2 percent of outstanding stock.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Web Concern Raises Funds
description: The Softbank Corporation, a leading Japanese provider of high-speed Internet access, sweetened the terms of a 199 billion yen ($1.84 billion) sale of convertible bonds and shares to help ensure demand from investors. The company sold 150 billion yen of bonds convertible into its shares, and 49 billion yen of new shares. It cut the price at which investors can convert the bonds, and gave a bigger discount for the shares than it had planned, bankers said. Softbank, which is controlled by billionaire Masayoshi Son, needs funds to pay debt that rose to 336.1 billion yen as of Sept. 30 after the company invested in broadband Internet services. Softbank shares fell by the daily 500 yen limit after the sales.

title: Mayor Accepts Blame for Lag In Suspensions

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: EYE FOR AN EYE, JUDGE RULES A judge in Punjab Province sentenced a man to be blinded by acid after he was found guilty of doing the same to his fiancee. The judge ordered that a doctor carry out the punishment publicly at a sports stadium."This is an Islamic way of doing justice," the judge said. The defendant is likely to appeal his conviction and sentence, the police said. (AP)

title: Working in France : Tax relief in sight for expats
description: PARIS  One of the great perks of working overseas for an international company is the extra income conferred by an expat package. As compensation for the pain of relocation, employers typically reward their expatriate workers with inflated salaries that can sometimes nearly double what they would make at home.

description: HEINBERG -- Seymour. Be loved husband of Beatrice. Devoted father of the late Sue Stetzer and Marshall Heinberg. Loving grandfather of Jenny and Molly Stetzer and Sophie and Simon Heinberg. Services at 12 noon, Sunday, 12/14 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 1311 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY 10605.

title: PAPA JOHN'S, A PIZZA CHAIN, EXPECTS EARNINGS TO RISE
description: Papa John's International, the pizza chain, expects 2004 earnings to rise to $2.20 to $2.28 a share, as changes made at its restaurants begin to increase sales. Papa John's, based in Louisville, Ky., expects to earn $1.84 to $1.90 a share in 2003, excluding costs related to an accounting change. Papa John's has improved service at its 2,796 restaurants by increasing employees' hours and increasing some managers' pay, a spokesman, David Flanery, said. The projection was well above the $2.08 a share expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Shares of Papa John's rose $1.13, to $32.33 a share.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Lewis M. Allen, a theater and film producer, misidentified a Tony Award won by his production of ''Annie.'' It was for best musical, not best play. The obituary also included a credit erroneously. The producer of the play ''The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie'' was Robert Whitehead.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Banned From Campaigning
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal ordered Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, to stop campaigning for a seat in the Serbian Parliament. He is a candidate of the Socialist Party in elections Dec. 28. The court put the same gag order on a fellow inmate, Vojislav Seselj, the leader of the nationalist Radical Party. Both men violated a ban on communicating with the media and misused telephones at the United Nations detention center by spreading political messages, the court said. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Rises
description: Industrial output in India increased 5.4 percent in October, bolstered by consumer demand for goods like televisions and refrigerators. The rate of growth slowed, however, from the 7.0 percent recorded a year earlier. The manufacturing sector grew 6.2 percent, compared with 7.3 percent a year ago, but the mining and electricity sectors slumped. Industrial activity accounts for less than a third of India's gross domestic product but contributes significantly to government revenue. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: H.A. Aliyev, K.G.B. Officer And Azeri Leader, 80, Dies
description: Heydar Aliyev, a former Soviet secret police general who for 30 years ruled his native Azerbaijan with an iron fist, first as its Communist leader, then as elected president after independence, died yesterday at a clinic in Cleveland, where he had been treated for congestive heart failure since early August. His death was confirmed by Tahir Taghi-Zadeh, a political counsellor at Azerbaijan's embassy in Washington, Reuters reported.

title: STANLEY WORKS TO PURCHASE CHICAGO STEEL TAPE
description: Stanley Works, the largest maker of hand tools, agreed to purchase the Chicago Steel Tape Company and related assets and affiliated companies collectively known as CST/Berger for $62 million. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter. Stanley Works wants to add products used by professional surveyors, the company said. Stanley Works said on Monday that it was selling its home-door business to the Masonite International Corporation for $160 million. The purchase of CST/Berger will make up for about 35 percent of the revenue and 50 percent of the profit that Stanley Works will lose by selling the door business.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Pension Curbs Pass
description: Brazil's Senate gave final congressional approval to President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva's legislation curbing public employees' pensions, a measure that he has called critical to narrowing the country's budget deficit. The Senate approved the legislation, which raises the retirement age for federal workers and forces them to finance a bigger share of their own pensions, in a 51-to-24 vote. The changes will save the government about 50 billion reais ($17 billion) over the next 18 years, according to the social security minister, Ricardo Berzoini. Mr. da Silva had said pension cuts would be critical to bolster investor confidence in Brazil's ability to pay its $400 billion in debt, which is the largest among the world's developing economies.

title: A Fetish Of Candor
description: I think we are all disgusted by the way George W. Bush's administration has allowed honesty and candor to seep into the genteel world of international affairs.

title: Stringer Estate Must Repay Vikings
description: The estate of Korey Stringer, the offensive tackle for the Minnesota Vikings who collapsed and died two years ago from the heat during a training camp practice, must repay the team and other defendants about $47,000 in legal expenses, Hennepin County District Judge Gary Larson ruled this week.

title: WEYERHAEUSER TO SELL TIMBERLAND TO PAY DOWN DEBT
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company agreed to sell 160,000 acres of timberland in western North Carolina and South Carolina to Forest Investment Associates for about $140 million to repay debt. The sale is expected to close by Wednesday, Weyerhaeuser said. Forest Investments, which is based in Atlanta, manages land and timber investments for pension plans and trusts. Weyerhaeuser, which is based in Federal Way, Wash., had long-term debt of $12.1 billion at the end of September, according to its most recent earnings statement. The company said this year that it would sell 344,000 acres in Tennessee and the Carolinas.

title: Our Enemies at Home
description: In April, as Baghdad fell and American soldiers began searching for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq, federal officials uncovered a cache of deadly chemicals much closer to home -- in the eastern Texas town of Noonday. The stockpile included a fully functional sodium cyanide bomb capable of killing hundreds, as well as neo-Nazi and antigovernment literature, illegal weapons, half a million rounds of ammunition, and more than 100 explosives, including bombs disguised as suitcases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANSHEN, RUTH NANDA
description: ANSHEN--Ruth Nanda. Died peacefully and with dignity at her home in New York on December 2nd, 2003, after a long illness, at 103 years of age. Her daughter, Judith Franks and her son-in-law, Hugh Franks survive her. Dr. Ruth Nanda Anshen was a worldrenowned philosopher, author and editor. Dr. Anshen was the author of several books including ''The Anatomy of Evil'', ''Biography of An Idea'', ''Morals Equals Manners'' and ''The Mystery of Consciousness: A Prescription for Human Survival''. She was a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts of London, a member of the American Philosophical Association, the History of Science Society, the International Philosophical Society and the Metaphysical Society of America. In 1958, she established the Anshen-Columbia University Seminars on the Nature of Man, in which many prominent scientists, theologians, writers, artists, world leaders and philosophers participated. A funeral service will be held Wednesday, December 17th, 2003 at 10AM at Woodlawn Cemetery, East 233 St and Webster Ave, Bronx, N.Y 10470. 718-920-0500.

description: GARDINER--James B. Died unexpectedly December 11, at the age of 96. He is survived by his daughter Cynthia of Tucson, AZ and son James of Burlington, VT and three grandchildren. Mr. Gardiner had a long and distinguished career as an actuary with MetLife and the State of NY retiring at 95, and was an active member of many genealogical societies. He loved mountain climbing and math. His unfailing good humor will be missed by all who knew him, and his passing is deeply grieved. Funeral will be private. Memorial donations may be made to People for the American Way, 1460 Broadway, NY, NY 10036.

title: Toward a Final Design
description: Public response has been generally tepid since the eight finalists in the design competition for the 9/11 memorial at ground zero were announced three weeks ago. To a great degree, that may simply be due to scale. The models and renderings of the plans simply do not convey how big the memorial really is or what it would be like to stand in its midst. As the designers refine their ideas and reveal more detail, however, the plans' potential has become more apparent. Some of them could do a masterly job of performing the many services the public has a right to expect from the 9/11 memorial.

title: Property issues : Homeowners in rural Spain lose ground to 'urbanization' law
description: VALENCIA, Spain  A man's home is supposed to be his castle, but hundreds of homeowners in rural villages along Spain's eastern coast, foreign and Spanish, are finding that the principle only applies to 70 percent of their property, sometimes less. The rest is eligible for seizure by towns and development companies to be used for projects that the owners say are expensive and of dubious utility.

title: China Inflation Rate Is Up; Higher Food Prices Cited
description: Rising food prices pushed inflation in China to its fastest pace in more than six years during the 12 months through November, Chinese agencies said on Friday, a day after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned of a risk that the Chinese economy could overheat.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Plans Investments
description: The power supply company E.On said that it planned investments of 13.8 billion euros ($16.9 billion) between now and 2006. The major share of the spending, 8.7 billion euros ($10.6 billion), will be on projects to expand the company's power and natural gas delivery networks and to carry out environmental protection measures at power plants. The company also said that it planned to make acquisitions totaling 5.1 billion euros ($6.2 billion), primarily to increase the stakes it already holds in businesses in Central Europe and Scandinavia. ''These may include investments in natural gas production interests in Russia and the North Sea,'' E.On said in a statement. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: Japanese business executives were far more upbeat in the last quarter than expected, but they are less optimistic about their prospects in the coming year, a central bank survey showed on Friday.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: EX-PENTAGON OFFICIALS SENTENCED Two former top Pentagon officials each were sentenced to 24 years in prison for taking more than $1 million in bribes and accepting prostitutes from government contractors. The two  Robert Lee Neal Jr. and Francis Delano Jones Jr.  were convicted in federal court in July of conspiracy, extortion, money laundering, witness tampering and obstruction of justice. President Bill Clinton appointed Mr. Neal in 1996 as director of the Pentagon office of Small and Disadvantaged Business Utilization, which helps minority-owned businesses obtain contracts. Mr. Jones, his top assistant, joined the office in 1999. (AP)

description: For Giants receiver Tim Carter, a long and painful season has come to an end. For receiver Ike Hilliard, it just gets longer.

title: World Briefing: Europe

The section is set on a 7,000-square-foot vacant plot near the Nordbahnhof train station that comes with building permission. But under the terms of the sale, the wall cannot be painted, moved or torn down.

description: Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill late Friday that would have given thousands of city workers who responded to the Sept. 11 attacks better retirement benefits by allowing them to claim many medical problems that stemmed from the hazardous conditions at the site.

title: Taking a Hard Road For a Nobel Prize
description: Re ''A Doctor's Quixotic Quest for a Nobel Prize,'' [Dec. 7]: As a retired academic I know that all major universities use a candidate's publications to evaluate their research ability and creativity as part of the information needed for making tenure and promotion decisions. Without taking sides in the Damadian controversy with the Nobel Committee, I am positive that Dr. Damadian's publications were a major factor in his being denied a part of the prize. Although Dr. Damadian's paper was published before Dr. Lauterbur's, this may not be significant because many world-class journals have delay periods of two or more years between the time the manuscript is received and the time it is published in the journal. These long delays are due to slow referees returning papers with their critical comments, and the additional time it may take for the authors to make the appropriate revisions.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Theory Is Finished
description: In April, the academic journal Critical Inquiry convened what it called an ''intellectual town meeting'' at the University of Chicago to debate a question that was weighing heavily on the minds of humanities professors across the country. Was it true, the journal wanted to know, that ''the great era of theory'' -- that is, literary and cultural theory -- ''is now behind us''? In the 1970's and 80's, legions of students and professors in humanities departments embraced the view that the world was a ''text'' -- that the personal and political were shaped by language and that literary and cultural critics possessed tools as powerful as those of, say, political scientists for understanding the world and effecting social change. While outside observers have long inveighed against theory's abstruse argot and political pretensions, this year theory seems to have lost much of its cachet, even among its would-be defenders.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Noroton and Noroton Heights; A Haven for Both Sailors and Commuters
description: THE Noroton section of Darien is defined by two peninsulas that claw their way into Long Island Sound, their curved appendages protecting enough coves and inlets to make the area a haven for beachgoers and sailors. From there, Noroton spreads inland across the congestion of the Boston Post Road, then over Interstate 95 and the train tracks into the closely packed commuter neighborhoods of Noroton Heights. It is the water, however, that gives Noroton both its name -- an Indian word assigned to the river along Darien's border with Stamford -- and its identity.

description: WE have become a nation of porters. Everywhere you go people are pulling things behind them on wheels and are always in the way of those of us who don't own one of these collapsible contraptions -- all 17 of us at last count.

title: For Two Brothers, an Award Inspired by Mosquito Bites
description: Being forced to wear long pants on a hot summer day might not seem the stuff of great scientific inspiration. But such was the origin of a research project that led Mark and Jeffrey Schneider, brothers from South Windsor, to capture top honors and a $100,000 prize last week in the team category of the Siemens Westinghouse Math, Science and Technology competition.

title: At the Helm in Winter
description: THE day after the one-two punch of the first winter storm of the season had ended, while most people were still hunkered by the fireplace, a small number of dedicated sailors were shoveling out their dinghies and preparing their masts for an afternoon of sailboat racing on Long Island Sound.

title: The Case of the Shifting Bookshop
description: WE moved from a five-floor walkup in Chelsea to the Upper West Side in the late 1980's, knowing that if we had children, we'd need a park nearby, not to mention an elevator. Moving meant regret: leaving the semi-bohemian aura of our first neighborhood, where little shops dotted the streets and small, cheap restaurants made cooking in almost superfluous.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Cinema Meets Real Life
description: In ''American Splendor,'' Paul Giamatti plays Harvey Pekar, a grumpy file clerk at a Cleveland hospital who records the small oddities and frustrations of his daily existence in a series of comic-strip vignettes. ''Ordinary life is pretty complex stuff,'' he observes, and the movie, which came out in August, takes this statement as both its theme and its organizing principle. As fans of the comic book from which the film takes its title will know, Harvey Pekar is a real person, and he appears in the movie not only in the rumpled, jowly form of Giamatti but also in his own unremarkable skin. Giamatti's Pekar ambles through the real streets of Cleveland, while Pekar's Pekar shows up from time to time, posed against a blank white background that suggests an uninked comic-book page. One of them acts out the other's real life, while the person whose real life it is comments on the action.

description: Leon Botstein has long believed that teachers colleges have been getting it all wrong. Now he is doing something about it.

description: Stephen Reiter follows New Jersey politics closely, and periodically he browses www.politicsnj.com -- the Web site for political junkies from High Point to Cape May. Last month he was shocked by something he read there.

title: This Old House, The Versailles Version
description: WHEN it comes to sprucing up historic monuments, the French like to think big. The $1.2 billion Grand Louvre project, which spawned I.M. Pei's glass pyramid in 1989, is still renovating museum galleries two decades after it was begun. Now, in a separate initiative, it is the Chteau of Versailles' turn to undergo a major restoration.

title: New London Neighbors Find It Best to Keep a Little Distance
description: CONNECTICUT COLLEGE'S effort to take over the management of the Lyman Allyn Art Museum, its neighbor here in New London, has ended where it began -- in court.

title: Italian Debate on Fertility Bill Raises Issue of Church Influence
description: The Senate's approval on Thursday of a bill drastically limiting fertility treatments was itself freighted with issues of enormous importance to the nation's identity, like the size of its future population and the relationship between secularization and the beliefs of the Roman Catholic church.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Offloading Your Memories
description: Can your computer be enlisted to help you remember all the details of your life? In a way, it's already starting to do that. Your e-mail files contain a good portion of your personal communication, and your calendar software has a record of every dentist appointment and staff meeting you've had in the last few years. But while it's easy to track down an address that your colleague e-mailed you six months ago, it's a bit more challenging to reconstruct a joke your friend told you during a phone call sometime in the late 90's. So why not take matters a step further and record everything? Now that most of our information streams are built out of zeros and ones, it's vastly easier to capture all those bits for posterity: every phone call, every passing conversation, every book you read or face you see -- the totality of information that flows through a human life.

title: Building a Better Bra Shop
description: Hope Reeves (Nov. 30) might have broadened her readers' interest if she had referred to a 19th-century novel, ''The Ladies' Paradise,'' by mile Zola. In the book, Zola interweaves the story of an innocent who triumphs with a remarkably detailed history of the creation of the department store. He describes methods used by today's merchants, including the sale, the loss leader, the arrangement of merchandise.

title: Gauging The Winners In the Medicare Bill
description: THE Medicare bill that President Bush signed into law on Monday could be a boon for health insurers. The law contains a new prescription drug benefit, but there is much more to it than that.

''There's a joke in the movie where a middle-aged man is making out with a middle-aged woman, and he says, 'What about birth control?' And she replies, 'Menopause.'

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14  President Bush today hailed the capture of Saddam Hussein as a turning point in the history of Iraq and "a hopeful day" for its people, but he warned Americans that the violence against United States forces occupying the nation would continue.

title: Greatest DVD's Never Made: A Most Wanted List
description: THE DVD player is the fastest-growing consumer-electronics product in history, and the pace is not slowing down. Since it came on the market six years ago, Americans have bought 61 million players, almost one-third of them this year alone, and that's as of the week before Thanksgiving. More than 36,000 films are now available on DVD and nearly half of those were released in just the last two years.

title: Last Call for Cuba?
description: WE jumped at the opportunity to join a 10-day tour of Cuba last February. My husband, Mike, and I went legally as part of a study group flying by charter from New York. Shortly afterward, the American government announced that it would not approve any more such ''people to people'' educational visits, and soon it will be impossible for most American tour groups to go to Cuba.

title: Investing; Why Cash Is Still King at Some Stock Funds
description: AS the Dow Jones industrial average raced toward 10,000 this year, some managers of stock mutual funds resisted the temptation to join the bull stampede. Convinced that stocks were overpriced and, in some cases, that the market was headed for a big fall, these contrarians curtailed their stock purchases and raised substantial cash reserves.

title: Key Democrat Asks Rowland To Step Aside
description: The leader of the Connecticut Democratic Party called on Gov. John G. Rowland on Saturday to step aside while federal investigators continue looking into allegations that repairs were done on his private cottage at a discount in return for promises of state work.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Video-Game Art
description: You may not think of video games as art, at least not in the same way that a painting by Picasso is art. Yet highbrows have always nursed a secret passion for low forms, if only to keep their taste from going stale, and video games are the latest pop phenomenon to be upgraded from economy to museum class. This year, several games were created expressly as objets d'art, rather than as commercial ventures, and academics published books with suitably dense thoughts on ''gaming.'' In much the same way that Warhol swiped imagery from cartoons and advertisements, many young artists today see video games as the definitive pop experience, a form to cannibalize and critique.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Instantly Pass Trend, The
description: In a 1997 New Yorker article, Malcolm Gladwell charted the typical life cycle of a trend. First, ''innovators'' (otherwise known as ''cool people'') pioneer a style. Then it is picked up by ''early adopters'' (or people who hang out with cool people). Next, it passes to the ''early majority'' (people who see cool people across the street), followed by the ''late majority'' (people who see cool people on MTV). Finally, it winds its way to the ''laggards'' (you and me).

title: War and Never Having To Say You're Sorry
description: SOMETIME in the mid-1960's, the Vietnam War became known as ''McNamara's War.'' In the seven years Robert S. McNamara served as Secretary of Defense for Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon. B. Johnson, the United States commitment in Vietnam soared -- in a soothingly gradual fashion -- from fewer than a thousand Americans to just under half a million. Mr. McNamara, in turn, went from being heralded as a whiz kid to being hounded as a war monger. In 1965, a Quaker protester set himself on fire below Mr. McNamara's Pentagon office window. In 1967, antiwar activists tried to burn down the his vacation home in Aspen, Colo. And in 1972, an artist who spotted him on a ferry tried to heave him into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: New Iraqi Leaders Confront Their Former Dictator
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 14  The wild gray beard was gone, and he sat on a metal Army cot, just awake from a nap, in socks and black slippers. He was not handcuffed. He did not recognize all his visitors, but they recognized him. That was the purpose of the visit: to help confirm that this was, in fact, Saddam Hussein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUDWIG, EILEEN DENARI
description: LUDWIG--Eileen Denari. Of San Francisco, CA, beloved wife of James J. Ludwig and devoted mother of Lisa Constance Ludwig, died on December 3, 2003 after a three year long courageous struggle fighting lung cancer. A memorial service was held at Grace Cathedral and a reception followed at the Pacific Union Club. A native of NY, she was Buyer for the Park Avenue Room for all Saks Fifth Avenue stores before she moved to San Francisco in 1970 to marry Jim. In San Francisco, she was active in many non-profit organizations including serving as President of the San Francisco Opera Guild and a founding member and President of Achievement Rewards for College Scientists. She was a beautiful woman who never lost her love for fashion and the fashion world. She was considered one of the best dressed women in San Francisco. Contributions may be made to the Eileen D. Ludwig Scholarship Fund at Achievement Rewards for College Scientists, PO Box 29405 San Francisco 94129 or to the Eileen D. Ludwig Thoracic Oncology Fund for Lung Cancer Research at the UCSF Foundation, PO Box 0248, San Francisco, CA. 94143.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Unjuicing Golf
description: Is it possible to hit a golf ball too far? Not if you're a duffer. We consider the so-called trampoline effect the greatest accidental discovery since Flubber. The wizards who design golf clubs happened upon this miracle in the mid-90's, when they began making bigger and bigger driver heads out of metal stretched thinner and thinner, and found that when the club heads didn't just cave in, the metal sometimes sprang back so quickly that it actually added a little something extra to the shot -- a high-tech slingshot. Amateurs and pros alike eagerly embraced the new futuristic drivers, and while the former mostly hit deeper into the woods, the latter caused a problem for the PGA Tour. The clubs were making golf courses too short.

title: In an Oversexed Age, More Guys Take a Pill
description: CHRIS LONDON remembers the first time an impotence drug came to his emotional rescue. A 41-year-old lawyer and executive recruiter in Manhattan, Mr. London had been on a few dates with a lawyer who told him she couldn't judge a man without first having sex with him. The two made plans to meet after work, and Mr. London said he felt pretty certain about what was going to happen. He also felt not a little anxious.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Proving You're Human
description: Want a free e-mail account at Yahoo? It's yours, once you pass a little test. When you sign up, Yahoo now presents you with a small picture of a distorted word, something that looks as if it had been written on cellophane and stretched out of shape. If you can read the word and type it correctly into a response box, then you'll get your free e-mail.

title: Private Sector; At AARP, Pushing for Change

A client of the firm, William D. Novelli, the executive director and chief executive of AARP, had unintentionally locked himself inside.

After setting it adrift on a river, they stood on a boat and took turns trying to whack a golf ball through the television.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Turnout Wins Elections
description: Anyone with a television knows that TV ads have been the centerpiece of political campaigns for the last 40 years, especially in the closing weeks, when a lot of fence-sitting voters make up their minds. The old-fashioned, labor-intensive tactics that parties use to deliver voters to the polls -- doling out leaflets, pounding on doors, driving voters to their polling stations -- have largely become afterthoughts to the most powerful and cost-effective tool of the technological age: the 30-second attack ad.
