If no longer in fashion, the phrase will at least soon be found tucked in the pages of the oft-hallowed, though rarely glitzy, Oxford English Dictionary.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Nobody does trials like Americans. We made it an art form. It's almost as fundamental a part of our culture as jazz or rock 'n' roll.''

title: African Girls' Route to School Is Still Littered With Obstacles
description: For as long as anyone could remember, the girls of this village had been forbidden to go to school. They were to be educated instead by the local voodoo priest, in a secret rite of passage not to be spoken about to anyone. When they finished, they were to be married. They and their children were to forever enjoy the protection of the voodoo priest.

title: Page Two: Dec. 7-13; IN BRIEF
description: * A report delivered to President Jacques Chirac of France called for a new law banning the wearing of ''conspicuous'' religious symbols in French public schools -- large crosses for Christians, head scarves for Muslim girls or skullcaps for Jewish boys.

title: Dangerous Seduction
description: To the Editor:

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Junk Food Is Good for You
description: In October, KFC issued a press release stating that ''fried chicken can, in fact, be part of a healthy, balanced diet.'' The accompanying ad campaign included a spot in which a wife asks her husband if he remembers that they had talked about eating better. After he grimaces, she triumphantly produces a bucket of fried chicken and declares, ''Well, it starts today.''

title: Airlines and U.S. In a Bag Battle
description: THE good news about the holiday travel season is that in some sense, the worst is already over. The Sunday after Thanksgiving -- traditionally the busiest day of the year for air travel -- has passed without notable delays or disruptions, thanks in part to good weather. But even though travel is spread over a longer period in late December, flying at Christmas presents a different challenge: dealing with all the baggage that passengers check, drag through security and cram into overhead compartments, a daunting task for both the government and the airlines.

title: Lift Your Voice: Sing Into Healing Therapy
description: IN this season of fa-la-la-la-la, dozens of people who practice alternative means of healing recently learned a theory of the healing powers of some less easily transcribable syllables: wo, ah, nda, a, ya, ya.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Cameron Surprises Mets By Accepting Contract
description: The Mets obtained the free-agent outfielder Mike Cameron on Saturday night when he accepted a three-year contract from a relieved Jim Duquette. Cameron, a two-time Gold Glove winner who played for the Seattle Mariners the last four seasons, is set to sign a deal believed to be worth close to $20 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACKSON, IRMA EVELYN
description: JACKSON--Irma Evelyn. February 26, 1911 - December 8, 2003. Treasured wife of Roberts Brock Jackson. Daughter of Pearl Radlow and Abraham Lowenstein of Boston; sister of the late Carolyn Lewis and Bernice Factor. Graduated from Teacher's College in 1929. Received a Master's degree in Directing and Acting from Yale Drama School, 1940. Toured the South Pacific with the USO as Manager and actress of six girl troupe. Survived by her amazing husband of 54 years. Beloved by grandnephew, David Raymond Lewis and grandniece, Kimberly Lewis Pratt, and great-grandnephews, Douglas and Paul. With love from all of your friends at 161 West 75th.

title: Advocates for Reservoir Move To Halt Housing Development
description: IN a move unusual for its last-minute fervor, a group opposed to a 23-home development on the Amawalk Reservoir in Somers is urging New York City and other governments and charitable groups to try to buy the 29-acre site in question and keep it from being developed.

title: The Beast of Queens
description: I agree that ivy would be a most welcome addition to the Van Wyck's concrete columns, particularly because it's very difficult (I suspect) to paint graffiti over a lush growth of ivy. Unfortunately, the ivy alone will take a long time to beautify the Van Wyck and its columns.

title: WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: Amy L. Domini, 53

title: Mr. Rowland's Neighborhood: Quiet and Not Too Flashy
description: IT was shortly before noon on a recent December day at the Morris Deli and the line was already snaking past the candy jars and down the cereal aisle. A man wearing insulated coveralls was eating shepherd's pie off a paper plate. Others were ordering overstuffed sandwiches to eat in their pick-up trucks. Homemade cookies sat under a glass dome.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Theater for One
description: An essential part of the experience of live theater has always been that it happens in public. It's not like television or a movie, which you can watch alone in your living room. At the theater, you are part of a crowd, and your fellow spectators inevitably become part of the way you watch the play.

title: Record Snowfalls Bring Utah Skiers Out Early
description: After much anxiety earlier this fall, when National Weather Services forecasters predicted a winter dry spell in the Rocky Mountains, the region's ski-resort operators were relieved when an early-November shift in the jet stream delivered a steady blast of storms from the Northwest. The Wasatch Mountains in Utah, in particular, received more than 11 feet of snow in November at ski resorts like Alta and Brighton, surpassing the total snowfall record for that month.

title: CRIME
description: Jonathan Kellerman's characters are most alive when they are at death's door. So it helps that the hospital setting of THE CONSPIRACY CLUB (Ballantine, $26.95) provides a number of bedside scenes for the protagonist -- not Alex Delaware this time out, but a young and caring staff psychologist named Jeremy Carrier -- to exercise his skills with patients facing grueling procedures like spinal taps.

title: Dance Listings
description: ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER  World premieres by Robert Battle, Alonzo King, Jennifer Muller and Dwight Rhoden; highlights include revivals by Judith Jamison and Donald McKayle. City Center, 131 W. 55th St. (212) 581-1212. Today and next Sun., 3 and 7:30; Tue.-Fri., 8; Sat., 2 and 8. Through Jan. 4.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Cancer Vaccine, The
description: Treating cancer with radiation or chemotherapy is a bit like firebombing a house to get rid of pests: it can do the job, but good stuff is going to get damaged in the process. Researchers have long searched for a more targeted approach that wouldn't injure healthy tissue. Now they may have found one in a surprising place: the human immune system.

title: No Safety Issues With Reduced Road Salt
description: Pound Ridge has reduced the amount of salt it puts on roads, and no bad accidents could be attributed to the change in policy after the snowstorm on Dec. 5, the Town Supervisor Joy Simpkins said. After salt contamination was found in wells belonging to a church, a school, and at least two other buildings in town last year, officials decided to use less salt, and signs were posted urging drivers to proceed with caution.

title: Elizabeth Leichtung, Jonathan Bayer
description: Elizabeth Ann Leichtung, a daughter of Carole and Marvin Leichtung of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Jonathan Lewis Bayer, a son of Bernard Bayer of Salem, S.C., and the late Rosalee Perl Bayer. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 15
description: Dallas Cowboys (8-5) at Washington Redksins (5-8)

title: A Notion At War
description: In Washington, it is often assumed that the answer to every crisis is to be found in a Big Idea -- ''the vision thing,'' as President George Herbert Walker Bush once called it, somewhat dismissively. Just as nature abhors a vacuum, so administrations abhor an absence of ideas (or at least convenient catch phrases). Muddling through, which is the reality of politics, rarely seems enough.

title: 'All We Want Is Respect'
description: WHO cares about East Rutherford?

title: Elizabeth Houlihan, Robert Seabaugh
description: Ruth Elizabeth Houlihan and Robert McNair Seabaugh were married last evening in St. Louis. Msgr. Walter E. Nolan performed the ceremony at St. Francis Xavier College Church at St. Louis University.

title: Page Two: Dec. 7-13; YOUNG AND IN TROUBLE
description: Both Florida and Virginia allow juveniles accused of murder to be tried as adults, and both allow older teenagers to be put to death. But an appeals court decision in Florida and a trial in Virginia suggest that the legal system can nonetheless find ways to take account of the ages of young defendants in big trouble.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q&A column on Nov. 30, about a day trip from London to a cemetery in France that is the resting place of American soldiers who died in World War I, misstated the distance between the Gare du Nord and the Gare de l'Est in Paris. It is one subway stop, not a few.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIGHTBOWN, MARY JANE
description: LIGHTBOWN -- Mary Jane. The staff of the Department of Architecture and Design of The Museum of Modern Art, sadly notes the passing of longtime colleague Mary Jane Lightbown. From 1968 until her retirement in 1984 her research on architecture and design informed the museum's publications, exhibitions and enriched the permanent collection.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Flop Penance
description: In Hollywood, making a flop has always meant never having to say you're sorry. Instead, studio executives and stars usually resort to evasion, denial or outright cluelessness. John Travolta, for example, defended the widely ridiculed ''Battlefield Earth'' by stating serenely, and somewhat astonishingly: ''Many critics didn't give 'Alien,' '2001: A Space Odyssey' or 'Blade Runner' good reviews on their initial releases, but have since revised those opinions. I feel that's going to happen with 'Battlefield Earth.' ''

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Injectable Beauty
description: The idea that beauty can be pumped into us -- a vaguely sinister notion -- gained momentum this year with the proliferation of injectable anti-aging treatments. These products bear names that sound clinical and exciting -- CosmoDerm, Restylane, Hylaform, Juvderm, Silikon 1000 -- though in plain terms they are wrinkle fillers. They are considered an alternative to plastic surgery and a next-generation companion to Botox, which can banish frown lines and tiny creases around the eyes, but not folds around the mouth. A half-dozen of the treatments are awaiting F.D.A. approval but are already widely used in Europe and by leading dermatalogic surgeons in the United States.

title: Home of the Antikitsch
description: Giant snowflakes suspended from streetlights on Millburn Avenue in Millburn cue shoppers that the boutiques on the street are in full holiday swing. But you would never know it at PAD, a dining ware store at No.535. A window display done up in vintage glass decanters, expensive-looking serving bowls and funky handmade vases sidesteps any green-and-red or silver-and-gold color scheme. And not one smiling snowman is to be found inside the 900-square-foot store. Furthermore, ''there are no kitty cats or dogs on our things,'' said the owner, Parry Yohannan, who opened the store last year after spending most of the 1990's as national visual director for the Pottery Barn chain. ''We stay away from cute -- if it's difficult to use or impractical, it doesn't belong here.''

title: A Baghdad Neighborhood, Once Hopeful, Now Reels As Iraq's Turmoil Persists
description: Ghazalia is a neighborhood on edge.

title: To Be Young, Gifted and Gay
description: QUEER STREET

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 16 about the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center, a new Smithsonian flight museum in Chantilly, Va., referred incorrectly to a P-40 War Hawk that will be displayed there. It is painted to resemble those used by the Flying Tiger Fighter Group in World War II; it was not actually flown in combat. •

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Nicotini, The
description: There is nothing as alluring as vice, except possibly the combination of two vices. A Florida club owner may have come up with a cure for smokers' rage over their recent exile from bars: a martini infused with nicotine-rich tobacco. (Sound delicious? How can it not be?) The Nicotini, as it is known, comes in various forms -- among them a Quick Puff (a single shot) and, more enticingly, a Black Lung (mixed with Kahla). Result: The stimulant and the depressant enter the boxing ring that is your body and battle for dominion -- but then, that's hardly a new sensation for anyone who has ever smoked in a bar.

title: Mironov Barred for 2 Games, and Rangers Call It Unfair
description: TORONTO, Dec. 13  Rangers defenseman Boris Mironov was suspended for two games for the attempt-to-injure match penalty he was assessed late in the third period of the Rangers' 3-1 victory over the Sabres in Buffalo on Friday night, the National Hockey League announced Saturday.

title: Where the Dough Rises but Slowly
description: DOUGH, mounds and mounds of it, is everywhere at the Bread Factory in New Rochelle. At 5:30 one wintry morning, a mammoth refrigerator at the bakery was filled with trays of bread dough that needed to be chilled, while giant mixers with 400-pound capacity were filled with the early makings for foccacia, paesano and kalamata olive bread. Nearby, a huge gob of dough for Irish soda bread sat on a table ready to be shaped by hand.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 16 about the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center, a new Smithsonian flight museum in Chantilly, Va., referred incorrectly to a P-40 War Hawk that will be displayed there. It is painted to resemble those used by the Flying Tiger Fighter Group in World War II; it was not actually flown in combat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, MORTON
description: GOLDBERG--Morton. 89, on December 11. Father of Sandra Goldberg, brother of Stella LeVine. World War II veteran, Captain U.S. Army. Great negotiator and avid golfer. In lieu of flowers, please donate to a favorite charity.

title: PULSE: Gifts for Small Packages; Little Coats, Big Style
description: For children, the holidays are pure, happy promise -- no long lines for them, no dense shopping crowds, only an abundance of receiving and believing. Despite this year's resurgence of plastic toys like Barbie and G.I. Joe, parents may still find stylish ways to decorate their offspring in finery and fun. Here are some of the season's gladdest offerings for the stroller and schoolyard set.

title: Anusha Chari, Nathan Letts
description: Dr. Anusha Chari, a daughter of Chandra Chari and P. R. Chari of New Delhi, was married on Monday to Dr. Nathan P. Letts, the son of Barbara Smart Letts of Guilford, Conn., and the late Dr. Roger W. M. Letts. Betty Peskin, a deputy marriage commissioner, officiated in San Francisco's City Hall. On Dec. 21, Mrinal Pande, a friend of the bride's family, will lead a celebration of the couple's marriage at Chitrakoot, a private guesthouse in New Delhi.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Airborne Humans
description: On July 31, Felix Baumgartner jumped out of an airplane at 30,000 feet and began plummeting to the English countryside below him. But within seconds, his wings caught the air, and he spun around, straightened up and peacefully soared off into the distance like an eagle. Baumgartner was no ordinary skydiver: he was wearing a six-foot-wide carbon-fiber fin strapped to his back, making him look something like a human version of a Delta-winged military jet. He began his glide over the east coast of Britain, but before long he was heading out over the English Channel toward France, streaking through the air at 220 miles an hour.

title: Third Tower Is Proposed for EAB Plaza
description: THE new owners of EAB Plaza in Uniondale, Long Island's tallest and largest office complex and one of its most prestigious business addresses, confirmed last week that they would press ahead with plans for a major new building.

title: In the Seventh Year, 'Lord of the Rings' Rests
description: ''WELL, I'm back.''

title: Lottery Numbers
With McDyess Returning to Starting Role, Knicks End a Skid
description: With forward Antonio McDyess finally breaking into the starting lineup, the Knicks finally ended their losing streak.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Homeland-Security Neighborhood Watch, The
description: The United States has roughly 47,000 strategic facilities -- from ports, pipelines and oil terminals to chemical plants, power stations and dams -- that are vulnerable to terrorist attack. Despite much hand-wringing and speechmaking about homeland security, little has been done since Sept. 11 to significantly upgrade security at infrastructure facilities. Fencing remains inadequate. Guards are too few and too expensive for individual companies to afford them round-the-clock, and many of the sites are just too vast and remote to properly patrol.

title: A Train to the Plane, At Long Last
description: Kennedy Airport passengers will have a new ground-transportation choice starting Wednesday at 2 p.m., when the long-awaited AirTrain JFK will begin service. The light-rail link connects the airport's nine terminals with parking lots, car rental locations and nearby train, bus and subway stations.

title: Op-Art; WANT TO BUILD A BRIDGE?
description: This Friday, on Dec. 19, New York's Williamsburg Bridge will turn 100. Leffert L. Buck, the chief engineer, finished his plans for the bridge in 1896. At the time, the Brooklyn Bridge, then only 13 years old, was already carrying considerably more people and vehicles than its builders had predicted. To accommodate the expected heavy commuter traffic between the Lower East Side and the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, Buck envisioned a bridge approximately half again as wide as its more famous neighbor, with 10 rather than six lanes for trains, trolleys and carriages. There would also be two paths for pedestrians. (The Brooklyn Bridge has only one.)

title: Guilty as Charged
description: What a shame that Rachel finds her love for her brother defeated by the crimes he committed. For years he reached across their age difference and geographic separation to connect with her, sharing music, movies, jokes.

title: 4 Bodies Leave Hamlet On Edge
description: FOR as long as some longtime residents could remember, every few years a hunter or hiker would stumble across human remains left to decompose in the vast pine barrens surrounding this still-rural hamlet. They said they just shrugged it off, thinking nothing more than that their woods had replaced the Meadowlands as the mob's preferred dumping ground.

title: PULSE: Gifts for Small Packages; Dance a Night Away
description: For children, the holidays are pure, happy promise -- no long lines for them, no dense shopping crowds, only an abundance of receiving and believing. Despite this year's resurgence of plastic toys like Barbie and G.I. Joe, parents may still find stylish ways to decorate their offspring in finery and fun. Here are some of the season's gladdest offerings for the stroller and schoolyard set.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-36

title: Woman and 2 Girls Found Dead After Fire in East Hartford
description: A woman and two girls believed to be her daughters were found dead after a suspicious house fire early yesterday in East Hartford, Conn., and the authorities said they were looking for the woman's ex-husband, who has a criminal history of setting fires.

title: LIPA Considering Rise In Home Electric Bills
description: The Long Island Power Authority is considering increasing residential electric bills by 3 to 5 percent next month to help pay for the increased cost of oil, natural gas and purchased power, according to its chairman, Richard Kessel.

title: The Plight of Gays In the Military
description: To the Editor:

title: Arabs Welcome of Arrest Is Tinged With Regret
description: CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 14  The capture of Saddam Hussein has reinforced the ambiguity that many people in the Arab world felt about the American-led war and occupation of Iraq.

title: A Beloved Teen Movie Is Back: This Time, in Black
description: WHILE it did not land with the generation-defining thud of John Hughes's ''Breakfast Club,'' the 1987 teen movie ''Can't Buy Me Love'' was a commercial success and continues to inspire a cult following. Even now, the movie stands out for the ruthless simplicity of its plot: does high school really happen unless you are popular? The actor Patrick Dempsey played Ronald Miller, a senior class nobody whose Saturday nights revolve around ''chips, dips and dorks.'' When Ronald pays the prettiest cheerleader in school to be his girlfriend, he suddenly rises from ''totally geek to totally chic.'' And then the discovery of the ruse and the inevitable downfall. What's unexpected is what has happened to Ronald 16 years later. He's been reincarnated as an African-American named Alvin, the star of the new movie ''Love Don't Cost a Thing,'' an ''urban'' remake of ''Can't Buy Me Love.''

title: Looking Back in Anger
description: Dark Memories of Roy Cohn

title: Alfred Kazins America
description: In Brownsville tenements the kitchen is always the largest room and the center of the household. As a child I felt that we lived in a kitchen to which four other rooms were annexed. My mother, a "home" dressmaker, had her workshop in the kitchen. She told me once that she had begun dressmaking in Poland at thirteen; as far back as I can remember, she was always making dresses for the local women. She had an innate sense of design, a quick eye for all the subtleties in the latest fashions, even when she despised them, and great boldness. For three or four dollars she would study the fashion magazines with a customer, go with the customer to the remnants store on Belmont Avenue to pick out the material, argue the owner down - all remnants stores, for some reason, were supposed to be shady, as if the owners dealt in stolen goods - and then for days would patiently fit and baste and sew and fit again. Our apartment was always full of women in their housedresses sitting around the kitchen table waiting for a fitting. My little bedroom next to the kitchen was the fitting room. The sewing machine, an old nut-brown Singer with golden scrolls painted along the black arm and engraved along the two tiers of little drawers massed with needles and thread on each side of the treadle, stood next to the window and the great coal-black stove which up to my last year in college was our main source of heat. By December the two outer bed-rooms were closed off, and used to chill bottles of milk and cream, cold borscht, and jellied calves' feet.

title: The Plight of Gays In the Military
description: To the Editor:

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Social Networks
description: Just a few years ago, the network was what people tapped into at parties or business conventions or what they called upon if the market turned sour or they were in desperate need of a job. In the time since, a coterie of ''network thinkers'' have begun to extend the language of the network -- ''nodes'' and ''hubs'' and ''links'' -- to phenomena ranging from the workings of the world economy to the possible spread of a dangerous pathogen. Several network theorists, most notably Albert-Laszlo Barabasi of Notre Dame and Duncan Watts of Columbia, have recently discovered that varieties of systems display a common architecture that governs their dynamics and structure. The way a cluster of neurons fires, for instance, has marked similarities to the way a disease like SARS travels the globe or the way a contagious idea disperses. Apparently, lots of complex networks look like lots of other complex networks (the Internet and the North American power grid, for example). And apparently the idea that everything is connected to everything else no longer seems so far-fetched.

title: Credits
description: The Rodney Smith photographs in this issue were taken at the following locations:

title: Political Savvy Gets U.S. Flags On Foreign Ship
description: For the first time in 50 years, a cruise ship flying the American flag will soon be sailing the seas. There will be no mistaking it for anything but an all-American vessel. It will be named Pride of America. Red and white stripes, blue stars and a huge bald eagle will decorate its hull. Its public rooms will strike a patriotic theme: the Liberty restaurant, the Capitol Atrium, Jefferson's Bistro, the John Adams Coffee Bar.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Tornado in a Can
description: The awesome destructive force of tornadoes -- iconized in ''The Wizard of Oz'' and fetishized in ''Twister'' -- has been harnessed by a 65-year-old farmer who, as central casting would have it, hails from Kansas.

title: Students Get a Turn at Running the Council
description: It was a rare, working Saturday in the City Council chamber, but Speaker Gifford Miller was not in his customary seat. Instead, a confident 18-year-old woman was using his microphone, directing the debate on his floor.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Iraq, Outsourced
description: America's most important ally in the Iraq war may be a multinational force after all -- one composed of private military contractors. There is no official count of how many paid civilians are stationed in Iraq, but analysts estimate that the number could be as high as 20,000. (Britain, by comparison, has 11,000 troops in Iraq.) These contractors, often former military personnel from armies around the world, are employed not by any sovereign government but by multinational corporations.

title: Rutgers Wins by Stopping Princeton's Standout Scorer
description: For Rutgers to beat Princeton, it had to slow Judson Wallace, a junior center who was averaging 22.8 points a game, eighth best in the nation. Obviously, that message got through Saturday. Rutgers forced Wallace into a miserable afternoon and escaped with a 51-49 victory.

title: Christmas Will Be Bloody This Year
description: THE ''Top Gun'' image of George W. Bush's victory landing on an aircraft carrier has been officially recalled. Since the mission was not accomplished after all, we were given a replacement tableau of the president bestowing Thanksgiving grub on troops stuck in a long, hard slog.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 23 about the 2003 Havana Biennial included misspellings provided by the Museo de Bellas Artes in Havana for two artists' names. They are Marco Castillo, not Merco, and Dagoberto Rodriguez, not Rodrigues. The article also misspelled the surname of an artist represented by a Los Angeles gallery owner who commented on the commercialization of Cuban art. He is Juan Carlos Alom, not Alon.

title: Some Ancient Creatures Get a Whole New Look
description: APALEONTOLOGIST'S work is never done. The study of dinosaurs and their world, which vanished some 65 million years ago, is a matter of conjecture and educated guesses, so yesterday's theories are constantly being revised.

title: Hear Them Roar: Let the Boom Begin
description: AFTER a three-year absence because of a moribund economy, the ritual announcement of Wall Street's year-end bonuses was on display again this year. How the billions in bonus money was spread around made front-page news last week in New York, where the tabloids used the phrase ''eye popping'' to describe the amounts being dispensed. The man of the hour was Philip J. Purcell, chairman and chief executive of Morgan Stanley, who raked in $12 million.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; PowerPoint Makes You Dumb
description: In August, the Columbia Accident Investigation Board at NASA released Volume 1 of its report on why the space shuttle crashed. As expected, the ship's foam insulation was the main cause of the disaster. But the board also fingered another unusual culprit: PowerPoint, Microsoft's well-known ''slideware'' program.

title: The Evolution Of a Daffy Species
description: FOR just about every American born since World War II, the Warner Brothers cartoons occupy a prime piece of subconscious real estate. Thanks to innumerable television showings, the Warner cartoons mean more to us now than they did to the theatrical audiences they were originally made for in the 30's, 40's and 50's. They are our true national fairy tales, focused on primal fears and desires and filled with archetypes of human behavior that approach the profundity of the Greek myths.

title: The Beast of Queens
description: Hugo Lindgren seems piqued that the AirTrain does not provide a direct Manhattan to Kennedy Airport ride, without realizing that this is part of the design genius (The Way We Live Now, Nov. 30). The derided ''change in Jamaica'' opens the system up to airline travelers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties; not everyone lives in Manhattan.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; See-Through Coat, The
description: Susumu Tachi, a professor at the University of Tokyo, introduced invisibility to the fashion world this year in the form of a see-through raincoat. Tachi's hooded coat -- the central element in ''optical camouflage technology'' -- is made of retro-reflective material (think of the trim on a fireman's uniform or the stripe on a child's backpack). Its effect is something like this: You're on the sidewalk, facing Saks, and a taxi is stopped behind you. A shopper emerges from the store and, rather than seeing you standing there in your shiny coat, she looks straight through you and sees the yellow cab.

title: Detouring To Peru's Past
description: THE itinerary was set: the Andes to the Amazon. Start out hiking through pre-Inca ruins in the Cloud Forest. Descend to a sultry paradise, spending the week's end in a romantic jungle hideaway.

title: For the Love of God (And a Good Woman)
description: OLIVIER MESSIAEN'S ''Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant-Jsus'' (''Twenty Gazes on the Child Jesus'') must be the longest love song ever written in the language of the piano. It is addressed principally to God, as the source of love, expressing divine love together with human love for the divine. But it also conveys the composer's love of sound, and of the sounds of the piano in particular, whether thunderous or mist-thin, always touched with resonance. And it tells of the immediate musical and personal contact Messiaen felt with the pianist for whom he wrote the work in 1944: Yvonne Loriod, his future wife.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOULKES, KIMBERLY
description: FOULKES--Kimberly. On December 8. Beloved daughter of Richard and Ruth Foulkes. Loving sister of Mark Foulkes of Nantucket. Donations to your favorite charity in memory of Kimberly will be deeply appreciated by her family.

title: Dirk Flentrop, Builder of Organs, Dies at 93
description: Dirk A. Flentrop, a Dutch organ builder who influenced a generation of American counterparts in making pipe organs that play and sound like the classical Baroque instruments of Bach's time, died at his home in Santpoort, the Netherlands, on Nov. 30, his company, Flentrop Orgelbouw, announced. He was 93.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Body Language Reveals All
description: Each issue of US Weekly is chock-full of science. Yes, it's also chock-full of celebrities -- celebrities at premieres, celebrities nuzzling at after-parties, celebrities in sunglasses taking out the trash. But in US, and other star-tracking magazines like In Touch and Star, the photos of these celebrities now come accompanied with reams of analysis from experts in the science of body language.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Tribute Bands in Denial
description: A reliable, if resolutely unhip, way to make money in music is to pretend to be a famous band -- to play its songs, note for note, and dress up like its members. This is called being a tribute band, and musicians do it because getting the public to listen to original songs can be very hard.

title: Who's Afraid of Eliot Spitzer?
description: IT may be a slow night in Fort Smith, Ark., but inside the cavernous Knights of Columbus ballroom on the outskirts of town, the joint is jumping. More than 200 investors have gathered to hear Louis G. Navellier, founder of the Navellier family of growth funds, expound on the markets and make his pitch for a slice of their savings.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; G.P.S. Art
description: Long ago came the ancient Nazca lines in Peru. More recently, in the 1960's and 70's, came Earth artists like Michael Heizer, making tracks in the Nevada desert with a motorcycle; Robert Smithson, building his spiral jetty in Utah; and Richard Long, turning walks in the English countryside into conceptual drawings through space.

title: BEAR HUNT BEGINS
description: After long debate, lawsuits and protests, the state's first black bear hunt since 1970 started in deep snow on Monday. Wildlife officials said the goals were to slow the growth rate of the bear population and to reduce potentially dangerous encounters with people. Hunters killed 116 bears on Monday, 66 on Tuesday and 39 on Wednesday, for a three-day total of 221. Opponents of the six-day hunt complained in midweek that hunters were killing cubs. The charge disturbed Martin J. McHugh, the director of the Division of Fish and Wildlife. ''Hunters are not targeting cubs,'' he said. ''They're hunting bears.'' Nevertheless, rules of the hunt permitted the killing of cubs. Robert Hanley

title: Dispatches From a World Gone Wonderfully Wrong

Above the barking and yelping, a somber narrator intones: ''All the scenes you are about to see are real and were shot as they were taking place. If sometimes they seem cruel, it's only because cruelty abounds on this planet.'' And then, with a bit of sarcasm: ''And anyway, the duty of the reporter is not to make the truth seem sweeter, but to show things as they really are.'' description: A baseball umpire's job behind the plate has long been considered more a matter of art than a science, which is one reason managers lose their tempers so often. According to the official rules, the strike zone is defined by the width of the plate, from the batter's knees to his chest. But in reality, no two umpires ever call it the same way -- some shave the corners, others expand them and almost nobody respects the upper reaches of the zone. Pitches just above the belt buckle are called balls pretty much all the time.

But then came something else: the beats got murky and fidgety, and local M.C.'s crowded the stage, barking out fierce, mile-a-minute rhymes. People pushed forward, straining to see who had the microphone.

Her daughter, Judith Franks and her son-in-law, Hugh Franks survive her. Dr. Ruth Nanda Anshen was a worldrenowned philosopher, author and editor. Dr. Anshen was the author of several books including ''The Anatomy of Evil'', ''Biography of An Idea'', ''Morals Equals Manners'' and ''The Mystery of Consciousness: A Prescription for Human Survival''. She was a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts of London, a member of the American Philosophical Association, the History of Science Society, the International Philosophical Society and the Metaphysical Society of America. In 1958, she established the Anshen-Columbia University Seminars on the Nature of Man, in which many prominent scientists, theologians, writers, artists, world leaders and philosophers participated. A funeral service will be held Wednesday, December 17th, 2003 at 10AM at Woodlawn Cemetery, East 233 St and Webster Ave, Bronx, N.Y 10470. 718-920-0500.

title: QUICK BITE/Glassboro; Charms 101
description: To Margie and Ted Tannenbaum, retired Rowan University professors, it takes more than a college and a town to make a college town. In a real college town, campus life spills out into the streets. Students gather at local haunts to chat, hang out and study over steaming mugs of coffee. Downtown Glassboro, pitted with vacant storefronts, offers few of these charms. So, last April the Tannenbaums opened the town's first real coffee shop: Eleven East Cafe. Now it is a favorite among Rowan students and locals alike, who stop in to lounge on overstuffed vintage furniture while drinking lattes ($2.25 and $2.75) or specialty concoctions like mango vanilla iced tea with raspberry syrup ($2). Snacks include bagels, pretzels dipped in chocolate (85 cents each, or two for $1.50) and organic, vegan treats baked by the Tannenbaums' daughter, Jessica, that taste surprisingly good in spite of their wholesomeness. These include a rich orange cinnamon biscotti ($1.25) and the buzz bar ($2.25), with dense layers of chocolate, peanut butter and raspberry jam beneath a cashew crust. If you're not part of the study crowd, you can peruse the work of local artists on the walls or pull a magazine from the coffee table heap. A back room offers more seating and a charmingly haphazard array of board games and books from the Evergreen, a used bookstore next door, which the Tannenbaums also own. If you like your coffee with a collegiate, Vermont-style ambience, you will sing the cafe's praises. And if you want to sing them in front of an audience, you can: Friday and Saturday are open-mike nights. Jessica Bruder

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORTH, WILLIAM C.
description: PORTH--William C., of Wilmington, Delaware, formerly of Garden City, New York, on November 26, 2003, at age 89. Born in Brooklyn and a graduate of James Madison High School, Brooklyn College, and St. Lawrence Law School, he was a member of the New York Bar for over 60 years. At various times, he was a partner in the firms of Miller, Montgomery, Spalding & Porth and Burke & Burke, Vice President and General Counsel of New York University, and Professor of Forensic Medicine at N.Y.U. Medical Center. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II and the Korean War, being honorably discharged in 1952 with the rank of Captain. He was part of the Normandy landing and was wounded during combat in Germany and was awarded the Purple Heart. For over 55 years, he was devoted to the craft of Freemasonry. In New York, he was a member and Past Master of Lynbrook Lodge No. 1018, Past District Deputy Grand Master for the First Nassau District of the Grand Lodge of New York, and a member of Lynbrook Massapequa Lodge No. 822. At the time of his death, he was a member of Christiana Lodge No. 35 in New Castle, Delaware. He was also a member of the Johnson and Chesterton Club of Oxford, England and a recipient of its Edmund Burke Award. Predeceasing him were his wife of 49 years, Doris (nee Zimmermann), and his sisters, Mildred and Winifred. He is survived by his second wife, Helen, of Princeton, New Jersey, and his daughter, Susan, of Wilmington, Delaware, and his son, William, of Charleston, West Virginia. There will be a private memorial service by invitation. Communications may be sent to William C. Porth, Jr., at 1561 Thomas Circle, Charleston, West Virginia, 25314. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Masonic Home of Delaware, 4800 Lancaster Pike, Wilmington, Delaware, 19807. For information Chandler Funeral Homes & Crematory, www.chandlerfuneralhome .com

title: The Lost Boy
description: AN interesting fact about ''Peter Pan,'' the play by James M. Barrie, now approaching its centenary, is that Captain Hook was an afterthought. According to Andrew Birkin, author of ''J. M. Barrie and the Lost Boys,'' ''it was only due to the prosaic necessity of a 'front-cloth scene' to give the stagehands time to change the scenery . . . that Hook was conceived at all.'' An interlude on a pirate ship was added and Hook (''O man unfathomable,'' wrote his creator) was born. An expert dramatist like Barrie, already rich from a string of hit plays and books, knew his yarn needed a bad guy, but he thought he already had one: Peter himself. Birkin writes that among the over 700 notes for ''Peter Pan'' discovered in the 1980's was one reading ''P. a demon boy (villain of story).''

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Translucent Leather
description: When the first example of a pliable translucent leather appeared this year on the runway at Fendi, many in the audience assumed it was something else -- latex, perhaps. In fact, it was a treated version of the same brittle, waxy stuff used to make cowboy lampshades in the Southwest. But the confusion was not altogether surprising. Postmodernists like Karl Lagerfeld of Fendi and John Galliano, who also used the translucent leather in his Dior show (in the form of jeans), have made it impossible for us to look at fashion straight. In using a natural material to simulate the cold, clammy feeling of fetish gear, they have flipped the terms around. ''Natural'' can appear unnatural too. Certainly the 12 garments that Lagerfeld designed from the high-tech cowhide did not behave like garden-variety cowhide. They moved with a lightness, and you could see through them.

title: LOVE & TAXES
description: IN previous autobiographical solo shows, Josh Kornbluth expressed anxieties about growing up with Communist parents (''Red Diaper Baby'') and flunking calculus at Princeton University (''The Mathematics of Change''). But the subject of his latest show, ''Josh Kornbluth's Love & Taxes,'' which opened last week at the Bank Street Theater, inspires a more universal neurosis -- the I.R.S. Mr. Kornbluth, who wrote the monologue with his director, David Dower, performs what could be described as a tax nightmare. After not paying the government for seven years, he amassed a $27,000 debt that ballooned to $80,000 because of penalties, interest payments and an expensive bill from a holistic tax attorney/therapist. This excerpt is taken from the beginning of the show, when Mr. Kornbluth describes his job at the time, working, ironically, for a tax attorney. JASON ZINOMAN

title: Working Relationships
description: IT is, of course, all in the family.

title: Corrections
description: A roundup review of the year's books on architecture in the Book Review last Sunday misstated the given name of an architectural historian who contributed to ''Symphony: Frank Gehry's Walt Disney Concert Hall.'' She is Dana Hutt, not Diana.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Allison Charlene Bonner and Clinton Kenneth Shillingford misidentified the site at one point. As noted elsewhere in the report, it was Brooklyn. (The island of St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands is where the bridegroom's father lives and works.)

title: A One-Celled World Explored in Song, and Now in a Book
description: FROM swamp water seen under a microscope to novelty song to children's story -- that's the improbable route of the one-celled world explored in ''Amoeba Hop,'' a new book by Christine Lavin, the contemporary folksinger with Westchester roots.

title: Flying in the Face Of Mediocrity
description: We have how-to books for women, TV channels for women and now an entire airline (Jonathan Dee, Nov. 30). Golly! Please sign me up for the experience of ''appreciating the human transaction'' of paying for airline food!

title: INVESTING WITH: Jerome R. Powers; Westcore Plus Bond Fund
description: JEROME R. POWERS, lead manager of the $56 million Westcore Plus Bond fund, says he has been finding bargains among junk bonds.

title: Has Irrational Exuberance Hit China?
description: POWER plants in China cannot keep up with electricity demand, and so many steel mills are being built there that all the world's iron ore mines together may not be able to supply them adequately. Inflation, in the 12 months through November, ran at the fastest pace in six years, and the country's money supply is rising 20 percent a year.

title: A Wartime Parallel
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An essay and a picture caption last Sunday about memorial designs for the World Trade Center site referred incorrectly to the selection of the design of the Gateway Arch in St. Louis by Eero Saarinen, cited as an example of the way a landmark design should be chosen. The work was the winner of the Jefferson National Expansion Memorial design competition. It was not a direct commission.

title: A Fleet of Cruise Ships That Go Full Circle
description: The season of world cruises is about to begin, with at least five ships setting off in January. A new line, Discovery World Cruises, launched its sailings last month.

title: Suffolk Legislature Picks G.O.P. Presiding Officer
description: The Suffolk County Legislature's Republican caucus has chosen one of its own, Joseph Caracappa, to replace Maxine Postal, a Democrat, as presiding officer next year, apparently ending seven years of control by a cross-party coalition. Mr. Caracappa, 35, of Selden, was deputy presiding officer this year and ran recent legislative meetings while Ms. Postal was ill.

title: Seasonal Fade
description: A blizzard of pink clothing has slipcovered fashionable seasonal shoppers who usually favor Christmas red. It started last spring with the popular pink raincoat and has now spread to sidewalk vendors' hats and scarves and to designer fur coats. Everyone -- from city skiers in snowsuits, above, to a bicycle messenger, left -- is thinking pink.

title: Hardcover Highlights
description: NONFICTION | FICTION

title: Bentley Waters, Brendan Gaffney
description: Bentley Jane Waters, the daughter of Jeffrey Waters of New York and the late Dana Waters, was married yesterday to Brendan Joseph Gaffney, a son of Dr. Donna Gaffney and John T. Gaffney of Summit, N.J. The Rev. John J. Whalen officiated at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Manchester Center, Vt.

title: Teenager Shot to Death on Street After Being Chased From a Party
description: A Brooklyn teenager was shot to death early yesterday, shortly after he arrived at a party in a Crown Heights storefront.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: A Rutgers Comes Home

title: Boys in the Band
description: SKY HIGH

title: Bad Behavior at School
description: To the Editor:

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; G.I. Bill for College Athletes
description: Michael Kennedy is a 64-year-old professor of geography at the University of Kentucky who has never studied geography. He previously spent 20-odd years in Kentucky's school of architecture despite having no architectural training. So it is fitting that Kennedy, who also has zero experience in athletics, came up with an idea this year to fix big-time college sports. ''You don't need to be able to lay an egg,'' he says, ''to know when one is rotten.''

title: Executive Life; Boardroom to Duty Roster,  la Clark Kent
description: EXECUTIVES often say that one of their major duties is putting out fires. And then there are those who spend part of their free time as volunteer firefighters, or as police officers.

title: Colgate Thaws Out and Advances to I-AA Championship
description: After two weeks of winning in the snow, Colgate showed Saturday that it could win in the heat. As a result, the Raiders qualified for the Division I-AA national championship game on Friday.

title: Sports of The Times; In 1964, a Teenager Showed He Could Play
description: WHEN Maurice Clarett raised the possibility of jumping to the National Football League as an Ohio State freshman, the first person I thought of was Andy Livingston. Livingston was the Clarett of my generation -- a talented teenager who wanted to play pro football. He is the skeleton in the N.F.L.'s closet: tangible evidence that a teenager can be successful in the league.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Mind Over Matter, for Real
description: Consider the plight of a quadriplegic when confronted with an object that he wants to pick up. Though it sits directly in front of him, his desire to reach out and grab it is thwarted by his paralyzed body. But now there's hope: this year, scientists demonstrated that monkeys, properly trained and specially wired, can channel the mere thought of reaching and grasping into the actual reaching and grasping of a surrogate robotic arm. If all goes well, trials of the technology on humans will begin soon.

title: Hope Shines Through in a Winter Garden
description: A COLD wind tore through my garden last weekend, bringing the first snow and driving me and other warm-blooded creatures in for the winter's hibernation. But even though I am tempted to take to my couch, armed with luscious garden catalogs to dream of next year, I am admonished by the words of the late, great English gardener Rosemary Verey: ''A garden in winter is the absolute test of the true gardener.''

title: Husseins Capture Restores Sense of Unity Among World Leaders
description: LONDON, Dec. 14 — The capture of Saddam Hussein restored a sense of unity today among world leaders as they welcomed the seizure of one of the Middle East's most brutal dictators and expressed hope that his arrest would open a new chapter of stability and reconciliation in Iraq.

title: The Hidden War
description: To the Editor:

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Enough Debating -- Let's Start Hating
description: Liberals have long complained that the right overwhelms them with personal attacks and vicious allegations, while the left tries, navely, to make a more noble and substantive case. They certainly don't have to worry about that anymore. A new strand of vitriol has consumed the Bush-hating left. Just look in any bookstore, where the ''new and noteworthy'' table sports diverse works like Michael Moore's ''Dude, Where's My Country?''; Al Franken's ''Lies and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them''; ''Bushwhacked,'' by the Texas journalists Molly Ivins and Lou Dubose; Joe Conason's ''Big Lies''; ''The Lies of George W. Bush,'' by David Corn; and so on.

title: I Am a Soldier, Too
description: The recruiter said she would travel. Now, twenty months after enlistment, nineteen-year-old Private First Class Jessica Lynch steered her groaning diesel truck across a hateful landscape of grating sand and sucking mud, hauling four hundred gallons of water in the rough direction of Baghdad on a mission that just felt bad. Back home, boys with tears in their eyes had offered to marry her, to build her a brand-new house, anything, to get her to stay forever in the high, green lonesome. She told them no, told them she was going to see the world.

title: Chinese Toy Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics Makes Strange . . . Oh, It Was Just Breakfast
description: With all the reality dating shows on television and sagas of love won and lost on the Internet, it was only a matter of time before this sort of thing went political.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Ethical Sneaker, The
description: In an advertisement on the back of its September-October issue, Adbusters -- the magazine for the anticorporate, culture-jamming set -- announced a new wrinkle in its continuing campaign to cause headaches for Nike and its C.E.O., Phil Knight. The ad read: ''Phil Knight had a dream. He'd sell shoes. He'd sell dreams. He'd get rich. He'd use sweatshops if he had to. Then along came a new shoe. Plain. Simple. Cheap. Fair. Designed for only one thing. Kicking Phil's [expletive].''

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Sir Ian McKellen; Middle Earth Ambassador
description: SIR IAN McKELLEN stood in the porte-cochere at the Four Seasons Hotel in Beverly Hills one recent evening, demonstrating how tired he was for Andy Serkis, his co-star in ''Lord of the Rings: Return of the King,'' and for Mr. Serkis's wife, the actress Lorraine Ashbourne. ''I'm not bearing up,'' admitted Sir Ian, who plays Gandalf, mock-buckling his long legs.

title: Sports of The Times; Schilling and Pettitte Throw Agents a Changeup
description: STANDING tall in Astros pinstripes, with his wife and children happily circling him like Whos around the tree in Whoville, Andy Pettitte displayed the peace of a man liberated from an oppressive Boss.

title: Antique Sales Slow and Shops Are Closing
description: EDWARD CARNEY stepped into Greenwillow Antiques in Cannondale not to buy, but in the hope of selling advertising space in a TransWestern phone directory. Instead, he heard a familiar refrain from antiques dealers. Business is down and they won't be buying much advertising until things improve.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Bite-Size Nukes
description: For 50 years the United States has maintained nuclear weapons with the express intention of not using them. Nukes keep the peace, the thinking goes; they are more about threatened payback than military utility. But there's a new school of thought among military thinkers: maybe we should all learn to stop worrying and love the Bomb -- at least in miniature.

title: Stepping Out With My Baby, Gingerly
description: THE wedding couple's traditional first dance is a riveting moment. All eyes turn as the music swells and the couple sweep onto the floor. Yet surprisingly few couples give the moment much thought, and it shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUGGAR, GEORGE S.
description: DUGGAR--George S. of Medford, OR (formerly of Belmont, CA) on November 30, 2003 in his sleep, aged 88. Professor Duggar's early (pre-and post-World War II) research in urban geography, urban renewal planning and forecasting housing demand blossomed into later studies of public finance which influenced urban planning and renewal. His long and brilliant career included work with the New York and San Francisco Planning Departments, a stint with the OSS, and directing the new UN Center for Regional Development in Nagoya, Japan. He taught at numerous universities in the US and outside of it, and was a published author. He is survived by his wife, Margaret Pelton (''Peg'') Duggar, 1200 Mira Mar #

title: Pakistani Inquiry Reveals Details of a Woman's 'Honor Killing'
description: News of the death of Afsheen Musarrat, 22, quickly gave rise to speculation.

title: What Bashir Saw, What New York Became
description: TEN years ago, when the City section was new, a former engineering student from Kabul staked his claim to a patch of Times Square, crossroads of the world, mall under construction. He is still there on the northwest corner of 43rd Street and Broadway, in a city that has changed profoundly yet remained the same.

title: From a Cider Mill Site To Luxury Homes
description: Construction began this week on 27 luxury homes that will be built on the site of the former Schultz's Cider Mill, the 80-year-old farm stand that became an institution in Armonk. The high-end endeavor by Antares, a real estate company based in Greenwich, Conn., is being touted by the developer as ''the most exclusive gated community ever to be built in Westchester.'' The company bought the property for $13 million in October from Michael Fareri.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Coincidence Theory
description: More than half of Americans believe in ''anomalous phenomena'' like clairvoyance, unexplained coincidence, prayer healing and psychokinesis. Yet mainstream science remains unconvinced. After all, these anomalies appear to fly in the face of everything we know about how mind and matter interact. But that may be about to change. This year, Elizabeth Lloyd Mayer, a professor of psychology at the University of California, Berkeley, introduced a conceptual model to explain seemingly inexplicable events scientifically.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; New Tools for an Occupation
description: During the invasion of Iraq, the American military displayed amazing technological superiority, firing missiles that flew nearly 1,000 miles before hitting their targets precisely, with a margin of error of just a few feet. Once the occupation of Iraq began, though, the military faced a whole new array of challenges: car bombs, donkey-drawn rocket launchers and improvised explosive devices. And what did the Pentagon pull from its shock-and-awe cupboard then?

title: A Laboratory for Sign Language
description: CHASE BANK, PBS, Barneys New York, Mobil Oil: few corporate logos, posters or shopping bags are as familiar as these and scores of others created over the last 40 years by the graphic-design firm Chermayeff & Geismar. Yet while its work is ubiquitous, the firm's name is largely unknown. Since graphic design is usually unsigned, even the most prolific creators are rarely recognized outside a small professional circle. Now an exhibition, ''Chermayeff & Geismar Inc: Designing Over Four Decades'' at the Cooper Union School of Art in Manhattan (through Feb. 21), and a new book, ''Designing'' (Graphis Press), is putting the firm's identity in front of its most notable work for the first time.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Ultracams
description: It was an astonishing year for sports-viewing couch potatoes. Consider these developments. In its coverage of the U.S. Open tennis tournament, the USA Network enlisted something called Hawk-Eye ball-tracking technology, which used super-slow-motion cameras to clearly show whether 140-mile-per-hour serves had landed a millimeter inside or outside of the service box. Fox Sports used what it calls Mega Super Slo Mo, mesmerizing postseason viewers with impossibly intimate visions (at a rate of 7,000 frames per second) of the rotation of pitched baseballs. NBC employed stop-motion analysis of golf swings, and ESPN blurred even further the line between sports viewing and video gaming with its under-the-hoop floor cam, which allowed for a sneaker's-eye view of gigantic men throwing down mighty dunks.

title: At a Factory Outlet in the Bronx, Pas de Deux on the Cheap
description: THE SETTING -- A warehouse on a desolate side street in the South Bronx last weekend. A snowstorm whipped snowdrifts against the brick walls, half burying the only car on the street, and a small paper sign was the only hint of KD Dids' dance wear factory.

title: Corrections
description: The L.I.@Work column on Nov. 23, about the rechartering of several credit unions on Long Island, misstated the ranking of one of them, the Bethpage Federal Credit Union. It is the second-largest on the Island; the Teachers Federal Credit Union, based in Farmingville, surpassed Bethpage in total assets this year. The article also misidentified the credit union that has enrolled the largest number of Long Island school employees. It is Teachers, not the Suffolk Federal Credit Union.

title: A Finale Of Sweets
description: When you uncork the slender, graceful bottle of Duck Walk's 2001 Blueberry Port, you imagine you're in a blueberry distillery. The fruit virtually gushes out, powered by 19 percent alcohol. You put a small amount in a glass, inhale, sip, and you're ready to meet winter head-on.

title: Building a Better Bra Shop
description: Thank you for highlighting the unpleasantness of department-store bra shopping. I have walked out in frustration more often than I have made a purchase. Perhaps if the sales staff were paid on commission or were replaced by underwear fetishists who at least seemed interested in the merchandise.

title: Film Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: Clemens Will Take a Month To Decide on a Comeback
description: Roger Clemens will decide in about 30 days whether he wants to stay retired or pitch next season for the Astros, his agent said Saturday.

title: NO RISE IN GAS TAX
description: A proposal to increase the state gasoline tax was derailed last week when Governor McGreevey said he would not support the measure -- at least for now -- because he feared it would smother the state's economic recovery. A commission appointed by the governor had said that without the increase, the state's Transportation Trust Fund would soon run out of money to pay for construction and repair of roads and bridges. The increase had the backing of construction unions and some business groups, but many drivers opposed it. Democratic lawmakers were unable to win support from Republicans, even after they proposed using some of the tax increase to eliminate the highly unpopular tolls on the Garden State Parkway.

title: Inventing a Nation
description: In the fall of 1786 the fifty-four-year-old president of the Potomac Company, George Washington, late commander in chief of the American army (resigned December 23, 1783, after eight years of active duty) was seriously broke. Majestically, he had refused any salary from the revolutionary American government so seldom in useful Congress assembled. But it had always been agreed that should their cause be victorious, Congress would pay the General's expenses, which it did, with some awe at Washington's meticulous bookkeeping and lavish way of life-Congress had to cough up $100,000.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Makeup for Men
description: Heretofore, men's personal grooming has been more a matter of maintenance than augmentation; a haircut as opposed to a henna treatment. But in this age of rampant metrosexuality, when even Maxim magazine has its own line of hair color for men, the arrival of Jean Paul Gaultier's Tout Beau seems a cultural inevitability. Tout Beau is the first line of makeup specifically aimed at men. According to a Gaultier press release, the Tout Beau line -- including a powder bronzer, a concealer and kohl liner for eyes and lip balm in three shades: natural, fair skin and tawny -- is a ''bold, virile line of revolutionary tools'' designed to ''enhance masculinity'' and ''offer each and every man the right to be naturally handsome.''

title: Coming Back as an Atheist
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; A Hobson's Choice at a Hospital in Valhalla: A Cut in Pay, or No Job
description: IN a narrow office at the Westchester Medical Center here, Andrew Stasko reached into his desk and produced a business card: ''Chief of Cardiac Perfusion,'' it read.

title: PULSE: Gifts for Small Packages; Two Hoops, No Waiting
description: For children, the holidays are pure, happy promise -- no long lines for them, no dense shopping crowds, only an abundance of receiving and believing. Despite this year's resurgence of plastic toys like Barbie and G.I. Joe, parents may still find stylish ways to decorate their offspring in finery and fun. Here are some of the season's gladdest offerings for the stroller and schoolyard set.

title: King Absorbs a Shot, but Keeps Swinging
description: These are frustrating times for Don King. Instead of crashing the airwaves for call-in interviews, blitzing television shows or staging outrageous public stunts to promote last night's eight-fight card in Atlantic City, King spent much of the past five weeks in a small first-floor courtroom at State Supreme Court in Lower Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDINER, JAMES BRONSON II.
description: GARDINER--James Bronson II. 1st New York Continental Chapter, Sons of the American Revolution, mourn the passing of Compatriot Gardiner, who died December 11, 2003. He was 95 years young. Jim joined the SAR in 1952, and became President of the New York Chapter, President of the Empire State Society and President-General of the National Society from 1969 to 1970. In 1995, Jim became a founding Charter Member of the 1st New York Chapter. We are deeply saddened by Jim's death, but we celebrate his long and productive life. Wesley Oler, President

title: The King of Retail, in the Spotlight
description: To the Editor:

title: For Democrats, It's Union vs. Union in Iowa Race
description: It was 9 degrees, and the shivering, stomping union members were pressing political fliers into the gloved hands of scores of steelworkers outside the Firestone plant here. ''Support Dick Gephardt!'' shouted John Campbell, 47, this week as he mingled with the men starting their shift.

title: Looking Back In Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Indiana Seeks to Give Coach A Championship Parting Gift
description: The Indiana men's soccer team has certainly grown under Coach Jerry Yeagley, developing into one of the nation's best.

title: The World; In India, a New Heyday for English (the Language)
description: IT seemed an unorthodox, even risky, career move when Birbal Jha, then a 21-year-old with a master's degree in economics, started the British Lingua, an English coaching center, 10 years ago. There was only one other English-language coaching institute in this city in Bihar, a state that is a center of Hindi nationalism.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 23 about online dating misstated the address of a Web site for men seeking casual sex with other men. It is m4m4sex.com.

title: The Hunt for Bin Laden Is More Complex, Experts Say
description: It took about eight months for American troops to find Saddam Hussein and capture him in an underground hideout in Iraq, an accomplishment that prompted President Bush to say today that the United States would now move forward in the war on terror "capture by capture, cell by cell, and victory by victory."

title: Flawed Process
description: To the Editor:

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Sampling Bob Griese
description: ''Throwback'' jerseys and caps -- gear emblazoned with the logos of old sports teams -- are all the rage. What makes the jersey of a particular player popular is hard to fathom: it's a mysterious blend of fame, fashion and obscurity.

title: Missed Tackles by Jets Put Defense in Disarray
description: There have been days this season when running backs moving through the front seven of the Jets' defense have looked like steel balls careering off the flippers of a pinball machine, the amount of yardage and missed tackles rolling up as quickly as the points in an arcade game.

title: Vandalism Goes Beyond Just Bad Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Winter Makes An Entrance
Michelle Saposnick, Matthew Halpern
description: Dr. Michelle Lauren Saposnick, a daughter of Myles M. Saposnick of Ardsley, N.Y., and the late Carol J. Saposnick, was married last evening to Dr. Matthew Evan Halpern, the son of Sheila H. Halpern and Leonard B. Halpern of Wynnewood, Pa. Rabbi Sholom Stern performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

title: Susan Laufer, Jason Krauss
description: Susan Jonas Laufer, the daughter of Patricia Jonas Laufer and Robert L. Laufer of New York, was married last evening to Michael Jason Krauss, a son of Rita Krauss and Herbert I. Krauss, also of New York. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Vote Getters
description: A run for office should be about the ideas candidates have, not about the best image on a campaign poster or button. Gail Collins's feature only brings light to the fact that we as voters do not take the time to ''hunker down'' and make an educated choice about our leaders. Hope this is a taste of reality to those who vote for the candidate with the ''jazziest'' poster

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Suspended Nationhood
description: There are no good peacekeeping ideas. The best ideas are merely the least bad among dangerous, difficult and costly alternatives. One new idea, floated this year in response to three of the world's most intractable conflicts, was actually to resurrect an old idea: colonial-era trusteeship.

title: Life on a Banana Peel: Elliott Erwitt's View Of an Absurd Cosmos
description: IF you need a smile during the holidays, drop in on ''Elliott Erwitt: Leica Lifetime Achievement Award 2003,'' through Jan. 3 at the Leica Gallery on Broadway and Bond Street. Over the years Mr. Erwitt has produced a passel of photographs to smile at (and, for ballast, some to be very serious about). He recently turned 75 and still packs a grin in his camera bag and carries it around. He attended the opening of his 60-work show in a Japanese traffic policeman's vest lighted up brighter than a Christmas tree. He sometimes answers the telephone saying simply ''Speaking.''

title: A Boss for the Boss
description: The collapse of Enron and WorldCom, the fall from grace of Martha Stewart and Richard Grasso and the humbling of Wall Street in general have spawned new legislation, regulatory reforms, criminal prosecutions, lawsuits, books, articles and -need we add? -- stock-market losses. It has also spawned a revolution.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 16 about a fatal gangway collapse on the Queen Mary 2 at St.-Nazaire in western France referred imprecisely to the ship's ranking. At 1,132 feet in length and a cost of $800 million, it is the largest and costliest of passenger vessels, but not of vessels over all.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Thunder Run, The
description: A convention of military strategy is that you do not rush tanks into the center of a hostile city unless you wish to lose them. In 1994 the Russians learned this fatal lesson when they sent an armored column into Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, and guerrillas picked the tanks off with rocket-propelled grenades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOSES, IDA K. (NEE KATZ)
description: MOSES--Ida K. (nee Katz), on December 11, 2003 at age of 88. Born in Englewood, NJ, lived many years in Rockland Co., NY, Palm Beach Gardens and Oviedo, FL. Beloved wife of late David H. Moses; mother of Dr. Lois M. Shofer, Annapolis, MD and Naples, FL; Ken Moses, Stillwell, MN. Grandmother of Larry Isaacs, N. Grafton, MA; Amy Edwards, Plantation, FL; M. David Shofer, Baltimore, MD; and Lauren M. Shofer, Lombard, IL. Great-grandmother of Justin and Matthew Isaacs. Also survived by two wonderful nieces, Reba Reznick, Winter Springs, FL and Elaine Langsam, Massapequa, NY.

title: The King of Retail, in the Spotlight (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column on Nov. 30, with a passage about the word ''twit,'' misstated the given name of a columnist for The Washington Post who used it recently. He is David Ignatius; Paul, his father, was secretary of the navy in the late 1960's and was president of The Post.

title: The Siege, the Battle, the Fairy Tale
description: ''Forget the Alamo'' is the prescription for racial and cultural harmony given by a character in John Sayles's ''Lone Star,'' a 1996 film about modern Texas. ''I doubt if that's going to happen anytime soon,'' is the response of Beth Dietrich Segarra, executive producer of ''Remember the Alamo,'' a two-hour documentary that has its premiere Tuesday night at 9. ''What we need to do is to get straight exactly what about the Alamo we should remember.''

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Fish-Eater's Cheat Sheet, The
description: The plight of the modern American restaurant-goer: first we examine the menu, then we examine our conscience. The steak dinner has become a guilt trip, and veal an unforgivable sin. Chicken is out unless it's organic and free range and properly educated.

title: A Fast Boat to Rochester?
description: The relationship between this city and Toronto, its Canadian neighbor to the northwest, has all the drama these days of two rival middle schools fighting over who's best.

title: Slaves in the Family
description: INVENTING A NATION

title: Not Everything Is Bigger in Texas
description: In the remote high country of West Texas, altitude 5,050 feet, this ranching and tourist community offers itself as Denver without the snow and the traffic. It is a dusty speck of a place, unincorporated, starkly beautiful, featuring blue-jean informality and life uncomplicated by locked doors and stoplights.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Quiet Parties
description: Fran Lebowitz once said that if she could will any technological innovation into existence, it would be a silence machine: turn it on, and all those cellphones, beeping trucks and -- worst of all -- human voices that pollute our lives would instantly be hushed.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: WAR TORN

title: Restoring Order in a Cataclysmic Symphony
description: SHORTLY after conducting the premiere of his Sixth Symphony in 1906, Gustav Mahler concluded that the work was destined to be a ''hard nut, one that our critics' feeble little teeth cannot crack.'' And indeed, the Sixth continues to puzzle scholars and to shock listeners. It is Mahler's only symphony ending in utter despair. Naked death triumphs.

title: Science Called, And He Followed
description: THE art on the office wall of Dr. Roger Knowles features an indistinct shape that could be a cloud, a partial shoeprint or the stain from a pot of green paint tipped on its side.

title: Tales From the Apple-Pie-Baking Wars
description: JUST in time for the holiday baking season, Whole Foods in Millburn held an apple pie-baking contest. Although the store expected at least 15 entries (the judges didn't think they could handle any more pies in one sitting) only 9 contestants showed up. Hot yoga is in; pie-baking is about as popular as Martha Stewart.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Hammock Doesn't Work Anymore, The
description: Television networks have long counted on viewer loyalty -- or, if you prefer, laziness: people's tendency to sit through subpar shows sandwiched between their favorite ones. But this year TV execs have noticed a disturbing trend: viewers finally seem to have figured out how to use their remote controls. Much as kids are now thinking more in terms of downloadable singles than of filler-heavy albums, TV watchers are focusing more narrowly on their best-loved shows and ignoring the networks' also-rans.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Getting On With Life After Nearly Losing It

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRESCO, LEON E.
description: FRESCO--Leon E. April 19, 1915 to December 10, 2003. Son of the late Emanuel and Leah Fresco. Beloved husband to the late Doris. A World War II veteran, he served as Captain in the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers in the South Pacific. Loving father, grandfather, uncle, brother, and friend to many. Funeral services in Florida.

title: Bring Back the Gods
description: GREEK GODS, HUMAN LIVES

title: Around Central Park, Building by Building
description: MANHATTAN WITHIN: A Journal

title: Does Your Pet Need A Gym Membership?

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Time Gap, The
description: In 1972 the superaccurate atomic clocks that keep the world's official time were ''paused'' for precisely one second. This little-noticed leap second was a crude solution to a problem that began five years earlier, when atomic clocks replaced the rotation of the earth as the authoritative instrument for measuring time. Because atomic clocks are more consistent than the earth (which slows slightly almost every year), the earth had fallen one second behind. To help the planet keep pace, 31 additional leap seconds have been added since 1972.

In its broad rivers and quiet canals and noble palaces, in its narrow streets and cramped passages, elegance and squalor still coexist; the city echoes with possibility and despair. ''I love thee, Peter's own creation,/I love thy stern and comely face,'' declared Pushkin. He and other great Russian writers lived there; recently I visited four of their homes.

title: Players Without a Program
description: Hollywood always prefers its fiction  clef, so if there's a vaguely gossipy quality to DANGEROUS COMPANY: Dark Tales From Tinseltown (Miramax, $22.95), Peter Bart's collection of interrelated short stories, that just means the author knows his target demo. As editor in chief of Variety, the entertainment industry's most influential trade publication, Bart makes friends and enemies in roughly equal measure; before taking over the magazine, he was a studio executive at Paramount and MGM. Having achieved a unique kind of power -- in Hollywood, headlines from the trades often carry the weight of papal bulls -- Bart is beyond using mere fiction to settle scores or curry favor. Indeed, his mission here at times seems more akin to earnest undergraduate crusading than Tinseltown dishing. Several stories explore issues of ageism, lookism and homophobia among writers, actors and producers; another story argues intelligently for a reconsideration of the ratings system by which mature sexual content automatically condemns certain motion pictures to art-house obscurity. Too often, though, these stories have the cursory feel of a pitch made over the last bites of dessert at Orso. At the heart of ''Friend of the Family,'' in which a dueling producer and director finally discover a compelling reason to cooperate, is little more than a third-act plot twist dressed up as emotional conflict. And the unifying conceit of Bart's stories -- that all the characters either live on or frequent an exclusive street in the Hollywood Hills -- would be more at home in a nighttime soap opera than serious fiction. Still, it's fun to play along and guess which real-life figures Bart has in mind as he editorializes about all that's venal and vicious in the city whose rules he helped draft. Jeff Turrentine

title: Greek Gods, Human Lives
description: The ancient Greeks did not have a sacred text like the Bible. No one decided what versions of the myths were authoritative. Authors were free to tell the stories as they chose, with their own emphasis, provided they preserved the principal characters and basic plots. The Greeks learned about the gods from poetry written in the eighth and seventh centuries B.C., the most important and influential of which, Hesiod's Theogony and Works and Days , and the great epics attributed to Homer, the Iliad and the Odyssey , still survive. Hesiod's poem Theogony offers an account of the beginnings of the world and a genealogy of the gods, detailing their names and how they are related to one another. At the same time, it explains why, in a world with so many different gods, the lives of humankind are dominated by a particular family of gods on Mount Olympus, the head of which is Zeus. Hesiod describes how Zeus came to be the most important god and shows why it is better for the world as a whole that Zeus (rather than his predecessors) is in charge. Hesiod's Works and Days tells myths that explain why Zeus has made life hard for humans and why they must work to survive while the gods live at their ease, free from cares.

''There he found lizards and porcupines. . . insects and grubs, and made them part of his diet.'' Things pretty much took off from there. Cavemen discovered fire -- and cooking; civilizations sprang up on the fertile land bordering great rivers. Explorers went off in search of spices; noodles were brought back from China. The Egyptians figured out how to leaven bread; the Syrians and Palestinians developed an oil-rich olive. Somewhere along the way lots of people made the joyous discovery that everything from grain to grapes could be fermented.
