title: Imposing a 'Flip Tax' Retroactively
description: Q. While transferring the minutes of our co-op shareholder and board meetings from paper copies to a computer disk, I came across an amendment passed by the board in 1983 that may have never been exercised. The amendment stated that an additional 1.5 percent of the sale price ''be paid to the co-op at the time of closing, by certified check.'' There have been four apartments resold since 1983 and there is no record of this amendment ever being referred to. It was the buyer who was to pay the additional 1.5 percent, not the seller. Is the amendment still valid? Can these funds still be collected from the present shareholders of these apartments? R. R. Call, Manhattan.

title: Editorial Observer; Nowadays, Owning a Ball Club Means Always Having to Say You're Sorry
description: All those humiliating Monday mornings, and nobody ever told me he was sorry. As a kid growing up in Mexico in the 1970's I rooted for Atltico Espaol, a soccer team whose ineptitude caused me endless grief. But in distinct contrast to the self-flagellation and contrition consuming the National Football League's disappointing teams this season, Atltico's management didn't seem to feel any particular need to account for its performance.

title: Jeffersons Demons
description: am burning the candle of life," he told a friend, "without present pleasure, or future object." "A dozen or twenty years ago this scene would have amused me," he said. "But I am past the age for changing habits." Under the perpetual dullness of the winter sky, Jefferson contemplated the "empty bustle" of Paris and studied the means by which the beautiful people in that city sought to escape their demons.

title: Sturgis Riddle, 94, Dean Emeritus At Episcopal Cathedral in Paris
description: The Very Rev. Sturgis Lee Riddle, dean emeritus of the American Episcopal Cathedral in Paris, died on Tuesday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Introduction
description: The theme of our Design issue was inspiration, but many readers were inspired instead to offer advice on political candidates, on publishing a book, on shopping for and selling lingerie. Some offered facetious suggestions for the all-frills airline. Others called the AirTrain a good thing.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Real Man's Wiffle Ball, The
description: One day about eight years ago, a former minor-league pitcher named Chris Mackie had a vision of a ''plastic ball that played like a real baseball,'' one that, unlike a Wiffle ball, wouldn't curve all willy-nilly when thrown or be irreparably dented the first time a batter made contact. So Mackie started tinkering, and after several tries, he came up with the Quickball, a plastic sphere that is a half-inch smaller in diameter than a Wiffle ball but twice as thick. Whereas the Wiffle has elongated holes on only one hemisphere (and therefore unpredictably rises or dips or curves), the Quickball has holes on both sides, arranged symmetrically for balanced air flow, and raised seams that allow for control over a variety of pitches.

description: Between Paris Hilton's exploits and the comedy/tragedy masks of MTV's ''Rich Girls,'' it's been a big year for spoiled girl humiliation. But while these real-life spectacles may be diverting, none can hold a candle to the antics of TV rich girl Nellie Oleson, the sociopathic villainess of ''Little House on the Prairie.''

title: Republicans Turn Efforts to the Uninsured
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13  Fresh from their victory on Medicare, Congressional Republicans and the Bush administration say they are planning a new initiative to help provide health insurance to people under 65 who have no coverage.

The Rigler-Deutsch Feeding Centers in NACOEJ Compounds in Addis Ababa and Gondar, Ethiopia, daily serve thousands of nourishing meals to destitute and malnourished Jewish women and children, enabling them to survive famine, disease and poverty while waiting to make Aliyah. title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Give Felons the Vote
description: More than 4.6 million Americans -- or 2 percent of the voting-age population -- are barred from voting because of a criminal record. Because more than 60 percent of the prison population is black or Latino, the voting power of these groups is disproportionately diluted. Nationwide, 1 in 8 African-American men is denied the right to vote because of a prison record. In Florida -- and in Alabama, until recently -- the number is nearly 1 in 3.

title: Blas F. Ople, 76, Philippine Secretary, Dies
description: MANILA, Dec. 14  The Philippine foreign affairs secretary died today in a hospital in Taiwan after falling ill on an airplane flight, officials and family members said.

title: A Former Drug Agency Official Faces Charges of Stealing Funds
description: A former senior official in the Drug Enforcement Administration's New York office is expected to be charged this week with stealing more than $150,000 from the agency's funds used to pay informants and other incidental expenses, according to a law enforcement official.

title: The World; When the Chinese Consumer Is King
description: FOR decades, the United States was the world's only significant mass market, offering businesses more than enough consumers to buy up ever greater volumes of their merchandise and services. To gain access to all these consumers, companies had to operate inside the country. And they could do so very profitably, because they benefited from economies of scale, meaning that each item coming off an assembly line was less expensive to produce than the one before.

description: Ethel Winant, who became one of the first female executives in network television when she was awarded a vice president's title at CBS in 1973, died on Nov. 29 at a hospital in Canoga Park, Calif. She was 81.

description: WITH the cunning of a baseball stadium habitu, the little girl with strawberry-blond hair scanned the empty front-row seats below her at last Sunday's matinee of ''A Christmas Carol'' here at the Bay Street Theater.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Labor Disputes Can Be Deadly for Consumers
description: Since the rollover crisis involving Firestone tires and (mostly) Ford Explorers became public three years ago, investigators have proposed a number of different theories for the blowouts, yet none have proved wholly satisfying. Though it's clear that a single Bridgestone/Firestone plant in Decatur, Ill., produced many of the flawed tires, a Firestone study found no ''one overriding factor'' behind the failures. Some tires seemed to have impurities in the rubber that bound the steel belt, while others had problems in the area between the tire's steel belt and its so-called shoulder.

title: Inspiration: Where Does It Come From?
description: Where, indeed! Arthur Lubow (Nov. 30) says that ''artists are influenced primarily by other artists.'' There are, however, other, perhaps greater, influences: nature; the zeitgeist; the social, intellectual, religious, spiritual and political environments; even the subconscious. Dreams may trigger the ''eureka!'' effect, and the company of a muse helps. The Shakers, creators of some of the most significant early-American designs, acknowledged inspiration and talent to be a divine gift. Ultimately, the phenomenon of inspiration remains a mystery.

title: The World; The Hot Titles On Baghdad's Mutanabi Street
description: FOR more than 12 years, in a bustling square mile of curbside commerce featuring everything from pets and auto parts to cigarettes and Arab fashion, Faris Mahdi has sold books. For most of that time, it has been a dicey business, with Saddam Hussein's Sunni-dominated regime banishing many texts to the underground, particularly those on Shiite Islam. No more.

title: Captain Yee's Ordeal
description: The military's mean-spirited and incompetent prosecution of Capt. James Yee, the former Muslim chaplain at Guantnamo Bay, illustrates the danger of allowing the war on terrorism to trump basic rights. After holding Captain Yee in solitary confinement for nearly three months, and smearing him with adultery and pornography charges, the military is now uncertain whether the documents whose confidentiality he is charged with breaching were even confidential. In the interest of justice, and of resurrecting their own reputation, military prosecutors should drop the case.

When the ballots were tabulated and the totals announced last night, White, the Sooners' senior quarterback, emerged as the 69th winner of the Heisman Trophy as the outstanding college football player in the United States.

title: Record Snowfalls Bring Utah Skiers Out Early
description: After much anxiety earlier this fall, when National Weather Services forecasters predicted a winter dry spell in the Rocky Mountains, the region's ski-resort operators were relieved when an early-November shift in the jet stream delivered a steady blast of storms from the Northwest. The Wasatch Mountains in Utah, in particular, received more than 11 feet of snow in November at ski resorts like Alta and Brighton, surpassing the total snowfall record for that month.

Inside is a recently retired Concorde, stunt planes, fighter planes, and the prototypes for the Space Shuttle. Also inside is the Enola Gay, the plane that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, and protesters say they will be outside on opening day, because the exhibit describes only the plane, and not the effects of the bomb. title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Futures Markets in Everything
description: Even for an institution accustomed to P.R. fiascos, the Pentagon hit something of a milestone this year with its aborted Policy Analysis Market, or PAM. The idea was to find an efficient way of collecting a wide range of expert opinion about threats to national security. To do this, the Pentagon created a futures market -- a cross between a betting pool and a stock market -- in which government officials and other experts would buy and sell ''assets,'' or futures, linked to developments in the Middle East. An asset might be, say, an imminent terrorist attack in Jordan. If experts believed that such an event was likely, they'd snatch up the asset, and its value would rise. Though individual investors would stand to benefit, the real beneficiary would be U.S. policy makers, who'd get otherwise diffuse opinion distilled into a single, easy-to-interpret number: the price of a future.

And for all the clamor for dwindling supplies of vaccine, no one knows how effective the current vaccine will be against the Fujian strain.

title: Letting 'Let It Be' Be: McCartney Wins
description: WHEN the Beatles broke up in 1970, the band's manager handed tapes of the ''Let It Be'' recording sessions to the producer Phil Spector and asked him to assemble them into an album. By all accounts, John Lennon was happy with the finished product, but not all the other Beatles were. Layered with Mr. Spector's orchestral touches, it was very different from the back-to-basics project they had envisioned. So last year Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr asked engineers at Abbey Road Studios to go back to those very same tapes and put together a different album with most of the same songs.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Billboards That Know You
description: Does it sometimes seem as if the billboards you pass on your daily commute are targeted to appeal to people exactly like you? Well, depending on where you drive, it could be that the billboards are listening in on your car radio as you drive past. Using a specially equipped dish manufactured by Mobiltrak, a Phoenix company, advertisers are now able to detect which radio stations drivers are listening to and then alter the messages on their electronic billboards to match the demographic that clusters around those stations.

title: Where There's Smoking Gun, There's Fire
description: ON Thursday afternoon, William Bastone, the editor of the Smoking Gun Web site, stood in a private dining room on the second floor of Planet Hollywood in New York, listing people who hate him and his organization.

title: Page Two: The Week Ahead; ENVIRONMENT
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to introduce a proposal this week that would regulate mercury emissions from power plants. The proposal, similar to market-based programs that helped reduce acid rain, would allow coal-burning power companies to buy and sell the rights to mercury emissions. Environmental groups argue that market-based trading works well for pollutants that disperse easily, like sulfur dioxide, which contributes to acid rain, and nitrogen oxides, which contribute to smog. But hazardous toxics like mercury tend to concentrate near the power plants that emit it.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: SCREENWRITERS have enough trouble without being asked to make orchid horticulture sexy. But in Spike Jonze's wacky ADAPTATION (2002), that is exactly what the screenwriter Charlie Kaufman (Nicolas Cage, not as his most appealing) is asked to do. If only orchids incited sex, drugs and violent deaths! Meryl Streep plays Susan Orlean, the real author of the real book ''The Orchid Thief.'' She's a writer for The New Yorker, not the sort of woman you'd expect to be attracted to a virtually toothless redneck (Chris Cooper, who won the best supporting actor Oscar). So when she says, of him, ''It's intoxicating to be around someone so alive,'' you know something's up. Ms. Streep's best scene is playing stoned, fascinated by her toes and imitating a dial tone -- Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 4:10 a.m. on HBO.

title: Spinks Silences Mayorga in a Stunner
description: Ricardo Mayorga, the fighter from Managua, Nicaragua, who was seemingly on his way to becoming fighter of the year, stumbled badly on Saturday night when Cory Spinks scored a shocking 12-round majority decision to become the undisputed welterweight champion.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Jules Verne Project, The
description: The dream of exploring our planet's center is probably as old as our understanding that the earth is round -- or, more precisely, spherical -- and therefore has a center. But until this May, when David Stevenson, a professor at Caltech, proposed a real-physics method for getting probes to Earth's molten outer core, it has been an idea strictly for dreamers like Jules Verne and the makers of this year's science-fiction movie ''The Core.'' After all, we're talking about a place where it's about 4,000 degrees Celsius and pressures are up to 3.5 million times as great as up here on the surface. Worse, though the outer core lies only about 1,800 miles down -- around the distance from New York to Denver -- there's a solid mantle of rock to get through every inch of the way. As of right now, the deepest that we've ever dug is an anemic seven miles or so, at the Kola Peninsula well near Murmansk, Russia. The drill bit got stuck in rock in 1989, and the project was abandoned.

description: GORDON--Mollie on December 7, 2003, 96 years old. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Mother of Joan Langer and the late Carol Gordon. Grandmother of David (Nancy), Robert (Jennifer), Jonathan (Debra) great-grandmother of six. Services were private.

title: For a Local Artist, an Inaugural Unveiling
description: THE early reviews are upbeat for a Darien artist's portrait of President George W. Bush, which went on permanent display at the Yale Club in New York City on Monday night.

title: Frame After Frame, It's a Varsity Sport
description: THE seven members of the team are not easily tilted by the prospect of a winless season. That is a good thing because, by their own admission, that could very well be the way they are headed.

title: The Disability Gulag
description: Having cared for a man who is a quadriplegic for nearly 20 years, I read the article with a certain knowledge about the subject. Johnson spoke about freedoms, and she is absolutely correct. Most disabled people are fully capable of making their needs known to their caregivers -- people like me.

title: The Disability Gulag
description: Johnson's article was very powerful and yet, at the same time, troubling. It was written to, among other things, support passage of federal legislation called MiCassa, the Medicaid Community Assistance Services and Supports Act, a well-intended but ultimately unaffordable bill that aspires to provide one-on-one, in-home care for persons with disabilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRATON, JOHN D., JR.
description: STRATON--John D., Jr., on December 10, 2003. Beloved husband of Marie Louise, loving father of Joseph, Paul and the late Laurence. Dear brother of Beatrice A. Straton. Devoted father-in-law of Sarah, cherished grandfather of Jack and Emma. Friends may call Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9:30 at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue, Floral Park, NY (at RR Plaza). 516354-0634. Mass of Christian burial, Monday, 10:30am at St. Anne's R.C. Church, 35 Dartmouth St, Garden City, N.Y. 11530. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Lying in Wait for Deer, Actually Loaded for Bear
description: GALILEE, Pa.

title: A Magic Elixir For the Noses on the Vitrine
description: IF less is more, then nothing must be everything.

title: For Music Teachers, a Few Bars of 'Joe Hill'
description: Since the early 1980's, Catherine Aks has taught voice at the Elaine Kaufman Cultural Center on West 67th Street, working up to 13 hours a week. She received no health or retirement benefits, and she would have liked more consistent pay raises from year to year, but like most of the teachers she accepted her lot. Music teachers, she noted, are not known as the loudest horns in the orchestra.

title: A Brow Uncovered, Then Unfurrowed
description: Jennifer Lopez and Assemblyman Stephen Kaufman have one thing in common beyond their Bronx roots. Both have depended mightily on double-sided tape: she during the 2000 Grammys, when she used it to secure a famously revealing dress; he for decades to attach his toupee.

title: Sarah Lawrence and John Stern
description: THE back of John Stern and Sarah Lawrence's wedding invitations were stamped with an insignia bearing the motto of Augustus Caesar, the first Roman emperor: Festina lente, or Make haste slowly. It was an appropriate theme for the couple, who have danced around the inevitable for 40 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NASH, FLORENCE J.
description: NASH--Florence J., died on December 8, 2003 at the age of 89. Devoted wife of the late Monroe Nash. Loving mother of Irwin & wife Esther, Carl & wife Sharon, Laura and Theodore Nash. Grandmother of Jay, Wendy, Aaron, Abigail, Adam, Daniel, Jonathan, Rebecca, Uziel, Shahar, Joshua and Maayan. Survived by two of her five sisters, Charlotte Oremland and Deborah Bowman. Funeral services were held at Ahavath Torah, Englewood Cliffs, NJ and burial was at Cedar Park Cemetery on December 9. Donations in her honor may be made to the Connecticut Hospice, Branford, CT.

title: The Second City Comedy Crew Pulls an All-Nighter
description: IT began as most improvisational comedy shows do: with a suggestion from the audience. The theme was ''Things you associate with the holidays.'' Audience members who packed the 180-seat cabaret theater shouted out ideas. ''Cranberry Sauce!'' ''Gingerbread!'' ''Liquor!'' ''Family conflict!''

title: The Play That Tamed 'Taming of the Shrew'
description: IN the last three decades or so, ''The Taming of the Shrew'' has joined the ranks of Shakespeare's so-called problem plays, indeed leaped right to the head of the queue. True, it has never been without its detractors (more than 100 years ago, George Bernard Shaw judged it ''disgusting''), but until recently it was largely taken as an acceptably hearty and harmless misogynist joke; Taylor and Burton could perform it and elicit the same smug chortles as John Wayne's spanking of Maureen O'Hara in ''McLintock!''

title: Where He Learned It
description: To the Editor:

title: Clone T.R.? Not Yet. His Tree? You Bet.
description: IN 1885, when Theodore Roosevelt and his family moved into the 28-room Queen Anne-style home in Cove Neck that they called Sagamore Hill, the shingle house crowned a barren hill that once was a wheat field with clear views of the water in three directions. Aside from a single white oak growing a stretch away from the house, the 95-acre estate was in dire need of landscaping.

title: U.S. Considers an Increase in Pay for Iraq's New Soldiers After Many Recruits Desert
description: The allied military commander in Iraq, Lt. Gen. Ricardo Sanchez, said on Saturday that American troops had ''achieved a significant decrease in attacks'' with the help of Iraqis who were coming forward in growing numbers to identify those planning and mounting insurgent strikes.

title: Double Vision
description: CHRISTMAS WAS OVER. Feeling a shame-faced pleasure in the restoration of normality, Kate stripped the tree of lights and decorations, cut off the main branches and dragged the trunk down to the compost heap at the bottom of the garden. There she stood looking back at the house, empty again now-her mother and sister had left the morning after Boxing Day-seeing the lighted windows and reflected firelight almost as if she were a stranger, shut out. A few specks of cold rain found her eyelids and mouth. All around her the forest waited, humped in silence. Shivering, she ran back up the lawn.

title: The Hunt for Bin Laden Is More Complex, Experts Say
description: It took about eight months for American troops to find Saddam Hussein and capture him in an underground hideout in Iraq, an accomplishment that prompted President Bush to say today that the United States would now move forward in the war on terror "capture by capture, cell by cell, and victory by victory."

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Drought-Proof Lawn, The
description: After decades of indulgence, the great American thirst for domestic turf is becoming literally unquenchable. The nation's 50 million lawns drink 270 billion gallons of water every week. Depending on the city, between 30 and 60 percent of urban fresh water is used for watering lawns. So when water shortages strike, as they increasingly do, the lawn feels it first.

title: Snapshots of New York: 1993 and 2003
description: There's more parkland, and there are more buildings named Trump. There are fewer X-rated emporiums in Times Square, fewer foreign tourists and not a single Checker cab. By measures large and small, New York 2003 wears a far different face than it had when the City section made its debut.

title: An Islamic Terrorism Suspect, Living in Norwegian Refuge, Plays Down His Past
description: While bombs explode in Iraq, killing soldiers and civilians, one of the men the United States says is partly responsible is sitting in a garret apartment in the land of the Vikings, dreaming of an Islamic state in the country he left behind.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the spiritual messages found in the film ''Groundhog Day'' by people of different faiths misstated a phrase in a quotation from Angela Zito, a director of the Center for Religion and Media at New York University, who offered a Buddhist interpretation that treats the character played by Bill Murray as a bodhisattva -- a being far along the path to enlightenment. She said, ''I can think of one bodhisattva, and that is the Dalai Lama,'' not ''There is only one bodhisattva.''

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Espresso You Can't Mess Up
description: Home-brewed espresso used to represent gourmet coffee-making in its highest form. The perfect cup was as much about the ritual of grinding the beans and tamping the coffee just so as it was about the drink itself.

title: The Risks of Journalism in Bangladesh
description: Salah Uddin Shoaib Choudhury, a Muslim editor and commentator in Bangladesh, has a rare virtue -- he champions dialogue and decency in a culture hemmed in by extremism and corruption. When his weekly newspaper, Blitz, published articles favorable to Israel, it was blacklisted by various companies. Some people demanded that the paper be banned. Mr. Choudhury was thrown out of a private television company.

title: New Jersey Masala
description: SUBURBAN SAHIBS

title: General Clark to Testify for the Prosecution at Milosevic Trial
description: Washington has agreed that Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the former NATO commander and a contender for the Democratic presidential nomination, can testify in the war crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic. But the Bush administration has demanded the right to edit videotapes and transcripts of the sessions before they are made public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELSON, BERNARD
description: ELSON -- Bernard. Loving husband of the late Gert. Beloved father of Richard, Tatiana, Robert, Robin, Roger and Sheryl. Adored grandfather of Brooke, Wendy, Sarab, Zach, Avtar, Oliver and Katya, and great-grandfather of Henry. Brother-in-law of Vivian and Gloria. Loving uncle of Barry, Ronnie, Janet, Danny and Glen. He will be missed but never forgotten.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Of Secrets, Shame and Solace
description: CONFESSION, though perhaps good for the soul, is not generally good for the bank account, as any white-collar defendant facing a costly lawsuit well knows. But some enterprising authors apparently think that tell-all memoirs about how besotted and greedy they were during the stock market bubble will be the exception to the rule -- that, by confessing to their own dot-com foolishness, they can recoup some of the hard cash that their foolishness cost them.

title: Winter's Blockbuster Soundtrack
description: 'COLD MOUNTAIN' -- After ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?,'' the producer T Bone Burnett has returned to Appalachian traditions for another soundtrack album that reimagines rural music. For the songs of love and death on ''Cold Mountain,'' he lined up the White Stripes' Jack White, with a changed, unmannered voice, and Alison Krauss, who gently backdates new songs from Elvis Costello and Sting. But the revelation is the Sacred Harp Singers from Liberty Church in Henagar, Ala., whose tradition predates the Civil War. Their homespun voices, nearly shouting the do-re-mi syllables of the scale in rough-hewn harmony, should introduce new listeners to the galvanizing sound of shape-note singing.

title: Readers React to the Capture of Saddam Hussein
description: NYTimes.com readers shared their views in the Struggle for Iraq forum about the news that the deposed Iraqi leader had been taken into custody by coalition troops. Some readers saw his capture as a positive turning point in the Iraq war, while others thought it will have little effect on the opposition.

title: Discovering A Soft Spot For Children
description: Tom Henderson did it for his wife. She needed something soft and cuddly to nurture, so he figured he would get her a foster child.

title: Illinois Boy and Colorado Girl Win Nationals
description: While the favorites Shadrack Kiptoo and Galen Rupp dueled in the lead, Matt Withrow of Tinley Park, Ill., surged from behind in the homestretch yesterday to win the National High School Cross-Country Championships in San Diego.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Joshua Millett, Las Vegas, Dec. 4, 2003

title: Investing; Forecasts Are Upbeat For the Israeli Market
description: THE Nasdaq stock market, heavy with technology stocks, is having its best year since 1999. So is the Israeli market, also dominated by tech issues, many of which trade on American stock exchanges.

title: 2003: THE 3rd ANNUAL YEAR IN IDEAS; Gray-Goo Problem, The
description: For years, many members of the scientific community have been excited by the prospect of nanotechnology, the design of machines and robots on a molecular scale. But scientific ethicists and environmental activists are increasingly alarmed by its potential abuses. In January, the ETC group, a Canadian watchdog organization for socially responsible technology, released ''The Big Down,'' a report on nanotechnology. No less a figure than Prince Charles, having read the report, publicly announced that he was distressed by something called the gray-goo problem, in which a swarm of millions of rapidly self-replicating microscopic robots, in a ravenous quest for fuel, would consume the entire biosphere until nothing remained but an immense, sludgelike robotic mass.

title: A Malibu With a Little More
description: CATEGORIES of cars and trucks keep blurring. Pity the poor customer who has to figure out whether she wants a station wagon, a sport utility, a minivan or a sedan.

description: Following is a transcript of remarks in Baghdad, Iraq, by Paul Bremer III, the American administrator, and Lt. Gen. Ricardo Sanchez, the allied military commander in Iraq, as recorded by Federal Document Clearing House Inc.:

title: NO MORE YANKEENETS
description: The board of the conglomerate YankeeNets voted last week to dissolve, ending a fractious four-year relationship between the owners of the Nets and the Yankees. The break-up allows the teams to keep their shares in the YES television network that YankeeNets created and puts the Nets' owners in charge of selling the team, whose mounting financial losses had irked George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees. Three offers have been made for the Nets: $275.5 million from Stuart Feldman, a venture capitalist who has indicated an interest in moving the team to Newark; $267.5 million from the developer Charles Kushner and Senator Jon S. Corzine, who said they would keep the team in New Jersey; and $275 million from Bruce Ratner, a New York developer who would move it to Brooklyn. George James

description: The following is the text of President Bush's remarks on Sunday following the capture of Saddam Hussein as transcribed by Federal News Service.

description: Roberto Arguelles will never face the firing squad that he chose as the means of his execution after he was convicted of kidnapping and killing four people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAME, JOSEPH
description: KRAME--Joseph. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Joseph Krame, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Marilyn, and the entire family. Marc Goldberg, President Rabbi Stanley Platek

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POPPER, EDWIN L.
description: POPPER--Edwin L. Age 93, died at home on December 12, 2003. He had lived with Alzheimer's disease for many years. He was married to Eleanor D. Popper for 59 years, and is survived by three cousins, James, Will, and Charles Hochman. Ed was the last president of Leo Popper and Sons Glass, a firm which imported sheet glass and other glass items from Europe. Among the firm's customers, since the early twentieth century, were many studios of The Stained Glass Association of America. He was a graduate of Harvard University, class of 1931, receiving a Master's degree there, and after a year's study abroad on a fellowship he returned to Cambridge and became an instructor at Radcliffe College. He also served as a tutor at Harvard's Winthrop House. During World War II he served as a naval officer in harbor entrance control at Portland, ME, and later at Pearl Harbor. He will be remembered for his delight in people, his elfish sense of humor, and for an erudition which never diminished another person. His joy in life was radiant. Ed would be happy to know that contributions in his memory would go to Harvard University to benefit the Widener Library where he spent many happy and stimulating hours. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Tuesday, December 16, at 11:30 A.M.

title: Valerie Colas-Thibouville, Wright Ohrstrom
description: Valerie Christine Cantrell Colas-Thibouville, a daughter of Maryanne and Pierre Henri Colas-Thibouville of Manhattan and Paris, was married last evening to Wright Riggs Shepard Ohrstrom, a son of Sandra Shepard Wright of Washington and George L. Ohrstrom Jr. of The Plains, Va. The Very Rev. James Parks Morton, the dean emeritus of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in The Plains.

description: Coalition troops discovered Saddam Hussein hiding in a hole below the farm house, located in Adwar, 10 miles from Tikrit.

title: Steinbrenner Extends Cashman's Contract
description: Very soon, Brian Cashman will receive a legal document notifying him that the Yankees have exercised the option on his contract for 2005. This would normally be good news for Cashman. But there is nothing normal about the Yankees these days.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 22 about the Mexican D.J.'s known as sonideros, who record immigrants' messages over music, referred imprecisely to the academic specialty of Cathy Ragland, who provided background information from her research. It is ethnomusicology, not musicology.

description: It seems almost silly to ask whether a federal investigation into the reported payment of hundreds of thousands of dollars in payoffs from a strip club operator to local politicians could tarnish Sin City's image.

description: Fred P. Hochberg, President Clinton's deputy administrator of the Small Business Administration from 1998 to 2001, has been named dean of the Robert J. Milano Graduate School of Management and Urban Policy at New School University. Mr. Hochberg earned a bachelor's degree from New York University and an M.B.A. from Columbia University. He also attended the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. Kimetris N. Baltrip (NYT)

description: Today

title: Saddam's Past, Iraq's Future
description: For decades Iraq was held together by the outsized personality of Saddam Hussein and his grandiose vision of Iraq's role in the Arab world. But while Mr. Hussein has passed from the scene, his vision of Iraq may linger. The future of Iraq may well depend on how Iraqis and their American overseers respond to the dream Mr. Hussein created but never realized.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 452 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans on Friday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VALKENIER, ROBERT W.
description: VALKENIER--Robert W. Of NYC and New Milford, CT. Died peacefully at home in NYC, on December 12, 2003, two days before his 79th birthday. An editor retired from the Council on Foreign Relations, Rob is survived by his wife Elizabeth, his daughter Lisa, his brother Paul, and many friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the New Milford Public Library, 24 Main St, New Milford, CT 06776. Memorial service to be announced

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUBA, DONALD L.
description: KUBA--Donald L. The firm of Warshaw Burstein Cohen Schlesinger & Kuh has lost a loyal friend and colleague for over 40 years, whose early death we deeply mourn. A scholarly lawyer, a creative problem solver, Don was firm but self-effacing, effective but courteous, and always tenacious. He applied his tenacity for the benefit of the firm, wherever needed. He also became a scholar in the field of fine arts, which became his avocation. A gentle man, we will miss him. All of us express our sympathy to Leona, Melissa and David.

title: For Candidates, a Day to Celebrate First and Worry Second
description: The news about Saddam Hussein fulfills what many Americans have long viewed as a crucial test for measuring success in the war in Iraq and thus could rob Democrats of an issue they have increasingly challenged President Bush on, Democrats said on Sunday.

title: People
description: David R. Drobis will retire Dec. 31 as chairman and senior partner at Ketchum, New York, part of the Omnicom Group. Mr. Drobis, who has worked at Ketchum in various posts for 36 years, will become chairman emeritus; the post of chairman will not be filled. Raymond L. Kotcher continues as chief executive and senior partner.

title: U.S. Hopes Husseins Capture Will Bolster Support in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 15  The Security Council will meet Tuesday to discuss Iraq, and the United States ambassador, John D. Negroponte, said today that he hoped the capture of Saddam Hussein would spur member states to close ranks behind American plans for the transformation of the country.

title: Uncle and Nephew Fatally Shot At Doorstep of Queens Building
description: A man and his nephew were shot dead early yesterday as they reached the doorstep of the uncle's home in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Alliance Is Said to Be Near a Settlement in Fund Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York attorney general's office are working out the final details of a settlement with Alliance Capital over improper trading in its mutual funds, senior people briefed on the negotiations said yesterday.

description: LEVINE--Harold. J. Levine Judaica records with sorrow the passing of family member and former President. Seymour & Danny Levine

title: Arrest by U.S. Soldiers  President Still Cautious
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 14  Saddam Hussein, once the all-powerful leader of Iraq, was arrested without a fight on Saturday night by American soldiers who found him crouching in an eight-foot hole at an isolated farm near Tikrit, haggard, dirty and disoriented after eluding capture for nearly nine months.

title: In Their Own Words: The Democratic Candidates
description: Following are comments by the Democratic presidential candidates yesterday on the capture of Saddam Hussein:

title: Bush's Cautious Demeanor Masks White House Elation
description: President Bush on Sunday hailed the capture of Saddam Hussein as a turning point in the history of Iraq and a ''hopeful day'' for its people, but he warned Americans that the violence against United States forces occupying the nation would continue.

description: To the Editor:

title: Iraqis Just Recently Set Rules to Govern Tribunal
description: After United States officials finish interrogating Saddam Hussein, he is expected to become the principal defendant before a special Iraqi-led criminal tribunal that was formally established only last week, Iraqi and American officials said Sunday.

title: Players and Nonplayers in Floppy Sleeves
description: One of the main concerns of Marina Rosenfeld's ensemble compositions (as distinct from those she creates using turntables) has been the interplay between professional musicians and people who never picked up an instrument before becoming involved in her work. From a certain perspective, and in a certain kind of music, the prospect could be interesting: nonplayers, after all, are not bound by the techniques, conventions and expectations that professional musicians bring to their work; and if they are inventive enough, they may produce some unusual or unexpected sounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUIRSKI, PHYSIL ''FISHIE.''
description: BUIRSKI -- Physil ''Fishie.'' Age 95, died December 13, in Hallandale, FL. Born 1908, in Capetown, South Africa. Received an MBA from Columbia University. Businessman in Johannesburg and NYC. Married 65 years to the late Pearl. Ever-present father of Peter and Cathy, devoted grandfather of Max and Diana, caring brother of Abe and the late Margot Barkham and Pauline Forbath. The Buirski family has lost its patriarch. We were lucky to have Fishie for so long but will miss him deeply. ''Tot siens.''

title: U.S. Officers Display the Rat Hole Where Hussein Hid
description: AD DWAR, Iraq, Dec. 15  After the gilded palaces and the tyrant's life of luxury, it came down to this for Saddam Hussein: a final hiding place beneath a scrappy peasant farmer's courtyard that was as small and dark and dank as a coffin, and a trembling decision to surrender that saved him from an almost certain death at the hands of American troops.

title: At Least 17 Die in Attack on Police Station West of Baghdad
description: Just 12 hours after Saddam Hussein was captured, a car bomb exploded Sunday outside the police station in this town 60 miles west of Baghdad, and military officials said at least 17 people had been killed and 33 wounded. It was the deadliest attack on American-led forces since two police stations near Baghdad were hit with car bombs three weeks ago.

title: A Philippine Official Dies While on a Trip
description: The Philippine foreign affairs secretary died Sunday in a hospital in Taiwan after falling ill during a flight, officials and family members said.

title: Indian Party Seems Unable to Halt Decline
description: The Indian National Congress, the party that dominated independent India's first half-century, is now being routinely described as having one foot in the trash can.

title: Afghanistan Faces a Test In Democracy
description: Afghans gathered Sunday for a historic grand council, or loya jirga, to debate and approve a new constitution that will pave the way for national elections. It will also be a test for President Hamid Karzai, as he faces growing political discord and opposition to his vision for a democratic system with a strong presidency.

title: Technology Said to End Errors in Chips Caused by Radiation
description: Researchers at an STMicroelectronics laboratory in France have developed a semiconductor memory technology that is immune to soft errors caused by background radiation, potentially eliminating an important barrier to shrinking the size of computer chips.

title: Phone Service Over Internet Revives Talk Of Regulation
description: Politicians have worked hard to keep access to Internet connections and many forms of Internet communication free from regulation and taxation. But the debate over how government treats the Internet is likely to reach a new level of intensity now that Internet technology is colliding with one of the nation's most lucrative businesses, telephone service.

title: Saddam Hussein in Custody: A Chapter Is Closed

title: A Fight Against Corruption
description: Former presidents of small, corrupt nations do not, lamentably, have many bad weeks. But last week was one of them. Nicaragua's former president, Arnoldo Alemn, was given a 20-year jail term for corruption. And in Zambia, the corruption trial of Frederick Chiluba began -- a rare attempt in Africa to prosecute a former head of state for a crime that is all too endemic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHACHTER, OSCAR
description: SCHACHTER--Oscar. Hamilton Fish Professor of International Law and Diplomacy at Columbia University, former Director of United Nations Institute of Training and Research, and Director General Legal Division United Nations. Beloved husband of Muriel Sackler, devoted father of Judith Schachter and Ellen Leventhal, loving grandfather of Jennifer McLoughlin, Matthew Modell, Philip Leventhal and Josh Leventhal. Caring brother of Marvin Schachter and Honey Zimmer, and father-in-law of Albrecht Funk and J. P. Leventhal. Widower of Mollie Miller Schachter. Service Monday, December 15, at 11:15 am, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th and Amsterdam Ave. His magnificent heart and mind shall live forever.

title: The Orioles Sign Tejada And May Not Be Done
description: When Manager Lee Mazzilli was asked Sunday afternoon if the Baltimore Orioles were going to start spending their surplus of money on free agents, he smiled and promised that they would act soon.

title: Bearing Questions, 4 New Iraqi Leaders Pay Hussein a Visit
description: The wild gray beard was gone, and he sat on a metal army cot, just awake from a nap, in socks and black slippers. He was not handcuffed. He did not recognize all his visitors, but they recognized him. That was the purpose of the visit: to help confirm that he was, in fact, Saddam Hussein.

description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 15  Israeli soldiers in the Gaza Strip shot dead two unarmed Palestinians attempting to breach a fence and enter Israel before dawn today, and troops also tore down Palestinian buildings in southern Gaza linked to mortar attacks a day earlier.

title: U.S. Officials Say Hussein Denies Ordering Postwar Attacks

description: Neither snow nor sleet nor being located nearly halfway around the world would stop the Indiana junior all-American Ned Grabavoy from making his second College Cup appearance on Sunday.

title: Ex-Nurse Charged With Murdering Priest in Jersey Hospital
description: SOMERVILLE, N.J., Dec. 15  A nurse with a history of job dismissals was charged on Monday with killing one patient and trying to murder another with drugs at a central New Jersey hospital, and a prosecutor quoted the nurse as saying that he had slain 30 to 40 patients in his 16-year career "to alleviate pain and suffering."

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Inquiries Begin For Mother Accused Of Fatal Beating
description: A woman accused of beating her 2-year-old to death for urinating in her pants is scheduled to appear in court today, as inquiries by social-service agencies have begun as to why the woman was given favorable reviews as a mother. Last week, the woman, Uniqua Smith, 20, of Yonkers, was charged with second-degree murder in the death of her daughter, Theresa. Ms. Smith is being held without bail at the county jail. Caseworkers from the Westchester County Department of Social Services and Westhab, a private social-service agency and housing provider, acknowledge writing favorable reports of Ms. Smith. In a meeting this week, the department will convene social workers and law enforcement officials for what is called a fatality review. It is not mandated, but is sometimes convened in special cases. New York State's Office of Children and Family Services will conduct its own investigation, which will take six months. The county is supposed to perform an investigation separate from the fatality review. Marek Fuchs (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POPPER, EDWIN L.
description: POPPER--Edwin L. Age 93, died at home on December 12, 2003. He had lived with Alzheimer's disease for many years. He was married to Eleanor D. Popper for 59 years, and is survived by three cousins, James, Will, and Charles Hochman. Ed was the last president of Leo Popper and Sons Glass, a firm which imported sheet glass and other glass items from Europe. Among the firm's customers, since the early twentieth century, were many studios of The Stained Glass Association of America. He was a graduate of Harvard University, class of 1931, receiving a Master's degree there, and after a year's study abroad on a fellowship he returned to Cambridge and became an instructor at Radcliffe College. He also served as a tutor at Harvard's Winthrop House. During World War II he served as a naval officer in harbor entrance control at Portland, ME, and later at Pearl Harbor. He will be remembered for his delight in people, his elfish sense of humor, and for an erudition which never diminished another person. His joy in life was radiant. Ed would be happy to know that contributions in his memory would go to Harvard University to benefit the Widener Library where he spent many happy and stimulating hours. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Tuesday, December 16, at 11:30 A.M.

Her daughter, Judith Franks and her son-in-law, Hugh Franks survive her. Dr. Ruth Nanda Anshen was a worldrenowned philosopher, author and editor. Dr. Anshen was the author of several books including ''The Anatomy of Evil'', ''Biography of An Idea'', ''Morals Equals Manners'' and ''The Mystery of Consciousness: A Prescription for Human Survival''. She was a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts of London, a member of the American Philosophical Association, the History of Science Society, the International Philosophical Society and the Metaphysical Society of America. In 1958, she established the Anshen-Columbia University Seminars on the Nature of Man, in which many prominent scientists, theologians, writers, artists, world leaders and philosophers participated. The party for Mrs. Rosen's 95th birthday is only the most recent of so many wonderful celebrations your family was fortunate enough to share with your elegant and cultured mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. You are indeed blessed to have such cherished memories. Herrick, Feinstein LLP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARTLEY, ROBERT L.
description: BARTLEY--Robert L., on December 10, 2003, at age 66, of cancer. Beloved husband of Edith Bartley. Loving father of Elizabeth, Susan & Katherine Bartley. Son of Theodore F. and the late Iva Mae Bartley. Brother of Phyllis Sutter and Dale Bartley. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81st St, Monday 2-5 & 7-9pm. Funeral services at Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims, Orange St between Hicks and Henry Sts, Brooklyn Heights, Tuesday 4pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to Plymouth Church, 75 Hicks St, Brooklyn, NY 11201 or the Brooklyn Red Cross, 100 Pineapple Walk, Brooklyn, NY 11201.

title: Arab Countries Call for Quick Transfer of Power to Iraqis
description: Arab officials and commentators said today that they hoped the capture of Saddam Hussein would mean a new stage of stability and self-government for the Iraqi people, and some said it was now more important than ever for the United States and Britain to transfer power to Iraqis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, SAMUEL
description: SHAPIRO--Samuel. Age 87. Interment December 15. Private services. Survived by his wife Ellen, sister Nora, brothers David and Herman, children Daniel (Charlayne) and Vivian, ten grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

title: Metro Matters; A Building Still Looking For Respect
description: MOST New Yorkers are familiar with 2 Columbus Circle, the infamously eccentric building on the southern border of Columbus Circle. It's the one with the blank, white-marble walls, the corner portholes, and the columns that the architecture critic Ada Louise Huxtable famously likened to lollipops.

title: A Bookish Contretemps in Providence
description: The Providence Athenaeum is the kind of place where first editions of Robert Burns's poetry, medieval manuscripts and the latest best sellers nestle under the same roof. The oil paintings are authentic, and Oriental rugs muffle the footsteps of those who come in for the books, the lectures or simply for refuge. Cellphones are not welcome, but dogs are, and the librarian keeps biscuits on hand for them.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Outlook issue of Business Day on Dec. 1 about the competition between cable and satellite television operators misstated the name of a sports package offered by DirecTV. It is NFL Sunday Ticket, not Sunday Night Football.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-23

title: The Capture of a Dictator
description: The United States achieved its most important military objective in Iraq since the fall of Baghdad when it captured Saddam Hussein. President Bush rightly claimed yesterday that it was a critical milestone toward the reconstruction of Iraq. The image of Mr. Hussein, bedraggled and bearded, being humbled before Iraqi leaders, some of whom had survived his torture chambers, was a tonic of relief. One indisputable fact in the bloody and divisive saga of Iraq is that this man ranked with the world's most vicious dictators. His crimes are monstrous. Hundreds of thousands of his people were murdered or tortured at his order and some may have been brutalized by his own hands.

title: A truly heroic task
description: UN Secretary General Kofi Annan, 65, discusses the role of the global organization in Iraq, conflict with the US superpower and its doctrine of preemptive attack, as well as the need to strengthen the battle against poverty and AIDS.

title: William V. Roth Jr., Veteran of U.S. Senate, Dies at 82
description: William V. Roth Jr., a longtime senator who gave his name to a popular tax-sheltered retirement account and a 1981 tax cut, died here on Saturday. He was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLATELL, JACK, D.D.S.
description: KLATELL--Jack, D.D.S. December 11, 2003. Beloved husband of Arla. Loving father of Robert and Penny, and David and Nancy. Proud grandfather of Christopher, James, Jenna, Jeremy and Devon. Devoted brother of Bea Fuchs. A renowned dentist and teacher. Memorial service Tuesday, December 16, 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Jack Klatell Fund at Columbia University School of Dentistry and Oral Surgery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANGSAM, LARRY SOL
description: LANGSAM--Larry Sol. Loving son of R. Judith Levine, brother to Andrew Langsam, father, husband and uncle. Born November 23, 1949. You were loved and will be missed.

title: 2 Car Bombers Attack Iraqi Police, as Insurgency Continues
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 15  Two powerful car bombs exploded at police stations in Baghdad today, killing at least six Iraqi officers and announcing that the insurgency here has not ended with the capture of Saddam Hussein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DREIFUSS, ROBERT LEON
description: DREIFUSS -- Robert Leon. Swiss born, dynamic, entrepreneur. Attended the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania and was the President of R.L. Dreifuss, Inc. Mr. Dreifuss served as a member of the Community Board 8 in NYC. He loved his family which included his three daughters, Danielle Butin, Marguerite Gelfman, Suzanne Dreifuss, son-in-laws, Mitchell Butin and Peter Gelfman, his sisters Juliette Braunschweig and Lis Gaines, his grandchildren Sam, Caroline, Justine, Max and Sally, and his cherished nieces and nephews. He lived his life to the fullest and will be missed by many. Services were held Sunday at Frank E. Campbell, with burial at Sharon Gardens.

title: McDyess and Houston Lead Knicks to Victory
description: They would not merit a second look among the spectacular dunks on nightly highlight shows, but in the final minutes of last night's game at Madison Square Garden, Antonio McDyess provided two dunks that not only his orthopedist could love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ABRAHAMS, INA
description: ABRAHAMS -- Ina. Eldest daughter of the late Bertha and Charles. Beloved sister of Ethel, Elizabeth and Roy Solomon, Esta and the late Seymour K. Ackerman. Devoted aunt and grandaunt. Graveside services at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Monday, December 15, at 11 am.

title: In City Streets, an Unwelcome Sentry
description: It sometimes seems that car alarms were invented as part of a mass sleep-deprivation experiment. How else to explain the setting off of honking and whooping devices around the city just as the average New Yorker reaches the R.E.M. sleep phase? Often the alarm is false, set off by a passing truck, a gust of wind or a glancing blow from an opening taxi door. So when the police get a call, it's usually someone complaining about the noise, not reporting a possible robbery in progress. In fact anyone who's been awakened by an alarm would cheer the thief who takes away the vehicle -- and noise -- and quickly.

title: Rock the Vote Tackles Discrimination
description: Rock the Vote and the Los Angeles County Commission on Human Relations began a campaign Saturday intended to challenge the public to consider discriminatory attitudes in everyday life. The campaign, created by the Los Angeles office of Crispin Porter & Bogusky, includes a 30-second commercial in which a fast-food restaurant charges drive-through customers double prices if they speak English poorly or not at all. The commercials and posters direct people to a Web site (zerohour.com) that offers information about discrimination along with links to the Web sites of Rock the Vote (rockthevote.com) and other groups.

title: Falcons And Vick Subdued By Colts
description: The Atlanta Falcons' media guide describes Michael Vick as ''Houdini in cleats.'' Against the Indianapolis Colts on Sunday at the RCA Dome, Vick pulled a disappearing act. In only his second start of the season, Vick performed none of the tricks that have made him one of the N.F.L.'s most exciting players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, CLAIRE
description: SILVER--Claire. Died peacefully and with dignity at her home in Woodland Hills, CA. Devoted wife to David, loving mother to Jillian and Jan, Carole and Harvey, Joe and Renee, adored Grandma to Annie, Matt, Scott, Adam and Jenny, and Great-Grandma to Hayden. She lived her life caring for her family, friends, and whomever knew her. As a pioneer in the insurance industry, her business acumen and abilities served as a model for all women. Her wisdom, grace and gentle nature will be forever missed. Services Wednesday, noon, at Riverside Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

title: Disquiet on the Set; At Navy Yard, It's Hollywood vs. a Blue-Collar Past
description: In running away with Hollywood, is the Brooklyn Navy Yard running away from its proletarian past?

title: A Perfectionist Is at Home in a Role Funny and Loose
description: On a shelf next to Donna Murphy's dressing table at the Al Hirschfeld Theater is a quotation from Martha Graham: ''No artist is pleased. There is no satisfaction whatever at any time. There is only a queer, divine dissatisfaction; a blessed unrest that keeps us marching and makes us more alive than the others.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Found Dead In Apartment
description: The police responded to a 911 call at 220 Throop Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday morning to find a 33-year-old man with his throat cut in the bathtub of an apartment and a dead woman under a bed, bound with rope, a police spokesman said. The man was in serious condition at Bellevue Hospital Center, the police said. The call came from a pay phone, the spokesman said, but the caller, who said he had awoken in the apartment to find a man committing suicide, was not there when the police arrived. The woman's family identified her as Evelyn Figueroa Kemp, 44, and said that she had a long addiction to crack and that she lived in the apartment with one male roommate. Neighbors said that there had been loud parties in the apartment over the past three days, but that Saturday night had been quiet. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: A Careful U.S. Plan To Dispel All Doubt On Hussein's Fate
description: The announcement of Saddam Hussein's capture followed a careful plan devised over months and intended, according to those who worked on it, to dispel any doubt among Iraqis and a skeptical Arab world that he was in American hands.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article last Monday about the Los Angeles River recounted its history and described the reporter's trip downriver in a kayak. In research for the article, the reporter consulted a 1999 book by Blake Gumprecht, ''The Los Angeles River: Its Life, Death, and Possible Rebirth.'' Several passages relating facts and lore about the river distilled passages from the book. Although the facts in those passages were confirmed independently -- through other sources or the reporter's firsthand observation -- the article should have acknowledged the significant contribution of Mr. Gumprecht's research.

title: Success of Cancer Drug to End Its Trial Early
description: Millennium Pharmaceuticals is expected to announce today that it is ending a controlled clinical trial of its drug Velcade earlier than expected because the drug has already proved to be effective in slowing the progression of multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow.

title: Bid for New York Magazine: A Dance of Money and Ego
description: It is a measure of the allure of New York magazine that a group of cold-eyed, wealthy executives is prepared to hold hands and jointly contribute more than $50 million to buy a publication that has made little money in the last three years for Primedia Inc.

title: Cheney Energy Group Case to Get High Court Hearing
description: The United States Supreme Court said today that it would hear arguments from the Bush administration about why it should not be required to turn over information about Vice President Dick Cheney's energy task force.

title: New Hope on Immigration
description: Without more detail, it was hard to determine, exactly, what Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge meant when he called for an ambitious plan to give millions of illegal immigrants some kind of legal status. But his candid comments in Miami last Tuesday, which apparently caught the White House off guard, offer the first hopeful sign since the World Trade Center attack that the Bush Administration is returning to immigration reform.

description: America Online in Dulles, Va., has narrowed a review on the creative and media duties for its interactive advertising assignments to three finalists. Billings are estimated at $55 million to $60 million.

Wang May Reinstate Bid for Nets
description: Charles B. Wang, who withdrew his $265 million offer to buy the Nets on Dec. 4, is close to reinstating his bid, two people with knowledge of his position said yesterday. If he returns, there would again be four bidders for the team.

title: Bush Leaves Unclear Role of Iraqis In Any Trial
description: President Bush vowed Monday that any trial for Saddam Hussein would be fair and open, and involve Iraqis, but he left unresolved the administration's willingness to back a plan by the Iraqi Governing Council to try Mr. Hussein for war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Corning Sells Software Business To Workers
description: Corning, the world's largest maker of fiber optic cable, sold a software business, Corning IntelliSense, to the unit's workers, the latest in a series of asset sales. Financial terms will not be disclosed, said Sandeep Akkaraju, chief executive officer of the newly formed IntelliSense Software Corporation. The company will be based in Wilmington, Mass. IntelliSense Software will focus on developing software and design tools for specialized microchips, Mr. Akkaraju said. It will also provide support to existing software customers. Corning slashed jobs, and sold or shut businesses, as sales of telecommunications equipment slumped in the last couple of years. A company spokesman, David Hill, did not immediately answer a voice mail message seeking comment. Corning shares rose 2 cents, to $10.80.

description: Dr. John W. Trinkaus is a professor of management as well as a Santa researcher.

title: U.S. Officers Display the 'Rathole' Where Hussein Hid
description: After the gilded palaces and the tyrant's life of luxury, it came down to this for Saddam Hussein: a final hiding place beneath a scrappy peasant farmer's courtyard that was as small and dark and dank as a coffin, and a trembling decision to surrender that saved him from an almost certain death at the hands of American troops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HECKER, MINDELLE SCHUL MAN
description: HECKER -- Mindelle Schul man, 81. Raised in Union City, New Jersey, and a long time resident of Teaneck, New Jersey . Died in her home in La Jolla, CA on December 11. Loving wife of the late Bruce A. Hecker, she is survived by her beloved daughters Lynn Beyerle and Deborah Potashnik, granddaughters Justine and Romy Potashnik, and son-in-law Frank Beyerle. Mindy's intellect and worldliness were inspiring. She was a continuing source of love, kindness and generosity who never failed to nurture her adoring family. A woman of character, Mindy walked in beauty like the night.

title: Triumph Tinged With Regret in Middle Earth
description: After the galloping intelligence displayed in the first two parts of ''The Lord of the Rings'' trilogy, your fear may be that the director, Peter Jackson, would become cautious and unimaginative with the last episode, ''The Return of the King.'' Look at what ''The Matrix'' did to the Wachowski brothers; the last two were like action movies made for CNBC.

description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 16  Israel developed a risky plan in 1992 to assassinate Saddam Hussein at a funeral but shelved it after five Israeli soldiers were killed while training for the mission, according to news reports today.

title: Mr. Smith Limps Home
description: It's no secret that the House Republican leaders went into full arm-twisting mode last month when they kept a midnight roll-call vote open an extraordinary three hours to finally squeeze out a victory for President Bush's Medicare prescription plan. One of the hounded Republicans, Representative Nick Smith of Michigan, was angry enough the next day to write a newspaper column for constituents alleging that ''bribes and special deals'' had been offered to sway holdouts like himself.

description: When the Yankees finally announce all the moves they have made this winter, their roster will include 17 former All-Stars. There should be a sign outside the clubhouse: No Admittance Without Proof of All-Star Status.

description: WEINER--Rae. Passed on December 14, 2003 in Boca Raton, FL. Much-loved mother to Sheila Weiner Rozzo of FL and Michael Weiner of CA. Funeral service 2 PM graveside Wellwood Cemetery Tuesday, December 16, 2003. Joining her predeceased husband, Benjamin, and her son, Jerome.

description: Antenna Software plans to announce today that it has agreed to acquire RPA Wireless in a deal that will combine two companies in the New York area that provide wireless communications services for businesses. Terms were not disclosed. Antenna Software is based in New York and RPA Wireless is based in Jersey City. Both companies are privately held. James Hemmer, the chief executive of Antenna, will remain chief executive of the combined company. Dom Intartaglia, chief executive of RPA Wireless, is planning to retire, Mr. Hemmer said. No layoffs were expected as a result of the acquisition.

description: United States and allied troops will have to remain in Iraq for at least ''a couple more years'' to secure the country's stability and protect its borders against attack, the American commander of those forces said in an interview in Baghdad on Saturday.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Racist Slogans Appear On Art Works
description: All but one of 39 billboard-size panels on display in a park in St. Petersburg were slashed or sprayed with racist slogans over the weekend. The panels were part of an international art exhibition urging world brotherhood, and the police said the defacing would be investigated as a hate crime. The show, sponsored by the Florida Holocaust Commission, toured Europe and Africa without incident. It is scheduled to visit New York and Boston, among other cities. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: CHESAPEAKE, Va., Dec. 16  The pictures, projected onto a large screen across the courtroom from the jury, told the two sides' stories.

description: GAITHERSBURG, Md., Dec. 16  In a 23-to-4 vote, two expert advisory committees to the Food and Drug Administration recommended Tuesday that a so-called morning-after pill to prevent unintended pregnancies be sold over the counter.

title: 3 Fire Victims Had Been Shot, Police Say
description: A woman and her two daughters who were found dead after a house fire in East Hartford on Saturday had been shot, an autopsy completed yesterday showed. A search continues for the man who is the woman's former husband and the girls' father. The police said he would be charged with their murders.

title: Remember, Please, All the Things It Wasn't
description: If the main thing you remember about the Alamo is that you're supposed to remember it, you won't do yourself any harm by tuning in to ''Remember the Alamo,'' a lightly revisionist documentary that will have its premiere tonight on the History Channel. The show is meant somehow to coincide with the nonrelease of the allegedly troubled Touchstone movie on the same subject, the 1836 battle in Texas that whatever else it did or meant, sealed the legend of Davy Crockett.

title: Interior Designer Sent Bills to Tyco, Witness Says
description: The office manager at the interior design firm used by L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International, testified yesterday that all the bills went to Tyco, including at least $33,000 in limousine charges.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Drug Business Sold
description: Aventis, France's biggest drug maker, said it would sell its generic drug business in France to Ranbaxy Laboratories of India as part of a plan to focus on its main health care activities. Aventis, which is based in Strasbourg, said the transaction was expected to be completed in the first quarter of next year. Details were not disclosed. Aventis is selling assets to reduce its 3.45 billion euros ($4.2 billion) in net debt and gain a higher credit rating. The purchase of Aventis's generic drug business will help Ranbaxy, India's biggest drug maker, to increase sales.

title: Robert Bartley
description: New York is a place where unlikely people are thrown together -- at parties, on the subway and at church. Church is where I met Robert Bartley, the quiet, self-effacing man who transformed The Wall Street Journal's editorial page into the pre-eminent voice of conservatism during his 30 years as its editor. I was in the same business as Mr. Bartley, who died last week of cancer at the age of 66, but we had different perspectives on a great many things.

title: Advertising Opportunities Disguised as Touchdowns
description: Joe Horn of the New Orleans Saints may one day be viewed as a product placement revolutionary for celebrating a touchdown Sunday night by appearing to call his family on a cellphone previously secreted beneath the padding of a goal post.

title: Making a Toast Without Dropping One's Guard
description: Ovid Battat, who owns a wine and olive oil importing company in Freehold, N.J., vividly remembers the faux pas he committed on one of his first trips to Italy, in a restaurant in Tuscany with a group from a winery. ''I was pouring wine tilting my wrist backwards over some glasses,'' Mr. Battat said. ''The table just came to a halt -- people almost jumped out of their seats, and started pushing their chairs back. Two or three people made me stop, and said we had to get rid of the bottle. Nobody would drink from that wine.''

title: A Blue Holiday May Be a Red Herring
description: Everyone knows the holiday season can be hazardous to one's health. Just think of the warnings already abundant in the news media, alerting to the perils of gluttony and excess, not to mention overshopping. Even the fitness clubs are gearing up for their post-holiday campaign, in time to capitalize on the ill effects of guilty pleasure.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Europe-Africa Tunnel
description: Spain and Morocco have taken the first steps to building a railway tunnel under the Strait of Gibraltar that would connect Europe and Africa. The Spanish public works minister, Francisco lvarez-Cascos, said the countries will spend $33 million over the next three years on engineering tests and geological surveys between Tarifa, in southwestern Spain, and Tangiers. A decision to dig is expected in 2008. Mr. lvarez-Cascos said the railway, to be modeled after the Channel Tunnel, would stretch roughly 24 miles. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Uncertain Future for the Past's Treasures
description: Stranded! That's how I feel each time the World Monuments Fund releases its list of 100 most endangered sites. As if the present were a beach onto which every artifact of humankind will eventually wash up. A vast inventory already lies there, waterlogged on the sand, with flies buzzing around: mosques, palaces, little mud-baked villages, tombs to die for, temples, rock paintings: much of this in advanced states of disintegration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POPPER, EDWIN L.
description: POPPER--Edwin L. Age 93, died at home on December 12, 2003. He had lived with Alzheimer's disease for many years. He was married to Eleanor D. Popper for 59 years, and is survived by three cousins, James, Will, and Charles Hochman. Ed was the last president of Leo Popper and Sons Glass, a firm which imported sheet glass and other glass items from Europe. Among the firm's customers, since the early twentieth century, were many studios of The Stained Glass Association of America. He was a graduate of Harvard University, class of 1931, receiving a Master's degree there, and after a year's study abroad on a fellowship he returned to Cambridge and became an instructor at Radcliffe College. He also served as a tutor at Harvard's Winthrop House. During World War II he served as a naval officer in harbor entrance control at Portland, ME, and later at Pearl Harbor. He will be remembered for his delight in people, his elfish sense of humor, and for an erudition which never diminished another person. His joy in life was radiant. Ed would be happy to know that contributions in his memory would go to Harvard University to benefit the Widener Library where he spent many happy and stimulating hours. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Tuesday, December 16, at 11:30 A.M.

title: DEVON ENERGY TO SELL PROJECT TO QUEST RESOURCE
description: The Devon Energy Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its coal-bed methane project in Southeast Kansas and Northeast Oklahoma to the Quest Resource Corporation for $126 million to focus on exploration in other areas like the Gulf of Mexico. The purchase price is about equal to Devon's investment in the Cherokee Basin properties, the company said. Quest will buy about 330 producing wells, an estimated 200 miles of pipelines and interests in about 375,000 leasehold acres in a transaction that is expected to close on Dec. 22. Both companies are based in Oklahoma City.
