title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Wesley K. Clark's transition from Army general to presidential candidate misstated the circumstances of the Republican Party's 1952 nomination of Dwight D. Eisenhower, the most recent general elected president. He overcame a strong run by Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio; the nomination was not effectively handed to him.

title: Trade Tower To Reflect Compromise
description: Months of architectural wrangling over plans for the tallest building at the World Trade Center site -- and in the world -- have apparently ended in a 1,776-foot compromise that would include an asymmetrical spire favored by Daniel Libeskind rising atop a cable-framed wind farm proposed by David M. Childs.

title: UNION PLANTERS ISSUES WARNING ON PROFITS
description: The Union Planters Corporation, Tennessee's largest bank, said yesterday that profit might fall as much as 10 percent next year and that it would lay off workers as fewer customers take out mortgages. The bank, which is based in Memphis and has 732 branches, said fourth-quarter mortgage volume might fall more than 50 percent from the third quarter, resulting in 2003 earnings per share of $2.51 to $2.56. The bank said it expected to take a charge to cover severance costs in 2004. A spokesman, Richard Trigger, declined to specify the number of job cuts. The bank's stock fell $3.59, to $30.41

title: A Plea to Invest in What's Good
description: At the annual meeting yesterday of the largest investment organization catering to university and college faculties and staff, investors raised questions about the chief executive's pay and urged greater emphasis on selecting stocks according to the social and moral character of corporations.

title: Tiny Particles Put Heart in Peril
description: Minuscule particles in air pollution pose a greater risk to the heart than to the lungs, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the increased demand for flu vaccinations of children in New York City referred imprecisely to a new guideline by the American Association of Pediatrics. It has encouraged flu shots for nearly all children 6 months to 2 years old and for some older than 2, but not for all children.

title: Afghanistan Opens a Rebuilt Road to Unite North and South
description: DURANI, Afghanistan, Dec. 16  The presidential special envoy and American ambassador to Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, did not begin his remarks here today with the words "We did it," but he might as well have.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARFIELD, HENRY
description: HARFIELD--Henry. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Ave. at 10:30 AM on Thursday, December 18, 2003. Died on September 13, 2003 in New York City at age 89. Beloved father of Susan Harfield Leness Peck. Survived also by grandchildren Amanda Leness Gubbin, Susan Leness Gilbert, Anthony Harfield Leness, Sarah Harfield Piel and Katharine Harfield. Greatgrandfather of Henry Maxwell Gilbert, Eliza Leness Gilbert and Griffin Piel McAlinden. Predeceased in 1999 by his wife of 59 years, Marion Bussang Harfield and in 1996 by his daughter, Ellen Harfield Piel. Yale Class of '34 and Columbia Law School Class of '37. At his death he was of counsel to Shearman & Sterling. Memorial donations may be made to Yale University, Class of '34, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521 or to East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978.

title: Rome Too Costly? Try Columbus, Ohio
description: The federal government sets maximum daily travel allowances for its employees for more than 1,000 cities worldwide, and private businesses can use them as a crib sheet for what to pay their executives. The rates for the continental United States are determined by the General Services Administration (http://policyworks.gov/org/main/mt/homepage/mtt/perdiem/perd04d.html); Alaska, Hawaii and United States overseas locations are available from the Department of Defense (www.dtic.mil/perdiem/pdrates.html) and figures for foreign locations are set by the State Department (www.state.gov/m/a/als/prdm/). A sampling follows. SETH W. FEASTER

title: AUSTRALIAN BANK TO BUY EXELON UNIT FOR $135 MILLION
description: Macquarie Bank of Australia said it had agreed to buy Exelon Thermal Technologies for 182 million Australian dollars ($135 million). Exelon Thermal, a unit of the Exelon Corporation, provides mainly chilled water for cooling purposes from centralized plants to customers in office buildings in Chicago. The purchase is similar to the bank's recent acquisitions of South East Water in Britain and the Arlanda Express airport rail link in Sweden, Macquarie's chief financial officer, Greg Ward, said. The plants ''provide a platform for further acquisitions'' of similar assets in North America,'' he said.

title: Trial of Young Sniper Suspect Moves to Closing Arguments
description: CHESAPEAKE, Va., Dec. 16  Closing arguments in the murder trial of Lee Malvo, the younger member of the sniper duo that terrorized the Washington area last fall, were scheduled to begin early this afternoon.

title: Dreams And Glory
description: Howard Dean is the only guy who goes to the Beverly Hills area for a gravitas implant. He went to the St. Regis Hotel, a mile from Rodeo Drive, to deliver a major foreign policy speech, and suddenly Dr. Angry turned into the Rev. Dull and Worthy.

title: And Out Went the Whales
description: For Steve Jenkins, a writer and an illustrator putting together a children's book on evolution, the trouble was whales. Just as Mr. Jenkins was finishing the text for his book ''Life on Earth,'' he learned that some scientists were questioning whether whales had, in fact, evolved from hooved carnivorous land mammals called mesonychids.

title: Illinois Tool Raises Its Profit Forecasts
description: Illinois Tool Works, a maker of plastic car parts, laminate flooring and welding equipment, raised its profit forecasts yesterday for the fourth quarter and the full year because of higher sales and lower taxes.

title: Doctors Promote Healing, With a Zing of the Strings of a Harp
description: The only light in the room is the flicker from the wall-mounted television, thankfully on mute. I watch a car salesman walking through a used car lot mouthing his pitch. Propped by pillows, David lies against the rail of his hospital bed.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS FALLS. Natural gas fell as utilities and industrial users burn cheaper reserves or alternatives. In New York, natural gas for January delivery fell 26.7 cents, or 3.7 percent, to $6.954 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: China Brands Muslim Groups As Terrorists
description: China issued its first formal list of terrorists on Monday, accusing four Muslim separatist groups and 11 individuals of committing violence and acts of terror, while calling on other nations to help in cracking down on them.

title: A Dignitary Examines Community Court
description: Lord Falconer of Thoroton, the highest-ranking judicial official in Britain, visited the Midtown Community Court yesterday and pronounced himself ''utterly delighted.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Faces More Deficits, Comptroller Says
description: The local economy appears to have pulled through the recession, but New York City still faces budget gaps in the next few years, the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., reported yesterday. Next year's gap, which the Bloomberg administration put at $1.8 billion, could rise to $2.3 billion if Gov. George E. Pataki wins his court battle to halt a deal for the state to take over the city's debt from the 1970's. The next year's gap will be $3.4 billion to $3.9 billion, the report said. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Oracle Quarterly Earnings Beat Estimates by a Penny
description: Oracle reported better-than-expected earnings on Monday because of new licenses for its software and increased corporate spending in the slightly stronger economy. The company posted net income of $617 million for the second quarter, or 12 cents a share, compared with $535 million, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 8.2 percent, to $2.5 billion from $2.3 billion a year earlier.

title: Battle for Safeway Nears End As Grocer Agrees to Takeover
description: A nearly yearlong battle over one of Britain's largest supermarket chains neared an end on Monday, as Safeway agreed to a new 3 billion ($5 billion) takeover by William Morrison Supermarkets.

title: Well-Chosen Words Point Children to Right Track
description: The only advice book I read before my twin sons were born in 1969 was ''Between Parent and Child'' by the psychologist Dr. Haim G. Ginott. It has just been reissued in a reverential revised and updated version by his widow, Dr. Alice Ginott, who is also a psychologist, and Dr. H. Wallace Goddard, a family life specialist.

title: National Briefing | Politics: Web Listing Political Meetings
description: Meetup.com, a Web site that energized Howard Dean's campaign with monthly grass-roots meetings, said it would use data from Capitol Advantage to set up such meetings for backers of all candidates for president, governor, the Senate and the House. By Jan. 15, meetings are to be scheduled in 500 races. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Americans Suspect Steroid Use In Sports Is Common, Poll Finds
description: Most Americans are troubled by performance-enhancing drugs, which they believe are widely used by the nation's athletes, according to the latest New York Times poll.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: American League

title: With Good Riddance to Hussein, Bush Vows Resolve
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  President Bush said Monday that he had a simple message for the captured Saddam Hussein  "Good riddance, the world is better off without you"  and said he would leave it to the Iraqi people to determine if their former leader should be executed.

title: Sprint to Record Charges
description: The Sprint Corporation, the long-distance phone company, said yesterday that it would record charges of $365 million, mostly in the fourth quarter, for job cuts and a decision to scrap a wireless billing system.

title: Federal Panel Gives High Marks to Joint Replacement Surgery
description: Despite excruciating pain and decreased mobility, many people with knees damaged by arthritis put off joint-replacement surgery out of fear and uncertainty. But last week, a federal panel found that replacing a diseased joint with artificial parts quickly relieved pain and improved mobility and quality of life in 90 percent of the patients.

description: Canyon Ranch, Tucson, an operator of health resorts and spas, to Yesawich, Pepperdine, Brown & Russell, Orlando, Fla., as the first agency of record for its account. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: AIDS After 'Angels': Not Gone, Not Forgotten
description: The young clerk at one of the video stores near me vanished last month, after two-and-a-half years in which he went from noticeably thin to gaunt, with red welts that appeared and disappeared, and a personality that changed, behind the counter, from polite to brittle, and then to something more like silent, angry, embattled and sad.

title: City Hall and Teacher Unions Unite Against School Violence
description: Putting aside months of feuding, the Bloomberg administration and the unions for teachers and principals joined forces yesterday on the issue of violence in the public schools, vowing to use a number of strategies, including the swift removal of the most dangerous students, to make schools safer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBELL, ARTHUR
description: LUBELL--Arthur, on December 14th, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Mary. Loving father of Ruth Tallury, Diane Hochner and Lewis Lubell. Cherished grandfather. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Thurmond Kin Acknowledge Black Daughter
description: The family of the late Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina acknowledged on Monday that Essie Mae Washington-Williams, a retired teacher living in Los Angeles is the daughter of Mr. Thurmond and a black woman who worked for his family as a maid nearly 80 years ago.

title: Confession or Not, It's a Complex Road to Conviction in Serial Killings
description: Investigators trying to determine whether a nurse who worked in New Jersey and Pennsylvania killed one person, or 40, or none at all, face a long, hard hunt through thousands of pages of records, hundreds of witness interviews and, mostly likely, the exhumation of long-buried bodies, their colleagues who have been through the process said yesterday.

description: Sore throats are among the most common reasons that children are taken to doctors, and prescriptions for antibiotics are among the most common results.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, EUGENE H.
description: GORDON--Eugene H., 89, attorney, of Portland, OR, formerly of Stamford, CT, New York City and North Branford, CT, died on December 13, 2003. Beloved spouse of Marjorie (nee Grossman) for 65 years; proud and loving father of Barbara GordonLickey (Marvin), Bill Gordon (Katharine Clemens), Douglas Gordon (Caryl) and Fritz Gordon (Lisa Simeoni); devoted to his 13 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. NYU '35 summa cum laude; Yale Law School '38, member Law Review; formerly partner in Solinger & Gordon; of counsel to Hall, Dickler. His intellect, wisdom and generosity touched many lives, and he will be greatly missed. Donations in his memory may be made to Yale Law School Scholarship Fund or charity of your choice.

title: Nurse Accused of Slaying Patient Reportedly Admitted 30 Killings
description: A nurse with a history of job dismissals was charged on Monday with killing one patient and trying to murder another with drugs at a hospital here in central New Jersey, and a prosecutor quoted the nurse as saying that he had slain 30 to 40 patients in his 16-year career ''to alleviate pain and suffering.''

title: After Losing Momentum, Kerry Is Shifting Tactics To Gain 'Bounce' in Iowa
description: It has come to this, for Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts: to win the Jan. 27 Democratic primary in New Hampshire, where he was once seen as the heavy favorite, his aides now believe he will first have to win or come close in Iowa, defying expectations and gaining the kind of favorable publicity his campaign has sorely wanted for months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WRIGHT, MARTHA E.
description: WRIGHT--Martha E. of South Setauket on December 13, 2003. Born February 6, 1919 -in Newfane, Vermont. Married Frederick O. (Bud) Wright, D.V.M. in 1941 until his death in 1987. Married Samuel I. Wright in 1990 until his death in 2000. Board member of the Huntington United Way, president of the board of Huntington Pederson-Krag Center. Long time volunteer for League of Women Voters. Office manager for Ft. Hill Animal Hospital in Huntington and wife of owner, Frederick Wright. Beloved father of Suzanne F.W. Lemakis (Emmanuel) and Jeanne W. George (Lisle W.). Loving grandfather of Emilie Ruth Lemakis, Athena Katherine Lemakis and Charles Frederick George. Memorial service Wednesday 10 AM at the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship Church, Stony Brook. Cremation was private. Bryant Funeral Home, Setauket. Interment of ashes Will take place at a later date in Rhinebeck, NY.

title: People
description: Todd Gallentine was named to the new post of co-creative director at Kelliher Samets Volk, Burlington, Vt., sharing those duties with Bill Drew, now also co-creative director. Mr. Gallentine had been vice president and group creative director at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Joy Fades as Iraqis Chafe Under a Grim Occupation
description: In the evening gloom, on a dirt track a quarter mile from this country's largest killing field, the two brothers spoke of the need for answers.

description: The First Data Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a late agreement to settle a government lawsuit blocking its planned $7 billion acquisition of Concord EFS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAFIAN, MURRAY Z., PH.D.
description: SAFIAN--Murray Z., Ph.D. Much beloved husband of Lenore, proud and loving father of Leslie (Stephen) Kuhn and adoring grandfather of Ally, Peter, Willa and Nicholas. Peacefully at home on December 14, 2003. Master teacher, wise therapist, valued and respected by his professional community; forever missed by his loving family. Funeral services at Temple Beth El, 229 Bedford Road, Chappaqua, New York on Wednesday, December 17th at 1:30 PM.

title: More Violence for U.S. Troops in Pro-Hussein Heartland
description: FALLUJAH, Iraq, Dec. 16  American troops killed at least 17 Iraqis in the last day, the military reported today, in ambushes and in violent rallies around the nation's Sunni Muslim heartland that still boiled in anger and disbelief at the capture of Saddam Hussein.

description: HALZEL--Lee Epstein Abramowitz. On Monday, December 15, 2003, of Chevy Chase, MD. Formerly of Swampscott, MA. description: The long-running labor dispute raging at a 170-employee bakery here has taken unusual turns in recent years, including accusations of death threats, illegal firings and managers forcing workers to have sex with them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAGAN, RACHEL
description: KAGAN--Rachel. It is with enormous sorrow that we share the news of our mother's death on December 13th, 2003 from breast cancer. She fought valiantly for as long as she was able. She took her leave with the same love, generosity, humor and grace that marked her entire life. She was a beloved wife, an adored mother, a cherished sister, aunt, cousin and friend who will be carried in the hearts of everyone who knew her. Funeral Tuesday, December 16th, at 1:30 PM, Boulevard Riverside Chapels, Hewlett, LI.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that the Central Intelligence Agency would be in charge of interrogating Saddam Hussein, and he strongly defended the treatment of the former Iraqi leader since his capture Saturday as legal, proper and humane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUMBER, MARY JOSEPHINE ''JO''
description: CUMBER--Mary Josephine ''Jo''. Mary Josephine ''Jo'' Cumber, 81, of Chester Village West, wife of the late Warner G. Cumber, died Friday, December 12th, 2003 at Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, CT. Jo spent most of her years in Douglaston, LI where she began her lifelong passion for sailing, tennis, bridge and gardening. Her Douglaston friends remained dear to her and loyal up until her final hours. After relocating to the CT shoreline in 1980 her determined spirit found her sailing, her Dyer dingy at 75, sharing her time with numerous volunteer organizations and serving on the Guild of the Good Speed Opera House for 21 years. She is survived by three daughters Linda Gifkins of Brooklyn, NY, Jane Allen of Old Saybrook, CT and Elizabeth Billik of Pelham Manor, NY, five grandchildren and a sister Peggs Francis of Marion, MA. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Good Speed Opera House Guild, POB 1360, East Haddam, CT 06423, attn: Bill Stamm or The Chester Hose Co. (ambulance service), POB 214, Chester, CT 06412.

title: Honoring the Centennial of Flight With Flight
description: A replica of the Wright brothers' 1903 Flyer will try to take off at 10:35 a.m. tomorrow from the original site, 100 years to the minute after the original. If the wind is not too fast and not too slow, and everything else cooperates, the airplane will hop the same 120 feet, with President Bush and thousands of others gathered to watch on the beach at Kill Devil Hills, N.C.

title: A Brief History of the Resistance
description: No less than Napoleon would recognize today's Iraqi battlefield. Two suicide bombers attacked Iraqi police and American forces yesterday, showing that the local insurgency that has plagued allied troops over the last six months continues despite the capture of Saddam Hussein. Indeed, the word ''guerrilla'' comes from the Spanish insurgency against France in the early 1800's -- a campaign, seemingly without leaders or direction, that at one point tied up three of Napoleon's armies.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Bomb Suspect Says He Trained In Qaeda Camp
description: A Turk charged with preparing the truck bombs that killed 62 people in Istanbul last month has told investigators that he received explosives training at a camp run by Al Qaeda in Afghanistan, The Associated Press reported. The suspect, Fevzi Yitiz, was captured Dec. 10 as he entered Turkey from Iran, according to an unidentified Turkish official quoted by the news agency. Mr. Yitiz said that he spent three months in the camp in 1994 and that two of his accomplices in the bombings met Osama Bin Laden last year, the official said. Mr. bin Laden approved the attacks, the report said. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Bomb Aimed at Pakistani Leader Weighed Nearly Half a Ton
description: A powerful remote-controlled bomb that exploded seconds after President Pervez Musharraf's motorcade passed it on Sunday night was made of 800 to 1,000 pounds of high explosives, the interior minister, Faisal Saleh Hayat, said Monday.

title: DILLARD'S INCREASES ITS REVOLVING CREDIT LINE
description: Dillard's, a 65-year-old department store chain, said yesterday that it had more than doubled its senior revolving credit line to $1 billion as it tries to halt sales declines. The company, based in Little Rock, Ark., will be able to tap $835 million of the line immediately, while the remainder will be available upon the redemption of some preferred securities. The previous credit line was $400 million.

description: PODVOLL--Edward Mitchell, MD, 67, of Boulder, CO, died December 10 at his residence. A Sukhavati (Memorial Service) was held on December 13 in Boulder. Memorial contributions may be made to the Edward Podvoll Memorial Fund, c/o Windhorse Guild, 1501 Yarmouth Ave., Boulder, CO. 80304.

title: Mets Mull Options In Right
description: Jim Duquette, the Mets' general manager, headed for the airport Monday with right field on his mind. He has two possible deals in the works to unload outfielder Roger Cedeo, who was more or less the team's right fielder last season after failing in center, and he was also planning to meet Tuesday with Brian Jordan, the outfielder who has tormented the Mets for years, particularly as a member of the Atlanta Braves.

description: The nuclear power industry may find its revival in space -- on the way to Jupiter.

title: Sports of The Times; Minority Candidates Should Get Fairer Shake
description: IT didn't come easy. Diversity never does. But at last, the National Football League has sharpened the teeth in its guidelines to provide at least a fairer shake to African-Americans who aspire to be one of its 32 head coaches.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about plans by Southwest Airlines to serve six cities from Philadelphia misstated the number and destination of direct US Airways flights to Chicago from Philadelphia, one of the line's hubs. There are six, not nine. They go to O'Hare International Airport, not Midway Airport.

title: Motorola Narrows to 2 Its Search for New Chief
description: Motorola, looking for a new chief executive as it struggles to reverse a long-term decline in its business, has narrowed its search to two candidates and will announce a choice soon, a company spokeswoman said last night.

title: In Surprise Move, Wasserstein Will Buy New York Magazine
description: In a surprising finish to a spirited bidding battle, the investment banker Bruce Wasserstein confirmed late this afternoon that he had reached a deal to buy New York magazine from Primedia Inc. for $55 million in cash.

title: Mrs. Clinton Wary of Iraq Plan
description: A day after the Bush administration announced that Saddam Hussein had been captured, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said Monday that it should consider delaying its timetable for transferring power from the American occupation authority to a self-ruling Iraqi government by next summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILSON, BARBARA
description: WILSON--Barbara, Psychotherapist, of New York City, died December 15, 2003. Adored wife of Gordon Wilson. Loving mother of Deborah, Denise, Claude and Ian and mother-in-law of Gene Levy, Lea Abrams and Marianela Wilson. Loving grandmother of Riley, Johanna, Maggie, Daniel, Mariah, Chloe, Eva Rose, Cristian and Gordon. Beloved by her mother Lillian Campbell and brother Frank Keach, and many cousins. Graduated from Fordham University, Summa Cum Laude, and current member of Board of Advisors of Fordham University at Lincoln Center. Graduate degree from New York Institute of Technology. Past Chairwoman of the Board of the West Side YMCA, member of the Board of Managers 1981-1998, and Woman of the Year in 1988. Visitation at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave on Thursday, December 18, 2-5 and 7-9PM. All whose lives she touched were aware of her immense capacity for giving love and compassion and help, and of her innate sense of fun. She lit up the lives of so many. Donations in her memory may be made to The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund. A memorial service in celebration of her life is being planned. The date will be announced later.

title: Seabiscuit at the Gate, With Some 30's History to Enhance a Legend's Reality
description: From its making to its opening in July, Gary Ross's ''Seabiscuit,'' released on DVD today by Universal, heard the hoofbeats of its source material. ''It was probably the first time since 'The Godfather' that an adult book had been a best seller at the time the movie came out,'' Mr. Ross said last week from Los Angeles. ''So everybody knew the story.''

title: EDWARDS LIFESCIENCES TO BUY VALVE COMPANY
description: The Edwards Lifesciences Corporation, the world's biggest maker of artificial heart valves, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Percutaneous Valve Technologies for $125 million to gain a technology used to implant valves without opening the chest. The cash purchase will reduce first-quarter profit by as much as $90 million, or $1.50 a share, Edwards said. Edwards, which is based in Irvine, Calif., may pay $30 million more if Percutaneous reaches certain development goals. The purchase gives Edwards a technology that allows a heart valve to be replaced under local anesthesia using a catheter. Percutaneous is based in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: BHUTAN: STRIKES AGAINST INDIAN MILITANTS The usually peaceful Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan began a military operation to destroy training camps used by Indian guerrilla groups operating hit-and-run attacks on the neighboring Indian states of Assam and West Bengal. "Bhutan is faced with the most difficult period in its history," said a statement released by the Bhutanese Embassy in New Delhi. About 3,000 Indian militants belonging to three different groups are believed to have operated 30 camps in Bhutan for the past 12 years. India, which has pressured the Bhutanese government to remove the camps, has provided training and military and logistical support to Bhutan's army.    Hari Kumar (NYT)

Bloomberg said happily yesterday at a news conference where he and his police commissioner released federal figures showing that the city has continued to push crime down more aggressively than most major cities.

title: City Gives $5 Million to Man Wrongly Imprisoned in Child's Rape
description: A man who spent seven years in prison after he was wrongfully convicted of raping a girl at a Bronx daycare center won a $5 million settlement from the city, his lawyer announced yesterday.

title: A Martian Invasion
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel on Terror Calls for Board On Protecting Civil Liberties
description: A federal commission on terrorism recommended on Monday that the White House establish an independent bipartisan panel to review whether new laws and regulations proposed by the government might infringe on civil liberties.

title: Rebuilding Iraq With Clean Hands
description: With Saddam Hussein finally in custody and the future of Iraq looking a little more secure, we're hearing calls for President Bush to rip up the list of countries that the United States has deemed eligible to bid on prime contracts for rebuilding Iraq. Mr. Bush should stick to his guns; that list of 63 countries, all of whom helped the American-led coalition, was good policy. But it's important to be clear about why it is a good idea -- because in the piata grab for the $18.6 billion in reconstruction contracts, some basic points have gotten lost.

title: Vatican Official Says U.S. Treated Hussein Like a Cow
description: ROME, Dec. 16  A senior Vatican official and critic of the war in Iraq said today that he felt compassion for Saddam Hussein, and he reproached the United States for releasing video footage showing the former Iraqi leader handled "like a cow."

title: Justices Agree To Tackle Antitrust Case
description: The Supreme Court, accepting a closely watched international price-fixing case for review, agreed on Monday to decide how United States antitrust law applies to transactions that take place entirely overseas.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Staten Island Ferry Set For Repair
description: The city's Department of Transportation has reached an agreement with a Staten Island company to repair the ferry that plowed into a concrete pier in October, killing 10 people. The $5.96 million contract was awarded to Caddell Dry Dock and Repair. The company said it would repair the boat by May 15. The ferry, the Andrew J. Barberi, has been sitting in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. A barge will deliver it this week to Caddell so that work can begin. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: President Signs Law Aiming to Limit Spam
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16  President Bush signed a highly anticipated law this morning to restrict junk commercial e-mail, which now accounts for more than half of all e-mail traffic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GERSON, HARVEY
description: GERSON--Harvey of New York City. Survived by wife Kathy, children David, Stephanie and Eric, and Ross, sister Sandy Koenig, uncle of Rachel and Lyle. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, New Jersey, Wednesday, 12:30PM. 1-800-378-1892.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Interpreter Bill Advances
description: The City Council passed a bill yesterday requiring the city's social service agencies to provide translation services for people who do not speak English. The bill, which the Bloomberg administration supports, is to be phased in over five years. It also requires the agencies to make documents available in the six most-requested languages: Arabic, Chinese, Creole, Korean, Russian and Spanish. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Mondavi Founder Resigns
description: The Robert Mondavi Corporation, the maker of Woodbridge and Opus One wines, said its founder, Robert Mondavi, resigned from the company's board at the annual shareholder meeting on Friday and would remain chairman emeritus.

title: Powell Has Surgery to Treat Prostate Cancer, Staff Says
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell underwent surgery for prostate cancer on Monday, several months after doctors detected the disease in its early stages, officials said.

title: Bin Laden and Omar: Far Harder to Find
description: If American forces found Saddam Hussein hiding in an eight-foot-deep hole in central Iraq, why have they not found Osama bin Laden or the fugitive Taliban leader, Mullah Muhammad Omar?

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: Frequent Flier; No Place to Ignore Local Advice
description: I've had to negotiate with a lot of different characters over the years, but it wasn't until last March that I had to negotiate with a monkey and lost.

title: Sniper Suspect Is Described As Eager, Not Brainwashed
description: Lee Malvo was a petty criminal prone to violence long before he met John A. Muhammad and has recently been plotting his escape from custody, two prosecution psychologists testified on Monday at Mr. Malvo's trial here on capital murder charges.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.P.S. Looks to Congress For Relief on Pensions

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: New Phone Service
description: Hutchison Whampoa, Asia's biggest investor in European cellphone networks, plans to start its advanced wireless service in Hong Kong next month after reaching a deal with NEC to solve a handset shortage that delayed the introduction by a year. NEC agreed to supply one million phones this month to Hutchison, which began so-called third-generation services in Europe and Australia this year. Hong Kong is the only place in Asia, excluding Taiwan, with more cellular accounts than people and will be the seventh market for Hutchison's service. A lack of phones forced Hutchison, which is based in Hong Kong, to delay the service.

title: U.S. Opposes Chosen Route For Pipeline Under Hudson
description: The United States Commerce Department has upheld the Pataki administration's opposition to a proposed 425-mile natural-gas pipeline from Lake Erie to Westchester County, agreeing that the state has the right to prevent it from crossing the Hudson River into Westchester at a proposed spot, state and federal officials said on Monday.

title: A Sizzling Hot Stove Rouses the A.L. East
description: Theo Epstein, the general manager of the Boston Red Sox, delayed an interview to use an automated teller machine in the lobby of the Marriott hotel here. Epstein needed a little money, which is the same thing the Texas Rangers have been telling the Red Sox they need to help facilitate trading Alex Rodriguez for Manny Ramirez. Actually, the Rangers want about $25 million, much more than Epstein could have pulled from the machine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENOCK, MARK
description: HENOCK--Mark. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Mark Henock, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Janet, and the entire family. Marc Goldberg, President Rabbi Stanley Platek

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Ford Urged To Revamp Police Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company, maker of a car that police unions say bursts into flames when hit from behind, should include a fire-suppression system as a standard feature of the 2005 police car version, according to a report by the New York State Senate. Ford has offered to make such a system an option for the Police Interceptor, the 2005 Crown Victoria model that is made for patrol duty. State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, left, Republican of Yonkers, made his recommendation in a new report by the Committee on Investigation and Government Operations, which he heads. Kristen Kinley, a Ford spokeswoman, said the fire-suppression system now being developed would not be standard because not all police vehicles ''require such advanced technology, designed primarily for high-risk patrol such as highways.'' In December 2002, a state trooper was killed when a Jeep Cherokee crashed into his Crown Victoria. Al Baker (NYT)

title: A Brand New Aircraft in Search of Buyers
description: The Boeing Company, which is expected to announce plans today to market its 7E7 jetliner, faces the immediate and challenging task of finding buyers for the plane, a medium-range aircraft that is its first new plane in more than a decade.

title: In Secaucus, A Rail Station Brings Relief To a Workday
description: After two months of use on the weekends, the $450 million Secaucus Transfer station had its premiere for the crush of weekday commuters on Monday and drew raves from riders.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Leaseholder Loses Court Fight
description: Larry Silverstein, the World Trade Center leaseholder, lost his bid to reverse an appeals court ruling that the Sept. 11, 2001, attack on the twin towers did not entitle him to a $7 billion insurance payment. The three-judge appellate panel that issued the ruling in September denied his petition for a rehearing. Mr. Silverstein had made the request on the ground that the panel misinterpreted New York law when it found that a policy issued by the Travelers Indemnity Company did not require that the two plane crashes be seen as separate events, each requiring a loss payment of $3.55 billion.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: BMC Software Buying Network Associates Unit
description: BMC Software, which makes and maintains business-management software, agreed yesterday to buy the Magic Solutions unit of Network Associates for $47 million to add customer-service programs for small and midsize companies. BMC plans to keep 200 workers at Magic Solutions, which is based in Plano, Tex., and makes software used to log and answer customer calls. Network Solutions also makes McAfee and Sniffer computer-security programs. The deal will close in the first quarter, Network Associates said. BMC aims to take sales from companies including Computer Associates International and Peregrine Systems by acquiring Magic Solutions, which has about 4,000 clients, a BMC spokesman, Arch Currid, said. The deal will add to profit in the fiscal year beginning in April, BMC said. The company, based in Houston, had net losses in its first and second quarters. Customer-service products were not part of Network Associates' main business in computer-security software, the chief financial officer, Stephen Richards, said on a conference call. Mr. Richards, also the company's operating chief, said he expected no opposition to the purchase from the Securities and Exchange Commission even though BMC's Remedy division sells similar software. BMC shares fell 5 cents, to $16.95. Network Associates fell 6 cents, to $14.37.

title: Meeting on New Constitution, Afghan Women Find Old Attitudes
description: After hours of tedium on Monday in the selection of deputy chairmen for Afghanistan's constitutional convention, or loya jirga, there came a moment of illusion-shattering truth.

title: Judges Say Democratic Official Issued List of Favored Lawyers
description: Several judges in Brooklyn have told investigators that a Brooklyn Democratic Party official had given them a list of lawyers to consider when handing out court appointments, according to a law enforcement official and a lawyer involved in the case.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR DROPS. The dollar fell against the euro on concern that low interest rates will deter foreign investors from buying United States financial assets. In New York, the euro settled at $1.2299, up from $1.2288 on Friday.

title: Iraqi Minister Scolds U.N. for Inaction Regarding Hussein
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 16 — Iraq's foreign minister, Hoshyar Zebari, accused the United Nations Security Council today of having failed to help rescue his country from Saddam Hussein, and he chided member states for bickering over his beleaguered country's future.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Rebels Kill 9 Guards
description: From two to four dozen Chechen rebels crossed into the neighboring region of Dagestan, killed nine Russian border troops and seized four hostages before disappearing into the rugged, snow-covered Caucasus, officials said. The rebels appeared to have stumbled into a firefight with federal forces. The fate of the hostages, including two hospital workers, remained unclear. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A Big Museum Opens, to Jeers as Well as Cheers
description: The Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum opened a vast, gleaming new building on the edge of Dulles International Airport here on Monday, filled with aircraft of every description, including the B-29 that carried the first atomic bomb dropped on Japan.

title: Man Held in Killings Of Woman and Boy
description: A Long Island man was charged yesterday with fatally stabbing his girlfriend and strangling her 11-year old son, then dumping their bodies in a water-drainage area, the police said.

title: Security Council to Discuss A Possible New Role in Iraq
description: The Security Council is to discuss Iraq on Tuesday, and the United States ambassador, John D. Negroponte, said Monday that he hoped the capture of Saddam Hussein would spur member states to close ranks behind American plans to transform the country.

title: Russian Oil, French Taxes and Foreign Intrigue
description: Elena Collongues-Popova worked for years in silence, as the financial architect of parts of the early empire built by Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, who controls Yukos, the giant Russian oil company.

title: MTV is trying to make a Nobel laureate into a hero for teenagers.
description: WITH a new advertising campaign, MTV Networks Europe hopes to turn Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Burmese dissident, into a Nelson Mandela for the music video generation.

description: In the stormy world of climate science, Dr. Jerry D. Mahlman, 63, is considered a giant.

title: 2 Step Down From Board Of Troubled Health Chain
description: Two longtime board members of HealthSouth, the embattled chain of hospitals and clinics, resigned yesterday as part of a settlement with a pension fund that sued the company.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Interim U.S. Attorney Named
description: David N. Kelley, the former deputy to James B. Comey Jr., the United States attorney for the southern district of New York, was appointed yesterday to replace him on an interim basis for 120 days, or until a permanent replacement is named. Mr. Kelley, 44, was sworn in by Judge Michael B. Mukasey of Federal District Court. Mr. Comey, 42, was named deputy attorney general in October by President Bush. Mr. Kelley, who led the Justice Department's task force in Washington investigating the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, began his career as a police officer and is a veteran prosecutor in terrorism cases. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Executive Resigns
description: The French bank Crdit Agricole said its deputy chief executive, Dominique Ferrero, left, quit, the second resignation in less than three months by a former top Crdit Lyonnais officer. Mr. Ferrero, who ran the investment-banking unit, stepped down at a board meeting in Paris. Edouard Esparbes, 59, the head of Crdit Agricole's biggest regional bank, will succeed him as deputy chief executive and head of investment banking, a spokeswoman, Louise Tingstrom, said. Mr. Ferrero, 56, was named head of Crdit Agricole's corporate and investment banking division in June after the 16 billion euro ($19.6 billion) purchase of Crdit Lyonnais, where he had been chief executive. His departure follows the Oct. 2 resignation of Crdit Lyonnais's chairman, Jean Peyrelevade, who quit to defend himself against claims he was aware of wrongdoing related to the bank's purchase of assets of a failed California insurer, Executive Life, in the early 1990's.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column in the Travel section on Dec. 7, about Oaxaca, Mexico, referred incorrectly to a weaver in a nearby town, Teotitln del Valle. Arnulfo Mendoza is not dead; his father, Emiliano, whose weavings are also sold there, died recently.

title: Edwards Is Looking Toward Changes
description: Herman Edwards went home Sunday night, intent on enjoying for a few hours one of the slivers of happiness the Jets' disappointing season had provided, a 6-0 victory over Pittsburgh. Edwards did not turn on the television searching for the late scores, so he did not find out until Monday morning that Denver had won to officially eliminate the Jets from the playoff race.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Nov. 19 about the killing of an 8-year-old boy during a drug-related shootout in East New York, Brooklyn, misspelled his given name. He was Daesean Hill, not Dasean.

title: Abercrombie Again Picks Racy Team
description: Last week Abercrombie & Fitch canceled its racy quarterly magazine because of controversy over a corporate image built on young collegiate types prone to playing naked air guitar. The retailer announced that in the place of the provocative A&F Quarterly, it would expand a more traditional catalog it publishes. But this week the company, which has nearly 700 stores, revealed plans to shoot the newest edition of the catalog next month using, surprise, the same art director, Sam Shahid; photographer, Bruce Weber; stylists and crew who made the quarterly risqu in the first place.

title: In Grip of Economic Decline, Venezuela Seeks Stability
description: Trucks once wheezed along these streets, loaded with goods from the factories that flocked here in the 1970's when the government sought to make Cua a manufacturing hub.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the Lunch Club and other online services in New York City for people seeking new friends misspelled the surname of a participant and misstated his marital status. He is Brad Stonberg, not Stoneberg, and he is single, not married.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: No Charges In Car Scandal
description: A prosecutor decided not to file charges against Antony Leung, the former financial secretary, for buying a luxury Lexus sedan a month before announcing a budget last March that more than doubled taxes on luxury car purchases. The director of public prosecutions concluded that it could not be proved that Mr. Leung, who resigned in July, deliberately sought to evade the tax increase. Mr. Leung saved $24,000 in taxes but denied that he thought about the coming tax increase. He donated $48,000 to charity after the purchase became known. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Lehman Chip Analyst Gets New Position
description: A top Wall Street semiconductor analyst, Daniel T. Niles of Lehman Brothers Holdings, will move to the company's asset-management business to lead a new unit focused on technology shares. Mr. Niles will be chief executive of the business, called Neuberger Berman Technology Management, said Kerrie Cohen, a spokeswoman for the New York-based firm. Mr. Niles, 36, followed chip makers and computer makers for Lehman, the world's fourth-biggest securities firm by capital. Money managers surveyed this year by Institutional Investor magazine voted Mr. Niles the top semiconductor analyst, and he was named a runner-up for his coverage of computer companies. Mr. Niles starts his new assignment next month. He will report to Neuberger Berman's president, Robert Matza, and remain in San Francisco.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: CITY FACES MORE DEFICITS, COMPTROLLER SAYS The local economy appears to have pulled through the recession, but New York City still faces budget gaps in the next few years, the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., reported yesterday. Next year's gap, which the Bloomberg administration put at $1.8 billion, could rise to $2.3 billion if Gov. George E. Pataki wins his court battle to halt a deal for the state to take over the city's debt from the 1970's. The next year's gap will be $3.4 billion to $3.9 billion, the report said.   Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: EMC Acquires Software Maker For $635 Million
description: The EMC Corporation took a significant step to broaden its business yesterday with the purchase of VMware for $635 million in cash.

description: A new study finds that having a stroke puts people at higher risk for developing Alzheimer's disease.

title: New Democratic Group Finances a Republican-like Attack on Dean
description: A new Democratic group that is running advertisements against Howard Dean and has not yet disclosed its sources of financing has introduced by far the toughest commercial of the primary election season.

title: Motorola Selects Former Sun Executive to Be Its New Chief
description: OT"> Motorola Inc. , the struggling mobile telephone maker, said today that it had named Edward J. Zander, a venture capitalist who spent four years as president and chief operating officer at Sun Microsystems , to succeed Christopher B. Galvin as chairman and chief executive.

description: DUCAT--Josef B. December 13, 2003. Beloved father of Suzanne B. and Vivian S. Devoted companion of Renata Senter. Grandfather of Hannah, Hugo and Oscar. Father-inlaw of Stanley Cohen and Ray Segal. ''Let's be positive''. Donations to charity of your choice.

title: ABBOTT LABS AGREES TO BUY I-STAT FOR $392 MILLION
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the i-Stat Corporation, a provider of blood testing systems, for about $392 million. Abbott already owns about 10 percent of the company, which is based in East Windsor, N.J. It is paying $15.35 for each of the shares it does not already own. Shares of i-Stat closed yesterday at $15.21, up $2.34, or 18 percent, on heavy volume on the Nasdaq exchange. Abbott said the acquisition would give it continued access to a broad product portfolio, including i-Stat's automated hand-held blood analyzer for bedside testing. I-Stat also has several products in development, including tests for congestive heart failure.

title: Attacks Go On; Car Bomb Kills 6 Iraqi Officers
description: Two powerful car bombs exploded at police stations in Baghdad on Monday, killing at least 6 Iraqi officers, wounding more than 20 other people and announcing that the insurgency here has not ended with the arrest of Saddam Hussein.

title: France and Germany Agree to Substantial Cuts in Iraq Debt
description: PARIS, Dec. 16 — France and Germany agreed to work toward a "substantial reduction" of Iraq's towering foreign debt next year, marking a significant step forward in the United States' effort to rebuild the devastated country as well as progress in mending ties with the two countries most opposed to the American-led war there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHE, FRIEDA
description: ROTHE--Frieda. I mourn the passing of Frieda Rothe, an enthusiastic champion of the artists she represented, and music in general. She will be warmly remembered. Lee Lamont

description: Frank Simek has had his taste of the big time, and he wants more.

title: Hussein Tells Interrogators He Didn't Direct Insurgency
description: Saddam Hussein has denied playing any direct role in commanding Iraqi insurgents or in planning attacks after he went into hiding, and he said his government possessed no prohibited weapons, United States government officials said Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLATELL, JACK, D.D.S.
description: KLATELL -- Jack, D.D.S. Dean Ira B. Lamster, Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, notes with deep sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Jack Klatell, Clinical Professor of Dentistry, on December 11, 2003. He graduated magna cum laude from City College in 1937 where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and received his D.D.S. from Columbia University in 1941. As Director of the Department of Dentistry at Mount Sinai Hospital, Jack was a dedicated educator and was instrumental in the development of the intramural program between the University and Hospital. He was a member of the American Dental Association, the American Academy of Oral Pathology, the American Association of Hospital Dentists, the Metropolitan Council of Hospital Dental Chiefs, and the Academy of General Dentistry. As a clinician, he provided exemplary care to his countless patients. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Arla, sons Robert and David, and the entire Klatell family.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 28 about the strategic significance of the former Soviet republic of Georgia to both Russia and the United States misspelled the given name of a Georgian political analyst who said Russia preferred to have weak neighbors. He is Archil Gegeshidze, not Archile. The article also misstated the name of his organization. It is the Georgian Foundation for Strategic and International Studies, not the Georgian Institute for Strategic Studies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Department Spokesman To Leave
description: Michael O'Looney, the principal spokesman for the New York City Police Department, will leave the department next month to take a job at Merrill Lynch, the police said. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said in a statement that Mr. O'Looney, who joined the Police Department in January 2002, would be replaced by Paul J. Browne, a former journalist who served as press secretary and chief of staff to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. Mr. O'Looney, whose last day at the Police Department will be Jan. 15, will take over as vice president of corporate communications at Merrill Lynch. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHEMESH, MURRAY
description: SHEMESH--Murray. The Department of Pathology of Columbia University notes with sadness the passing on December 11 of Murray Shemesh whose wife, Mildred, has long been associated with our department and the College of Physicians and Surgeons. A man of many talents and interests, Murray was first and foremost a family man. Our condolences to Mildred, daughter Lorraine and son Mark, grandchildren, and the family. Michael L. Shelanski, M.D., Ph.D. Jay H. Lefkowitch, M.D.

title: Corrections

title: The Modern Adds Art As Its Building Grows
description: As it races to finish its $858 million expansion and renovation, the Museum of Modern Art has also been acquiring close to $40 million worth of paintings, drawings and sculpture, hoping to reopen in a year with an even richer permanent collection than before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAURO, JAMES V.
description: LAURO--James V. Born November 22, 1920. Died December 11, 2003 at his home in Round Top, NY. He retired from his company, Analytical Service Labs, and worked previously at the New York Produce Exchange Labs. He was a member of the Harbour View Club and Downtown Athletic Club. Mr. Lauro served in the Chemical Mortar Division during WW II, and received the Silver Star as well as two Purple Hearts. Mr. Lauro is survived by his children, Erika, Gretel and Michael as well as seven grandchildren and one great granddaughter. Viewing is on December 16, 2-4 and 6-8 at the Richards Funeral Home in Cairo, New York.

title: A Worker Is Killed In a Trench Collapse
description: A construction worker was accidentally decapitated in a Staten Island sewer tunnel yesterday when co-workers tried to dig him out of the collapsed trench with a backhoe, Fire Department spokesmen said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Baby Dies After Being Crushed
description: A 21-month-old baby has died from injuries she sustained when a neighbor accidentally fell on her at a party on Saturday night, the police said. The child, India Bryant, of West 160th Street in Washington Heights, had apparently fallen, and the neighbor tried to help her up. Instead, the neighbor fell on the child and crushed her, the police said last night. The baby died on Sunday night at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. No charges were brought. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUPONT, ALANA LAWRENCE
description: DUPONT--Alana Lawrence. Passed away on December 13, 2003, in Burlingame, California, after a brave, yearlong battle against cancer. A loving family including her husband of twenty-eight years, Peter W. Dupont, and their three daughters, Lilly, Daisy, and Charlotte were by her side. She left many friends and family members in New York, and California, whose lives she enriched with her joyful, creative, and generous spirit. She was an accomplished sportswoman, holding several titles in squash. She enjoyed wide recognition as an artist, known for her uniquely expressive work particularly in portraiture and landscape. Services January 17, 2004, 11AM, Christ Church, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, her family welcomes gifts in Alana's memory to: The Alana L. Dupont Fine Arts Education Fund, c/o Peninsula Community Foundation, 1700 South El Camino Real, San Mateo, CA 94402.

title: With Roster in Place, Finally, Knicks Look for Consistency
description: On Sunday night, Don Chaney finally had the Knicks' roster in place the way it was imagined on paper. But the result, even in victory, was not quite what had been envisioned.
