Adored grandfather of Liliana, Cole, and Evie. Memorial service All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue at 80th Street, NY, NY, Saturday, December 20, 2003 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Columbia University, Department of Surgery, Edmund N. Goodman Educational Fund, 630 West 168th Street, New York, New York 10032.

title: 2 Palestinians Killed by Israelis At Boundary of the Gaza Strip
description: Israeli soldiers in the Gaza Strip shot dead two unarmed Palestinians trying to breach a fence and enter Israel before dawn on Monday. Troops also tore down Palestinian buildings in southern Gaza that the Israeli military said were linked to mortar attacks a day earlier.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ALABAMA: JUDGES STEP ASIDE FOR APPEAL The eight State Supreme Court justices recused themselves from hearing the appeal of former Chief Justice Roy Moore, who seeks reinstatement after removal from office in November by the State Court of the Judiciary. In August, the eight justices ordered a Ten Commandments monument removed from the State Judiciary Building after Chief Justice Moore refused to comply with a federal judge's order to do so. The court drew seven names from a pool of retired judges, include former Gov. John Patterson. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEARSON, AMY
description: PEARSON--Amy, on December 15th, 2003. Beloved wife of Nick. Devoted mother of Robb. Loving niece of Toby Lebenson. Dear cousin of Buddy and Penny Lebenson. Services Wednesday, December 17th, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Back at Desk, Gov. Rowland Is Under Fire
description: On his first day back at work Monday after admitting three days ago that he had provided false and misleading information about who had paid for renovations to his Litchfield cottage, Gov. John G. Rowland spent the day sequestered in his office, working the phones, meeting with aides and planning his strategy to rebuild his image and keep his job.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Melvin Berning was named executive vice president for advertising sales at A&E Television Networks, New York, overseeing A&E, the Biography Channel and the History Channel. He succeeds Whitney Goit , who was named senior executive vice president. Mr. Berning had been president for United States broadcast at MediaVest USA, New York, part of the Starcom MediaVest Group division of the Publicis Groupe. At MediaVest, he will be succeeded by Donna Speciale , who had been executive vice president and director for national and local broadcast at MediaCom U.S., New York, part of the MediaCom Worldwide division of the Grey Global Group. The A&E networks are owned by the ABC division of the Walt Disney Company, the Hearst Corporation and the NBC unit of the General Electric Company.

title: Teenagers Want More Advice From Parents on Sex, Study Says
description: Adults are far more likely than their children to think that it is embarrassing for teenagers to admit to being virgins, and in fact teenagers wish their parents were a bit bolder in advising them about whether to have sex, according to a national study being released today.

title: Camera Down the Hole, And the World Follows It
description: Saddam Hussein was not locked into leg irons. He didn't writhe in a police hold; he didn't appear with his hands cuffed.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Restoring Big Rams

title: After 12 Years, Sweet Victory: The Bushes Pursuit of Hussein
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15  On Feb. 28, 1991, at the end of the Persian Gulf war, the first President Bush confided to his diary, "Still no feeling of euphoria," and added: "The television we see accurately reflects the humiliation of Saddam Hussein and it drives the point home to the American people. But internationally, it's not there yet, at least in the Arab world that has been lined up with Saddam."

title: Looking Ahead: The Trial of an Iraqi Tyrant
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 From Marque Funds Settle With S.E.C.
description: Robert T. Littell, the former investments director of the Marque Millennium Group, a New York money management firm, has agreed to pay a $15,000 fine to settle civil fraud accusations brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Patriots And Profits
description: Last week there were major news stories about possible profiteering by Halliburton and other American contractors in Iraq. These stories have, inevitably and appropriately, been pushed temporarily into the background by the news of Saddam's capture. But the questions remain. In fact, the more you look into this issue, the more you worry that we have entered a new era of excess for the military-industrial complex.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Court Lifts Stay Of Execution
description: The United States Supreme Court lifted a stay of execution that it granted last week to a death row inmate who said part of the execution procedure was unconstitutional. In an action joined by other condemned prisoners in Texas, the inmate, Kevin L. Zimmerman, said that pancuronium bromide, one of three chemicals commonly used in states that execute prisoners by lethal injection, caused impermissible pain. Justice Antonin Scalia, who halted Mr. Zimmerman's execution 20 minutes before it was to be carried out, was in the majority in the 5-to-4 decision to lift the stay. A new execution date will be set for Mr. Zimmerman, who was convicted of murder in a robbery in 1987. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: The Squabbling Illini: Rallying Cries Lead to Rift
description: The history books say the last Indian tribe in Illinois was forcibly relocated to Kansas and then Oklahoma early in the 19th century.

title: F.D.A. Moves to Let Drug Treat Obese Teenagers
description: The Food and Drug Administration effectively approved the use of an obesity drug, Xenical, for adolescents yesterday. This is the first time that a weight-loss drug has been permitted to treat overweight children.

title: THE CAPTURE OF HUSSEIN: 'High-Value Target No. 1'; Hussein's Final Hiding Place: A Small Roadside Compound
description: Yesterday, allied forces gave a tour of the site where Saddam Hussein was captured, providing a detailed view of the sparse conditions in which he spent his final time as a fugitive. Mr. Hussein was discovered Saturday night hiding in a hole in the ground near a mud hut here. Objects are shown as they were positioned at the time of the tour. ARCHIE TSE

title: The Morning-After Pill
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Dec. 7 about American soldiers in Iraq misstated the year in which the Allies captured Rome. It was 1944, not 1943.

title: British Ignite A Debate On Drugs And Suicide
description: Many American psychiatrists were taken by surprise last week when British drug regulators told doctors to stop writing prescriptions for all but one of a newer generation of antidepressant drugs to treat depressed children under 18.

title: Health Care Workers Who Kill
description: Since 1975, more than 20 health care workers in the United States have been convicted or implicated in the deaths of multiple patients. Some recent cases:

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Tutu Critical Of Zimbabwe Support
description: Desmond Tutu, the retired South African archbishop and Nobel Peace Prize winner, sharply criticized his nation's government for backing Zimbabwe's president, Robert Mugabe, in the face of rising global attacks of Mr. Mugabe's human rights record. Recalling that South African blacks demanded that the world intervene in the nation's internal affairs to end injustice, Mr. Tutu said South Africa, perhaps Zimbabwe's leading supporter, could not stand by in the face of abuses there. In Ethiopia, an unrepentant Mr. Mugabe pressed his theme that Zimbabwe's was but a whipping boy for white colonialists, telling a conference on Sino-African relations that Western nations were ''predatory warrior states'' bent on oppressing small nations like his. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Nairobi Journal; Is Polygamy Confusing, or Just a Matter of Family Values?
description: When President Mwai Kibaki of Kenya arrived at the White House recently for a state visit, his wife, Lucy Kibaki, was at his side, resplendent in a flowing gown.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Oil Decisions
description: The energy minister, Einar Steensnaes, decided to reopen much of the Barents Sea to oil drilling after a two-year suspension to study the potential effect of spills on marine life. At the same time, he said oil companies would not be permitted to resume exploration off the Lofoten Islands in the Norwegian Sea, saying oil companies could not guarantee the safety of rich cod-spawning waters there. Both areas are above the Arctic Circle. By opening one and keeping the other closed, Mr. Steensnaes drew the ire of both environmentalists and the oil industry. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: Painting Hussein's Portrait
description: Saddam Hussein has long been an obsession for the world, and particularly the United States. Yet Iraq was so cut off from the outside that it was impossible for anyone -- including, it seems, American intelligence officials -- to get a clear picture of who he really was. We got a series of vivid but inconsistent portraits, colored to fit various political agendas. Now that the real man is under interrogation, we hope a single realistic version will emerge.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Executive Salary Revised
description: The drug maker GlaxoSmithKline, which had its pay plan rejected by shareholders, said it would leave the salary of its chief executive alone but would cut his severance. The new pay plan will allow the executive, Jean-Pierre Garnier, to get shares and options worth about 3.2 million ($5.6 million) after three years. His salary will remain at 967,000 with a bonus pegged to performance goals, a Glaxo spokesman said. Mr. Garnier earned a combined salary and bonus of 2.5 million last year. Earlier this year, Glaxo's investors rejected a plan that would have given Mr. Garnier as much as $28 million if he were fired. Shareholders, led by the Association of British Insurers, pushed to link salary and severance pay to the performance of stock.

title: Clark Testifies Against Milosevic at Hague Tribunal
description: In a grenade-proof courtroom far from the battlefields of the Balkans, Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, came face to face on Monday with Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the former NATO supreme commander who waged war against him.

title: Looking Ahead: The Trial of an Iraqi Tyrant
description: To the Editor:

title: France Says It Is Willing to Make Deal on Iraq's Foreign Debt
description: Seizing the initiative a day after the announcement of Saddam Hussein's capture, France said it would work with other nations to forgive an unspecified portion of Iraq's immense foreign debt.

title: A Tough Call on Touchdown Celebrations
description: The stunt that New Orleans Saints receiver Joe Horn pulled after scoring a touchdown against the Giants on Sunday night became the talk of the N.F.L. yesterday, which was either the best thing about it or the worst thing about it, depending on your point of view.

title: Finding Hussein Took Skill And Plenty of Legwork
description: Just before 8 p.m. on Saturday, the power suddenly went out across this village, plunging it into darkness on an already moonless night.

title: With Acquisition, Lions Gate Is Now Largest Indie
description: One of Hollywood's leading independent studios, Lions Gate Entertainment, acquired the ailing Artisan Entertainment on Monday, creating the largest independent studio in the industry.

title: Generals Say Husseins Capture Will Hurt Rebel Recruiting
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 16 — The capture of Saddam Hussein has yet to slacken the pace of attacks against American forces in Iraq, but it will likely hurt recruiting for the insurgency over time, two senior American generals said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Charge At Bayer
description: The German drug and chemicals maker Bayer said it would take a charge of 2.2 billion euros ($2.7 billion) in the fourth quarter to write down the value of assets it is selling and, as a result, post a loss for the year. Investors had expected the write-down, which was related to Bayer's polymer and chemicals operations and to its health care unit. Bayer is turning parts of those businesses into a new company that will be spun off to shareholders. The company said that it expected operating income, which excludes one-time items, to increase by about 10 percent and that its dividend would not be affected. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: How About a Game B For 'Monday Night'?
description: For a few years, television and football thinkers have ruminated over how to strengthen ABC's ''Monday Night Football'' ratings and its too frequently weak matchups.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: AZERBAIJAN: BIG TURNOUT FOR EX-LEADER'S FUNERAL More than a million people filled the streets of Baku, the capital, for the funeral of Heydar Aliyev, who ruled the oil-rich former Soviet republic almost continuously for 34 years until he became too ill to continue in October. Joining the mourners were President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who was forced from the presidency of Georgia last month.    (AP)

title: The Neediest Cases; Better Life on the Horizon, But for Now, No Daughter
description: On the first night in their two-bedroom apartment, So Ching Chan and her husband, Yun Sang Lau, slept on the floor. They made a bed of blankets and crumpled-up plastic bags. Their dinner table was a piece of cardboard. Their meal was two cans of soup.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: President Vetoes Pro-Berlusconi Bill
description: President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi of Italy refused to sign a media bill widely seen to favor Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's media empire and sent it back to Parliament, saying the legislation could ''allow the formation of dominant positions'' in the media. It was the first time Mr. Ciampi, whose position is largely ceremonial, has declined to sign a bill for anything other than budgetary reasons. He would be obliged to sign if Parliament passes it a second time. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOGLIO, JANET A.
description: GOGLIO--Janet A. of Merrick on December 13, 2003. Attorney at Law and a Certified Public Accountant. Devoted daughter of Esther and the late Ferdinand Richard Goglio. Loving sister of Barbara Goglio. Also survived by her aunts, cousins and her many colleagues and friends. A Funeral Mass was offered at Sacred Heart Church in North Merrick with interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YORK, HARRIET GLOVER
description: YORK -- Harriet Glover, passed away on Wednesday, December 10, 2003 at Santa Rita Care Center in Green Valley, AZ. Mrs. York was formerly of Palm Beach, FL, New York City and Easthampton, NY. She was raised in Palm Beach, then lived for almost forty years in New York City. She lived for several years in Easthampton immediately before moving to Green Valley, AZ. She is predeceased by her husband Gordon, her sister Clara Glover, her son Donald and her parents. She is survived by her loving daughter Pamela and her granddaughter Sarah. There will be a memorial service in New York in the Spring.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Saturday about three Texas death row inmates who were scheduled to be executed last week misstated the number who were spared because of court inaction. One inmate, not three, was spared because the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit let a deadline expire without ruling on the inmate's request for a stay. (The two others were granted stays by other courts.)

title: CVS Forecasts Growth
description: The CVS Corporation, the drugstore chain, said yesterday that profit in 2004 would increase to as much as $2.18 a share amid rising sales and cost reductions.

title: Corrections
description: The On the Ground column in the Business Travel pages on Dec. 2, about Fort Myers, Fla., gave an outdated name for a recommended restaurant downtown. Shooters Waterfront Caf was renamed Toucan Charlie's Bar and Grill last year. It operates under new management at the same address, 2220 West First Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 28 about the strategic significance of the former Soviet republic of Georgia to both Russia and the United States misspelled the given name of a Georgian political analyst who said Russia preferred to have weak neighbors. He is Archil Gegeshidze, not Archile. The article also misstated the name of his organization. It is the Georgian Foundation for Strategic and International Studies, not the Georgian Institute for Strategic Studies.

title: Bill Allowing Stem Cell Work Clears New Jersey Assembly
description: The Assembly passed a bill on Monday that would make New Jersey the second state in the nation to permit embryonic stem cell research, a controversial practice that uses human cells and embryos to search for new treatments for Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's and other illnesses.

title: A Club for Aspiring Scrooges
description: One of Lea DeLaria's pet peeves at holiday time is the ubiquity of ''Silent Night.'' Ms. DeLaria, a comedian and jazz singer, detests it because, as she points out, most women are not exactly silent when giving birth. And early in her show, ''Virgin Mary, Make Mine a Double: A Very Lea Christmas,'' which runs through Saturday at the Belt Theater, a dingy back room of the Zipper Theater at 336 West 37th Street in Manhattan, she offers her revised version: a feral howl of pain.

title: After 12 Years, Sweet Victory: The Bushes' Pursuit of Hussein
description: On Feb. 28, 1991, at the end of the Persian Gulf war, the first President Bush confided to his diary, ''Still no feeling of euphoria,'' and added: ''The television we see accurately reflects the humiliation of Saddam Hussein and it drives the point home to the American people. But internationally, it's not there yet, at least in the Arab world that has been lined up with Saddam.''

title: They Held Out for Marriage; After 6 Decades of Decorum in Public, Gus and Elmer Eloped
description: In the language of their generation, Gus and Elmer were friends.

title: Congress to Weigh Easing U.P.S. Role On Pension Funds
description: Congress is expected to consider a proposal early next year that would shift responsibility for billions of dollars in future pension promises to the federal government from United Parcel Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, NATALIE ZWEIG
description: ROSEN--Natalie Zweig. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of Natalie Zweig Rosen, beloved mother of our member, David Rosen. May the entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion & Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, JAMES
description: MILLER--James. On December 14, 2003. Beloved husband of Arlene. Devoted father of Mark and Barbara, and sonin-law John Palefsky. Loving grandfather of Harrison, Susan and Michael. He was appointed a midshipman at the U.S. Naval Academy by President Harry S. Truman and graduated with the class of 1951. After serving on the U.S.S.F.D.R. aircraft carrier, he resigned his commission to enter the business world. He attended Cornell University under the combined business-law program, receiving an M.B.A. in 1958. He was a Fellow of the Life Insurance Management Association and was a member of the New York Society of Security Analysts. He owned businesses, managed property and wrote articles and books on financial matters.

title: Likely M.T.A Budget Cuts 22 Subway Elevator Operators' Jobs
description: Unbowed by vigorous neighborhood opposition, a committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's board approved a budget yesterday that includes cutting the number of elevator operators in five subway stations in Washington Heights.

title: German Leader and Opponents Compromise on Economic Plan
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany, in a deal that salvages two pillars of his ambitious economic agenda, has yielded to demands by the conservative opposition to scale back a proposed tax cut and to loosen entrenched labor laws.

title: Senator Breaux Won't Seek Re-election
description: John B. Breaux, a moderate Democratic senator and one of the few bipartisan dealmakers left in Congress, announced Monday that he would not run for re-election next year, becoming the fifth Southern Democrat to abandon the Senate.

title: Sunscreen: No Link to Cancer
description: A new study has found no evidence that sunscreen, commonly used to reduce the risk of skin cancer, actually increases the risk, researchers said yesterday.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Judges Step Aside For Appeal
description: The eight State Supreme Court justices recused themselves from hearing the appeal of former Chief Justice Roy Moore, who seeks reinstatement after removal from office in November by the State Court of the Judiciary. In August, the eight justices ordered a Ten Commandments monument removed from the State Judiciary Building after Chief Justice Moore refused to comply with a federal judge's order to do so. The court drew seven names from a pool of retired judges, include former Gov. John Patterson. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PENSAK, CHARLOTTE S.
description: PENSAK--Charlotte S. Died on December 12 at age 87. Beloved wife of Stanley. Had a long teaching career at LIU and Upsala College.

title: INSIDE
description: Foundry Managers Indicted On Safety Violation Charges

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, JOSEPH
description: COHEN--Joseph. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Joseph Cohen. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Gary Miller, Chairman of the Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ASTUTO, GLORIA
description: ASTUTO--Gloria. Wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Lisa and Gasper Vultaggio, Marie and Bill McDaid, Tammy Ann and Thomas Bomengo, Jennifer Astuto and Cesar Zuniga. Also survived by six grandchildren. Reposing at Colonial Funeral Home, Hylan Blvd. at Tysons Lane, S.I. Mass of the Resurrection Thursday 9:45 AM, Our Lady Star of the Sea RC Church. Interment Moravian Cemetery.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Check Point To Acquire Zone Labs
description: Check Point Software Technologies, an Internet security company, announced yesterday that it would acquire Zone Labs, a competitor that is privately owned, for $205 million. The price includes $113 million in cash and approximately $92 million in shares, the companies said. Check Point, which has its international headquarters in Ramat Gan, Israel, and its United States headquarters in Redwood City, Calif., is a major provider to businesses of Internet security products for the perimeter of company computer networks, including firewalls. Zone Labs, which is based in San Francisco, makes Internet security products that are popular with small businesses and consumers. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Manhattan Forecast: Shades of Snow
description: At one crucial point in the new hit film ''Something's Gotta Give,'' Diane Keaton, who plays a writer reawakened to love in the late stages of midlife, implores Jack Nicholson to liberate her from a particularly choking turtleneck. The sweater, like nearly everything else in the closet of her character Erica Barry's dreamy Sagaponack home is cirrus-cloud white, a color chosen to remind viewers that she has lived untouchably high up above the hills and dales of her own emotional need.

title: Candor or Deceit?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Words Rule, but Her Music Sets Them Free
description: THE composer Jeanine Tesori's slim right hand seems permanently attached to her flagon of Starbucks, whence comes the dark trickle of fuel for a bright, stream-of-consciousness soliloquy on the consequences -- all positive -- of her flourishing new collaboration with Tony Kushner, the ''Angels in America'' auteur whose latest offering, ''Caroline, or Change,'' is a winter sellout at the Public Theater. Next stop Broadway. The prospect gets her glowing; add in the unlimited caffeine from her afternoon dosage, and Ms. Tesori starts flitting through her Upper West Side apartment like a gamine, Type A Peter Pan in khaki flares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EPSTEIN, JANICE (NEE KAUFMAN)
description: EPSTEIN--Janice (nee Kaufman). On December 14, 2003. Devoted wife of the late William. Beloved mother of Carla Silber and mother-in-law to Dan Silber. Treasured grandmother of Rebecca and Abigail. Cherished aunt. Sister of the late Louis Kaufman, Mary Kaufman, Florence Silverstein and Bess Fisher. Proud graduate of NYU Washington Square College. Her energy for life and love of her family will remain her most important legacies. She lived life to its fullest. Her absence will leave a void in the hearts of her family. Shiva will be at the home of Dan and Carla Silber. Services Tuesday 1:30 pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Stamping Out Polio
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOTEL, RAE
description: KOTEL--Rae. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Rae Kotel. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Gary Miller, Chairman of the Board

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bhutan: Strikes AGainst Indian Militants
description: The usually peaceful Himalayan kingdom of Bhutan began a military operation to destroy training camps used by Indian guerrilla groups operating hit-and-run attacks on the neighboring Indian states of Assam and West Bengal. ''Bhutan is faced with the most difficult period in its history,'' said a statement released by the Bhutanese Embassy in New Delhi. About 3,000 Indian militants belonging to three different groups are believed to have operated 30 camps in Bhutan for the past 12 years. India, which has pressured the Bhutanese government to remove the camps, has provided training and military and logistical support to Bhutan's army. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Bill Irwin's Classic of Clowning, Illuminated With a Postscript
description: Time stands still for no clown. Or so it would seem from the second half of the delightful ''Regard Evening,'' which opened last night at the Peter Norton Space of the Signature Theater Company. In Act II middle age lands like an anvil upon poor Bill Irwin. His back is stiff, his steps are cautious, and he is slow to pick up on his cues. This is a man, after all, who is glimpsed dozing in bed with a copy of a book called ''Social Security and You.''

title: Meteorite That Killed 90% of Species May Have Hit Tropics
description: Scientists who support a controversial theory that a meteor crash coincided with the largest mass extinction in earth's history now assert that they have narrowed the location of the impact -- somewhere on land in the tropics.

title: Winter Whites
description: Manhattan women have developed a suddenly vigorous appetite for clothes in ivory, cream and oatmeal.

title: The Book of Life
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEMAN, ROBERT B.
description: FREEMAN--Robert B. (July 17, 1940 to December 6, 2003). Model/actor/restauranteur. Is survived by sister and brother, Irene and Jerry, niece, nephews and friend Renee Hunter. Donations can be made to Bailey-Holt House.

title: After Dinner Down Under, Chances Are It'll Be a 'Sticky'
description: THE Australians call them ''stickies'' and treasure them. So do many others lucky enough to have tasted these fortified dessert wines, properly named muscat and tokay, a pair of uncommon elixirs made only near this dozy old town along the Murray River, northeast of Melbourne and southwest of Sydney.

title: How to Treat a Vanquished Foe
description: To the Editor:

title: BANK OF NEW YORK TO ACQUIRE TRUST BUSINESS IN HAWAII
description: The Bank of New York Company, a leading provider of corporate trust services for company and municipal debt, agreed to buy the Bank of Hawaii Corporation's corporate trust business. The sale involves the transfer of about 80 bond trust and agency agreements, worth about $3 billion, to the B.N.Y. Western Trust Company, the Bank of New York said. Terms were not disclosed, a spokesman, Kevin Heine, said. The purchase, expected to close early next year, adds to the bank's portfolio of more than 85,000 trustee and agency agreements, representing more than $1 trillion in securities, for 30,000 clients. Bank of New York has been using acquisitions to expand its corporate trust business, which manages paperwork for bond issuers.

title: Dissident Episcopal Bishops Form New Group
description: Thirteen Episcopal bishops opposed to their church's approval of an openly gay bishop in New Hampshire plan to announce today that they are forming a rival network of dioceses and parishes, Bishop Robert W. Duncan of Pittsburgh says.

title: Pity at the Vatican for a Captive
description: A senior Vatican official expressed compassion for Saddam Hussein on Tuesday and reproached the United States for releasing video images showing the former dictator being handled ''like a cow'' as an Army doctor checked his teeth.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: After 9 Years, The Defense
description: The genocide trial of the former Ethiopian leader, Mengistu Haile Mariam, entered the defense phase, nine years after its start. Mr. Mengistu, who lives in exile in Zimbabwe, is being tried in absentia with scores of his former aides. Ethiopia's courts have convicted more than 1,000 people for their roles in the so-called Red Terror, which Human Rights Watch has labeled ''one of the most systematic uses of mass murder by a state ever witnessed in Africa.'' Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bid For Chemical Maker
description: The investment company Blackstone Capital Partners has offered 3.1 billion euros ($3.83 billion) to take over Celanese, a specialty chemicals maker based in Germany, for $1.6 billion euros. Celanese said it would support the takeover bid, which will pay stockholders 32.50 euros a share, a 15 percent premium to Celanese's closing price on Monday. Blackstone, based in New York, will assume 446 million euros in debt and other liabilities of 1.04 billion euros. The company is a spinoff of Hoechst's chemical businesses and 29 percent of it is owned by the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation. Celanese's chief executive, Claudio Sonder, above, will retain his position; he has announced his intention to retire next October. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Electric Industry Is Urged To Be More Tightly Linked
description: Engineers meeting here for the first public technical session about the Aug. 14 blackout said on Tuesday that to avoid a recurrence, the industry should be more tightly linked, through mutual regulation and data sharing, though the path to that point was unclear.

title: Japanese Bar Snacks That Skip the Sushi and Noodles
description: IN a year when New York restaurants seemed to sink into a comfortable world of pizzas, hamburgers, sandwiches and steaks, one cuisine stood well apart from the retreat: Japanese. New Japanese restaurants like Yujin in Greenwich Village, Matsuri in Chelsea, Sumile in the West Village and Asiate in the new Mandarin Oriental Hotel on Columbus Circle leaped forward into new realms. More, like Marcus Samuelsson's forthcoming Riingo on East 45th Street, are coming.

title: A Down East Holiday Chowder
description: SAM HAYWARD, who is the chef and an owner of Fore Street in Portland, Me., is a Mainer by adoption, not birth. In fact, he grew up in Tennessee and Louisiana, and received his early professional training in New Orleans before settling here almost 30 years ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Beaches Get $65 Million In Aid
description: The state and federal government yesterday promised to pay most of the cost of restoring the millions of tons of sand washed out to sea from New Jersey's coastal resorts during the fall and winter storms. Bradley M. Campbell, the environmental protection commissioner, announced that $34.5 million in state money would be added to $30.5 million in federal aid to restore bulkheads, piers and beach erosion up and down the Jersey shore. Iver Peterson (NYT)

title: Earnings at Lehman and Bear Stearns Exceed Forecasts
description: In a reflection of a continuing rebound in the securities industry, two important Wall Street investment banks reported earnings today for their fiscal fourth quarter that exceeded the consensus estimates of industry analysts.

title: Final Arguments at Trial of Sniper Suspect
description: The pictures, projected onto a large screen across the courtroom from the jury, told the two sides' stories.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Milosevic Trial Helps Clark Try To Gain Notice
description: American presidential politics can be played on any stage, and for the past two days it has unfolded behind closed doors in a courtroom in the Netherlands.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Attacked At Subway Station
description: A man was stabbed Monday night at the 181st Street Station, which is scheduled to lose two elevator operators under cost cuts proposed by the Metropolitan Transit Authority. Critics of the plan to reassign 22 of the 50 elevator operators said more, not fewer, operators are needed, especially in the evening. The M.T.A. votes on the plan tomorrow. Around 10:15 p.m Monday, the 20-year-old man, whose name was not immediately released, was stabbed once in the stomach. Witnesses described the attackers as a man and a boy, about 22 and 14, who attacked the man on the platform for the No. 1 train. The victim was listed in stable condition at Harlem Hospital. Three elevator operators work at the station in Washington Heights, but two leave during the overnight hours. A spokesman for New York City Transit said the number of operators at the time of the attack, one, would have been the same under the old plan and the proposed new one. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: SBC Signs Equipment Deal With Alcatel
description: SBC Communications said yesterday that it had reached a four-year deal with Alcatel for it to supply equipment for SBC's much-awaited push to build high-speed fiber optic connections to homes and offices. Beginning in June, SBC evaluated proposals from 20 companies before deciding on Alcatel, a company spokesman, Jason Hillery, said. Alcatel was among the favorites because SBC had already used Alcatel equipment to outfit a San Francisco business and residential complex with what is known as fiber to the premises, or F.T.T.P. SBC, BellSouth and Verizon Communications say F.T.T.P. will counter the growing threat from the nation's top five cable companies, which within the last year began complementing their cable TV and broadband services with local and long-distance dialing over an Internet connection.

title: Yankees Announce Schedule
description: The Yankees released their 2004 schedule yesterday for a regular season that is somewhat irregular.

title: For Some, It's a Very Moo Shu Christmas
description: SOMEWHERE, Christmas will look like this: cheerful children opening presents that don't break by noon; a glazed ham taking pride of place on the heirloom cherrywood sideboard as the heady aroma of gingerbread wafts through the house, which is itself set upon snow-covered hills where the leafy pine boughs are filigreed in ice.

title: Batter Up (and Over) For Hanukkah Latkes
description: About the closest you can get to putting homemade potato latkes on the table for Hanukkah without actually grating the potatoes is to use a new shortcut, Ruthie & Gussie's Traditional Potato Pancake Batter. Steve Gold, the owner of Murray's Chickens, developed the batter, which is sold frozen, and named it after his mother, Ruthie Gold, and his aunt, Gussie Rados. The batter, which is kosher, makes extremely tasty but slightly fragile latkes, and contains preservatives. A 28-ounce tub, about $5, makes nearly two dozen small pancakes. It is sold at Garden of Eden, Gourmet Garage, Fairway and ShopRite stores, and also at kosher butchers, including Fischer Brothers & Leslie, 230 West 72nd Street.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Dec. 9 about movie studios that resumed sending videotapes of films to awards voters after a judge overturned a ban referred incorrectly at two points to the organization that had imposed it. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was the Motion Picture Association of America, not the Motion Picture Academy of Arts and Sciences.

title: A $1.2 Billion Development to Give Camden a Lift
description: Officials planned to announce Wednesday the largest single investment ever proposed for this poverty-ridden city, a $1.2 billion mixed-use project that would be built along the banks of the Delaware River.

title: New Intel Chip For Digital TV Could Remake The Market
description: The Intel Corporation is planning to do to digital television what it has already done to computing.

title: Bush Signs Law Placing Curbs on Bulk Commercial E-Mail
description: President Bush signed a highly awaited law on Tuesday to restrict junk commercial e-mail, or spam, which now accounts for more than half of all e-mail traffic.

title: The News From Iraq, And the Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Put an S.U.V. Under the Tree By Living in It
description: WE searched in vain through the streets of Times Square. ''Christmas,'' we called into the glittery din. ''Oh Chri-i-i-stmas.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We believe it was not just your local neighborhood meeting.''

title: Bravo, Maestro! From Woodwinds and Strings
description: To the Editor:

title: Striking Workers Plan Safeway Boycotts
description: A two-month-old strike in Southern California against four supermarket chains got a big show of support on Tuesday: labor leaders from around the country marched with several thousand grocery workers through the streets of this enclave of wealth and backed their call for one-day walkouts at other stores nationally.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Another Reason Not to Frolic In Fountains

title: Grateful for Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEUROHR, DR. FERDINAND
description: NEUROHR -- Dr. Ferdinand died November 5 at home in Homosassa, FL. A board-certified prosthodontist, he practiced in Manhattan for over forty years. Active in many dental organizations, president of several; he felt his greatest honor was presidency of the American Academy of Restorative Dentistry. He attended Poly Prep in Brooklyn and donated a science lab in memory of his father and brother. Ferd served in the Navy, active and reserve, 1944-71. He is survived by his wife of fifty-three years, Barbara, three sons, Ferdinand III, Bruce and John, and eight grandchildren.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Broadcast for Mideast

title: A Small-Scale Attack on Urban Despair
description: Meg Campbell has banned French fries and fast food from Codman Academy, the small charter high school she opened here three years ago. Her students, who are overwhelmingly poor and black, eat fresh fruit and veggie burgers. With Ms. Campbell pushing them, they walk up to 10 miles a week and play tennis.

title: Indictment Charges Ex-Governor of Illinois With Racketeering
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 17  Former Gov. George Ryan was charged today in a sweeping federal indictment accusing him of doling out favors and public contracts in exchange for kickbacks while serving as Illinois secretary of state and governor.

title: McDyess Upset as Knicks Don't Compete
description: When the Golden State Warriors raced up the court last night, they were usually far ahead of a lackadaisical Knicks defense.

title: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES PROMOTES ITS PRESIDENT
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises, the soft drink bottler, promoted its president and chief operating officer, John R. Alm, to chief executive, replacing Lowry F. Kline, who is stepping down after less than three years. Mr. Kline, 63, will remain chairman and keep management duties, the company said. The changes are effective Jan. 1. Mr. Alm, 57, president since 2000, was passed over for the top spot in April 2001 when Mr. Kline got the job. Mr. Alm has represented Coca-Cola Enterprises in meetings with the Coca-Cola Company that were aimed at developing innovative packages and increasing impulse purchases of soft drinks at higher prices.

title: Deal Leads Architect to Lower His Sights, and the Trade Center Tower
description: In the end, the magic number for resolving the design impasse over the Freedom Tower at the World Trade Center site turned out to be 276 feet.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: STATEN ISLAND: 11TH DEATH FROM FERRY CRASH A woman died yesterday from injuries she received when a Staten Island ferry crashed into a pier in October. The woman, Deborah Castro, a secretary with an insurance company in Manhattan, was pronounced dead at 7:15 a.m. at Staten Island North Hospital. She lost both legs and her abdomen was torn in the Oct. 15 crash at the St. George Ferry Terminal, said Alan Ciani, her brother-in-law. She also suffered a broken arm and lost an ear. Mrs. Castro was the 11th person to die in the aftermath of the crash. Dozens more were wounded.    Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ESTESS, JENIFER
description: ESTESS--Jenifer. For your wit and wisdom. For your love and strength. For your courage and inspiration. For being part of my life. ''Today I consider myself the luckiest man on the face of the earth.'' William Baldwin

title: Early Snows Leave A Few Optimists In Retailing
description: Everybody in the retail industry is talking about the weather. While snowstorms continue to wreak havoc with analysts' projections for the holiday shopping season, a few remain optimistic.

title: Costa Rica Balks at Approving Central American Trade Pact
description: The Bush administration's attempt to reach agreement this week on a free trade area with five Central American nations suffered a reversal on Tuesday when Costa Rica announced that it was delaying its final approval.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Friday about Dzhamal Gamidov, an emaciated 11-year-old Russian boy freed by kidnappers after more than three years in captivity, misstated the year in which his father, Gamid, a former finance minister in the southern republic of Dagestan, was killed in a bombing. It was 1997, not 1977.

title: Marriage Amendment Backed
description: In an interview with Diane Sawyer of ABC News, President Bush gave tentative support on Tuesday to a constitutional amendment that would preserve marriage as only between a man and a woman.

title: Taiwan Reports SARS Case
description: Health officials in Taiwan announced Wednesday that a medical researcher had contracted severe acute respiratory syndrome, apparently while working with the virus in a military laboratory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENGEL, PATRICIA W.
description: ENGEL--Patricia W. The Board of Trustees and Staff of Maimonides Medical Center note with sadness the passing on December 14, 2003 in California of Patricia Engel, mother of Pamela S. Brier, President of Maimonides. Our condolences to the entire family. Martin D. Payson, Chairman

title: Cossette Post Hires 2 Senior Executives
description: Cossette Post in New York, part of the Cossette Communication Group, is hiring two senior executives for new posts and joining in opening a sports-marketing agency.

title: Motorola Picks an Outsider to Be Its Chief Executive
description: Motorola has chosen a highly regarded outsider from Silicon Valley, Edward J. Zander, over its popular second in command to succeed its retiring chairman and chief executive, Christopher B. Galvin.

title: Sports on TV Changed When N.F.L. Chose Fox
description: A decade has passed since Fox acquired National Football League television rights and established Rupert Murdoch's network as a viable competitor to its three rivals.

title: Ex-Tyco Treasurer Testifies on Loan Use
description: A former treasurer of Tyco International Ltd. told a New York jury yesterday that he approved company loans to the former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, that were used to pay for jewelry, invest in sports teams and buy real estate.

title: Link Between Afghanistan's North and South Is Restored
description: The American ambassador to Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, did not begin his remarks here on Tuesday by saying, ''We did it,'' but he might as well have.

title: Preparing for the Bird Flu
description: While Americans scramble to protect themselves against a form of influenza that is only slightly different from strains that have circulated before, experts are keeping a wary eye on several bird flu strains that could someday pose a radically new challenge. Should avian flu mutate enough to spread easily from person to person, it could set off a global pandemic.

title: For Japan's New Homeless, There's Disdain and Danger
description: The memory of how three youths pounced on him one night with sticks and fists twisted Masahiko Sugai's face with pain. The homeless people living with him here, clustered under a bridge linking this city with Tokyo, avoided the topic.

title: Mets Make Jordan Wait After Not Signing Guillen
description: Jose Guillen will be playing right field for a new team, but it will not be the Mets. Brian Jordan would like to find a new team, but the Mets are keeping him in limbo.

title: The Southern Hemisphere, Via London
description: AN empty plate is a canvas, and it inspires two competing impulses in most chefs. The minimalists like to keep a lot of white space, all the better to frame a few focused flavors. The maximalists like to fill the plate, dazzle the eye and keep the palate busy with lots of textural contrasts and arresting flavor combinations.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: LAWMAKERS ACCEPT ARMENIAN GENOCIDE Parliament adopted a resolution, 107 to 67, recognizing the killing of Armenians under the Ottoman Empire in World War I as genocide, defying the Swiss federal government and angering Turkey. Foreign Minister Micheline Calmy-Rey spoke against the resolution, and a spokeswoman said the government hoped the resolution would not strain Switzerland's relations with Turkey, which is deeply concerned about the issue. Turkey reacted swiftly, saying the Swiss assembly bore responsibility for any negative consequences its decision might cause.    (Reuters)

title: More to Come From the Flu This Season, Experts Say
description: The full impact of this season's influenza is yet to be felt, particularly in the East, federal health officials said yesterday.

title: L.I. Man Mourned Pair He Is Accused of Killing
description: In the weeks before the police found the bodies of Yesenia Lilly and her 11-year-old son, her boyfriend handed out ''missing'' posters, cried with the woman's family and even filed a missing-persons report, the police and family members said Tuesday.

title: Jenifer Estess, 40; Fought Lou Gehrig's Disease
description: Jenifer Estess, a theatrical producer who set up a foundation for research into Lou Gehrig's disease after she learned she had it, died yesterday at her apartment in Manhattan. She was 40.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Broadcom Settles Patent-Infringement Suit
description: The Broadcom Corporation, which makes communications chips for cable modems, set-top boxes and home-networking products, will pay Pctel $3.5 million and become a customer to resolve a patent-infringement lawsuit. Pctel, a maker of wireless-networking software, agreed to drop its lawsuit and license Broadcom's use of modem patents and two Ethernet-networking patents. Pctel also promised not to sue Broadcom for infringing any other patents. Pctel sued 3Com, Agere Systems, Lucent Technologies and U.S. Robotics, along with Broadcom, earlier this year. Pctel, which is based in Chicago, claimed its former competitors were using its patented inventions for modems without permission. Shares of Pctel fell 12 cents, to $8.44. Broadcom shares fell 59 cents, to $32.52.

title: AIDS Costs in South Africa Are Rising
description: As the AIDS epidemic devastates South Africans, the rising costs of the disease are leading not only to higher insurance premiums and reduced benefits, but also to questions about how best to balance the economic viability of the insurance industry with the government's desire to improve access to financial services and create a bigger private social safety net.

title: Fassel Dismissed by Giants, as He Expected
description: In an emotional team meeting this morning, Giants Coach Jim Fassel informed his players that he had been fired as their coach, adding that he would remain in his post to coach the team's final two games. According a player who was in the room and two team officials aware of the speech, Fassel, the Giants' coach since 1997, acknowledged it was an outcome he was expecting.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 456 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: The Kennedy Assassination As the Root of America's Ills
description: Conspiracy theorists alert! In Keith Reddin's speculative and rueful new play, ''Frame 312,'' the single gunman explanation for the assassination of President John F. Kennedy 40 years ago is instantly dismissed. But that's just the beginning of what the playwright has in mind. It is the suggestion of the play that the crime and its cover-up have remained resonant in the collective American psyche, and that they have curdled the American experience.

title: Oscar Schachter, 88, Law Professor and U.N. Aide
description: Oscar Schachter, who helped frame the legal underpinnings of the United Nations and taught at Columbia University Law School for the last 28 years, died on Saturday in Manhattan.

title: Flight Students' Option: Degree in Global Security
description: Since 1928, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University has been a dominant name in aviation and space education. Twenty-five thousand students from around the world take classes at the university's campuses in Prescott and Daytona Beach, Fla., and at its 130 off-site centers.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gtech Posts 40% Income Increase
description: The Gtech Holdings Corporation, the world's biggest supplier of online lottery systems, said yesterday that net income rose 40 percent in its third quarter as the company cut expenses. Net income rose to $45.9 million, or 69 cents a share, from $32.8 million, or 57 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. That figure includes a $3.3 million after-tax gain from the consolidation of the partnership that owns Gtech's headquarters in West Greenwich, R.I. Revenue for the period that ended on Nov. 22 fell to $254.9 million from $256.5 million. The company's cost of sales fell to $13 million from $39 million a year earlier. Shares of Gtech rose 47 cents, to $48.27.

title: Ebersol to Lead NBC Sports Through 2012
description: Dick Ebersol, who has run NBC Sports since 1989, said yesterday that he would continue in the position for nine more years. The primary reason for his decision to stay is to keep producing the Olympics through the 2012 Summer Games, the last that NBC has agreed to carry. ''My passion hasn't changed in 36 years,'' he said. ''It's the Olympics.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: 11th Death From Ferry Crash
description: A woman died yesterday from injuries she received when a Staten Island ferry crashed into a pier in October. The woman, Deborah Castro, a secretary with an insurance company in Manhattan, was pronounced dead at 7:15 a.m. at Staten Island North Hospital. She lost both legs and her abdomen was torn in the Oct. 15 crash at the St. George Ferry Terminal, said Alan Ciani, her brother-in-law. She also suffered a broken arm and lost an ear. Mrs. Castro was the 11th person to die in the aftermath of the crash. Dozens more were wounded. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: That First Flight
description: One hundred years ago today, Wilbur and Orville Wright -- bicycle manufacturers from Dayton, Ohio -- flew a self-propelled, heavier-than-air winged aircraft four times into the sea breeze near Kitty Hawk, N.C. The sheer practicality of the way they went about flying is as interesting as the fact that they succeeded. They gathered what literature there was on the subject, wrote to the few experts in the field and then, as Newton might have put it, thought of it without ceasing. They experimented with models, full-size gliders and an innovative wind tunnel before developing a truly practical glider in 1902 and a powered craft, the Wright Flyer, in 1903.

title: China's Velvet Glove
description: I've been searching for the limits of freedom on this visit to China, and I found them here on Saturday -- when the authorities detained me.

title: Industry and Housing Surge; Consumer Price Gauge Drops
description: Manufacturing and home construction jumped in November and a measure of consumer prices fell for the first time in almost 21 years, government reports released yesterday showed.

title: The Prosecution of a Dictator: A Decade's Digging Is Already Done
description: Any court to try Saddam Hussein will have a head start on building a case against him, thanks to efforts by Iraqi exiles, Kurdish groups and international human rights organizations over the past decade to prove that the former Iraqi leader was responsible for genocide and other international crimes.

title: BSkyB Loses Soccer Rights For 8 Games
description: European antitrust regulators and the pay television company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, British Sky Broadcasting, have reached an agreement that will end BSkyB's exclusive rights to broadcast top soccer games in England.

title: Bush Authorizes a Black History Museum
description: In a brief private ceremony in the Oval Office, President Bush on Tuesday signed into law legislation allowing creation of a National Museum of African-American History and Culture as part of the Smithsonian Institution.

title: At Last I Am Completely Free, Thurmonds Daughter Says
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 17 — Essie Mae Washington-Williams carried a splinter in her heart for the past 60 years and today, in front of hundreds of people, she pulled it out.

title: Sports of The Times; George III Sees All He's Done, And Approves
description: OUR greatest generals and geniuses are never appreciated until they are gone, until history grants them their proper due. I know this. I accept this. So I, George M. Steinbrenner III, will remain in the saddle, undeterred, front and center, leading my troops as we prepare for battle to protect the citadel of champions, the Fort That Ruth Built, from the invaders north and south.

description: To the Editor:
