description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Immucor Shares Plunge On Earnings News
description: Immucor, a maker of blood-testing products, said profit fell in its second quarter as the company spent money to meet regulatory deadlines in Europe, and United States sales declined. Net income for the three months that ended on Nov. 30 dropped to about $2.8 million, from $3.4 million a year ago, the company, based in Norcross, Ga., said. Earnings for the quarter were about 6 cents below the 20-cent average estimate by seven analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial, Immucor said. Immucor is struggling with extra costs that stemmed from a Dec. 7 deadline for seeking approval of some products in Europe. Earnings for the year ending next May 31 will probably rise, increased by sales of the company's Galileo automated blood test in Europe and price increases in the United States, Immucor said. Shares of Immucor fell $2.93, to $18.68.

title: The Family That Eats Together . . . May Not Eat the Same Thing
description: JANICE GOLDKLANG, a New York publisher, was reveling about dinnertime in her home in Pelham, N.Y. ''There are like five conversations going on at once,'' she said. ''Food is flying around, the dog is eating what falls from the table and no one is sitting down.''

title: Plans for Space Are Realistic, Official Says
description: When President Bush decides on a new policy of space exploration for the nation, the goals will be realistic and achievable, the NASA administrator, Sean O'Keefe, said on Tuesday.

title: Trying Saddam Hussein
description: The trial of Saddam Hussein must do several things at once. It must educate Iraqis and the world about the nature of his regime, adhere to the highest international standards of fairness, and provide a mechanism for appropriate punishment. The best way to achieve those goals is by creating a tribunal inside Iraq under United Nations authority, staffed by Iraqi and international judges and prosecutors.

title: The Kitchen Faucet Is a Vegetable's Best Friend
description: ONLY in New York would a stranger walk up to a woman about to pop a grape from a produce display in her child's mouth and say, ''Don't do that!'' The mother retreated, but the busybody's point was well taken. Produce should be washed before being eaten. Only recently has it become clear that fruits and vegetables have been responsible for about as many reported cases of food poisoning as beef, chicken, fish and eggs combined.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about Essie Mae Washington-Williams, who said her parents were the late Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina and a black woman who worked for his family, referred incorrectly to his marriage to Nancy Thurmond. She was his estranged wife, not his former wife. In some copies the article also misidentified the lawyer who represents the Thurmond estate. He is J. Mark Taylor; Bentz Kirby represents Ms. Washington-Williams.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review yesterday about ''The Return of the King,'' the third film in the ''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy, misstated part of the title of the first. It was ''The Fellowship of the Ring,'' not ''of the Rings.''

title: Time Warner Board Move
description: Time Warner has named Robert C. Clark, former dean of the Harvard Law School, to its board, raising the number of directors to 14.

title: Schumer Wants Kennedy Link To Be Paid for With 9/11 Aid
description: Weighing in on a fractious debate over transportation priorities in Lower Manhattan, Senator Charles E. Schumer offered a plan yesterday to pay for the construction of a much-discussed rail link from downtown to Kennedy Airport without any state or local money.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged With Murdering Woman
description: The police charged a Bronx man yesterday with murdering a woman and burning her body, which was found last week in a trash bin in Queens. Detectives arrested the man, John Medina, 27, of East 197th Street, and charged him with second-degree murder and third-degree arson. Mr. Medina was also charged with acting in a manner to injure a child, because he had driven his child in a car that contained the body of the murdered woman, a police spokeswoman said. The body of the woman was found burning in a trash bin at a gas station on Northern Boulevard on Dec. 11, the police said. They have not released her name.

title: Where Dinosaurs Roamed, She Throws Stones
description: REMEMBER the riddle about the extinction of the dinosaurs? It bedeviled many of us as children. It seemed to have been solved two decades ago with the theory that a single meteor plowed into the Earth 65 million years ago. Poof, we thought, the dinosaurs were gone.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Fines For Ashcroft Committees
description: John Ashcroft's Senate campaign committee and a political action committee he controlled were fined $37,000 by the Federal Election Commission for improperly transferring money during his unsuccessful re-election bid in 2000. The case involved a mailing list of donors that was developed by the political action committee for Mr. Ashcroft, now attorney general, at a cost of about $1.7 million. Glen Justice (NYT)

title: Iraqi Official Criticizes Security Council for Quibbling and Failing to Help Depose Hussein
description: Iraq's interim foreign minister, Hoshyar Zebari, took the United Nations Security Council to task Tuesday for having failed to help free his country from Saddam Hussein, and he chided its members for bickering over his country's future instead of coming to its immediate assistance.

title: G.I.'s Fight Off Convoy Attack; Raid Iraqi Cell
description: American troops killed at least 17 Iraqis in ambushes and violent rallies on Monday and Tuesday, the military reported, as repercussions of the capture of Saddam Hussein continued to be felt from Washington to the seething Sunni Muslim heartland of Iraq.

title: Hinckley Granted Unsupervised Trips From Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  A federal judge ruled here today that the mental condition of John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot President Ronald Reagan and three others in 1981, had improved enough for him to have unsupervised visits from the psychiatric hospital where he has been living for more than 20 years.

title: Saddam Is Ours. Does Al Qaeda Care?
description: While President Bush was careful to remind Americans that even with Saddam Hussein behind bars, ''we still face terrorists,'' the White House and Pentagon have characterized the arrest as a major victory in the war on terrorism. But is Iraq really the central battleground in that struggle, or is it diverting our attention while Al Qaeda and its confederates plan for new strikes elsewhere? There's strong evidence that Osama bin Laden is using Iraq the way a magician uses smoke and mirrors.

title: Many Things Chocolate, All Handmade
description: Laure de Montebello, left, a pastry chef, started making confections to sell on her own after her daughter, Claire, was born three years ago. Business was good, so last spring she opened Claire's Confections, 138 East Main Street, in Port Jefferson, N.Y., with a partner, Angela Fields.

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; For Boston and Texas, Trade Becomes a Must
description: The dalliance between the Boston Red Sox and the Texas Rangers about a trade featuring Alex Rodriguez and Manny Ramirez switched to a serious dialogue over a month ago. The discussion about swapping the two highest-paid players in baseball was so delicate that the owners of both teams elbowed the general managers aside to handle the talks. Now, after all the time invested, it would be disastrous for both teams if the multimillionaires failed to trade places.

title: The Face of Scare Politics
description: Let's hope that this week will mark both the beginning and the end of the use of Osama bin Laden as a prop in political campaign commercials. The current TV ad starring the most infamous face in terrorism is part of a ''stop Howard Dean'' movement from his fellow Democrats. Perhaps the true originators -- whose identities are as murky as Qaeda operatives' -- can be persuaded to cease and desist as a holiday present to the people of New Hampshire and South Carolina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EPSTEIN, JANICE (NEE KAUFMAN)
description: EPSTEIN--Janice (nee Kaufman). On December 14, 2003. Devoted wife of the late William. Beloved mother of Carla Silber and mother-in-law to Dan Silber. Treasured grandmother of Rebecca and Abigail. Cherished aunt. Sister of the late Louis Kaufman, Mary Kaufman, Florence Silverstein and Bess Fisher. Proud graduate of NYU Washington Square College. Her energy for life and love of her family will remain her most important legacies. She lived life to its fullest. Her absence will leave a void in the hearts of her family. Shiva will be at the home of Dan and Carl Silber.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBELL, ARTHUR, ESQ.
description: LUBELL--Arthur, Esq. The entire Yeshiva University family is deeply saddened by the passing of a cherished and devoted friend of our university and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS), who in his discretion, and in consultation with his clients established several major gifts at our university's undergraduate schools, at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and at the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. He was beloved by all who knew him. Heartfelt condolences to his children: Ruth Tallury, Diane (and David) Hochner, Lewis (and Terry) Lubell, Esq., and his seven grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: RULING ON MEDICAL MARIJUANA A federal appeals court ruled that a law outlawing marijuana may not apply to sick people with a doctor's recommendation in states that have medical marijuana laws. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit said prosecuting these medical marijuana users under a 1970 federal law was unconstitutional if the marijuana was not sold, transported across state lines or used for nonmedicinal purposes. The finding was a blow to the Justice Department, which argued that state medical marijuana laws were trumped by the Controlled Substances Act of 1970. Eight other states have laws similar to California's. (AP)

title: The Wright Brothers Centennial Re-enactment Falls Flat
description: KILL DEVIL HILLS, N.C., Dec. 17 — After all that, Orville and Wilbur had better luck a hundred years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CANTOR, B. GERALD
description: CANTOR--B. Gerald. My Darling Bernie, Happy Birthday. I will always remember how you touched my life. Love, Iri

title: Sirius Satellite Radio Teams With N.F.L.
description: The National Football League signed a seven-year, $220 million deal with Sirius Satellite Radio to carry its games nationwide. The agreement, which starts in 2004, features all locally and nationally produced regular-season radio games and wild-card and divisional playoff games. In 2005 it will add the conference championships and the Super Bowl.

title: Testaverde Considers Retiring
description: Vinny Testaverde said Tuesday that he would rather retire than become the Jets' No. 3 quarterback next season, which could create a quandary this off-season. According to people familiar with the Jets' thinking, the team wants him back, but probably as insurance behind the starter, Chad Pennington, and the backup, Brooks Bollinger.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Sentenced In 9/11 Fraud
description: A man who pleaded guilty in June to fraud by soliciting donations for a bogus charity for families of New York police officers killed in the line of duty -- including the World Trade Center attack -- was sentenced yesterday to eight years and one month in prison. The defendant, Justin Patrick White, 59, of Queens, paid out less than six cents of every dollar donated. In 2000 and 2001, he collected $441,075 in donations from businesses and individuals for the Police Survivor's Fund, but paid out only $24,500 to slain officers' families, a federal indictment said. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBLIRER, ROBERT
description: DUBLIRER--Robert, on December 14, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy Block. Cherished companion of Harriet Platt. Devoted stepfather of Dr. Johanna Fisher. Loving brother of Arthur and the late Harold. Dear uncle of Michael, Robert, John, Jane Kosminsky and the late James. Memorial service to be held at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC, Friday, 11AM to 1PM; also Saturday, 10:30 AM, Trinity Lutheran Church at St. Paul's Avenue and Beach Street, Staten Island.

title: Sports of The Times; It's April When Devils Are in Town
description: AS readers may have noted, my autumnal mission has been to catalog the relative woes of New York sports. (And I haven't even gotten to the ghastly state of St. John's basketball.)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about British regulators' warnings against prescribing certain antidepressants for children misstated the class of chemical compound to which one drug belonged. Effexor, made by Wyeth, is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, or S.N.R.I. (not a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, or S.S.R.I.).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BERNSTEIN, RAINE SARAH
description: BERNSTEIN--Raine Sarah. December 17, 1997-June 3, 2001. Never far from our thoughts. Always in our hearts.

title: Beef Prices Fall, but Consumers Aren't Buying That
description: THE good news is that wholesale beef prices are dropping, down about 20 percent since hitting all-time highs in October.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Opens Health Center
description: The New York Hotel Trades Council, the umbrella group representing 25,000 hotel workers in New York City, opened a new seven-story health center in Harlem yesterday. The center is intended to provide medical and dental services to 500 hotel workers and family members each day. The new center, called the Harlem Health Center, is being operated by the trades council and by the benefit funds of the Hotel Association of New York. The center contains examination rooms, consultation rooms, dental chairs, laboratories, a physical therapy department, a radiology department and a pharmacy. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Plan for Snowmobiles in 2 Parks Is Voided
description: On the eve of the winter snowmobile season in Yellowstone National Park, a federal district judge on Tuesday evening struck down the Bush administration's regulations permitting 950 snowmobiles a day in the park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONANT, MELVIN A.
description: CONANT--Melvin A. Memorial service Thursday, January 1, 2:30PM at Calvert Marine Museum, 14200 Solomons Island Road, Solomons, MD 20688. Donations: Calvert Marine Museum or the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, Woods Hole, MA 02543.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUPONT, ALANA LAWRENCE
description: DUPONT--Alana Lawrence. Passed away on December 13, 2003, in Burlingame, California, after a brave, yearlong battle against cancer. A loving family including her husband of twenty-eight years, Peter W. Dupont, and their three daughters, Lilly, Daisy, and Charlotte were by her side. She left many friends and family members in New York, and California, whose lives she enriched with her joyful, creative, and generous spirit. She was an accomplished sportswoman, holding several titles in squash. She enjoyed wide recognition as an artist, known for her uniquely expressive work particularly in portraiture and landscape. Services January 17, 2004, 11AM, Christ Church, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, her family welcomes gifts in Alana's memory to: The Alana L. Dupont Fine Arts Education Fund, c/o Peninsula Community Foundation, 1700 South El Camino Real, San Mateo, CA 94402.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Dec. 8 about the inability of the Jets' defense to stop the Buffalo Bills' offense in a 17-6 football loss misspelled the surname of the Jets' defensive coordinator. He is Ted Cottrell, not Cotrell.

title: From Boy Wonder to Ethics Case; The Personal Dimension in Governor Rowland's Political Life
description: Almost lost in the seemingly petty details of hot tubs and gutters and work on a lakeside cottage done free under unexplained circumstances is the remarkable story of the man whose job now seems to hang by a thread.

title: Unions Resist Labor Agenda Of Premier In Quebec
description: Quebec's powerful labor unions have moved to counter Premier Jean Charest's agenda of budget cutting, privatization and limits on labor's collective bargaining power with accelerated disruptions of services and noisy marches across the province.

title: Sharon Deputy Urges Major Unilateral Concession if Talks Fail
description: Israel's deputy prime minister said Tuesday that Israel should prepare to make concessions with a ''grand, one-sided move'' if peace talks with the Palestinians should fail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENENSON, ABRAM S.
description: BENENSON--Abram S. Renowned scientist, research doctor, professor and editor of the APHA ''Communicable Diseases in Man'', died peacefully December 15, 2003 at his home in Lenox, MA. He is survived by Regina vA Benenson, his loving wife of 64 years, his children Michael, Thomas, James and Sonia, and seven grandchildren.

title: European Union Tells French Utility to Repay Tax Breaks
description: The European Commission on Tuesday ordered lectricit de France to repay more than a billion euros in tax breaks and accumulated interest, the biggest return of state aid that the union's competition regulator has ever demanded.

title: France and Germany Join U.S. In Effort to Reduce Iraq's Debt
description: France and Germany agreed Tuesday to work with the United States toward a ''substantial reduction'' of Iraq's towering foreign debt next year. The accord marked a significant step forward in the United States' effort to rebuild Iraq, as well as progress in mending ties with the two countries most opposed to the American-led war there.

title: CALENDAR
description: Champagne, With a Kick

title: The Dolphins Wilt Again In the Heat of December
description: After Monday night's draining loss to Philadelphia, the Miami Dolphins still had some hope of reaching the playoffs. But their fans seem to have lost faith. Most of them vacated Pro Player Stadium well before the Eagles were assured of victory.

title: Brodeur Proves Fallible, After All
description: Three straight shutout defeats by Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur had provoked the Islanders to lots of soul-searching and strategizing. Brodeur had become a physical and psychological barrier to the fragile bunch from Long Island, and they were desperate.

title: Elizabeth Bates, 56, Researcher On the Development of Language
description: Dr. Elizabeth Bates, a leading expert on the way infants develop language and an outspoken critic of the theory that humans are endowed at birth with a language module, died on Sunday at her home in San Diego. She was 56.

title: Behind Closed Doors
description: When George W. Bush was running for president, he was inspiring on the subject of privacy. But it was not your privacy or mine he was talking about. He has gone all out to keep his administration's energy-legislation deliberations from public scrutiny.

title: E. N. Goodman, Stomach Surgeon And Innovator, 95
description: Dr. Edmund N. Goodman, a prominent New York surgeon who developed a procedure for detecting stomach abnormalities and treated legendary New Yorkers like Gov. W. Averell Harriman and Eleanor Roosevelt, died on Dec. 9 in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RILEY, MARY FRANCES KIERNAN
description: RILEY--Mary Frances Kiernan, 78, of Bronxville, New York, on December 14, 2003. Predeceased by husband Timbes Riley (1959), longtime companion Raymond D. Von Frank (2001), and father John M. Kiernan Sr. Survived by her mother Agnes Kiernan. Loving mother of Lynn (Richard) Riley Feinson, of New York City, Brian (Maureen) Riley of Tampa, Florida, and Christopher (Karen) Riley, Esq., of Montebello, NY. Grandmother of Tim Riley Jr., John Patrick Riley, Margaret Mary Riley of Tampa & Katie Riley of Montebello. Mary Riley was a graduate of Columbia University (MLS), Fordham University and the College of New Rochelle. During World War II, she was a licensed pilot and a draftswoman for Sikorsky Aircraft. She was later employed by Fordham University for 36 years and retired as Director of Libraries for both the Rose Hill and Lincoln Center campuses. Mary was a longtime member and former president of the Bronxville Women's Club, an avid golfer, gardener and skier, and a parishioner of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church for over 40 years. She was ever loyal to her faith and to her family. Viewing will be in McGrath's Funeral Home, Bronxville, New York 2-4 and 7-9PM Thursday on December 18 with a funeral Mass at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville on December 19 at 10 A.M. Burial will be in Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVERSTEIN, MARVIN
description: SILVERSTEIN--Marvin. Beloved husband of Carole. Devoted father of Susan and Bruce. Loving Pop-Pop of Ryan. Father-in-law of Geoffrey. Brother of Charlotte Deutsch. Loving uncle and great uncle.

title: M.T.A. Officials Accused in $18 Million Price-Gouging
description: Two former high-level officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and a current employee were indicted on racketeering charges yesterday. They are accused of helping a Brooklyn plumbing contractor steal about $18 million over four years by overcharging the authority in what prosecutors called ''a massive theft'' of public money.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Midtown Manhattan; A Building Made Congenial For Smaller Office Tenants
description: It took some time, and the departure of a major tenant, but the 44-story office tower at 140 East 45th Street has lately been quickly assuming the role envisioned for it more than 20 years ago: providing modern office space to smaller tenants in the Grand Central Terminal area.

title: New York Magazine Sold for $55 Million To Wall St. Figure
description: Combining stealth and an all-cash bid of $55 million, Bruce Wasserstein, the Wall Street deal maker, emerged yesterday as the surprise winner of the auction for New York magazine, which fostered the careers of writers like Tom Wolfe and Jimmy Breslin and became the template for the modern city magazine.

title: National Briefing | National Security: Qaeda Camp Attendee Gets 7 Years
description: The first of a group of men from Lackawanna, N.Y., to admit attending a training camp run by Al Qaeda weeks before the Sept. 11 attacks received the lightest sentence in the case to date. The defendant, Faysal Galab, 27, pleaded guilty on Jan. 10 to helping the terrorist group, less than four months after federal agents arrested the six men from the same neighborhood. Judge William M. Skretny of Federal District Court cited the timing of Mr. Galab's guilty plea before sentencing him to seven years in federal prison. David Staba (NYT)

title: Boeing to Build New 7E7 Jetliner in Seattle Region
description: Months of uncertainty for the Seattle region ended Tuesday as Harry C. Stonecipher, the chief executive of Boeing, stood on a stage here and announced to the thunderous cheers of Boeing employees, ''The 7E7 will be built right here in Puget Sound.''

title: Bruno Vows To Reduce State Cost Of Medicaid
description: With county executives screaming about the skyrocketing cost of medical services, the leader of the Republican majority in the State Senate said on Tuesday that he would push hard this year to reduce the cost of Medicaid. His announcement set the stage for what is likely to be a struggle with the Assembly's ruling Democrats.

title: Curtis to Play European Tour
description: Ben Curtis, the reigning British Open champion, will join the European Tour next year.

title: U.S. Intensifies Warning on Terrorism in Saudi Arabia
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  The State Department intensified its warnings about terrorism in Saudi Arabia today, advising Americans not to travel to that country and telling non-essential diplomatic employees they can leave if they wish.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Nov. 20 about an inquiry by a panel of government and industry officials into the causes of the August blackout misstated the full given name of Herb Dhaliwal, the Canadian minister of natural resourcess and a leader of the inquiry. It is Harbance, not Herbert.

title: Kerry Says Dean Lacks Presidential Traits
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts attacked Howard Dean on Tuesday as inexperienced, inconsistent and weak on foreign policy, and maintained that Dr. Dean lacked both ''the judgment to be president'' and ''the credibility to be elected president'' for asserting that America was no safer because of Saddam Hussein's capture.

title: John A. Mulheren Jr., 54, Leading Trader in 80's, Dies
description: John A. Mulheren Jr., a charismatic Wall Street trader during the 1980's and chief executive of one of the New York Stock Exchange's largest specialist firms, died on Monday at his home in Rumson, N.J. He was 54.

title: Crime Database Misused For Civil Issues, Suit Says
description: The Departments of Justice and Homeland Security are unlawfully using a national crime database to get local police departments to enforce civil immigration laws, lawyers who have assembled a federal class-action lawsuit against the practice said yesterday.

title: The Neediest Cases; Hope After a Lost Life Haunted by Drugs
description: Commander Barnes pulled out a worn black notebook. ''What I feel, I express,'' he said as he began flipping through the colorful graffiti-style images drawn on the card-stock pages. ''I'll show you.'' He stopped at a picture of a large crevice dividing a barren landscape. At the bottom of the two-page spread, the word ''Sinner'' appeared in red flames, and ''Saint'' in cool blue lettering.

title: Teams in the Majors Waiting for 2 Cubans
description: At nightfall on Oct. 24, the baseball players Maels Rodrguez and Yobal Dueas, their wives and a few other people waded out about 25 yards from a beach on the western shore of Cuba and were lifted onto a fishing boat from Mexico. Some locals, playing dominoes and drinking under a street light, recognized them but were late in alerting the authorities.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Archdiocese To Reduce Parishes
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston will consolidate and close some of its 357 parishes in 2004 to save money. Archbishop Sean O'Malley said that the number and locations of the parishes was not known but that a list of parishes eligible for reconfiguration would be released in mid-March. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KECKEISSEN, RITA G.
description: KECKEISSEN--Rita G., on Monday, December 15, 2003, after a short illness. She graduated from the College of Mount Saint Vincent in 1939, and received a Master's Degree from Columbia University in 1959. She retired in 1983 as Reference Librarian of Columbia University, but continued to work as a researcher for the Oxford English Dictionary. She is survived by her loving sister, Gertrude K. Farrell, and nieces and nephews and their children. She was predeceased by Ann K. Lombardo, and Sr. Mary Gertrude Keckeissen, S.C. Friends may call Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY. Mass of Christian Burial is at 9:45AM at Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, 8 Carman Road, Scarsdale, NY.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-31

title: MITSUBISHI AND CHRYSLER TO JOIN FORCES ON TRUCKS
description: Mitsubishi Motors and DaimlerChrysler will build two sets of midsize pickup trucks at Chrysler's factory in Warren, Mich., starting next year. The companies will pool their technology but design different trucks. Mitsubishi is the latest Japanese company to invest more in America's lucrative truck market. Eric R. Ridenour, executive vice president for product development at Chrysler, said the alliance would allow the companies to reduce the time and cost of developing and producing the new lines. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: American Express Reviewing Its Account
description: The American Express Company has placed in review most of the media planning and buying duties for its worldwide account, the latest big marketer to reconsider its media agency lineups. Total billings for the account were estimated at $350 million to $400 million.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about a personal representative for classical musicians misspelled her surname. She was Friede F. Rothe, not Roth.

title: He Loved the South but Painted Its Evils in Words
description: Back in the 1970's, when the novelist Erskine Caldwell was living in Arizona, The Atlanta Constitution began a profile of him with the terse apology: ''Erskine Caldwell. There. We've said it. Not so very long ago any Georgian pronouncing that name might have been run out of the state on a rail. If he were lucky.''

title: Rationing For Vaccine For Meningitis
description: Spot shortages of a vaccine to prevent meningitis in babies have led the American Academy of Pediatrics to notify its members that the vaccine is being rationed and that if a widespread shortage occurs the vaccination schedule will be changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALZEL, LEE ABRAMOWITZ
description: HALZEL--Lee Abramowitz. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science (ACWIS) mourns the passing of Lee Abramowitz Halzel, a longtime devoted member of the ACWIS Board of Directors who made many visits to the Weizmann Institute in Israel. She was the benefactor of the Lee and William Abramowitz Chair in Macromolecular Biophysics with her late husband William Abramowitz. We extend our deepest heartfelt condolences to her children and the entire family. Robert B. Machinist, Chairman, American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President Martin S. Kraar, Executive V.P. Stuart Eizenstat, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Prof. Ilan Chet, President Weizmann Institute of Science

title: Matching Familiar Songs With Their New Relatives
description: David Bowie the rocker took the stage of Madison Square Garden on Monday night. He was wearing sneakers, black jeans, a pinstripe T-shirt and the deconstructed tatters of a tail coat, and he was casually balancing nostalgia against what he can still pull off.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the deaths of three crew members of a cargo ship in the Hudson River at Albany misstated the vessel's name. It is the Stellamare. Willemstad is the name of its home port, in Curaao, not part of the ship's name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CALLAHAN, REV. MSGR. BRIAN F.X.
description: CALLAHAN -- Rev. Msgr. Brian F.X., on December 15, 2003. Pastor of St. Thomas Aquinas Church (Flatlands). Beloved son of the late Thomas P. and Frances M. Loving brother of Maj. Thomas P. (USAF, ret.) and Sr. Elaine M. Callahan O.P. and the late Gloria C. Schroeder and William. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. Visiting Wednesday, 2-5 & 79PM; Thursday 2-5PM at the St. Thomas Aquinas Rectory, 1550 Hendrickson St, Brooklyn. Mass of Transferral Thursday 7:30PM, Mass of the High Priest Friday 10:30AM. Interment in St. John's Cemetery.

title: Not Just Girl Songs With a Cute Face
description: To a sold-out crowd at the House of Blues two weekends ago, a singer delivered lyrics about one-night stands, threesomes and masturbation, adding a Prince cover for good measure. ''You gotta stick with me,'' he said at the end of the show. ''There's more than this to come.''

title: A CONTRACEPTIVE CLEARS A HURDLE TO WIDER ACCESS
description: In a 23-to-4 vote, two expert advisory committees to the Food and Drug Administration recommended Tuesday that a so-called morning-after pill to prevent unintended pregnancies be sold over the counter.

title: Prosecutors Not Penalized, Lawyer Says
description: A lawyer who won the largest wrongful conviction settlement in the city's history said yesterday that during his investigation he uncovered dozens of cases of prosecutorial misconduct in the Bronx district attorney's office that did not result in disciplinary action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCDERMOTT, FRANCIS X.
description: McDERMOTT--Francis X. of Hicksville, LI on December 15, 2003 (WW II Vet, US Army). Beloved husband of Doris for 55 years. Loving father of Joseph (Kathleen), John, Peter (Kathy), Anne (Rich), Patricia (Ray), Bernadette (Peter), Ellen (Michael), Kathleen (Andrew), and the late Mary (John). Devoted brother of Donald (Theresa) and Raymond. Cherished grandfather of twenty. Treasured great-grandfather of three. Friends may call Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9pm at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Homes, Hicksville Chapel (2 blks south LIRR, corner of West Marie St). Mass Friday 9:45AM at St. Ignatius RC Church, Hicksville. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Liver Fdn, 80 Wall St., NY NY 10004, or Ronald McDonald House, 267-07 76th Ave., New Hyde Park, New York 11042, in his memory would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, CHARLES
description: KAUFMAN--Charles. August 11, 1910--December 15, 2003. Beloved husband of Blanche. Devoted father of Isabel and Steven. Treasured father-inlaw of Michael and Aviva. Cherished grandfather of Andrew, Sivia, Lauren and Seth. Charlie will be sadly missed but lovingly remembered by all of his family and friends, as he brightened so many lives during his wonderful life.

title: 'An Institution Adrift' No More, CUNY Earns Praise in Report
description: Four years ago, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the former Yale president, led a task force for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that pronounced the City University of New York ''an institution adrift.''

title: The Priest Whose Death Led a Nurse To Confess
description: In the days before he was given an overdose of heart medication, there was reason to hope that the Very Rev. Florian J. Gall, although gravely ill, was showing signs of improvement, according to people who knew him and visited him in the hospital.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a terrorist list issued by China misstated a position of Human Rights Watch regarding peaceful advocacy of independence for the Uighurs, a Muslim ethnic group. Human Rights Watch is neutral on Muslim Uighur independence, not a supporter. The article also misspelled the given name of a Human Rights Watch researcher who was quoted. She is Sara Davis, not Sarah.

title: Two Voices, Two Ways of Being Always True to the Musical Self
description: The concerts that are hardest to hear fresh are those by musicians you know well. Two of America's leading vocal artists gave recitals last week: the soprano Rene Fleming at Carnegie Hall, with the Orchestra of St. Luke's, on Thursday, and the mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson at Zankel Hall, with the pianist Peter Serkin, on Saturday. One of the big challenges of listening to them perform is overcoming one's own preconceptions to hear what it is they are really delivering on a given evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENSTEIN, FRANCES
description: GREENSTEIN--Frances, died at NYU Medical Center on December 16th, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Devoted mother of Susan and Fred Oberstein. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer. Dear sister of Pauline and Bernie Coler, Roz Goldin, Dick and Claire Grossbaum, and Laurie Seldon. Services Thursday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to NYUMC-ICU, Development Office, 1 Park Ave., NY NY 10016 (Attn: Lauren Lavine) or the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KWITNEY, PAUL
description: KWITNEY--Paul, Sept. 20, 1928-Dec. 16, 2003, after a long, torturous struggle with Parkinson's. Cherished son of the late Esther and Harry Perach - Kwitney, precious brother of Ziva, devoted uncle of Alisa. Accomplished attorney, Zionist activist, benefactor to many. Survived also by beloved wife Sally, daughters Debby and Lynn and five grandchildren. We mourn the Paul that was and could be no longer and will miss him till the end of days.

title: Chrebet Hopes To Be Ready For Jets' Camp
description: The haze that had enveloped Wayne Chrebet's days lifted a few weeks ago. His headaches have subsided, the sensitivity to noise and light has abated. Chrebet has begun taking the first tentative steps back toward football.

description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Royal Bank of Canada, Toronto, the largest bank in Canada, agreed to buy William R. Hough & Company, St. Petersburg, Fla., an underwriter of municipal bonds. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, EDMUND N., MD.
description: GOODMAN -- Edmund N., MD. Age 95, of Sands Point, New York, on December 9, 2003. Beloved husband of Marian. Loving father of Wendy, Tonne, Edmund Jr., and Stacy Vincent (Glyn). Adored grandfather of Liliana, Cole, and Evie. Memorial service All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue at 80th Street, NY, NY, Saturday, December 20, 2003 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers please send contributions to Columbia University, Department of Surgery, Edmund N. Goodman Educational Fund, 630 West 168th Street, New York, New York 10032.

title: Firefighter From Post-9/11 Class Dies in Warehouse Blaze
description: A rookie firefighter died yesterday while battling a fire at a second-floor warehouse in Upper Manhattan, becoming the first New York City firefighter to die by fire since Sept. 11, 2001.

title: The Civil War Is a Risky Business: Miramax's Bet on 'Cold Mountain'
description: It's become a rite of December: Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of Miramax Films, begins his walk along the movie season's high wire while Hollywood looks up to see if, this time, he will fall.

title: Gore Rejection Energizes Lieberman on the Stump
description: Ten days ago, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman was trying to rally his troops and win over voters here with sober policy discussions about families and values. ''I'm presenting an agenda that values families and makes it easier for parents to give children the values they want to give them,'' he said at the time.

title: How to Treat a Vanquished Foe
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Stock Exchange Agrees to Divide Top Positions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday that the New York Stock Exchange had agreed to split the roles of chairman and chief executive as part of an overhaul of the Big Board's practices.

title: South Korea Decides to Send 3,000 More Troops to Iraq
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 17  After months of consideration, South Korea said today that it had decided to send 3,000 more troops to Iraq.

title: In Settlement, Alliance Agrees to Cut Fees
description: An expected agreement by Alliance Capital to slash its mutual fund management fees will put pressure on other mutual funds to lower their costs, regulators and industry analysts said.

title: U.S. Plans to Offer Official Coverage of Iraq Directly to Viewers
description: For months administration officials have complained that they are not penetrating the news media ''filter'' to inform the American public about their progress in Iraq. The arrest of Saddam Hussein was a sorely needed spike in generally dismal dispatches, they said.

title: Two Unions Criticize Ads For Attacks Against Dean
description: Two labor unions that provided financing for a shadowy Democratic political group running tough commercials against former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont criticized the advertising campaign yesterday, and one said it might ask for its money back.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Decline In Computer Services
description: A leading Eu-ropean provider of computer services, Cap Gemini, cut its profit forecast for the second time in two months, setting off a 14 percent decline in its share price. Orders worth about 500 million euros ($617 million) have been postponed, meaning second-half operating profit will be 2 percent to 3 percent of sales, and revenue will fall, the chief financial officer, William Bitan, said. He said second-half sales would be 2.7 billion euros ($3.3 billion), lower than an earlier forecast of 2.75 billion euros. Fourth-quarter sales will show ''slight growth'' from the third quarter.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechen Rebels On The Run
description: Russian forces on foot and aboard helicopters clashed for a second day with a group of guerrillas that crossed from Chechnya into the neighboring region of Dagestan, officials told various news agencies. The guerrillas, who killed nine Russian border troops and seized four hostages on Monday, seized several more hostages, but the official Russian Information Agency reported in the evening that all of the hostages had been freed. Officials reported that six to eight guerrillas had been killed, but the bulk of the rebel force, estimated to number from two dozen to four dozen, appeared to have escaped into the mountains. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUCHMAN, ROSE, (NEE SCHWARTZ)
description: BUCHMAN -- Rose, (nee Schwartz), of Cresskill, NJ, on December 16, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Alfred. Devoted mother of Janet and Maurice Laine and Stephen Buchman. Dear sister of Anne Katof. Loving grandmother of two grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Service Wien & Wien, Thursday December 18, 10AM. For further info: 1-800-322-0533.

title: City Council Spars With Bloomberg Over Lead Paint Legislation
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council took turns yesterday accusing each other of endangering the health of New York City's children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LESHAW, MARJORIE (NEE STARK)
description: LESHAW -- Marjorie (nee Stark). Of New York City, on December 16, 2003. Survived by her husband Edward, son James, daughter Nancy Setterquist, sister Lila Hershey and four grandchildren. Services are Thursday; graveside 1:30 PM at Cedar ParkBeth-El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Donations to Multiple Sclerosis Foundation.

title: In Europe, a Shopping Tradition Updated
description: Patrice Wagner came here more than a decade ago to help turn around the big Galeries Lafayette department store, which opened in old East Berlin after the wall came down, and then foundered. Fourteen months ago, that task complete, he became general manager of the big Kaufhaus des Westens, or KaDeWe, a western Berlin landmark.

title: Taiwan Passes 2 Resolutions Asking China to Remove Missiles
description: Taiwan's national legislature approved two separate resolutions on Tuesday that call on China to remove nearly 500 missiles pointed at the island, as Taiwan's vice president described the missiles as ''state-sponsored terrorism.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Arrest In Van Gogh Thefts
description: The police in the coastal resort town of Marbella arrested a 31-year-old Dutchman, Octave Durham, who they say stole two van Gogh paintings from the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam in December 2002. The paintings were ''View of the Sea at Scheveningen'' (1882) and ''Congregation Leaving the Reformed Church at Nuenen'' (1884). There was no mention of where the paintings might be. The museum has not put a value on them, but van Goghs have sold at auction in recent years for tens of millions of dollars. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Paris Official Rejects Anti-Semitism News
description: The French domestic intelligence chief, Yves Bertrand, on Tuesday disputed recent reports of rising anti-Semitic attacks in France, arguing that statistics showed a sharp drop in such incidents.

title: Rowland Vows to Stay On as Governor
description: CROMWELL, Conn., Dec. 17 — In his first public address since admitting he made false and misleading remarks about work on his private cottage, Gov. John G. Rowland today apologized for his actions but vowed to stay on the job.

title: Bush's Approval Ratings Climb In Days After Hussein's Capture
description: The capture of Saddam Hussein has lifted Americans' view of the state of the nation and their opinion of President Bush, while at least momentarily halting what had been a spiral of concern about the nation's economic and foreign policy, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: U.S. and Europeans Agree on Sharing of Airline Passenger Data
description: The European Union said Tuesday that it had agreed to allow the United States to continue to collect passenger records on all airline travelers flying to the United States from Europe, heading off a trans-Atlantic showdown over a policy that the Bush administration says is vital to combating terrorism.

title: Seoul Has Big Plans for North Korea (Nightmares, Too)
description: North Korea, so the scenario unfolds, gradually moves to a market economy under the grip of its one-party rule. Its leaders keep tight control on the political and social repercussions of economic reforms, but over time the changes ineluctably lead to more wealth and a more open society.

title: For White Wines and Some Reds, A Vessel With Built-In Chill
description: Decanting red wines is a common practice, to aerate the wine and soften tannins. With this graceful hand-blown carafe from NapaStyle, there is now a reason to decant white wines. The pocket opening on one side holds ice, to cool the wine without diluting it. It is also useful for reds like Beaujolais nouveau that should be drunk at about 55 degrees. It comes with a cork stopper. The cost is $28 plus shipping from (866) 776-6272 or www.napastyle.com.

title: High Over Kitty Hawk, Looking for a Profit
description: The foggy lens of history has been kind to Wilbur and Orville Wright. We regard the boys from Dayton, Ohio, as American heroes who, 100 years ago today, flew the first airplane and ushered in the age of air travel. At the time, though, the brothers' achievement was barely recognized -- and their motives were far from visionary.

description: To the Editor:

title: Notes Prompt Judge to Halt Chrysler Trial
description: A judge abruptly suspended the trial of Kirk Kerkorian's lawsuit against DaimlerChrysler on Tuesday after lawyers for the automaker turned over notes from a former Chrysler executive that could bolster Mr. Kerkorian's case.

title: As Sharon Prepares Speech, Israel Wonders What Hell Say
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 17  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel is scheduled to make a speech on Thursday, and it would seem that all of Israel, certainly all of the Israeli press, is speculating about what he will say.

description: PAIN KILLER

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Ex-Representative Won't Run
description: John Thune, a Republican and former United States representative, said he would not run in a special election to fill a vacancy left by Bill Janklow, the state's only representative in the House. Mr. Janklow, a Republican, said he would resign after he was convicted this month of killing a motorcyclist in a car accident. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Off the Menu
description: FABIO GRANATO and VITTORIO ASSAF have opened GEISHA , 33 East 61st Street, next door to one of the Serafina restaurants they own. The two-story space, designed by David Rockwell, has references to Japan and to geishas, like translucent umbrella-style lights over the bar. The chef, MICHAEL VERNON , a former sous-chef at Le Bernardin, and ERIC RIPERT , his former boss there, have devised a fusion menu. There is also a separate sushi room. Geisha will not take reservations.

title: Market Place; Calpers files a suit against the Big Board, claiming its trading system defrauded investors of millions.
description: THE nation's biggest pension fund filed suit against the New York Stock Exchange and its seven specialist firms yesterday, claiming that the exchange's trading system has defrauded investors of many millions of dollars.

title: Florida Sugar Growers
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Treat a Vanquished Foe (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Terms Given to Greek Terrorist Group Members
description: ATHENS, Dec. 17 - A Greek court sentenced the leader, chief hit man and four other members of the November 17 terrorist organization to multiple life sentences today for spearheading a spree of killings, rocket attacks, bombings and bank heists since 1975.

title: As Iraqis Become the Targets of Terrorists, Some Now Blame the American Mission
description: The bomb was meant to kill American soldiers, but, once again, it hit Iraqis. Aimed at two passing Humvees, the explosion last month on a traffic median ripped into a passing bus in eastern Baghdad, killing three riders. Haider Kassim, 11, crawled from the carnage, his leg shredded by shrapnel. But he refused care until his mother and aunt, each with more serious wounds, were treated.

title: Finally a Starter, Palmer Is Happy With His Work
description: For a few plays Sunday night, the cobwebs disappeared and the game opened up in front of Giants quarterback Jesse Palmer. He took the snap, rolled to his left and saw tight end Visanthe Shiancoe wide open, right where he was supposed to be.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Fatally Shot While Delivering Pizzas
description: A Ukrainian immigrant who supported his wife and grandson by ferrying pizzas around his Brooklyn neighborhood was shot in a robbery after dropping off an order on Sunday, and died the next morning, the police said. The Domino's delivery man, speaking in broken English, was able to give only a vague description of his attacker before he died.

title: Large REIT's Are Paring Their Noncore Holdings
description: During the last year, Boston lost more jobs than almost any other metropolitan area tracked by the United States Department of Labor -- a decline of 1.9 percent from last October to this one. During the same period, however, employment in Atlanta grew by 3 percent, one of the highest rates in the nation, and Dallas showed a 1.1 percent gain in jobs.

title: Deciding The Terms Of a Breakup
description: The Russian oil majors Yukos and Sibneft are expected to announce on Wednesday that they have formally ended their on-the-rocks $13 billion merger, but the terms of their divorce might not be clear for some time.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: New York Magazine Acquired for $55 Million

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Contract For Iron
description: The iron ore producer Companhia Vale do Rio Doce has signed a 10-year contract to supply China's top steel maker, the Shanghai Baosteel Group Corporation. In a statement released late Monday, Vale, as the mining company is known in Brazil, said it had signed a deal in Beijing to supply Baosteel with iron ore over 10 years, starting in 2006. The agreement expands a contract signed in 2001, under which Vale supplies Baosteel with six million tons of iron ore a year. By 2010, the Brazilian company hopes to be shipping 20 million tons to Baosteel. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article on Thursday about British regulators' warnings against prescribing certain antidepressants for children misstated the class of chemical compound to which one drug belonged. Effexor, made by Wyeth, is a selective serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, or S.N.R.I. (not a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor, or S.S.R.I.).

title: Kidd's Finger Is Pointing At Coaches
description: As Nets players continued to deny that Jason Kidd criticized them during his postgame address Saturday night in Memphis, a person with intimate knowledge of the team said yesterday that the target of Kidd's frustration was the coaching staff.

title: Jazz Players Are Different, But the System Still Works
description: Eighteen years after John Stockton and Karl Malone started perfecting their pick and roll, the Utah Jazz has finally proved it is more than just a two-man team.

title: PROSPECTIVE BUYER FOR FLAGSHIP F.A.O. SCHWARZ STORE
description: FAO Inc., which recently sought bankruptcy protection for a second time this year, received an offer for its flagship F.A.O. Schwarz toy store on Fifth Avenue in New York as liquidators prepare to sell off the company's assets. The proposal also covers the F.A.O. Schwarz name, David Levene, a lawyer for the retailer, said. He declined to comment further. ''We are waiting for the buyer to send us a draft contract for us to review,'' Mr. Levene said. FAO plans to shut its 38 Right Start and 15 F.A.O. Schwarz stores if buyers are not found. A deadline was extended to today from last Monday.

title: Hospitals Didn't Share Records Of Nurse Suspected in Killings
description: In mid-2002, a web was tightening around Charles Cullen.

title: A general, a messiah and 'Bush's fiance' : Top Manila job draws all manner of seekers
description: MANILA:  Her name is Salve Ruiz-Bush. She is 47 years old. George W. Bush, she said, convinced her to run for president of the Philippines. She and Bush, she said, are engaged.

title: Big Turnaround In Anchorage
description: A thaw has begun in Alaska.

title: Bravo, Maestro! From Woodwinds and Strings (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Coming Soon to Arab TV's: U.S. Answer to Al Jazeera, Production Values and All
description: The United States' next great hope for winning Arab hearts and minds hides in a squat two-story building in a generic industrial park here, just off I-95. The only hint of what may lie within is the black-tape lettering on the front door that reads ''News.''

title: He Is His Own Producer, and Much More
description: Dig into the Playbill for ''I Am My Own Wife,'' and you'll find the kind of biography you don't see often. ''Anthony Marshall (Producer),'' it reads, ''is an investment adviser, author, former intelligence officer with the C.I.A. and diplomat.''

title: Human Rights in Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERLMAN, SETH
description: PERLMAN--Seth. Frances' beloved son, Andy's ''kid'' brother died December 13. His sweetness and beautiful smile will be cherished.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Assessment Raised
description: The Bank of Japan lifted its assessment of the economy for a fourth month, encouraged by higher personal spending. The central bank said the economy was gradually recovering and would continue to do so. Consumer spending, which makes up more than half of growth, was upgraded to stable from weak. The report was released after the bank's policy board left its monetary stance unchanged at its last meeting of the year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Cossette Post Hires

title: Putting a Guy Into a Frock Takes Teamwork; Actor, Director and Playwright Collaborate on a One-Man Show
description: Doug Wright's play ''I Am My Own Wife'' might never have gotten to Broadway, might never have been written at all, had Moiss Kaufman not put on a dress.

title: Aide Says Wang Stands by Decision on Nets
description: An aide to Charles B. Wang reaffirmed yesterday his refusal to re-enter the bidding to buy the Nets. Wang withdrew his $265 million offer on Dec. 4, but two people involved in the bidding suggested Monday that he was reconsidering.

title: Seeking Dickens Amid Fog And Folderol
description: When Edmund Morris published ''Dutch,'' his biography of Ronald Reagan, four years ago, he was roundly condemned for making things up. Mr. Morris's chief crime against fact was interpolating a character, named Edmund Morris, into Mr. Reagan's life. This fictional Edmund had been privileged to witness what the biographer had not: Mr. Reagan as a lifeguard, a radio announcer and a spokesman for Barry M. Goldwater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PENSAK, CHARLOTTE S.
description: PENSAK--Charlotte S. Died on December 12 at age 87. Beloved wife of Stanley and grandmother of Daniel. Had a long teaching career at LIU and Upsala College.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULHEREN, JOHN
description: MULHEREN--John. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of John Mulheren, a cherished friend who was greatly admired for his extraordinary generosity and compassionate concern. John earned enormous respect for his deep devotion to humanitarian causes and improving the lives of the less fortunate. He expressed an unwavering commitment to UJA-Federation and our beneficiary agencies, in particular the New York Legal Assistance Group (NYLAG). A leader in the financial community, he was honored by UJA-Federation's Wall Street Division in 2001. John will be remembered for his vibrant personality and for his kind efforts to improve the community. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Nancy; to his children; and to the entire Mulheren family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: ARTS BRIEFING
description: HIGHLIGHTS

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Waterfront Review
description: The New York State Assembly has scheduled a public hearing to review the Hudson River Park Trust, which operates a five-mile stretch of Manhattan waterfront from Battery Park to 59th Street. Assembly Hearing Room, Room 1923, 19th Floor, 250 Broadway, Manhattan, 10:30 a.m. Information: (518) 455-3888.

title: '92 Israeli Plan To Kill Hussein Is Reported
description: Israel developed a risky plan in 1992 to assassinate Saddam Hussein at a funeral but dropped it after five Israeli soldiers were killed while training for the mission, according to Israeli news reports on Tuesday.

title: Bravo, Maestro! From Woodwinds and Strings
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans Plan Convention Full of Sights and Symbols
description: Center stage at the Republican National Convention in New York next summer may be round, rotating and built on a platform high above the floor of Madison Square Garden, event organizers said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Aircraft Venture
description: The commercial aircraft maker Empresa Brasileira de Aeronutica plans to develop regional jets with the China Aviation Industry Corporation II in an effort to tap China's growing demand for aircraft. Embraer and AVIC II, as the two are known, would expand a year-old venture in Harbin in northeastern China to design and build the new airplanes, the companies said in a statement, without giving details. The venture currently assembles Embraer's ERJ 145 jetliner. The expansion would help Embraer tap a market where it has forecast that sales could total as many as 635 regional jets in the next 20 years. It would also help AVIC II, formed in 1999, move China closer to its goal of becoming a leading aircraft maker.

title: Americans' Thirst for Wine Is Rising
description: AMERICANS, most of whom once thought of wine as effete and elitist, might be surprised -- astonished, even -- to learn that the United States is the third largest wine consuming nation in the world and will almost certainly become the largest by the end of this decade.

title: In 2 Hours, You're Greek
description: MANY of us had our earliest experiences with braised foods not at the pricey restaurants that have recently rediscovered their appeal but at the Greek diners that never forgot it. So it's not surprising that I associate braised lamb shanks with egg-lemon sauce, a Greek staple. But when I set about to recreate this standard dish I found the sauce superfluous.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the views of L. Paul Bremer III, the American administrator in Iraq, about the country's future misstated the weight of the bombs that United States forces have dropped recently on sites believed to harbor urban guerrillas. They are 500 pounds each, not 500 tons.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Prosecutor Plans Michael Jackson Charges
description: The Santa Barbara County district attorney, Thomas W. Sneddon Jr., said he would file formal child molesting charges against the singer Michael Jackson on Thursday or Friday. Mr. Jackson was arrested on Nov. 20 and released on $3 million bail, but the accusations against him have not yet been detailed. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Chirac Wants Religious Attire Banned in Public Schools
description: PARIS, Dec. 18  President Jacques Chirac called today for a new law banning the wearing of head scarves for Muslim girls, large crosses for Christians and skullcaps for Jewish boys in public schools.

title: A Snowmobile Shift For Park Is Rejected
description: On the eve of the winter snowmobile season in Yellowstone National Park, a federal district judge struck down the Bush Administration's regulations permitting more than 950 snowmobiles in the park, saying that the Clinton Administration's decision to phase out snowmobile use in that park had been arbitrarily reversed.

title: In Reversal, E.P.A. Won't Narrow Wetlands Protection
description: Making an abrupt change in its approach to the Clean Water Act, the Environmental Protection Agency announced Tuesday that it would jettison plans to remove federal protection from millions of acres of wetlands.

title: A Troubled Life of Many Nursing Jobs Before a Sensational Claim
description: The sketchy outlines of Charles Cullen's life, gleaned from the vague recollections of those who know him and the few official papers on which his name appears, suggest a story of a childhood marred by the early death of his father, a troubled career as a nurse, a bankruptcy, more than one suicide attempt and a divorce.

title: At a New Fishmonger's, Haven't We Met Is Not a Line
description: Wild Edibles, the fishmonger with markets in Murray Hill and Grand Central Market, has moved into part of the space that had held a Healthy Pleasures market at 2491 Broadway (93rd Street). The sign says Wild Edibles-Jake's Fish Market because Jonathan Meyer, an owner of Wild Edibles, has bought the name and has hired some of the staff of Jake's, a fish market at 88th Street and Broadway that closed a few months ago. In addition to fresh seafood, shoppers will find prepared seafood, like crab cakes and teriyaki tuna.

title: Bomb Kills 17 in Iraq
description: A bomb exploded next to a fuel truck in Baghdad, killing 17 people in a nearby bus and dealing a blow to any hopes that the capture of Saddam Hussein last Saturday would ease guerrilla attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOYLE, MARIE G.
description: DOYLE--Marie G. (retired police officer NYPD) of Flushing, NY on December 15, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Thomas (NYPD). Devoted mother of Thomas, Michael, Christopher and the late Timothy. Loving grandmother of Kathleen and Christina. Visiting Wednesday 7-9PM, Thursday 2-5 & 79PM Cassidy Funeral Home, 156 Willis Ave, Mineola, NY. Funeral Mass 10AM, Friday, Holy Family RC Church, Flushing, Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Global Intelligence
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: A Sumptuous Wilderness Camp
description: If your idea of camping is more mogul than macho, the new luxury Aman-i-Khas resort in Rajasthan, India, awaits.

title: Personal Shopper: Board Games
description: Slow fun for game boys and girls.

title: Revenue Up, But Mayor Urges Cuts In Spending
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg urged his senior staff yesterday to continue to push for ways to cut spending, warning that the city must remain fiscally vigilant despite signs that the city economy is improving.

title: Two Good Decisions; Banishing Snowmobiles
description: In a federal courtroom in Washington, D.C., on Tuesday, Judge Emmet Sullivan declared a halt to the Bush administration's plan to continue and indeed expand snowmobile use in Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks. His ruling, which reinstates a Clinton-administration plan to phase out the snowmobiles, is a victory for the parks, their wildlife and the visitors who come to enjoy both. Beyond that, it is a resounding rebuke to the Bush administration, whose eagerness to satisfy a narrow political constituency caused it to violate its statutory obligation to protect the parks from degradation and to leave them, as the law commands, ''unimpaired'' for future generations.

title: The Competitors; A Game of Phone Catch-Up on the Net
description: THE big telephone companies are scrambling to catch up with upstart competitors in the race to provide low-cost telephone service over the Internet. They may be late to the game, but they say their services will offer better voice quality -- a claim questioned by the smaller operators and industry analysts.

title: As Groucho Used to Say, 'Hello, I Must Be Going'
description: ''They told me it's time to go right now,'' Wyclef Jean said, but the audience wasn't convinced. He was onstage at the B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, the star of a Christmas concert sponsored by the R & B radio station WBLS. Lots of performers try to hype up the crowd by pretending the show's over, but Mr. Jean must have set some sort of record on Monday night when he began this routine after having performed precisely two songs.

title: Final Word: 'My Father's Name Was James Strom Thurmond'
description: Essie Mae Washington-Williams began simply, ''My father's name was James Strom Thurmond.''

title: Around the World and Under the Tree
description: THE highlights of this year's design books could cause a wave of armchair traveling -- to Chilean fishermen's cottages, Nigerian mud mosques, even home theaters in Las Vegas dressed up in Baroque costumes. Or these volumes might set off construction of backyard pebble mazes and driftwood furniture. For the dreamer or the do-it-yourselfer on your holiday list, one of the following might do the trick.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Rapper Surrenders On Assault Charge
description: The rapper Nas, 30, charged with assault, turned himself in to the police yesterday in Greenwich Village. Investigators said Nas, whose full name is Nasir Jones, hit an unidentified stranger with a bottle at Cielo, a nightclub on Little West 12th Street, in the early morning of Dec. 10. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Serbs May Help Patrol Afghanistan, but Qualms Abound
description: A convoy of jeeps sped though an Albanian village in southern Serbia one recent day. Inside, troops with their faces hidden by camouflage masks sat with their guns at the ready.

title: Annan Wants to Meet With Iraqi Council and U.S. Coalition
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 18  Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that he was seeking a meeting next month with members of the Iraqi Governing Council and representatives of the United States-led coalition to see if the United Nations' return to Baghdad could be accelerated.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the morning-after pill under consideration by the Food and Drug Administration for over-the-counter sales misstated its effectiveness. According to its distributor, the Women's Capital Corporation, the pill, known as Plan B, can reduce the chance of pregnancy by 89 percent if used within 72 hours of unprotected sex — not prevent up to 89 percent of unplanned pregnancies.

title: Prostate Cancer: Who Is at Risk?
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT APPROVES REPUBLIC ENGINEERED'S ASSETS SALE
description: Republic Engineered Products, the biggest North American maker of steel bars used in automotive axles, received bankruptcy court approval to sell its assets to Perry Strategic Capital for $123.5 million. A group of banks led by the FleetBoston Financial, which has secured claims on Republic Engineered's assets, will receive $101.5 million in cash and $21 million in new notes, John Dillard, a spokesman for Perry, said. Perry will also assume $154 million in debt, he said. Judge Marilyn Shea-Stonum of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Akron, Ohio, approved the plan on Tuesday, Republic Engineered said. Perry is paying an additional $1 million that will go to other unsecured creditors, Dillard said. Republic is based in Fairlawn, Ohio.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: NEW ACTING HEAD OF MEDICARE AND MEDICAID Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy G. Thompson named Dennis Smith, head of the federal health insurance program for the poor, as acting administrator of the agency that oversees Medicare and Medicaid. Mr. Smith, a former Virginia Medicaid director, will run the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. (AP)

title: Century After Wright Brothers, a Train to J.F.K.
description: A hundred years to the day after the Wright brothers first flew, nearly 60 years after Robert Moses dismissed an early version of the idea, 40 years after Idlewild Airport became Kennedy, and 34 years after man landed on the moon, New York City got its long-awaited train-to-the-plane link yesterday.

title: Woody Guthrie's 'This Menorah Is Your Menorah'
description: ''This Land Is Your Land,'' of course. ''Hard Travelin','' certainly. But ''Honeyky Hanukkah''? ''Hanukkah Tree''?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHENKEL, JAMES M.
description: SCHENKEL--James M. of Vero Beach, FL, formerly of Garden City, NY, died on December 16, 2003. Born August 19, 1913, he graduated in 1934 from Colgate University class of 1934 and was a Naval Lieutenant during World War II. He retired in 1978 from Home Life Insurance Company in New York as Vice President and Chief Actuary, FSA, MAAA. Predeceased by his wife of 55 years, Elizabeth Johnston in 2001, he is survived by son James P. Schenkel, Pacifica, CA, daughters Mary E. Schenkel, Vero Beach, FL, and Margaret S. Heydorn, Westchester, NY, and granddaughters Elizabeth and Ruth Schenkel, Pacifica, CA.

title: U.S. Cancels Pension Plan At Kaiser
description: Departing salaried employees of Kaiser Aluminum pulled money out of their pension fund so quickly last year that they virtually wiped out the assets, according to the government, which canceled the pension plan yesterday, saying it had to protect what was left for past and future Kaiser retirees.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: 6 From Greek Terror Group Get Life Sentences
description: A Greek court sentenced the leader, the chief assassin and four other members of the November 17 terrorist organization to multiple life sentences on Wednesday for a string of killings, rocket attacks, bombings and bank robberies since 1975.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Premiers In Talks
description: Seeking to break an impasse in the stalled Northern Ireland political process, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain met with the Irish prime minister, Bertie Ahern, in London but reported no immediate progress in what he said would be a ''short, sharp and focused'' round of diplomacy. The talks were joined by David Trimble, leader of the largest Protestant party, the Ulster Unionists, and later in the day Mr. Blair met with the Sinn Fein leader, Gerry Adams. Mr. Blair's review of factors that led to the breakdown of a power-sharing government also included a session on Tuesday with the Rev. Ian Paisley, the hard-line icon of unionist politics whose Democratic Unionist Party won the most seats in elections on Nov. 26. Mr. Adams said at a news conference that there should be a ''relatively short period'' to evaluate whether Mr. Paisley was willing to join a power-sharing government with Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The column name and the byline were omitted last Thursday from reports on cocktail glasses, artificial foliage and a courtyard at the Lyce Franais in Manhattan. The column was Currents, and the writer was Craig Kellogg.

title: 'Because It's There': Commandeering a G.P.S. Navigator
description: RAY AND ELNA KAWAL hit the open road this fall on an 8,000-mile trip in their 2002 Chevy Tahoe with General Motors' OnStar navigation system serving as their North Star.

title: STOCK EXCHANGE IS SAID TO SELECT CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The New York Stock Exchange is expected to announce as soon as today that John A. Thain, the president of Goldman Sachs, will be the new chief executive of the exchange, according to a person who has been briefed on the situation.

title: Tigers, Tents and Oh, Yes, a Spa: A Wilderness Camp of a Sumptuous Sort
description: If your idea of camping is more mogul than macho, the new Aman-i-Khs wilderness camp (above) awaits. It lies in the hills of Rajasthan, India, within view of Ranthambhore National Park. Unlike many other tent hotels, safari camps and eco resorts, which can be decidedly basic, this resort is full-on luxe. There are nine tents in all, six for guests plus one each for lounging, dining and spa treatments. (The cotton-canvas tents, about 1,100 square feet, can be taken down for cleaning and storage in the summer when the resort is closed.) The tents come, as all tents should, with full plumbing and electricity, housed in a polished cement slab. Amenities include a king-size bed (above right), shower, soaking tub, dressing area and air-conditioning; there is also a screened sitting area (right). The custom furniture is teak. A four-night stay (which includes a night in Delhi, car and driver and meals) is $2,300. The Web site is www.amanresorts.com. (Safety note: high walls and round-the-clock security keep the local tiger population outside.)

title: Case of Ill Researcher Underlines Dangers in SARS Laboratories
description: The World Health Organization said yesterday that a 44-year-old medical researcher who is ill with SARS in a Taiwan hospital appeared to be an isolated case. The researcher apparently developed SARS, or severe acute respiratory syndrome, after working with the virus in a military laboratory in Taiwan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REINGOLD, ERNA C.
description: REINGOLD--Erna C., 61, of Stamford, CT and Saratoga Springs, NY, died Wednesday, December 17, Greenwich, CT. Founder and President of Mermaid Seafood, Inc., of Greenwich, CT. Survived by loving family members, Joel Reingold, Rachel Mulcahy, Coro Gorriti, Javier Gorriti, mother Fenya Crown, sister Joanna Koss. There will be a memorial service to be announced in January. For information Knapp & Son Funeral Home of Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT.
