description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PAKISTAN: 2 JOURNALISTS ARRESTED Pakistan arrested two French journalists for visiting Quetta without valid visas and for taking photographs of "prohibited areas," Reuters reported. Immigration officials said the journalists, who work for the magazine Express, would be put on trial and face three years in prison. Pakistan recently begun issuing visas to journalists that restrict their travel to certain cities. Journalists have called the policy censorship, but officials say it is for their safety. Immigration officials said the French journalists received visas allowing them to travel to Islamabad, Lahore and Karachi but not Quetta. Afghan officials accuse Pakistan of allowing the Taliban to use Quetta as a base for reorganizing its forces. Pakistan denies the charge. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Ignoring Memphis Eruption, Nets Coast
description: In the first game since they criticized Byron Scott and his coaching staff, Jason Kidd and Kenyon Martin pointed a finger back at themselves and gave Scott, their embattled coach, some breathing room.

title: MSG and FSNY May Be Dropped By Time Warner
description: Time Warner Cable said yesterday that it might not carry the MSG Network and Fox Sports New York beyond Dec. 31 because of a disagreement over the terms of a proposed long-term deal with Cablevision, the channels' owner.

title: Money for Hudson Park Trust Is Running Out
description: The plan to create a five-mile-long park along the Hudson River waterfront to 59th Street from Battery Park was announced in 1998 with great fanfare and a $200 million commitment from the city and the state.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about preservationists' efforts to buy the Farnsworth House, a Mies van der Rohe design in Plano, Ill., misstated the cost of repairs after a flood in 1997. It was $250,000, not $10 million.

title: Metro Matters; Pack Light. Not for Trip, But for AirTrain.
description: WHAT would a New York innovation be if it didn't generate an instant debate? Couldn't happen, as witness inaugural day of the new AirTrain, the sleek, new light rail line linking Kennedy International Airport to mass transit at Jamaica and Howard Beach.

title: National Briefing | National Security: Last In Group Gets Sentence For Aiding Al Qaeda
description: A man who met Osama bin Laden after leaving a Qaeda training camp received a sentence of nine and one-half years in prison for helping the terrorist group. The man, Sahim Alwan, 31, was the last of six men from Lackawanna, N.Y., to be sent to federal prison. All six pleaded guilty to similar charges earlier this year. David Staba (NYT)

title: Grey Worldwide Picked For BMW Work
description: BMW of North America in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., part of BMW, has named the Los Angeles office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group, to handle the creative duties for its Western regional account. Billings on the assignment, handled by Mendelsohn/Zien Advertising for more than a decade, were estimated at $30 million.

title: Bush's Worldview, and Dean's
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Flies High Over Flights Birthplace
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17  The Wright brothers never knew life could be so good at 40,000 feet. After all, their first flights barely got off the ground.

title: United Airlines Seeks $1.6 Billion in U.S. Loan Guarantees
description: Ayear after failing in its first bid to secure government loan guarantees and being forced to file for bankruptcy protection, United Airlines went back to a federal loan board today for a $1.6 billion bailout package that it is counting on to help it emerge from Chapter 11 proceedings.

title: House at the End of the Line
description: THE modest compound where Saddam Hussein spent his last few hours of freedom offered a curious mixture of squalor, on the one hand, and on the other a selection of domestic items that had been carefully chosen, by Mr. Hussein or someone close to him, to support a life on the run.

title: Mickens Comes Up Big as a Starter
description: For eight seasons, it has always been someone else's job. Ray Mickens, at 5 feet 8 inches, was already an anomaly for an N.F.L. nickelback. But in the glamour spots on the corners for the Jets were Otis Smith, Aaron Glenn, Marcus Coleman, Aaron Beasley and Donnie Abraham.

title: National Briefing | Politics: Dean's Rivals Respond Ambivalently To Attack Ads
description: Asked by Howard Dean's campaign to denounce attack advertisements run against him by a group that has resisted disclosing its financing, some Democratic rivals responded ambivalently. Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts said he did not like independent advertisements, but agreed with the thrust of the group's most controversial spot, in which Dr. Dean's national security qualifications are questioned as a magazine cover of Osama bin Laden's face is shown. ''This is not the time for untested leadership to step in the shoes of the leader of the free world,'' Mr. Kerry said. A spokesman for Senator Joseph I. Lieberman called the advertisement ''over the top'' but said Republicans could unleash far worse if Dr. Dean won the nomination. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAIGE, JACK
description: PAIGE--Jack, on December 16, 2003, at the age of 92. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Loving father of Barbara and Paul Elliot, Karen and Rick Berdon, and Fran and Charles Katz. Adoring grandfather of Lauren, James, David, Nancy, Tracy, Michael, Tori and Todd. Proud great grandfather of Dylan and Katie. Dear brother of Anita Feintuch. Funeral service, Thursday, December 18, 2003, 12:30 P.M., at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHACHTER, OSCAR
description: SCHACHTER--Oscar. Columbia University mourns Oscar Schachter, Hamilton Fish Professor Emeritus of International Law and Diplomacy. First in class in Columbia Law School (1939), Editor-in-Chief of Columbia Law Review, on faculty since 1975, Honorary Doctor of Laws 2000, taught International Law and Human Rights through 2003. Sympathy to Muriel Sackler, Judith Schachter, Ellen Leventhal, Marvin Schachter and Honey Zimmer. Memorial Wednesday, January 21, 2004, 4:30PM, Columbia Law School, 435 W. 116th St.

title: Freedom Deal Approved
description: The shareholders of Freedom Communications, which has been owned by the Hoiles family for seven decades, voted overwhelmingly yesterday to approve a deal to sell a minority stake to two investment firms.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Knitwear Maker Settles Labor Charges
description: The United States Department of Labor announced yesterday that Danmar Finishing, a Brooklyn company accused of overtime violations and illegal retaliation against workers, had agreed to pay $410,000 to workers: $400,000 in back wages to 175 workers, and $10,000 to 13 workers to compensate for retaliatory actions against them. Last year, Shakira, left, the Latina singer and songwriter who had modeled Danmar's clothes, criticized the company after it was accused of avoiding overtime payments by forcing workers to clock out after 40 hours and then return to work. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Mutual Fund Ex-Executive Is Sentenced To Prison
description: A former senior executive at Fred Alger Management was sentenced yesterday to one to three years in prison for tampering with evidence sought by the New York attorney general in connection with the investigation of improper trading in mutual funds.

title: Long Day For Knicks Portends Many More
description: In the wake of what Allan Houston called ''one of the most embarrassing losses since I've been here,'' the Knicks held a team meeting Wednesday to address complaints, roles and expectations. Then they sat through a long film session and went through an exhausting practice.

title: Making Something Out of Nothing
description: IMAGINE a touch screen on which the elements of the image displayed can be moved around with a fingertip. Now imagine the same scene without the screen: the image can still be moved with a fingertip, but it floats unsupported above a quietly whirring gray box that is connected to a laptop computer.

title: Facing Up to the Inevitable, Fassel Says He's Out
description: At first, John Mara thought nothing of Giants Coach Jim Fassel's coming to talk to him. Fassel visits his office almost every day, to talk about personnel matters or injuries or whatever. Over seven seasons, it has become a pleasant part of Mara's day.

title: New Jersey Says 37 Children Died of Abuse During Year
description: Despite New Jersey's high-profile effort to revamp its child welfare system, 37 children died of abuse or neglect in the state this year, including 18 who were known to state social workers, according to state records released on Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Killed By Truck
description: A woman was fatally hit by a truck in Bay Ridge yesterday, the police said. The woman, Janny Mak, 67, was pronounced dead at Lutheran Medical Center. The truck driver, John Gilly, 29, who was turning left onto 79th Street from Fourth Avenue, told the police that his truck would not stop. He was issued summonses for failing to yield to a pedestrian and operating outside the prescribed truck route for the area, the police said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Interest Rate Cut
description: Norway's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate to a record low in a bid to weaken the country's currency, the krone, after its two-year advance against the dollar pushed inflation below the target rate. The bank lowered the deposit rate to 2.25 percent from 2.5 percent, the eighth reduction in a year. The bank indicated that it might pare borrowing costs again because of easing inflation. The krone fell as much as 0.6 percent.

title: David S. Lewis, 86, Executive Who Led General Dynamics
description: David S. Lewis, an aeronautical engineer who took the helm of the ailing General Dynamics Corporation, pushed it to profitability and retired after what was seen as mild official censure by the Navy for cost overruns, died on Monday in Charleston, S.C., his son David said. He was 86.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about indications that the New York City economy is recovering referred imprecisely to a figure showing an increase of 11,000 jobs in September and October. It included a seasonal adjustment; the increase was not partly a result of seasonal factors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBELL, ARTHUR, ESQ.
description: LUBELL--Arthur, Esq. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of a cherished member of our extended family. Arthur's contagious warm smile was a reflection of his kindness and concern for his fellow human being. He will be sorely missed and his memory will endure as a lasting blessing. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Josh S. Weston, Honorary Chairman Raphael Benaroya, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Ronald Gray, Executive Vice President

title: Facing Deficit, Virginia Governor Proposes Redoing Tax Code
description: Stepping into a political minefield, Gov. Mark Warner of Virginia proposed a sweeping overhaul of the state's tax code on Wednesday that he said would reduce taxes for two-thirds of Virginians, increase revenue and shift more of the tax burden onto the rich.

description: An article yesterday about the morning-after pill under consideration by the Food and Drug Administration for over-the-counter sales misstated its effectiveness. He is Craig Ferrell Jr., not Chris. The article also misstated the title of Michael Wishnie, a lawyer for the plaintiffs, at New York University. He is a full professor, not an associate professor.

title: Rowland Goes Through the Motions, but Says Very Little
description: Coming from a politician under siege for not being truthful, the apology that Gov. John G. Rowland offered on Wednesday had one thing going for it: one would be hard-pressed to find anything false or misleading in it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHERMAN, LYDIA
description: SHERMAN -- Lydia. Hadas sah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc., mourns the passing of Lydia Sherman, beloved wife of Nathan, of blessed memory, and cherished mother of Shelley Sherman and David Diamond. Lydia was a generous benefactor of Hadassah, devoted to Israel and the Jewish people. Her legacy will live on through the projects she supported at the Hadassah Medical Organization. We extend our deepest condolences to her family. June Walker, National President

title: Priest-Abuse Panelist Describes Diocese Pressure on Her to Quit
description: The panel that reviews allegations of sexual abuse by Catholic priests on Long Island works in a secret world where members do not discuss investigations publicly, have agreed not to talk to reporters and even protested when the diocese wanted to use their names in a news release.

title: Yonkers Girl Killed in Fire In Downtown Apartments
description: A fire raced through a five-story apartment building in downtown Yonkers last night, killing a young girl and leaving about 10 families homeless, Fire Department officials said.

title: Candidates in Presidential Contest Are Failing to Move Democratic Primary Voters, Poll Shows
description: Three years after one of the most disputed presidential contests in the nation's history, Americans remain polarized and divided as they approach the 2004 White House election. But most voters, including most Democrats, are largely unmoved by any of the nine Democrats who are seeking to unseat President Bush, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Israel Awaits Latest Word From Sharon On Next Step
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel is scheduled to speak at a conference in the seaside town of Herzliya on Thursday, and it seems that all of Israel, certainly all of the Israeli press, is speculating as to what he will say.

title: A Pact on Central America Trade Zone, Minus One
description: The United States sewed up its first new trade agreement in a year marked by reversals and setbacks, completing negotiations on Wednesday with four Central American countries to create a regional free trade pact.

title: National Briefing | Politics: Clark Calls For Iraqi Trial Of Hussein
description: Saddam Hussein should be tried in Iraq by Iraqis, Gen. Wesley K. Clark said, and the death penalty should be an option. ''Capturing Saddam increases our chances for success,'' General Clark said in Concord, N.H. ''If we succeed in Iraq, America will be safer. Because if we fail in Iraq, our enemies will be emboldened.'' General Clark said the ''cause of justice'' would be served only if the question of punishment was decided by Iraqis, not the international community or the United States. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

The deferrals were requested by officials seeking to gather as much cash as possible to campaign in the New Hampshire primary. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Shiny, Bright and Seasonal
description: The Tinsel Trading Company is a treasure-trove of decorative ornaments and vintage and new trimmings. Marcia Ceppos owns the business, started by a grandfather of hers 70 years ago. She sells tassels for curtain tiebacks, cords, passementerie, beads and beaded trims as well as metallic fabrics (some from before 1950), silk and velvet flowers, There are also old and new Christmas tree ornaments and new goose-feather trees. The Tinsel Trading Company is at 47 West 38th Street; www.tinseltrading.com or (212) 730-1030. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Life Term In Girls' Killings
description: A former school custodian, Ian Huntley, 29, was convicted and sentenced to life in prison for the murders of two 10-year-old girls, Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman, in August 2002. The case generated an outpouring of shock and emotion for the hideous nature of the crimes that sundered the sense of rural calm and security for the 8,000 residents of Soham, 70 miles northeast of London. Mr. Huntley's girlfriend, Maxine Carr, 26, was acquitted of murder charges but convicted of lying to investigators. She was sentenced to a term of three to five years. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

description: Manhattan Coach Bobby Gonzalez stamped his feet on the hardwood, placed his palms on his head and stormed to the end of the Jaspers' bench in disbelief.

title: Sharon Says Israel Might Use Wall to Create Palestinian Border
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 18 — Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, said in a major policy address today that if the current peace efforts fail to bring progress within months, Israel will begin severing links with the Palestinians by pulling out of some settlements and establishing a new "security line."

title: New York and Microsoft Expected To File Civil Suits in Spam Case
description: Eliot Spitzer, the New York state attorney general, and Microsoft plan to file civil suits today charging one of the nation's most prominent e-mail marketers with fraud stemming from sending unsolicited commercial e-mail, commonly known as spam, according to several people involved in the cases.

description: Byron Scott might have lost his locker room, but at least for the short term it does not appear he will lose his job.

title: People
description: Patrick Hagerty, associate publisher at Newsweek magazine, New York, was promoted to United States publisher. He continues reporting to Gregory J. Osberg, executive vice president and worldwide publisher. Newsweek is owned by the Washington Post Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POLLOCK, EUGENE D.
description: POLLOCK -- Eugene D. Passed away December 14, 2003 in Aventura, FL, at age 91. Beloved husband of the late Josephine, loving father of Wendy Pollock, Hillel and Beth Pollock, grandfather of Lara and Marc, uncle of Dennis and June Pollack. Former executive of National United Jewish Appeal, serving over 35 years. Mentor and friend to many. Known for his compassion, relentless intellect and search for adventure.

title: CHECKFREE BUYS AMERICAN PAYMENT SYSTEMS
description: The CheckFree Corporation, whose software is used to pay bills on the Internet, has agreed to acquire American Payment Systems, a division of UIL Holdings, for about $110 million in cash to add more than 8,000 walk-in locations. American Payment Systems has locations in the 75 largest metropolitan areas and seven million households use its services. The business has more than $40 million in annual revenue, CheckFree said. Customers use CheckFree's services to pay telephone, credit card, utility and cable-television bills. The American Payment Systems purchase, expected to close in the first half of next year, will let the company reach the 20 percent of the population that prefers to pay bills in person, CheckFree said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Exports Rise
description: Singapore's exports, excluding oil, rose 2.3 percent in November compared with a year ago, the government said. Exports were led by petrochemicals to China. The number was a disappointment after October's 20.6 percent rise. Despite strong demand from Asia, overall export growth was held back by lower demand from the United States for pharmaceuticals and disk drives. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Executive Named
description: Dieter Vogel was elected the supervisory board chairman of the media company Bertelsmann, the company said. Mr. Vogel, left, who is currently the deputy chairman, will succeed Gerd Schulte-Hillen as leader of the 14-member board at the beginning of next year. Mr. Schulte-Hillen, a longtime chief executive of the Bertelsmann subsidiary Gruner & Jahr, is leaving his post after disagreeing with Bertelsmann's chief executive, Gunter Thielen, and the controlling Mohn family on the company's business strategy. His successor, who is a former head of the steel maker Thyssen, already presides over the supervisory board of the mobile phone company MobilCom and the investment group WCM. Bertelsmann is based in Gtersloh, Germany.

title: The New-Look Yankees Will Test Torre
description: Gary Sheffield's diamond earrings sparkled as he sat beside Manager Joe Torre at a news conference at Yankee Stadium yesterday. The earrings, of course, will have to go. The squabbling with George Steinbren ner, the Yankees' principal owner, which began before Sheffield signed his contract, will have to go, too. The lethal right-handed bat can stay.

title: Corrections
description: The column name and the byline were omitted last Thursday from reports on cocktail glasses, artificial foliage and a courtyard at the Lyce Franais in Manhattan. The column was Currents, and the writer was Craig Kellogg.

title: A Public Health Victory
description: Science and public health triumphed over ideology on Tuesday when two expert advisory committees to the Food and Drug Administration voted 23 to 4 in favor of allowing the so-called morning-after pill, which can prevent unintended pregnancies, to be sold without a doctor's prescription.

title: Danish Design Relights the Way
description: The ahead-of-its-time VP-Globe (above) was made by the Danish designer Verner Panton in 1969. Now, along with other Panton lamps, it is being reissued. VP-Globe -- a plastic sphere housing five aluminum reflectors suspended by steel chains -- comes 16 inches in diameter for $1,995, or 20 inches in diameter for $2,495. At the MoMA Design Store, 81 Spring Street (Crosby Street); www.momastore.org or (800) 447-6662. Other Panton rereleases include the Fun DM1 Chrome, $985, a jewel-like creation of polished metal disks. Information: www.12timer.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OVESEY, REGINA
description: OVESEY--Regina. Wife of the late Dr. Lionel Ovesey. Mother of Candace and Michele Ovesey. Grandmother of Paul, Alexandra, Craig and Nicholas. First woman in the U.S. to own an ad agency recognized by the Association of American Advertising Agencies. Winner of numerous advertising awards, with work exhibited worldwide, including at the Smithsonian. Co-director of the Public Advertising System at the School of Visual Arts. Member of the Executive Committee of the Lexington Democratic Club. Stanford University, Phi Beta Kappa. Memorial service on Wednesday, January 7, 2004, 4PM at Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street and Madison Ave. Donations in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, NY, NY 10087 for lung cancer research.

description: Michael Jackson, the international pop star, was formally charged today with child molestation in a case involving a teenage houseguest at the singer's ranch near Santa Barbara.

title: Data and Bookmarks Dangle From Your Key Chain
description: With their large storage capacity and small size, U.S.B. flash memory drives have become a common way to carry large files from one computer to another. The tiny devices are getting even more useful, as demonstrated by the Migo from Forward Solutions, which can not only carry files but synchronize Outlook mailboxes so your correspondence is up to date no matter what computer you are using.

title: U.S. Intensifies Its Alert on Saudi Arabia
description: The State Department intensified its warnings about terrorism in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday, advising Americans not to travel there and giving nonessential diplomatic employees the option to leave.

title: Musicians Protesting Monopoly In Media
description: Musicians rocked for peace in the 1960's. They rocked for Africa in the 1980's. Now they're rocking for stricter corporate media regulation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALSH, ELOISE A.
description: WALSH--Eloise A. On December 12, 2003. Beloved sister of Margaret. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Mourning Surgery Said to Be Set
description: Less than a month after center Alonzo Mourning left the Nets because his kidney disease was worsening, he will have kidney transplant surgery Friday in New York, according to an article in The Miami Herald on Wednesday.

title: For the Deaf, Communication Without the Wait
description: THE spread of high-speed Internet access and the increasing sophistication of videoconferencing tools have given the deaf broad new access to a simple pleasure that most people take for granted: chatting on the telephone. New products and services promise to liberate the deaf from the slow text-based telecommunications systems that have been their primary option for decades.

title: Under Rules, Train Whistles Will Lose Some of Their Blare
description: The distant whistle of a passing train is about to get a little more distant.

title: National Briefing | Politics: New Jersey Governor Plans To Endorse Dean
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey plans to endorse Howard Dean's presidential campaign on Friday in Trenton, the first sitting governor to publicly back Dr. Dean, the former governor of Vermont. Two sitting governors have already endorsed Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Self-Portrait as Obscure Object of Desire; Jack Pierson's Autobiography, of Sorts, in Photographs of Unidentified Men
description: A new book of photographs by Jack Pierson features 15 images of beautiful men, arranged to suggest the arc of a lifetime -- beginning with a young boy and progressing to old age with men in various stages of undress. There's nothing surprising about that; Mr. Pierson has been photographing beautiful naked men for years. In this case, though, the photographs are offered under the title ''Self Portrait.'' But none of the images is of the artist himself.

title: Editorial Observer; Senator Strom Thurmond's Not-So-Secret Black Daughter
description: African-Americans and white Americans are so deeply entangled by blood that racial categories have become meaningless. When discussing the issue in public, I typically offer my own family as an example. We check ''black'' on the census and appear black to the naked eye, but we are also descended from white ancestors on both sides. Despite appearances, I told an audience not long ago, ''I am as 'white' as anyone in this room.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Protocols For Looted Art
description: The European Parliament adopted a resolution that calls on its administrative arm, the European Commission, to take steps to help the owners of art looted by the Nazis regain their property. The laws of some countries dealing with looted artworks have lapsed, and there is no international convention that applies. Lawmakers urged the commission to undertake a study by the end of next year on setting up a catalog of data from public and private archives on looted items and document existing claims. They also urged the formation of a cross-border authority to deal with ownership disputes. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Moscow Journal; African Students' Harsh Lesson: Racism Is Astir in Russia
description: The morning starts with 100 push-ups for Constant Olivier Diboi Kath as he prepares for the most dangerous moment of his day -- his subway ride to chemistry class on the other side of town.

title: National Briefing: National Security
description: LAST IN GROUP GETS SENTENCE FOR AIDING AL QAEDA A man who met Osama bin Laden after leaving a Qaeda training camp received a sentence of nine and one-half years in prison for helping the terrorist group. The man, Sahim Alwan, 31, was the last of six men from Lackawanna, N.Y., to be sent to federal prison. All six pleaded guilty to similar charges earlier this year.

title: 'Ring' Fanatics' Long Wait Finally Ends, With an Eyeful
description: An hour before the noon starting time, the theater was nearly full, the rest of the ticket holders still in line on the street. Some had been here since 5 a.m.; some were rumored to have arrived the evening before. Given what the director, Peter Jackson, and his actors and crew must have endured in New Zealand for a year and a half, the fans reason, it is a small sacrifice.

title: Bear Stearns And Lehman Top Forecasts
description: Two Wall Street investment firms reported quarterly earnings yesterday that exceeded expectations, a reflection of a continuing rebound in the securities industry.

title: The Worst Meal of the Year
description: ''If I had my way and I shan't,'' wrote that doyenne of British food writers, Elizabeth David, ''my Christmas Day eating and drinking would consist of an omelet and cold ham and a nice bottle of wine at lunchtime, and a smoked salmon sandwich with a glass of Champagne on a tray in bed in the evening.'' Ah, wouldn't that be bliss! Like Thanksgiving in the United States, Christmas in Britain has grown into an inescapable culinary dinosaur from which you chicken out at your peril -- even in an era when a new, lighter British cuisine is being promoted by young chefs like Jamie Oliver. Families, the majority of which are better kept apart, are suddenly thrown together for a ritual feast lasting several days, plowing their way through a few million roast turkeys, mince pies and Christmas puddings and cakes, not to mention swimming the alcohol lake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSEN, NATHALIE (NEE ZWEIG)
description: ROSEN -- Nathalie (nee Zweig) on December 12, peacefully, four days after her 95th birthday, when she was surrounded by her family. Beloved wife of the late Clement Rosen, cherished mother of David and his wife Andrea Penkower Rosen, and of Marc and his wife Susan Pinsky. Adored by grandchildren Alexis, Amanda, Avery and Clement, and loving great grandmother to Kevin, Daniel and Jamie. She taught kindness and a love of books, art and music to her children, and was beautiful, sensitive and sweet-natured throughout her entire life. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Hadassah or Hatzalah.

title: Surviving 9/11, but Not Aftermath; A Wall Street Landmark to End Short Run as a Luxury Hotel
description: The great gray dowager empress of Wall Street was transformed four years ago into the belle of the ball. Today, the ball is nearly over.

title: CLOROX ELEVATES BOARD MEMBER TO CHAIRMAN
description: The Clorox Company has named Robert Matschullat, a board member for four years, as chairman, keeping the post separate from that of the chief executive. Mr. Matschullat, 56, will succeed the retiring chairman, Craig Sullivan, on Jan. 1, the company said. The post of chief executive and chairman were separated in July when the president, Gerald Johnston, succeeded Mr. Sullivan as chief executive. Mr. Matschullat, a retired vice chairman of the Seagram Company, will oversee the board's efforts to improve corporate governance and to evaluate Mr. Johnston's performance. Mr. Johnston has increased spending on developing new products and marketing to try to keep consumers from switching from its major lines, which include Glad bags and Hidden Valley salad dressings, to cheaper store brands.

title: Retracing the Last Fatal Steps In a Young Firefighter's Life
description: About 15 minutes after firefighters started battling the blaze, the smoke closed in, wiping the screen of the world blank and leaving only darkness and heat.

description: The nurse who prosecutors say has admitted killing as many as 40 hospital patients is thinking about offering to cooperate with investigators in identifying his victims in exchange for avoiding execution, his lawyer said Wednesday.

title: M.T.A. to Unveil Management Reforms
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, long criticized as a secretive collection of fiefs largely unaccountable to taxpayers or the riding public, is embarking on what it says is a major overhaul of how it conducts its affairs.

title: Catalogs: Catnip for Young Consumers
description: CHILDREN often ''read'' catalogs as if they were magazines, especially when the sales pitch is sweetened with playful touches like games and jokes. And naturally, when they pore over the pages, they want to buy the products shown. ''The other day I saw a 2-year-old choosing bedding in one of our Chicago stores,'' said Jamie Cohen, an owner of Land of Nod, a children's furnishings company whose catalog, right, will reach four million households next year. Founded seven years ago by Mr. Cohen and his childhood friend Scott Eirinberg, the company now has three stores and is half-owned by Crate & Barrel.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Eminem Stops Distribution Of CD
description: Eminem has stopped the hip-hop magazine The Source from distributing a CD of previously unreleased music in which he disparages black women. In a ruling on Tuesday by Judge Gerald Lynch in Federal District Court in Manhattan, lawyers for the rap star were granted an injunction that bars the magazine from issuing the CD with its February issue. Eminem accused the magazine of breaching federal copyright laws by reproducing the recording without his consent. ''The magazine was also ordered to remove the song from its Web site,'' said Dennis Dennehy, a spokesman for Interscope Records, the parent label. Eminem, who is white, has said that he made the tape after breaking up with a black girlfriend in 1988. He has since apologized. A spokesman for The Source declined to comment yesterday. Lola Ogunnaike (NYT)

title: Man Who Shot Reagan Allowed To Visit Parents Unsupervised

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNOPPERS, ANTONIE T.
description: KNOPPERS--Antonie T. Died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on Tuesday, December 16 at age 88. Beloved husband of Ria, proud father of a son Bastiaan Knoppers of Amsterdam, Netherlands, and three daughters, Mieke Knoppers Cole of New York, NY, Anneke Woodward of Atlanta, GA, and Els Knoppers of Arlington, MA, and devoted grandfather of eight grandchildren. Dr. Knoppers lived life fully and passionately. He loved music intensely, especially opera. A native of the Netherlands, he received his medical degree in 1939 from the University of Amsterdam and a doctorate in pharmacology in 1941 from the University of Leiden. He was Professor of Pharmacology at the Free University of Amsterdam. Dr. Knoppers became a citizen of the United States in 1958. Dr. Knoppers joined Merck and Co. in 1952 and held various positions in the International Division of Merck Sharp and Dohme, becoming President of the Division in 1957, elected a member of the Board of Directors of Merck in 1970, and President and Chief Operating Officer of Merck in 1971 until his retirement. He served as Chairman of the International Chamber of Commerce, Chairman of the Salzburg Seminar, and as a Director on the Boards of Hewlett Packard, Scott Paper Co., Humana, Ahold, Centocor, Agouron, and the Salk Institute. Dr. Knoppers was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, the Century Club, Baltusrol Club, and the Metropolitan Opera Club, proudly serving as President of the Opera Club 1987-1988. His excitement for life was contagious and will be missed. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Ricardo O'Gorman Garden and Center, 23 W 129 St, New York, NY 10027 or the Wright Center on Aging, Box 5907 GPO, New York, NY 10087. Funeral services at Christ Church, 561 Springfield Ave, Summit, NJ on Saturday, December 20 at 11:00 AM.

title: DIDDY ON BROADWAY
description: The rap impresario P. Diddy, left, will star in the spring in the first Broadway revival of Lorraine Hansberry's pioneering kitchen-sink drama, ''A Raisin in the Sun,'' the producer David Binder said yesterday. As The New York Post reported, P. Diddy will play the working-class chauffeur Walter Lee Younger, a role made famous by Sidney Poitier, who originated the part on Broadway in 1959 and did a reprise in the film version two years later. P. Diddy, who has never appeared in a play but has had supporting roles in films, including ''Monster's Ball,'' auditioned twice for the role. ''We were all incredibly impressed by his chops,'' Mr Binder said. Kenny Leon will direct. P. Diddy is only the latest hip-hop artist to give Broadway a try. Mos Def starred in Suzan Lori-Parks's ''Topdog/Underdog'' on Broadway in 2002, and Russell Simmons produced ''Russell Simmons' Def Poetry Slam'' last year. JASON ZINOMAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ESTESS, JENIFER
description: ESTESS--Jenifer. The Estess family and the entire Project A.L.S. organization and friends are mourning the loss of Jenifer Estess. Jenifer passed away on Tuesday morning, December 16, 2003 in her home, after a long and courageous struggle with ALS. Jenifer fought this disease, as she lived her life, with dignity and courage. She was an inspiration to all who knew her and countless others who were afflicted with ALS and other neurological disorders. Jenifer's dream was that, someday, there would be a cure for ALS and the related diseases of Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, and Huntington's. She devoted her energy to making that dream a reality. She knew that progress in finding a cure would take years and would likely come too late for her. Her wish was that Project A.L.S. would go on and that all of us would fight this disease for years to come until a cure is found. To the thousands of Project A.L.S. supporters, we pledge to honor Jenifer by continuing the fight to find a cure for this dreaded disease. Through the efforts of the world's leading doctors, researchers and with your support, we look forward to continuing this fight until a cure is found. Services will be held on Friday, December 19th at 3PM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street. Donations can be made to Project A.L.S. and mailed to Project A.L.S. 511 Avenue of the Americas, PMB 341, NY, NY 10011. Robert S. Kaplan, Chairman of the Board of Project A.L.S. Peter J. Hulbert, Co-Chairman of the Board of Project A.L.S. Board of Directors, Project A.L.S.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Grant For Teaching City History
description: The federal Department of Education has awarded $2 million to promote the teaching of New York City history, Schools Chancellor Joel I. title: Technology Briefing | Software: VeriSign To Buy Guardent For $140 Million
description: VeriSign Inc., which sells software that verifies the identities of computer users, agreed to buy closely held Guardent yesterday for $140 million in cash and stock to add network security services. The transaction includes about 150 full-time workers from Guardent, which is based in Waltham, Mass., and has an operations center in Providence, R.I. The agreement is scheduled to close next quarter and will not affect 2004 earnings, VeriSign said. VeriSign is the main operator of the database of Internet addresses and is increasing its security services as demand for Web site names slows. The company said in October that it was selling its Web-address sales unit, Network Solutions, to the investment firm Pivotal Private Equity for about $100 million. Shares of VeriSign, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., fell 22 cents, to $15.32.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 2 Journalists Arrested
description: Pakistan arrested two French journalists for visiting Quetta without valid visas and for taking photographs of ''prohibited areas,'' Reuters reported. Immigration officials said the journalists, who work for the magazine Express, would be put on trial and face three years in prison. Pakistan recently begun issuing visas to journalists that restrict their travel to certain cities. Journalists have called the policy censorship, but officials say it is for their safety. Immigration officials said the French journalists received visas allowing them to travel to Islamabad, Lahore and Karachi but not Quetta. Afghan officials accuse Pakistan of allowing the Taliban to use Quetta as a base for reorganizing its forces. Pakistan denies the charge. David Rohde (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NATO CHIEF STEPS DOWN Lord Robertson, NATO's secretary general, ended a four-year term that included the alliance's response to the Sept. 11 attacks, peacekeeping in Afghanistan and deep divisions over the Iraq war. He left NATO headquarters in Brussels for the last time after leading a meeting with envoys from the 19 member nations. His successor, Jaap de Hoop Scheffer, a former Dutch foreign minister, starts work on Jan. 5. Lord Robertson, who was previously a secretary of defense in Prime Minister Tony Blair's cabinet, declined to extend his term, preferring a return to the private sector as deputy chairman of Cable and Wireless, the British telecommunications company. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 3Com Reports $139 Million Loss
description: The 3Com Corporation, a maker of computer networking equipment, said yesterday that its second-quarter loss doubled to $139 million as sales dropped and operating expenses were little changed. The net loss was 37 cents a share, compared with a loss of $68.5 million, or 19 cents a share, in the same period a year ago, 3Com said. Revenue this quarter will be unchanged or down slightly from the previous three months, the company said. 3Com, which is based in Marlborough, Mass., has not reported a quarterly profit in almost four years, and sales have dropped from a peak of $1.6 billion in 1998. 3Com is counting on resale agreements with larger companies to lift revenue. Its shares rose to $7.83 in extended trading after falling 20 cents, to $7.70, in regular trading. The company was expected to have a loss of 14 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. 3Com said its per-share loss was not comparable to Thomson Financial's estimates.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Palm Restaurants Settle Bias Case
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said it reached a $500,000 settlement with the Palm Restaurants, a chain of 25 restaurants accused of discriminating against women in hiring for jobs as waiters, bartenders and kitchen help. The Palm, with restaurants in New York, Las Vegas, Los Angeles, Miami and Washington, agreed to mandatory training to help supervisors avoid discrimination. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Separating the Killers From the Boys
description: Lee Malvo, the teenager charged in the Washington-area sniper attacks, is on trial for his life in an adult court in Chesapeake, Va. Although ''kids who kill'' seem like a modern phenomenon, we've actually been struggling for more than a century with how to regard and treat them. Are they men or merely boys? Should it make a difference in the way we think about their punishment?

title: Setting Out the Welcome Mat at Your Home on the Web
description: IF you want to post pictures of your grandchildren online, publicize a home business or organize a community group, or if you simply suspect that everyone who's anyone has a home page on the Internet, it may be time to set one up. The process may be easier than you think.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, JEREMIAH
description: KLEIN--Jeremiah. Park East Synagogue extends deepest sympathy to our esteemed Cantor Ari and Lauren Klein and to the entire family on the loss of the Patriarch of the family, Rev. Jeremiah Klein. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Wharf Bid Opposed
description: A Toronto property group, the Brascan Corporation, teamed up with Paul Reichmann, the founder of Canary Wharf, to oppose a group led by Morgan Stanley that has bid $2.7 billion for Canary Wharf. The two have pledged to vote against the offer, and to back any bid the other puts forward. Together with the investor Franklin Resources, which also opposes the Morgan Stanley deal, Mr. Reichmann and Brascan have 24.7 percent of Canary Wharf's stock. Shareholders are to vote on Monday on the sale of two of Canary's office towers, a deal that is an integral part of the Morgan Stanley bid. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Shopping Game

title: Two Good Decisions; Rescuing Wetlands
description: President Bush has shown himself to be more deft on clean-water issues than he has on snowmobiles. To the surprise and delight of conservationists, his administration announced on Tuesday that it would abandon a draft proposal that would have narrowed the jurisdiction of the Clean Water Act and greatly reduced federal protections for streams and wetlands. The proposal would have opened millions of acres to commercial development and the pollution that goes with it.

title: Moment of Truth
description: Of all the fascinating reactions to Saddam Hussein's capture, the one that intrigues me most is the French decision to suddenly offer some debt forgiveness for Iraq. Why now? I believe it's an 11th-hour attempt by the French government to scramble onto the right side of history.

title: Remember 'Weapons of Mass Destruction'? For Bush, They Are a Nonissue
description: In the debate over the necessity for the war in Iraq, few issues have been more contentious than whether Saddam Hussein possessed arsenals of banned weapons, as the Bush administration repeatedly said, or instead was pursuing weapons programs that might one day constitute a threat.

title: Second Hand Isn't Always Low
description: Second hand low: usually. Second hand high: occasionally. But second hand middle? That can be right too but is usually overlooked. An example is in the diagramed deal, played this year at Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUCA, DR. WILLIAM P. JR.
description: LUCA--Dr. William P. Jr. 79, of NYC on December 9, 2003. Beloved father of Elyse Feller, Peter, William, Hans, and Carl. Cherished grandfather of four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A mass will be held on Saturday, December 20, 2003 at 11:15AM at St. Ignatius Episcopal Church, 552 West End Avenue, NYC. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to St. Ignatius Episcopal Church, NYC or to the Boys' Club of New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oil Agreement Renewed
description: The government of Brunei and Royal Dutch/Shell renewed 40-year-old agreements to allow Shell to drill for oil and natural gas there. Shell will be allowed to mine in the country, which borders Malaysia on the South China Sea, for another 19 years. The agreement covers both onshore and offshore drilling. Output from Brunei accounts for just under 5 percent of Shell's existing production.

title: He Almost Made Fans Forget Parcells
description: Behind thick eyeglasses that made him look as if he would be more at home in a mathematics lab than in a football locker room, Jim Fassel arrived at Giants Stadium six years ago. He had a bland image that fit the colorless team under his charge. No one could even pronounce his name correctly.

title: Sports of The Times; With His Connection, Coughlin Is a Candidate
description: TIMING is everything. If this were a year ago and Jim Fassel were suddenly out as the Giants' coach, General Manager Ernie Accorsi would surely have been tempted, if not expected, to phone Bill Parcells, who was then at liberty and living down the Jersey Shore. And surely Parcells would have at least considered returning to the Giants, if not leaped at the opportunity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINN, ANNE BRINE
description: FINN--Anne Brine, 75, of Sharon, CT; formerly of Ardsleyon-Hudson, NY died December 17th of Multiple Myeloma. She leaves her beloved husband of 53 years, Robert Macy Finn, eight children: Robert Jr., Maggie Gray, Anne Nelson, Christopher, Mary Wood, Timothy, Kathleen Carr, Nicholas and seventeen grandchildren. Everyone she met was touched by her quiet grace. Memorial service December 20th at 11:30 AM St. Mary's Church, Lakeville, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, BEVERLY N.
description: ROBERTS--Beverly N., 92, at home on December 14, 2003. Professor, Chairman of English, A&T University; English and art teacher, Principal and field supervisor, NYC Board of Education. Survived by children Adrienne of Denver, Antoinette and Richard, both of DC; brother Gerald; sister Wilhelmina; 2 grandchildren; relatives. Viewing Friday, December 19, 4-7 PM, J. Foster Phillips Funeral Home, 179-24 Linden Blvd, Jamaica, NY. Service 7 PM. Interment in Columbia, SC.

title: Yes, New Jersey Draws Top Snowboarders
description: At Mountain Creek, people are learning to have fun with the typical reaction they hear when someone is told there is a snow-sports resort 47 miles from New York City.

title: Why Did He Buy New York? Hey, Wasserstein Loves Deals
description: Those who worried that the recent tussle among billionaires for control of New York magazine would leave the storied publication as a personal platform for the winning mogul's social and business agenda might be able to relax. The interests of Bruce Wasserstein, the Wall Street deal maker and the magazine's new owner, appear far more academic than busying himself with the publication's journalism. Almost oddly so.

title: Figurines Found in German Cave Are Among Earliest Artwork
description: Three small figurines carved of ivory from mammoth tusks have been found in a cave in southwestern Germany, providing stronger evidence that human ancestors were already adept at figurative art more than 30,000 years ago, an archaeologist is reporting today.

title: Bush to Undergo Medical Scan of Knees
description: President Bush, whose joints seemed to defy the advances of time, will have a diagnostic scan of his knees on Thursday because of pain he has experienced while running.

title: Not Necessarily Cute or Cuddly
description: Paul Budnitz, above, is the owner of Kidrobot, which sells cutting-edge toys for the over-12 set. Such items are a perfect way to merge the commercial and fine arts, said Mr. Budnitz, 36, whose background includes software design and filmmaking. At his SoHo shop (his first is in San Francisco), articulated Gumby dolls ($6.95 and $8.95, one of the few familiar American toys) share space with $200 (and up) limited editions like Spraycan Monster and a set of three hip-hop spacemen, the De La Soul figures. Junkie, a vinyl-and-plastic toy, above right, is by Michael Lau, and modeled after a fellow Hong Kong graffiti artist ($119.95). Kidrobot is at 126 Prince Street (Wooster Street); (212) 966-6688 or www.kidrobot.com.

title: Pampered Pets? Ask the Litter Box Repairman
description: THIS is the season in which animals will come wrapped, presented as gifts. What's the word on this bit of holiday cheer? Let's ask Wendy Diamond, the founder and editorial director of Animal Fair, the glossy magazine for style-conscious animal lovers and their pampered pets. The quarterly's covers have featured Rene Zellweger, Jessica Alba, Shania Twain and Lauren Bush with their quadrupeds. Think the Vanity Fair of the pet world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARD, ROSLYN
description: WARD--Roslyn. Of Manhattan Beach, CA. died December 15, 2003, the day after her 98th birthday. A graduate of Columbia Teachers College, she was the daughter of the late Herman and Sarah (Sadie) Weinberger; beloved mother of Dana Ward of Manhattan Beach, CA. and the late Michael Ward; dear sister of the late Miriam Dubilier and the late Beatrice Weinberger Sutter, revered aunt of Laurence Sutter of New York; adored grandmother of Jessica Ward of Sierra Madre, CA. Cremation was private. Donations in Mrs. Ward's memory may be made to the National Federation of the Blind, 1800 Johnson St., Baltimore, MD 21230, the Glaucoma Research Foundation, 490 Post St., Ste. 1427, San Francisco, CA. 94102, or any organization aiding victims of glaucoma or the blind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUPONT, ALANA LAWRENCE
description: DUPONT--Alana Lawrence. Passed away on December 13, 2003, in Burlingame, California, after a brave, yearlong battle against cancer. A loving family including her husband of twenty-eight years, Peter W. Dupont, and their three daughters, Lilly, Daisy, and Charlotte were by her side. She left many friends and family members in New York, and California, whose lives she enriched with her joyful, creative, and generous spirit. She was an accomplished sportswoman, holding several titles in squash. She enjoyed wide recognition as an artist, known for her uniquely expressive work particularly in portraiture and landscape. Services January 17, 2004, 11AM, Christ Church, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, her family welcomes gifts in Alana's memory to: The Alana L. Dupont Fine Arts Education Fund, c/o Peninsula Community Foundation, 1700 South El Camino Real, San Mateo, CA 94402.

title: Best Supporting Actor: A Malibu Ranch House
description: In the DreamWorks film ''House of Sand and Fog,'' opening in New York tomorrow, the character played by Sir Ben Kingsley (above) buys a house, and the promise of a new life, for $45,000 at an auction. The place is supposed to be in Northern California, near Half Moon Bay. In reality, it is a two-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath ranch-style house in Malibu, overlooking the ocean (albeit from the roof, just as in the film). Fake power lines and facades of pretend neighbors' houses were brought in to make the property look less desirable, and a collapsing white picket fence was installed. Inside (mostly a studio set) the wallpaper and paint were made to look worn. ''We wanted it to look shabby, but not pathetic,'' said Maia Javan, the film's production designer. But don't get your hopes up. Real estate agents surveyed estimated that the house, unprepossessing as it is, is worth close to $600,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNUTE, MARTHA
description: SCHNUTE--Martha. December 10, 2003. Dear sister of Sara Lochhaas, Louise Schnute and Ruth Nisbet, loving aunt of Stephanie Nisbet, devoted daughter of the late Martin and Edna (Fehr) Schnute of Falls City, NE. Educated at Cornell University School of Nursing and Hunter College in New York. She was a dedicated nurse educator who gained the admiration, love and respect of her many students through the years. Memorial services will be held January 10, 2004 at 11AM at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, 619 Lexington Avenue, N.Y. N.Y. 10022. Memorials may be sent to the Music Fund at St. Peter's.

title: Taliban Detainee Is Depressed, Lawyer Says
description: The first civilian lawyer allowed to visit a detainee at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, said on Wednesday that his client was depressed, was enmeshed in an inadequate legal system that violated his rights and had been ill served by his home government of Australia.

description: Otto Graham, who led the Cleveland Browns to pro football supremacy in the decade after World War II and became one of the game's greatest quarterbacks, died yesterday at a hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 82.

title: Hussein Enters Post-9/11 Web Of U.S. Prisons
description: Saddam Hussein is now prisoner No. 1 in what has developed into a global detention system run by the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency, according to government officials.

description: MARMOR--Judd, MD. The Trustees, Officers and Members of The American Academy of Psychoanalysis and Dynamic Psychiatry express profound sorrow for the loss of Dr. Judd Marmor, Founding Member and Past-President of the Academy and Past-President of the American Psychiatric Association. description: George Ryan, who as governor of Illinois emptied the state's death row, was indicted on charges of racketeering conspiracy, mail and tax fraud and lying to investigators, in connection with his granting of contracts while a public official.

title: Iran Signs Pact Allowing Inspection of Its Nuclear Sites
description: Iran signed a protocol to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty today that allows the International Atomic Energy Agency broader rights of access to sites in the country, a move intended to help establish confidence that Iran's nuclear program is peaceful.

title: Economic Scene; Are bigger vehicles safer? It depends on whether you're a passenger or a target.
description: TRAFFIC fatalities in the United States fell steadily from 54,600 in 1972 to 34,900 in 1992. But then they started to rise again, and by 2002 there were 38,300 traffic deaths a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREBE, SYLVIA T.
description: GREBE--Sylvia T. Sylvia Thresher Grebe, 96, died December 10th in Hamden, CT. Grebe Memorial Scholarship, American University, 4400 Massachusetts Avenue NW, Washington, D.C. 20016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, RITA
description: BROWN--Rita on December 17, 2003. Devoted mother of Eric and Janice, Jordan and Karen, loving sister of Ann Zucconi, cherished grandmother of Rachel, Ilana, Justin, Hayes and Nikki, beloved aunt of Jenny and Jon. Funeral service Friday, 11AM, at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Shoot Armed Man In Building Hallway
description: A police officer responding to telephone calls from an apartment building in Inwood last night shot and critically wounded an armed man who had threatened residents, the police said. Officers went to the 18th floor of the building, at 213 Nagle Street, where a man with a gun was standing in the hallway near an apartment doorway, the police said. The man, who was not identified by the police, was taken to New York Presbyterian Hospital. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sega's Rating Raised
description: The credit rating of the game maker Sega was raised by Moody's Investors Service as a result of its efforts to cut its debts and increase profit. Moody's now rates Sega's long-term debt at B1, up from B3, and has raised its outlook to stable. Sega returned to profitability last year after exiting its money-losing video game console business to concentrate on arcade games and video game software. The upgrading will affect about 80 billion yen ($744 million) in debts. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about ''Prisoner of Paradise,'' a documentary about the German actor Kurt Gerron, misidentified the character he played in the original staging of ''The Threepenny Opera.'' It was Tiger Brown; Macheath was played by Harald Paulsen.

title: Johnny Cunningham, 46, Master of the Traditional Celtic Fiddle, Dies
description: Johnny Cunningham, one of the great Celtic fiddlers of his generation as well as a producer and composer, died on Monday at the apartment of his girlfriend, Trisha McCormack, in New York. He was 46, and had a home in New Bedford, Mass.

description: IN the most pressurized moments, when Jason Kidd is being stared at as closely as a fingerprint, it has become increasingly difficult to tell whether he is blowing kisses or throwing his voice.

title: WACHOVIA BUYS LEND LEASE UNIT FOR $41.6 MILLION
description: Wachovia Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the United States commercial real estate business of the Lend Lease Corporation, Australia's biggest real estate company, for $41.6 million to expand a business that makes about $1 billion of multifamily mortgages a year. The purchase of the unit, Lend Lease Mortgage Capital, which is based in Dallas and has about 50 employees, is the second acquisition of a commercial real estate firm by Wachovia in the last month, a bank spokesman, Jim Pierpoint, said.

description: Google, the Internet search engine, has begun an experiment with book publishers in which the contents of the first chapters of books, reviews or other bibliographic information is indexed and made available to Web surfers.

title: States Try to Limit Drugs in Medicaid, But Makers Resist
description: Kentucky's Medicaid program was $230 million in the red last year, and drastic cuts were on the table. A state panel proposed excluding Zyprexa, an antipsychotic medication that is the state's single biggest drug expense, from the Medicaid list of preferred medications.

description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18  "Cold Mountain," the story of a soldier making his way home in the Civil War-ravaged South, topped the list of the 61st annual Golden Globe nominations with eight, including nods for the movie's three stars, as well as best dramatic motion picture, best director and best screenplay.

title: As Franco Returns, Cedeo Nears Exit
description: John Franco returned to the Mets yesterday, agreeing to a $1 million contract with another $1 million in potential bonuses as he prepares for his 15th year with the team. Mike Cameron, the free-agent center fielder who agreed to a three-year, $19.5 million contract with the Mets last week, passed his physical and will be introduced at a Shea Stadium news conference this afternoon.

description: By eliminating the cable, a cordless mouse removes one bit of clutter from the desktop. But some models add another: a recharging cradle.

title: The Client Is Refined, Picky and 3 Feet Tall
description: SUSAN ZISES GREEN wishes all her Park Avenue clients were as focused as Eliza. ''She was very discerning and opinionated,'' said Mrs. Zises Green, an interior designer. ''I asked her is this a room where she'd entertain friends. She was very aware of where friends would sit. We tried to get a floor plan that would get the most open space.''

title: Slow Fun for Game Boys and Girls
description: BOARD games are much in evidence this holiday season, not just in toy stores but in bookstores and hardware stores, too. Many are new, but the classics are dominating store displays. They are a pleasing corrective, it seems, to high-tech gadgets and video games, and they are a good way for families to spend time together. Some game boards look good enough to be left out on the coffee table or hung on the wall.

title: Corrections
description: The column name and the byline were omitted last Thursday from reports on cocktail glasses, artificial foliage and a courtyard at the Lyce Franais in Manhattan. The column was Currents, and the writer was Craig Kellogg.

title: No Warnings As Nurse Left Job After Job
description: Using a device that helped him speak a few words, Francis J. Henry managed to say ''I love you'' to his wife, Deloris. He was in poor shape, a nurse recalled -- he had multiple injuries from a car crash, great trouble breathing, an oxygen tube in his throat, and Parkinson's disease.

title: VOESTALPINE ADDS TO MARKET SHARE IN UNITED STATES
description: Voestalpine, Austria's biggest steel maker, plans to buy the rail track-building assets of the Meridian Rail Track Products Corporation to almost double sales in the United States, increasing its market share in the country to about 44 percent. The purchase will add $50 million in sales a year in the United States to the $60 million the company now has, Wilhelm Nitterl, a Voestalpine spokesman, said in a telephone interview. Total rail construction sales in the United States are about $250 million, Mr. Nitterl said. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: TUPPERWARE'S CREDIT RATING REDUCED TO JUNK LEVEL
description: Tupperware Corporation's credit rating has been cut to junk by Standard & Poor's Ratings Services because the food-container company is facing risks in rebuilding its Tupperware party business in the United States. The rating on Tupperware's long-term corporate credit and senior unsecured debt was lowered to BB+ from BBB-, the S.&P. said. The rating affects about $305 million in debt, and S.&P. said it may cut the company's rating again. Tupperware stopped selling products through the discount retailer Target Corporation in September. Sales at Target had cut attendance at Tupperware parties, where independent representatives have sold the products since the 1950's. ''Sales aren't really growing, and you have margin pressure continuing, so that is clearly a concern,'' an S.&P. analyst, Jean Stout, said in an interview. ''We are concerned about when they are going to be able to stabilize operating margins.''

title: Courts Deal Blow to Bush on Treatment of Terror Suspects
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 — Bush administration tactics in the campaign against terrorism suffered a pair of setbacks today in two federal appeals courts thousands of miles apart.

description: Morgan Stanley said yesterday that its profit rose 42 percent in the fourth quarter, helped by gains in stock and bond trading. The company increased its dividend for the first time since 2001.

title: PHARMACOPEIA TO SPIN OFF DRUG-DISCOVERY BUSINESS
description: Pharmacopeia, which makes software for drug makers and develops compounds for potential medicines, said yesterday that it planned to spin off its drug-discovery business, change its name and move to San Diego. Pharmacopeia, based in Princeton, N.J., wants to distribute ownership in the new company by means of a stock dividend late in the first quarter, the chief financial officer, John J. Hanlon, said. The new company will take Pharmacopeia's name, Mr. Hanlon said. The remaining company will become Accelrys Inc. That business has about 530 employees and had 2002 revenue of $95.1 million. The drug-discovery company will stay in Princeton and have about 170 employees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUTHRIE, PHILIP ALLEN
description: GUTHRIE--Philip Allen, age 53. We mourn the untimely death of Phil, beloved parent with Patricia Chiono of Katherine, adored brother of Elisabeth and Shannon, cherished son of Thomas and the late Jane Guthrie. Phil was an unfailing source of great humor, compassion, devotion and love to countless family members and friends. May his kindness and courage be an inspiration to us all. title: National Briefing | Education: Rice Hires Columbia Dean
description: Rice University in Houston said David W. Leebron, dean of the Columbia University School of Law, would become its president on July 1, succeeding Malcolm Gillis. Mr. Leebron, 48, has been the Columbia law dean since 1996. The law school has 1,300 students and 70 full-time faculty members, and Mr. Leebron has nearly doubled its endowment, to almost $300 million. Rice has almost 5,000 students, including 2,850 undergraduates. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

Cherished grandfather of Alexandra, Vanessa, Jeremy, Charlotte, Spencer, Matthew, Eric, Nicole and Miles. Beloved brother of Frances and Stuart Eichenfield. Services to be held Sunday, 3PM at Gutterman's, Woodbury, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Boys & Girls Clubs of America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITE, SEYMOUR ''STEVE''

Survived by the love of his life Estelle, children Jill, Wendy (Ian), grandchildren Lindsay, Josh (Debbie), Rebecca, and brother Sheldon (Miriam).''Stay Well''

title: Terrorism Drills Showed Lack of Preparedness, Report Says
description: A classified Bush administration report has found that the largest counterterrorism exercise conducted by the federal government since the Sept. 11 attacks was marred by communications problems, serious shortages of medical supplies and hospital rooms and confusion over where the residue of a radiological attack would spread, administration officials said on Thursday.

description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Rodriguez Negotiation 'Is Dead,' the Red Sox Say
description: The draining drama about whether Alex Rodriguez will relocate from the Texas Rangers to the Boston Red Sox took another turn yesterday when the teams failed to complete a trade by the afternoon deadline that had been set by the commissioner. A short time later, it took another detour when Larry Lucchino, the president and chief executive of the Red Sox, said, ''The proposed deal is dead.''

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend on Friday about ''Duet,'' which depicts the actresses Sarah Bernhardt and Eleonora Duse, misstated the given name of an actor who, like them, became a theatrical subject in his own right. He was Henry Irving, not William. The review also misspelled the middle name of the actor who played the male roles. He is Robert Emmet Lunney, not Emmett.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Date Set For Diana Inquest
description: The authorities announced plans to hold an official inquest into the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, who was killed in a car accident in Paris in 1997. The inquest, which will examine how the princess died, will open on Jan. 6 in London but will immediately adjourn for an indeterminate period while officials begin examining 6,000 pages of documents sent from France. Such inquests are matters of routine for all British citizens who have died abroad and whose bodies have been returned to Britain, but this one was delayed because of the long police investigation in Paris. A separate inquest will be held in Surrey into the death of Dodi Al Fayed, who was killed with Diana in the crash. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: When Hanukkah Is in Jeopardy, A Jewish Superman Gets the Call
description: ''The Hebrew Hammer'' is the story of Mordechai Jefferson Carver (Adam Goldberg), a Jew who by the time the opening credits are done has grown from a tubby, victimized young schoolboy into an avenging, street-smart superhero, with a wardrobe and a theme song ripped off from ''Shaft.''

title: In Debate on Antiterrorism, The Courts Assert Themselves
description: The broad presidential powers invoked by the Bush administration after Sept. 11, 2001, to detain suspected terrorists outside the civilian court system is now being challenged by the federal courts, the very branch of the government the White House hoped to circumvent.

title: Waking Up Wellesley Women
description: Julia Roberts, center, plays a fish out of water -- a free-spirited Californian teaching at demure, snooty Wellesley College in 1953 -- in the new film ''Mona Lisa Smile.'' The director, Mike Newell, is a ''master of the feel-good ensemble piece,'' Stephen Holden writes, and the film is ''a star-watcher's guilty pleasure.''

It was Mawae's fifth consecutive selection to the Pro Bowl. The game will be played in Honolulu on Feb. 8.

title: A Memorial That's True to 9/11
description: Like many people touched by 9/11, I'm still mourning the loss of a dear friend who worked on the 106th floor of one of the twin towers. Last year, to honor my friend's memory and those of the thousands of others who died, I created a sculpture titled ''Tumbling Woman,'' a bronze statue of a naked woman in perpetual free fall. If it sounds familiar, that's probably because you remember the fuss it caused. About a week after it was installed at Rockefeller Center, the sculpture was removed. ''Too soon to be seen'' is what I was told as the piece was being draped with a cloth and taken away. Perhaps.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: LITHUANIA: PRESIDENT FACES IMPEACHMENT Impeachment proceedings were begun against President Rolandas Paksas, accused of violating the constitution and his presidential oath and of having links with organized crime. The process was begun with the filing of a petition in the 141-seat Parliament signed by 86 lawmakers. Just 36 signatures were required to initiate the process, and if the issue comes to a vote, Mr. Paksas, 47, a former champion stunt pilot, would be removed if 85 lawmakers vote in favor. A parliamentary committee must now decide whether the charges merit going further. (AP)

title: Deal Saves City $100 Million a Year in Health Costs
description: The Bloomberg administration reached its most important labor agreement to date yesterday, signing an accord on health benefits that achieves $100 million in annual savings through numerous steps, including higher co-payments for doctor visits.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Toothpaste Maker Acquired
description: The Col-gate-Palmolive Company said it had agreed to buy a Swiss toothpaste maker, Gaba Holding A.G., for as much as $830 million. Colgate, based in New York, also forecast a decline in North American sales in the fourth quarter. The company said that the number of units sold would fall for a second consecutive quarter because of lower-than-expected sales in the United States of Simply White, a whitening gel for teeth. Gaba, which makes Meridol toothpaste, has sales of about $300 million in Europe. Colgate will pay from $630 million to $830 million for Gaba, which is based in Therwil, Switzerland. Colgate said the acquisition would reduce its earnings by 3 percent in 2004 and would begin adding to profit by 2006. Its shares fell 6.6 percent.

description: Tehran signed a measure with the United Nations that will allow surprise inspections at its nuclear sites. An International Atomic Energy Agency official said the agency expected Iran to implement the agreement immediately, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: U.S. Negotiating Over Role Of G.I.'s in a Sovereign Iraq
description: The Bush administration has begun delicate negotiations with Iraq's transitional leaders on the freedom American-led military forces will have to carry out operations against insurgents after the transfer of sovereignty to a new government in Baghdad on June 30, officials say.

While they expressed support for the music director, Lorin Maazel, a musician who attended said they had not discussed Mr. Maazel's contract, which expires in 2006.

title: Robert Stanfield, 89, a Tory Who Lost Twice to Trudeau
description: Robert Lorne Stanfield, a onetime standard-bearer for Canada's conservatives who twice lost elections to become prime minister, died on Tuesday in Ottawa. He was 89.

title: Spitzer Files Suit Against 3 Over Spam
description: The attorney general of New York, Eliot Spitzer, filed a civil lawsuit yesterday against three marketing companies, accusing them of sending fraudulent e-mail messages, and said that he would seek penalties so large that they would drive each company out of business.

title: Abused Boy Spurs Advocate To Sue State
description: Connecticut's child advocate, in the first lawsuit she has filed since being appointed in 2000, sued the state's child welfare agency this week, saying it mishandled a boy who was sexually abused as a young child and spent a third of his life shuttled between programs that never helped him.

title: Child's Play: Grade-School Grandmasters Square Off
description: CHRISTOPHER HEUNG arrives a marked boy. Not that he seems aware of it. As he nibbles on the oversize chocolate chip cookie he has started his dinner with, he exhibits no concern about defending his back-to-back national chess championships.

title: F.T.C. RULES AGAINST SCHERING-PLOUGH AND UPSHER-SMITH
description: Schering-Plough and Upsher-Smith Laboratories illegally agreed to keep generic versions of a heart medicine off the market in 1997 and 1998, the Federal Trade Commission decided yesterday. With a 5-0 ruling, the commission reversed an F.T.C. administrative law judge's dismissal of accusations that Schering-Plough unlawfully paid Upsher-Smith $60 million to keep low-cost alternatives to its K-Dur 20 potassium-chloride supplement off the market. Schering-Plough and Upsher-Smith said that the $60 million was paid to settle patent-infringement lawsuits and that there was no proof the agreement delayed competition by generic drugs. Schering-Plough said that it would ask a federal appeals court to review the decision.

title: A Keeper of the Flame Takes the Long View of Romance
description: No singer has been able to capture the balance of hauteur, heartbreak and playfulness that made Mabel Mercer, who perfected the talk-sing style called parlando, a cabaret oracle in the 1950's and 60's. At her best, Mercer, who died in 1984, could transform even the most frivolous ditty into a dramatic monologue infused with the compassion and twinkling merriment of a romantic sage.

title: National Briefing | Washington: More Homeless And Hungry
description: Hunger and homelessness rose in many of the largest cities in the United States this year, a report from the Conference of Mayors said, and officials predicted that such problems would continue next year despite improved economic conditions. The report found that requests for emergency food aid increased 17 percent from last year and that requests for emergency shelter rose 13 percent. Low wages and high housing costs were cited as factors, the report said. John Files (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Diplomats In Second Strike
description: The Foreign Ministry staff went on strike for the second time in a month after talks broke down between their unions and the government. The unions are fighting reductions in living allowances and other perks that will be eliminated in budget cuts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELANO, WILLIAM A.
description: DELANO--William A. died peacefully at home in the early hours of December 15th of renal failure. He was 79. Bill was a veteran of World War II, serving in China. He was a graduate of Yale Law School in 1953, which he attended after two years of volunteer service with the American Friends Service Committee in Berlin, Germany from 1948-50. He was an Associate at Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam and Roberts from 1953-1961. In 1961 when the Peace Corps was formed, Bill worked on the first legislation and became the first General Counsel. He devoted his life to volunteerism, philanthropy, and public service. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Georgia, their four children, Daniel, Peter, Andrew, and Laura, three grandchildren, Bessie, Duncan, and Trinity as well as family and friends all over the world with whom he loved sharing the joy of life in good times and counsel and comfort in bad times. WLYMTTCT & UTTMAB, B! In lieu of flowers his family welcomes donations in Bill's honor to the National Peace Corps Association, 1900 L Street NW, Suite 205, Washington, D.C. 20036-5002, and the Black Alumni of Pratt c/o Dwight Johnson, President, 200 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11025

title: Dean Lays Out a Domestic Plan to Wake Up His Party
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Dec. 18  Howard Dean sketched out an expansive "new social compact for working families" on Thursday but did so in a way that immediately put him at odds with the moderate wing of his party over domestic issues.
