description: Sean Kelly Gallery

title: HUDSON GROUP COMPLETES PURCHASE OF W.H. SMITH STORES
description: The Hudson Group, operator of newsstands at airports, bus stations and train stations, said yesterday that it had completed the purchase of 155 stores in 23 North American airports from W.H. Smith of Britain for $64 million. The purchase includes shops at La Guardia, Kennedy and Newark airports and at airports in Chicago, Los Angeles and Boston, among other cities. Hudson, based in East Rutherford, N.J., said it would convert the shops to Hudson News outlets. W.H. Smith said it sold the outlets, along with its hotel business in the United States, because they were losing money after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, deterred travel.

title: The Rural Life; Quarantine
description: Like half of America, I came down with the flu recently. That means quarantine at the top of the house, in a spare bedroom with a view of the sugar maple and the pasture beyond it, where the horses are standing in falling snow. I was raised to believe that sleep is a sovereign remedy for everything but death itself, so I drift between waking and sleeping, visited mostly by one of the cats, who likes the third floor -- a converted attic -- as much as I do. I wake just long enough to see the snow falling, and to judge how sick I feel, before drifting off again. The pleasure of it -- waking only long enough to know you're dozing -- confirms something one of Ishmael's shipmates said in ''Moby-Dick'': ''Damn me, it's worth a fellow's while to be born into the world, if only to fall right asleep.''

title: Gaffe Aside, China Life Opens Strong In Hong Kong
description: Shares of the China Life Insurance Company jumped 26 percent on Thursday in their first day of trading here, the latest sign of strength in the Hong Kong stock market as China's economy and the local economy prosper.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Comcast Approves Buyback Plan
description: Comcast approved a plan yesterday to buy back as much as $1 billion of common stock after improving operations at the AT&T Broadband business, which it acquired a year ago. Comcast said that it expected cash flow, or operating income before depreciation and amortization, from its cable operations to rise 15 percent to 17 percent in 2004. The company has forecast profit on that basis of $6.3 billion to $6.4 billion in 2003. The buyback plan comes as Comcast has upgraded cable systems to offer more services and has reversed customer losses at the former AT&T unit. Comcast, which is based in Philadelphia, has cut debt about $7 billion since the November 2002 acquisition.

title: U.S. Victims Called Victors In Settlement of French Case
description: Federal authorities praised a $770 million settlement with the French bank Crdit Lyonnais and other parties as a triumph for more than 300,000 policyholders of Executive Life, the insurance company whose collapse precipitated the affair.

description: Anton Kern

title: California Lottery Gets 8 Proposals
description: Eight agencies and agency teams have submitted proposals to take part in a review for the account of the California Lottery Commission.

title: For Giants, There's Still A Season To Finish
description: Thursday's practice was like so many of the past seven years. Jim Fassel barking at his players, pushing and prodding them in preparation for Sunday's game against the Dallas Cowboys. There was little hint that anything had changed in the wake of Fassel's announcement Wednesday that he would step down as coach at season's end.

title: Prudential Data Sought in Inquiry
description: Prudential Financial Inc. said yesterday that the United States attorney in Massachusetts had subpoenaed the company for documents pertaining to the investigation into improper trading of mutual fund shares.

title: CIGARETTE MAKER FOUND PARTLY RESPONSIBLE IN MAN'S DEATH
description: A New York jury said yesterday that Brown & Williamson, the maker of Lucky Strike cigarettes, was partly responsible for a Brooklyn man's death from lung cancer. A six-person jury at New York Supreme Court in Brooklyn said the man, Harry Frankson, who smoked cigarettes for more than 40 years, was 50 percent at fault for his illness, while British American Tobacco, which has operated in the United States as Brown & Williamson, and other defendants held the rest of the blame. The case was brought by Gladys Frankson, Mr. Frankson's widow. The jury will reconvene on Jan. 7 to determine punitive damages. It awarded the plaintiff $350,000 in damages, which will be reduced by half because of the percentage of fault allocated to the plaintiff. The company said it expected the case to be reversed eventually.

title: The Bullpen Picture Is Coming Into Focus
description: The Yankees are nearly finished remodeling their bullpen. They traded Chris Hammond to the Oakland Athletics for two prospects yesterday, clearing the way for them to re-sign another left-hander, Gabe White.

title: Poland Takes Pride In Assertive Stance Toward Neighbors
description: Poland is on the outs with much of Europe these days, but to judge from the defiance of its top officials, opposition leaders and ordinary Poles, that suits people here just fine.

title: U.S. COURTS REJECT DETENTION POLICY IN 2 TERROR CASES
description: A divided federal appeals court in New York ruled yesterday that President Bush lacked the authority to detain indefinitely a United States citizen arrested on American soil on suspicion of terrorism simply by declaring him ''an enemy combatant.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cutbacks In Subway Elevator Operators
description: As protesters chanted slogans, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board approved a 2004 budget yesterday that includes cutting 22 of 50 elevator operators in subway stations in Washington Heights. Residents had been fighting the cutbacks, which affect five stations on the A, 1 and 9 lines, ever since a proposed budget was released in July. Yesterday, more than 30 residents trooped to a podium to speak, while a small group chanted outside, but the $7.97 billion budget passed with little debate. The elimination of the positions at the subway stations, the deepest in the transit system, is expected to save $1.15 million. Transit officials will keep one operator at each station at all times with some elevators going unmanned. The board also decided to use $152 million in surplus funds to prepay a portion of a large deficit expected in 2005. The projected deficit is $688 million, down from $840 million. Michael Luo (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 11 about the Humber School of Creative and Performing Arts, a comedy school in Toronto, credited it erroneously with two distinctions. It is not the only school in the world that offers a diploma in comedy; others include the cole Nationale de l'Humour, in Montreal. And the 1975 film ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' was shot not on what is now the Humber school's campus but at the Oregon State Mental Hospital, in Salem.

title: A Lonely Pair, After More Than One Elusive Goal
description: To describe ''The Butterfly,'' a delicate, visually translucent film, as the heartwarming story of a friendship between a grumpy old man and an 8-year-old girl might suggest that this tender wisp of a movie is the latest icky tearjerker in which a sweet little angel melts the frozen heart of a bitter curmudgeon. But if the French movie, directed by Philippe Muyl, partakes of that formula, its combination of psychological insight and emotional restraint helps it transcend sentimentality.

title: The Padilla Decision
description: In a signal 2-to-1 ruling yesterday, a federal appeals court in Manhattan struck a blow against egregious presidential overreaching in the name of fighting terrorism. The court, ruling in the case of Jose Padilla, the so-called dirty bomber, denied the Bush administration's sweeping claim that the president has executive authority to hold Americans indefinitely in secret without access to lawyers simply by declaring them ''enemy combatants.''

title: Trial of Tyco Ex-Executives Adjourns
description: The fraud trial of Tyco International's former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, and its former chief financial officer, Mark Swartz, adjourned for the holidays yesterday after a former board member, James Pasman, completed his testimony.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Sept. 11 Funds To Be Distributed
description: About 2,800 children who lost parents in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack will each be mailed $1,000 checks as part of a plan to disburse the last $4.1 million in a fund established by Gov. George E. Pataki for families of the victims. In addition to the $2.8 million for the children, about $1.3 million in checks of about $3,000 will be disbursed to 400 to 500 people who were physically injured that day. Michael Marr, a spokesman for the State Department of Taxation and Finance, which administers the New York World Trade Center Relief Fund, said the governor wanted the remaining money distributed in time for the holidays. Altogether, the fund will have distributed $70 million to 5,610 people from 2,678 families, Mr. Marr said, not including the injured people who will be added to the list as they apply. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Two Flawed People, Divided by a House
description: ''House of Sand and Fog,'' adapted from the novel by Andre Dubus III, is one of several recent movies that try to harvest the terror and grandeur of classical tragedy from the everyday sorrows of contemporary American life. In some ways, Vadim Perelman's film, an impressively self-assured directing debut, is more rigorous, or at least more Greek, in its understanding of tragedy than either Clint Eastwood's ''Mystic River'' or Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu's ''21 Grams.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORKER, WALLACE JACOB
description: BORKER--Wallace Jacob. Of Scarsdale, NY died on December 12, 2003 at the age of 84. He is survived by his wife Bettie, son David, granddaughter Marina, and sister Leonora Kurzweil. We will never forget him. A private service was held. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the American Cancer Society.

title: A Brigade Extended, a 2nd Back in Action
description: A brigade of the Army 82nd Airborne Division will remain in Iraq for two months longer than planned, and units from another brigade of the 82nd will go there for four months to fill a gap in combat power during next year's troop rotation, senior officials said Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCEVOY, JAMES
description: McEVOY--James. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James McEvoy, associated with The Times from June 1966 until retiring in February 1996.

title: Doctors Say Bush Has Typical Runner's Knee
description: For years, President Bush's joints seemed to defy the forces of age and time. He ran ever faster miles, instituted a professionally timed race for the White House staff and consulted running experts on improving his speed. But on Thursday, in the complex medical wording of a statement from his medical team, there it was for all to see: Mr. Bush, 57, finally has runner's knee.

title: 2 Yankees And Worker Are Charged In Fight
description: Jeff Nelson, Karim Garcia and a Fenway Park groundskeeper were charged Thursday with assault and battery for their roles in a bullpen fight during Game 3 of the American League Championship Series between the Yankees and the Red Sox.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ESTESS, JENIFER
description: ESTESS--Jenifer. The Columbia University Medical Center faculty, alumni and staff mourn the loss of Ms. Jenifer Estess, founder of Project A.L.S. and a valued friend and supporter of Columbia's A.L.S. research programs. We extend our sincere condolences to her family, especially Valerie and Meredith Estess, who together with their sister founded Project A.L.S. With deepest sympathies. Gerald D. Fischbach, M.D., Executive Vice President for Health and Biomedical Sciences and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University

title: Transfixed by Painful Recollections
description: A VERY skilled, very scary act of seduction is taking place in a red velvet room on West 42nd Street. That's where a whey-faced spellbinder called Lemon has set up camp, amid walls of crimson curtains, on the stage of the Harold Clurman Theater. Lemon has a story she wants to tell you. She thinks it's a wonderful story. You will probably disagree with that, but there's no way you're not going to listen.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toyota Forecasts Growth
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said its global car sales would grow 4 percent in 2004 because of demand in the United States and Japan. Toyota expects to sell 6.33 million cars next year, with sales increasing 5 percent overseas and 2 percent at home. The carmaker will update some of its cars in Japan and may start producing a full-size pickup truck. As part of its strategy to make more cars where they are sold, Toyota expects to increase production 15 percent overseas next year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: British Plan Major 'Wind Farm' To Generate Power Along Coasts
description: Energy companies plan to erect more than 1,000 turbines off England's coast in a $12.4 billion project to build the largest source of wind energy.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ARKANSAS: TIMETABLE FOR CLEANER WATER Arkansas will be allowed 10 years to reduce the flow of phosphorous into the Illinois River basin of Oklahoma under an interstate agreement announced by Gov. Mike Huckabee. Phosphorous runoff from the state's billion-dollar poultry industry and the growth of northwest Arkansas have been blamed for contamination of scenic rivers in Oklahoma. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Doctors' Reports Swayed Hinckley Judge
description: The federal judge who granted John W. Hinckley Jr. unsupervised visits with his parents outside of the psychiatric hospital here where he has lived for 21 years was persuaded by testimony from five doctors who saw ''clinically significant improvement'' in Mr. Hinckley since he shot President Ronald Reagan in 1981.

title: Behind-the-Scenes Technocrat Takes Top Billing at Big Board
description: In tapping John A. Thain, a top Goldman Sachs executive, to restore its tattered image, the New York Stock Exchange is turning to a dispassionate Wall Street technocrat whose manner and methods contrast sharply with the back-slapping approach to running the exchange favored by Richard A. Grasso, its former chairman.

title: Playboy Relics Are a Big Draw
description: A typed manuscript of a Jack Kerouac story, with his handwritten corrections, sold for $71,700 on Wednesday at a Christie's auction of more than 300 letters, pictures and pieces of memorabilia from the archives of Playboy magazine.

title: U.S. Chides France on Effort To Bar Religious Garb in Schools
description: The Bush administration on Thursday gently criticized a French proposal to ban head scarves and other conspicuous religious items from the public schools, saying that such displays constitute ''a basic right that should be protected.''

title: American Executive to Leave the German Bank WestLB
description: Robin Saunders, the American banker who ran a high-risk investment unit at the German bank WestLB, will leave the bank by mutual consent after the unit's losses drew an investigation and led to the resignation of the bank's chief executive last summer.

title: Philadelphia Factory Report Spurs Optimism
description: The economy is enjoying a burst of energy heading into the new year, three reports showed yesterday. A gauge of Philadelphia-area manufacturing soared to the highest level in a decade, the index of leading economic indicators rose and jobless claims matched a nearly three-year low.

title: 'Fine Prints From Six Centuries: Mantegna to Matisse'
description: David Tunick

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITLOCK, GLORIA
description: WHITLOCK--Gloria, 74, of Palm Beach, Florida, died in the morning of December 18th, 2003. Born July 30, 1929, in Buenos Aires, Argentina, she was the only daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leo D. Welch. Her father was the Chairman of Standard Oil of New Jersey, Citibank, Comsat, and an arbitrator between the railroad and Amtrak. Mrs. Whitlock was a graduate of Foxcroft School and Sarah Lawrence College. She was a former Ford Model and avid Bridge player. She was preceded in death by her husband, Emmet Whitlock. She is survived by two daughters, Veronica Whitlock of Old Greenwich, CT, and Valantina Whitlock of Rowayton, CT; three grandchildren, four stepchildren and three step-grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWNER, HARRY M.
description: BROWNER--Harry M., 96, Associate Professor of Political Science and History at Palm Beach Community College; taught economic-geography in NYC; professional photographer; employed by the post office. Born in Brooklyn of immigrant parents, he quickly became his father's interpreter; his father was a builder and he translated Yiddish into English for the other workers. Educated at NYU and Columbia University. A member of the Hillcrest Jewish Center, Hebrew Congregation of Somers, Temple Beth Shalom in Mahopac, and Temple Beth El in Palm Beach, FL. His late wife of 57 years was Lee Carlin Browner. Survived by two daughters and sons-in-law, Eleanor and Bill Greco of Forked River, NJ, and Barbara and Charles Schiller of Yorktown Heights, NY; grandchildren, Laura, Andrew and Zachary.

title: Mourning's Kidney Donor Is a Cousin
description: After dozens of fans came forward to offer Alonzo Mourning a kidney, he found a match in his family. Rod Thorn, the president of the Nets, said on Thursday that Mourning was receiving a kidney from a cousin, who was not identified. Mourning will undergo transplant surgery Friday in New York and will most likely be hospitalized for five to seven days.

title: Sharon's Limited Vision
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel did little to advance the cause of Middle East peace yesterday when he warned the Palestinians that if they did not move to uphold their end of an agreement soon, Israel would act unilaterally. He is right that the Palestinian Authority is required, under the American-sponsored peace plan known as the road map, to dismantle terrorist networks, and has failed to do so. But he is wrong that the plan views that step as a precondition to Israel taking its own painful steps, namely the freezing of Jewish settlement in the West Bank and Gaza Strip and an end to confiscation and demolition of Palestinian homes and property. The sides are to act simultaneously.

title: Andres Serrano -- 'America'
description: Paula Cooper Gallery

title: Game Maker Faces Lawsuit By S.E.C. On Accounting
description: Take-Two Interactive, maker of the hit video game series Grand Theft Auto, disclosed on Thursday that federal regulators plan to file a civil suit against the company, its chairman and two former executives over questionable accounting practices.

title: 6 Hostages Held at Gunpoint, and an Angry Cat to the Rescue
description: The neighbors wondered as they stared through their peepholes. Police officers had stampeded the 10th floor of an apartment building in upper Manhattan on Wednesday night and shot a man who had pointed his gun at them, officials said.

title: Johnny Cunningham, 46, Celtic Fiddler
description: Johnny Cunningham, one of the great Celtic fiddlers of his generation as well as a producer and composer, died on Monday at the apartment of his girlfriend, Trisha McCormick, in New York. He was 46, and had a home in New Bedford, Mass.

title: Dances for Grass and a Dear Departed Dog
description: The Central Station festival of Eastern and Central European dance became unusually international on Dec. 12 at St. Mark's Church when the church's Danspace Project offered works by Zoltan Nagy and Ioana Popovici as part of its Global Exchange series.

title: Start Your Engine
description: For years, aftermarket auto shops have offered devices that attach to the car ignition and start the car remotely with the push of a button. But not every driver wanted an add-on system.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Worker Killed In Butcher Shop
description: An argument in a butcher shop ended in death last night when one worker fatally stabbed another, the police said. Two workers in the shop, on Marcy Avenue in Williamsburg, began to argue about 6:15 p.m., the police said. One of them, an 18-year-old man, stabbed the other, a man in his 20's. The victim, Jose Lewis, was pronounced dead at 6:50 p.m. after he was taken to Woodhull Hospital. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: On TV, Putin Fields the Questions, but Is Himself a Puzzle
description: Surprisingly, President Vladimir V. Putin stumbled a bit over several questions during a well-prepared three-hour television call-in program on Thursday.

title: Three Pianists Create Times For Subduing or Seducing
description: Someone described Thelonious Monk as a jazz musician who happened to be walking by a piano at performance time. That blunt, lurching style was not of the piano or in particular opposition to the piano; it operated in a world of its own. Listening to three classical-music pianists around the city recently made clear that each had his own thoughts on the keyboard as friend, enemy or neutral trading partner.

title: Morning-After Pill
description: To the Editor:

title: Architects Unveil Revised Freedom Tower Design
description: Lower Manhattan is to reclaim its place on the world skyline with a torqued and tapering tower that would dematerialize in its upper reaches before piercing the bottom of the clouds at 1,776 feet.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a march in support of grocery workers in Southern California misstated the number of supermarket chains that are on strike. It is two -- Vons and Pavilions, subsidiaries of Safeway Inc. Union workers at Ralph's Grocery Company, a division of Kroger, and at Albertson's have been locked out.

title: Durst Gets Land to Build Tower Near Times Square
description: Completing an effort begun 36 years ago by his father, the developer Douglas Durst yesterday bought the last of 32 parcels on an entire city block near Times Square, where he intends to build a 50-story skyscraper.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-22

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: New Charges In Arms Plot
description: Hemant Lakhani, a British man who was arrested in August on charges that he plotted to sell shoulder-fired missiles to a man posing as a terrorist, was indicted yesterday on additional federal charges that he offered the would-be terrorist an assortment of weaponry including a dirty bomb and suggested targets and attack plans. The new charges were included in an indictment unveiled by the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie. The indictment describes Mr. Lakhani, 68, as someone capable of putting the missiles, which came from Russian sources, in the hands of terrorist organizations. Mr. Lakhani, who has been held by federal authorities since Aug. 12, will be arraigned in several days, investigators said. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Moyra Davey
description: American Fine Arts

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Diners who admire the pared-down, simple approach to cooking practiced at Craft and Craftbar can find it in a new part of town.

title: Brazil's President, Once a Dark Horse, Describes a Bright Present
description: President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, defending the unpopular pro-market policies he once demonized but which have marked his first year in office, said on Thursday that the sacrifices Brazilians had made this year would be repaid with sustained economic growth.

title: Chief of Sept. 11 Panel Assesses Blame but Holds Off on Higher-Ups
description: The chairman of a federal commission investigating the Sept. 11 terror attacks said on Thursday that information long available to the public showed that the attacks could have been prevented had a group of low- and mid-level government employees at the F.B.I., the immigration service and elsewhere done their jobs properly.

title: After Niagara Falls Punishment, Slowly He Turns, to the Circus
description: Nearly two months after becoming the first known person to survive an intentional plunge over Niagara Falls without any sort of protection, a Michigan man returned to plead guilty and said he planned to live out a more common, and less dangerous, fantasy -- running away to join the circus.

title: Halfway There, A Family Stops to Eat
description: FOR travelers inclined to take the long and winding back roads, there is, perhaps, no greater reward than stumbling upon a ramshackle old roadside restaurant. With little more than a clapboard frame and a colorful sign, the best of them seem to promise to hungry passersby all the most desirable charms: Delicious Food, Local Character, Depression-Era Prices.

title: U.S. Begins Investigation Of Airlines
description: As United Airlines went back to a federal loan board for a second time yesterday, seeking approval for $1.6 billion in loan guarantees, the Justice Department opened an antitrust investigation into United's role in encouraging a hostile takeover bid for a regional carrier it uses on the East Coast.

title: Thomas Kiesewetter
description: Jack Tilton Gallery

title: CITRIX SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY EXPERTCITY FOR $225 MILLION
description: Citrix Systems, which makes software used to share programs over computer networks, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Expertcity for $225 million in cash and stock. Citrix Systems may pay an additional $12 million if certain financial goals are met in 2004, it said. The acquisition of Expertcity will expand Citrix's range of software products, especially those for Web-based desktop access and software used for online training and customer service, the company said.

title: INTERMAGNETICS IS BUYING INVIVO FOR $152 MILLION
description: Intermagnetics General, a maker of components used in magnetic resonance imaging systems, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Invivo Corporation for about $152 million to add monitoring systems for patients undergoing M.R.I. tests. Invivo agreed on the price of $22 a share after turning down an offer of $15 in cash and $4 in Intermagnetics stock as too low last month. Intermagnetics, spun off from General Electric in 1971 and based in Latham, N.Y., plans to add Invivo's monitors to its M.R.I. products. Invivo is based in Pleasanton, Calif., and has about 300 employees. Intermagnetics' largest business is designing and producing superconducting magnets for M.R.I. machines.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 11 about the Humber School of Creative and Performing Arts, a comedy school in Toronto, credited it erroneously with two distinctions. It is not the only school in the world that offers a diploma in comedy; others include the École Nationale de l'Humour, in Montreal. And the 1975 film "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" was shot not on what is now the Humber school's campus but at the Oregon State Mental Hospital, in Salem.

title: McGreevey Is First Governor to Endorse Dean
description: TRENTON, N.J. (AP) -- Democrat James E. McGreevey became the first governor to endorse Howard Dean, saying the former Vermont governor shares his support for middle-class families.

title: Athletes Awarded
description: Shalene Flanagan, a senior at North Carolina from Marblehead, Mass., who won her second straight N.C.A.A. women's cross-country title this year, has been named the outstanding runner in her sport for the second straight year.

title: 2 Youthful Debuts in 'The Nutcracker'
description: The ballerina role of the Sugarplum Fairy in George Balanchine's ''Nutcracker'' has tripped up the occasional guest star at New York City Ballet. Yet it was no surprise that Megan Fairchild, a highly talented 19-year-old corps member, and Joaquin De Luz, a recruit from American Ballet Theater, moved fluently through their debuts as the Fairy and her Cavalier at the New York State Theater on Saturday afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULHEREN, JOHN A., JR.
description: MULHEREN--John A., Jr. A prince among men, John Mulheren's untimely passing is a tragic and sudden loss for many. A visionary of the ''Street,'' I will miss his brilliant mind, but moreover, his large and giving heart. John was devoted not only to many causes, but to his community and loving family. What he did for others remains a lasting testimony to his remarkable character. I was proud to be his friend and partner. It can truly be said that ''only the good die young.'' I extend my deepest sympathies to Nancy and the entire Mulheren family. S. Donald Sussman

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday about a union demonstration outside Chef Solutions bakery in North Haven, Conn., misidentified the people with signs calling for a boycott. They were members of the United Auto Workers, which is seeking to organize workers there. They were not employees of the bakery.

title: A Tuscan Mirage Under the Nevada Sun
description: FORGET about the water canons of Bellagio, the miniature skyscrapers of New York-New York or the indoor canals of the Venetian Resort. Who needs the throbbing lights of Las Vegas when you can drive 30 minutes to an even flashier mirage in the Nevada desert -- one that features a 320-acre artificial lake, swaths of evergreen grass and a piazza created in the image of a Mediterranean fishing village?

title: Fatal Fire Site Had a History Of Violations
description: The fire that killed a 9-year-old girl on Wednesday night erupted in an apartment building that had outstanding code violations, including one concerning fire safety, according to city records. The building, owned by a city police officer, had been cited more than once this year, officials said.

title: Faulty Doors at Kennedy Airport Mar Start of AirTrain
description: Just hours after its high-profile debut, the AirTrain system had to be shut down by the Port Authority for two hours Wednesday night because platform doors failed to open and trapped passengers in their trains.

title: Influenza Spreads to 36 States But Does Not Rise to Epidemic
description: Influenza has become widespread in 12 more states in the last week, bringing the total to 36, with sporadic cases in the remaining states, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said yesterday. But the outbreaks have not reached the level of an epidemic, the centers said.

title: Peeping Phones: Doesn't Privacy Matter?
description: To the Editor:

title: South African Leader Visits Zimbabwe to Urge Talks
description: Under growing pressure over his reluctance to condemn the authoritarian government in Zimbabwe, South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, flew there on Thursday to try to persuade President Robert G. Mugabe to negotiate with the democratic opposition.

title: More Scrutiny Sought For Health Workers
description: Gov. George E. Pataki outlined legislation yesterday that would require stronger background reviews of nurses and other health-care professionals and ensure that medical institutions share full and frank employee records.

title: National Briefing | Politics: Anti-Dean Spots To End
description: The Democratic group running attack advertisements against former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont said its campaign would end, at least for now, this week. The group, Americans for Jobs, Health Care and Progressive Values, said that the campaign was finishing as scheduled and that the cessation had nothing to do with the heavy criticism the spots had drawn. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: Canada Split on Lumber Fight With U.S.
description: For years, Canadian sawmills have waged a battle with their American rivals and Washington over cross-border trade in softwood lumber. In recent weeks, however, the loudest arguments have been among the Canadians themselves over a proposal to end a bitter trade dispute between the United States and Canada.

title: A Team in Full, the Colts Strike a Rare Balance
description: Left unspoken amid the rubble that surrounded Jim Fassel's firing this week was the belief by Fassel and some of his N.F.L. coaching peers that the Giants entered this season with more holes than perceived, that the top of the Giants' 53-man roster appeared solid but that the bottom was weak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASGOW, DOROTHY
description: GLASGOW--Dorothy. On December 18, 2003. Beloved wife of Lloyd. Mother of Donna and Jenny. Grandmother of Byron O'Hanlon. Services are private.

title: Kerry Lends Campaign $850,000 and Plans More
description: Senator John Kerry lent his presidential campaign $850,000 and is borrowing against his home in Boston to obtain more as national polls show him lagging far behind Howard Dean and other rivals in the race for the Democratic nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAUS, IRVING R.
description: KRAUS--Irving R. Beloved husband of Bebe, father of Douglas, Aileen (Missy) and Matthew, father-in-law of Alice Kraus, Jeffrey Cohn, and Jane Kraus, grandfather of Amy, Jonathan, Grace, Hanna and Mason, on December 17, of progressive supranuclear palsy. A funeral service will be held at Temple Beth El, 200 South Bedford Road, Chappaqua, New York at 1:00PM on Sunday, December 21. Shiva at the home of Alice and Douglas Kraus, 311 Whippoorwill Road, Chappaqua, New York, on Sunday December 21, from 4:00PM9:00PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Society for PSP, Woodholme Medical Building, 1838 Greene Tree Road, Suite 515, Baltimore, Maryland 21208, or The Mighty 8th Air Force Museum, 175 Bourne Avenue, Pooler, Georgia 31322. A gentle man of great integrity, we will carry his memory with us always in our hearts.

title: G.I. Slain in Ambush; First Since Hussein Capture
description: An American soldier was shot to death in an ambush in Baghdad on Wednesday night, the military said on Thursday. He was the first soldier to be killed by hostile fire since Saddam Hussein was captured last weekend.

title: Op-Art
Learning to Break the Rules
description: The capture of Saddam Hussein was a much-needed shot in the arm for American intelligence services. President Bush made special mention of our intelligence analysts in his address after the capture. Yet, as a onetime C.I.A. analyst, I think it's important to examine why this mission was so successful. In large part, it was because analysts were allowed to ignore many long-held beliefs about how intelligence is ''supposed'' to work.

title: Comptroller Urges Crackdown On Pushcart Food Monitoring
description: The New York State comptroller warned yesterday that New York City food vendors were not being properly monitored and that complaints, including one about a bagel with roach-tainted cream cheese, languished unchecked for months.

title: Head of Iraqi Arms Search May Be Ready to Step Down
description: David Kay, the head of the effort by the United States to find the banned weapons cited by President Bush as a primary reason for going to war with Iraq, is considering stepping down in the next few months before the group he leads completes its search and issues a final report, government officials said Thursday.

title: The Wonder of Flight
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Baxter International, Deerfield, Ill., the world's biggest maker of treatments for blood diseases, said it had sold its 21 percent stake in Acambis, Britain, a vaccine maker.

title: Tourist sector tries to upgrade its image
description: NICOSIA  Mention Cyprus to most people and the images evoked will typically be of sun, sand and sea. They have served the country well. After 1974, when Turkey's invasion put Kyrenia and Famagusta  the two jewels of Cyprus's tourist crown  beyond reach, new resorts were built up almost from nothing.

title: Residential Real Estate; Improved Economy Cited as Mortgage Delinquencies and Foreclosures Fall
description: Mortgage delinquencies and foreclosures in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have dipped over the last year, as they have across the country, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association -- surprising some market observers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBIN, JERILYN S.
description: RUBIN--Jerilyn S., 61, of Hollywood, FL, died December 17. A beloved and loving mother of Courtney and Diana, daughter of Ruth Fine, and wife of Dr. Eben Rubin. Donations may be made to the National Brain Tumor Foundation, 800-934-2873

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We keep seeing ourselves as a small country. In fact, Poland is a big country. We are half of what is joining Europe in terms of population. We should have the responsibilities that come with being a big country.''

title: NASA Releases Rare Pictures From a Fourth Space Observatory
description: Humanity's vision of the universe became clearer on Thursday when NASA declared the last of its Great Observatories operational and released extraordinary images of cool, distant objects.

title: A Constant and the Variables at Goldman
description: John A. Thain's impending departure to run the New York Stock Exchange will leave the Goldman Sachs Group coping with the most sweeping change in its management ranks since it became a public company in 1999.

title: U.S. Moves to Deny Benefits to 2 Ex-Freddie Mac Officials
description: Federal regulators took a step yesterday toward forcing two top former Freddie Mac executives to forfeit millions of dollars in benefits, asserting that they should not receive severance and bonuses because they played a role in improper manipulation of the company's earnings.

title: Michaels Ready to Introduce His Voice to Another Game
description: You never sense that Al Michaels worries that he will be subpar on the air. He is never completely satisfied with his work, but he would have no reason to doubt himself. Through 18 years at ABC's ''Monday Night Football,'' he has been a superb and dominant play-by-play voice.

description: When Jim Fassel pushed for the announcement of his firing as Giants coach on Wednesday, two weeks before the end of the regular season, he said he wanted to give the organization a head start on finding a new coach. But how much of an advantage the Giants gain is hard to measure.

title: Swimming Beneath a Waterfall of Pirouettes and Lifts
description: Steps pour out like lava in ''Bounty Verses,'' Dwight Rhoden's new work for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and the final premiere of the company's City Center season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LTON, SHIRLEY BARON
description: LTON--Shirley Baron, born in New York, but longtime resident of Durham, North Carolina. Wife of Joel, mother of Valerie & Kenneth, and grandmother of five. A Memorial service January 10, 2004, in Durham, NC.

title: Divergent Sounds From 2 Currents in the Mainstream
description: As far apart as their styles are, Karrin Allyson and Luciana Souza both exemplify mainstream jazz singing at this moment; they're separate points along the spectrum. Ms. Allyson's roots are in the Midwest, and in a nonchalant vision of jazz that allows it to share space with folk and blues and pop; Ms. Souza's roots are in Brazil, and her kind of jazz song is a specialized form with delicate harmonies and arrangements. Their double bill at Zankel Hall on Wednesday night looked awkward on paper but worked neatly in practice.

description: On the day after they spoke blunt and even bitter words, many of the Knicks were saying the right things in a tone as melodic as Muzak.

description: Matthew Marks Gallery

title: An Artist's Span, Austere to Extravagant
description: ANYONE who is interested in the art of the last 30 years -- or the next 30 -- should see the excellent, long overdue survey of Joan Jonas's work at the Queens Museum of Art. Its revelations are almost guaranteed to knock you sockless. Ms. Jonas is now in her mid-60's, but her lushly innovative multimedia installations could not be more pertinent to the present. Also germane: she was multicultural before it became fashionable.

title: More Ghosts Than Originally Planned
description: The ghosts are out in force for ''Rose's Dilemma,'' the transparent comedy by Neil Simon that opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club. While ectoplasm might seem appropriate for a show about a woman's sexually active relationship with the specter of her dead lover, ''Rose's Dilemma'' is haunted in ways that its creators surely never dreamed of.

title: Dr. Judd Marmor, 93, Dies; Led Change in View of Gays
description: Dr. Judd Marmor, a psychiatrist who was influential in having homosexuality removed from the American Psychiatric Association's official list of clinical disorders, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles, his son, Dr. Michael F. Marmor, said. He was 93.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Enforcement Lacking, Report Says
description: State environmental regulators are too willing to postpone enforcement action, a performance review by the state auditor said. The report said the voluntary compliance policy of the State Commission on Environmental Quality delayed, by an average 76 days, notice to offenders that a civil penalty had been imposed. A commission spokesman called the $570,000 in overdue penalties the auditor cited insignificant but said the agency would study the report. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Annan Seeks January Talks On Return of U.N. to Iraq
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said Thursday he was seeking a meeting next month with members of the Iraqi Governing Council and representatives of the United States-led occupation authority to determine whether the United Nations' return to Baghdad can be accelerated.

description: To the Editor:

description: A New Home For a Balthus

title: To Keep Her Allure, Aphrodite Changed With the Times
description: Aphrodite, the Greek goddess of beauty, love and desire, was said by the Greek poet Hesiod to have been born in the sea, from foam that arose at the place where the genitals of Uranus, first ruler of the universe (but no Mr. Nice Guy), fell after castration by his son Cronus. She landed on the island of Cyprus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, RICHARD
description: SOLOMON--Richard, on December 18, 2003. Beloved husband of Myra. Father of Debra and Philip. Loving stepfather of Sydra and Karlin. Dear brother of Alice Gertzog. Adoring grandfather of Leah and Henry. Service Friday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Rusizi National Park Journal; A Crocodile Satisfies a Yen for Men (as Food, That Is)
description: There is a large empty enclosure set up by the edge of the Rusizi River here, one that the Burundian authorities hope will one day lure tourists to this part of central Africa.

title: A Country's Most Authentic Art Is Often Its Best Ambassador
description: Japan has been much with us of late, given films like ''Lost in Translation,'' Sofia Coppola's muted meditation on gaps between cultures and people, and ''The Last Samurai,'' the Tom Cruise vehicle that treats cultural differences on a rather grander scale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOWENSTEIN, JULIUS
description: LOWENSTEIN -- Julius. We extend our sincerest condolences to Ruth Lowenstein and her daughters, Marilyn and Vivian, on the passing of her beloved husband and their father. As a Golden Founder and supporter of the Department of Cardiology, together with his wife, his outstretched hand of kindness made an invaluable contribution to the people of Jerusalem and Israel. May Ruth, her grandchildren, great grandchildren and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Sidney Adler, Treasurer Lee Weinbach, Pres. Nat'l Women's Div. Paul S. Glasser, Nat'l Dir.

title: Ticket Sales For 3rd 'Rings' Set Record
description: ''The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King,'' the final installment in the trilogy based on J. R. R. Tolkien's books, broke opening-day box office records around the world on Wednesday, raking in $34.1 million in the United States and a total of $23.5 million in 19 other countries.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Wal-Mart Offers Online Music
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer and a top seller of compact discs, began offering music yesterday for customers to download from its Web site for 88 cents a song, a price that undercuts those of online competitors like Apple Computer's iTunes Music Store. Wal-Mart, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., said it planned to gather customer feedback from the site in the next few months, make changes, and ''officially launch the service'' next spring. The service, called Music Downloads, is available at www.walmart.com. Competitors, including iTunes and Napster, offer song downloads for 99 cents. The move mimics Wal-Mart's entry into the business of renting DVD's by mail, when it cut prices to draw customers away from rivals like Netflix. Wal-Mart is seeking a foothold in online music as downloading is blamed for the declining sales of CD's. Global music sales fell 11 percent, to $12.7 billion, in the first half of this year, after declining 7 percent last year and 6 percent in 2001, according to the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry, a trade group. Shares of Wal-Mart rose 70 cents, to $52.60. The market for legally downloaded music will be $35 million this year, a fraction of annual music sales, said David Card, an analyst at Jupiter Research, a technology research firm. He estimates that online music sales will increase to more than $100 million next year and approach $700 million by 2008.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ULRICH, MAX M.
description: ULRICH--Max M. A celebratory service will be held at the Anthony R. Pizzi Funeral Home, Northvale, N.J. Saturday, December 20 at 10AM. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Nyack Hospital Foundation, 160 North Midland Avenue, Nyack, N.Y. 10960 or the South Orangetown Volunteer Ambulance Corps, Tappan, N.Y.

title: Telling It Right
description: ''This is a very, very important part of history, and we've got to tell it right.'' So says Thomas Kean, chairman of the independent commission investigating the 9/11 attacks. Mr. Kean promises major revelations in testimony next month: ''This was not something that had to happen.'' We'll see: maybe those of us who expected the 9/11 commission to produce yet another whitewash were wrong. Meanwhile, one can only echo his sentiment: it's important to tell our history right, not just about the events that led up to 9/11, but about the events that followed.

title: Group Says at Least $6 Billion More Is Needed to Fix New York Schools
description: Satisfying a court mandate to offer children ''a sound, basic education'' will cost New York State at least an extra $6 billion over three to four years, the plaintiffs in the case said yesterday.

title: U.S. to Steer Ex-Arms Experts to Peaceful Jobs
description: The State Department said Thursday that it was starting a two-year program that could spend some $22 million to help provide several hundred former Iraqi weapons scientists and technicians with nonmilitary jobs in a post-Saddam Hussein Iraq to prevent them from working for countries of concern or for terrorist groups.

title: U.S. Warns Israel Against Steps That Harm Peace Plan
description: The Bush administration, responding coolly to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's announcement of a possible ''disengagement plan'' in the West Bank, warned Israel on Thursday against taking unilateral steps that effectively abandoned the American-sponsored peace plan, called the road map, which would establish a Palestinian state.

title: Books at the Top: Guilty Pleasures
description: In the introduction to his latest biblical thriller, Tim LaHaye announces, '' 'Babylon Rising' is my newest attempt to create another uniquely satisfying combination of suspense and substance.'' Not content to let others do the back-patting, Dr. LaHaye also expresses the hope that this is ''a real page-turning series that manages to be both a totally absorbing story and extremely relevant to our times.''

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Paid But Jobless
description: Argentina's jobless rate is falling in part because the government is paying people like Paulino Villalba to stay off the rolls of unemployed. ''I wish I could say I have a job,'' Mr. Villalba, 42, a former systems technician for the BellSouth Corporation's Argentine unit, said during a demonstration by unemployed people in Buenos Aires last week. President Nestor Kirchner's government says the 150 pesos ($51) it gives Mr. Villalba each month is the equivalent of collecting a paycheck for a job. Mr. Villalba, who has been out of work for two years, has received the payments for about six months. Such handouts helped drive down the jobless rate to a four-year low of 14.3 percent in the third quarter from a record 21.5 percent in May 2002, the government said yesterday. Argentina's actual unemployment rate, counting those receiving government handouts, is still above 16 percent, said Pablo Morra, an economist at Goldman Sachs & Company in New York.

title: Having Fun With an Unhappy Marriage
description: What is it about the Opera Orchestra of New York? On one level, the performance of Donizetti's ``Anna Bolena'' that they offered on Dec. 14 at Carnegie Hall was kind of a mess: riddled with bloody cuts, the orchestra leaden, some of the performers approximate about things like hitting their pitches. And yet it was also kind of fun, and some of the performances shaped up into things one was happy to hear. Altogether even the Grinchiest among us came away with some degree of pleasure.

title: Mets Not Done, Even With Cameron
description: As Mike Cameron rotated from one television interview to another, with Shea Stadium's field as a backdrop beyond the Diamond Club windows, Jim Duquette addressed a crowd of reporters yesterday near a small stage. Duquette, the Mets' general manager, had little time to boast about how Cameron completed the team's defense.

title: Dunham Continues His Domination of Islanders
description: On Wednesday, Rangers Coach Glen Sather said he wished his No. 1 goaltender, Mike Dunham, would start playing ''the way he was playing in the first 20 games.''

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Tuesday about ''The Return of the King'' misstated a line of dialogue that was cited as an example of the movie's mournful tone. In it, the character Gandalf says: ''There never was much hope. Just a fool's hope'' -- not ''a false hope.''

title: Halfway Home
description: ON the back roads of one family's life, a roadside restaurant has come to mean more than just a meal. Three generations, traveling between upstate New York and central Pennsylvania, have stopped at Red's & Trudy's in Portville, N.Y. Page 7.

title: Thorn Attempts to Divert the Blame From Kidd and Scott
description: Rod Thorn carved his reputation with the Nets by hiring a head coach who had only two years' experience as an assistant and by trading for a point guard who had made numerous enemies with his previous teams.

title: RealNetworks Accuses Microsoft Of Restricting Competition
description: RealNetworks filed a $1 billion antitrust lawsuit on Thursday accusing Microsoft of using its monopoly power to restrict competition and limit consumer choice in digital media markets.

description: A federal report says prison workers in Brooklyn abused illegal immigrants arrested after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Page A32.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHITEL, JOAN
description: CHITEL--Joan. On December 17, 2003. Beloved wife of Bob. Devoted mother of David and Douglas and mother-inlaw of Cristina. Loving daughter of Dr. Joseph Ormand and the late Estelle Ormand. Dear sister of Kenneth, Richard and Diane Ormand. Services Friday, 12:45PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to The Carcinoid Cancer Foundation, Inc., 333 Mamaroneck Ave., Suite 492, White Plains, NY 10605.

title: Lined Up at the Door to Hear Messiaen at His Most Intricate
description: Olivier Messiaen, who died in 1992, would have been gratified and, I suspect, rather amazed to see the line of people at the Carnegie Hall box office on Monday night. They were hoping to get last-minute returned tickets to the sold-out recital by the pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard downstairs at Zankel Hall, a program devoted to Messiaen's complete ''Vingt regards sur l'Enfant-Jsus,'' more than two hours of some of the most complex, difficult and visionary music ever written for the piano. Though Messiaen conceived the 1944 work as an integrated suite of 20 pieces, he did not expect that it would be performed complete very often, let alone become a hot ticket in New York.

title: Going Off Road, Two by Two
description: TYRONE VIAS had never even been in an S.U.V., much less driven one off road. Nonetheless, a recent Saturday afternoon found him behind the wheel of a Land Rover Discovery, driving over rural trails studded with logs, boulders and turnover-threatening dips. It was all part of his birthday present from his fiance, Debbie Hummel: a couple's weekend at the Equinox Inn, in Manchester, Vt., including a special lesson in off-road driving. ''He was thrilled at the prospect,'' said Ms. Hummel, like Mr. Vias a social worker in New York City. ''And it was an escape from the city's craziness to stay at an inn.''

title: Returning to Danger, Desire to Serve Unquenched
description: BUT for a security alert in Kabul, where Afghans are struggling to hammer out a constitution, Barry Rosen would once again be leaving his family behind and putting himself in harm's way, all for the love of a region, a language, a literature and a religion that have captivated him for half his lifetime.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Asset Sales
description: The French government plans to sell 20 percent of toll-road operators Societe des Autoroutes du Nord et de l'Est de la France and Societe des Autoroutes Paris-Rhin- Rhone in 2004 to help finance infrastructure investments through 2012. France has been accelerating asset sales as its 56-billion-euro budget deficit ($69 billion) continues to breach European Union rules. The government raised 3.3 billion euros by selling shares in companies including Renault and Thomson this year. Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin said the government would keep its 50.3 percent holding in Autoroutes du Sud de la France, Europe's second-largest operator of toll highways. Vinci, the construction company, owns 18 percent of Autoroutes du Sud and has said it wants control.

description: Lottery Numbers

description: An article on Wednesday about a rookie firefighter who died in a warehouse fire misidentified the equipment that was knocked from his face. It was a self-contained breathing apparatus using compressed air, not an oxygen mask.

description: There are no planes behind the mammoth locked doors of Hangar 17 at Kennedy International Airport. Instead, it hides history.

description: Howard Dean sketched out an expansive ''new social compact for working families'' on Thursday but did so in a way that immediately put him at odds with the moderate wing of his party over domestic issues.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

description: The following is the text of Prime Minister Tony Blair's statement on Libya dismantling its weapons program as transcribed by e-Media, Inc.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Salesforce.Com Files For Public Offering
description: Salesforce.com has registered for an initial public offering of up to $115 million in common stock, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, based in San Francisco, is a host for applications that permit organizations to share customer information. Details about the number of shares to be offered and the estimated price range were not disclosed in the filing. Salesforce said it expected to use the net proceeds for general corporate purposes, including working capital and capital expenditures. It also may use a portion to finance investments or acquisitions, the filing said. Morgan Stanley, Deutsche Bank Securities, UBS Investment Bank, Wachovia Securities and William Blair & Company were listed as underwriters for the offering.

title: Cameras as Accomplices, Helping Race Divide America Against Itself
description: The problem of ''the color line'' was the American problem of the 20th century, according to W. E. B. DuBois. It is still a problem in the early 21st century, though few people are saying this in so many words. The International Center of Photography is saying it, with almost no words at all, in ''Only Skin Deep: Changing Visions of the American Self,'' a big, unwieldy group exhibition that has rumbled in just under the 2003 wire and turns out to be one of the most ambitious and stimulating shows of the year.

title: McGreevey Is First Governor to Endorse Dean
description: TRENTON, N.J. (AP) -- Democrat James E. McGreevey became the first governor to endorse Howard Dean, saying the former Vermont governor shares his support for middle-class families.

title: Clark Testimony Links Milosevic Directly to '95 Massacre
description: The former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, had advance knowledge of the plan to massacre Muslims in the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in 1995, Gen. Wesley K. Clark testified before the international tribunal in The Hague, according to a transcript released Thursday.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Windsor Locks: Charges In Triple Homicide
description: Two men have been charged and a third was arrested in connection with a triple homicide on July 30 at a Windsor Locks automotive repair shop. Erik Martinez, 21, of Hartford and Michael Castillo, 19, of East Hartford were each charged with three counts of murder, two counts of capital felony murder and conspiracy to commit murder, said Sgt. Paul Vance, a spokesman for the Connecticut State Police, the arresting agency. A third man, Jose Guzman, 22, of Orlando, Fla., is being held in Florida and will face the same charges upon extradition, the police said. Two of the victims, Robert Stears, 42, of Enfield and Barry Rossi, 43, of Suffield, were owners of the shop, B & B Automotive. The third victim, Lorne Stevens, 38, of Suffield was a mechanic there. Sources said a murder-for-hire scheme was behind the killings. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: A Law To Thwart A Basque Plan
description: Parliament approved a law that makes it a criminal offense to hold a referendum not sanctioned by Madrid. The leader of the Basque regional government is pursuing a referendum on greater independence. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Coke's North American Unit Loses Chief Amid Slow Growth
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that Jeffery T. Dunn, the president and chief operating officer of Coke's North American division, is leaving to pursue ''his own entrepreneurial goals.'' Steven J. Heyer, the Coca-Cola Company president and chief operating officer, will assume Mr. Dunn's responsibilities immediately, the company said.

title: Bush Says Libya Will Allow Arms Inspections
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 - President Bush announced today that Libya, which for decades has been estranged from the United States, had agreed to forsake weapons of mass destruction and to allow weapons inspectors from international organizations into the country.

description: Events

title: Creeping 1953 Feminism, Without Quite Dispelling Dreams of Prince Charming
description: ''You can bake your cake and eat it too!'' says the reassuring slogan that distills the comfy revisionist feminism informing ''Mona Lisa Smile.'' That slogan is repeated empathically enough to qualify as the defining mantra of a movie that pretends to be audacious. And the lurking duplicity in that loaded word ''bake'' (remember Hillary Rodham Clinton's sarcastic remarks about baking cookies?) winds up applying to the movie itself. Like ''Down With Love'' earlier this year, ''Mona Lisa Smile'' preaches disruptive female self-empowerment out of one side of its mouth while out of the other it invokes the dream of being swept up, up and away by Prince Charming.

description: Michael Jackson Charged With Molesting a Child

description: Israel will impose a security plan that will separate Israelis and Palestinians if the Palestinians fail to move quickly toward a negotiated peace, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said here in a speech on Thursday.

title: Families Speak as Green River Killer Gets 48 Life Terms
description: After hearing three hours of emotional monologues from the families of some of the 48 young women he murdered, Gary L. Ridgway stood in court on Thursday and read a meek apology from a yellow legal pad.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Suit Over Treatment Of Juveniles
description: The Justice Department has sued the state, contending that juveniles at two detention centers were routinely abused by staff members and that state officials had done too little to remedy the situation. Youths at the Oakley and Columbia Training Schools were commonly struck, shackled to poles and sometimes subjected to pepper spray while in restraints, the lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court at Jackson, said. The department said negotiations with the state to improve treatment of the juveniles had been unsuccessful. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Chevrolet greets the new year with an ambitious campaign to introduce 10 vehicles in 20 months.
description: WITH 10 new vehicles coming to the market over the next 20 months, Chevrolet knew its advertising would have to depart significantly from what had been done in the recent past. There would need to be less attention paid to lifestyle and feeling good and more to its new cars and trucks.

title: New Jersey Governor Endorses Dean
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey delivered a rousing endorsement today of the Democratic presidential candidate Howard Dean at a packed meeting of at least 500 people in a Trenton hotel.

title: Medicare Chief Joins Firm With Health Clients
description: Thomas A. Scully, the official who ran Medicare and Medicaid for the last two and a half years, announced on Thursday that he was joining Alston & Bird, a law firm based in Atlanta that represents many hospitals, drug manufacturers and other companies in the health care industry.

title: Nurse Accused in One Death Is Named Suspect in Another
description: The district attorney in Northampton County, Pa., named Charles Cullen on Thursday as a suspect in the death of a 78-year-old patient whose end may have been hastened by an overdose of the same heart medication that Mr. Cullen is accused of using to kill a New Jersey priest last June.

title: Notre Dame TV Deal
description: NBC Sports, whose current deal to carry Notre Dame home football games runs two more seasons, extended it yesterday through 2010. The rights fee is believed to remain at about $9 million a year.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Polytechnic President To Step Down
description: Polytechnic University in Brooklyn announced this week that Dr. David C. Chang would step down as president in June 2005, after 11 years in the post. He will become a professor of electrical engineering and will serve as chancellor until June 2008. Under Dr. Chang, 62, the university raised $275 million in a capital campaign, including $175 million left by a former professor, Donald Othmer, and his wife, Mildred. Polytechnic used some of the money to expand its campus at the MetroTech Center. But when enrollment fell to 3,300 from 3,500, the university had to make cuts. The endowment is now about $120 million, up from $13 million when Dr. Chang became president. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Bushs Remarks on Arms Agreement With Libya
description: The following is the text of President Bush's statement on Libya dismantling its weapons program as transcribed by Federal News Service. PRESIDENT BUSH: Good evening. I've called you here to -- today to announce a development of great importance in our continuing effort to prevent the spread of weapons of mass destruction.

title: President Will Retire At Marketing Group
description: H. Robert Wientzen, president and chief executive of the Direct Marketing Association in New York, will retire in July, the association said. A successor is being sought.

Box 231485, New York, NY 10023.

description: The Kremlin announced Thursday night that Russia would join negotiations to reduce Iraq's crushing foreign debt but emphasized that the talks would have to address the interests of Russian companies that signed contracts with the former Iraqi government.

description: CHESAPEAKE, Va., Dec. 19 — The jury in the case of convicted sniper Lee Malvo, which now has to consider whether he should be executed, heard emotional testimony today from relatives of people who were slain by Mr. Malvo and his partner.

title: Former Employees Say Nassau County Misused Housing Funds
description: Two former high-ranking Nassau County employees are suing the county and its executive, saying they were fired for raising concerns that the county was misspending federal money earmarked for urban development projects in poor neighborhoods.

title: Mining the Gold In Gay Nuptials
description: THERE may be plenty of people excited about the prospect of legalized gay marriage in Massachusetts, but Canadian tourism officials are probably not among them. That is because the provinces of Ontario and British Columbia, where same-sex marriage has been legal since the summer, have been doing brisk business, attracting gays and lesbians from the United States who want to tie the knot.

title: The Neediest Cases; Still Holding the Fort After Half a Century, With a Little Help
description: In 1950, Kate Ella Jones boarded a Greyhound bus in Richmond, Va., with her sights set on New York because, she says, she thought ''it would be a nice place to stay.'' And stay is exactly what Ms. Jones did -- in the same neighborhood in Far Rockaway, Queens, where she later raised her only child.

title: Boy Tries to Sneak Loaded Gun Into School in Bronx, Police Say
description: A 15-year-old boy tried to sneak a loaded 9-millimeter handgun into Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the Bronx yesterday morning, but was intercepted by a school safety agent, officials said.

title: Venezuela Tries to Lure Oil Investors
description: Outside this coastal city, just north of Venezuela's richest oil and gas fields, storage tanks brim with petroleum products, a network of pipelines hum with crude, and tankers load at the rate of 18,000 barrels an hour.

title: Vitamin Maker Agrees to Deal On Price Lawsuit
description: One of about two dozen vitamin manufacturers that are fighting accusations of price fixing made in a lawsuit by foreign purchasers has reached a settlement and is cooperating with the plaintiffs, a lawyer in the case said yesterday.

title: Greetings from Vanuabalavu!
description: JUST after Thanksgiving, the first holiday card arrived. Inside the thick creamy envelope was a glossy color photograph with five smiling faces beneath scuba masks and snorkels. The picture was shot underwater, with tropical fish swimming through coral reefs in a brilliant blue lagoon. Hawaii? The Caribbean? ''Galpagos Islands, 2003,'' read the hand-inked inscription.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Jobless Rate Falls
description: The unemployment rate in New York City dropped below 8 percent for the first time this year, as the city continued to see a modest increase in private-sector jobs, new state and city reports said. The unemployment rate dropped to 7.7 percent in November, compared with 8.8 percent two months earlier. Year over year, total private-sector employment is still down slightly in New York City compared with November 2002. But for the third straight month, the city had a seasonally adjusted increase in private-sector jobs, totaling now 11,800 since August, according to the City Office of Management and Budget. Of that total, 900 jobs were added in November. The pace of the recovery in the city is slower than in most of the rest of the state and in the nation. But the trends are pointing toward a recovery, state and city officials said. Eric Lipton (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOUTSCH, ENRIQUE H., M.D.
description: LOUTSCH--Enrique H., M.D. of Manhattan, died on December 15, 2003, of pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his wife, Cynthia Curran, a son, Johannes of Cos Cob, CT, a daughter Karen Gironda of Harrison, NY, and two grandsons, Nicholas and Conrad Gironda. Certified by the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology in 1969, Dr. Loutsch was a psychiatrist in private practice for over 30 years. He was a Fellow of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis and a member of the American Psychiatric Association. During the early years of his career he was a supervising analyst and lecturer at the Post Graduate Center for Mental Health. He was an accomplished marathon runner and a devotee of the arts. Dr. Loutsch will be remembered by all whose lives he touched, for his wisdom, intellect and wit. A memorial service will be held Friday, January 16, at 11:00AM, at St. James Episcopal Church on Madison Avenue at 71st Street, Manhattan. Donations in Dr. Loutsch's memory may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Pancreatic Cancer Research Center, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087 or to The Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th Street, New York, NY 10022.

title: Charitable Motives for a Racy Calendar, if Racy Is Still the Appropriate Word
description: ''Calendar Girls'' is not nearly as mortifying as one of the most recent films to use the phrase ''based on a true story'' -- this fall's remake of ''The Texas Chainsaw Massacre'' -- though the real-life story of ''Girls'' is particularly horrifying to at least one person: 16-year-old Jem (John-Paul MacLeod). Learning that his mother, Chris (Helen Mirren); her best chum, Annie (Julie Walters); and all of her middle-aged to elderly female friends are going to pose nude on a calendar to raise money for a local charity is a terrifying prospect for the boy.

title: Some Democrats Uneasy About Dean as Nominee
description: Many leading Democrats say they are uneasy about Howard Dean's candidacy for president and are reluctant to cede him the nomination for fear that his combative style and antiwar stance will leave Democrats vulnerable in November.

title: Change The Channel
description: Saddam is now a staple of the Leno and Letterman shows.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Getting Festive With Physics

title: On Schoenberg's Route to the Promised Land
description: It's safe to say that when the Metropolitan Opera presented its premiere production of Arnold Schoenberg's thorny opera ''Moses und Aron'' in February 1999 the company was not responding to a groundswell of public demand for a staging of the work. Rather it was James Levine's passionate belief in the opera that led the Met to present it. Mr. Levine's conviction was vindicated, though, for the production and performance were major successes, a starkly modern yet poignantly human staging by the director Graham Vick of an uncompromising and visionary opera.

title: U.S. Administrator Escaped Ambush in Iraq Two Weeks Ago
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 19  L. Paul Bremer III, the top American official in Iraq, said today that a convoy he was traveling in two weeks ago had been attacked. Neither he nor anyone else in the convoy, traveling in Baghdad, was hurt.
