title: U.S. Courts Reject Detention Policy in 2 Terror Cases
description: Adivided federal appeals court in New York ruled yesterday that President Bush lacked the authority to detain indefinitely a United States citizen arrested on American soil on suspicion of terrorism simply by declaring him "an enemy combatant."

title: Regulators Issue First Citation For Violation of No-Call Law
description: Federal regulators said yesterday that they had issued the first citation for violations of the national do-not-call list.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   URETSKY, JULIA
description: URETSKY -- Julia. Beloved wife of the late Max. Loving mother of Louis (Laura), Henry (Donnie), and Steve (Joyce Tuepker). Cherished grandmother of Chad, Jody, Michelle, Max and Al. Devoted sister of Harry (Pearl) Klein. Graveside services today, 1PM, at Wellwood Cemetery. For information call Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 718-377-7300.

title: Devils Restore Prowess On Defense in Shutout
description: It was exactly the kind of performance one would expect from the Devils and Martin Brodeur after a loss. Two nights after allowing an uncharacteristic five goals to the Islanders, the Devils were back on their game with a vengeance in a 3-0 victory Thursday night over the Atlanta Thrashers.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Rises
description: An index of confidence in the German economy rose this month to its highest level in almost three years. The index, which is compiled by the Ifo Institute and measures the economic outlook among business executives, rose to 96.8 from 95.7 in November, its eighth consecutive monthly increase. The assessment of the current business climate rose only slightly, but the rating for future expectations was at a nine-year high, Ifo said. The president of the organization, Hans-Werner Sinn, said the report showed that ''the economic recovery has set in and is gaining strength.'' Petra Kappl. (NYT)

title: Jackson Is Formally Charged With Child Molesting
description: Santa Barbara authorities formally charged Michael Jackson on Thursday with seven counts of child molesting involving a boy who was an overnight guest at Mr. Jackson's Neverland ranch outside of Santa Barbara in February and March.

title: Record Industry May Not Subpoena Online Providers
description: The recording industry cannot compel an Internet service provider to give up the names of customers who trade music online without judicial review, a federal appeals court in Washington ruled today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about Msgr. Charles M. Kavanagh, a prominent New York priest who was suspended in 2002 after an allegation of sexual abuse that he denies, omitted an explanation of his attire. Under the terms of his suspension, Monsignor Kavanagh is barred from publicly presenting himself as a priest. As the article noted, he did not wear his clerical collar during the interview. Later, when photographed at the offices of St. Raymond Community Outreach in the Bronx, he wore the collar.

title: Boston Indoor Games
description: Haile Gebrselassie, the 30-year-old Ethiopian distance runner who has won two Olympic gold medals and nine world championships, will run in the Boston Indoor Games on Jan. 31. Meet officials said yesterday that they expected him to run in the 3,000 meters, the event's longest race.

title: From Tiger Man to Sharp-Dressed Man for His Day in Court
description: Antoine Yates, the person who has come to be known as Tiger Man for housing his 400-pound Bengal tiger in a Harlem apartment, showed up at Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday in high style.

title: Alliance Settles Fund Trading Complaints
description: Alliance Capital Management, one of the nation's biggest investment firms, submitted to extraordinary oversight yesterday as well as substantial payments to settle complaints that it permitted some hedge funds and others to make improper trades in its funds.

title: Parmalat on Edge as Bank Says It Doesnt Have $4.9 Billion
description: PARMA, Italy, Dec. 19 — Parmalat, the Italian dairy and food giant, slid to the brink of insolvency on Friday after the company disclosed that a bank account that supposedly held nearly $5 billion of its money did not exist.

title: Detainees' Abuse Is Detailed
description: A report released yesterday by the Department of Justice's inspector general concluded that at one federal prison in Brooklyn, some staff members physically abused many illegal immigrants arrested after the Sept. 11 attacks, taunted them and illegally taped their meetings with lawyers.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Timetable For Cleaner Water
description: Arkansas will be allowed 10 years to reduce the flow of phosphorous into the Illinois River basin of Oklahoma under an interstate agreement announced by Gov. Mike Huckabee. Phosphorous runoff from the state's billion-dollar poultry industry and the growth of northwest Arkansas have been blamed for contamination of scenic rivers in Oklahoma. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: 2ND SNIPER FOUND GUILTY IN VIRGINIA
description: A jury convicted Lee Malvo of two counts of capital murder on Thursday. The jurors found that he pulled the trigger in the fatal sniper shooting of an F.B.I. analyst and rejected his argument that he was insane in the weeks that he and John A. Muhammad terrorized the Washington region last fall.

title: Apparent Need Of a Quorum For Mourning
description: BY midday yesterday, 15 floral wreaths and bouquets and a dozen or so votive candles had been laid by the closed doors of Ladder Company 36, on Vermilyea Avenue in Inwood. All the wreaths and many of the bouquets came not from individuals but from civic and religious institutions in that corner of Upper Manhattan.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Rail Plan Shelved
description: The government of Ma-laysia's new prime minister, Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, left, has shelved indefinitely plans to build a second railway the length of peninsular Malaysia, at a cost of 14.5 billion ringgit ($3.8 billion). The railway was one of the last big projects of Mr. Badawi's predecessor, Mahathir bin Mohamad, who had selected local companies to handle the project. Mr. Badawi said Wednesday that the government needed to prioritize projects and balance the budget. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Oil Spill's Effects Linger
description: Though most of the big environmental effects of the 1989 oil spill from the Exxon Valdez tanker quickly dissipated, the oil's toxic effects on various species around Prince William Sound persisted far longer than expected, a new analysis has found. The study, in the journal Science, found, for example, that residual oil in stream mouths harmed pink salmon eggs for at least four years after the accident. Pockets of oil have remained in coarse shorefront sediments, where they have continued to affect other life, the study said. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about plans by Alliance Capital to settle accusations of improper trading in mutual funds referred incorrectly to an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into another fund company, Putnam Investments. While the agency has reached a partial settlement with Putnam, its investigation is continuing.

title: Friendly visits to 'the other side' multiply with lifting of travel ban
description: NICOSIA  To return or not? That has been the question facing Greek and Turkish Cypriots since April 23, when internal travel restrictions were dramatically lifted by the Turkish Cypriot authorities. For the first time in almost 30 years  since Turkey's invasion in August 1974 in response to a coup against the government of Archbishop Makarios that was orchestrated by the military junta in Athens  people can return to the homes they were forced to abandon.

title: 'Cold Mountain' Leads Field Of Golden Globe Nominees
description: ''Cold Mountain,'' the story of a soldier making his way home in the Civil War-ravaged South, topped the field of nominees for the 61st annual Golden Globe awards, receiving eight nominations, including for its three stars and for best dramatic motion picture, best director and best screenplay.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Big Board Appointment Aims to Erase the Past

title: Houses Near Conservation Areas: Where the Wild Things Are
description: WHO -- Fran Gray, 53, manager of a bedding and bath store

title: Some Democrats Uneasy About Dean as Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18  Many leading Democrats say they are uneasy about Howard Dean's candidacy for president and are reluctant to cede him the nomination for fear that his combative style and antiwar stance will leave Democrats vulnerable in November.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS SIGNS $66 MILLION DEAL WITH DRUG DEVELOPER
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that it would give Lexicon Genetics at least $66 million as part of a joint effort to develop psychiatric and neurological medicines. Bristol-Myers said it would make an initial payment of $36 million and supply the rest over three years. Bristol-Myers may extend the alliance for two years in exchange for paying as much as $50 million. Bristol-Myers also said it extended a similar research agreement with Exelixis Inc. Working with Lexicon, which uses gene research to find new medications, may allow Bristol-Myers to increase sales of psychiatric therapies, building on the schizophrenia treatment Abilify.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EHRLICH, SHELDON J.
description: EHRLICH--Sheldon J. of Forest Hills, NY on December 15, 2003. Beloved husband of Joyce. Devoted father of Gayle and Diane. Loving grandfather of three grandchildren. Dear brother of Robert. Funeral services were conducted on December 17th.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: A Fine Line Grows Finer

title: Realism, Admittedly Slippery, Explores What Can and Can't Be Seen
description: By the end of the 1960's, abstract painting had purified itself close to death, at which point representational painting, led partly by a return to realism, came charging back. As representational impulses continue to animate contemporary painting -- John Currin's retrospective now at the Whitney is but one example -- the question of realism's nature and its influence keeps surfacing.

title: 36 Hours | Palm Springs, Calif.
description: IT'S possible to visit Palm Springs and never stumble across its stylish side. Palm Canyon Drive, the main drag, is still wall-to-wall with tourists wearing fanny packs, the soundtrack that blasts down the streets is unapologetically Sinatra, and the average age at many botes is well past retirement. But hidden on the side streets is an entirely different town, one catering to young Los Angeles hipsters who have rediscovered the desert in recent years. Drawn by the modernism revival and the abundant retro irony of Palm Springs, design snobs are slowly making over the area's midcentury hotels, restaurants and shops. Just two hours east of Los Angeles, Palm Springs and nearby Desert Hot Springs are now dotted with chic little hotels where people like Paul Thomas Anderson, Baz Luhrman and Natalie Portman rejuvenate on weekends, even if ''My Way'' still echoes over the loudspeakers.

title: Documents Show Rowland's Ties to a Contractor
description: Shortly after becoming governor of Connecticut, John G. Rowland became a partner in a private development group that included a paving contractor who has been awarded $1.3 million in state work during Mr. Rowland's tenure, according to documents and interviews.

title: Anne Chu
description: 303 Gallery

title: Schwarzenegger Declares Fiscal Crisis in California
description: Invoking emergency powers, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger declared a fiscal crisis in California on Thursday and said he would bypass the Legislature to impose $150 million in spending cuts.

title: Sports of The Times; Hope Trickles Away From Thirsty Red Sox Fans
description: A PROFESSOR of law and longtime Red Sox loyalist ducked out of late-morning litigation in Maine yesterday to return a call and in the process get an update on the status of the mother of all baseball trades, which, for him, has been both compelling and chilling.

title: America's Public Secret
description: ''The Branded Hand of Captain Jonathan Walker,'' above, an 1845 daguerreotype from Boston, is one of about 300 works in ''Only Skin Deep'' at the International Center of Photography.

title: Episcopalians Back Away From Break
description: One day after a council of conservative Episcopalians announced that 13 Episcopal dioceses had formed a new network opposed to their church's stance on homosexuality, three bishops sought to distance their dioceses from the network and said the announcement had been premature.

title: Colgate Has Lesson in Its Final Exam
description: Until a midweek snowstorm blew them down, the goal posts from Andy Kerr Stadium leaned against the Delta Upsilon fraternity house near Colgate University this week.

title: Palestinians Denounce Sharons Threat to Impose Split
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Dec. 19  From Yasir Arafat's fog-enshrouded compound here to the soggy streets of Gaza City, Palestinians said today that they would oppose any attempt by Israel to establish a unilateral border between them.

title: Inviting Audiences to Feast on His Memories
description: Near the beginning of ''Dinner With Demons,'' Jonathan Reynolds tells us that ''every woman I've asked'' finds it seductive to have a man cook a meal for her. Mr. Reynolds makes this observation as he prepares a turkey dinner on the Second Stage Theater's set, a working kitchen. This one-man show, running through Jan. 18, gives new meaning to the term ''dinner theater.'' Whether audiences will be seduced depends on why they are there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DE LEON, RAYMOND
description: de LEON--Raymond, 79, died December 16 in Gorham, ME. WW II veteran. Longtime social studies teacher in NYC high schools and Special Assistant to the Chancellor for Bilingual Education. Avid reader and conversationalist. Survived by daughter Andrea de Leon, her husband Todd Burrowes, and children Haley and Carter Burrowes, all of New Gloucester, ME, and his sister, Gloria English and husband Arthur of New City, NY.

title: I Am Strom Thurmond's Daughter
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Openings
description: Theater favorites Kristen Johnston, Lili Taylor and Bill Irwin are appearing in new Off-Broadway revivals.

title: Recent Openings
description: New plays by Bill Irwin, Lynn Nottage, Eliam Kraiem and Martin Moran recently opened in New York.

title: The Freedom Tower Design
description: A series of renderings provides views of the Freedom Tower, the 1,776 foot high building proposed for the World Trade Center site.

title: Radio Free America?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAUB, EDA (NEE FASSMAN)
description: TAUB--Eda (nee Fassman) on December 18, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Saul. Loving aunt, cousin and friend. Yiddish poet and author. Devoted philanthropist to Israel and Yiddish culture. Service Sunday, 11:15AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: It Did Matter, Matter, Matter: The Contract Failed by Five
description: Some of the characters in Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Ruddigore'' sing, ''It doesn't really matter, matter, matter, matter, matter.'' That is usually true in a bridge game if the contract is due to fail. One down or two down has little impact on the score.

title: Regina Ovesey -- Advertising Executive, 82
description: Regina Ovesey, the first woman to be chief executive of an advertising agency recognized by the industry's main trade group, the American Association of Advertising Agencies, died on Dec. 13 in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 82.

title: A No-Nonsense Coaching Style
description: Tom Coughlin met his Boston College players for the first time in an early morning meeting in 1991 and found a typical group of college students -- slouching in their chairs, wearing their hats backward, with no idea what was about to overtake them.

title: Accused Nurse Brings New Grief to Families
description: For scores of people in northern New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania, anguish about the death of a loved one returned with a jolt at news of Charles Cullen's admission, according to prosecutors, that he had killed 30 to 40 patients during his nursing career.

title: Felix Kaspar, 88, Figure Skater Who Was Known for High Jumps
description: Felix Kaspar, a 5-foot-4 Austrian who won world championships and an Olympic medal in figure skating and dazzled audiences with his jumping, died Dec. 5 in a hospital near his home in Bradenton, Fla. He was 88.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about New York City crime statistics gave an incorrect spelling at one point for the surname of a Democratic political consultant who discussed the political importance of dropping crime rates. He is George Arzt, not Artz.

title: Swerving Nets Steer Themselves Into First
description: The rubbernecking public turned its attention to the Nets this week, anticipating a gory disintegration just off the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: The Long-Lost Cousins of the Middle Class
description: As parents and children around the country gather with relatives to celebrate the holidays, our national conversation often focuses on common experiences. Families from different economic backgrounds repeat rituals of shopping, opening gifts and sharing meals. If middle-class people do pause to recognize the differences in the way we celebrate the season, they often emphasize what poor and working-class children may be missing. Will they have enough toys under the tree? Will their holiday feast be bountiful?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLINDER, PHILIP L.
description: BLINDER--Philip L. On December 18, 2003. Beloved husband of Lila. Loving father of Robin. Adoring grandfather of Adam and Eric. Service Sunday, 12:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSS, ANN GILMOUR
description: ROSS--Ann Gilmour died December 18, 2003 at Gladeview Health Care Center in Old Saybrook after a long illness. She is survived by her sister Mrs. Deane G. Marsh and her husband, the Rev. Donald Marsh of York, ME. She was the daughter of Bryant F. and Margurite Scarborough Gilmour. She was born in Brooklyn, NY, raised in Bayshore, NY, and had lived in Bellport, NY and New Canaan, CT before moving to Old Saybrook. She was a 1948 graduate of Wheaton College in Norton, MA. Mrs. Ross was a communicant of St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Old Lyme, CT. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 AM on Tuesday, December 23, 2003 in St. Ann's Church in Old Lyme. Donations may be made in her memory to St. Ann's Episcopal Church, 82 Shore Road, Old Lyme, CT 06371 or to the charity of one's choice.

title: A Sugarplum Fairy Who Won My Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STROH, HENRY
description: STROH--Henry, 99. Died December 17, 2003 in Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of the late Bertie. Will be forever missed by two children, ten grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. Graveside service Sunday, Dec 21, 11AM, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y.

title: National Briefing: Politics
description: MASSACHUSETTS: BIGGER SHARE OF TOBACCO POT A jury has awarded five law firms that helped Massachusetts win $8.3 billion from a nationwide tobacco settlement an additional $100 million in fees. The firms argued they should receive more than the $775 million, or 9.3 percent of the total settlement amount, they were awarded over 25 years by an arbitrator. They said the state breached a contract guaranteeing them one-quarter of the total settlement, and sought $1.3 billion.    Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, RICHARD
description: SOLOMON -- Richard. With fond remembrances of a real mensch. Elaine and Mel Finkelstein

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Forecast
description: The government expects the economy to grow 1.8 percent in real terms in the fiscal year that begins April 1, according to its new forecast. The government uses the forecast to determine spending and tax programs. But the government expects the economy to expand 0.5 percent in nominal terms, or without accounting for price changes, a sign it sees deflation slowing next year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: How to Save the World? Treat It Like a Business
description: When J. B. Schramm talks about getting poor kids into college, he sounds less like a bleeding heart than a corporate shark pitching a moneymaking scheme. He talks about market opportunities, about talent that is ''undervalued by the marketplace'' and ''economic muscle that's not being harnessed.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is not just a building. This is a symbol of New York. This is a symbol of America. This is a symbol of freedom.''

title: Beliefs; Scrooge has no regrets, but he can't help feeling that something's missing.
description: Scrooge was dead tired, to begin with. No doubt about it. He leaned back in the recliner, glanced at his Rolodex, and closed his eyes. The phone, he knew, would ring in a few minutes: Fred, coming to drive him to Connecticut for Christmas dinner.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Scholarship Fund Set Up
description: The chief executive of the Cott Corporation, a private-label soft drink supplier based in Toronto, has given up all but one dollar of his 2004 salary to help finance a college scholarship program for the children of employees, the company said. The executive, Frank Weise, received a salary of $425,000 last year as well as a bonus of $850,000. He will receive a bonus next year. Cott, which operates in the United States, Canada and Britain, reported a 30 percent increase in third-quarter net income. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: TJX WINS BIDDING FOR BOB'S, A RETAILER IN BANKRUPTCY
description: The TJX Companies, the owner of T.J. Maxx and Marshalls clothing stores, won the bidding for the bankrupt Bob's Stores, the chief financial officer, Donald G. Campbell, said yesterday. Mr. Campbell said TJX offered $113 million for Bob's Stores, though adjustments related to inventory reductions and other issues would decrease the final amount to ''less than $100 million.'' He declined to be more specific. The purchase must receive bankruptcy court approval. TJX said in October that it planned to acquire most of the assets of the closely held Bob's Stores, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection this year. TJX raised its offer to $113 million from $100 million and was designated the auction's winner Thursday, beating a bid by a joint venture led by Dick's Sporting Goods.

title: New Report Advocates Subway Line For East Side
description: An influential regional planning group issued a study yesterday that focused on the economic benefits of building a Second Avenue subway line while criticizing another study, released last month, that played down the relative worth of building it.

title: Fears of Retaliation for U.S. Limits on Iraq Work
description: Foreign governments are still angry about the Bush administration's decision to ban certain countries from bidding on reconstruction projects in Iraq, and the move may come back to haunt some of the biggest American companies, international trade experts say.

title: The Issues in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHITEL, JOAN
description: CHITEL--Joan. On December 17, 2003. Beloved wife of Bob. Devoted mother of David and Douglas and mother-inlaw of Cristina. Loving daughter of Dr. Joseph Ormand and the late Estelle Ormand. Dear sister of Kenneth, Richard and Diane Ormand. Services Friday, 12:45PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to The Carcinoid Cancer Foundation, Inc., 333 Mamaroneck Ave., Suite 492, White Plains, NY 10605.

title: A Skyscraper Has a Chance To Be Nobler
description: The surprise of yesterday's unveiling is that in its present form Freedom Tower is much closer to being a piece of architecture than the public had any right to expect. The forced collaboration between David M. Childs, of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, and Daniel Libeskind might have brought out the worst instincts of each, resulting in a corporate gloss on the apocalypse. Instead, the architects have come close to transcending what's left of their battered selves. With some shrewd editing, the design could become one of the noblest skyscrapers ever realized in New York.

title: G.O.P. Building Army of Volunteers to Get Out the Vote
description: They streamed into a ballroom here one recent night young men in investment-banker suits eager for a taste of big-time politics, married couples looking to make a difference, retirees for whom precinct organizing is an avocation -- and signed on as foot soldiers in a vast army of volunteers that President Bush is mobilizing for his re-election campaign.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: JUSTICE DEPT. BACKS REDISTRICTING The Department of Justice cleared a Republican-backed Congressional district map, just hours after a three-judge federal panel ruled that mid-decade redistricting is permissible under Texas law. The Justice Department evaluated the map to see whether it adhered to the federal Voting Rights Act, which protects minority voting rights. Texas Democrats had said that the map violated the act.   (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 4 about the community of Sandy Ground, which started as a settlement of free blacks on Staten Island, referred imprecisely to Weeksville, a similar settlement in Brooklyn. Its distinct identity was lost after the development that followed the completion of the Eastern Parkway in the 1860's and the Brooklyn Bridge in 1883; it was not mostly destroyed with the construction of the bridge. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Day for Tears As Survivors Talk of Pain Sniper Caused
description: ''I'm afraid to go to sleep because of the nightmares,'' Katrina Hannum, 25, told the jury now considering whether Lee Malvo should be put to death. ''Almost every night I have to watch this man shoot my mother in the head.''

title: UNION BANKSHARES TO ACQUIRE GUARANTY FINANCIAL
description: The Union Bankshares Corporation, which owns banks in eastern Virginia, agreed to acquire the Guaranty Financial Corporation for $54 million in stock and cash to expand into the Charlottesville, Va., area. Union Bankshares will pay 0.842 of its shares, $28 in cash, or a combination for each Guaranty share, Union Bankshares said. The total payment is limited to 40 percent cash and 60 percent stock. The price is 42 percent higher than Guaranty's closing share price on Wednesday, the last day they traded.

title: Bloomberg Vetoes Bill On Removing Lead Paint
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday vetoed a City Council measure that would regulate the removal of lead-paint hazards, including lead dust, from older apartments where young children live.

title: Army Reprimands a Romeo, But Not Everyone Is Happy
description: A United States Army colonel whom scores of women accused of simultaneously wooing them with promises of marriage was given a letter of reprimand and penalized $7,000 in pay, the Army said yesterday.

title: Sharon's New Offer: A Compromise, a Threat or Both?
description: The cottage industry that is Ariel Sharon-watching in Israel and elsewhere was very busy on Friday parsing Mr. Sharon's instantly famous speech of Thursday night and trying to answer the basic question: was Mr. Sharon's declaration an offer, a sort of olive branch, or was it a threat?

title: New Prime Minister Is Steering Canada Cautiously to the Right
description: As one of his first acts in office, Prime Minister Paul Martin fired Jean Chrtien's personal chef and replaced him and his Qubcois provincial meat-and-potato fare with a Portuguese-born chef known for his elegant presentations of nouvelle cuisine.

title: COMCAST AND VIACOM IN AGREEMENT ON CABLE SYSTEMS
description: The Comcast Corporation signed a multiyear agreement to continue carrying Viacom's television networks on its cable systems. Financial terms were not disclosed. The agreement extends contracts for some Viacom channels and renews others that were set to expire, the companies said. The agreement comes at a time when Comcast is seeking to lower its costs to carry programs. Comcast, which is based in Philadelphia, bought AT&T Broadband a year ago and now has 21 million cable customers, or about 30 percent of the total in the United States. Under the agreement, Comcast will be allowed to offer some MTV and CBS News programming through its video-on-demand service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIJOU, JOSEPH E.
description: BIJOU--Joseph E. Of Brooklyn, NY, died on December 19, 2003. He is survived by his beloved wife of 52 years, Sallee, his sons Elie and Leon, his daughters Rachel Bijou, and Luna Zemmol and his daughter-in-law Aura Bijou, and son-in-law Jonathan Zemmol, and five grandchildren. He will be deeply missed by his many relatives and dear friends. Funeral services will be held at 10:00 AM on Sunday, December 21 at the Magan David Synagogue, 2017 67th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Devils Turn Slow Start Into Easy Victory
description: The Buffalo Sabres entered Friday's game against the Devils having lost their previous six games. They were mired in a scoring funk and their starting goaltender, Martin Biron, had not played in two weeks. But in the game's first 30 minutes, it seemed as if those facts were lost on the Devils, who struggled to find their focus against one of the league's worst teams.

title: The Issues in Iraq (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons of Libya
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's long, strange odyssey toward international respectability took a welcome twist yesterday, with back-to back announcements from Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Bush that Libya had agreed to give up all efforts to develop unconventional weapons and to permit international inspections.

title: Marriage, Personified
description: To the Editor:

title: A Clash of the Seasons Inspires a Meeting of Cultures
description: Chen Shi-Zheng, the Chinese director best known for the lavish production of ''The Peony Pavilion'' at Lincoln Center four years ago, has made it something of a mission to translate the traditions of Beijing music theater for modern American audiences. He's fascinated by the collision of artistic idioms this implies, and his most recent work, ''Snow in June,'' is a wild amalgam. It's lovely and compellingly strange, if not quite fulfilling.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Aircraft Purchase Planned
description: The Hainan Airlines Company, whose biggest shareholder is the financier George Soros, plans to buy eight Airbus SAS 319's, worth as much as $440 million, to help expand its regional service. Mo Kaixiang, the head of the airline's purchasing department, said that the Development and Reform Commission approved the purchase and as soon as the airline selects an engine, it will sign a contract for the planes. The purchase is part of a contract signed with Airbus in April, when Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin of France visited China. Hainan Air operates more than 400 routes in China and flies to Asian destinations. Airbus, a unit of EADS, is based in Toulouse, France.

title: F.C.C. Approves Deal Giving Murdoch Control Of DirecTV
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday conditionally approved the News Corporation's acquisition of control of Hughes Electronics and its DirecTV subsidiary from General Motors.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the first weekday that a rail transfer station operated in Secaucus, N.J., misstated the number of New Jersey Transit lines that join there. It is 10 out of 11 (not 11 out of 12). In some copies the article also misstated the reopening date for the PATH station in Lower Manhattan. It was Nov. 23, not this month.

title: John Dreves, Designer for Steuben Glass, Is Dead at 90
description: John Dreves, a master crystal maker and creator of the classic olive bowl design that Steuben Glass introduced at the 1939 New York World's Fair, died on Nov. 16, the company announced this week. He was 90 and lived in Corning, N.Y.

title: Deadline Set in Asbestos-Related Case
description: A federal appeals court has set a Jan. 31 deadline for the district court judge who is overseeing bankruptcy proceedings of five companies battling asbestos claims to determine whether he must step down from one or more of the cases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUTHRIE, PHILIP ALLEN
description: GUTHRIE--Philip Allen, age 53. We mourn the untimely death of Phil, beloved parent with Patricia Chiono of Katherine, adored brother of Elisabeth and Shannon, cherished son of Thomas and the late Jane Guthrie. Phil was an unfailing source of great humor, compassion, devotion and love to countless family members and friends. May his kindness and courage be an inspiration to us all. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Solebury School, P.O. Box 429, New Hope, PA 18938. Services Sunday, 1:15PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: No Influence On Contracts, Rowland Says
description: Responding to questions for the first time since his admission that he accepted free work on his private cottage from companies doing business with the state, Gov. John G. Rowland said on Friday that he had no influence in the awarding of state contracts, had obeyed state laws and was determined to serve out his term.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Setback for Music Industry In Fight for Online Sharing

title: About New York; Private Lessons In the Halls Of Old Masters
description: IN that hushed hour before the doors open to Fifth Avenue, a young man named Fabian Berenbaum enjoys private consultations with Rembrandt and Rubens, El Greco and van Dyck. They whisper across the centuries. Notice, they say. Learn.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: ARGENTINA: EX-PRESIDENT CHARGED A court charged former President Carlos Saul Menem with tax fraud, saying he failed to declare $600,000 deposited in a Swiss bank account. The 74-year-old former leader, whose 1989-1999 administration was marked by persistent allegations of corruption, acknowledged the account only last year, after repeated denials of its existence. If convicted, Mr. Menem could be barred from ever holding public office again, but would not face a prison sentence. Justice Minister Gustavo Beliz recently said there were indications that Mr. Menem had at least three Swiss bank accounts. Mr. Menem dismissed those claims as inventions and made no public comment about the court charges yesterday. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Irregularities Push Parmalat Closer To Insolvency
description: Parmalat, the Italian dairy and food giant, slid to the brink of insolvency on Friday after the company disclosed that a bank account that supposedly held nearly $5 billion of its money did not exist.

title: In Small Town Scarred by 9/11, Voters Debate Bush's Iraq Strategy
description: When news broadcasts showed a ragged Saddam Hussein being dragged out of a hole in Iraq, there was elation in this small mining town, where one of four airliners hijacked on Sept. 11 crashed. For obvious reasons, battling terrorism is the election issue here.

title: Police Seize Fake Watches
description: A Jersey City man was arrested yesterday and somewhere between 50,000 and 100,000 counterfeit wristwatches were seized in a raid on a building in Chinatown, the police said.

title: How Others See Sharons Vision (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Ex-President Charged
description: A court charged former President Carlos Sal Menem with tax fraud, saying he failed to declare $600,000 deposited in a Swiss bank account. The 74-year-old former leader, whose 1989-1999 administration was marked by persistent allegations of corruption, acknowledged the account only last year, after repeated denials of its existence. If convicted, Mr. Menem could be barred from ever holding public office again, but would not face a prison sentence. Justice Minister Gustavo Beliz recently said there were indications that Mr. Menem had at least three Swiss bank accounts. Mr. Menem dismissed those claims as inventions and made no public comment about the court charges yesterday. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 16; TODAY'S GAMES
description: Atlanta Falcons (3-11) at Tampa Bay Buccaneers (7-7)

title: L.I.R.R. Managers Accepted Illegal Meals, Report Says
description: The Long Island Rail Road's former president and five managers got thousands of dollars in meals and entertainment from companies involved with the agency, according to an investigation that found they violated state law.

title: National Briefing | Politics: John Kennedy Aide Backs Clark
description: Theodore C. Sorenson, the former speechwriter for President John F. Kennedy, said he believed that Gen. Wesley K. Clark was the Democratic presidential candidate best qualified to handle issues of national security. ''The American people are more endangered now than they were on 9/11,'' Mr. Sorenson said. He said General Clark's experience as supreme allied commander of NATO forces during the war in Kosovo prepared him to repair what he said were the breaches in alliances caused by the Bush administration. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Kazaa Wins Dutch Ruling
description: The makers of Kazaa, the computer file-sharing program, cannot be held liable for copyright infringement of music or movies swapped with its free software, the Dutch Supreme Court ruled on Friday.

title: Jarvis Is Unable to Survive Lumps and Losses
description: A high-profile college basketball coaching job became open yesterday after St. John's fired Mike Jarvis. He will be replaced in the interim with the associate head coach Kevin Clark.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Gucci Posts Profit
description: The Italian luxury goods company Gucci Group reported its first increase in profit in three quarters yesterday, largely as a result of the popularity of its leather handbags that are secured by brass and silver horse bits. Gucci, which also owns the product lines of Yves Saint Laurent, Bottega Veneta, Alexander McQueen and Stella McCartney, said that operating income rose 17 percent. But Domenico de Sole, the chief executive, also reported that Saint Laurent, the famous fashion house that Gucci acquired in 1999, lost 20.7 million euros ($25.6 million) in the third quarter. Tracie Rozhon (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CREMIN, DANIEL
description: CREMIN--Daniel, native of Brosna, Co. Kerry, Ireland. Passed away peacefully on December 18, 2003. Survived by his loving wife Johanna and children Mary, Elizabeth, Caroline and William. Loving grandfather of Johanna. Cherished father-in-law of Christopher and Monnel. Beloved brother of Nora Mary, Shiela, Theresa, Margaret, Michael and Jeremiah. title: History You Can See, Hear, Smell, Touch and Taste
description: The English mistook the Indians' war chants for songs of welcome, while the Indians mistook the red wine the settlers offered them for blood. When Powhatan, the powerful Chesapeake chief, offered food to the Jamestown settlers, it was to signal the visitors' dependent status, allies who required his protection. To his delighted guests, however, the gesture had another meaning: proof of willing subordination. The Indians, the English agreed with relief, would become docile subjects of King James.

title: Op-Art; Tired of Shopping? Build a Gift
description: A hundred years ago, people didn't race to the mall in a panicked frenzy to do their last-minute holiday shopping. Many of them stayed home and made their own gifts. One of the simplest (and most popular) handmade gifts was the peep show, whose name long ago had far more innocent connotations. When these paper toys gained popularity in England in the early 1800's, they were meant to reproduce, on a much smaller scale, the large wooden tableaux carted from town to town in the countryside. For a small fee, villagers could peep inside the box and be amazed and delighted at the historical or religious scene depicted within.

Vitas Healthcare holders will receive $30 a share, Roto-Rooter said. Roto-Rooter has sold off health care subsidiaries as it focused on its core plumbing business in the past seven years. Shares of Roto-Rooter rose $9.24, or 26 percent, to $44.52.

The larger stake will help the companies coordinate their production. Through a tender offer, Matsushita Industrial will purchase shares at a 30 percent premium, to raise its stake to 51 percent. Matsushita Industrial will spend up to 146 billion yen ($1.3 billion) for the shares. Ken Belson (NYT)

This new tower, which will rise, pivoting gracefully, from the northwest corner of the World Trade Center site, is much, much better than we had any right to expect, given the widely reported differences between Mr. Childs, who is responsible for the tower's design, and Mr. Libeskind, who is responsible for the master plan.

title: RULING IS A SETBACK FOR U.P.S. AND FEDEX
description: A federal administrative judge ruled yesterday that an air cargo company at the center of an international ownership dispute is a United States business and that there was no evidence that it was illegally controlled by overseas interests as rivals have asserted. The decision by a Transportation Department administrative law judge, Burton Kolko, on Astar Air Cargo, formerly DHL Airways, serves as a recommendation to Transportation Department officials who will make a final ruling. The recommendation was a setback for FedEx and U.P.S., which had challenged the ownership and control structure of DHL Airways. DHL was based in Chicago before it was sold last summer for $57 million to a group of American investors and renamed Astar. The lead investor was the chairman of DHL Airways, John Dasburg. Fedex and U.P.S. said that Astar was controlled by DHL Worldwide, a unit of the German postal company, Deutsche Post.

description: From the above-ground pool and plastic crche on the front lawn to the Norman Rockwell figurines in the beige-on-brown living room, there is nothing flamboyant about the Kilian-Meneghin household. The couple -- a soft-spoken parish secretary and a nerdy Web administrator inseparable since high school -- have a pair of exceedingly polite children, an elderly cat named Spot and two well-maintained Saturns in the driveway. By most standards, the family is as all-American and unremarkable as they come.

title: Religious Symbols in France
description: President Jacques Chirac made the wrong decision on Wednesday when he announced his support for a legal ban in state-run schools on what he called ''conspicuous'' religious symbols. He offered Muslim scarves, Jewish skullcaps and large crucifixes as examples, but the dispute into which he stepped is about the scarves worn by devout Muslim women and girls. Speaking before an invited gathering that included religious leaders from all major faiths, Mr. Chirac cast his decision as a reaffirmation of France's commitment to a rigorous separation of church and state. But it is not that at all. Banning believers from following the discipline of their religions would amount to imposing the view of the state upon them.

The rules include audits of distributors and aim to stem the sales of counterfeit copies of Pfizer products, a spokesman, Bryant Haskins, said. The effort coincides with Pfizer's fight to halt Canadian pharmaceutical sales to consumers in the United States. Pfizer, based in New York, has cited the risk of fake drugs as it tries to stop Canadian drugstores from selling cheap medicines to Americans, mostly over the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAXTER, CHRISTINE EVELYN

Born in New York, daughter of Mary and the late Matthew Zagroba, devoted sister to the late Edward Zagroba, she graduated from St. John's University where she met and fell in love with her husband, Harold J. Baxter. As a devoted wife and mother, she built a warm, loving, faith-filled home with her husband and their four children, Christine, Patricia, Robert and Kathryn. Recently, she welcomed the addition of her daughter-inlaw Ruth, son-in-law Andrew Youngblood and grand daughter Claire Elizabeth into her family. Her life was a joyful example of faith, patience, love and kindness. Her laughter will be missed by her many dear friends. Calling hours at The Donohue Funeral Home, 366 W. Lancaster Avenue, Wayne, PA on Sunday, December 21 from 69PM. Funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Katharine of Siena Church, Monday, December 22, 2003 at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers remembrances may be made to Thomas Jefferson University Hospital, Bodine Center for Cancer Treatment, Attn: Miriam Schwed, 11th and Sansom Street, Philadelphia, PA 19107.

title: Reason and Faith, Eternally Bound

Reason's battles, though, continue unabated. Only now it finds its opposition in the more unyielding claims of religious faith. This latest conflict is over seemingly incompatible ways of knowing the world. It is a conflict between competing certainties: between followers of Faith, who know because they believe, and followers of Reason, who believe because they know.

title: A New Pathway To the Stars
description: The flop at Kitty Hawk the other day, when a reproduction of the Wright brothers' first plane swooned into a mud puddle instead of taking flight, seemed embarrassingly emblematic of America's manned space program, which is also going nowhere. Thirty-three years after the Wright brothers flew, paying customers were snoozing in berths aboard commercial airliners; 33 years after that, men walked on the Moon. Yet today, a third of a century after NASA's lunar triumph, we're down to a fleet of three grounded space shuttles and a low-orbit space station serviced by aging Russian rockets. It's time either to get moving again -- or to cash in our chips and leave human space exploration to other nations.

The other lesson is a bit more surprising: even in our age of astonishing forensic technology, murder by poison can still be a very difficult crime to uncover.

description: BABY DODDS -- If you want to smell the subsoil of American music, try an arresting documentary record from 1946, reissued by Atavistic: ''Talking and Drum Solos,'' by the drummer Baby Dodds. (This single disc also includes ''Country Brass Bands,'' an LP from 1954.) Recorded by the jazz historian Frederic Ramsey Jr., Dodds's original 10-inch EP offered his answers to a series of probing questions. What did drumming sound like before all this bebop existed? What exactly did you play in King Oliver's band, in Louis Armstrong's Hot Seven? What did those rhythms sound like, abstracted from the rest of the band? Dodds, who helped invent jazz drumming before there were such things as hi-hat or ride cymbals, demonstrates his rim-tapping and press-rolls, his playing tom-toms, woodblocks and bells, all amounting to a delicate science. And he goes further, constructing several ad-libbed solo performances, which he called ''Spooky Drums,'' Parts 1 and 2. They are among the great solo performances in jazz, and it would have required a leap of imagination by Dodds to consider them performances as such, since they were recorded more than 20 years before drummers played alone on stages.

title: Monster Mash
description: The Mummy, Dracula and the Wolf Man -- the gang's all here in HOLLYWOOD HORROR: From Gothic to Cosmic (Abrams, $45), Mark A. Vieira's delectably gruesome, if arbitrarily organized, compendium of fright flicks from classic Lon Chaney silents to drive-in fodder like the remarkably unscary Roger Corman cheapie ''The Terror,'' starring a wooden young Jack Nicholson. The book brings well-deserved attention to makeup artists like Jack Pierce, the genius behind the bucket-headed horror of Frankenstein's monster, the Mummy's moldy visage and the beehive for the Bride of Frankenstein. Vieira, who wrote ''Hurrell's Hollywood Portraits,'' also details the work of set designers like Charles Hall, who created the multistoried mad scientist's laboratory in ''Bride of Frankenstein,'' and Jack Otterson, who created the nutty Expressionist angles for ''Son of Frankenstein.'' The book makes a case that moodily lighted black-and-white portraits and production stills are an art form, but Vieira's argument dissolves into pure camp when he includes schlock like ''Monster on the Campus,'' in which the beast-man is seen to be wearing short-sleeve body fur with gloves. Films like Robert Aldrich's ''Kiss Me Deadly'' and Stanley Kubrick's ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' are shoehorned into the horror genre. Real Hollywood horrors like a washed-up Bela Lugosi cruising Beverly Hills funeral homes for a fix of paraldehyde with the no-budget director Ed Wood Jr. are lightly touched upon. Vieira's book is a nostalgic look back at a kinder, gentler era of monster-movie making. Eric P. Nash

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIPSTEIN, DR. CHARLES BENJAMIN
description: RIPSTEIN--Dr. Charles Benjamin. Renowned surgeon and educator, and pioneer in cardiac and colon/rectal surgery, died at his home in Florida on December 13, his 90th birthday. Born in Winnipeg, he grew up in Montreal, and received his M.D. from McGill University School of Medicine in 1940. Served as RCAF squadron leader during WWII. He began his career as a cardiac surgeon, and was an early practitioner of open heart and mitral valve surgery. Became the first director of surgery at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in 1954. Also taught at Downstate and Cornell, and served as chief of surgery at Maimonides and Brookdale Hospitals in Brooklyn. Moved to Florida in 1972, where he was clinical professor at Univeristy of Miami and on the staff of the Miami Heart Institute. Developed the ''Ripstein procedure'' for repair of rectal prolapse, spoke all over the world, and authored numerous articles. Loving husband of Barbara Adelman Ripstein for nearly 53 years. Devoted father to Ellen Ripstein of Manhattan and Dr. Linda Ripstein Dresnick, a Miami radiologist. Father-in-law to Mark Dresnick, and loving grandfather to Joel and Jeffrey.

title: Wise Men and Their Tales
description: Aman, a woman. Abraham and Sarah. Who has not heard of them? Everyone loves them. They radiate goodness, nobility, human warmth. Who doesn't claim kinship with them? Humankind is what it is because they shaped our destiny. He is the father of our people, she the mother. Everything leads us back to them. The promised land bears their seal. Faith-our faith-was kindled by theirs. A couple unlike any other, they inspire joy and hope. Tormented by our own troubles, we recall theirs, which give ours a transcendent meaning. Abraham, the first to be chosen, the first to choose God and crown him God of the universe; Abraham, synonymous with loyalty and absolute fidelity, a symbol of perfection. And yet ... a shadow hovers over one aspect of his existence. In his exalted life, we encounter a painful episode that cannot but puzzle us, if not cause us to recoil. title: Dumpster-Diving for Your Identity
description: Stephen Massey was only a few minutes late, yet he apologized profusely as he strode into the lobby of a crowded restaurant in downtown Eugene, Ore. ''I'm very punctual about my time,'' he said, clasping my hand in a firm shake. With his freshly combed hair, crisp white shirt and trimmed mustache, he looked like an off-duty cop or fireman -- a ''pillar of the community,'' as he later described himself, a wolfish smile playing across his lips. Far from it: Massey, 39, directed one of the most extensive and notorious identity-theft rings prosecuted so far by federal authorities. By the time investigators broke the case, Massey and his partner in crime, a computer whiz named Kari Melton, had ruined hundreds of people's credit. A judge sentenced them to prison in 2000; Melton was released in 2001, Massey the next year.

title: The Soul of Capitalism
description: First, we pause to acknowledge the ancestors. The discontents of present day American life are real enough but can seem quite trivial and self-indulgent when laid alongside the American past. Modern pressures lack the hard and often tragic bite of what earlier Americans commonly endured. Three or four generations ago most Americans lived in dwellings that lacked indoor plumbing, not to mention electricity and central heating. Most families were tenants, not owners. Life was simpler, certainly, but also much shorter. Half of the children born in 1900 were dead by the age 40 (in our time, 95 percent of the new babies will live to 40 and half will be still alive at 79). People, it is said, were more God-fearing in olden days, and probably so, since their lives were ruled by stark, random insecurities that dwarf our own: bad weather that could destroy livelihoods or abrupt waves of economic disorder; unspeakably harsh working conditions and inadequate incomes; the blind cruelties of uncontrollable diseases. Parents regularly experienced the sudden death of small children, an event that no doubt encouraged faith in an afterlife, the promise of a heavenly reward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COULSTON, DR. FREDERICK
description: COULSTON--Dr. Frederick. 89, of Alamogordo, NM, died Monday, December 15, 2003, in Alamogordo. Dr. Coulston was born December 4, 1914 in New York City to Samuel and Celia Goldstein. He attended Syracuse University where he received his Bachelor's Degree in 1936, his Master's Degree in 1939, and his Doctorate in 1942. During WWII, he was active in the Human Malaria Project, a research program to discover new drugs for malaria. He developed and taught the concept that the malaria parasite acted on the host through its chemical action, both pharmacologically and toxicologically, and the host in turn acted upon the parasite through humoral and immunological mechanisms. This was the beginning of his introduction into modern toxicology. Dr. Coulston had a long, awardwinning career, including Director of Experimental Pathology and Toxicology at the Steeling-Winthrop Research Institute. For the Albany Medical College he served as Director of the Institute of Experimental Pathology and Toxicology, Professor of Pathology, Pharmacology and Toxicology, Director of the Animal Research facilities, and assisted in the development of the first hepatitis vaccine. He founded and served as Chairman of Coulston International Corporation and Coulston Products, Inc. which developed and marketed Permanone, used during Operation Desert Storm by the U.S. military. He served as Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of the Coulston Foundation which performed research on HIV, various vaccines and hepatitis C. He also served as Chairman of the Board of Diagnostic and Technology Center, Inc. Dr. Coulston was a unique individual who believed strongly in education and was continuously teaching people to the very end of his life. He taught many of today's scientists in the fields of toxicology, parasitology and pharmacology. He was a man with many, many accomplishments, honors and awards, but foremost a dedicated scientist. Through his research work, Dr. Coulston has touched the lives of many human beings throughout the world. He dedicated his life to the health of mankind. He published countless scientific articles and was editor for several scientific journals. His many professional honors included Co-Founder and President of the Society of Toxicology; member of the World Health Organization; member of the International Atomic Agency Commission of the United Nations; President of the International Society of Ecotoxicology and Environmental Safety; co-Chairman of the Human Health Aspects to Accidental Chemical Exposure of Dioxins; recipient of the Arnold J. Lehman Award; President of the International Society of Regulary Toxicology and Pharmacology; co-author and sponsor of banning cyanide gold processing; and recipient of Businessman of the Year in 2002, given by President George W. Bush. Survivors include his son, Craig Wynn Coulston of Tularosa; his daughter, Cynthia Ann Oxley and her husband Lloyd of Dallas; two grandchildren, Eileen Marie Coker and her husband Christopher of Garland, Texas, and Michael Lloyd Oxley of Dallas; and two very special friends, Robbie Kayhart and Mary Villegas of Alamogordo. Funeral services will be conducted Monday, December 22, 2003, in the HamiltonO'Dell Chapel with F. Randolph Burroughs officiating. Interment will follow in Monte Vista Cemetery. For further information Hamilton-O Dell Funeral Home, Alamogordo, NM (505) 437-0530. To send a tribute to the family, please visit www.mem.com.

On a visit to his grandmother, where he has ''a whale of a time, paddling around in Granny's boat and tossing jam sandwiches to the snippy-snappy sea monsters,'' he begins to shrink. Wisely, his grandmother diagnoses the problem as an acute case of homesickness and sends him on his way. Despite his diminutive stature, brave Antonio secures a job swabbing the decks of a ship, serving as the lookout on a train and taming a huge wild horse, his small, determined song carrying him ever closer to the only place he wants to be: ''I'm on the way home! . . . For I want to be home with my mother!'' By the time Antonio reaches his destination, he is alarmingly tiny but -- no surprise! -- the combination of his mother's hugs and heaping portions of her home cooking quickly restores him to his normal size.

One balmy day finds him buzzing around the Old Courthouse in Santa Ana, in the heart of Orange County. It's a perfect Sunday afternoon, the kind of day when you just know you can be leader of the free world. The Ohio congressman has no doubt he will be president. Sitting in the courthouse during a 16-minute lunch between appearances, he enthusiastically pokes at my arm every which way to describe his coming triumph. He is scarfing down some of the vegan food that, he insists, makes him abnormally energetic. ''I have the ability to attract people who wouldn't normally vote in the primaries,'' he says fervently. ''I can touch people's hearts!''

title: Sloan Keeps Winning the Old-Fashioned Way

title: 'Tydings': Not Much Comfort, But a Lot of Joy (and Murder)
description: Christmas concerts these days lean heavily on Renaissance and Baroque works, probably as a way of creating an atmosphere that is quaint and warmly inviting. Lionheart, a finely honed male vocal sextet that specializes in medieval music (but is occasionally heard in contemporary works as well), has reconsidered that approach. Instead of revisiting the most popular pan-European Christmas hits of the 16th through 18th centuries, it has assembled ''Tydings Trew,'' a program focused on medieval England, with hymns, carols and motets that go back to the 13th century, sung in Latin and old English.

The company founded in 1972 (and bankrupt in 1998) was scooped up by Bonnell three years ago as part of an acquisition binge. ''I always said I wouldn't be a doting grandmother, but I'm afraid I am.'' Her dining room, already resplendent, is filled with holly and candles and teddy bears. ''There are always presents at the table, though we save the big ones for afterward,'' she says. The meal begins with baby shrimp from San Francisco -- ''I have to be true to my roots'' -- and features either duck, goose or pheasant. But it always ends with the traditional bche de Nol, made by her chef, Silvina Barroso. (Recipe on Page 62.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KITT, FRANCES
description: KITT -- Frances, 85, died peacefully on December 17, 2003, after a lingering illness. Her survivors include daughter, Edith Sawitsky, son-inlaw Michael Keane of South Orange, step-granddaughter Karin, great - grandchildren Anna Elisabeth and Herman of Oslo, son Kitt Sawitsky, daughter - in - law Heather Brown Sawitsky, and grandsons Aaron and Luke Sawitsky of Wellesley. Also surviving Frannie are her sister Ruth Beyers Stern of Dallas, brother Arthur Beyers, wife Norma of Manchester, NJ, sister-in-law Gloria Kitt Slobin, husband Bob of Delray Beach, sister-in-law Libby Beyers of San Rafael, and beloved cousins Nancy Kitt Mills and husband Steve of Chapel Hill, and Sylvia and Peter Bloom of Boynton Beach. She also leaves numerous cherished cousins, nephews and nieces and an extended circle of friends. Frannie was strong-willed, outgoing, and adventurous. She had unbounded curiosity about life and was intensely interested in the world around her. In her travels, she always sought to learn new things and make new friends. She amazed us all with her ability to stay in contact with family and friends even in her later years. Frannie combined a remarkable independence of spirit with unflagging compassion and concern. She will be missed. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations can be made to NY Community Trust Critical Needs Fund, 2 Park Ave, NY, NY 10016.

Roman Polanski accomplished that with THE PIANIST (2002), for which he won the Oscar for best director. Adrien Brody, who won the best actor Oscar, plays Wladyslaw Szpilman, a well-known pianist in prewar Poland. The film, based on Szpilman's own book, is an account of how he survived five years in the Warsaw ghetto. One minute, it seems, his privileged family is discussing where in their elegant apartment to hide their cash; the next they are being herded onto trains headed for the death camps -- Saturday at 9 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:10 a.m. on Starz.

title: Feeding Animals
description: To the Editor: I was distressed to see the Caiman Ecological Refuge, a so-called eco-lodge, featured in ''Adventure in the Pantanal'' (Oct. 26) by Tony Smith. The refuge allows activities that include feeding wild caimans and piranha fishing. Feeding wild animals is the antithesis of environmentally responsible tourism. Feeding makes animals lose fear of humans, which can be potentially dangerous. It also disrupts their natural life cycles and diet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLANK, BLANCHE DAVIS
description: BLANK--Blanche Davis. 80. December 19, 2003. Acting President, Dean of Social Sciences, Professor of Political Science, Hunter College; Vice-President, Yeshiva University. Blanche was the center of a large and loving family, whose motto for living was ''carpe diem.'' She was an extraordinary role model for her family, friends, and students. Her originality, commitment to justice, and independent spirit were inspirational to all. She will be sorely missed. She is survived by her husband Bud; daughters, Laura, Barbara, and Alice; sons-in-law, Steven Simkin, Barry Shapiro, and David Udell; and grandchildren, Alexander Simkin, Zachary Simkin, and Julia Udell. Those wishing to make contributions may send them to Hunter College for the Blanche D. Blank Endowed Scholar for Public Policy Fund. A memorial service will be held in the Harold Lewis Auditorium at the Hunter College School of Social Work, 129 E. 79th St, on January 22, at 4 pm, followed by a reception. The family will be sitting shiva Sunday through Thursday, December 21-25, 5-9 pm, at Premium Point, New Rochelle.

title: CONVICTIONS AND SENTENCES
description: From one end of the state to the other, it was a tough week for some municipal officials. On Monday, a former Hudson County Freeholder, Nidia Dvila-Coln, was sentenced last week to 37 months in jail for a bribery conviction, and a former Asbury Park mayor, Kenneth Saunders, and his political advisor, Rayfield James, were convicted of trying to bribe a former city councilwoman. In both cases, law enforcement officials had principals in the bribery cases secretly tape the politicians. Then on Tuesday, the former president of the Camden City Council, James R. Mathes Jr., was sentenced to 27 months in prison and ordered to pay a $3,000 fine in an investigation of Camden city government that had put former Mayor Milton Milan in prison. Mr. Mathes was convicted of accepting a diamond ring for a girlfriend from a jeweler selected by a Philadelphia mobster in the hope that he could then steer city contracts toward his associates. Ms. Davila-Coln, who had served 19 years on the Hudson County freeholder board, was sentenced for her May conviction in federal District Court of carrying cash from her boyfriend, Oscar Sandoval, to the Hudson County executive, Robert Janiszewski, in 1999 as payoffs for contracts. As for the Asbury Park officials, Mr. Saunders and Mr. James were convicted by a federal jury of bribing former City Councilwoman Sheila Solomon to get her vote for contracts on the city's waterfront development in 2000. Sentencing for Mr. Saunders and Mr. James has not been set, and the two men are deciding whether to appeal their cases. Robert Strauss

title: Sepharad
description: WE HAVE MADE OUR LIVES far away from our small city, but we just can't get used to being away from it, and we like to nurture our nostalgia when it has been a while since we've been back, so sometimes we exaggerate our accent when talking among ourselves, and use the common words and expressions that we've been storing up over the years and that our children can vaguely understand from having heard them so often. Godino, the secretary of our regional association-which has been rescued from its dismal lethargy thanks to his enthusiasm and dynamism-regularly organizes meals where we enjoy the food and recipes of our homeland, and if we are disgruntled that our gastronomy is as little known by foreigners as our monumental architecture or our Holy Week, we like having dishes that no one knows about, and giving them names that have meaning only to us. Oh, there's nothing like our gordal and cornezuelo olives! Godino exclaims, the plump ones and the long, pointed ones! Our rolls, our borrachuelos-we dream of those sugar-sprinkled pastries with a light touch of brandy-our layered pasta, our Easter cakes, our morcilla-our sausage has rice, not onion-our typical gazpacho, which is nothing at all like Andalusian gazpacho, and our wild-artichoke salad ... title: A Talk With the Ghost Of Top-10 Lists Future
description: IT is traditional, in the waning weeks of the year, for movie critics to look backward, sorting out the accomplishments and disappointments of the previous 12 months and noting the results on awards ballots and 10-best lists. (The results of that fretful and mysterious process will be published in this section next Sunday.) At a time when the annual tally of theatrical movie releases hovers around 500, and when every town with a population over that number seems to have its own film festival, those lists and prizes can seem downright stingy. Worse, they usually fail to capture some of the keenest excitement of the critic's job, which is the discovery of promising work by actors and filmmakers, young and not so young, at early stages of their careers. Think of this column, a partial roster of such work, not only as yet another end-of-the-year movie retrospective, but as an exercise in divination, a hopeful prophecy of the 10-best lists and Oscar tip-sheets of the future, and of reasons to keep going to the movies in years to come.

title: New Economy; Offshore Jobs In Technology: Opportunity Or a Threat?
description: The United States economy is finally getting stronger, but there seems to be one unsettling weakness: the apparent wholesale flight of technology jobs like computer programming and technical support to lower-cost nations, led by India.

title: McDonalds Picks DDB for a Global Campaign
description: The McDonald's Corporation in Oak Brook, Ill., has named the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group , to develop a worldwide advertising campaign for French fries in 2004.

title: Israeli Forces Arrest a Senior Hamas Official in the West Bank
description: Israeli security forces captured a senior Hamas official in the West Bank during raids conducted early Sunday, according to Israeli news reports and the Hamas leader's brother.

title: Bomb Kills 2 G.I.s and Translator in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 22  Two American soldiers and their Iraqi interpreter were killed here this morning when an improvised bomb exploded by their convoy, military officials said. Two other soldiers from the First Armored Division were wounded.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Thursday about the opening of the Airtrain at Kennedy International Airport misstated the borough for the Howard Beach station. It is Queens, not Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELANO, WILLIAM A.
description: DELANO--William A. The Trustees of the St. Mark's Historic Landmark Fund and the advisory board of the Neighborhood Preservation Center express their sadness at the passing of William Delano, husband of its esteemed Chair Emeritus, Georgia Delano. Whether in Chinese seamen's cap, kilt, or bowler, Billy was a true champion of neighborhood regeneration and international peace; and, always a steadfast friend of St. Mark's Church in-theBowery. We offer our deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCGARRY, JOSEPH G.

Beloved brother of Joanne, Catherine Susczynski (Charles) and Mary Ellen Cusumano (Vincent). Loving friend of Kevin O'Halloran. Also survived by one niece and four nephews. Reposing after 2 pm today, Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Ave (Exit 28N SS Pkwy), Wantagh. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:45 am, St. Martin of Tours RC Church, Bethpage, LI. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to IS 184 School in the Bronx appreciated. Family will receive friends Monday, 2-5 and 7-10 pm.

description: EDELMAN--Clara R. On December 18, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Herbert, loving mother of Renee Light, Martin and Walter Edelman. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Assemblyman Says the City's Housing Authority Keeps Too Many Apartments Vacant
description: The New York City Housing Authority is the biggest and, by many accounts, the best-run public housing agency in the country. Its 2,700 buildings have held up reasonably well. Few of its 419,000 residents move out. And there are more than 146,000 people ready to move in, determined to wait the decade or so that it can often take for an apartment to open up.

title: Mayor Voices Few Regrets At the Midterm
description: As he approaches the midpoint of his term, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who over the course of two years has slalomed from a pleasant political curiosity to one of the least-popular first-term mayors in a generation, said he regretted little that he has done since taking office at one of the most difficult times in New York City's history.

title: Japan Strengthens Financial Regulator
description: Japan's financial regulator has been granted a budget increase of 1.6 billion yen ($14.8 million), or 11 percent, to strengthen its ability to monitor banks, brokerage firms and accountants.

title: SCO Sends Second Warning Letter to Linux Users
description: The SCO Group plans to announce today that it is escalating its campaign to collect license fees from corporations using the Linux operating system, with warning letters to the companies. Supporters of Linux, including I.B.M. and other companies, say that SCO's interpretation of its claim over Linux is exaggerated.

title: Post-Jarvis Era Begins With a Similar Ending
description: The St. John's basketball team, unhappy that its coach was fired six games into the season, looked as if it were headed toward a serious beating Sunday on national television against No. 5 Georgia Tech. The Red Storm was behind by 21-6 after almost seven minutes.

title: Digital Gender Gap
description: As cable and other broadband companies strive to interest more consumers in advanced digital services like high-speed Internet access, digital cable service and high-definition TV's, they may want to rethink whether their marketing efforts are missing a critical group of consumers: women.

title: Teenagers and Sex
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/New CD's; Seducing With Words and Wiles
description: If their production schedules are as leisurely as their songs, it's no wonder that the rhythm-and-blues crooners Musiq (formerly Musiq Soulchild) and Joe only got around to releasing their 2003 albums in December. Both of them favor calm, undulating vamps that might continue unchanged through an entire song; both sing with rippling melismas by way of Stevie Wonder and Donny Hathaway. But their goals are different: Musiq has a world of hopes and situations to ponder, while Joe has just two things on his mind, romance and money.

title: Friendship and Business Blur In the World of a Media Baron
description: On the dust jacket of his recently published biography of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Conrad M. Black, the embattled media magnate, collected laudatory blurbs from an impressive set of conservative thinkers.

title: The Battle of Srebrenica, In Its Operating Rooms
description: WAR HOSPITAL

description: NORFOLK--William R. Attorney, age 62, died December 18, 2003, Tucson, AZ. He is survived by wife Marilyn, and daughters Stephanie, Allison, and Meredith. Private services have been held. If desired, memorials may be directed to New York Weill Medical Center, Dept. of Pulmonary Medicine, East 68th St., New York, NY 10024-4885 or Duke University School of Law, Durham, NC 27708-9902, or New York Methodist Hospital, 7th Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11215-3645.

title: Election Win Seems Assured for Guinean Leader, but His Nation's Fate Is Far From Certain
description: Voters turned out on Sunday to elect a president in the American-allied West African country of Guinea. But there was little doubt of the outcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IMBERMAN, MILTON
description: IMBERMAN--Milton, passed away peacefully December 19, 2003. Beloved husband of Hennie. Devoted father of Pauline and husband Marc Baylin. Loving grandfather to Emma and Eli. Also survived by his sister Ruth Taxel and adoring nieces and nephews.

title: Post-Mortems for a Media Deal Undone
description: Last Monday, Donny Deutsch, the advertising executive, and Michael Wolff, the often-caustic media columnist, were the toast of the New York Magazine Awards at the Four Seasons restaurant. Seated at a table along with Caroline Miller, editor in chief of the magazine, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, the two men, visible representatives of Mortimer B. Zuckerman's much-followed bid to buy New York, found themselves accepting early congratulations for their seemingly inevitable victory.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Pfizer Agrees to Buy Esperion for $1.3 Billion

title: Coughlin Is First Up For Giants
description: The Giants will kick off their coaching search Monday by interviewing Tom Coughlin, the only coach on their list they can talk to without waiting until the end of the regular season.

title: Van Horn's Hot Hand Tantalizes the Knicks
description: As his 3-pointers kept falling Saturday night, Keith Van Horn seemed to be not only bailing out his beleaguered coach, Don Chaney, but also resurrecting his game.

title: Kaiser Permanente Names Brand Agency
description: Kaiser Permanente in Oakland, Calif., the health maintenance organization, has named Campbell-Ewald, based in Warren, Mich., as its national brand agency for advertising, a new assignment. Spending for 2004 is estimated at $40 million.

title: Pfizer to Buy Maker of Promising Cholesterol Drug
description: Pfizer, maker of Lipitor, the leading drug to reduce harmful blood cholesterol, announced yesterday that it would pay $1.3 billion for Esperion Therapeutics, a small company that has pioneered a new series of drugs that mimic or enhance so-called good cholesterol.

title: U.S. Rarely Seeks Charges For Deaths in Workplace
description: Every one of their deaths was a potential crime. Workers decapitated on assembly lines, shredded in machinery, burned beyond recognition, electrocuted, buried alive -- all of them killed, investigators concluded, because their employers willfully violated workplace safety laws.

title: Higher Bid Made for Stake in Air Canada
description: Victor Li, son of the Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing, has submitted a sweetened investment offer to Air Canada yesterday as the company's board considered a competing bid from Cerberus Capital Management, a spokeswoman for Mr. Li's Trinity Time Investments said.

title: They'll Take Manhattan
description: Let's see. The city and the state of New York do not have enough money to adequately fund the public schools. Kids frequently find that gymnasiums, science labs, art classes, playgrounds and even qualified teachers are in short supply.

title: Illinois to Seek U.S. Exemption To Buy Drugs From Canada
description: Rod R. Blagojevich, the governor of Illinois, will ask the federal authorities to permit the state to ignore federal law and buy prescription drugs from Canada, aides said Sunday.

title: A Girl Cast Out 47 Years Ago Finds a Family Still Divided; Mystery of a Mother's Choice Continues to Torment Sisters
description: That cold April day in 1956, when Janina Surga Couto said goodbye to her three sisters, is fixed with piercing clarity in her memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COTTON, HARVARD A.
description: COTTON--Harvard A. 93, of Whitestone, NY, on December 19. Deeply mourned by his son Ross, his brother-inlaw and sister-in-law Bill and Betty Ruder and a warm and caring family of nieces, nephews and friends. Harvey was an extraordinary husband to his departed wife, Deborah, an inspiring high school math teacher in New York for over 35 years and a former President of Temple Hillel in Whitestone. His beautiful garden reflected a deep love of nature and sense of aesthetics. He conceived of, formed and managed S.H.I.P., the Supplemental Health Insurance Program for retired teachers that became a department of the UFT. We all will sorely miss him. Services are private.

description: United States military officials warned Sunday that fresh intelligence indicated that Iraqi insurgents might be planning a new wave of violence timed to the Christmas holiday, in part to avenge the capture of Saddam Hussein.

title: Gisela Konopka, 93, Professor; Studied Lives of Troubled Girls
description: Dr. Gisela Konopka, a pioneer in the study of troubled adolescents who provided groundbreaking insights on disruptive behavior among girls, died on Dec. 9 in Minneapolis. She was 93.
