title: Senate Republicans Eye Big Medicaid Cuts
description: Setting the stage for what promises to be one of the most important battles of the coming session, the Senate's Republican majority plans on Monday to propose cutting about $2.5 billion from health insurance for the poor over the next five years. The state would then use much of the savings to relieve counties from having to pay their share of one of the most expensive and fast-growing insurance programs, Family Health Plus.

title: INQUIRY SUGGESTS PAKISTANIS SOLD NUCLEAR SECRETS
description: A lengthy investigation of the father of Pakistan's atomic bomb, Abdul Qadeer Khan, by American and European intelligence agencies and international nuclear inspectors has forced Pakistani officials to question his aides and openly confront evidence that the country was the source of crucial technology to enrich uranium for Iran, North Korea and possibly other nations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GARITY, NATALIE LYONS
description: GARITY--Natalie Lyons. 12/22/89 Remembered with love every day by your family.

description: Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur looked up quickly after the puck rattled around his net, as if that should never happen.

title: Both Sides in a Trial Over Worker Safety Practices at I.B.M. Say Their Cases Are Strong
description: The trial of two retired I.B.M. factory workers accusing the company of knowingly exposing them to dangerous chemicals adjourned for the holidays last week after more than seven weeks of testimony. As the plaintiffs prepare to rest their case, and as I.B.M. prepares its defense, both sides say they like their chances.

title: For a Few Dollars Less, TV Making Moves Abroad
description: The future of television production, like that of many other consumer goods, lies largely in low-cost areas of Asia, especially China. Last month, Thomson, the French electronics company that sells televisions under the RCA brand in the United States, entered into a joint venture with TCL International Holdings of China to form the world's largest maker of TV's, with an expected annual production of 18 million sets.

title: On Familiar Ground, Kerry Labors to Win Over Voters
description: A bone-rattling December wind was blowing when Senator John Kerry started talking to the cameras and the notebooks gathered around him on the street in front of his presidential campaign headquarters here. Wearing a leather bomber jacket bearing the shoulder patches of the units he served with in Vietnam, he made the case he nearly always makes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Shooting Suspect Charged
description: A man who fled after a shootout with the police near Grand Central Parkway and 111th Street early Saturday was arrested yesterday in Manhattan, the police said. The man, George Konstantinides, 37, was found at the bar of the Milford Plaza hotel in Manhattan, law enforcement officials said. On Saturday, the police received a tip that Mr. Konstantinides was seen at Joey's Place, a restaurant and bar at 84-14 Astoria Boulevard. He left in a friend's limousine, threatening the driver with a gun, and when the police overtook the car, he got out and fired at the officers, a police official said. No one was hurt. Mr. Konstantinides was charged with attempted murder, gun possession, and kidnapping, said a spokeswoman for Queens District Attorney Richard A. Brown. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

A memorial Mass will be held on Tuesday, December 23, at 10:30 am, at The Church of St. Thomas More at 65 East 89th Street, NY, NY.

description: The Knicks, struggling with a 10-18 record and playing before empty seats at Madison Square Garden, today fired Scott Layden, their president and general manager, and replaced him with the former all-star Isiah Thomas.

title: Palestinians Attack Egyptian Foreign Minister
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 22 — After a day of meeting with Israel's leaders, Egypt's foreign minister, Ahmed Maher, was attacked and heckled this evening by Muslim radicals inside the Aksa Mosque here, one of the holiest sites in Islam.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: E-Commerce Report; The returns are early, but the new categories of 'stores' on Amazon.com are showing signs of promise.
description: AS in other recent holiday seasons, Amazon.com Inc. this year has successfully peddled the staples -- books, music and videos -- of online gift shoppers. But how about those alligator tenderloins, Callaway drivers and Mikimoto pearls? Amazon.com is wrapping up its first holiday season in which it has featured such goods and others in distinct ''stores,'' or categories. Since September it has opened four stores: gourmet food, sporting goods, jewelry and watches, and (just last week) health and personal care. Retailers who are participating in the new stores and analysts who have watched them closely said Amazon.com's sales in those categories had shown promise.

title: Russia Offers to Forgive 65% of Iraqs Debt
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 22  Russia offered today to forgive about two-thirds of Iraq's $8 billion in debt, after officials of the Iraqi Governing Council signaled that Moscow would have the chance to revive oil contracts signed under Saddam Hussein, its ousted leader.

title: Hope Lange, Versatile Actress And Emmy Winner, Dies at 70
description: Hope Lange, a film, television and stage actress noted for a natural comedic style and intelligent portrayals of women in difficult circumstances, work that brought her two Emmy Awards and an Academy Award nomination, died at a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif., on Friday. She was 70 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day last Monday about a large-format book on Bhutan produced by a computer scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology omitted a credit. The photographer was Jodie Hilton for The New York Times.

title: Good Nukes, Bad Nukes
description: The Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty is arguably the most popular treaty in history: except for five states, every nation in the world is part of it. For more than three decades, it has helped curb the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Freedom of religion is not just to practice the religion of your own, but the freedom and decency to respect someone else's desire. By the way, the tips were pretty good.''

title: Parmalat Is Said to Be Ready To Declare Insolvency in Days
description: Parmalat, the giant Italian dairy foods group, is expected to declare insolvency and seek legal protection from creditors before Christmas, a person close to the company said Sunday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Residents Criticize Arena
description: Opponents of a plan to build a 21-acre arena complex for the New Jersey Nets in the heart of Brooklyn complained yesterday that the plan would displace hundreds of residents. A civic group, the Prospect Heights Action Coalition, said that it had determined that roughly 1,000 people would lose their homes if the plan to build a arena complex at the intersection of Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues goes forward -- far more than the roughly 100 that officials had predicted. A spokesman for the developer, Forest City Ratner, disputed their figure, but Bruce Bender, a vice president at that company, pledged in a statement to ''treat homeowners and renters more than fairly.'' Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: The Trouble With Marvels: If It Sounds That Good, Will the Skeptical Buy It?
description: It sounds almost too good to be true: relieve aches and pains with a simple sock or glove.

title: In Portland, Toast of the Town Goes Belly Up
description: The picture seems to be everywhere in the cafeteria of the Portland Trail Blazers' arena, the Rose Garden; in the foyer of their corporate offices; in the media guide. It is a reminder of a time when the Trail Blazers were the N.B.A.'s premier team and the city's revered supermen.

title: Killing Them Softly, With Her Poem
description: All human beings make mistakes, something that Gov. John Rowland of Connecticut has been telling his constituents on a regular basis lately. The governor's biggest mistake is consistently failing to own up to a bad case of blurry ethics, even as he says he's apologizing. He might also have erred in allowing his wife to recite poetry without a license.

title: Cincinnati Loses Grip On Its Shot At Playoffs
description: The St. Louis Rams know their way to the playoffs. It was the Cincinnati Bengals who arrived seeking a playoff trip Sunday at the Edward Jones Dome, where the Rams had won 13 consecutive regular-season games.

title: White House Letter; A White House Christmas: Crab Cakes and Handshakes
description: When President Bush warned David Gregory of NBC at a news conference last week not to pocket the White House silverware at a coming party, he was a little more than halfway through an Iditarod of holiday receptions at the Executive Mansion. Leaving aside what Mr. Bush's wisecrack says about his attitude toward the news media, it does highlight some of the most arduous socializing the president does all year.

title: Fresh Eye on Wall Street
description: John Thain, a top Goldman Sachs executive, is highly qualified to lead the beleaguered New York Stock Exchange. Among other things, the world's been told, he will not have ''one of those strange retirement packages.'' That curious assurance by John Reed, the interim chairman of the Big Board who announced Mr. Thain's appointment as chief executive last week, speaks volumes about the exchange's need and desire to get beyond the Richard Grasso era. Mr. Grasso stepped down last September amid a scandal about his $187.5 million compensation packages that even board directors barely seemed to understand.

title: BROADWAY: 'OZ' CANCELLATIONS
description: Ten performances of the Broadway musical ''The Boy From Oz'' will be canceled when its star, Hugh Jackman, goes on vacations. Although ''Oz'' was panned by critics when it opened in October, Mr. Jackman received some of the season's most enthusiastic reviews, and the show, a biography of the Australian entertainer and songwriter Peter Allen, has been playing to full houses at the Imperial Theater. Cancellations of this sort are rare on Broadway. Even when stars like Nathan Lane in ''The Producers'' and Bernadette Peters in ''Gypsy'' were forced out by ailments, they were replaced by understudies. Mr. Jackman has an understudy, Kevin Spirtas, but the producers decided that replacing Mr. Jackman would so disappoint members of the audience that many would demand a refund. A spokesman for the show said, ''Due to the brevity of the breaks, the producers feel that it is not practical or feasible to bring in a star replacement.'' Performances will be canceled on Feb. 1, Feb. 3 to Feb. 6, March 28 and March 30 to April 2. To compensate for some of the lost shows, two have been added, on Jan. 26 and March 22. JASON ZINOMAN

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: QUEENS: SHOOTING SUSPECT CHARGED A man who fled after a shootout with the police near Grand Central Parkway and 111th Street early Saturday was arrested yesterday in Manhattan, the police said. The man, George Konstantinides, 37, was found at the bar of the Milford Plaza hotel in Manhattan, law enforcement officials said. On Saturday, the police received a tip that Mr. Konstantinides was seen at Joey's Place, a restaurant and bar at 84-14 Astoria Boulevard. He left in a friend's limousine, threatening the driver with a gun, and when the police overtook the car, he got out and fired at the officers, a police official said. No one was hurt. Mr. Konstantinides was charged with attempted murder, gun possession, and kidnapping, said a spokeswoman for Queens District Attorney Richard A. Brown. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Permits Publication Of Eminem Lyrics
description: A judge ruled yesterday that twenty seconds of a racially charged song by the rap singer Eminem can be included on a CD issued by the hip-hop magazine The Source. U.S. District Judge Gerald E. Lynch permitted excerpts of the song as long as The Source did not seek to profit from the release of the lyrics, but used the material to enhance its investigative report into Eminem's life. Eminem, left, had sought to block the song's release, which he wrote when he was 15. He is now 31. He said it does not reflect his current views, according to his lawyer. A spokesman for The Source said the lyrics would be included on a CD that will be sold with the magazine in early January. Eminem's lawsuit against The Source for copyright infringement is still under way. Faiza Akhtar (NYT)

title: Corrections

(The error also appeared in a correction published on Nov. 19 about both that article and an article on Nov. 16, and in an Op-Ed column on Nov. 13.) The poll showed that 59 percent of respondents regarded Israel as a threat to world peace, a greater percentage than cited any other country. (Other countries mentioned were Iran, North Korea and the United States, each 53 percent; Iraq, 52 percent; Afghanistan, 50 percent; and Pakistan, 48 percent. ) The poll did not find that respondents consider Israel ''the greatest'' threat.

The company is also involved in talks with the hedge funds that own private placement bonds, Ms. Dumas confirmed. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Bank Outlook Raised

The agency lifted its outlook on Bangkok Bank's financial strength rating to positive from stable, citing the bank's sale of 36.9 billion baht ($930 million) in new shares earlier this month, which the agency said would improve the bank's capital position. But Moody's cautioned that while an upgrade might be likely, it would be contingent on Bangkok Bank resolving its remaining problem loans. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: KENYA: THINNING OUT PRISONS President Mwai Kibaki freed 11,546 prisoners to ease crowding in prisons notorious among Kenyans as centers of malnutrition and disease. Kenya's 97 prisons hold tens of thousands of inmates, and the government blames a slow and corrupt judiciary for overcrowding. Most of those freed were petty or first-time offenders with a record of good conduct, a government statement said. (Reuters)

title: Pakistan's Nuclear Commerce
description: The United States has again been given good reason to wonder whether Pakistan is the trustworthy ally it claims to be. Fresh evidence indicates that it has sold nuclear-weapons secrets to Iran, North Korea and perhaps other countries over the years. Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, insists that he stopped such sales after seizing power four years ago. Yet just last year, American spy satellites detected a Pakistani plane picking up North Korean missile parts thought to be part of a swap for Pakistani nuclear technology. The Bush administration must demand stronger controls over Pakistan's nuclear labs, which seem to have been central to the transfers.

title: BRITISH GAS PRODUCER BUYS CAPACITY FROM EL PASO
description: The BG Group of Britain has agreed to buy capacity and contracts at the Elba Island liquefied gas terminal near Savannah, Ga., from the El Paso Corporation, an owner of natural gas pipelines, for $127 million. The accord gives the BG Group, which produces gas in eight countries, the master contract to 446 million cubic feet a day of capacity at the terminal. El Paso, which is based in Houston, is selling gas purchase and supply agreements, advancing its exit from energy trading, a spokesman, Mel Scott, said. Completion of the transaction will settle all disputes between El Paso and its trading partners.

Throughout much of the country, the holidays are a Smallville season of tartan jackets and candy-cane sweaters and plaid patchwork hostess skirts with velvet ribbon belts. It is a period when otherwise sensible readers of, say, Vogue or Foreign Policy can be spotted wearing battery-operated brooches and unfortunate novelty ties.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: QUEEN MARY 2 SETS SAIL The world's largest ocean liner, the Queen Mary 2, slid from its French shipyard in St.-Nazaire into the Atlantic Ocean for a test run that will take it to Spain and its British home port of Southampton. As many as 70,000 people gathered to watch the Cunard Line ship set sail. The occasion was tainted by an accident last month in which 15 people died when a gangway collapsed as they boarded the vessel. The ship is to leave Southampton for its maiden voyage to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Jan. 12. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: New Education Law Is Faulted in Gauging Performance

The papers, filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, specified such costs as court transcripts and fees for expert witnesses. In November, after four years of court battles, the family of Mr. Busch, who was 31, lost their case claiming that the shooting was unjustified when jurors said the officers acted in self-defense as Mr. Busch lunged at them with a hammer. title: GERMAN GROUP TO BUY CALIFORNIA HAIR CARE COMPANY
description: Henkel, the German chemicals group, said it had agreed to acquire the hair care company Advanced Research Laboratories of Costa Mesa, Calif., for an undisclosed price. ''The acquisition will take us a significant step forward in the American hair cosmetics market,'' the company said. Henkel announced last week that it was buying the Dial Corporation, the maker of Dial soap, Renuzit air fresheners and Armour Star canned meats, for about $2.9 billion. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: MACKAY--Jeremiah, 71, died December 20, 2003 from cancer at his Valley Stream home. He was an advertising sales veteran who opened the Long Island sales office of the New York Times in the 1970's. He is survived by his wife Catherine, their daughter Colleen of Santa Monica, CA, sons Jerry of Rockville Centre, Kevin and Brian both of Merrick and four grandchildren. title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 18 about French government efforts to combat an increase in anti-Semitism misstated the result of a recent European Union poll about threats to world peace. (The error also appeared in a correction published on Nov. 19 about both that article and an article on Nov. 16, and in an Op-Ed column on Nov. 13.) The poll showed that 59 percent of respondents regarded Israel as a threat to world peace, a greater percentage than cited any other country. (Other countries mentioned were Iran, North Korea and the United States, each 53 percent; Iraq, 52 percent; Afghanistan, 50 percent; and Pakistan, 48 percent. ) The poll did not find that respondents consider Israel ''the greatest'' threat.

title: Terrorism and Liberty
description: After four years of work, a federal commission on terrorism issued its final report last week. The report was unremarkable except for one recommendation that shone brightly through the usual thicket of bureaucratic prose. Aggressive antiterrorism policies, the report suggested, when combined with increasingly sophisticated surveillance technologies, could have a ''chilling effect'' on the right to privacy and other fundamental civil liberties. To prevent that from happening, the commission recommended that the White House establish a bipartisan panel to review how constitutional guarantees would be affected by all new laws and regulations aimed at enhancing national security.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: CITY SUES VICTIM'S FAMILY Lawyers for New York City filed legal papers yesterday to recover $176,000 for costs that the city incurred in defending a civil suit that centered on the fatal 1999 police shooting of Gidone Busch, a Borough Park, Brooklyn, man with a history of emotional problems. The papers, filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, specified such costs as court transcripts and fees for expert witnesses. In November, after four years of court battles, the family of Mr. Busch, who was 31, lost their case claiming that the shooting was unjustified when jurors said the officers acted in self-defense as Mr. Busch lunged at them with a hammer.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Cognizant Founder Is To Retire
description: The Cognizant Technology Solutions Corporation said yesterday that its founder, Kumar Mahadeva, would retire, and the company's longtime president, Lakshmi Narayanan, would succeed him as chief executive. Mr. Mahadeva, 52, who is also chairman, will leave the software services company in April 2004. John Klein, a board member since 1998, has been appointed nonexecutive chairman. Mr. Narayanan, 50, who has 28 years of experience in the Indian software services industry, joined Cognizant as chief technology officer at its founding in 1994. He has served as president and chief operating officer since 1996. Separately, the company said it would build three additional software development centers in India to house 6,500 new and existing employees. The company, which is based in Teaneck, N.J., previously signaled plans to hire 4,000 new employees in 2004 alone, a spokesman said. Construction of offices in Pune, Madras and Bangalore is set to begin in early 2004, Cognizant said.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Reports Data On High-Speed Net Access
description: The number of homes and businesses connected to the Internet through high-speed lines rose 18 percent in the first half of 2003, but the technology is not spreading as quickly as it did in 2002. Those findings were reported yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission, which tracks the deployment of certain technologies. According to the F.C.C. report, as of June 30, 23.5 million homes and businesses were connected to the Internet through high-speed lines, typically D.S.L. or cable lines, up from 19.9 million at the beginning of the year. That increase, 18 percent, compared with a rise of 23 percent during the second half of 2002. Competition to provide those lines remained fierce between cable companies and telephone companies, which provide D.S.L. During the first half of 2003, the number of D.S.L. lines increased 19 percent to 7.7 million, while high-speed cable access rose 20 percent to 13.7 million lines, the F.C.C. reported. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: EXPRESS SCRIPTS TO ACQUIRE SPECIALTY PHARMACY
description: Express Scripts Inc., the mail-order pharmacy company, agreed to pay $335 million in cash for the closely held CuraScript Pharmacy Inc. to gain new contracts, customers and patient support services. CuraScript, which is controlled by a private equity firm, GTCR Golder Rauner of Chicago, specializes in drugs that treat diseases like cancer and rheumatoid arthritis. It is the largest private company in the United States that offers specialty pharmacy services, and holds contracts with more than 175 managed care companies. The acquisition will give Express Scripts greater leverage in negotiating drug prices, the chief executive, Barrett A. Toan, told investors in a conference call. The deal will start adding to earnings next year, executives said. Express Scripts is based in Maryland Heights, Mo., and CuraScript is based in Orlando, Fla.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Falls
description: Brazil's jobless rate fell in November for the first time in three months as retailers hired staff for the holiday season and manufacturers prepared to increase output. Unemployment in Brazil's six-largest metropolitan areas fell to 12.2 percent in November from 12.9 percent in October, the government said. The rate was 13 percent, a two-year high, in August. Manufacturers in So Paulo state, Brazil's richest and most populous, hired 4,418 people in November, the So Paulo Industry Federation said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: More Corporate Upgrades
description: Standard & Poor's raised more corporate credit ratings than it cut for the first time since 1990, a reflection of cost-cutting efforts and stronger profits by Japanese companies, the ratings agency said. S.&P. raised the ratings of 22 Japanese companies or Japanese subsidiaries of foreign companies, while cutting 18. S.&P. also said 34 companies had the outlook for their rating raised compared with one last year. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Expands

The surplus increased to a greater than expected 990 billion yen ($9 billion) in the month as exports to Asia grew 11 percent. Exports over all, however, fell 2 percent. Japan's surplus with the United States shrank 30 percent, to 548 billion yen ($5 billion). Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Funny, Woody, You Don't Look Klezmer

There Guthrie, the guitar strummer from Oklahoma, wrote about Hanukkah, the Holocaust and his neighborhood, ''where the halvah meets the pickle, where the sour meets the sweet.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 16 Charged In International Cocaine Ring
description: Sixteen people in three countries were charged yesterday with conspiring to import hundreds of kilograms of cocaine into this country from Colombia and the Dominican Republic, federal prosecutors said. The charges were announced hours after the arrests yesterday morning in Colombia of two of the accused ringleaders of the scheme, Paulino de la Salcedo-Genau and Mauricio Rivas-Gomez. Others have been arrested in recent weeks in the New York area and the Dominican Republic, and four people accused in the scheme are fugitives, according to the indictment. The investigation, dubbed Operation Crown Jewel, was the result of joint work by law enforcement agencies in the United States, Colombia, and the Dominican Republic. If convicted, the defendants face a maximum sentence of life in prison. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RANSOHOFF, RITA M.
description: RANSOHOFF--Rita M. Died peacefully at home in Branford, CT December 13, 2003. She is survived by her loving children Joan Wynn and Joseph Ransohoff, grandchildren James, Benjamin, Olivia, Christopher, and Sianna, and son-and daughter-inlaw, Peter Wynn and Debrah A. Ransohoff. Dr. Ransohoff was a psychologist and author of numerous articles and books including ''Venus After Forty'' and ''Fear and Envy.'' In addition to a private therapy practice, she drew on wordwide travel as the basis of her cross-cultural studies of the treatment of women. She was a person of indomitable spirit and never-ending interest in the world who was devoted to friends of all generations, especially her grandchildren. A memorial service is being planned for early in the new year.

title: WAL-MART SAYS SALES PACE ROSE OVER THE WEEKEND
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said that sales picked up over the weekend, the final weekend before Christmas, after a slow start to the holiday shopping season. Sales so far this month at stores that have been open at least a year in the United States have risen at the low end of the company's forecast, which called for an increase of 3 percent to 5 percent over the 2002 period, Wal-Mart said on a recorded call. Wal-Mart, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., will release sales results through Christmas on Friday, Dec. 26. Pharmacy items, electronics, toys and girls' clothing were among merchandise that sold well in the week that ended Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 18 about French government efforts to combat an increase in anti-Semitism misstated the result of a recent European Union poll about threats to world peace. (The error also appeared in a correction published on Nov. 19 about both that article and an article on Nov. 16, and in an Op-Ed column on Nov. 13.) The poll showed that 59 percent of respondents regarded Israel as a threat to world peace, a greater percentage than cited any other country. (Other countries mentioned were Iran, North Korea and the United States, each 53 percent; Iraq, 52 percent; Afghanistan, 50 percent; and Pakistan, 48 percent. ) The poll did not find that respondents consider Israel "the greatest" threat.

description: China's national legislature moved to amend the Constitution on Monday to protect private property rights, the first time the Communist Party has formally protected private wealth since taking power 55 years ago.

description: Since the ancient Greeks, physicians have noted that certain personality types appear more vulnerable to infectious diseases. A new study suggests the reason is the hair-trigger response to stress that is more common among extremely shy or withdrawn people.

description: Fifteen years ago, I flew to San Antonio on my first business trip to monitor a drug trial for a pharmaceutical company. I had reserved a car, but there was a mix-up and the rental agency had to send me to another agency outside the airport. All it had was a pickup truck.

title: MEDI-HUT UNABLE TO VERIFY 2 YEARS OF FINANCIAL RESULTS
description: The Medi-Hut Company said it could not verify its financial results for the years ended Oct. 31, 2001, and Oct. 31, 2002.; some former executives of the company have pleaded guilty to accounting fraud. The company, which is based in Lakewood, N.J., and makes medical supplies, said it would refile reports for affected quarters, removing inaccurate, incomplete and unverifiable information. Three former executives, including the chief executive and the chief financial officer, pleaded guilty in August to conspiracy to inflate revenue and earnings. A fourth former executive pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice. New managers have not been able to locate documents necessary to verify 2001 and 2002 financial results, the company said.

title: The Brain Wave Made Me Do It
description: Scientists have experimented in recent years with machines meant to use brain waves to tell if someone is lying. Now, British researchers say they have figured out a way to use similar brain waves to tell something slightly different: whether someone is about to make a mistake.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Group Sells Towers
description: Shareholders of the Canary Wharf Group approved the sale of two of the group's office towers to Royal Bank of Scotland. Nearly 70 percent of shareholders voted for the sale, which is essential to a proposal from a group led by Morgan Stanley to take over the company. Paul Reichmann, founder of the Canary Wharf Group, and Brascan, a shareholder, oppose the takeover. Heather Timmons (NYT)

description: The world's largest ocean liner, the Queen Mary 2, slid from its French shipyard in St.-Nazaire into the Atlantic Ocean for a test run that will take it to Spain and its British home port of Southampton. As many as 70,000 people gathered to watch the Cunard Line ship set sail. The occasion was tainted by an accident last month in which 15 people died when a gangway collapsed as they boarded the vessel. The ship is to leave Southampton for its maiden voyage to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Jan. 12. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

description: The Ford Motor Company announced a sweeping restructuring yesterday of its relationship with the Visteon Corporation, its main parts supplier. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSELL, THOMAS W. JR.
description: RUSSELL--Thomas W. Jr. ''Tuck'' died peacefully at home in Essex, CT., on December 20, 2003. Beloved husband of the late Mary Ferguson, father of Tom, Jennifer, and Sarah, and step-grandfather of Kari Katzander and Karena Rasser. He graduated from Yale in 1939 and spent most of his business life at Abex Corporation, from which he retired as Chairman in 1970. At various times he was an elder of the Brick Presbyterian Church, senior warden of St. Johns Church, Fishers Island, New York, a member of the Metropolitan Opera Association, a director of the Opera Guild, and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, December 28, at 12:15 PM at the Union Chapel, Fishers Island. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Ralph Gabriel Scholarship Fund at Yale University would be appreciated (PO Box 803, New Haven, CT 06503).

description: According to legend, New Yorkers have hundreds of names for snow, depending on whether it is the stuff under the spinning tire of a car trying to escape being plowed in, the puffy or sticky mound on your snow shovel just as you begin to ponder the statistics of heart attacks, the streaks flying like sprites across an airport runway or the missiles stinging your face as you trudge up an urban canyon under a load of packages, the goop of suspicious integrity lying in wait as you step off the curb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POSILLICO, JOSEPH D. JR.
description: POSILLICO--Joseph D. Jr., on Sunday, December 21, at the age of 64, in his Huntington Bay Home. President of J.D., Posillico, Inc., Mr. Posillico was respected and admired by all in his field as an exceptional leader with a vast knowledge of the construction industry. His independent spirit and generosity were inspirational to all who touched his life. He has been a prominent member of the Long Island community for over 40 years. For the past 15 years, Joe served as President of J.D. Posillico, Inc., one of the most prestigious and largest heavy construction firms. He was a member of the Columbus Club and served on the Columbus Day Committee for the annual parade. Joe gave his time, energy and efforts to numerous charities and civil organizations including the Long Island Contractor's Association and Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Building Fund and Golf Outing. An avid golfer, Mr. Posillico was a member of the Huntington Crescent Club, North Fork Country Club, Gardiner's Bay Country Club, Jupiter Hills Country Club and Carnegie Abbey. He is survived by his beloved wife of 36 years, Whitney, and six children; Katherine Posillico McGowan, Joseph III, Wendy, Paul, Frank and Thomas Posillico. Cherished grandfather to Taylor McGowan and Grace Posillico. Joe is also survived by his two brothers, Dominic and Mario. Visitation is scheduled for Tuesday, 2-5 pm and 7-9 pm at M.A. Connell Funeral Home in Huntington. The Funeral Mass will be held 11 am Wednesday at St. Killian's Roman Catholic Church in Farmingdale. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Joseph D. Posillico Jr. Memorial Fund, c/o J.D. Posillico, Inc., 1610 New Highway, Farmingdale, New York 11735. We will miss him dearly and always remember him as a devoted husband, father, friend and a great man.

description: In the dim room at Noble Horizons, a long-term-care center in Salisbury, Conn., glow-in-the-dark stars shone faintly. Colored bubbles rose in a tall lighted column before a mirror. Fiber-optic strands winked orange, yellow and ice white. In recliners, three elderly people sat comfortably, holding teddy bears. Music played softly as scenes of an autumn woods -- a country fence, a deer -- were projected on a wall.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Symantec Wins $3 Million Judgment
description: The Symantec Corporation, the world's biggest maker of antivirus and antispam software, won a $3 million legal judgment against a company that sent unsolicited e-mail selling counterfeit Symantec programs. Symantec filed suit against Baltimore-based Maryland Internet Marketing in April, asserting it advertised unauthorized copies of programs including Norton SystemWorks, Norton AntiVirus and pcAnywhere via spam messages. Judge Percy Anderson of Federal District Court in Los Angeles ruled that Maryland Internet and its president, George Moore, must halt the sales and pay Symantec. Shares of Symantec rose 31 cents, to $33.90.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Lender Rescued
description: The country's biggest credit-card concern, the LG Card Company, will borrow 300 billion won ($252 million) this month, the second time in a month creditors have stepped in to support it. Woori Bank, Kookmin Bank and the National Agricultural Cooperative Federation will each lend 100 billion won for a month, a Woori spokesman, Kim Ki Rin, said. They are among eight banks that provided emergency loans of 2 trillion won in November to save the company from bankruptcy. LG Card, which is based in Seoul, ran into trouble after a credit boom turned sour, leaving more than 3.6 million Koreans behind on payments by at least 90 days in October, about 1 million more than a year earlier. The company's parent, LG Group, agreed to permit creditors to auction its controlling stake this month to avert a collapse.

description: The U.N. Children's Fund estimated in a report that 11 million children under 15 in sub-Saharan Africa have lost at least one parent to AIDS.

title: Holiday-Appropriate Clothing
description: There is one rule for seasonal dressing in Manhattan: However you choose to get yourself up at Christmas, do not show up the shrubbery.

title: Comically Focused on Mysterious Tasks
description: Modern dance from Eastern Europe has not been known for its lightness of spirit. So a program on Saturday night at the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church was a revelation. It was part of Central Station, an ambitious festival of Eastern and Central European dance.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: CYPRUS: NEW GOVERNMENT SOUGHT The Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash said he would ask one of the enclave's party leaders to try to form a new government. A general election on Dec. 14 in the Turkish Cypriot-held north of Cyprus returned a parliament evenly split between supporters and opponents of a United Nations plan for reunifying the island, complicating the task of forming a government. A settlement has become pressing because the internationally recognized Greek Cypriot government will join the European Union in May. (Reuters)

title: While reshaping a nation, they may also help reshape the EU : Changing times for Poland's youth
description: KRAKOW:  They are restless, hardworking and, according to one Polish sociologist, the "best-educated generation in the 1,000 years of Polish history."

title: Dave Dudley, 75, Pioneer of Truckers' Songs
description: Dave Dudley, the pioneer of truck-driving country songs and a former radio D.J. who recorded more than 40 country hits from 1961 to 1980, died on Monday in Danbury, Wis. He was 75.

title: Auction of LG Card Fails to Draw Bidders
description: An attempt to sell South Korea's largest credit card company, the LG Card Company, failed to attract a single bidder, as a Tuesday deadline for bids passed without any show of interest.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: STEVEN KOUTSOUMBARIS , left, the former chef de cuisine at March restaurant, is now the executive chef at Agata & Valentina, the Upper East Side fancy-food shop. But his responsibilities will go beyond making shrimp salad and lasagna to take out. In the spring, he will also run the kitchen at AGATA & VALENTINA FOOD BAR , which is to open opposite the store at 1513 First Avenue (79th Street), with a restaurant, a cafe and a wine bar.

title: Accounts
description: Pentax U.S.A., Golden, Colo., a camera and optical equipment manufacturer, to Della Femina Rothschild Jeary & Partners, New York, as agency of record on its account, which had been handled internally. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. The first campaign from Della Femina Rothschild, owned by top managers and the Omnicom Group, will promote Pentax digital cameras. Pentax U.S.A. is part of the Pentax Corporation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Loan Is Paid Off
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the developer Larry A. Silverstein used $702 million in insurance proceeds from the World Trade Center complex yesterday to pay off a lender and the company that operated the retail mall at the complex. In what he said was an effort to ease the rebuilding process, Mr. Silverstein paid GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation $562 million to satisfy the loan he took out when he leased the trade center in 2001. The Port Authority simultaneously paid Westfield America $140 million for its retail interest in the trade center. The deal allowed Mr. Silverstein to get back most of the $125 million in equity he and his partners put into the winning bid for the trade center leases. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Rangers Say Rodriguez Is Going to Stay in Texas
description: The continuing trade proposal that would put Alex Rodriguez in Fenway Park and send Manny Ramirez to Texas may have finally suffered a fatal hit yesterday after the Rangers made a substantial financial concession three hours before a team-imposed deadline but could not entice the Red Sox to complete the deal.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Hepatitis Cases Traced To Restaurant
description: Six people who ate at a pizza restaurant in Monroe have contracted hepatitis A, state health officials said yesterday. In November, an employee of the restaurant, McGowan's Pizzaland, fell ill with the disease, and that same month, six people who dined there also contracted the disease. The source of the outbreak is not known. The restaurant is closed and will reopen after an inspection by health officials. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Short-Order Cooks?
description: To the Editor:

title: VICE CHAIRMAN OF TIME WARNER TO STEP DOWN
description: The vice chairman of Time Warner, Kenneth J. Novack, an adviser to the former chairman, Stephen M. Case, said yesterday that he would step down at the end of the year to join his former law firm. Mr. Novack, 62, will remain on the board of Time Warner. Mr. Novack had served as outside legal counsel to America Online since the late 1980's and was its vice chairman in 2001 when America Online bought Time Warner. Mr. Novack said he would rejoin the law firm of Mintz Levin Cohen Ferris Glovsky & Popeo in Boston as senior counsel.

title: Earnestly Striving Onward, But With Wit
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater sparkled on Thursday night at City Center.

title: A Fast Bite Of Mexico
description: IN the world of fresh pastry, few things are quicker than churros -- those crullerlike strips of crisp fried dough that are street-corner snacks in Spain, Mexico and some New York City subway stations. In fact, there are few breakfast dishes or last-minute late-night snacks that can match a batch of churros.

title: The Ritual of Breakfast, Without the Stress
description: CONSIDERING how truly great breakfast can be, it is a shame that people rarely eat it properly. The decline of breakfast, a real cooked breakfast, is primarily a practical issue: few people have the time to eat it, let alone make it. But I think there is a psychological factor at play, too. Those of us who were brought up to believe that breakfast is the most important meal of the day never quite shook off the feeling, once grown up, that snatching a cup of black coffee on the run was an act of cool rebellion.

title: Panel Is Said to Study Harassment Accusation Against Councilman
description: The City Council's ethics committee held a closed-door session yesterday to discuss what several officials said were accusations of sexual harassment against Allan W. Jennings Jr., a maverick Democratic councilman from Queens.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Sayreville: Malfunction At Power Station
description: A malfunction last night in a power distribution station left nine communities in the northern and central part of the state without electricity. Employees at the station, owned by Jersey Central Power and Light, were working on the power distribution grid about 9 p.m. when a mechanical failure sparked several small fires, said Barry Eck, deputy coordinator for Sayreville's Office of Emergency Management. The fires were quickly put out, though power to the area cut out for about 90 minutes. George Sous, a spokesman for Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the largest power supplier in New Jersey, said about 30,000 of its customers temporarily lost power. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Santa Before His Beard And Some Bad-Boy Cheer
description: Tampering with the original Christmas mystery -- angels, shepherds, virgin birth -- would seem hazardous. Some might see it as an effort to improve on the Bible.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Food Units Sold
description: Northern Foods, the British maker of Goodfella's frozen pizza, is selling two Irish units, Batchelors Ltd. and Beck Smith Ltd., to a company owned by Barry's Tea and the Bank of Scotland (Ireland) for 62 million euros ($77 million). The units make and distribute food and drink products under brands like Batchelors, Sqeez and Amigo, the company said. The proceeds will be used to cut debt. Northern Foods, based in Hull, England, has closed cake and dessert plants and sold units to focus on prepared meals.

title: Hotels.com Begins Review of Account
description: Hotels.com in Dallas has begun a review for the creative portion of its account, which had been handled internally and on a project basis. Billings were estimated at more than $60 million.

title: Due Process for Priests
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Inspections for Disease Lag Behind Those Abroad
description: In discussing the case of mad cow disease apparently found in Washington State, Secretary of Agriculture Ann M. Veneman said yesterday that her department tested 20,526 cattle for mad cow disease last year. But that is only a small percentage of the 35 million commercially slaughtered each year.

title: Lawyers Take Suspicions On TV Azteca To Its Board
description: In one of the first applications of a new provision of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, outside lawyers for Mexico's second-largest broadcaster have told its board -- and, possibly, federal regulators -- that they think that the company violated United States securities laws.

title: Mob Story Plays Out to the Usual Ending. Nobody Moved.
description: Maybe Louis Barone was enjoying the soprano's suppertime rendition of ''Don't Rain on My Parade.'' Or maybe he had a strict habit of defending the honor of dames.

title: Strange Symphonic Bedfellows Despite Their Commonalities
description: Zubin Mehta and the Israel Philharmonic offered a new concept in theme programming last Wednesday night: symphonies that have the same number. Their concert at Carnegie Hall paired the Schubert Sixth with the Mahler Sixth, and six is surely all those two symphonies have in common. No, wait -- both were by Viennese composers. Both grapple with classical symphonic form. Why, the similarities abound.

title: Baghdad and Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Origin of Species: The Cocktail, Classified
description: THE English language badly needs a word to describe the thing that bartenders do. The important work of putting together spirits and flavorings in the combinations we call cocktails deserves a decent name, but there isn't one. ''Mixology'' is the best of a bad lot, a coinage that harks back to the overripe, mock-elevated style used by writers like H. L. Mencken, Herbert Asbury and Lucius Beebe, for whom drinks were inevitably ''libations,'' ''tinctures'' or ''potions.''

title: The Elephant and the Chili Pepper
description: Farmers in the Zambezi Valley of Zimbabwe have hit on a novel way to keep elephants from trampling their fields. They surround their crops with rows of chili peppers, whose smell is noxious to elephants. The peppers prevent battles that have harmed both man and animal, save crops and give farmers a lucrative new product to export.

title: No Joke! 37 Years After Death Lenny Bruce Receives Pardon
description: Lenny Bruce, the potty-mouthed wit who turned stand-up comedy into social commentary, was posthumously pardoned yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki, 39 years after being convicted of obscenity for using bad words in a Greenwich Village nightclub act.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Parametric Distributes Patch To Correct Flaw
description: The Parametric Technology Corporation, whose software is used by engineers at companies including Boeing and Toyota Motor, is distributing a patch to correct a flaw that will cause its programs to fail next month. Installation and communications functions in programs including the company's Pro/Engineer and Windchill software will cease to operate at 8:37 a.m. Eastern time on Jan. 10 unless the patch is used, Parametric said on its Web site yesterday. The software will consider Jan. 10 as an end point for the programs, similar to the way the year 2000 could have caused date-related problems for systems. Needham, Mass.-based Parametric, which discovered the flaw on Dec. 12, does not know why this date was set. Costs to fix the flaw will not hurt profit, and a specific estimate of those costs has not been determined, a spokesman, Joe Gavaghan, said. Pro/Engineer and Windchill permit computer-aided design and allow access to other Parametric programs that let designers inside and outside a company work on a project together and see changes in real time. Shares of Parametric fell 5 cents, to $3.85.

title: The News From Gotham: Courtesy Lives!
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALOMON, WALTER
description: SALOMON--Walter, 83. On December 22, 2003. Beloved husband of Eva for 58 years. Devoted father of Linda. Loving brother of Hans. Dear uncle of Mark and Garry. Services Wednesday 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Is for Apple Cider, Sparkling and Intense
description: ALTHOUGH they look harmless enough, grapes are tyrants, dominating fermented fruit beverages without rival. Only one fruit can make even the faintest claim to stand up among grapes: the apple.

title: An Enormous Landmark Joins Graveyard of Malls
description: No holiday bells ring through the Mall of Memphis this season. No holly, ribbons or blinking white lights bedeck the halls, where just 13 of 160 stores remain open. This giant, two-level, windowless monolith, with 90 acres of roof and yellow-striped parking lots, billed as the biggest mall in the mid-South, is going out of business at 6 p.m. on Christmas Eve.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Research In Motion Shares Soar On Profit News
description: Shares of Research in Motion, the maker of BlackBerry wireless e-mail pagers, had their biggest percentage increase ever after the company said yesterday that profit this quarter and next would exceed analysts' estimates. The company, based in Waterloo, Ontario, said late Monday that it added 154,000 subscribers in its third quarter for a total of 865,000, and revenue more than doubled. Research in Motion has lured customers with added features like color screens, Internet browsers and information organizers. Subsidies from wireless carriers have lowered the cost to consumers, and the company's co-chief executive, James L. Balsillie, said the company was adding manufacturing capacity to meet demand. Research in Motion's United States shares rose $23.51, or 51 percent, to $69.61. (Bloomberg News)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Extension Cords Are Recalled
description: Nearly 60,000 outdoor extension cords that were sold at Family Dollar Stores in the United States have been recalled, federal officials said, because they might cause those who handle them to be shocked or electrocuted. The stores and the manufacturer, the Royal United Corporation of North Bergen, N.J., announced the recall along with the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The 25-foot cords, called Durex Procraft Outdoor Extension Cords, should be returned to the stores for a refund, company officials said. John Files (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLIS, GWENDOLYN HANDY
description: WILLIS--Gwendolyn Handy. Devoted mother of Philip and Christopher, beloved sister of Albert, doting grandmother of Spencer, Kirsten and Britt. We remember her for her wit and lively spirit. Services December 30, 11AM at Church of Heavenly Rest, NYC.

title: Food Agency Cuts Zimbabwe Rations and Warns of Shortages
description: A shortfall of international aid has forced the World Food Program to halve the food ration for 2.6 million malnourished people in Zimbabwe, and aid officials say supplies for that country of some staples like cooking oil will completely run out early next month.

title: Former Illinois Governor Denies Corruption
description: George Ryan, former governor of Illinois, pleaded not guilty Tuesday to federal charges of racketeering conspiracy, mail and tax fraud, and lying to the authorities to cover up those crimes.

title: Once Skeptical, Briton Sees Iraqi Success
description: When Maj. Gen. Graeme Lamb, a 50-year-old Briton, arrived in June to lead the mainly European force controlling southeastern Iraq, he was skeptical, he said. He felt that ''this is going to be a lot more difficult than we realized.''

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 465 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Phone License Given Up
description: The financially troubled German wireless provider MobilCom has returned a license to offer third-generation, or 3G, cellphone service to the German government. The company said giving back the license, valued at $10.4 million, would allow it to offer more traditional cell service. MobilCom had little choice: its former partner, France Tlcom, pulled out of an agreement to finance a 3G network, and the cost of the license almost bankrupted the German company. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: For Builder Who Flew Pataki to St. Barts, Progress in the Meadowlands
description: A real estate developer who took Gov. George E. Pataki and his wife to St. Barts on a private jet in November stands to benefit from a $150 million railroad spur into the Meadowlands in New Jersey that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey approved two weeks ago.

title: Mourning Goes Home Four Days After Surgery
description: Including fans, friends and one former Knicks star, 500 people offered to donate a kidney to Alonzo Mourning.

title: An Eye For Essential Emotion; The Photographer David Douglas Duncan Distills a Lucky Life
description: David Douglas Duncan is the first to admit he is lucky: certainly lucky to have emerged unscathed from combat photography in World War II, Korea, Vietnam and several smaller conflicts; lucky to have become a friend of one of the 20th century's most famous artists, Pablo Picasso, about whom he published six coffee-table books; lucky to be in good health as his 88th birthday approaches in January.

title: A Japanese Fantasy, Baked in Manhattan
description: When Lady M cakes from Japan were introduced in New York, they had to be ordered individually, were made by hand by a solitary baker and cost about $90. Now the company has expanded, and the elegant, party-worthy cakes are sold for less stratospheric prices on the lower level at Takashimaya, 693 Fifth Avenue (55th Street), where customers can taste a sample. The large signature cake, made with 20 thin crepes layered with custard and serving 12 to 14, is $65; the smaller size, for 4 to 6, is $35. A chocolate cake with caramel, an apple cake with almond paste and shortbread, and a gossamer cheesecake are $55 to $70 in the large size. Cakes can be ordered a day in advance at (212) 861-9094, and will be delivered in Manhattan for $10 extra. Elsewhere, commercial delivery charges are added.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAUM, ALFRED
description: DAUM--Alfred. Of Syosset, N.Y. Devoted husband of the late Annette. Beloved father of Elliot Jay, Russell Alan and Sandra Michele. Loving father-in-law of Lynne and Kathryn. Services Friday, 10AM, December 26 at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I.

title: British Commander Sees Change in Iraq
description: A British general who is about to hand over his command of an area of southern Iraq with five million inhabitants said recent developments -- including the capture of Saddam Hussein and progress in restoring oil installations, power stations and running water -- have fostered a new confidence that the occupation can achieve its goal of building a stable Iraq and handing the country back to its people.

title: Sidney Rand, 87, President Of College and Ambassador
description: Sidney A. Rand, a Lutheran elder statesman who served as president of St. Olaf College and as United States ambassador to Norway, died on Dec. 16 in Northfield, Minn. He was 87.

title: Hollinger Auditor Quits
description: Hollinger Inc., the company that Conrad Black uses to control his newspaper empire, said its auditor, KPMG, resigned after the company's board refused to make management changes the firm requested.

title: Vivendi Pays $50 Million In Settlement With S.E.C.
description: Vivendi Universal agreed yesterday to pay $50 million to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it misled investors in its news releases and financial statements.

title: Judge Denounces Attorney General's Death-Penalty Push
description: A prominent federal judge in Brooklyn has added his voice to those of prosecutors who have been quietly seething because Attorney General John Ashcroft regularly overrules them and directs that they seek capital punishment when they have recommended against it.

title: Arizona Indians Turn to Real Estate Development
description: Rechanda Howard, a soft-spoken member of the Salt River Pima-Maricopa Indian Community, remembers how her grandfather, Joseph Ray, used to talk about the 90 acres of remote arid land that the federal government allotted to his family in 1913. ''He said the land would never be worth anything,'' said Mrs. Howard, now a grandmother herself.

title: Around Tree, Smiles Even for Wives No. 2 and 3
description: This is that time of year for those family holiday stories that grow so saccharine that when you finish them all your teeth ache. Merriment all around. Mom and dad. Brother and sister. And yes, the little grandchildren.

title: A Chinese Jewel in Melbourne, Striving Toward Perfection
description: THE flower drum, so called because it is shaped like a Chinese flower vase, is one of the world's oldest musical instruments. It is depicted on shells from the Shang dynasty, which ended around 1050 B.C.

title: Massacre in Nanjing
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Israelis Kill 8 in Camp Raid

title: Gephardt Exudes Confidence That He Can Defeat Dean
description: The question for Representative Richard A. Gephardt came from a would-be supporter troubled by a nagging question. Can an earnest and dogged presidential candidate still struggling to raise money actually beat Howard Dean?

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Justice Dept. Rules On 2 Music Services
description: Online music services sponsored by record companies do not violate antitrust laws, the Justice Department said yesterday. The department announced that it was closing its investigation of two services, Pressplay and MusicNet, created as joint ventures of the industry. Fledgling independent services had argued that the record labels were trying to stifle their companies, but in a statement, R. Hewitt Pate, assistant attorney general in charge of the department's antitrust division, said that the emergence of services like Apple's iTunes ''belies any concerns that the record labels used their joint ventures to stifle the development of the Internet music marketplace.'' John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Unwrapped Gifts, Ribbons, Mud and Tears
description: Though the earthquake on Monday was felt from Los Angeles to San Francisco, its destructive epicenter was here in this small central California city where two women died, nearly 50 buildings were damaged, sulfur springs bubbled through the streets and the historic clock tower crumbled to the ground.

title: Better Judges for New York
description: The news about State Supreme Court judges in Brooklyn grows worse every week. Now we have a few of the borough's jurists admitting that they had been given a list of lawyers approved for them by the local Democratic machine. The lawyers, party favorites, would be prime candidates for the most lucrative legal work handed out from the bench. The worst part is that this is probably legal unless somebody involved was actually dumb enough to verbalize the link between the party's work in electing judges and the judges' work in giving out favors to party regulars.

title: What did Olympics bring Sydney?
description: SYDNEY:  Suddenly the thin blue line reappears, zigzagging across the lanes like a taxi driver seeking the shortest route.

title: A large increase in revenue at Cond Nast may come with an asterisk next to its rate card figures.
description: IN a year of a general economic rebound, the magazine industry has experienced little of the bounce. Cond Nast Publications, however, is expected to finish this year with nearly $300 million more in advertising revenues than last year, or a spurt of about 34 percent, as measured by Publisher's Information Bureau, or P.I.B., the industry's clearinghouse for such information.

title: From a Young Teacher, a Way to Get Donors for Class Projects
description: Charles Best has always been more than he seems.

title: Some Find an Ailing Company's Debt Attractive
description: At their depressed prices, the bank debt and bonds of Parmalat are attracting some investors, but specialists in the securities of troubled companies say they are proceeding cautiously because of continued uncertainty over Parmalat's finances and the course of its bankruptcy.

title: BAXTER INTERNATIONAL LOWERS 2003 PROFIT FORECAST
description: Baxter International, the world's biggest maker of blood-disease therapies, reduced its 2003 profit forecast a third time. Baxter said it now expected net income to be $1.52 to $1.55 a share, down from an October estimate of $1.65 to $1.75. Baxter cut its fourth-quarter earnings forecast because of lower-than-expected income from selling assets, including a stake in Acambis, a British vaccine maker. Fourth-quarter profit from continuing operations will be 62 cents to 65 cents a share, Baxter said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected 68 cents. Sales for the year will still increase 8 percent to 10 percent, Baxter said.

title: Letters
description: Elbows on the Table

title: In Battle Over a Settlement, It's Israelis vs. Israelis
description: The Hebrew signs posted along the road to this hilltop settlement in the West Bank say, ''The Battle Begins in Migron,'' and on Tuesday as a thousand or more people arrived in a caravan of cars and vans and buses, ostensibly to put a Torah scroll into the synagogue, it was clear that the battle had begun.

title: KRISPY KREME NAMES A CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts has hired Michael Phalen from CIBC World Markets, the securities arm of the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, to succeed Randy Casstevens as chief financial officer. Mr. Casstevens, who has worked for Krispy Kreme since 1993 and became chief financial officer in January 2002, resigned to pursue personal interests, the company said. At CIBC, Mr. Phalen was an executive director of corporate finance, handling relationships with clients including Krispy Kreme. Previously, he was on a team at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown that managed Krispy Kreme's April 2000 initial public offering. Krispy Kreme is based in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: Excerpts From the Agriculture Secretary's News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference on Tuesday by Ann M. Veneman, the secretary of agriculture, about a finding of mad cow disease in Washington State, as recorded by The New York Times. The full text is online at www.nytimes.com/science.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Italy, North to South, Before the Curtain
description: FATE has dealt Azalea a couple of tough cards. The restaurant sits right next to a parking garage, so patrons on the west side of the dining room, if they peek out the window, can watch an endless parade of S.U.V.'s roll by as curtain time approaches on Broadway. The dining room itself is an awkward L shape, so narrow along the tall part of the letter that dinner is a nonstop game of bump-the-waiter if you sit with your back exposed to the traffic lane. Close quarters feel even closer because the room is overdecorated, with complicated blond-wood paneling and many, many Georgia O'Keeffe flower prints.

title: A Dividing Line Over Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Inventing a New Iraq
description: Early in the new year, Iraqi leaders are supposed to agree on an interim constitution, the first benchmark in the Bush administration's plan for transferring power to a transitional Iraqi government by summer. But, as America's administrator in Iraq, Paul Bremer III, reported to President Bush on Monday, Iraqis have still not reached an agreement on how that transitional government will be chosen or how power will be shared among the country's mutually suspicious religious and ethnic communities. These issues must be thrashed out in the coming weeks. Unless formulas can be found that satisfy Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds, Washington will not leave behind a stable, democratic Iraq.

title: Russian Court Extends Oil Chief's Detention
description: A Russian court on Tuesday extended the detention period for Russia's richest man, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, to March 25, well after the scheduled date of Russia's presidential elections. Lawyers for Mr. Khodorkovsky, the former chief of the oil company Yukos, said they would appeal the court's decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIVES, REGINALD W.W.
description: RIVES--Reginald W.W. Of Shrewsbury, MA, died December 22. Retired Norton Company Safety Specialist. He leaves two sons and a daughter, ten grandchildren, one great-grandchild. Funeral service Friday December 26 at 10AM in St. Luke's Church, Worcester, MA. Memorial donations may be made to St. Luke's Church Endowment Fund, 921 Pleasant St, Worcester, MA, 01602. www.callahanbrothers.com

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the ways Washington University in St. Louis improved its ranking in the annual survey by U.S. News & World Report missstated the name of a graduate student from South Korea who said she was attracted by the high rank of its social work school. She is Yunkyung Jung, not Yun Kyung.

title: Pennington Gets Defensive for Hackett
description: Jets quarterback Chad Pennington vehemently defended the team's offensive coordinator, Paul Hackett, on Tuesday, taking the blame for three clock-management mix-ups against the New England Patriots and calling criticism of Hackett ''annoying.''

title: Recipe: Cheeseball With Red Pepper, Olives and Smoked Paprika
description: Time: 20 minutes plus 2 hours' chilling

title: Mayor Says He'll Increase Security at Dangerous Schools
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg promised yesterday to crack down on violence in the public schools by flooding the most dangerous ones with additional safety agents and police officers and imposing swifter and tougher disciplinary measures, including a ''three strikes and you're out'' policy for repeat offenders.

title: A Hunan Holiday
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THROPE, MILDRED
description: THROPE--Mildred. Age 98, on December 23, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Devoted mother of Ryna Bab and David. Cherished grandmother of Andrew Bab, Emily Kirsch, Jeffrey, James and great-grandmother of Jason, Rebecca and Benjamin. Graveside service Wednesday 1:00 pm at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: NIKE SAYS LEBRON JAMES SNEAKER HAD STRONG DEBUT
description: Nike said its sneaker designed for the professional basketball player LeBron James was the biggest-selling new footwear in at least two years. About 33 percent of the retail stock of the shoes, which are called Air Zoom Generation and list at $110 a pair, was sold on Saturday, the first day of sales, said Scott Reames, a Nike spokesman. The company, based in Beaverton, Ore., considers similar releases successful if 25 percent of the stock sells in the first week, he said. In May, Nike signed Mr. James, who was the top pick in this year's National Basketball Association draft and plays for the Cleveland Cavaliers, to the richest endorsement contract ever for a rookie.

title: McDyess's Knee Is Acting Up
description: Antonio McDyess's surgically repaired left knee was sore and swollen before the game, and he was able to play only nine minutes -- all in the first half -- in last night's defeat to the Minnesota Timberwolves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAFF, ETHEL K.
description: BAFF--Ethel K. Much loved mother, grandmother, great grandmother. Died in peace December 22, 2003.

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP PURCHASE AIDS FLORIDA EXPANSION
description: Colonial BancGroup, a bank holding company with operations in six Southeastern states, agreed yesterday to buy P.C.B. Bancorp for $141 million in stock and cash to expand in Florida. The purchase will be paid with 75 percent stock and 25 percent cash, the company said. P.C.B., with assets of $664 million and deposits of $519 million as of Sept. 30, operates 16 branches through four subsidiaries, all in Florida. Colonial, based in Montgomery, Ala., has more than 270 offices in Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Nevada, Tennessee and Texas.

title: Giants' Change Stirs Lives of Assistants
description: A year and a half ago, the Giants' tight-ends coach, Mike Pope, and the team's top draft pick, Jeremy Shockey, were still getting to know each other. So, while the Giants were in Canton, Ohio, for their opening preseason game, Pope arranged to visit the Pro Football Hall of Fame with Shockey.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Wednesday about an ABC television interview in which President Bush discussed a constitutional amendment on same-sex marriage quoted him incompletely. (The quotation was also incomplete in a front-page article on Sunday about a New York Times/CBS News poll showing widespread support for an amendment to ban same-sex marriage.) What the president said was, ''If necessary, I will support a constitutional amendment which would honor marriage between a man and a woman, codify that.'' The Wednesday article, while omitting the words ''if necessary'' from the quotation, did specify them in a separate paragraph.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Inside the N.F.L. column on Friday about the Detroit Lions referred incorrectly to their losing streak in road games. Their loss to the Kansas City Chiefs on Dec. 14, their 23rd in a row, tied the National Football League record; it did not put the Lions a game away from a tie. The Lions broke the record on Sunday when they lost to the Carolina Panthers.

title: A Sweet Dream for Sweet Cream: Butter Puts On a French Accent

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon And WorldCom Settle Connection Dispute
description: Verizon Communications agreed yesterday to pay WorldCom $169 million to settle a dispute over network-connection fees. Since 1997, the companies have been arguing over whether their interconnection agreement requires Verizon to pay fees to WorldCom for calls made by Verizon customers to Internet service providers that are customers of WorldCom. As part of the settlement, Verizon also agreed to interconnection rates intended to avoid future litigation or arbitration. ''Approval of the settlement agreement will result in the adoption of amendments to the interconnection agreements that will resolve the uncertainties by establishing a rate regime applicable for a period of three years,'' WorldCom said in a motion filed Friday in Bankruptcy Court in New York. A hearing has been scheduled for Monday, during which Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez, who is presiding over the WorldCom bankruptcy, will hear arguments on whether to approve the settlement. Calls and pages to a WorldCom representative were not immediately answered.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: TRADE CENTER LOAN IS PAID OFF The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the developer Larry A. Silverstein used $702 million in insurance proceeds from the World Trade Center complex yesterday to pay off a lender and the company that operated the retail mall at the complex. In what he said was an effort to ease the rebuilding process, Mr. Silverstein paid GMAC Commercial Mortgage Corporation $562 million to satisfy the loan he took out when he leased the trade center in 2001. The Port Authority simultaneously paid Westfield America $140 million for its retail interest in the trade center. The deal allowed Mr. Silverstein to get back most of the $125 million in equity he and his partners put into the winning bid for the trade center leases. He is still waging a legal battle against his insurers, claiming that he is entitled to a double payment totaling nearly $7 million. So far, the insurers have paid $1.9 billion in claims.    Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

Third of four daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Garner Reed (Florance Hofflin), Mrs. Bodman was predeceased by her husband Edward Dunham Bodman (1991). She is survived by her daughter Alexandra Veit Schwaller of Carbondale, Colorado and her son Richard Veit of Staten Island, NY, her sister Anne, Mrs. Frederick Witherby of Boston, two granddaughters and two grandsons. Educated in New York at Dalton School and Chapin, and graduate of Bennington College, Mrs. Bodman worked for The Office of War Information (WW II) in New York, The Partisan Review, and briefly at the New Yorker, and Reader's Digest as well as Planned Parenthood. She was a devoted volunteer teaching children with learning difficulties at the Star Learning Center of St. Matthew's and St. Timothy's Church (NY). Member of The Cosmopolitan Club (NY) and the Wadawanuck Club, Stonington, and a lifetime resident of Tuckernuck Island, Nantucket, Mass. Burial will be private in Tyringham, Mass. Memorial services will be announced post holidays in New York and Stonington. In lieu of, flowers donations may be made to the Elizabeth Reed Keller Fund at Bennington College, Phillips Exeter Academy, for scholarships for Asian students in Edward Dunham Bodman's name, or The Tuckernuck Land Trust.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Immigrants Found In Refrigerated Truck

The immigrants, from Mexico and Central and South America, had been riding in the 38-degree trailer for as long as 10 hours and were cold and damp but did not require medical attention, the authorities said. The driver of the truck and a companion were jailed. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; A Woman and Four Children, Making Do in a Shelter
description: In June, Loretta Skaggs and her four children, Donovan, Dana, Aliyah and Tami, lost their apartment in Peekskill, N.Y. Ms. Skaggs said the building changed ownership, the landlord raised the rent to more than she could afford and the family was asked to move.

title: Lofton Says He's Happy To Be a New Yankee
description: The much-traveled center fielder Kenny Lofton officially joined the Yankees yesterday, and he immediately said he would blend in to give them a better chance to win the World Series.
