description: To the Editor:

title: Near Quarantine, Rumors Outnumber Facts
description: In a hastily called news conference on Tuesday night, Gov. Gary Locke of Washington sought to calm fears about the dangers to the public of the nation's first case of suspected mad cow disease, reportedly tracked to a dairy farm in south central Washington.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in World Business yesterday showing the closing figures for the main United States stock gauges reversed those for the Nasdaq and the S.& P. 500. The Nasdaq closed at 1,955.80, while the S.& P. 500 closed at 1,092.94.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Insurer Faces Write-Down
description: Shares in HHG, the British unit that was spun off from AMP, Australia's biggest life insurer, closed at 89 Australian cents (65 cents) on their first day of trading, about half their valuation in AMP's accounts. AMP valued HHG at 1.72 Australian dollars a share. The discount means AMP will be forced to book a write-down higher than the 2.5 billion Australian dollars ($1.8 billion) it had forecast. AMP spun off the unit, based in London, to focus on operations in Australia after losses in Britain caused AMP stock to fall 75 percent in two years. HHG, which owns Henderson Global Investors, Pearl Assurance, NPI and London Life, raised 190 million ($335 million) selling shares last week.

title: A Dividing Line Over Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Aram Kevorkian Dies at 74; Lent Humor to French Law
description: Aram J. Kevorkian, an American lawyer in Paris whose witty and opinionated newsletter on the spirit of French law served both corporate clients and devoted Francophiles on his mailing list, died Dec. 20 at the American Hospital in Neuilly. He was 74.

title: El Paso Plans Share Sale
description: The El Paso Corporation, the natural gas pipeline owner, is selling 8.8 million shares to raise $69 million as part of the $1.7 billion energy-pricing settlement with California and other Western states.

title: Millions of AIDS Orphans Strain Southern Africa
description: On the day last July that he and his wife died of AIDS, 36-year-old Samossoni Nhambo leaned up from a hospital bed a few miles from this dirt-road village of thatched huts and asked his preacher a despairing question: who would take care of his children?

title: As if Oranges Grew On Olive Trees
description: A century or so ago, oranges and tangerines were still exotic tropical fruit, and so a Christmas treat. Hark back, and consider a latter-day fruit-scented stocking stuffer. L'Olivier, the chain of olive oil and condiment stores, sells olive oil perfumed with mandarin orange; an 8.4-ounce tin is $16. (Some stores sell it in a set of four tins for $65.) Drizzle the oil on fish, float some on a tomato or seafood soup or use it to make a fragrant olive oil cake for the holidays.

title: Younger Sniper Given Sentence Of a Life Term
description: A jury spared the life of Lee Malvo on Tuesday, sentencing him to life in prison for murder and terrorism in the sniper attacks last year in the Washington area.

title: Sweet Aromas of a Farmhouse Kitchen on 9th Ave.
description: A classic pineapple upside-down cake, a surprisingly delicate poundcake and thick peanut butter and chocolate chip cookies are the stars at Billy's, a new bakery at 184 Ninth Avenue (21st Street). Its owner is Billy Reece, above left, who managed the Magnolia Bakery in Greenwich Village. His bright, airy store looks like a 1920's farmhouse kitchen. Some recipes are Mr. Reece's, some are his mother's and some are by Bel Torres, above right, the shop's baker, who has no objection to using canned fruit. Cakes and pies are $18 to $32, and are mostly $3.75 a slice. Cupcakes are $1.50.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Body Of Second Sailor Is Identified
description: The police yesterday identified the second of three Russian sailors lost when their cargo ship tipped over in the Hudson River on Dec. 9. The body of the sailor, Suleyman Rhasenevich, 43, was recovered by divers on Saturday, the police said. On Friday, divers recovered the body of his shipmate Yuri A. Akofin, 48, from the cargo hold of the ship, the Stellamare. The third sailor, Victor Alexeev, 46, is still missing. The bodies of Mr. Rhasenevich and Mr. Akofin will be flown home to St. Petersburg, a detective said. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSEPH, JIM
description: JOSEPH--Jim. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Jim Joseph, a cherished friend and a leader in Jewish education. Working with us to create The Partnership for Excellence in Jewish Education, Jim will long be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Mideast Politics Overshadow Christmas Eve
description: BETHLEHEM, West Bank, Dec. 24  The tortured politics of the Middle East seeped even into Christmas Eve festivities here today as schoolchildren banged their drums and blew on bagpipes while leading clerics on a parade through Manger Square.

title: Parmalat Files for Protection From Creditors
description: MILAN, Dec. 24 - After weeks on the brink of default, the Italian dairy and food giant Parmalat filed for protection from creditors on Wednesday under a new Italian government decree.

title: How to Take a Widow Three Stages Past Merry
description: Susan Graham's Merry Widow is a cross of Lucille Ball, Mary Tyler Moore and Carol Burnett.

description: The New York headquarters of Saatchi & Saatchi is reorganizing its top management.

title: Amid Celebrations, Guerrillas in Iraq Mount Several Attacks
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 24 — As Iraqis and coalition soldiers began their Christmas Eve celebrations, guerrilla fighters mounted a number of bomb attacks today, killing at least three American soldiers and six Iraqi civilians and wounding dozens of people, military and government officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GABRILOVE, HILDA W.

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Westchester; New Life as Science Complex For Old Ciba-Geigy Buildings
description: Five buildings in an office park here that was once the United States headquarters of the Ciba-Geigy pharmaceutical company have been sold for $24 million to a partnership that includes another drug company, Purdue Pharma of Stamford, Conn. Purdue Pharma had earlier purchased three of the nine buildings that made up the Ciba-Geigy headquarters.

title: The Not-Quite-True Story of Divorce and Its Truly Painful Consequences
description: The jiggling, swerving camera that pokes its nose into the troubled lives of three children in Geoffrey Enthoven's film ''Children of Love'' is so restless that you sometimes wish you could reach your hand into the screen and steady it. That camera's hyperactivity contributes to the nervous, disconsolate mood of Mr. Enthoven's first feature, which started out as a documentary about the effects of divorce on a single family but became fictionalized when the designated family declined to take part.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN TOWER CORP., Boston, an operator of cellphone towers, said that its Verestar unit had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after a potential buyer backed out, but that it did not expect the filing to have an adverse effect on its own operations or credit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIDLER, KATE S.
description: FIDLER--Kate S. January 5, 1905 to December 22, 2003, of Forest Hills, NY. A remarkable woman, ''Grande Dame'' of Pinelawn Memorial Park. Beloved wife of the late Herman Fidler, loving mother of Millicent Freedman, devoted mother-in-law of Herbert J. Freedman. Dear friend of May Rose Gordon, her housekeeper of 62 years. Adored grandmother and great grandmother of Robert, Ann and Jessica Freedman, Wendy Freedman, Jed Best, Joanna Best, James, Holly, Isaiah and Roy Freedman. Service Wednesday, December 24, at 11am at ''Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapel'' Queens Blvd & 76 Rd, Forest Hills, NY. Interment at Mount Ararat Cemetery, East Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, GERDA
description: MILLER--Gerda. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our founding Nursery School Director, Gerda Miller. As an expert in the field of Early Childhood Education, Mrs. Miller came to Rodeph Sholom in 1958 and developed a caring and nurturing environment for young children to learn. By the time she retired in 1975, the Nursery Program had greatly expanded and led to the creation of the Rodeph Sholom Day School, grades K-8. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her nephew Peter Rosendahl, and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Nancy Solomon, President

description: Even if beef from one infected cow got into the food supply, the chances that any consumer would develop mad cow disease are extremely low, experts on the disease say.

While I.B.M. is a leading supporter of Linux and ships its server computers loaded with the system, it does not sell commercial versions of Linux.

title: Court Blocks U.S. Effort to Relax Pollution Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24  A federal appeals court on Wednesday at least temporarily blocked a Bush administration rule, due to take effect on Friday, that that would have relaxed existing regulations and so allowed thousands of aging power and industrial plants to make upgrades without installing modern pollution controls.

title: The City Life; Christmas Crush
description: An orange alert? What most New Yorkers are feeling today is a red-and-green alert, the last-minute pressure of the holiday season itself. Every crowd this season has been amazed at the size of itself -- shoppers jammed together like pack ice on the sidewalks and streets. And in every crowd, especially today, there is an incipient panic, not from the threat of terrorism but from keeping a list, checking it twice and realizing that you'll never get to the bottom of it before the stores close.

title: Intelligence Cites Some U.S. Cities
description: Officials said Tuesday that they were analyzing recently collected terrorism intelligence to determine why a handful of American cities were mentioned, but they cautioned that the locales were not necessarily considered targets.

description: The decision by a jury here to spare Lee Malvo's life after finding him guilty in last year's Washington-area sniper rampage may hasten a movement to abolish the death penalty for juvenile killers, legal experts say.

description: As music continues to migrate to the hard drive, the computer has become a vital component of the modern stereo system. But there's nothing modern about getting up from the couch to open another music file.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 15 about a failed attempt to bomb President Pervez Musharraf's motorcade in Pakistan misidentified the military facility near a bridge in Rawalpindi where the bomb had been planted. It is the headquarters of army's X Corps, not XI.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Loan Company Downgraded
description: Takefuji, one of Japan's largest consumer loan companies, had its debt rating lowered by Moody's Investors Service, which cited the arrest of the company's chairman, Yasuo Takei. Moody's now rates the company's credit Baa2, down from A3. Mr. Takei, who was arrested Dec. 2 on suspicion of ordering illegal wiretaps, has since resigned. Moody's said the arrest hurt Takefuji's reputation. Ken Belsen (NYT)

title: NORTHWEST SEEKS TO DELAY PENSION PAYMENTS
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation sought permission yesterday to postpone some 2004 payments to its employee pension plans so it can preserve cash amid a slump in revenue. Northwest asked the Internal Revenue Service to let it reschedule $472.3 million in contributions to pension plans for all union workers, excluding the pilots, and for salaried employees, a spokesman, Kurt Ebenhoch, said. Northwest, which is based in St. Paul, is seeking to spread the payments over five years, instead of the normal 18-month period. Northwest said rescheduling the payments was part of its plan to preserve cash and manage costs. The carrier has had losses of $1.34 billion since 2000 because of an industrywide slump and increased competition from discount carriers. The amounts due for the pension plans will not be final until early 2004 and could change depending on the level of investment returns and interest rates in the rest of 2003, Mr. Ebenhoch said. Northwest shares fell 20 cents, to $12.45.

title: MYLAN RECEIVES APPROVAL TO SELL GENERIC HEART DRUG
description: Mylan Laboratories, a leading maker of generic drugs, said yesterday that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to sell Metolazone, a generic version of the Celltech Group's heart failure drug Zaroxolyn. Mylan is based in Pittsburgh. Celltech, a biotechnology company based in Britain, said in August that first-half sales of the drug in 2003 were 12.4 million ($21.9 million). The company said then that it was limiting promotion of the drug because of the patent expiration in 2002.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 16 about the landscape architect Michael Van Valkenburgh and two recent commissions of his -- a mile-long stretch of waterfront in Brooklyn and Teardrop Park in Battery Park City -- misidentified his birthplace. It was Lexington, N.Y., not Livingston, N.Y. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALOMON, WALTER
description: SALOMON--Walter. Congregation Habonim mourns the loss of a pillar of our community, Cantor Walter Salomon. A long-time member of Habonim, Walter brought his beautiful music into the life of our community for more than five decades. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Eva and daughter Linda Salomon. May his memory be a blessing. Rabbi Joanna Samuels Leo Asen, President

title: 4 G.I.'s and 6 Iraqi Civilians Are Killed in Bomb Attacks
description: As Iraqis and occupation soldiers began their Christmas celebrations on Wednesday and early Thursday, guerrilla fighters unleashed a string of intense rocket and bomb attacks across the country, killing at least four American soldiers and six Iraqi civilians and wounding dozens of people, military and government officials said.

title: Behind Smooth Footwork, Some Abrasive Gossip
description: The title of Robert Altman's likable new film, ''The Company,'' could be appropriate for any of his most important films, from ''McCabe and Mrs. Miller'' to ''The Player'' to ''Kansas City.'' Many of these pictures invite us to eavesdrop on characters busily talking away among themselves, sounding like a group of nervous, supportive actors revving themselves up for a performance before the curtain rises.

title: Even in Fabled Neverland, A World of Contradictions
description: Admirers of Peter Pan from J. M. Barrie's novel, rather than from the many stage and screen versions, will find a kindred spirit in P. J. Hogan, the Australian director whose film adaptation of the book opens nationwide today.

title: Cups Priced Lower Than Espresso
description: Tomorrow, 20 years worth of tableware will be sent from the Fishs Eddy warehouse in St. George, Staten Island, to the company's three Manhattan stores. And nothing will cost more than $1. Espresso cups will be 50 cents, oval olive dishes will be 75 cents, and casseroles and dinner plates will be $1. The stores are at 889 Broadway (19th Street), 1176 Broadway (77th Street) and 1388 Third Avenue (79th Street). The sale will continue for as long as supplies last. After that, shoppers can go to the warehouse, above, open all year at 139 Bay Street, a few steps from the ferry terminal.

title: Security Violation Causes Evacuation of a Terminal at La Guardia
description: Hundreds of passengers were forced to temporarily evacuate the Delta Air Lines terminal at La Guardia Airport last evening after a security breach by a passenger, officials said.

title: Scandal Outrages Europeans; Solutions May Be Patchwork
description: The widening scandal at Parmalat, the Italian food giant, has been termed, perhaps inevitably, Europe's Enron. The question is: Will it force the kind of corporate housecleaning that the collapse of Enron did two years ago in the United States?

title: With the Slightest of Movements, a Pilot's World Rotates
description: Flight simulator software has its limits. You can use your joystick to raise the wing flaps or open the throttle, but looking out a side window involves pushing a knob, which is certainly not what pilots do in a real plane. A new device from Natural Point, TrackIR2, makes simulation just a little more realistic by enabling you to look around your virtual plane just by turning your head.

title: They'll Stick With Film, Thank You
description: DON MISHELL is hardly a technophobe. A legal recruiter who lives in Jerusalem and does most of his business in California, Mr. Mishell depends on his computer for sending e-mail to far-flung clients, for writing and for maintaining databases. He is fond of his electronic organizer and he is grateful to Internet-based telephony for reducing the cost of his long-distance calls.

description: SHENZHEN, China, Dec. 25 - At least 191 people were killed and scores of others were injured after an explosion rocked a natural gas field in southwestern China and spread poisonous fumes into surrounding communities, local officials, medical workers and state media said today.

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: Talks For Ahold Unit
description: Royal Ahold of the Netherlands, the world's third-largest retailer, said it was negotiating with an Argentine executive, Francisco de Narvaez, and Casino Guichard-Perrachon of France as possible buyers of Ahold's Disco unit. Disco, which has 237 stores in Argentina, is worth about 150 million euros ($185 million), analysts said. The chief executive, Anders Moberg, above, has been reversing a strategy of global expansion after Ahold overstated profit by 970 million euros in the last three years.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 25 — Leaders of Sunni groups across the country agreed to form a council today in order to speak with a unified political voice during the transition of Iraq from American rule to Iraqi governance.

title: Yashin Has Surgery; Will Miss 10-12 Weeks
description: Just as he had elevated his play back to marquee status, Aleksei Yashin of the Islanders must watch and wait. Yashin will miss 10 to 12 weeks because of a severely cut right forearm that required surgery, the team announced yesterday. He had surgery to repair torn wrist tendons and a damaged nerve at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Sleeping With the Enemy
description: WHEN Bridgette Raes woke up this summer covered with red itchy bumps, the last thing she expected was bedbugs. A Manhattan dermatologist told Ms. Raes, a 29-year-old image consultant from Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, that she had scabies, an allergy to a common mite. She tried the Elimite Cream he prescribed, but the red marks continued to appear.

title: A Woman Faces the Inevitable While Refusing to Bow to It
description: The human capacity for cruelty and oppression is likely to be more and more in the news as the interrogation and subsequent trial of Saddam Hussein proceed. In the meantime a quieter reminder is available at the Lucille Lortel Theater, where Kathleen Chalfant is performing a monologue, ''The Last Letter,'' taken from ''Life and Fate'' by the Russian novelist Vasily Grossman.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Energy Venture
description: Gazprom, the natural gas producer, will form a venture with Surgutneftegaz, the oil producer, and the government-run Rosneft to exploit oil and gas fields in east Siberia and the Sakha region. East Siberia and Russia's Far East have combined reserves estimated at 6.6 trillion cubic meters of gas, Gazprom said. Russia is seeking to tap fields in the east and export the fuel to meet demand in Asia and the United States.

title: Charles Grean, 90, Composer, Arranger And Music Executive
description: Charles R. Grean, a pop composer, arranger and music industry executive for more than 60 years, died on Saturday at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 90 and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: Corrections

He lost to Mr. Trudeau three times, not two; in all three he had hoped to become prime minister.

title: Lovers Striving for a Reunion, With a War in the Way
description: Were it not for a gruesomely violent battle sequence at the beginning, a smattering of profanity and an occasional glimpse of unclothed flesh, ''Cold Mountain'' might easily be mistaken for the product of an earlier era of movie-making. The film, freely adapted by Anthony Minghella from Charles Frazier's best-selling novel, is an episodic romance that begins like a war movie and ends like a western, and it requires an old-fashioned critical idiom to do it justice. It is, as my predecessor Bosley Crowther might have said, one heck of a classy picture.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bailout For A Bank
description: The Bank of China will receive a $20 billion government bailout as soon as next week to help write off bad loans before a first-time share sale in 2005, an executive at the bank said. The bank will use the money to reduce bad loans and speed plans to sell shares, the executive said.

title: Corrections

It is a listing that includes the names of those who have already been baptized and is part of the church's genealogical archives; it is not the archives themselves.

title: Diverse Schools More Likely to Be Labeled as Failing, Study Says
description: Public schools with diverse student populations are far more likely than those with homogeneous populations to be labeled as failing under President Bush's education law, according to a new California study.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TUCK, JILL HOPE
description: TUCK--Jill Hope, nee Greenberg. 41, of Larchmont, NY. Born at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan, NY, Jill was an amazing mother and wife. She is survived by her father Paul Greenberg, her best friend and husband Fred and their four children, Lauren 14, Amanda 12, Jake 10 and Will 5. Jill was the daughter of the late Lenore Greenberg and sister to the late Gwen Greenberg. All three of these incredible women were tragically taken from us in an automobile accident near Akumal, Mexico on Saturday, December 20th. Jill lived with her family in Westchester County. She found a passion for horses when she was 8 years old and competed in the Hunter Class into her early adulthood. Jill's equestrian skills qualified her to show at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden. She graduated from the University of Virginia with a major in history and started her career at a law firm in Manhattan. She went on to work in commercial real estate at Integrated Resources. She met her soul-mate, Fred, at a Halloween party in the city and they were married two years later on Halloween day. She gave up real estate several years later to pursue her life's work as the devoted mother of her four children. In 1992, Fred and Jill moved to the Village of Larchmont in Westchester County. They soon became a moving force for the community. Jill's extensive involvement in Larchmont included being the Commissioner of the Girls' Junior Soccer League and a number of important fundraising efforts. Virtually every aspect of the community was touched by her contribution. Being a full-time mother to her four wonderful children in no way diminished her willingness to give of herself in her signature calming, self-possessed, effective and intelligent manner. She had a quiet but powerful way of bringing out the best in those around her. Our hearts are broken. Services Friday, December 26th, 10 A.M., at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY 10538.

title: A Frisky Colt As Rescuer Of a Family's Greatness
description: The large-screen Imax film process is a form in search of content. Able to create an image several stories tall with crystalline clarity, this 70-millimeter format is so overwhelming that it upstages whatever material it presents. Call it the wow effect: when the viewer is knocked out by the visual splendor, it is difficult to concentrate on dramatic issues or become deeply involved with fictional characters.

description: In egalitarian Norway, where the late, beloved King Olav was known to take the streetcar, it is everyone's business when the prime minister buys a luxurious, bombproof limousine.

title: Pakistan Leader Survives Another Assassination Attempt
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Dec. 25  Two suicide bombers rammed explosives-packed vehicles into President Gen. Pervez Musharraf's motorcade today, damaging his car in the second assassination attempt on him in 11 days. He escaped unhurt but the Interior Ministry said 14 people, including the bombers, were killed and 46 were wounded.

title: AM and FM Play Digital Catch-Up
description: THERE has been plenty of talk in recent months about satellite radio, streams of digital programming beamed from orbit for a monthly fee. But some earthbound AM and FM radio stations are beginning to broadcast digitally as well -- at no cost to the listener.

title: Pope Addresses Terrorism and Mideast in Holiday Message
description: VATICAN CITY, Dec. 25  Pope John Paul II used his Christmas messages today to plead fervently for an end to terrorism and a solution for bloodshed in the Middle East, his concern over recent world events casting a shadow over his traditional holiday celebrations.

title: INVITROGEN BUYS A RIVAL AS IT SEEKS BIOTECH CUSTOMERS
description: The Invitrogen Corporation, a maker of chemical kits used to analyze and clone genes, agreed yesterday to buy the BioReliance Corporation for $430 million to expand its production ability for biotechnology customers. Invitrogen will pay $48 a share, Tuesday's closing price, for BioReliance and assume about $70 million in debt, the companies said. Invitrogen, based in Carlsbad, Calif., expects the acquisition to be completed by April and to add about 19 cents a share to profit in 2004. The deal allows Invitrogen to offer more testing and manufacturing services to biotechnology companies that do not have the staff to perform those tasks. Shares of BioReliance, which is based in Rockville, Md., fell 2 cents, to $47.98. On Tuesday, the shares rose $4.51, or 10 percent, to $48. Invitrogen shares rose $4.40, to $69.55, yesterday.

description: It was a sign, Bob Sapp knew, that his self-described Beast phenomenon had gone too far: he shaved his chest for a television commercial and someone swept up the hair and sold it for $500.

description: Buoyed by the backing of several major unions and the endorsement of former Vice President Al Gore, Howard Dean had just begun to change his style and broaden his message beyond his antiwar stump speech.

description: The New York State comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said on Wednesday that he planned to call on the Legislature in January to overhaul the state's system of public authorities.

description: The murmurs began almost immediately, and Curtis Martin heard them. They seeped into his psyche with each game that was lost, with each yard not gained.

title: Law Gives Parmalat Shelter to Reorganize
description: Parmalat filed for protection from creditors under a new Italian government decree that allows it to reorganize. But despite Italy's move, Europe's patchwork of laws may make corporate housecleaning difficult, no matter how much countries want to clamp down as the United States did after the collapse of Enron.

Cox Radio said that about 7 of its 78 stations independently stopped playing the group's songs; the company did not ban them.

title: The Cranberry Is Not Just for Sauce
description: WHEN people think of cranberries, they most likely picture jelly for Christmas dinner, pink-studded muffins or ruby-red juice. Nobody much considers the plants that bear the fruit. But for gardens designed for beauty, not bounty, cranberries, along with some of their cousins like the lowbush blueberry, are overlooked jewels.

title: To Save Yourself a Trip, Download Pesky Forms
description: Q. I want to download Adobe Reader so that I can obtain some forms online. Where should I go to download it? Where will it be stored on my computer, and how do I summon it?

description: In bridge terms, free will appears to prevail over predestination all the time. Within the laws of the game, bidders can do whatever they like and opening leaders can choose whatever card they like. True? Not quite.

description: CONSIDER Christmas half a century ago. It was an age of international cooperation. Less well noticed, it was also an age of unusually enlightened economics.

description: IT'S assessment time, the calendar dictates, the time to declare what kind of year it has been. This always leads to facile theories and weak themes, but for once there does seem to be a credible title to this song. In New York, 2003 was the year of living modestly.

title: Suspect in a Shootout Is Arrested
description: A teenager was arrested in a hospital yesterday, where he was being treated for a bullet wound to his buttocks and pelvis believed to have come from a gunfight with the police in the Bronx hours earlier.

title: AUDITOR SAYS CRITICAL PATH IN DANGER OF CLOSING
description: Critical Path Inc., an e-mail software maker that earlier this year laid off 30 percent of its work force, said its auditor has said there is a possibility the company may go out of business. The auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers, has said there is ''substantial doubt'' that Critical Path can continue as a going concern because of recurring losses and lack of capital, the company, based in San Francisco, said in a regulatory filing. Critical Path, which last month hired a chief financial officer, has not had a profitable year since its initial offering in March 1999. Software-license and messaging sales have fallen for two years. The company is trying to raise $36 million by the first quarter, through a private placement and by selling stock to existing shareholders; without that money it will not be able to stay in business, it said in the filing.

description: To the Editor:

''Paycheck'' stars Ben Affleck and Uma Thurman in John Woo's take on that Philip K. Dick story. ''Peter Pan'' is adapted by the Australian director P. J. Hogan and Disney offers ''The Young Black Stallion'' in Imax format.

title: CHUBBY REDUX VIA REMIX
description: At age 62 and 43 years after ''The Twist,'' Chubby Checker, left, has once again come up with a top-five single: a hip-hop-flavored version of another of his 1960's hits, ''Limbo Rock.'' Using the argot of rap, he calls himself Chubby C for the new song, ''Limbo Rock (Remixes),'' and calls his band Chubby C &OD, featuring Inner Circle. OD is a hip-hop trio; Inner Circle is a veteran Jamaican reggae outfit best known for the omnipresent ''Bad Boys,'' the theme song of the syndicated cinma vrit television show ''Cops.'' Although ''Limbo Rock (Remixes)'' slipped this week to No. 6, the Dec. 20 issue of Billboard listed it at No. 3 on its hot dance singles sales chart, making it Mr. Checker's first top-five hit since the original ''Limbo Rock'' in 1962. The new hit has only reinforced the confidence that Mr. Checker, a longtime Philadelphia-area resident, has in his upbeat, family-friendly stage act. ''I mean, we kill,'' he said in a telephone interview from his office in Conshohocken, Pa. ''Elvis used to come watch us when he was in Vegas.''

title: A Bastion of Literature Is a Bulwark for Therapy; The Evolving Life of a Greenwich Village Street
description: Patchin Place, a peaceful and picturesque iron-gated mews tucked just off 10th Street and Avenue of the Americas, is a stop on Greenwich Village walking tours because it is the onetime home of the literary legends E. E. Cummings, Theodore Dreiser and Djuna Barnes.

title: Move to Dismiss Park Police Chief Is Criticized
description: Some members of Congress and the labor union that represents United States Park Police officers have urged the National Park Service, which oversees the police department, to reconsider its decision to fire its top uniformed officer.

description: Concern over the possible spread of mad cow disease has impelled the largest international markets for American beef to suspend imports from the United States after the discovery of a single suspected case of the disease on a farm in Washington State.

A year's must-have toy may quickly be forgotten, but train tracks will often stay on the living room floor for weeks into the new year or become a permanent fixture on a plywood table in the basement.

description: Romania may receive as much as $2 billion in foreign direct investment next year, a record, as the country prepares to join the European Union in 2007, Marian Saniuta, head of Romania's Foreign Investment Agency, said on Wednesday.

He was not sure why -- maybe it was the cancerous tumor she had had removed in May -- but Meminger had a bad feeling as they were being driven to Lenox Hill Hospital.

description: FOR those who prefer a quiet New Year at home curled up with a book or a stack of videos, nothing is more inviting than a warm throw (accompanied, of course, by a glass of Champagne).

title: For Risk-Takers, a Last-Minute Gala
description: ONE New Year's Eve in the late 1960's, my parents strung thousands of twinkling lights across the basement ceiling. Against one knotty-pine wall they set up a bar, and along another, a buffet table laden with such exotic delicacies as pigs-in-blankets and toast points with piped-on cream cheese topping. Then they dimmed the lights.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Steinbrenner Receives Subpoena
description: George Steinbrenner, left, and two other top New York Yankees officials were issued subpoenas on Tuesday by a state commission that is investigating the team's distribution of free tickets to public officials. According to subpoenas filed by the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, Mr. Steinbrenner; the team's president, Randy Levine; and its chief operating officer, Lonn Trost, have been directed to turn over all records regarding free tickets for the 2002 and 2003 season by Jan. 14. State law requires that companies and individuals making gifts worth $75 or more to public officials report those gifts to the commission. In an Oct. 23 letter, according to a lobbying commission official, a lawyer for the Yankees said that the team would provide the information in the next two weeks, but no further information was received. A spokesman for Mr. Steinbrenner, Howard J. Rubenstein, said he was not aware of any information that the team was required to provide. The subpoenas were first reported by The Daily News. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Earth Invades Mars
description: The last time Earth and Mars were as close together as they were last August, we were not ready with our spacecraft. That was some 60,000 years ago, and at the time, humans were still refining the pointed stick. This time, we are prepared. Over the next month or so, beginning early this morning, Earth is going to try to pepper Mars with craft. The first vessel to land will be the Beagle 2, named for the ship that carried Charles Darwin to South America and the Galpagos Islands, a voyage whose research eventually led to his theory of natural selection. Beagle 2, the first European spacecraft to visit Mars, successfully detached from its orbiter, Mars Express, last week after an uneventful flight and, if all went well during the night, was to land in an impact basin called Isidis Planitia.

title: Another Death May Be Linked to Ex-Nurse
description: The Pennsylvania State Police have opened an investigation into the 1998 death of an 83-year-old man at a nursing home that employed a nurse who prosecutors say has admitted to killing dozens of patients, a police official said Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: PEDESTRIAN IS KILLED BY CAR A 65-year-old man was struck and killed by a passing car as he crossed a busy Brooklyn street yesterday morning. The police said that the man, Alonza Mitchell of East New York, Brooklyn, was struck by a car as he crossed North Conduit Boulevard at Grant Avenue in East New York about 6 a.m. He was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead. A witness said the car that struck Mr. Mitchell was green, the police said. A family friend, Elizabeth Meningall, said that Mr. Mitchell was a retired transit worker who was returning from a friend's house after a hunting trip upstate and had planned to leave for South Carolina last evening. Oren Yaniv (NYT)

title: Tackling a Moscow Ripe for Refurbishing

Ready or not, in March, 100% Design Moscow (showing off Verner Panton, Herman Miller and Tim Dixon) will join Fidexpo, a furniture show that drew 20,000 visitors last year. The exhibition will be in Gostiny Dvor, a 19th-century building in Moscow, above right, with a courtyard covered by glass.

title: Congress's Missing Vision
description: Congress's main budget adviser has looked years into the future and concluded that the nation cannot afford its overheated present as Republicans continue cutting taxes, enriching spending and rolling ever larger debts a decade over the horizon. ''Fiscal autopilot is not an option,'' warned Douglas Holtz-Eakin, director of the Congressional Budget Office in a no-nonsense estimate of serial budget imbalances to come. Unless the deficit-and-tax-cut-happy Congress begins to put the brakes on now, future Americans will most likely be caught in an impossible crunch of historically higher taxes and plummeting health care and retirement benefits, Mr. Holtz-Eakin concluded in his forecast.

title: Whimsical Designs With a Serious Mission
description: Cyrille Varet, a furniture designer in Paris, had an idealistic notion two years ago. ''I wanted to find a bridge between my work as a designer,'' he said, ''and a way to help people who are living with H.I.V./AIDS in Africa.'' Last summer he started Ithemba, ''hope'' in Xhosa, with Scott Hart, an interior designer who lives in Capetown. They have trained 30 women in South Africa and 20 in Burkina Faso to embellish light bulbs with designs created by fashion designers like Stella Cadente, Vivienne Westwood and Xuly Bt.

title: The Hills Walk Alone in an Elephant's Eye
description: The musical is the happy narcissist of theater. It is always paying homage to itself: ''But enough about me -- let's sing about me!'' Tributes to dead stars make new stars. (Fanny Brice lives through Barbra Streisand.) Great stage musicals are reworked as movies, and great movie musicals are also tamed and put through their stage paces. (''Swing Time'' becomes ''Never Gonna Dance.'') And the spoofing never stops. The ''Forbidden Broadway'' revues have been going for years, and cheeky ''Urinetown'' may well do the same on tour.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: State Recovers Vaccine Payment
description: The state has recovered all but $70,000 of almost $1.7 million it paid an Arkansas company for 100,000 doses of flu vaccine that did not exist, officials said. The Georgia health director, Dr. Kathleen Toomey, alerted the police when the vaccine was not delivered as expected by the company, the Carter Trading Company. The rest of the missing money is expected to be recovered soon, officials said, and the state is trying to secure more vaccine from other sources. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: Concord's new entry-level two-megapixel camera, the Eye-Q Go Wireless, has a pleasing shape, a short learning curve and a 4x digital zoom. Its most outstanding feature, however, is its innovative use of Bluetooth to transmit images without cables.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELL, JOHN JEWETT, II,
description: BELL--John Jewett, II, 84, formerly of Milford, CT died Monday in Vero Beach, FL. He was a veteran of WW II, serving in the US Army 7th Regiment; a graduate of the Englewood School for Boys, the Eagle Brook School, The Governor Dummer Academy and Packard Business School; and had worked for CBS Television in NYC in a variety of positions until his retirement in 1986 as Associate Director/News Division and Director of Syndication. Mr. Bell was a member of the Society of Mayflower Descendants, Sons of the American Revolution and the Directors Guild of America. Survivors include his wife, Marilyn Blackburn Hill Bell of Vero Beach; son, John J. Bell, III of Sparks, NV; stepson, David B. Hill of Orange Park, FL; stepdaughter, Tracey Hill-Bensalem of Upper Montclair, NJ; and six grandchildren. Services are planned for a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to VNA Hospice House, 1111 36th St, Vero Beach, FL 32960. For information, contact The Thomas S. Lowther Funeral Home and Crematory in Vero Beach.

title: Old Outfits From the U.S. Have Real Value Abroad
description: The term swag has many cultural meanings. For employees in the ski industry, it is an acronym for Stuff We Always Get. As in, free stuff. One of the perks, for example, of being a ski instructor is the posh, usually stylish and warm uniform handed over by the resort. As it happens, the uniform is also handed back to the resort at the end of ski season.

title: At Least 3 Killed in Suicide Bombing Near Tel Aviv
description: PETAH TIKVA, Israel, Dec. 25 - In deadly attacks less than an hour apart this evening, a Palestinian suicide bomber struck at a bus stop near Tel Aviv, killing three civilians, and Israeli helicopters fired missiles that killed five people, including a leading militant, in Gaza City.

title: Report of Cow Disease Hurts Shares in Short Trading Day
description: Stocks declined in trading shortened for the holiday, led by McDonald's and Tyson Foods, after reports of the country's first case of mad cow disease. The Dow Jones industrial average fell for the first time in seven days.

title: Army Stepping Up Its Humvee Orders For Troops in Iraq
description: Attacks on Humvees in Iraq are reverberating in this small Indiana town, where a production line is gearing up to sate a growing hunger for these vehicles and to save soldiers' lives.

description: Moments after filling Madison Square Garden with two hours of terrific basketball and nearly as much obscenity on Tuesday night, Latrell Sprewell implied that he had had a storybook return, even if it might have required a parental advisory label.

title: Sheet Sets for Earth Lovers Who Are Tired of Earth Tones
description: Organic Home, a San Francisco company, has given organic bed linens a splash of color. ''No more oatmeal,'' said Marta Salas-Porras, the designer for Organic Home. Oh! bed linens, made of Indian cotton, include a series of patterns in green, blue and white designs and another in plum, red and orange. David Dow, who founded Organic Home with Allison Wing, said they use gentle, nontoxic dyes on their fabrics. ''To achieve bright whites, we use hydrogen peroxide, instead of chlorine bleach,'' he said.

title: MOODY'S RAISES ITS CREDIT OUTLOOK FOR XEROX
description: The Xerox Corporation had the outlook on its credit quality raised yesterday to stable from negative by Moody's Investors Service on expectations of higher sales and profitability and reduced debt. Xerox's operating margins widened to 9.4 percent from 8.6 percent in the year ended Sept. 30, Moody's said. Total debt is expected to drop to $12.5 billion this year and $10.6 billion in 2004, from $15.7 billion in 2002, Moody's said. Equipment revenue will continue to rise and will help increase sales of ink, paper and other products and services, the ratings agency said. The chief executive of Xerox, Anne M. Mulcahy, has reduced costs and introduced lower-priced products to regain sales lost to rivals like Canon Inc. and the Ricoh Company. Xerox is expected to continue to use cash flow for debt reduction, Moody's said. Moody's has a B1 rating on Xerox debt. The stable outlook means that it is inclined to leave the current ratings on Xerox unchanged. Moody's said the change in its ratings outlook affects about $8 billion of debt. Shares of Xerox rose 9 cents, to $13.18.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Minister Quits For Role In Parliament
description: Boris V. Gryzlov, the interior minister, resigned in order to join the lower house of Parliament. Mr. Gryzlov, who had served in the post since 2001, led United Russia, the party loyal to President Vladimir V. Putin that won an overwhelming victory in parliamentary elections this month. The party is expected to elect him speaker when the new Parliament convenes. Mr. Gryzlov, 43, has been mentioned as a possible prime minister in Mr. Putin's second term.

title: Indian Point Is Criticized For Shutdowns
description: The Indian Point nuclear plant had three times as many unplanned shutdowns in a 12-month period as any other plant in the nation, an official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said yesterday. The agency said in a report released a day before that a failure to follow protocol, insufficient quality control and poor contractor oversight contributed to the shutdowns at the plant in Buchanan, N.Y.

description: The report of mad cow disease split this beef-loving city into two camps on Wednesday. Some said they would not touch beef; others said they would go on happily eating it, though admittedly watching for the slightest sign of a wider problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, LENORE
description: GREENBERG--Lenore, nee Kronenberg. 67, of New York City. Survived by her husband Paul Greenberg, son-in-law Fred Tuck, and four adoring grandchildren, Lauren 14, Amanda 12, Jake 10 and Will 5. Loving and devoted mother to the late Jill Greenberg Tuck and the late Gwen Joy Greenberg. All three tragically taken from us in an automobile accident near Akumal, Mexico on Saturday, December 20th. Lenore was a graduate of Syracuse University and City College of New York. She taught for 31 years in the Hendrick Hudson School District. She continued using her talent for teaching at the 92nd Street Y where she led computer skills classes for seniors. Lenore was an outstanding, involved lifetime member of Hadassah. She also dedicated her energy to volunteer work at the Museum of Natural History. Lenore met the love of her life, Paul Greenberg, in a fortuitous encounter at the Montauk Manor and they were married for 44 years. She bore and raised her two girls, Jill and Gwen, in Westchester County but longed for the energy and vibrancy of NYC and, children successfully launched from nest, recently moved back to NYC to a Park Avenue apartment. She was a devotee of the theatre and ballet and took full advantage of all the city had to offer. Above all, her beloved girls and grandchildren were the main focus of her busy and full life. Her multitude of friends and surviving family mourn her passing deeply. Services Friday, December 26th, 10 A.M. at Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue, Larchmont, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Elan Sells Another Unit
description: The Elan Corporation, the drug maker that has sold more than $1.8 billion of assets, will sell a European sales and marketing business to Medeus U.K. for about $120 million. Elan will record a gain of $10 million before taxes for the sale. The unit being sold has operations in France, Germany, Ireland, Italy and Spain.

title: MEDTRONIC TO START LIMITED TEST OF HEART STENT
description: Medtronic Inc., the medical device maker, said yesterday that federal regulators gave it permission to start a limited test of a drug-coated heart stent while they seek more information on the device. Executives from the company, based in Minneapolis, plan to meet with Food and Drug Administration officials in January, a spokesman, Rob Clark, said. Medtronic sought approval in November to begin testing patients with its Endeavor stent, a tiny mesh tube used to prop open heart arteries. ''It will take us a bit of time to reply to the questions,'' Mr. Clark said. ''We hope to get those resolved in January.'' The F.D.A. request for more information may ''modestly delay'' approval of the device, said a Morgan Stanley analyst, Glenn Reicin, in a note to clients. The stent would compete with products from Johnson & Johnson and Boston Scientific in an annual market that analysts say will reach $6 billion by 2005.

title: Amid the Fighters, a Few Winners
description: LIKE television and rock 'n' roll, video games are one of those fads that just will not go away. Instead, they are saturating popular culture. This year we witnessed the release of three movies based on video games: ''Resident Evil,'' ''House of the Dead'' and ''Tomb Raider 2'' (the first sequel to a game-based movie). There were two television series, ''Pirate Islands'' and ''.hack//sign,'' in which characters found themselves trapped in video game worlds. And more and more popular books and scholarly papers focus on games and gaming.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Pearl River: Vandals Destroy Menorah
description: A menorah that was displayed in a public circle was destroyed Tuesday night or yesterday morning, the police said. The 12-foot menorah was part of a holiday display that included a Christmas tree and a crche, neither of which appeared to be damaged, Kevin Nulty, the chief of police of Orangetown, said. Chief Nulty said that the crime, which is still under investigation, had been classified as ''malicious mischief'' but could be reclassified as a bias crime if the circumstances surrounding the vandalism, including the vandal's state of mind, were established. This was the third year that members of the Rotary Club had erected a menorah in the same spot. In 2001, the menorah, valued at $1,200, was also damaged in what appeared to be a case of vandalism, although the menorah was completely destroyed this year. No arrests were made in the previous case. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: PARTNERS TRUST BUYS BSB BANCORP FOR $347 MILLION
description: The Partners Trust Financial Group, the holding company for SBU Bank, agreed yesterday to buy BSB Bancorp for about $347 million in cash and stock to create a bank with about $3.5 billion in assets in northern New York. Partners Trust, based in Utica, N.Y., and BSB Bancorp both focus on residential mortgage lending. BSB has eight branches in the Syracuse area, where Partners has been looking to expand, an analyst said. ''When you combine that with the ability of Partners to issue fresh capital, it becomes a very attractive merger,'' said Wilson Smith, director of research at Cohen Brothers & Company in Philadelphia. Shares of BSB Bancorp, based in Binghamton, N.Y., rose $6.03, to $39.56. Partners Trust shares rose $7.83, to $33.30.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Pedestrian Is Killed By Car
description: A 65-year-old man was struck and killed by a passing car as he crossed a busy Brooklyn street yesterday morning. The police said that the man, Alonza Mitchell of Manhattan, was struck by a car as he crossed Grant Avenue near Conduit Boulevard in East New York about 6 a.m. He was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead. A witness said the car that struck Mr. Mitchell was green, the police said. A family friend, Elizabeth Meningall, said that Mr. Mitchell was a retired transit worker who was returning from a friend's house after a hunting trip upstate and had planned to leave for South Carolina last evening. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, GWEN JOY
description: GREENBERG--Gwen Joy. 39, of New York City, NY. Gwen was the beloved daughter of Paul, sister-in-law of Fred Tuck and beloved aunt to Lauren 14, Amanda 12, Jake 10 and Will 5. Adoring sister of the late Jill Tuck and daughter of the late Lenore Greenberg. All three of these incredible women were tragically lost to us in an automobile accident near Akumal, Mexico on Saturday December 20th. Gwen was a graduate of the University of Virginia and the University of Richmond where she completed a Masters in Sports Administration. She took her deep love of sports to the next level and worked for the Washington Bullets. She later became the Alumni Director for Brooklyn Law School. Gwen's life revolved around her family and she was a second mother to her nieces and nephews. They traveled together extensively and she was a pillar of support for all of her family and her numerous friends. She was loved by many in spite of her devotion to the Dallas Cowboys and we all miss her more than these words can express. Services Friday, December 26th, 10 A.M., at the Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave, Larchmont, NY 10538.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street Friday, December 26 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Interment Saturday Dercember 27 at Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Coram, N.Y. title: A Holiday Set Apart
description: Strange what a corner of our lives this Christmas season is. The lights get brighter every year, the shopping more frenetic, the music more familiar, if that's possible. By mid-December, the Christmas songs -- the sincere and the insincere alike -- form an everlasting medley that sticks in the mind like chewing gum. Every emotional string has been tugged to fraying, and every appeal that can be made to the spirit of the season has been made over and over. The calendar is already crowded with commitments well into the New Year, as if you were to have no rest at all, and it may be that the coming of Christmas makes you feel less like Mr. Fezziwig and more like Scrooge every year. Yet somehow this holiday still feels as if we had all been snowbound into one week of the calendar and time couldn't go on until we dug ourselves out.

title: Mad Cow in America
description: Let's begin with the ifs. If the Holstein cow that was slaughtered in Washington State two weeks ago proves to be an isolated case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, and if the quarantine of the remaining herd was established in time, and if the cow's herd origin can be determined and the chain of events -- including the feed source resulting in that infection -- can be identified with no open ends leading into the food supply or the broader national cattle herd, then there is a chance that the American beef and dairy industries will not suffer unduly.

title: Riffing, Rocking and Jamming, Pushing the Clock Toward Midnight
description: New Year's Eve isn't just a calendar date; it's an industry, a full-employment program for makers of Champagne, party hats and toothpicks, for waiters and taxi drivers and bouncers, and not least for disc jockeys and musicians. The urge to greet the new year with public songs and dancing may well be primordial, and from local lounges to concert halls, in places that have music every night and places that don't, New Year's Eve is the occasion to crank up both the volume and the price. In New York City the night's offerings run from introspective songwriters to jazz swingers to jam bands to thumping, pulsating dance music. title: Sports of The Times; In Sports World, It's Hard to Forgive Behavior and Actions of Some People
description: IN the pages of The New York Times some 35 years ago, the celebrated political columnist James Reston wrote about Joe Namath, then the star quarterback for the Jets, who offered a ''guarantee'' that his team would beat the heavily favored Baltimore Colts in the 1969 Super Bowl. The Jets stunningly made good on the promise, and Namath was making great strides to attain folklore status in this country.

title: America's Own Home-Grown Corn-Fed Impressionism
description: Though always popular, American Impressionism, a movement that flourished between the mid-1880's and World War I, doesn't get much serious respect. ''The Golden Age of American Impressionism,'' an exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art on Long Island, isn't likely to change conventional opinion. The show's 50-plus works, including a few good paintings and many ranging from mediocre to just plain bad, affirms that American Impressionism was but a pale reflection of the real -- i.e., the French -- thing. Yet it is not without historical and psychological interest.

title: Riffing, Rocking and Jamming, Pushing the Clock Toward Midnight
description: New Year's Eve isn't just a calendar date; it's an industry, a full-employment program for makers of Champagne, party hats and toothpicks, for waiters and taxi drivers and bouncers, and not least for disc jockeys and musicians. The urge to greet the new year with public songs and dancing may well be primordial, and from local lounges to concert halls, in places that have music every night and places that don't, New Year's Eve is the occasion to crank up both the volume and the price. In New York City the night's offerings run from introspective songwriters to jazz swingers to jam bands to thumping, pulsating dance music. In most cases it's a good idea to make reservations or buy tickets in advance. (* denotes a highly recommended performance; New Year's Eve cabaret shows are listed on Page 44.) JON PARELES

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Shinsei To Become Commercial Bank
description: Shinsei Bank, Japan's first foreign-owned bank, will become a commercial bank on April 1. As a long-term credit bank, Shinsei is limited in the amount it can lend and the types of businesses it can enter. The conversion will give Shinsei, which is owned by the American investor group Ripplewood Holdings, more flexibility to expand its retail and investment banking services. Long-term credit banks, which typically issue bank debentures to raise money, were designed to help rebuild corporate Japan after World War II. With Japan's industrial maturation, they have largely lost their focus. Ken Belson (NYT)

They hesitated before the crowded display of plates, pitchers, doilies and chairs before deciding to go in. Meantime, Elisa Massimino, with the Cheshire-cat smile of a successful shopper, clutched a pale wooden box to her chest. On this day, she made a major score, an intact service of ornate Thai-made silver, complete with oyster forks, marrow knives and a lining of hot-pink velvet -- a steal at $115.

Not since I was a teenager enthralled by the cries and moans of the Five Satins and the Moonglows on early rock 'n' roll radio -- sounds that Paul Simon once described as ''deep forbidden music'' -- has the mystique of pop radio been so seductive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOELTERHOFF, OLGA CHRISTINA
description: HOELTERHOFF -- Olga Christina, (nee Goertz). Born May 14, 1912 in Riga in Latvia, died December 17, 2003 in Valley Cottage, NY. Her long and complicated life reflected the tragedy of the Baltic States. Driven from her beloved home in Jurmala by Hitler and Stalin, displaced and often ill, she survived through tenacity, intelligence, and compromise. For 45 years, America offered her a bewildering refuge where she cherished her small house, many pets and her only child, and freely expressed her views, most recently on shooting bears and invading Iraq in a selection of five languages. Her curiosity, love of the arts (especially the Metropolitan Museum) and memories of Riga, Hamburg, Milan, Berlin, Saloniki, Venice and Franco Corelli are lovingly treasured by her makeshift family: Manuela, Francesca, Marilyn, Sheila, Irene, Margaret, Hilda, Eddie, Pince Pince, Sugar, Emma, Minnie, Sparkle, Tosca, Cosimo. And, from another realm, her husband Heinz Alfons Martin Hoelterhoff and her mutt Apple.

title: Leading the Weapons Hunt in Iraq

The search team has turned up little of significance so far, its work has been slowed by a lack of security, and some of its staff and budget is being diverted to help in the struggle against Iraqi insurgents. A job that Mr. Kay hoped to wrap up relatively quickly now looks as if it will stretch into next fall.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Overseas Auto Output Rises
description: Domestic vehicle production for Japan's 12 automakers fell 3.5 percent in November, data showed yesterday, while exports from the country fell 4.2 percent. But overseas output, led by Nissan Motor and Mazda Motor, posted gains on surging demand in Europe and the United States. Nissan raised overseas output 23 percent; Mazda said production abroad increased 20 percent. The increase was 12 percent at Toyota and 5.5 percent at Honda. Mitsubishi was the only one of the top five with a drop, as production abroad fell 36 percent.

title: 36 Hours| Oakland, Calif.
description: IN 1988, five decades after Gertrude Stein said of her native Oakland, in vintage Steinspeak, ''There is no there, there,'' the city pointedly erected a sculpture named ''There'' in the heart of town. It was a symbolic act. Living in the shadow of San Francisco, Oaklanders are feisty about defending their city, the target of frequent undeserved put-downs. Visitors are almost always surprised by Oakland's physical beauty, with majestic redwood forests, stunning Victorian houses and spectacular views of San Francisco Bay. Oaklanders' easy interaction across racial and ethnic lines could be a national model for diversity, and that spirit of acceptance also nurtures a rich and lively cultural life. Even Stein has been misconstrued: in her famous quote, she was talking about the loss of her Oakland family, not the city itself. BRENDA PAYTON

Since one disc often couldn't hold it all, multiple-disc sets became commonplace, usually with the movie on one DVD and the extra features on another.

title: NORTHROP WINS $900 MILLION RADAR PROJECT FOR AIR FORCE
description: Northrop Grumman, the maker of the Global Hawk unmanned spy plane, will receive an Air Force award worth about $900 million by the end of March to build and test airborne radar that can track ground targets and cruise missiles. On Dec. 4, the Defense Department approved development and demonstration of the multiplatform radar technology insertion program, said Chuck Paone, a spokesman for the Air Force Electronic Systems Center, which oversees the program. The project will run from 2004 through 2010, he said. The new radar is intended to replace Northrop's joint surveillance target attack radar system, which was used in Kuwait, Bosnia, Afghanistan and Iraq. That system can track only ground targets. Northrop received a $303 million design contract for the radar in 2000. The radar will be installed on Northrop's Global Hawk unmanned spy plane, and a larger version will go on a manned aircraft for surveillance of wider areas, Mr. Paone said. Northrop shares rose 32 cents, to $94.47.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Refiner Raises Funds
description: The Itochu Corporation of Japan and the Taiyo Oil Company bought $24.4 million of shares in the SK Corporation, South Korea's largest oil refiner, in a move that may help the company fend off a possible hostile takeover by Sovereign Asset Management, investors said. Itochu and Taiyo, both customers of SK, purchased a combined 0.74 percent stake in the company. Sovereign, a hedge fund based in Monaco that owns 14.99 percent of the SK Corporation, wants to oust directors at the company who favor using funds to bail out affiliates. Local SK Group creditors oppose Sovereign, as they may have to write off loans if cash is not provided to their units, and the sale to the two Japanese companies was seen by analysts as strengthening SK's hand.

title: Pork Shortage for the Homeless
description: The grinding effects of three years of lost jobs are showing up in continuing increases in hunger and homelessness in the nation's major cities. More than four out of five cities had to turn away applicants at emergency shelters this year. Limited resources are being pinched by rising demand, particularly from increasing numbers of families who are losing their homes, according to a survey by the United States Conference of Mayors. Requests for emergency food rose again, with more than 1 in 10 of the needy turned away for lack of resources. Most of the mayors anticipate that the demands will only grow next year despite the recovery.

Sales in November rose 29 percent compared with a year earlier, to 137 billion yen ($1.27 billion), the association said. The group, which is based in Tokyo, said its data covered 80 percent to 90 percent of all digital camera sales and shipments globally.

title: BIOPURE SHARES DECLINE 14% ON NEWS OF S.E.C. ALERT
description: Shares of Biopure, which is developing a human-blood substitute, fell about 14 percent yesterday after the Securities and Exchange Commission indicated that it might take action against the company. The company said Wednesday after United States markets closed that it received a so-called Wells notice from the S.E.C. The document is an alert that S.E.C. staff members might recommend charges against a company and gives the company a final opportunity to argue its case. The company said the S.E.C. inquiry probably involved talks with the Food and Drug Administration about testing Biopure's experimental blood substitute, Hemopure, in trauma patients. Biopure had said it expected approval in August for use in orthopedic surgery patients. Biopure will respond ''promptly and thoroughly'' to the notice, said a spokesman, Douglas Sayles. The company said it did not disclose communications with the F.D.A. because it did not believe that they were material. With approval, Hemopure would be first human-blood substitute available in the United States. The product acts like red blood cells to deliver oxygen to the body. Unlike donated blood, Hemopure does not have to be matched to a patient's blood type. Shares of Biopure fell 39 cents, to $2.43.

title: A See-Through State Government

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Debt Registry Established
description: Argentina will set up a voluntary registry of creditors holding the country's $88 billion in defaulted bonds, the economy ministry said. The government said it would open the registry on Jan. 12 with offices in London, Tokyo, Washington, Rome, Frankfurt and Buenos Aires. The announcement follows this week's unexpected visit to Argentina by an International Monetary Fund team. The two-day mission came amid rising tensions between Argentina and the agency, with the I.M.F. admitting that concern over Argentina's handling of its debt restructuring was one factor delaying approval of the first review of September's financial aid accord. The economy minister, Roberto Lavagna, said this week that the I.M.F. wanted the country to improve its relationship with creditors and to speed the restructuring process. Creation of a registry of creditors could help the country identify appropriate representatives of creditors for negotiations.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: BENIN: TOLL IN CRASH RISES TO 113 Foreign Minister Rogatien Biaou put the death toll in the crash of a UTA Boeing 727 on Thursday at 113, up from 82. Twenty-two people were injured, leaving 26 of the 151 passengers and 10 crew members unaccounted for. The pilot, a Libyan, survived. The plane failed to become airborne on take-off and skidded down the runway, smashing into a building before tumbling nose down into the Gulf of Guinea. Aviation officials suggested the plane was overloaded or unbalanced. UTA had been denied a license to register the plane in Lebanon because it did not fulfill "technical requirements," said the Lebanese transport minister, Najib Mikati. Instead the plane was registered in Guinea. But Guinea's transport minister, Cellou Dalein Diallo, said that after "all the customary checks, nothing prevented the delivery of an airworthiness certificate." (Agence France-Presse)

title: MEDIMMUNE'S ANTITRUST CASE AGAINST GENENTECH BLOCKED
description: MedImmune cannot pursue antitrust claims in its suit to invalidate a patent controlled by Genentech, the biotechnology company, for the method to create drugs using antibody molecules to fight diseases. Genentech and the Celltech Group of Britain reached a confidential agreement in 2001 to end a dispute over whose scientists first created the method of manufacturing combined human and nonhuman genes. MedImmune sued earlier this year, claiming the companies were wrongly using that agreement to demand royalties from competitors. Judge Mariana Pfaelzer in Federal District Court in Los Angeles ruled that there was no antitrust violation because a federal judge approved the agreement. The patent that is the subject of the dispute was issued under rules set by the United States Patent and Trademark Office, she said. ''This is not a case of an anticompetitive private agreement receiving immunity because it passed through government hands in some ministerial way,'' Judge Pfaelzer wrote in her decision issued on Wednesday. The MedImmune drug, Synagis, treats infant lung infections. The drug, which became available in the United States in 1998, had sales of $516 million last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDLEY, PEGGY (NEE MARION MILLER)
description: LINDLEY--Peggy (nee Marion Miller), of Old Black Point, Niantic, Connecticut, on December 25, 2003. Wife of the late Daniel Allen Lindley, she is survived by her son, Daniel Allen Lindley, Jr., grandchildren Daniel Allen Lindley III and Helen Lindley Hastings, and five greatgrandchildren. Born in New York City in 1907, she graduated from the Brearley School and left Bryn Mawr to study painting in New York with Walt Kuhn and at the Art Students' League. She had a solo exhibition in Englewood, New Jersey, and participated in group shows in New York City and Old Lyme, Connecticut. A retrospective exhibition of her paintings was held in The Red Barn at Old Black Point in August of 1996. Her piano and recorder playing, her Julia Child inspired cooking, and her enthusiasm were enjoyed by many friends over many years. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church, Niantic, Connecticut, in the summer of 2004.

A colorful mural, which begins on one wall and envelops the entire ceiling, depicts a maiden's dream: a handsome fellow encircled by a giant fish.

title: Chunnel Trip Is Faster By 20 Minutes
description: Americans planning to ride Eurostar, the train that goes through the English Channel Tunnel, can now buy tickets online and pay in dollars for trips between London and Paris or London and Brussels. And with the completion in September of a 46-mile section in England of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link, the trip is about 20 minutes shorter, as well -- 2 hours 35 minutes to Paris and 2 hours 20 minutes to Brussels. Top speed on the new stretch is 186 miles an hour, the same as in France and Belgium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAW, CAROLINE WIESS
description: LAW--Caroline Wiess. Of Houston, died peacefully at home on her birthday, December 24, 2003. She was born on Christmas Eve in Beaumont, TX in 1918 to Olga Keith and Harry Carothers Wiess. She attended Kinkaid School, The Ethel Walker School, and Sarah Lawrence College. She married William Howard Francis in 1948 and was happily married until his death in 1958. She married Theodore Newton Law in 1960. They shared twentynine wonderful years until Ted died in 1989. Caroline was predeceased by her parents and two sisters: Elizabeth Wiess Smith and Margaret Wiess Elkins. She is survived by her stepson, T.N. Law, Jr., of Oklahoma city, her brother-in-law, James A. Elkins, Jr., her nieces, Sandra Lloyd Smith, Sharon Smith Keller, Sydney Smith MacPherson, Elise Elkins Joseph, and Leslie Elkins Sasser, and her nephew, James A. Elkins III. Numerous grandnieces and nephews, and her loving friend Jo Marsh also survive her. She was actively involved in many cultural, educational, and civic activities in Houston, and Caroline was especially devoted to The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 p.m. on Monday, December 29, 2003, at St. John the Divine Episcopal Church, 2450 River Oaks Boulevard in Houston with The Reverend Dr. Laurens A. Hall officiating. Her family suggests that memorial contributions may be directed to The Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, P.O. Box 6826, Houston, TX 77265-6826 or your favorite charity. For information contact Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, Houston.

title: Reading the Signs
description: I HAVE had lots of amazing experiences in my life, but one of the most important was getting to know Margaret Mead. I was working on my Ph.D. in Communications at Columbia and was taking courses in anthropology, sociology and psychology. Nonverbal communication was a budding field -- it amazed me when you talked to people and you had the distinct impression that what they were saying to your face was inconsistent with what they believed. I began to research that area and came out with a plan for my doctoral dissertation on nonverbal behavior.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 14 about political betrayals in history misstated the position held by William Howard Taft under President Theodore Roosevelt, who later turned against him in Taft's presidential re-election campaign. He was secretary of war, not vice president. The article also misstated the timing of the split between Franklin Delano Roosevelt and his vice president, and a correction in this space last Sunday misstated the vice president's given name in some copies. The split came before Roosevelt's third term, not his second; the vice president was John Nance Garner, not James.

title: Word for Word/Kissinger on Pinochet; The Human Rights Crowd Gives Realpolitik the Jitters
description: HENRY KISSINGER, who had been President Richard Nixon's national security adviser, became his secretary of state less than a month after a bloody military coup in Chile toppled its leftist president, Salvador Allende, on Sept. 11, 1973, and brought Gen. Augusto Pinochet to power. The Nixon administration had instigated and supported Allende's overthrow, but the extensive human rights abuses that resulted were to plague Mr. Kissinger until he left office in 1977, along with President Gerald Ford.

title: CRIME
description: O frabjous day! In his new 87th Precinct police procedural, THE FRUMIOUS BANDERSNATCH (Simon & Schuster, $25), Ed McBain takes us through the looking glass and into the surreal world of the music business. Armed with lots of informative dope on the cutthroat marketing practices of this $12 billion industry, McBain spins a riotous, if ultimately sobering, tale about a record release that goes awry. Barney Loomis, the C.E.O. and sole shareholder of Bison Records, is giving a lavish press party (on a yacht, yet!) for Tamar Valparaiso's debut album, ''Bandersnatch,'' when two masked men crash the party and kidnap the sexy 20-year-old singer. In short order, a ransom is demanded, the F.B.I. steps in, the press jumps all over the story, and the CD shoots to the top of the charts. But in the end, you know that the hysteria will be resolved by Steve Carella, ''a weary detective sitting behind a cigarette-scarred desk in a grimy squad room.''

title: Follow That Nun!
description: Sam Gamett, the protagonist of Jim Kokoris's novel SISTER NORTH (St. Martin's, $23.95), is a Chicago lawyer who doesn't like the inspirational knickknacks that Maureen, his assistant, keeps giving him. What does she think he's going to do with a framed photograph of a nun on a bicycle? Sam doesn't know -- or care -- that the woman in the picture is Sister Maria North, the nun with the popular television show, or that Maureen is a dedicated fan. It all begins to matter deeply, however, after a crazed client walks into Sam's office, pulls a gun on him and blows Maureen away instead. Sister North's nighttime show becomes Sam's salvation. He has to meet her -- and drives all the way from Chicago to Lake Eagleton, Wis., only to arrive in a cross between a tourist trap and a necropolis. But Sister North has mysteriously vanished (her show is in long-term reruns), and Sam's hope crashes. He wants to know why he's still alive, and he thinks only she can tell him. Jim Kokoris's characters, and scenes set in Midwestern bars and buses and restaurants, would do Tom Waits proud. Everyone's made desperate by the waiting, including us. But there is a payoff. When Sister North does finally reappear, her answer to Sam's existential question is unexpected, hilarious and more than worth the trip. Sally Eckhoff

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAFTEL, STANLEY
description: SHAFTEL -- Stanley. Prom inent Long Island, NY, architect, passed away on December 26, 2003, at the age of 79. He was born on March 14, 1924, in Brooklyn, NY. After graduating from Brooklyn Tech, he was a pilot in the Naval Air Corps from 1942-1943. With his degree in architecture from Oklahoma A&M University, he began practice in New York City, and opened his own architectural firm in 1952. He specialized in unique contemporary custom homes and numerous developments throughout New York and 16 other states. He also taught architecture at NYIT in Westbury, Long Island. description: TURYN--Arthur. Born Warsaw, Poland, 1919. Son of Nachman and Esther (nee Sendacz) and brother of Simeon, Sara and Mira, all murdered in the Holocaust. Husband of Charlotte (nee Levitan), 1948-1989. Father of Richard, Emile, Larry and Michael. Lifelong friend of Alexander Reindorf, of Warsaw and Rehovoth, Israel. Member of Warsaw Bet-ar. title: Cape Town
description: The Portuguese navigator Bartholomeu Dias, on a mission from King Joo II to find a way around the southern tip of Africa, discovered the Cape of Good Hope in 1488, and for the next 400 years, most people save sailors and South Africans pretty much forgot about it. But in the last five years that has begun to change: well-heeled Germans, British and Italians are snapping up land on sheer promontories and pristine beachfronts along the 30-mile finger of Cape territory, and its hub, Cape Town, has sprouted luxury hotels and classy shops like Whack-a-Mole games sprout moles. Unavoidable, for the world is rediscovering South Africa now that apartheid has been gone for a decade. But too bad, in a way: before long, this loveliest of African cities will be a genuine Riviera, with all that implies.

But unlike, say, a critic rereading ''Alice in Wonderland'' through the lens of historical materialism in the 1950's, the Darwinian social theorist today might just see his findings trumpeted in major newspapers -- especially if they have something to do with sex.
