title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOVE, FREEMAN DONNELLON, M.D.
description: LOVE--Freeman Donnellon, M.D. Age 91, surrounded by family, in Danbury, CT. on December 26, 2003. Former resident of Sandy Hook, CT., Brooklyn Heights and Goshen, NY. Devoted and beloved husband of 62 years of Andree Walton. Cherished father of Francis W. Love (Lorrie Barstow), Peter W. Love (Gael Malkenson), Georgette Love and Patsey Love. Cherished uncle and loving guardian of Margot Marshall, Lucinda Marshall Tyler, Robert Marshall and Constance Marshall Verhulst. Adored grandfather of Heather Denise Love, Graham Hamilton Love, Page Lyle Love, Freeman Donnellon Love II, and Rachel Walton Love. Adored granduncle of Andree and Otto Verhulst, and Sam Marshall-Harvey. He was predeceased by his seven brothers and sisters: Grace Blust; Cornelius Ruxton Love, Jr.; Harriet Smith; Richard Love; his twin brother Robert; Hamilton Love; and Margretta Marshall. Born in Brooklyn Heights in 1913, Dr. Love was the son of Cornelius Ruxton Love, M.D. and Grace Anderson Smith. He attended Poly Prep Country Day School Class of 1933, Brown University Class of 1937, and Cornell Medical School. Dr. Love served with distinction in the Army Medical Corps during WWII where he attained the rank of Major. He was attached to the 71st Armored Division. His unit spearheaded the liberation of POW and concentration camps in Germany and Austria. Upon return from the war, he joined his father's practice in general medicine in Brooklyn Heights, and was associated with Samaritan, Brooklyn, Long Island College, and Kings County Hospital, where he served as Clinical Professor of Internal Medicine. He retired from general practice in the late 1960's and became Medical Director of the Morgan Guarantee Trust Co., retiring in 1982. He was the only person to be elected member of both the Medical Club of New York and the Medical Club of Brooklyn during that time. Dr. Love was a trustee emeritus of Poly Prep CDS and a founding board member of St. Anne's School in Brooklyn Heights. Dr. Love was a man of the highest integrity. His wit, sense of duty and love of family will be sorely missed by those close to him and others lucky enough to have known him. He returns with honor. Services private. Donations in his name may be made to Poly Prep CDS Scholarship Fund or the charity of your choice.

On back-to-back nights earlier this month, he dropped in to Lotus on West 14th Street for the unveiling of a new fashion line, and turned up at the opening of Crobar, a dance club in Chelsea, mingling with stars like Rosie Perez, long-stemmed models and middle-aged rous trussed in dinner jackets. Wherever he goes, Mr. Jimenez himself is an object of fascination. ''You get the buttonhole,'' he said. ''You get the table, you get the attention.''

title: The New Republicans

Bush's style the way they did for his father or Ronald Reagan when they were in office. We have thus had an unobstructed view of what the 21st-century version of the party looks like. It's very clear this is not the father's G.O.P.

title: In Winter, The City Almost Sleeps; The Greens Play Very Firm

But not so for Sam Kim, a stationery store owner from Bedford Park, in the Bronx. He can be found, three or four days a week, breathing fresh air and getting in his exercise at the Van Cortlandt Golf Course in Van Cortlandt Park.

Mr. Andrews, 48, represents the third generation of clockmakers in his family, following in the steps of his grandfather Andreas Andreasenne, who came to this country from Copenhagen more than 100 years ago.

title: Abroad in a Chastened World
description: WHATEVER possessed me last summer to take my children to three places damaged by violent acts of man or God? Bali. Madagascar. Hong Kong. Peerlessly beautiful places that have been the scenes of, respectively, terrorist atrocity, civil strife and pestilence. It was not, as one cynical friend suggested, morbid curiosity or an unnatural taste for risk. Nor was it the desire to demonstrate solidarity for three places that, in fact, are old friends to our relentlessly peripatetic family. (We live in Italy, spend summers in Africa and often travel to Asia. No, I'm afraid the whole thing was done on impulse, inspired by the appearance of super bargain fares from airlines like Cathay Pacific and Thai, right about the time school let out.

Frank Gehry's masterpiece is architecture without boundaries. It is inseparable from the music performed inside it and from the kinetic energy of the city outside its bodacious walls. A building that is to 21st-century Los Angeles what Garnier's Opera House was to 19th-century Paris: the empathic center of the world.

title: Mexico Adrift

The government's failure to deliver on high public expectations could unleash a reaction that would jeopardize the country's political and economic modernization.

title: The Albums and Songs of the Year
description: 1. OUTKAST: 'SPEAKERBOXXX/THE LOVE BELOW' -- (Arista) One CD is about women; the other CD is about ghetto life. And yet they manage to avoid nearly every clich that these themes typically bring out in rappers. The two-disc set unfolds like a great independent movie: you never know what to expect next. By the end, you want to get down on your knees and say, ''Thank you, OutKast, for saving mainstream rap this year.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 14 about political betrayals in history misstated the position held by William Howard Taft under President Theodore Roosevelt, who later turned against him in Taft's presidential re-election campaign. He was secretary of war, not vice president. The article also misstated the timing of the split between Franklin Delano Roosevelt and his vice president, and a correction in this space last Sunday misstated the vice president's given name in some copies. The split came before Roosevelt's third term, not his second; the vice president was John Nance Garner, not James.

title: If Beauties Multiply, They'll Be Plain to See

In it, middle-class Americans -- a police officer, a waitress, a local radio D.J. -- were transformed by plastic surgery, sometimes several procedures at a time, from plain Janes and Johns into coiffed, glossed movie-star lookalikes.

title: The Movies of the Year
description: 1. 'MASTER AND COMMANDER: THE FAR SIDE OF THE WORLD' -- I surprise myself with this choice, but Peter Weir's old-fashioned high-seas adventure surprised me with its energy and sweep. The battle sequences are appropriately rousing and bloody, but the film's greatest accomplishment is its recreation of the hierarchies and rituals of the British Navy during the Napoleonic wars. Russell Crowe plays Jack Aubrey with all the charisma of a 19th-century rock star, and Paul Bettany is terrific as his intellectual pal, Stephen Maturin. The best war movie in a year of war movies, and one of the best ever.

title: For Parents, Courses on Remedial Bullying
description: THESE are good times for bullying. Last January in Connecticut, J. Daniel Scruggs, a 12-year-old, hung himself, ostensibly because of torment he had endured at the hands of his classmates. Daniel had missed 44 out of the previous 78 days of school. And last summer, the authorities say, some high school football players from Bellmore, N.Y., apparently thought sodomy, with broomsticks and golf balls, was a good way to shore up team spirit.

title: Banner Year For Lost Opportunities
description: The biggest disappointment of the year has been the failure of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to protect the ground zero planning process from political interference. I refer not only to the fast-track timetable decreed by Gov. George E. Pataki, which has imposed the civic equivalent of cloture on public discussion, but to the symbolic subtext of Daniel Libeskind's design concept, which is political in assuming that answers have been found to questions that have not yet been asked.

title: A Drinking Life: McSorley's at 150
description: MCSORLEY'S Old Ale House will celebrate its 150th birthday in 2004, and over those many years it has been the subject of memorable paintings and photographs. Many of these appear in a calendar that can be purchased at the Museum of the City of New York gift shop and at the bar, 15 East Seventh Street, New York, N.Y. 10003. It costs $10, or $12 by mail.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Patty Jenkins; Monstrous Fun
description: ''MAKING a movie was freaking easy, compared to this,'' said Patty Jenkins as she wrestled with the seat levers of a black Cadillac Escalade. She was struggling to get the back seat down for three pals, one of whom was her boyfriend, Jesse Stern, a writer for television. Behind the wheel was the car's owner, BT, a k a Brian Transeau, the D.J., musician and composer who wrote the score for Ms. Jenkins's first feature film, ''Monster.'' That BT refused to put gas in the Escalade's empty tank and was moving onto the freeway was no cause for alarm. ''We like to live on the edge,'' Ms. Jenkins said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CECI, JOSEPH WILLIAM
description: CECI--Joseph William. 79, on December 23, 2003. Beloved husband of Virginia. Loving father of Vincent, Christine, Timothy and the late James by his first wife, the late Lynn Ceci. Affectionate step-father of Gary, Greg, Denise and Louis, Jr. Dear brother of Rosemary, Anna and the late Eleanor. Beloved grandfather of Shannon, Richard, James and William. Veteran of World War II and Korean Wars. Graduate of CCNY/Queens College. New York based Captain with American Airlines for more than 30 years. Active leadership and board roles with Town of North Hempstead Urban Renewal Agency, Locust Valley Library, Allied Pilots Association Flight Safety Group. An extraordinary man whose inspiration, love and vitality, will live in the hearts of many always. Memorial service to be held on Saturday December 27th at 3PM at the North Shore Universalist Unitarian Society, 48 Shelter Rock Rd., Manhasset, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Joseph W. Ceci, St. Francis Development Office, St. Francis Hospital, 100 Port Washington Blvd, Roslyn, NY 11576.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: BIKE BARGAIN VBT -- Bicycling Vacations is taking $300 a couple off the price of its escorted tours of France in April through June. With the discount, rates start at $1,895 a person, based on double occupancy, for seven days. The price includes six nights in hotels and country inns, most meals, two bilingual guides, scheduled sightseeing, a support van and use of a bike and helmet. Air fare is extra. Itineraries include the Loire Valley, Provence, Burgundy and Normandy. The routes are rated easy in most cases, with the Provence tour listed as easy to moderate. For information, call (800) 245-3868 or visit www.vbt.com.

title: Page Two: The Week/Dec. 20-26; A Mad Cow on American Soil
description: Of the roughly 36 million head of cattle slaughtered annually in this country, at least one of them, a Holstein from a diary farm near Yakima, Wash., has now tested positive for mad cow disease. It took two weeks to get lab results, agriculture officials said, and will take days longer to say how widespread the outbreak could be. But by Wednesday, McDonald's, Tysons and other companies in the meat business were suffering as investors readied for consumer reactions. Matthew L. Wald

title: In Black and White
description: Although Sammy Davis, Jr., was descended from the dangers of the Negro plantation-this one located in rural North Carolina-it was the Cuban blood that would confuse him for a lifetime. Family members on the Cuban side would refer to it as "this Cuban thing." They meant the currency implied in a particular shade of skin color. And, linked to that, they meant the way love and resentment and distance and abandonment can infect any family, the way it could zoom in and out of mothers and sons and daughters, like a storm whooshing sideways on a horizontal force of its own, missing no one. So it was with his own family.

title: Reports of Rape and Torture Inside Zimbabwean Militia

Within an hour, she had donned a nun's habit as a disguise and slipped out of the church through a side entrance, literally fleeing for her safety, said Ms. Siyangapi and human rights groups that are now sheltering her.

title: Business People; Hip Professor Meets Hip Businessman

title: QUICK BITE/Westfield; Eat, Stretch and Meditate
description: Instead of lite vinaigrette, what you get on the side at On the Side is a panoply of options to pamper yourself. Follow the curvy stone path that winds through the seven-table cafe and you'll arrive at two gleaming yoga studios, four manicure/massage/facial treatment rooms, a glass-enclosed meditation yard and a boutique. The proprietor of the spa and cafe, Barbara Mitchell, aligns herself more with the foodie crowd -- she is a graduate of the Natural Gourmet Cookery School in Manhattan and rips a page out of Alice Waters's cookbook in her efforts to use only regional, organic foods. But she loves to work out, she said, ''and I had to do more than just the cafe to get the business off the ground'' a year ago, ''so I thought a spa complemented it nicely.''

title: One Dog Night
description: Some overnight guests are dogs. Some may even be coming for New Year's Eve. And what good host would want a visitor to sleep on a cold hard floor? Aero Paws provides dogs with a fleece-covered place to rest their furry heads. It inflates in a minute thanks to an electric pump, which also adjusts the bed's firmness. (Some pets like a soft bed and others a hard one, according to the mattress authorities at Aero.) The bed comes in three sizes: small ($59.99), medium ($69.99) and large ($89.99). At Gracious Home, 1220 Third Avenue (70th Street) or 1992 Broadway (67th Street) or (800) 338-7809. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Personal Business; Those Year-End Bonuses Aren't Always Green
description: JESSICA VARGA received no year-end bonus check this year. Not a share of stock or even a gift check from her employer, DVC Worldwide, a marketing firm in Morristown, N.J. Yet Ms. Varga, an assistant account executive who has never received a bonus, does not seem to mind: she was given her very first office -- in fact, a coveted corner one.

title: Suspicions Linger After the Death of a Teacher
description: EIGHTEEN months later, the death of Leslie Buck continues to fascinate the residents of Stonington.

title: Finding a Vacuum in Office Politics
description: Peter Handal has some advice for executives who want to increase workplace productivity. "Ban water-cooler conversations," suggests Mr. Handal, the president and chief executive of Dale Carnegie Training, the global workplace consulting firm. He is only half joking. In a new survey of more than 2,000 workers, the company found that 63 percent rated office politics as the biggest waste of time in the workplace. Mr. Handal said his staff was initially surprised at the results.

title: Ideas & Trends; Middlemen in the Low-Wage Economy
description: AFTER federal agents raided 60 Wal-Mart stores in October and found more than 200 illegal immigrants in the cleaning crews, the world's largest retailer was quick to defend itself from this enormous embarrassment. Wal-Mart's officers said they had no idea those workers were illegal, insisting they knew next to nothing about the workers from Mexico, Mongolia, Russia and elsewhere because they were employed by contractors. Nor did Wal-Mart know, its spokesmen said, that the contractors were cutting corners by not paying overtime or Social Security taxes or by flouting other labor laws, as the investigators claimed.

title: The Brewers Want a Winner More Than Anybody Else
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: That Stubborn Jar, And Other Obstacles
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Find Politics Still an Uphill Path
description: FOUR years ago, Vivian Viloria-Fisher, a member of the Suffolk Legislature, predicted at a news conference that the Legislature's newly formed four-member women's political caucus would quickly become obsolete because the number of female and male officials would soon be equal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MINTZ, THOMAS F.
description: MINTZ--Thomas F., 39, of New York City, on December 17, 2003. Beloved son of Mary F. Mintz and the late Roger M. Mintz Sr., of Foxboro, MA. Loving brother of Kathy Muncy of Abington, MA; Robert Mintz of Ft. Meyers, FL; Roger Mintz Jr. of New York City, NY; and George Mintz of Franklin, NH. Devoted uncle of Katrina Mintz of Framingham, MA. Donations may be made in celebration of Tom's life and his valiant fight with diabetes to the American Diabetes Association Memorial and Honor Program, PO Box 2680, North Canton, OH 44720. Memorial services are planned for a future date in New York City.

title: The Classical Moments of the Year
description: 1. VOYAGES OF THE DAMNED -- Berlioz's ''Damnation de Faust'' offered the best and the worst by way of a single piece, both productions German-inspired and both on the West Coast. In June the San Francisco Opera wrestled Berlioz's expansive soul to the ground, force-feeding it with grim sadomasochism and freighting it with messages of despair that it was never meant to carry. In September, at the Los Angeles opera, Achim Freyer's production would have seemed equally strange to 19th-century audiences. Yet his devotion to the music gave the strangeness a cogency and aptness.

title: The Weak Will Try To Shift The Battle
description: THE American military has now fought two wars in two years, earning two dramatically swift battlefield victories that are already changing the face of future warfare.

title: Karbala Transformed After Suicide Attacks
description: KARBALA, Iraq, Dec. 28  So revered is this city among Shiite Muslims around the world that its golden domes and minarets draw millions of pilgrims each year to spiritual reflection.

title: Corrections
description: The information box with a restaurant review of La Zingara on Dec. 14 misstated the location. It is Bethel, not Danbury.

title: Leaving Suffolk Better Off
description: WHAT was lacking was any sense of stability.

title: Roslyn Brought to Task Over Housing Project
description: The Glenwood/Glen Head Civic Association is distressed that the Roslyn Board of Trustees will not require an environmental impact statement for a housing project proposed for the southern end of Hempstead Harbor. Instead, the trustees will apparently rely on an environmental impact statement for a previous proposal.

title: Film Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: Halting the Spread of Nuclear Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Questioning The Age Of Wal-Mart
description: WAL-MART, it seems, is the corporate Pied Piper of modern global capitalism, leading the way toward an economic future of admirable efficiency and low prices but also painful change for many workers and communities. And 2003 was the year the ''Wal-Martization of the economy'' really came into view. The retailing powerhouse toppled more rivals and became the target of lawsuits for unpaid overtime and a federal investigation into its use of poorly paid illegal immigrants as janitors.

title: Murdoch Gets a Jewel. Who'll Get His Crown?
description: RUPERT MURDOCH, the chairman of the News Corporation, has been trying to buy or build an American satellite television business for 20 years, a campaign that sometimes appeared to be his life's work.

title: For those who get up from the tables, a New Year's splash
description: New Year's Eve in Las Vegas is, not surprisingly, staged as a night of extreme entertainment.

title: California's Year
description: The holiday season is supposed to be about Americans coming together, but this particular stretch -- the New Year run-up -- is also a reminder of how far apart we are. Contemplating its year in review, California looks back on 12 months of budget catastrophes and political crises punctuated by a series of weather disasters that sounds like a plague report from the Old Testament. Most of the nation's citizens, by contrast, ended the year with the same governor they had at the beginning, and never gave a moment's thought to tragic mudslides.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''No Fixed Points: Dance in the Twentieth Century,'' on Dec. 7, misstated the title of the current Broadway hit by Twyla Tharp to the music of Billy Joel. Like the song itself, the production is called ''Movin' Out,'' not ''Movin' On.''

title: In Winter, The City Almost Sleeps; Italian Ice Water In His Veins
description: TEN dollars a day is not much to run a business on. It barely pays for a week's electricity or the tap water it takes to make a barrel of Italian ice. Still, that's what Pete Benfaremo often takes in this time of year. But that doesn't faze the Lemon Ice King of Corona, who has presided over the corner of 108th Street and 52nd Avenue in Queens for 58 years -- spring, summer, fall and winter.

title: Democracy Reigns, but Uneasy Lies the Head That Wears the Crown
description: EVER since the Renaissance spawned the set of ideas that coalesced as the modern concept of democracy, Western leaders have told themselves that the political creed to which they adhere and which, to a great extent, has conquered the modern world, is the most elastic, the most accommodating and, therefore, the most enduring.

title: The Classical Moments of the Year
description: 1. MOVIN' ON DOWN? -- For starters, a salute to Paul Kellogg and the adventurous New York City Opera for their visionary proposal to decamp from Lincoln Center and build a new house at ground zero. That developers questioned whether an opera company might be too rarefied an institution to anchor an arts complex at this meaningful site was the most discouraging turn in the classical-music season. More power to ''the people's opera.''

title: Alternate-Side Parking Rules in 2004
description: Following are the days on which alternate-side street-cleaning rules will be suspended next year in New York City. Boldface indicates major legal holidays, on which stopping, standing and parking rules are suspended, except where they are normally in effect seven days a week. Drivers should follow posted signs carefully to avoid tickets.

title: The People's Patrician
description: Paul Moore b. 1919

title: For a Utility Company, A Problem With Parrots
description: Frustrated by an increasing number of power outages caused by parakeets nesting on utility poles, the United Illuminating company plans to meet with the State Department of Environment Protection early next month to find a solution.

title: Page Two: The Week/Dec. 20-26; A Merciful End to the Sniper Case
description: A Virginia jury spared the life of Lee Malvo, the younger of the two snipers who terrorized the Washington area last fall, killing 10 people. In sentencing Mr. Malvo to life in prison, the jury appeared to take account of his youth -- he was 17 at the time of his crimes -- and of his lawyers' argument that he had been under the influence of the other sniper, John Muhammad. Mr. Muhammad, 42, was sentenced to death last month. Both men face more trials in Virginia and other states for additional shootings in their killing spree. Adam Liptak

title: Woman in the Ring
description: Elizabeth Hulette b. 1960

title: Hardcover Highlights
description: NONFICTION | FICTION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENFELD, ADELE S.
description: ROSENFELD--Adele S., 87, died December 19 at Foulkeways, Gwynedd, PA. Formerly of Staten Island, Mt. Vernon, NY. Beloved wife of Leonard J., mother of Susan Rosenfeld and Paula Schram, grandmother of three, greatgrandmother of six, sister of Stephen Siegel. Civic leader, gifted teacher and poet. Contributions may be made to Foulkeways Child Care Center, 1120 Meetinghouse Road, Gwynedd, PA. 19436.

title: Late-Night Guests as Morning People
description: ELLEN DEGENERES gave the slightly pregnant Gwyneth Paltrow a pram on a Dec. 8 segment of ''The Ellen DeGeneres Show.'' She also teased her about ''some horseplay with Coldplay.'' (Coldplay is the band led by Chris Martin, whom Ms. Paltrow had secretly married a few days before the show was broadcast.) On Dec. 10, Ms. DeGeneres asked Tom Cruise to recreate his famous air-guitar slide from the film ''Risky Business,'' and he did, pointing out that this time ''I'm gonna leave my pants on.'' The next day Ms. DeGeneres had a request for the newly minted couple from the reality show ''Average Joe'': ''Would y'all make out for us right now?'' Then she ended the week drinking Champagne with Diane Keaton, who was promoting her film ''Something's Gotta Give.'' ''We figured if we got you likkered up enough,'' Ms. DeGeneres said, ''you'd do that nude scene here.''

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about an unofficial DVD of the television series "Firefly" misstated the name of the publication in which a Roger Ebert column advocated the creation of commentary tracks by fans. It was the print magazine Yahoo Internet Life; there is no online magazine called YahooLife.com.

title: New Luxury Hotels Lead A Revival in Miami
description: MINIMALIST chic may have been the prevailing formula among the boutique hotels that thrived in South Beach in the 1990's, but the latest trend, fueled by a growing number of business travelers jetting in from this country and Latin America, is unabashed luxury.

title: A Co-op's Rules on Dogs and Bikes
description: Q. Last summer, my co-op announced a new house rule, telling shareholders that pets and bicycles must enter and leave through heavy metal doors that open onto a Dumpster area in the rear. As a bicycle rider in my 50's, the thought of having to open metal doors instead of using the automatic sliding doors in the front of the building made me angry. When questioned, the board said it was to ''preserve the appearance and value of our building.'' We have now been told that those who disregard this rule will be fined. What recourse do I have? . . . Blossom Nickinski, Manhattan.

title: A Los Angeles Stunner Gives Inspiration
description: GARDENERS need inspiration at this time of the year, a vision or two of what can be done when hard work and nature conspire to create beauty. Late this fall I drew my low-season lift not from a plantsman but from an installation artist, Robert Irwin, who says he barely knew a clematis from a grapevine before he set out to design the stunning gardens at the J. Paul Getty Center in Los Angeles.

title: To Do: Kill Self
description: THE TRUE AND OUTSTANDING ADVENTURES OF

title: Tasteful Imitations And Sagging Follow-Ups
description: Jon Pareles, Neil Strauss, Ben Ratliff and Kelefa Sanneh listened to a lot of bad pop music in 2003; herewith, their least fond recollections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, PAULA REIBEL
description: SCHWARTZ--Paula Reibel, 78, of ovarian cancer on December 21. Playwright, author of 36 Elizabeth Mansfield Regencies and three historicals by Paula Reibel, Paula Jonas and Paula Reid. She wrote as she lived, with intelligence, wit and style. Condolences to her family. Devoted readers and book business friends mourn her passing. Victoria Pryor, Arcadia

title: BENEFITS
description: Come Hear the Music Play

title: The Year In Documentaries
description: DOCUMENTARIES commanded an extraordinary amount of attention this year, from Andrew Jarecki's ''Capturing the Friedmans,'' first shown at at the Sundance Film Festival in January, to Nathaniel Kahn's ''My Architect,'' a surprising commercial success that opened in November at Film Forum in Manhattan and continues to draw large crowds.

title: Flying Tigers
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''A Museum Increases Its Wingspan'' (Nov. 16), by Matthew L. Wald, about the new Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center in Chantilly, Va.: As a member of the original Flying Tigers, I would like to comment on the P-40 on display there. On April 15, 1941, President Roosevelt signed an order forming the American Volunteer Group to aid China in its fight against the invading Japanese. This order, permitting American military pilots to resign and join Gen. Claire Chennault's group being formed in China, was answered by men from the Army, Navy and Marines.

title: Our Towns; On Farm of Pampered Cows, Couple Cringes at the Mention of Mad Ones
description: ANY doubt about who is really in charge at Ken and Julie Bechtold's dairy farm along a rustic ribbon of road is dispelled at the stockade fence out front. There, outside a weathered barn, a yellow sign urges visitors to yield with a simple message: ''Moo Cow Xing.''

title: Here to There, Cheek to Cheek
description: MY husband and I may be the best amateur hustle dancers in Toronto. Don't envy us too much; doing the hustle is a lonely calling in a city fixated on fox trot and swing. Without a community of fellow dancers, we have nowhere to practice between lessons and no opportunity to study other hustlers' techniques and style. That's why we found ourselves considering the Hustle Dance Cruise 2004, a four-day Caribbean jaunt replete with lessons and dance parties. Even better, the hustle contingent would be part of a much larger Royal Caribbean trip, so if we tired of the dance floor there would be plenty of other things to do.

description: To the Editor:

description: Sir Wilfred Thesiger b. 1910

title: Birth of a Vacation
description: Kemmons Wilson b. 1912

title: Rebecca Bell, Mark Sorensen
description: Rebecca MacLeod Bell and Mark Axel Sorensen were married yesterday in Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. Wendy Fitting, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the First Unitarian Universalist Church of Gloucester. The Rev. Dr. Cecil H. Rose, who is the maternal grandfather of the bride and a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Halting the Spread of Nuclear Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: New England Rolls Into Top Spot in the A.F.C.
description: Few seasons end as they begin, but considering the New England Patriots' karma and will, who is surprised that New England's did? Ambushed in their season opener at Buffalo, 31-0, the Patriots gained redemption and much more in flipping Buffalo, 31-0, on Saturday at Gillette Stadium.

title: Page Two: The Week/Dec. 20-26; Pakistan's Nuclear Secrets
description: When he is not narrowly escaping assassination attempts -- two roadside bomb attacks in the last two weeks -- President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan is under pressure to do something about his country's rogue nuclear scientists.

title: Nets Pursue Griffin Despite Assault and Drug Charges
description: The Nets are positioning themselves to take another gamble, on one of the highest-risk players in the N.B.A.

title: The Stories of Richard Bausch
description: Nobody In Hollywood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUPNICK, ELLIOT
description: ZUPNICK--Elliot. Died on Thursday, December 25 after a courageous battle with prostate cancer. He is survived by Lillian, his beloved wife of 57 years, his loved and loving children Judith and Henry (Judith), his adored and adoring grandchildren Daniel, Benjamin and Sarah, his brother Sidney (Toby), his sister Ruth Hendel (Philip), his aunt Ruth Beck (Alex). Also by many in-laws, cousins, nieces and nephews. He was a brilliant and charismatic professor of economics for almost fifty years, first at CUNY and then at Columbia University where he taught, encouraged and inspired many generations of students. A modest and gentle man of great integrity, he will be greatly missed. The funeral will take place on Sunday, December 28 at Plaza Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue at 10AM.

title: UP TO 13 ARE DEAD IN ATTACKS IN IRAQ
description: At least four soldiers from the occupying forces and at least nine Iraqis were killed Saturday in four highly organized suicide bombing attacks in this Shiite holy city 60 miles southwest of Baghdad. More than 100 soldiers and civilians were wounded. Most of the casualties were not American.

title: Friendly Persuasion
description: During this season of thick tension, high drama and mini-nervous-breakdowns, we would all do well to take some lessons from the exemplary lives of Lee Bailey and Mary Cantwell. Bailey, who died this year at 76, was the author of 18 books on food and entertaining, a sort of lifestyle guru before there was such a thing and the antithesis of Martha Stewart. ''I really am too lazy to make radish roses, even if I liked them,'' he wrote in the introduction to ''City Food,'' where he also explained why the coconut flan on Page 33 of his book was photographed showing the crack where it had been put back together. ''I wanted you to see that it is the overall presentation that is important and that a few imperfections are perfectly acceptable.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HECHTMAN, PAULINE
description: HECHTMAN--Pauline, 92. After a full, enriching life succumbed to short illness on December 24. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Mother of Robert, mother-in-law of Phyllis Erna, both of McLean, Virginia. Proud grandmother of Douglas Marc. Dedicated educator, former principal of P.S. 184 and 41 in Brooklyn. Subsequently served as Secretary of NYC League of Women Voters.

title: Meredith Epstein, Jeffrey Goodman
description: Meredith Harper Epstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Epstein of Jericho, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Jeffrey William Goodman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan R. Goodman of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Marvin Antosofsky is to officiate at Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHURCH, JOSEPH
description: CHURCH--Joseph. December 23, 2003. Beloved husband of Alexandria. Devoted father of Amanda and Joseph. Cherished grandfather of Susannah Jane. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral private. A celebration of his life will be announced at a later date.

title: Business; Catering to a Love Affair With the Past
description: NOT long ago, scrapbooks were fusty repositories of yellowing newsprint and dried prom corsages. Now, they are more likely to be put together using archival-quality materials, sophisticated layouts and polished graphics.

title: Toronto Hotels Add Tax To Promote the City
description: More than 100 hotels in the Toronto metropolitan area have agreed to levy a 3 percent charge on rooms beginning in January to finance an international marketing campaign to promote the city. The Greater Toronto Hotel Association said the charge was needed because the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome last spring had devastated the tourism industry. Government financing for marketing purposes was too meager to do the job, according to the association.

title: Year-End Is Crucial For Alcohol Sales, Too
description: TIME for a little holiday libation?

title: Ancient Myths, Made in America
description: The producer Robert Halmi Sr., who has transformed myths from ''The Odyssey'' to ''Gulliver's Travels'' into movies, spoke of his newest foray into fantasy, ''Dreamkeeper,'' like a man obsessed.

title: A New Movement Logs On to the Democratic Party and May Reshape It
description: EVEN if Howard Dean's own electoral ambitions are not realized, he may take credit for ushering in an era of movement politics that could have implications for the Democrats, and Republicans, for years to come.

title: The Art and Artists Of the Year
description: 1. PAIRS -- While Picasso and Matisse duked it out at the Modern, Manet and Velzquez paired off at the Met in the ultimate blockbuster. The first rooms were a survey of great Spanish painting of the 17th and 18th centuries; after that came a virtual Manet retrospective, with some Degas and Courbet thrown in for good measure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHANNING, ALEID KATHLEEN
description: CHANNING--Aleid Kathleen. Of Stonington, CT and formerly of New York City and Lenox, MA. Passed away on December 21, 2003 at the age of 88. Beloved aunt of Julia Channing Bell and her husband Mark of Marshfield Hills, MA. William E. Channing and his wife Philippine and his daughter and three sons of Santa Fe, NM, Aleid Channing of London, England and Christopher Malcolm of Hants, England. A memorial service will be held at Calvary Church, Stonington, CT on Saturday, January 24, 2004 at 11:00 AM. A spring burial will take place in Lenox, MA.

title: Minnesota's Garnett Isn't Lone Wolf Anymore
description: Come June, one of two things will define Latrell Sprewell's season: his profane behavior in his return to Madison Square Garden, or his role in lifting the Minnesota Timberwolves to championship contention.

title: Tub Tales
description: To the Editor: Ms. Baker described the magnificent bath she enjoyed at Singita Private Game Reserve in South Africa.

title: Please, Mr. Postman
description: IT had all the makings of a practical joke. But Glenn Nordlinger never found it funny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERENTSON, JOHN FRANKLIN
description: BERENTSON--John Franklin. On December 19th in New York City. After graduating from Lehigh University, he served in the U.S. Navy and became a successful cable TV executive, but will best be remembered as a selfless husband, father and friend. He was the cherished husband of Lynne Gorman Berentson and beloved father of and best friend to Ben Berentson. He is mourned by his three loving sisters, nieces, nephews, mother-in-law and many devoted friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITAN, UR, HANA
description: LEVITAN-UR--Hana. Died on December 26 at home in Larchmont just short of her 102nd birthday. Survived by daughter Lillian Bernstein (Leslie), three grandchildren and their families. Services Sunday, at noon, at Riverside Chapel, Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Second Best
description: Landrum B. Shettles b. 1909

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about an unofficial DVD of the television series ''Firefly'' misstated the name of the publication in which a Roger Ebert column advocated the creation of commentary tracks by fans. It was the print magazine Yahoo Internet Life; there is no online magazine called YahooLife.com.

title: In Lieu of Flowers: Remembering 17 Who Made a Difference
description: Long Island First

title: A Premium Steak, at a Premium Price
description: I took a chance on Flames Steak House, on the advice of a friend who knows a good steak when he sees one. He wasn't wrong in his assessment: the prime porterhouse I shared with him at Flames outflanked every other piece of beef I've eaten in 2003.

title: Stories of a Corner Office, and Advice for Getting There
description: IT'S fair to ask why a chief executive of any major company wants to write a book. In this case, the question applies to David F. D'Alessandro, the chairman and chief executive of John Hancock Financial Services, who has written ''Career Warfare: 10 Rules for Building a Successful Personal Brand and Fighting to Keep It'' (McGraw-Hill, $21.95).

title: Using Illumination to Truly See
description: ALTHOUGH mostly in the dark, ''The Luminous Image VI'' at Collaborative Concepts here is all about light. Organized by Franc Palaia, the exhibition brings together two dozen national and international artists making photo-based artwork in which illumination is an integral element. Contributions range from light boxes and video projections to illuminated photo sculpture and window transparencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TUCCILLO, AMELIA P.
description: TUCCILLO--Amelia P. Patron of the arts and accounting manager for National Bulk Carriers for 35 years, was born in Hoboken, NJ, to Italian immigrant parents. She moved to Hasbrouck Heights, NJ, and later moved to Manhattan where she worked, played and loved. Retiring in the late 90's, she loved the NYC lifestyle. A woman filled with a joy of life and commitment to all, died December 21st at the age of 67. Survived by two nieces, Melina Mara, photojournalist and Theresa Woolverton, homemaker; a robust Italian family; and many loving friends who will never forget her companionship.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: This is the 10th anniversary of The Lives They Lived. As always, we are trying not to be definitive but, rather, intuitive in our choices. To that end, we have not focused on the lives of numerous prominent people (some pictured above) who were honored by many publications, including this newspaper. Among them were politicians like Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Strom Thurmond and Paul Simon and actors like Bob Hope and Gregory Peck. There were also the director Elia Kazan, the tennis player Althea Gibson, the scientist Edward Teller and one of the fathers of TV news, David Brinkley. Not mentioned, but remembered, are the victims of the October Staten Island Ferry disaster. And, of course, there are the more than 450 Americans who, along with an unknown number of Iraqi civilians, have been killed since the beginning of the Iraq war.

title: Schwab Earns a Shutout On Brodeur's Night Off
description: A Pittsburgh Penguins home game might as well be played in a motel lounge. Thousands of dingy orange seats at Mellon Arena were empty Saturday night. A band played. Dancers gyrated. The organist pounded the keys. Nothing.

title: The Programs of the Year
description: --> 1. `SIX FEET UNDER' Were the last four episodes even television? They passed like a fever, which broke at the end of the season with a moment of brilliant reckoning. The asphyxiating new figure of Lisa (Lili Taylor)  sanctimonious, organic destroyer of the show's totems, art and sex  disappeared, as if to shame us for disliking her. Implicated viewers stood by for absolution, or for Lisa's final revenge. And then she turned up dead. To expand our hearts? To take us down with her?

title: The Search for Survivors
description: Hopes of finding more earthquake survivors in the Iranian city of Bam began to fade on Sunday.

title: The Collectible SL's
Vodafone Faces a Challenge As It Covets Vivendi Assets
description: Since he took the helm of the British wireless giant the Vodafone Group in July, Arun Sarin has raised dividends, narrowed losses and set his sights on one of the most valuable assets of a competitor. With the asset play, he may have cleared the way for one of the biggest deals of 2004, or set the stage for public humiliation.

title: Killed in Iraq
description: The Department of Defense has identified 476 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans:

title: Thomas's Early Moves Get Knicks' Attention
description: All the Knicks were on the team plane to Orlando immediately after their second victory in two nights Saturday in Miami, as mandated by their new boss, Isiah Thomas. No detours to South Beach, and no solo trips up the Florida Turnpike.

title: Detroits Big Three Prepare for Battle
description: Detroit's auto show is akin to the May Day parades of the old Soviet Union, a chance for automakers to show off their latest and most powerful armaments: the new cars and trucks they are bringing to market and the fresh designs they want to run up the flagpole.

title: Messier Sees Hard Fight for Playoffs
description: The Rangers' season has not yet reached its halfway point, but Mark Messier said Sunday that he agreed with Bobby Holik's assessment earlier this month that the Rangers would spend the rest of the season fighting for a playoff berth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICHOLSON, JAMES J.
description: NICHOLSON--James J. Of Pelham Manor, NY, and Chatham, MA. Died December 28, 2003, at his home in Pelham. Beloved husband of Margaret (Peggy) (nee Cullen) Nicholson. Cherished father of John C. Nicholson of Wilmington, DE, Louise N. Howe of Bethesda, MD, and Jeanine R. Nicholson of San Francisco, CA. Adored grandfather of James Ryan, Sean C. and Nicholas G. Howe, Hailey R., Caroline H., and Laney G. Nicholson. Visiting hours will be held at the Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave, Pelham, NY, on Monday 7-9 pm. The Funeral Mass will be celebrated at the Holy Family Chapel of the College of New Rochelle, Castle Place, New Rochelle, NY, on Tuesday, 11 am. Interment will be private in Chatham, MA. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The James J. Nicholson Scholarship Fund of the College of New Rochelle or to the Pelham Public Library.

title: Libyas Nuclear Program Mostly Dismantled, U.N. Inspector Says
description: LONDON, Dec. 29  The United Nations top nuclear inspector, Mohamed ElBaradei, said today that Libya's nuclear program was years away from producing a nuclear weapon and was largely dismantled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, ARTHUR J.
description: GORDON -- Arthur J. 85, passed December 23, 2003, in Arizona. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Muriel; children Andy Gordon and Meg Singer; son-in-law Jeff Singer; grandchildren Debbie and Pam Singer; Zena Bagatelle, his loving companion; and brother Jerry Gordon. Arthur was admired by friends and family alike. He will always be remembered as a humorist, raconteur, athlete and first-rate card magician. Arthur will be missed dearly.

title: Dominican Republic in Crisis
description: In the late 1990's, the Dominican Republic had the fastest-growing economy in Latin America. Fueled by tourism, manufacturing and money sent home by Dominicans abroad -- many of them in New York -- the economy grew nearly 7 percent a year. Today that economy is in collapse. Protests are common, and at least eight people were killed during a strike in November. Extraordinary as it sounds, the troubles are largely due to a single bank collapse and its aftermath, a meltdown due to cronyism, corruption, lax regulation and secrecy.

title: The Country Will Blossom
description: Governing Council member Dara Nur al-Din discusses the trial of Saddam Hussein before a war crimes tribunal and the future of Baghdad following the downfall of the dictator.

title: Wizard Stores Face Closing
description: Wizards of the Coast, a subsidiary of Hasbro that makes trading-card and role-playing games like Magic: the Gathering and Dungeons and Dragons, said yesterday that it would close its chain of retail stores.

title: Journalist fired for book critical of French newspapers : Author sees anti-U.S. reporting

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMERLING, SYLVIA
description: SMERLING--Sylvia. July 15, 1917, to December 27, 2003. Beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother. Loving and beloved sister, aunt and cousin. Passed at 1 am, on Saturday, December 27, 2003, in Berkeley, CA. Sylvia is survived by her sisters Pearl Goldsmith and Anita Eshay, her daughters Doree Friedman and Karen Friedman, and daughter-in-law Nancy Johnson, her grandchildren Paolo Friedman, Joanne Vanvick Friedman, Nina Friedman, Alexandria Friedman, her two great-grandchildren Kyra and Kadin Friedman, nephews and nieces Arthur and Linda Goldsmith, Harvey and Leni Goldsmith and Howard Eshay, her lifelong friend and cousin Rosalyn Cohen who was truly another sister to her, and many, many loving and well loved cousins. Sylvia exuded caring, humor and wit. She was a brilliant mind, a feminist in the true sense of the word. Her visions were ahead of her time. She imparted to her daughters the notion that they could do anything that they set their sights on. As a result they became good mothers themselves and the most caring children they could be. Sylvia grew up in the Bronx and lived all her life in New York City, a place she cherished. Throughout her upbringing and education she developed a strong sense of justice and compassion, which she practiced with all those in her sphere. Her actions were always peppered with humor. Later in life she married her lifelong cherished friend, William Smerling, who preceeded her in death. Although her two sisters remained her best friends throughout her life, she touched everyone she met, and her circle of friends grew, spanning the generations. She will be forever missed as a spirit of light, integrity, and humor. Sylvia, you leave a hole in the hearts of all who knew you, but we are all bigger and stronger for making this journey with you, and once again, we thank you for the amazing opportunity, the blessing of being part of your life. Services will be held on Wednesday, December 31, 2003, at 11:15 am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: THE YEAR IN PICTURES: IN AMERICA
description: IN AMERICA, the year was tinged with eerie echoes of the past: the country again went to war against Iraq, a space shuttle explosion killed seven astronauts, and child abuse charges were leveled against a pop superstar who came under suspicion a decade ago. The Christmas holiday was marked by the post-9/11 reality of heightened terror alerts, and Democratic candidates filled the early stages of the presidential primary campaign with heated words over the United States continued role in Iraq. The economy improved, though by how much was a matter of debate; profits increased and the stock market rose, but the job market remained weak and wage growth was slow. On Wall Street, scandals ensnared a number of high rollers, including Martha Stewart, America's premier domestic diva, who is to go on trial next month. A power failure spread across eight states and parts of Ontario, and deadly wildfires claimed a record number of acres in California. A man and a teenager who terrorized the Washington area last year during the sniper shootings were convicted of capital murder in separate trials. In sports, the Cubs and the Red Sox made it to the brink of the World Series before once again breaking their fan's hearts. There were also more gentle reminders of the past. A new Harry Potter book was unleashed after a three-year hiatus; Chicago, the movie version of a hit Broadway show, captured the Oscar for Best Picture. And a well-known actor was elected governor of California.

She graduated from Stuart Hall and Brown University. Upon graduation, she was affiliated with an ophthalmology practice. title: THE YEAR IN PICTURES: NEW YORK
description: NEW YORK had an odd year, and residents can be forgiven if they felt washed up or left in the dark at times. Record rainfall drenched the region in the spring, bringing gloom but proving a boon to foliage. The country's biggest power failure left the area without lights for a couple of days in August, but the relative calm showed how far New York City had come in the quarter-century since its last blackout. Broadway musicals were dark for four days in March during a musicians' strike, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg helped resolve. But the mayor's popularity dropped, and his proposal to eliminate partisan elections for city offices failed miserably at the polls. In July, Councilman James E. Davis, who had crusaded against violence, was assassinated at City Hall by a political rival. A Staten Island Ferry boat crashed in October, killing 11 and raising questions about the ferry's operation. In September, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, Richard A. Grasso, resigned amid criticism of his pay package. In sports, Roger Clemens retired from the Yankees after becoming a 300-game winner. And Jim Fassel was fired as head coach of the Giants after a disappointing season. In a sign that the city is constantly rejuvenating, the design of the first tower at the World Trade Center was unveiled this month. ''This is not just a building,'' Gov. George E. Pataki said of the 1,776-foot structure. ''This is a symbol of New York. This is a symbol of America. This is a symbol of freedom.''

title: For Your Information . . .

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Army Drops Charge Against Sergeant
description: The charge against a sergeant accused of cowardice in October has been dropped a second time. In November, a charge of cowardice against Sgt. Georg Andreas Pogany of the Army was dropped and replaced with a lesser charge of dereliction of duty. His lawyer said that was dropped two weeks ago and that Sergeant Pogany, who is based in Fort Carson and still uncharged, was offered a separate hearing on an even lesser dereliction-of-duty charge. Sgt. Pogany has turned the hearing down, risking a court-martial but hoping no further action will be taken, his lawyer, Rich Travis, said. Army officials are ''considering their next options,'' a Fort Carson spokesman said. Sergeant Pogany was an interrogator in Iraq who said he suffered a panic attack when he saw an Iraqi mangled by a machine gun. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Vitesse To Buy Cicada For $66 Million
description: The Vitesse Semiconductor Corporation, a maker of chips used in telecommunications gear, agreed yesterday to buy closely held Cicada Semiconductor for about $66 million to add products used for high-speed data transmission. Cicada's products will increase 2004 revenue by about $10 million, said Vitesse, based in Camarillo, Calif. Cicada will trim its work force to about 40 employees, Vitesse said, without elaborating. Businesses are increasing the speed of their data networks with gigabit Ethernet gear, which is made by Cicada and others. Vitesse is expanding in that market by adding Cicada's gigabit transceivers, helping it compete with larger rivals. A call to Vitesse's office seeking comment was not returned. A call to Roger Taylor, a spokesman for Cicada, was not immediately returned. For more than a year, Vitesse and Cicada, based in Austin, Tex., have jointly sold gigabit switching products consisting of Vitesse switches and Cicada transceivers. The acquisition, expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2004, will double Vitesse's revenue in the market for switches used in local-area networks, Vitesse said.

title: Interpublic Sells Most Of Modem Media

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: 7 Teenagers Die In Crash
description: Seven teenagers from Statesville were killed in a crash when the 15-year-old driver of their stolen car tried to outrun the police, the authorities said. A police officer from Troutman noticed the 2001 Dodge Intrepid driving erratically on Highway 21 and signaled it to pull over just after midnight, but the car raced off, reaching 100 miles an hour, the State Highway Patrol said. All the occupants, ages 13 to 18, were killed when the car ran off the road and landed on its roof in a creek. Tests were being run to see if alcohol was a factor. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Facing Up to the Inevitable, in Search of a Good Death
description: The year was 1958, I was 16 and my mother was lying in a hospital bed connected to all sorts of tubes and was dying of cancer. As her life slipped away, a nurse slapped an oxygen mask on her face and asked me to hold it. There was no chance for either of us to say goodbye or ''I love you.'' I carry this medicalized memory of my mother's death with me to this day.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: IMPERIAL HOME FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION AGAIN
description: The Imperial Home Decor Group, a wallpaper maker, has sought bankruptcy protection for a second time and plans to sell the company to a Canadian company for $8.5 million. Imperial Home, a closely held company based in Cleveland, filed on Saturday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. The bankruptcy filing was made after the Bank of America Corporation refused to lend Imperial Home money it needed to print wallpaper and sample books within the next two months, Daniel Behrendt, chief financial officer at Imperial Home, said in court papers. Imperial Home asked Judge Joel Rosenthal to approve auction procedures for the company. The closely held Blue Mountain Wallcoverings of Mississauga, Ontario, is the highest bidder so far.

title: The Detailed Shape Of Things to Come

But this spring there's only word that counts: fashion.

title: Architecture Panorama: Once Around the Park

title: Experts Try to Assess Risk From Diseased Cow
description: There are two fears that Americans seem to have in the wake of the discovery of mad cow disease in a Washington cow, and the science of assessing them is very different.

title: U.S. Bans Dietary Supplement Linked to Number of Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  The Bush administration today announced that it was banning the herbal weight-loss supplement ephedra from the marketplace because it represents an unacceptable health risk.

title: Navy Is Seeking to Ground Texas Techs Aerial
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 29 (AP) — Craig Candeto and his fellow Midshipmen truly are happy to be here.

title: Before the Flood, a Visitation by Angels
description: Few films make better use of a commentary and making-of documentary than ''Northfork,'' Michael Polish's stunningly atmospheric, often mystifying tale of a wondrous visitation on the high plains of Montana. Mr. Polish wrote the screenplay with his twin brother, Mark. This is their third collaboration -- ''Twin Falls Idaho'' and ''Jackpot'' are the others -- and on a DVD released today by Paramount they talk about hardships on the set while revealing something of their own evocative if not immediately fathomable imagery and vision.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the outlook for online advertising in 2004 referred imprecisely to a Web site that automatically positioned advertisements for luggage stores next to a news article about a murderer who carried his victims in a suitcase. It was Google, not Yahoo's Overture Services.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Old Testament Followers Sue Prisons
description: Yahwists, religious followers of Old Testament food and grooming requirements, have filed suit in Pulaski County Circuit Court against the Arkansas prison system, seeking to let inmates grow their hair and beards and eat kosher meals. Prison officials say beards and long hair would be a security risk. The plaintiffs are not inmates but are filing as taxpayers concerned for Yahwist inmates, said one of their lawyers, David O. Bowden. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, which includes Arkansas, told the state last year that it must serve kosher meals to an inmate or let him serve time in another state. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: U.S. Bike Makers Seek Dominance in Europe
description: When Lance Armstrong won his fifth Tour de France in July, it was not the only cycling victory for an American. As he rolled across the finish line in Paris, he rode a bicycle made in the United States by Trek.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRESSELHUYS, RICHARD
description: DRESSELHUYS -- Richard. Community Board 6, Manhattan, is saddened at the passing of our friend and colleague, Richard Dresselhuys.

title: Parmalat Prepares to Sell Soccer Team
description: Parmalat plans to convert about 50 million euros ($62.2 million) of the debt from its soccer team Parma A.C. into shares as a prelude to a spinoff.

title: Bus Thief's Trip To Kennedy Raises Alarm, And Questions
description: It may not have been the crime of the ages, but it was a remarkable feat.

title: Musharraf's Quandary
description: If Islamic extremists were behind the two attempted assassinations of President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, he may be forced to reconsider his simultaneous support for the United States and his reluctance to confront the militants more directly. But cracking down on the militants would have political costs.

description: FREEDOM ON FIRE

title: A Balcony Burglar Again Scales Fort Lee's Heights
description: Spider-Man, he is not. Still, the police are looking for a burglar who has been scaling buildings, breaking into at least 14 apartments and condominiums here since the beginning of December.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BISTRIAN, PETER (PATRICK)
description: BISTRIAN--Peter (Patrick). 87, of Amagansett, NY on December 27, 2003. Beloved husband of Mary Laura nee Ryan. Loving father of Patrick Jr., Bruce R., Barry A., Bonnie Krupinski, Barbara Borg, and Betsy Avallone. Dear brother of the late John and Louis. Also survived by 15 grandchildren, 22 greatgrandchildren and nephews and nieces. Services will be held Tuesday, December 30, 11am at the Amagansett Presbyterian Church. Interment at Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton. Memorial donations to the Amagansett Presbyterian Church, the Joslin Diabetes Center, Boston, or the Amagansett Volunteer Ambulance Corps would be appreciated.

title: Incoherent on Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Dispute in Michael Jackson Camp Over Role of the Nation of Islam
description: Officials from the Nation of Islam, a separatist African-American Muslim group, have moved in with Michael Jackson and are asserting control over the singer's business affairs, friends, employees and business associates of Mr. Jackson said.

title: After Romp, Knicks' Revival Coming Home On a High Note
description: The Knicks smiled and smacked high-fives after making nearly every open shot. The momentum they jump-started in Memphis on Friday and built Saturday in Miami was now surging with joy.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CATTLE PRICES DROP. Cattle futures fell after Japan said it would not lift a ban on American beef until tighter safety measures were taken. In Chicago, cattle for February delivery fell 5 cents, or 5.8 percent, to 81.175 cents a pound.

title: LILLY GAINS APPROVAL FOR TREATMENT FOR BIPOLAR DISORDER
description: Eli Lilly & Company, maker of one of the world's top-selling schizophrenia drugs, Zyprexa, won federal approval to combine that medicine with its Prozac antidepressant in a single pill for bipolar disorder. The pill, called Symbyax, will reach pharmacies in the United States by mid-January, Lilly said. More than two million American adults have bipolar disorder, or manic depression, according to the National Institutes of Health. The illness causes episodes of euphoria and restlessness, alternating with periods of depression and fatigue.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the reaction of the pet food industry to a case of mad cow disease in Washington State referred incorrectly to previous cases of the disease involving pets and their food. There have indeed been some: cats in Britain were reported to have been infected through food made from contaminated beef.

title: SEITEL INVESTORS END BUYOUT PLAN BY BUFFETT
description: Seitel, a provider of geological data to oil companies that is in bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with shareholders on a reorganization plan, ending a proposed buyout by Berkshire Hathaway. Berkshire, the company run by the investor Warren E. Buffett, bought $255 million of Seitel's senior, unsecured notes this year. Seitel's shareholders had challenged the prepackaged plan that Seitel brought with it to bankruptcy protection. Under that plan, Berkshire, which is based in Omaha, was supposed to get control of Seitel, which is based in Houston, and the shareholders would have received $10.1 million, or about 40 cents a share. Instead, Berkshire and Ranch Capital, which also bought prebankruptcy debt, will be paid off under a plan to be detailed in papers filed with the court before a Jan. 30 hearing.

title: Sheep Ailment May Hold Clues to Mad Cow Disease
description: No one knows for sure when or where the first cow went mad, but the first recorded case occurred in December 1984 when a dairy cow on a farm in West Sussex began to stumble around and act strange. That cow, identified only as No. 133 in a British government report, died two months later, as others on the same farm fell ill. An autopsy on one in 1985 found its brain full of holes, like a sponge. Sick animals turned up on other farms, and by 1986 the British knew they were facing an epidemic of a terrible new cattle disease.

title: Iraqi Civilian Killed by Bomb Apparently Aimed at G.I.s
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 30 — An Iraqi civilian was killed and three others wounded today when a homemade bomb apparently intended to harm a convoy of American soldiers exploded on a crowded commercial street in central Baghdad.

title: Ashcroft to Remove Himself From Inquiry Into C.I.A. Leak
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 — Attorney General John Ashcroft will remove himself from an investigation into who gave the name of a Central Intelligence Agency officer to a newspaper columnist and turn over the inquiry to a special counsel, the Justice Department said today.

title: PRO FOOTBALL -- Teams Making the Call on Embattled Coaches; Upheavals Begin With Three Firings
description: The first day of the N.F.L.'s firing season yesterday claimed Gregg Williams of the Bills, Dave McGinnis of the Cardinals and Dick Jauron of the Bears. That brought the number of coaches fired this season to five, including the Falcons' in-season dismissal of Dan Reeves and the Giants' previously announced parting with Jim Fassel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEILER, ALFRED W.
description: FEILER--Alfred W. Died on December 27, 2003 in Durham, NC at the age of 90. Passionate, intellectual, witty rapporteur and political critic. Ali will be missed by friends and family. Former resident of Berlin, Paris, London, New York and Chapel Hill. Ali is survived by his wife of 68 years, Lily, his two daughters, Ylana (Miller) and Mirriam (Rosen), their husbands Martin and Howard, and his grandchildren, Joshua Miller and and Zinaida Miller, Benjamin Rosen and Gabriel Rosen. The funeral will take place on Wednesday, December 31, at 10AM at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'' 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICHOLSON, JAMES J.
description: NICHOLSON--James J. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of James J. Nicholson, cherished friend of long-standing, former member of the Board of Trustees and its Chair from 1985 to 1991. Ever the man of wit, warmth and compassion, he stood in the midst of this community for almost three decades as one who served. Wise counselor, guide and leader, he inspired us with a breadth of vision and boldness of action, always imprinted with his characteristic reverence for people. He contributed immeasurably to the advancement of this college, and his friendship has been a great gift. We celebrate his life. Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D. President Jean Baptiste Nicholson OSU Ohair, Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DURGIN, DON
description: DURGIN--Don. The Contemporary Arts Council of The Museum of Modern Art mourns the loss of Don Durgin, husband of its esteemed member, Catherine Meacham Durgin. Our thoughts and sympathies are with Catherine and the entire Durgin family. Richard Anderman and Anne Coffin, Co-Chairmen

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about Don Lamond, a big-band drummer, misstated the site of the Peabody Conservatory, where he studied. It is in Baltimore, not Philadelphia.

title: Putin and His Political Allies Extend Power in Parliament
description: The newly elected Russian Parliament convened Monday and after a quick bit of horse-trading, the bloc supporting President Vladimir V. Putin established a two-thirds majority, which will allow it to pass any laws or make any constitutional changes it wishes.

title: Dragging Out the Demons, Inching Up the A List
description: Emerging from the afternoon shadows dappling the garden of the Chateau Marmont, Benicio Del Toro strolls toward the patio restaurant, his hands in his jeans pockets, his eyes squinting in the sunlight. He's in no hurry and seems unaware of the commotion his presence is causing among the lunch crowd. It's a surprising reaction in a place where celebrities come and go virtually unnoticed, where Kate Moss had just minutes before drawn only sidelong glances. But for Mr. Del Toro, people are rising off their seats, peering baldly, nudging each other.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 22 about the ways Washington University in St. Louis improved its ranking in the annual survey by U.S. News & World Report referred imprecisely to the ratio of applicants to undergraduate openings. The university has 15 times as many applicants as it can enroll, not 15 times the number it can accept. (Its acceptance rate of 24 percent reflects the fact that not all accepted students choose to enroll.)

title: Extra Security For Revelers In Times Sq.
description: With the city at a heightened state of alert, unprecedented security measures will be in place on New Year's Eve in Times Square, where revelers will have to pass through metal detectors borrowed from city schools for the night, officials said yesterday.

title: Reviewing Stories of 2003
description: FREDDY ADU -- He is so skilled that some people simply do not believe he is 14. He played for the United States in the under-17 world championship in Finland and then was a late addition, and finally a starter, for the under-20 team that went to the quarterfinals in the United Arab Emirates.

title: Slim-Fast bets that its campaign featuring Whoopi Goldberg and new products will lift its sales.
description: IN time to capitalize on the inevitable flood of New Year's resolutions to lose weight, the Slim-Fast Company has enlisted Whoopi Goldberg to entice consumers to forsake fatty foods and competing diet programs and join the Slim-Fast plan.

title: A Soldier's Return, to a Dark and Moody World
description: Jeremy Feldbusch joined the Army to travel the world. Now the only place he can go by himself is the 40 steps from his bed to the reclining chair in the living room.

description: All Squawk Together Now

title: LIBYA'S ATOM BID IN EARLY PHASES
description: The top United Nations nuclear inspector, Dr. Mohamed ElBaradei, said Monday that Libya's nuclear program was years away from producing a nuclear weapon and that important pieces of equipment were now largely dismantled and stored in boxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORREE, SUSAN
description: BORREE--Susan. On December 26, 2003. Beloved mother to Yvonne Borree. Memorial service to be held Tuesday, December 30, 2003, 5PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Oracle Obtains $1.5 Billion Line Of Credit
description: The Oracle Corporation, the software maker that has made a hostile $7.5 billion bid for PeopleSoft, said yesterday that it had obtained a $1.5 billion line of credit from ABN Amro Bank and Credit Suisse First Boston to help consummate the merger. Oracle had cash and short-term investments worth $8.1 billion as of Nov. 30, the company, based in Redwood City, Calif., said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Oracle said its Dec. 24 agreement allows it to draw on $1.5 billion as part of a 364-day, unsecured ''acquisition facility.'' Oracle had said in earlier filings that it had received a $5 billion revolving line of credit from Credit Suisse to help cover acquisition costs. An Oracle spokeswoman, Jennifer Glass, did not immediately answer a phone call and e-mail message seeking comment. In the event the new line of credit were unavailable, Oracle said it would raise money from other lenders or by issuing securities so that it could complete its offer for PeopleSoft, based in Pleasanton, Calif.

title: PRO FOOTBALL -- Teams Making the Call on Embattled Coaches; Jets Are Reshaping Their Defense
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards values consistency over upheaval. But that was before he experienced his first losing season as a head coach.

description: BASEBALL

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon-Worldcom Settlement Is Approved
description: WorldCom received court approval of a $169 million payment from Verizon Communications to settle a dispute over network-access fees. The settlement, approved yesterday by Judge Arthur J. Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, ends a six-year-old dispute over whether Verizon must pay when its customers make calls to Internet access providers that use WorldCom's phone lines. Verizon, the nation's largest local-telephone company, also agreed to pay revised interconnection rates to avoid future legal problems. The dispute ''is possibly the largest collective piece of litigation'' at WorldCom and ''resolving it is very key in all of the processes,'' Alfredo Perez, WorldCom's bankruptcy lawyer, told Judge Gonzalez. In July 2002 WorldCom filed the biggest bankruptcy case in United States history in terms of declared asset value. The company, based in Ashburn, Va., expects to complete its reorganization and come out of bankruptcy early next year as MCI, the name of its best-known unit. Verizon shares rose 41 cents, to $34.32.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Shared Bailout Pushed
description: The eight largest creditors of LG Card, South Korea's largest credit card company, asked other lenders to join a bailout of the company and help spread the 5.15 trillion won ($4.3 billion) cost that no bank has been willing to shoulder alone. Woori Bank, one large creditor, along with Hana Bank and Kookmin Bank are among 16 lenders that may work together to manage LG Card and offer a second loan of 2 trillion won to allow the card company to keep operating, Woori's chief executive, Lee Duk Hoon, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, EDWIN E.
description: MILLER--Edwin E. Writer, editor and critic of film, music and theater, 82, died December 29, 2003 in Manhattan. Survived by his son Eric Edwin, and his cousin/mate, Dr. Vera Miller. Husband of the late Lydia Joel. Father of the late Diana.

title: Agriculture Secretary Announces New Rules for Safety of Beef
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman announced several new rules today to improve the safety of America's beef products, as regulators cope with the first case of mad cow disease in United States history.

description: TING--Chih-Hung, born in Hupei, China on July 12, 1925, died in his home at 78. Formerly a diplomat with the Nationalist Chinese government, resigned in the 1960s. Joined WZW Financial Services, Inc. and became Associate Vice-President. A year later became Regional VicePresident at O-R Securities. Survived by wife Lih-Hwa; son Stephen and daughter-inlaw Li-Hsi; son Simeon; daughters Sara; Sharon, sonin-law Andre Dawkins and granddaughters Arielle and Alexis Dawkins; daughter Sandee, son-in-law Peter Simshauser, grandsons Ryan and Derek and granddaughters Erin and Lara Simshauser. Visitation on Thursday, 37PM, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue. Funeral services will be held at same Frank E. Campbell Chapel, Friday, January 2 at 11:30AM.

title: AMERICANS ORDER FOREIGN AIRLINES TO USE MARSHALS
description: Increasingly concerned about the threat of terrorists' hijacking an international flight, the Bush administration issued an emergency order on Monday demanding that foreign airlines place armed air marshals on flights that travel into, out of or over the United States if American officials determine there is a threat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMERLING, SYLVIA
description: SMERLING--Sylvia. July 15, 1917, to December 27, 2003. Beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother. Loving and beloved sister, aunt and cousin. Passed at 1 am, on Saturday, December 27, 2003, in Berkeley, CA. Sylvia is survived by her sisters Pearl Goldsmith and Anita Eshay, her daughters Doree Friedman and Karen Friedman, and daughter-in-law Nancy Johnson, her grandchildren Paolo Friedman, Joanne Vanvick Friedman, Nina Friedman, Alexandria Friedman, her two great-grandchildren Kyra and Kadin Friedman, nephews and nieces Arthur and Linda Goldsmith, Harvey and Leni Goldsmith and Howard Eshay, her lifelong friend and cousin Rosalyn Cohen who was truly another sister to her, and many, many loving and well loved cousins. Sylvia exuded caring, humor and wit. She was a brilliant mind, a feminist in the true sense of the word. Her visions were ahead of her time. She imparted to her daughters the notion that they could do anything that they set their sights on. As a result they became good mothers themselves and the most caring children they could be. Sylvia grew up in the Bronx and lived all her life in New York City, a place she cherished. Throughout her upbringing and education she developed a strong sense of justice and compassion, which she practiced with all those in her sphere. Her actions were always peppered with humor. Later in life she married her lifelong cherished friend, William Smerling, who preceeded her in death. Although her two sisters remained her best friends throughout her life, she touched everyone she met, and her circle of friends grew, spanning the generations. She will be forever missed as a spirit of light, integrity, and humor. Sylvia, you leave a hole in the hearts of all who knew you, but we are all bigger and stronger for making this journey with you, and once again, we thank you for the amazing opportunity, the blessing of being part of your life. Services will be held on Wednesday, December 31, 2003, at 11:15 am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: In the End, 'Rich Girls' Has It All Over 'The Simple Life'
description: Because of thematic similarities, two programs are often compared that are in fact entirely different from each other. MTV's ''Rich Girls,'' which started in October, and Fox's ''Simple Life,'' which started this month and ends tonight, received this treatment. Some viewers may not have learned to tell them apart. This would have been a grave mistake.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Thursday, 2 to 6 and Friday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Fatima Church, 5 Strathmore Rd, Scarsdale, N.Y. Saturday 10AM. Entombment Ferncliff Mausoleum. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association or the Parkinson's Disease Foundation. To place condolences on line www.mem.com.

title: At Final Meeting, Mara Talks and Players Listen
description: Their gloomy season over, their coach headed out the door and the interviewing for his replacement already started, the Giants expected to clean out their lockers quietly on Monday morning to face a long, uncertain off-season. But into their final meeting walked the co-owner Wellington Mara, who addresses the team so seldomly that his mere presence brought players instantly to attention.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: North Caldwell: Two Prisoners Escape From Jail
description: Two men escaped from the Essex County Jail Annex in North Caldwell by climbing over a security fence yesterday afternoon, said Lt. Ronald Charles of the State Department of Corrections. The men, Brian Walsh, 23, of Jersey City, and John Straile, 32, of Hillside, escaped just after 2 p.m. and had not been found by early last evening, said Capt. Steven Gallagher of the North Caldwell Police Department. Mr. Straile was in jail for burglary and resisting arrest in Newark, and for violating his parole from a previous offense in Pennsylvania. Mr. Walsh was in the jail for not completing a program similar to parole. The authorities say they think Mr. Walsh could be traveling to West Orange. The police described Mr. Walsh as white, 190 pounds and 5-foot-9, with a shamrock tattoo on his neck. Mr. Straile is Hispanic, 185 pounds and 5-foot-10. Jason George (NYT)

title: Five Iraqis Die From Injuries, Raising to 19 Toll in Attacks
description: The death toll from the wave of bombings in the southern Shiite holy city of Karbala has risen to 19 with the deaths of 5 more Iraqis from their wounds on Sunday.
