description: PULLMAN -- Margaret. On December 29, 2003. Cherished wife of the late George. Devoted mother of Linda Fish (Ira). Dearest Nanny of Jane, David, Daniel, Samantha, Emily, Eliza and Gabriel. Loving sister of Jack, Joe, the late Sam and Kitty.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: IRAN: EUROPEAN HOSTAGES FREED Three European cyclists kidnapped on Dec. 2 have been released, the Interior Ministry said. The cyclists, two Germans and an Irishman, were seized by bandits or drug-runners in Iran's rugged eastern border region, officials said. Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi was quoted on state television as saying the three were in good health, but details of their release were not immediately available. Iran had said it would not pay a $6 million ransom demanded by a caller and had encouraged Ireland and Germany to take the same position. (Reuters)

title: A Trove of New-Found Gems Brings P. D. Q. Bach More Kudos
description: The orchestra in Avery Fisher Hall was playing the spirited introduction to a piano concerto. The volume and the intensity were building, and just when the soloist was about to make his grand entrance, the unspeakable happened: a cell phone rang. Amazingly, the ring came not from somewhere in the audience but from the pocket of the piano soloist himself -- and to make matters worse still, he took the call!

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: PORTUGAL: 10 CHARGED IN PEDOPHILE INQUIRY Prosecutors brought formal pedophile charges against 10 people, including an opposition lawmaker, two popular television personalities and a former ambassador. The case, which alleges that more than 100 children at state-run homes for orphans and the underprivileged were raped or otherwise molested, has gripped the nation for more than a year. Many of those charged are already in preventive detention, and prosecutors had until the end of January to bring charges. Among those charged is Paulo Pedroso, an employment minister in the last Socialist government and the Socialist Party's second-ranking official. Mr. Pedroso has maintained his innocence and has claimed that the allegations against him are politically motivated. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENSON, ISABELLE LU BOW
description: STEVENSON -- Isabelle Lu bow. 1913-2003. Of New York City. Wife of 64 years of John A. Stevenson (who predeceased her), mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt and Chairman of the American Theater Wing, an organization she has been with for over 40 years. She leaves her beloved daughters, Susan M. Brown of New York City, Laura S. Maslon (James) of Venice, CA; her niece Francine Ringold-Johnson (Manly) of Tulsa, OK; her grandsons, David S. Brown, Ethan W. Brown; greatgranddaughter Ella; greatnieces and nephews Leslie, John, James and Suzanne and their children. Friend and supporter of the theater for more than 60 years. Services will be held Tuesday, December 30, at 2 pm, at All Souls Unitarian Church, 1157 Lexington Ave. Instead of flowers, contributions should be made to the American Theater Wing.

title: Colleges Struggle to Help Black Men Stay Enrolled
description: Watching Simon Jackson in class is like watching a man who is conflicted about being in college. For long stretches, he huddles silently in the back corner, his head sunk into his bulky jacket. But every so often he strides to the front of the room to chat with the professor or to write on the chalkboard, self-assured to the point of cockiness.

description: George Steinbrenner worked at home in Tampa, Fla., yesterday and joked about his fainting spell on Saturday, said Howard Rubenstein, his spokesman.

description: A speeding car plowed through the juncture of two roads here early Monday, glanced off an empty brick building and slammed broadside into an apartment house, the police said. They said that the three young men in the car were killed but that none of the seven residents of the three-story apartment house were hurt.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Locomotive Contract
description: The Canadian manufacturer Bombardier has won a contract to supply 48 electric locomotives to the Italian railroad company Trenitalia. The deal is worth 103 million euros ($128 million) and follows earlier orders from Trenitalia for 240 similar locomotives, Bombardier said. Bombadier's chief executive, Paul M. Tellier, above, recently outlined plans to restructure rail car manufacturing in Europe, where the company has more than 30 factories, some operating at less than half of capacity. The head of the rail car unit resigned earlier this month. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: A Nuclear Headache: What if the Radicals Oust Musharraf?
description: Two recent assassination attempts against Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, have renewed concern in the Bush administration over both the stability of a critical ally and the security of its nuclear weapons if General Musharraf were killed or removed from office.

title: In Houston, Residents Cringe as They Ponder the Gridlock to Come
description: Jen Marie Rau should love it when work crews tear up the city's streets and its spaghetti tangle of freeways, sending motorists into a dither: her family business, Key Maps, has been charting greater Houston's highways and byways since 1957.

description: A federal judge has ordered Connecticut's beleaguered child welfare agency to comply with a stringent plan to improve within three years to end its court oversight.

title: In Southern Stop, Clark Promises to Enforce Voting Rights
description: Forty years after four black girls were killed in a church bombing here, Gen. Wesley K. Clark visited the same church on Monday and said African-Americans were still in danger of having their votes go uncounted and their voices unheard.

title: The Unkept Promise
description: There is a deceiving sense of timelessness to the stillness of rural life. The jungles of Mindanao offer few clues as to whether it's the early 20th century, or the early 21st. Nor do the highlands of Guatemala, the Mekong Delta in Vietnam or the cotton-rich plains of the Sahel in West Africa. But these disparate regions are very much of the present, stitched into the quilt of global commerce. World trade links us to them, as surely as it links London, Tokyo and New York.

title: Za-Kpota Journal; Benin's Youngest Boys Join Hard Cycle of Migrant Labor
description: The hands of small boys hold up this place. As young as 8, barely able to handle picks and shovels, the small boys of this cluster of dust-poor villages are sent to break stones in the quarries of neighboring Nigeria.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARKIN, LOUISE PAULA (NEE ZWEIFLER)
description: BARKIN--Louise Paula (nee Zweifler), 72, of Brooklyn, NY. Passed away peacefully in her home surrounded by family after a courageous battle against cancer. Through her life-long dedication to education, she influenced the lives of so many as a professor, principal, teacher and mentor. Beloved wife of Dudley for more than fifty years. Devoted and loving mother of Stephanie, Dale and Michael and mother-in-law of Steven Cherniak, Eric Chaikin and Beth Barkin. Cherished ''Foofa'' of grandchildren Harlan, Seth, Spencer, Dane, Brooke and Sloane. Caring sister of Alvin and Steven. Her multitude of friends and surviving family mourn her untimely passing deeply. She will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Reading is Fundamental, Pancreatic Cancer and Emphysema Research. Funeral services Tuesday, December 30, 2003, 12 noon at Gutterman's, Inc., 175 N. Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Stores of the Future Will Think for You
description: If fashion seemed plagued last year with the chronic drears, the economy was only partly to blame. One of the most poorly kept secrets among analysts of the clothing business and, indeed, of retailing in general is that consumers have begun defecting from the culture of shopping, surfeited with information and alienated by what increasingly seems like the mere illusion of choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUEOVJIAN, MRS. MYRNA R.
description: GUEOVJIAN--Mrs. Myrna R. 64, died Saturday, December 27, 2003 at Memorial Health University. Native of the Bronx, NY, living mostly in Pelham Manor, NY. She had been a resident of Savannah for the past nine years. She was a member of the Landings Association. She was a retired Art teacher, teaching in the New Hyde Park School System in Long Island, NY. She was a volunteer with the Victims Rights Program in Chatham County. Surviving is her husband, John Gueovjian of Savannah, mother Sophie Disk of Lansdale, PA, brother Fred Disk of Warminster, PA, sister Joan Disk Kettner of Lansdale, PA, stepdaughter Marian Altuater of Woodbridge, CT, Denise Miller of Skillman, NJ, step-grandchildren, Anna and Bethie, and four nieces. Remembrances to the American Cancer Society. Fox & Weeks Funeral Directors, Hodgson Chapel.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Utility Averts Seizure
description: The AES Corporation., owner of power plants in 27 countries, won an 11-year extension from Brazil's government-owned development bank on $1.2 billion of loans taken to buy Latin America's biggest power distributor. The extension averted a government seizure of the utility. Profit from AES Brazilian units will be dedicated to reducing the businesses' $2.3 billion of debt for the next four to five years, AES's chief operating officer, Joseph Brandt, said in a telephone interview from the company's offices in Arlington, Va. The agreement prevents default on a loan to buy Sao Eletropaulo Metropolitana SA., ending 18 months of talks.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: Frequent Flier; Lingering Odor of Smelt and a Damp Wool Suit
description: Everybody's had strange seat companions on airplanes, and with all of the flying I've done in the last couple of decades, I'm no different. But nothing tops the seatmate I had on a trip I took in 1993.

title: Worthy Subjects Downstairs, Too, Lords and Ladies
description: The walls of many British castles and stately homes are lined with portraits of ancestors wearing the bemedaled uniforms of generals or the ermined gowns of members of the House of Lords. But a few wealthy families happened to notice who was actually running their homes and estates and decided that these housekeepers, head gardeners, stable grooms and the like should also be remembered in paintings.

title: Earl Hindman, 61, the Neighbor Unseen on 'Home Improvement'
description: Earl Hindman, the actor known to millions as the odd neighbor barely seen as he peeks over the backyard fence in the long-running television situation comedy ''Home Improvement,'' died yesterday at Stamford Hospital in Connecticut. A Stamford resident, he was 61.

title: Sick Cow Was Old Enough to Have Eaten Now-Banned Feed
description: Federal officials said Monday that the Washington State dairy cow afflicted with the nation's first case of mad cow disease was born in April 1997, just four months before the United States and Canada outlawed the use of cattle feed containing ingredients considered the principal, if not only, means of transmitting the disease.

title: The Tightrope Is Fraying Under the President of Pakistan
description: After the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, Gen. Pervez Musharraf made a bold choice to reverse his country's support for the Taliban government in neighboring Afghanistan, and instead to ally Pakistan with the American campaign against terror.

title: Cowboys and Panthers Take Similar Paths to Next Stop
description: Bill Parcells and the Dallas Cowboys were downright misty-eyed after beating the Carolina Panthers at Texas Stadium on Nov. 23. After years of mediocrity, the 24-20 victory established Dallas as a true contender for the playoffs.

title: One Mad Cow Sets Off a Stampede
description: The discovery of mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy, in a cow in Washington State should concern us all. Yet this is less because of any risk of contracting the disease through eating beef and more because a knee-jerk reaction by the public, news media and policy makers could threaten our ability to make a reasoned and effective response to the threat.

description: In November, you might have read in this space about a company called Travel Sentry that developed a lock technology in conjunction with the Transportation Security Administration and the luggage industry.

title: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Canal Profit
description: The Suez Canal, Egypt's second-largest source of hard currency after tourism, reported record revenue of $2.57 billion in 2003, up from $1.947 billion in 2002, the Canal Authority's chief director, Ahmed Fadel, said at a news conference on Saturday. He added that the 32 percent increase in revenue is the highest in the canal's 134 years of operation and that it is a result of increases in European coal imports from Australia, and in oil tanker traffic. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Portugal: 10 Charged In Pedophile Inquiry
description: Prosecutors brought formal pedophile charges against 10 people, including an opposition lawmaker, two popular television personalities and a former ambassador. The case, which alleges that more than 100 children at state-run homes for orphans and the underprivileged were raped or otherwise molested, has gripped the nation for more than a year. Many of those charged are already in preventive detention, and prosecutors had until the end of January to bring charges. Among those charged is Paulo Pedroso, an employment minister in the last Socialist government and the Socialist Party's second-ranking official. Mr. Pedroso has maintained his innocence and has said the allegations against him are politically motivated. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NORRIS, ELIZABETH D.
description: NORRIS--Elizabeth D. A lifelong resident of NYC, died December 24 in Wilton, CT. Retired librarian/archivist for the YWCA of the USA. Survivors include four nieces and one nephew. Harding Funeral Home, Westport, CT.

title: Nets Creating Support Group Around Griffin
description: Eddie Griffin is searching for an apartment in New Jersey, but he is not looking for a roommate. He believes he is finally ready to live alone.

title: Big Board Halts Trading In Shares Of Footstar
description: Shares of Footstar, the operator of the Footaction and Just for Feet athletic shoe stores, will be delisted by the New York Stock Exchange because of its delay in filing financial statements.

description: It wasn't always obvious that the Vacanti boys Jay, Chuck, Marty and Frank -- were destined to become doctor-scientists, much less that they would come to dominate the esoteric field of tissue engineering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIBSON, ELLEN AMY
description: GIBSON--Ellen Amy. 84 years of age. On December 26, 2003. Beloved wife of the late Henry John. Devoted mother of Colin John. Loving mother-inlaw of Maureen McNellis. Dear grandmother of Maggie Beth, fond sister of Stanley George. Mrs. Gibson was a lifelong resident of London, England. The love she had for her family was her greatest gift. Always loved, always remembered. Funeral from Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment of Ashes will be held at The Enfield Crematorium, London, England. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Friends Seminary, 222 E. 16 St, New York, N.Y. 10003 att: Fred Bush.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Dec. 22 about problems at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in Manhattan referred incorrectly to a group of board members who met this spring to review the museum's mission and leadership. It was sanctioned by the board; it was not a splinter group. The article also misstated the size of the museum's operating budget. It is about $9 million, said Paul K. Herzan, president of the board, not $4 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFER, JULIANA (TEKULA)
description: HOFFER--Juliana (Tekula). Died December 26, 2003 at her home in Mountain View, CA. She will be missed by her husband Lawrence Hoffer, her mother Doris Tekula Borkon, and her sisters Nadine Tekula Bompane and Joan Tekula Bogen. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National Foundation for Juvenile Diabetes.

title: Isabelle Stevenson, Doyenne of the Tony Awards, Dies at 90
description: Isabelle Stevenson, the president of the American Theater Wing for more than 30 years, its chairwoman for the last five years and one of the best-known figures in the theater world, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan, her daughter Laura said. She was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOPER, RAYMOND V.
description: COOPER--Raymond V. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Raymond V. Cooper, associated with The Times from 1950 until retiring in 1991.

title: After Complaining About Failure to Stop Attacks, Dean Explains Himself to Party Chairman
description: Howard Dean reached out to the Democratic national chairman on Monday, a day after rebuking him as failing to stop attacks by Mr. Dean's rivals for the Democratic nomination, even as those candidates seized on the episode as grist for new criticism.

title: Traversing The Mystery Of Memory
description: Ah, those were the days. At least that's what the nostalgic among us feel. And those hard-nosed realists who are immune to its siren call dismiss it -- wrongly, of course -- as cheap sentiment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MELCHNER, LUCILLE
description: MELCHNER--Lucille, 98. On December 28, 2003. Adored wife for 66 years of the late Bernard. Beloved mother of Richard and Susan. Grandmother of Leanne and Charles Rettig, Gordon and Andy, and Jason. Greatgrandmother of Breena and Guy. Donations to Hospice by the Sea, 1531 West Palmetto Park Rd, Boca Raton, Fla. 33486.

title: RELIANT PLANS $1 BILLION BOND SALE TO BUY POWER PLANTS
description: Reliant Resources, which sells electricity in 13 states, has reached an agreement with a group of banks on a plan to sell bonds to raise as much as $1 billion to buy power plants in Texas. The company also paid off $917 million in debt ahead of schedule. The accord with the banks, led by the Bank of America Corporation, ''allows us to raise debt to fund acquisitions to support our Texas retail business,'' a spokeswoman for Reliant, Sandy Fruhman, said. Terms of loans obtained in March had precluded such bond sales, she said. Reliant, which is based in Houston, needs to have its own plants in Texas to guard against swings in wholesale electricity prices, analysts and investors have said.

title: Spare the Rod, Save the Nation
description: It was April 19 and the Marine battalion I was commanding in Iraq was leaving Samarra to begin a long trip south through Baghdad along highways we had fought on just a few weeks earlier. Major combat operations were coming to a close, and we were headed to the small south-central city of Diwaniyah to undertake the uncertain business of post-conflict operations.

title: Bronx Man Is Rescued From His Own Paper Prison
description: A Bronx man trapped for two days under an avalanche of newspapers, magazines and books was rescued by firefighters and neighbors yesterday in a small urban drama that recalled the macabre 1947 tale of the Collyer brothers.

description: The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index hit a record high yesterday. At least it did if all 500 stocks in the index are treated as equal.

title: Sheep Ailment May Hold Clues to Mad Cow Disease
description: No one knows for sure when or where the first cow went mad, but the first recorded case occurred in December 1984 when a dairy cow on a farm in West Sussex began to stumble around and act strange. That cow, identified only as No. 133 in a British government report, died two months later, as others on the same farm fell ill. An autopsy on one in 1985 found its brain full of holes, like a sponge. Sick animals turned up on other farms, and by 1986 the British knew they were facing an epidemic of a terrible new cattle disease.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RITZ, ESTHER LEAH MEDALIE
description: RITZ--Esther Leah Medalie. Born May 16, 1918, died in Milwaukee, WI, December 26, 2003. Preceded in death by husband Maurice Ritz. Survived by sons David and Peter; daughter, Joyce Kemp; sister, Louise Bloom; brother, Yale Medalie; five grandchildren, and many nieces, nephews and cousins. A Memorial Service is planned for spring. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the political candidates and charities of your choice.

title: Long Island Family Grieves for a Quake Victim
description: On Thursday night, Adele Freedman and Tobb Dell'Oro called relatives in the United States and gushed about how they had been enchanted by the ancient Iranian city of Bam, family members said.

title: Vatican Official Is Killed by Gunmen in Burundi
description: The Vatican's senior official in war-ravaged Burundi was killed Monday after gunmen fired at his car as he returned from pastoral duties, the Vatican said this evening.

description: As a young man, Champ Hallet, 38, was doing everything a champion should not do: robberies, drugs, alcohol and hanging out with what he called the ''wrong crowd.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIBERMAN, SUSAN JANE HADLEY, M.D.
description: BIBERMAN -- Susan Jane Hadley, M.D. On December 27, 2003 at age 84. Retired Full Professor at Cornell Medical School. Beloved wife of David, mother of David Hadley and Anne Biberman. Sister to Cornelia Hadley, Helen Obert, and Priscilla Hadley. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cornell Medical School.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: H.I.V. Test Approved
description: An Irish manufacturer of diagnostic medical devices, Trinity Biotech, received approval from the Food and Drug Administration for Uni-Gold Recombigen, an H.I.V. test that provides results in 10 minutes and is the only test that can screen serum, plasma and whole blood, the company said. The product is already used extensively in Africa, and Trinity has recently increased its sales force in the United States in anticipation of approval by the F.D.A. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Portraits of a Social Outcast Turned Serial Killer; Finding a Tragic, Searching Figure Beyond a Murderer's Dark Side
description: After she was arrested at the Last Resort bar, in Port Orange, Fla., in January 1991, on an outstanding charge of carrying a concealed weapon -- an arrest that would quickly lead to a charge of murder and culminate in her execution in October 2002 -- Aileen Wuornos, a stocky, straggly-haired woman with desperate eyes and a foul mouth, didn't hesitate to tell judge and jury exactly what she thought of them when she appeared in court.

title: SOFTWARE COMPANY ACQUIRES HEALTH SERVICES PROVIDER
description: I-trax, which sells software to help companies limit medical costs, said yesterday that it would buy Meridian Occupational Healthcare Associates, which does business as CHD Meridian, for about $80 million in cash and stock to gain sales. The closely held Meridian provides nurses and other health care services at employer sites. I-trax, which is based in Philadelphia, said it would buy Meridian with $35 million in cash, $10 million in preferred stock and 10 million shares of common stock. The transaction will add $178 million to I-trax's $7 million in expected sales this year, the chief executive, Frank A. Martin, said in an interview. Meridian is based in Nashville, Tenn.

title: People
description: Mark Androw, president and executive producer at the Story Companies, Chicago, was elected to a one-year term as chairman at the Association of Independent Commercial Producers, New York and Los Angeles, succeeding Al Califano, chairman and executive producer at A-List, New York. Mr. Androw had been vice chairman.

title: Kmart Still Has Martha Stewart, But Wal-Mart Has Its Mainstays
description: Kmart's closing of hundreds of stores so it could emerge from bankruptcy protection may have made it hard for people to find the stylish, moderately priced linens, kitchenware and other goods that Martha Stewart designs exclusively for the company. But Wal-Mart appears bent on trying to take up the slack.

Golda Cemetery, Huntington, L.I., 1PM Tuesday. Donations to UJA Federation, New York City office, or 5 Towns Kiwanis in her memory would be appreciated.

title: Interpublic Sells Most of Modem Media
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies in New York said yesterday that it had sold nearly all of its remaining shares in Modem Media, of Norwalk, Conn. Interpublic sold almost 11 million shares in a public offering, leaving it with 148,000 shares, or 0.6 percent of the company's stock.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: ARMY DROPS CHARGE AGAINST SERGEANT The charge against a sergeant accused of cowardice in October has been dropped a second time. In November, a charge of cowardice against Sgt. Georg Andreas Pogany of the Army was dropped and replaced with a lesser charge of dereliction of duty. His lawyer said that was dropped two weeks ago and that Sergeant Pogany, who is based in Fort Carson and still uncharged, was offered a separate hearing on an even lesser dereliction-of-duty charge. Sgt. Pogany has turned the hearing down, risking a court-martial but hoping no further action will be taken, his lawyer, Rich Travis, said. Army officials are "considering their next options," a Fort Carson spokesman said. Sergeant Pogany was an interrogator in Iraq who said he suffered a panic attack when he saw an Iraqi mangled by a machine gun. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Christmas Tree Recycling
description: The Sanitation Department will collect and recycle Christmas trees that are stripped of lights and ornaments and left curbside between next Monday and Jan. 10, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The program, which was suspended last year to save money, will resume this year, with the trees turned into mulch and scattered in parks and gardens around the city. The city will also hold its annual MulchFest this Saturday and Jan. 10, at which people can take their trees to selected parks and see them turned into mulch. A list of locations is available at www.nyc.gov or by calling 311. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: When Infections Strike Back
description: Women with recurrent symptomatic yeast infections often believe that their sexual partners may be to blame for reinfecting them. But a new study finds that outbreaks in women are not related to infections in their partners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOMEZ, OLGA
description: GOMEZ--Olga. On December 20, 2003, in a traffic accident. Beloved wife of Julio, mother of Olga and grandmother of Wilka. A gentle and compassionate woman of great integrity. An experienced social worker, Olga was a beacon of life for everyone who knew her. She will be greatly missed. Memorial service will be held Saturday, January 3, 2004, 12 noon at Saint Augustine Church, 116 6th Ave (off Flatbush Ave), Brooklyn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOLAN, MARY T.
description: DOLAN--Mary T., on December 27th, 2003 of Manhasset. Beloved wife of Eamonn. Loving mother of Edward. Devoted grandmother of Caroline and William. Cherished sister of Charles Golden, the late Arthur J. Golden and the late Florence. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday 11:15 AM St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Killer of Intruder Held on Drug Charge
description: A Brooklyn man defended himself and his girlfriend by shooting and killing a man who broke into their apartment on Sunday night, the police said. The couple were later arrested after the police found more than a pound of marijuana they said belonged to them.

title: Dean Raises $14 Million And Sets Record, Aides Say
description: Howard Dean has raised at least $14.1 million in the fourth quarter, bringing his annual total to almost $40 million and setting what aides say is a one-year record for Democratic fund-raising in a presidential race.

description: Fabio's Got A Real Pretty Mouth, Too

title: F.D.A. APPROVES 2ND BLOOD LITHIUM TEST FROM AKERS
description: Akers Biosciences, a maker of medical tests, says it has received marketing clearance from the Food and Drug Administration for one type of its diagnostic test for levels of lithium in the blood. The device will be sold by ReliaLab of Basking Ridge, N.J., Akers said. Akers received F.D.A. approval for another of its lithium tests this year. The second clearance broadens Akers's customer base to include the offices of doctors, in addition to clinics and laboratories, the chief executive, Raymond F. Akers, said in a statement. Akers Biosciences is based in Thorofare, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 22 about the ways Washington University in St. Louis improved its ranking in the annual survey by U.S. News & World Report referred imprecisely to the ratio of applicants to undergraduate openings. The university has 15 times as many applicants as it can enroll, not 15 times the number it can accept. (Its acceptance rate of 24 percent reflects the fact that not all accepted students choose to enroll.)

title: G.I.'s Provide Public Works As Well as Security to Iraqis
description: When First Lt. Ryan Peay reported for duty here in mid-October, his assignment was to call in 105-millimeter artillery strikes on the opposing forces' positions. With major combat in Iraq long over, that job lasted about two days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, HOWARD
description: STEIN--Howard. Beloved husband of Helene. Loving father and grandfather. Served in US Army in WWII. Was an investment advisor for forty years. He will be sorely missed by family and friends.

title: Islanders, in a Role Reversal, Defeat the Devils Once Again
description: Having shed their underdog complex against the Devils by winning the previous two meetings, the Islanders went for a dominating flourish Monday night at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Scanning a Brain for Bipolar Root
description: A part of the brain involved in emotion is much smaller in both teenagers and adults who have bipolar disorder, a recent study has found, a discovery that may help doctors make an earlier diagnosis of the disease.

title: Core of a Comet Lights Up January's Night Sky
description: Before the sun rises on Sunday, the Quadrantid meteors will make their yearly appearance, about one a minute streaking across the dark sky. A California astronomer says he has finally figured out where all those streaks of light came from.

title: Behind a Graceful Spire, Science, Art and Passion
description: IN hard hat, Guy Nordenson was one of the structural engineers who clambered for months through the smoking rubble of the World Trade Center. Now, minus the headgear, in the hushed spaces of his office near ground zero, he holds forth about torque and taper, about Ezra Pound and T. S. Eliot. He speaks with considerable stillness and insistency, just as he does with his architecture students at Princeton.

title: Experts Seek New Effort To Control Hepatitis A
description: In the wake of recent food-borne hepatitis A outbreaks, scientists and medical experts are urging the federal government to intensify its efforts to quash the disease.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Deadly Argument
description: A 25-year-old man was shot to death yesterday evening after getting into an argument with a teenager who was an acquaintance of his, the police said. The man, Michael Kendrick, was shot once in the head on Harrison Avenue at about 6:15 p.m. by the teenager, according to the police. Mr. Kendrick died at St. Vincent's Staten Island Hospital. The police later arrested Tushaun Cato, 16, of Port Richmond, and charged him with murder, a police spokesman said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELSON, SELMA (NEE LURIE)
description: KELSON--Selma (nee Lurie), age 70, on December 28, 2003. Beloved wife of Leonard. Loving mother of Andrea (Chris Fleming) and Judith (Jonathan Schuster). Devoted sister of Marian Useloff. Cherished grandmother of Jack and Nora Fleming and Liliana Kelson. Adored aunt of Andrew and Jen Useloff. Great aunt of Ethan. Services Tuesday, 11:45 am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be made to Center for Jewish History, 15 West 16th St, NYC, 10011.

title: Israel Orders Prompt Evacuation Of 4 Tiny West Bank Outposts
description: The Israeli government on Sunday ordered the evacuation of four unauthorized Israeli outposts in the West Bank, circumventing for the first time lengthy legal procedures that in the past have complicated government efforts to reverse the incremental spread of Jewish settlements.

title: Fighting for the Footprints of Sept. 11; Families Renew Call for a Memorial That Includes Traces of Towers Themselves
description: They are still there, row upon stubby row of rusting steel column remnants, abandoned in the rubble. Barely visible, they appear thoroughly unremarkable. But this is ground zero rubble. And the remnants mark the footprints of a national wound, the stumps of the twin towers of the World Trade Center.

title: Aging Oil Rigs Raise Safety Issues
description: Three decades ago, when the offshore oil fields that make Britain a net exporter of energy were being developed, most experts thought the fields would be running dry sometime around now. The industry planned accordingly, building platforms and rigs meant to last 25 to 30 years in the gale-force winds and towering waves of the North Sea.

title: FedEx Agrees to Buy Kinkos for $2.4 Billion
description: The FedEx Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Kinko's, a privately held copy center operator, for $2.4 billion in cash in an effort to win more small business customers and enhance its competitive position with United Parcel Service , its main rival.

title: Iran Welcomes U.S. Aid; Some See Opening for Better Ties
description: BAM, Iran, Dec. 30 - President Mohammad Khatami said today that the arrival of an American aid team in this earthquake-ravaged city was a welcome development but should be viewed as just that - a humanitarian gesture and not a harbinger of improving relations between the United States and the Islamic Republic.

description: In percent

title: Accounts
description: Dialog Telecommunications, Charlotte, N.C., a local and long-distance telephone service provider, to Boone/Oakley, Charlotte, as its first agency of record. Spending has not been determined. Under the three-year contract, the agency's compensation will depend in part on the number of new customers that sign up.

title: Philippines Deporting Brothers Suspected of Terror Links
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30  Authorities in the Philippines said today that they were deporting two American brothers arrested for suspected links to terrorism. One of the men worked until 2000 for the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, the laboratory said.

title: POTLATCH PRESIDENT WILL POSTPONE HIS RETIREMENT
description: The Potlatch Corporation, a lumber and paper maker, said that Richard L. Paulson, its president and chief operating officer, would delay his retirement until March to oversee the start-up of a $66 million tissue mill in Las Vegas. Mr. Paulson, 62, had planned to retire on Wednesday. The chief executive, L. Pendleton Siegel, will assume Mr. Paulson's duties, a spokesman, Michael Sullivan, said. Mr. Paulson has been with the company for 43 years and has been president and chief operating officer since May 1999. He previously ran the company's coated-paper business, which made glossy paper for magazines and catalogs but was sold in 2002 for $480 million to Sappi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DELUCA, NELLA
description: DeLUCA--Nella. Passed away peacefully on December 28, two months short of her 91st birthday, after a courageous battle with cancer. Nella was married to Matthew I. DeLuca, Sr, for 57 years. He passed away November 1993. They had a wonderful life together and leave their daughter Adele and son Matt, Jr. and his wife, Marguerita, grandchildren Vincent, Gina, Robin, Jay, Matt III, and great grandchildren Dakota and Matthew. The family will honor their mother's request for mass at St. Joseph's R.C. Church in Garden City on Tuesday, December 30 at 10AM, followed by interment at St. Charles Cemetery (there will be no wake). title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Threat To Boycott Election Is Dropped
description: The leader of a semiautonomous province withdrew his threat to boycott the presidential vote on Sunday, easing a major point of tension in the former Soviet republic after the peaceful ouster of its former president, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in November. The leader of the province of Adzharia, Aslan Abashidze, who had supported Mr. Shevardnadze, praised the mediation efforts of the American ambassador to Georgia, Richard M. Miles. In Russia, where Mr. Abashidze had turned for support, President Vladimir V. Putin had appeared to give him little encouragement and met in the Kremlin last week with the interim president of Georgia, Nino Burdzhanadze. As tensions rose in advance of the election, gunmen fired a rocket-propelled grenade at a television station linked with the opposition to Mr. Shevardnadze. No injuries were reported. The report for the year ended Sept. 27, which was due yesterday, will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the end of February, the company said. Friedman's, based in Savannah, Ga., said it wanted to resolve issues with lenders before it filed the report. The Justice Department and the S.E.C. are investigating issues, including how Friedman's treats doubtful accounts, to determine whether the company issued false financial statements, Friedman's said last month. A company that sells merchandise on credit must make allowances for uncollectible accounts, which reduces profit.

HSBC said that it would pay no more than $20 million to buy half of Fujian Asia. Ping An will subsequently inject $23 million into Fujian Asia as part of the deal, diluting HSBC's stake to 27 percent. Fujian Asia is to be renamed the Ping An Bank Ltd. Fujian Asia Bank is one of seven domestic-foreign joint venture banks that China created in 1993 in an experiment that has since been overtaken by Beijing's decision to allow foreign banks to acquire larger stakes in existing domestic banks. title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: BATTLING TO RESTORE POWER Repair crews battled blocked roads, damaged equipment and downed trees in their efforts to restore power to 258,000 homes in Northern California left in the dark by this week's storm, officials said. By the morning, electricity had been restored to 88 percent of the customers affected, a spokesman for the Pacific Gas and Electric Company said. The company is still dealing with 241 power failures from Bakersfield to the Oregon border. Winds gusting to 50 miles an hour were the main cause of the problems, the spokesman said. Trees were pushed into power lines, and lines were slapped together, causing the damage behind the blackouts, he said.    (AP)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Former Official Pleads Guilty To Misconduct
description: The former finance officer for Hainesport Township pleaded guilty yesterday to misconduct in a case involving the diversion of $339,000 in municipal money. The official, Kristine Wisnewski, 32, will be barred from employment in the public sector and could face a maximum prison sentence of 10 years, a fine of up to $150,000, and restitution. Ms. Wisnewski, a township employee since 1994, resigned from her position in August, and was arrested on Sept. 2, authorities said. According to State Attorney General Peter C. Harvey, from November 2000 to September 2001, Ms. Wisnewski diverted funds from accounts partly designated for housing and sewer projects. Sentencing is scheduled for March 3. Stacy Albin (NYT)

Its mournful minor-key songs are drenched in the blues, and they often trudge along as if they're burdened by a world of woe. But at the Beacon, fans turned them into a beery dance party anyway.

title: The Budget Politics of Being Poor

Officials in 34 states are opting to slash Medicaid and poor children's health insurance coverage as a path of least resistance to the balanced budgets mandated by law.

You can find it now in New York, in a dark green frosted bottle with a stopper that suggests an African headdress. Imoya is made in Cognac-style copper pot stills by KWV International, one of the largest wine producers in the wine country near Cape Town. The brandy is plush, full-bodied and assertive, with a nut-sweet aroma and a spicy richness. Imoya is about $30 for a 750 milliliter bottle and is also available in a gift package with two brandy snifters for about $32 at Chelsea Wines, 200 West 21st Street; Spring Street Wine Shop, 187 Spring Street (Thompson Street); and PJ Wine, 4898 Broadway (204th Street).

title: Corrections
description: A thumbnail summary of highlights on Dec. 2 with an article about the unofficial Middle East peace plan known as the Geneva accord referred incompletely to the Western Wall, which the provisions call for Israel to retain. It is the only surviving remnant of the Jewish temple in Jerusalem destroyed by the Romans in A.D. 70. While the wall is regarded by many Jews as the holiest site in Judaism, others say that distinction belongs to the entire Temple Mount. Since the seventh century, that area has also been the site of two Muslim holy structures -- the Dome of the Rock and Al Aqsa Mosque; it is one of the world's most contested religious sites.

In the kitchen of his home here one fall day, something unexpected happened, yet the dish he was making turned out fine. ''Make a silk purse out of a sow's ear,'' he said. In unison they opened up the British theater to new ideas and possibilities, and they were soon grouped together as Angry Young Men. The label never quite fitted. Each proved to have an individuality, and Bates had a virtuosity that made him the most difficult to define. When he died on Saturday, the question remained: what was an Alan Bates role?

Lehman, which provided financing to Le Meridien in 2001, and Starwood are buying the debt from lenders including Merrill Lynch & Company and CIBC World Markets Inc. Le Meridian, which is based in London, was taken over by creditors this year after the company delayed rent and missed debt payments because of a slump in tourism. Le Meridien, formed by Air France in the 1970's, owns 126 hotels in cities from New York to Tashkent, Uzbekistan. Demand for its rooms declined this year because of the war in Iraq and the outbreak of SARS. Starwood is based in White Plains.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Micromuse Delays Annual Report
description: Micromuse Inc., whose software detects failures in telephone networks, delayed filing its 2003 annual report, which was due Monday, because of an internal accounting inquiry. The review, related mostly to expense recognition, probably will lead to a restatement of results for the years ended Sept. 30, 2000, through 2003, the chief executive, Lloyd Carney, said on a conference call yesterday. The inquiry will result in new costs of about $2 million in the first quarter ending tomorrow, San Francisco-based Micromuse said in a statement. It also backed away from a profit forecast. ''You just shouldn't rely on previous guidance for earnings at this point,'' the chief financial officer, Michael Luetkemeyer, said on the call. He declined to elaborate. Shares of Micromuse fell 7 cents, to $6.83. In October, Micromuse estimated a first-quarter profit, excluding certain costs, of 3 cents to 4 cents a share, and net income of 1 to 2 cents a share. Micromuse said first-quarter sales won't be hurt by the review and raised its forecast, estimating revenue will be at the ''high end of or slightly exceed'' the $34 million to $35 million it forecast on Oct. 29. The company was expected to earn 4 cents a share on sales of $34.3 million in the first quarter, the average estimates of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial. (Bloomberg News)

title: Corrections

title: ACTUANT BUYS COMPANY TO EXPAND SALES IN EUROPE
description: The Actuant Corporation, which makes tools and hydraulic systems for trucks and recreational vehicles, bought Dresco for about $30 million to sell do-it-yourself electrical equipment in Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. Dresco has about 120 employees and $30 million in annual sales. The purchase will ''modestly'' increase earnings at Actuant next year, the company said. Dresco, based in Wijchen, the Netherlands, sells electrical switches and cables to retailers, Actuant's chief financial officer, Andrew G. Lampereur, said in an interview. Actuant, which is based in Milwaukee, will have sales of $650 million in the year ending Aug. 31, Lampereur said.

title: COURT BLOCKS GENERIC VERSION OF ZOLOFT, A PFIZER DRUG
description: A federal court barred Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, a leading manufacturer of generic drugs, from producing a low-cost version of Zoloft, a best-selling antidepressant, the drug's maker, Pfizer Inc., said. The United States District Court in Massachusetts dismissed Teva's lawsuit seeking to invalidate Pfizer's patent for a form of sertraline, the active ingredient in Zoloft, Pfizer said. The court also rejected Teva's claim that its version would not infringe on Pfizer's patent. Zoloft, used to treat depression, panic disorder and obsessive-compulsive disorder, had sales of $2.74 billion last year. It accounted for about 8 percent of the total sales of $32.4 billion for Pfizer, which is based in New York. Teva is based in Petah Tikva, Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, LEE
description: FRIEDMAN--Lee. Born April 19, 1942, his life unpublicized on purpose was the king of make it happen. In a career that launched the era of celebrity marketing in fashion and rock and roll, his inner circle was a mega database of who's who of the famous, the notsofamous and the unbelievably talented. Lee's heart beat to the tune of everything and everyone in his everything. His candid version of obvious, hip and what mattered trademarked his light up your life persona. A self-made, exquisitely honed success story and daddy of two baby girls at twenty something, his life as business mogul, father, grandfather, son, brother and best friend steered its course through his own brand of spirituality. Eternally optimistic, he owned the glass is half full mantra. Always in the moment, at 61 he understood young. A philanthropist, dedicated to New York City, the city he loved with a passion, well read and traveled and an avid foodie, Lee will be incredibly missed--the world a bit lonelier place until perhaps the next generation is lucky enough to produce another Lee. Lee Friedman passed away on December 26, 2003 from cancer. The son of Jean Friedman and the late Alfred Friedman he is survived by his daughters, Tiffany Friedman, Jessica Brown and sonin-law Erio Brown, his grandchildren, Stella Brown and Dillon Brown, his sister Abby Kinsley Davison and brotherin-law, Richard Davison. Please send your love to Lee and his family with donations to Friends In Deed, 594 Broadway, New York 10012. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: No Bids For Lender
description: The final deadline for submitting bids for South Korea's troubled credit card company, LG Card, passed with no bidders stepping forward. A spokesman for LG's main creditor, Woori Bank, said lenders would discuss a plan to jointly run LG, the country's largest credit card company, until a buyer can be found. But the plan is contentious because it would require a costly debt-for-equity swap. LG Card's domestic creditor banks have already provided almost $2 billion in emergency loans and are reluctant to provide more. LG Card's debts exceed its assets by more than three trillion won ($2.5 billion). As a last resort, the Korea Development Bank, a government entity, has said it could run LG Card until a buyer turns up. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: The Right Thing, at Last
description: After an egregiously long delay, Attorney General John Ashcroft finally did the right thing yesterday when he recused himself from the investigation into who gave the name of a C.I.A. operative to the columnist Robert Novak. Mr. Ashcroft turned the inquiry over to his deputy, who quickly appointed a special counsel. There was little chance of a credible outcome for the investigation as Mr. Ashcroft had originally chosen to run it: under his personal supervision, using Justice Department lawyers whose futures are dependent on his good graces. Even the normal investigative units of the F.B.I. would have been cut out of the loop.

title: In Packed Square, Fear Is Pushed Out By the Big Party
description: Helicopters swept the sky, and clusters of police officers stood guard on street corners. But for revelers in Times Square, the New Year's Eve countdown was about party, not panic.

description: The lights are strung, the stage is set and Baby New Year is waiting in a cage, hissing.

title: Dow Average Falls Slightly After a Year of Big Gains
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell for the first trading day in three yesterday after a decline in consumer confidence and slower-than-expected growth in Midwest manufacturing dented the optimism that had lifted the benchmark to its first annual gain in four years.

title: U.S. Issues Safety Rules to Protect Food Against Mad Cow Disease
description: The secretary of agriculture imposed a broad set of new rules yesterday to try to protect the nation's food supply from mad cow disease, including banning the use of sick ''downer'' cows and certain beef parts as well as ordering speedier testing of suspect animals.

title: Hispanic Day Laborers Sue Freehold, Claiming Right to Gather to Seek Work
description: A group of Latin American day laborers filed suit in Federal District Court on Tuesday, contending that this borough is restraining their First Amendment rights by preventing them from congregating at a vacant lot to solicit work.

title: U.S. Forces Conclude Anti-Taliban Sweep
description: American forces have wound up the largest combat operation here in more than a year, a monthlong operation involving 2,000 troops across the south and east of Afghanistan.

title: Ranchers and Companies Support New Restrictions
description: In an effort to maintain consumer confidence and to appeal to countries that have closed their borders to American beef, domestic cattle ranchers and food companies said yesterday that they largely supported the Department of Agriculture's decision to increase restrictions on beef production.

title: Office Pool, 2004
description: In last year's office pool, for the second year running, I accurately predicted the best-picture Oscar winner. Forget all of the other predictions, which were varying degrees of mistaken; I shoulda been a film critic.

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: New Year's Day, with travel information for New Year's Eve

title: F.D.A. APPROVES BLOOD TEST FOR HEART FAILURE
description: Biosite Inc. said it had received Food and Drug Administration approval to market a heart-failure blood test for Beckman Coulter Inc. The test, called Triage B.N.P., detects a marker in the blood that can help diagnose congestive heart failure within 15 minutes, Biosite said. The test also helps doctors determine the severity of heart failure, potentially reducing unnecessary hospitalization and treatment for patients who are short of breath, the company said. Sales of the test, which is already available in Europe, more than doubled in the first six months of this year, to $27.8 million from $8.1 million a year earlier.

title: From China, Hangover Help
description: I FIRST encountered jook in Hong Kong at dawn after a very long night. I was steered to an anonymous little place, where, I am quite sure, I was not the only person with a headache. It was there that I discovered that this savory Chinese rice porridge was among the world's best breakfasts, especially after a night of indulgence.

title: Deficits, Debt and Doom
description: Forums highlights, featuring readers' comments on the state of the economy and bagels.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Sanitation Worker Charged In Rape
description: A Department of Sanitation worker has been arrested on charges that he approached a woman early on Christmas Eve, identified himself as a police officer and raped her, the authorities said yesterday. The worker, Clarence Evans, 49, of East 174 Street, lured the woman into his car just after midnight on Dec. 24, said he would have to arrest her, then drove her to a secluded area and attacked her, the authorities said. He was arrested on Monday and charged with rape and impersonating an officer. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the acquittal of a Russian physicist who was charged with espionage, a verdict seen as a setback for Russia's security services, misstated President Vladimir V. Putin's history with Russia's intelligence agencies. He served the K.G.B. as an officer in East Germany; the agency he headed was its successor, the Federal Security Service.

title: Bomb Misses U.S. Convoy in Baghdad, but Kills an Iraqi Civilian
description: An Iraqi civilian was killed and three others were wounded when a homemade bomb apparently intended to harm an American military convoy exploded Tuesday morning on a crowded street in central Baghdad.

title: Flaky Chicken Potpies To Thaw a Winter Day
description: Kathy Herring, right, and Linda Twining, far right, wholesale bakers in Princeton, N.J., are selling their signature dish, chicken potpie, in stores. It comes frozen, but after 45 minutes or so in the oven the delicately flaky crust acquires a lovely burnish, and moist chunks of free-range chicken with organic vegetables in a seasoned sauce bubble beneath it. A single-serving pie is about $7, and a large pie serving four is about $20.

title: Ann S. Kheel, 88; Active in Civic Affairs
description: Ann Sunstein Kheel, a civic leader and environmentalist whose posts included chairwoman of the State Parks Commission for the City of New York, died on Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Center in Manhattan, her family said. She was 88 and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: A Prime Minister Cut Down To Size
description: Dario Fo's scathing satires on authority and establishment have carried the playwright to the heights of Italian letters, a pinnacle capped with a Nobel Prize. But in his new play he aims at his favorite target, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, from a considerably more modest stature.

title: So Much Clutter, So Little Room: Looking Inside the Hoarder's Lair
description: The cases never cease to fascinate: reclusive people trapped by their own accumulations, in rooms made unlivable by floor-to-ceiling heaps of newspapers, books and saved objects -- from twist ties to grand pianos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEVENSON, ISABELLE LU BOW
description: STEVENSON -- Isabelle Lu bow. The Board, staff and members of the Alliance of Resident Theatres/New York (A.R.T./New York), mourn the passing of Isabelle Stevenson, Chairman of the American Theater Wing. A great lady of the theater, Isabelle was a true benefactor, working on behalf of the theater and in the service of thousands of actors, directors, playwrights, designers, theater companies, producers, and above all--audiences--for more than 60 years. Our deepest condolences go to her daughters, Susan Brown and Laura Maslon, her niece Francine Ringold-Johnson, and their families, as well as the Board and staff of the American Theater Wing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANDER, MARVIN (MARK)
description: LANDER--Marvin (Mark), 75. Died December 16, 2003. Beloved brother, cousin, uncle. Born Wilkes-Barre, PA. Graduate University of Scranton, Cornell Law School. In U.S. Army Counter - Intelligence Corps. Attorney, Criminal Division, New York Legal Aid Society. Founded Criminal Law Bulletin, Idea and Image. Passionate sports fan, antic jokester. Donations to charity of your choice, or Kaley Holocaust Remembrance Fund, Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 E. 79 St, New York, N.Y. 10021. Andrea and Howard Lander Harriette and Gabor Kaley Claudette and Benjamin Pick Jeanette Dudnick

title: Original Stars Return to Light Up 'The Producers'
description: ''I used to be the king, the king of old Broadway,'' Nathan Lane sang last night in the opening number of ''The Producers.'' It couldn't have been more appropriate, though of course Mr. Lane is still the king.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Food Stuff column last Wednesday about mandarin-scented olive oil misidentified the store chain that sells it. It is Oliviers & Company, not L'Olivier. (www.oliviersandco.com)

title: How Disappearance in '84 Blighted Family in Iraq
description: A month after American troops occupied Baghdad, the family of Dr. Taki al-Moosawi was gathered at his Baghdad home, watching one of the Arab satellite channels that have become popular since the toppling of Saddam Hussein made it possible for any Iraqi, not just the ruling clique, to have satellite receivers.

description: An exceptionally violent Monday night and Tuesday in the city added seven names to the list of those killed in 2003, now at 594 and uncomfortably close to the 600 mark hailed for the last year as a sign of a safer New York.

title: Tastes of Apple and Tomato Perk Up a Party Nibble
description: Little sausages to sear quickly in a pan and skewer on toothpicks make great last-minute cocktail nibbles. The new line of mini-sausages from the Aidells Sausage Company in San Leandro, Calif., come in three flavors: chicken and apple; Cajun andouille; and sun-dried tomato. The last two are made with chicken and turkey. For great pigs-in-blankets, all you need is frozen puff pastry. The miniatures come in 12-ounce packages, each containing about 32 pieces, for $5 to $6 at Food Emporium, Gourmet Garage, Fairway, Kings and Costco stores. More sources are shown at www.aidells.com.

description: Forums highlights, featuring the highs and lows in the past year's movies and pop music.

It is still employed by Ms. Stewart, though a lawyer from another firm will try the case.

title: Gaffney Departs Quietly, Going Out as He Governed
description: His term would not expire for another day, but on a cool, clear Tuesday morning, the Suffolk County executive, Robert J. Gaffney, quietly called it a career. He answered phone calls, bubble-wrapped his mementos and was driving home by 3:30 p.m.

title: Cowboys Exploring Unfamiliar Territory
description: The Dallas Cowboys are in the playoffs for the first time since 1999, a stunning turnaround for a franchise that was 5-11 in each of the previous three seasons.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend on Friday about Broadway musicals referred incorrectly to Boy George's score for ''Taboo.'' Although it includes several songs written in the 1980's, a majority are new songs composed for the show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POSMAN, JEAN
description: POSMAN--Jean. Died peacefully on December 29, 2003, at the age of 94. Beloved wife of Hy for 63 years, loving mother of Linda, Jerry and his wife Eva. Devoted grandmother of Ellen, Eric and Kris. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, December 31, at 11AM, at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Knicks Put On Show With Purge Under Way
description: When the Knicks gathered in the locker room before their game with Miami last night, Clarence Weatherspoon's locker had already been stripped of its nameplate, an ominous tip-off to the trade that was completed just before the actual tip-off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AGNELLO, MARY, C.M.
description: AGNELLO--Mary, C.M. on December 28, 2003. She was a teacher with the NYC Board of Education. Longtime resident of Stuyvesant Town. Graduate of NYU. Friends may call at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, Friday, January 2nd, 9-9:30am. Mass of Christian Burial at Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Ave., NYC, 9:30am. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

description: ROSENTHAL--Leighton A., husband of Honey (nee Rousuck). Father of Jane R. (Michael) Horvitz and Cynthia Boardman. Grandfather of four. Brother of Charlotte Kramer. Services in Cleveland, Ohio, Wednesday, December 31. Contributions to the Cleveland Clinic Heart Center.

description: A Dover Township police officer died Tuesday night after being hit by a New Jersey Transit commuter train while investigating a fire near the tracks, the Morris County prosecutor announced yesterday.

title: Iran Thanks U.S. for Help, but Refrains From an Embrace
description: President Mohammad Khatami said Tuesday that the arrival of an American aid team in this earthquake-ravaged city was a welcome development but should be viewed as just that -- a humane gesture and not a harbinger of improving relations between the United States and the Islamic republic.

description: NEW YORK

title: Edwards Sets Work Safety Plan
description: Accusing the Bush administration of failing to protect workers, Senator John Edwards of North Carolina will announce a plan to decrease workplace deaths and injuries by strengthening laws and hiring more federal safety personnel, his campaign said Tuesday.

title: Booby-trapped parcels found at offices : Taking aim at the EU?
description: PARIS:  Booby-trapped packages sent to European Union agencies originated in the Italian city of Bologna, investigators said Tuesday, including the latest explosives-laden parcel discovered at an EU judicial coordination office in The Hague.

title: Yukos Faces Tax Charge As Merger Rift Widens
description: Russia's tax ministry said Tuesday that Yukos, the country's No.1 oil company, owed 98 billion rubles, or about $3.3 billion, in taxes and penalties for 2000, confirming long-circulating rumors that the government would try to collect back taxes from the company.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Sales To Rise 18% In 2004
description: Global semiconductor sales will rise 18 percent next year, the biggest jump since 2000, on demand for personal computers and mobile phones, the International Data Corporation said yesterday. Worldwide chip sales will reach $188.8 billion in 2004, the market researcher said in a statement. International Data revised an April prediction of 16 percent after a ''very strong recovery'' in the second half of the year. Mobile-phone makers like Nokia are selling more as they benefit from demand for cheap handsets in emerging markets and as users in the United States, Europe and Japan buy phones with cameras and organizer functions. Economic growth and price cuts are helping to spur personal computer sales to consumers and businesses. In 2000, worldwide chip sales jumped 37 percent to $204 billion, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association. International Data expects 2003 revenue to grow 14 percent. From 2003 to 2008, the semiconductor market will grow at an annual growth rate of 12.5 percent, rising to $282 billion in 2008 from $160 billion this year, International Data said.

title: Democratic Candidates Differ On Economy, but Often Subtly
description: As the Democratic presidential candidates put the economy at the front and center of their campaigns, their differences boil down to a handful of issues: how much to roll back tax cuts, how much to raise spending, how much to reduce deficits and how to approach trade.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Prison Union Seeks Ouster Of the Chief Of Corrections
description: The union representing sergeants at New Jersey prisons is asking Gov. James E. McGreevey to dismiss Corrections Commissioner Devon Brown, saying he made racially charged comments in a speech about the inequitable treatment of blacks and Hispanics in the criminal justice system.

title: West Side Trattoria With Velvet-Booth Style
description: SOME restaurants take a while to find their footing. Others hit the ground running. 'Cesca belongs to the second group. Like Ouest, the other joint venture of Godfrey Polistina and Tom Valenti, his chef and partner, 'Cesca knew what it was and where it was the moment it opened its doors. Diners did, too. Never before have I been forced to accept so many 5:30 reservations.

title: Marketers are preparing radio commercials that also send text messages to car dashboard displays.
description: FOR marketers, it may finally be paradise by the dashboard light. Big radio companies like Clear Channel Communications and Infinity Broadcasting are equipping some stations with technology that broadcasts not just commercials but text messages that appear on car radio displays. And advertisers like First Charter Bank in Charlotte, N.C., which will use the approach in a campaign beginning in late January, are signing on to see whether extra text can give their spots extra heft.

title: Rangers' Winning Overtime Habit Continues
description: Call them Tom Poti and the Heartbreakers.

title: Judge Rules Against US Airways On Calculating Pilots' Pensions
description: In a ruling that could make it harder for financially troubled companies to reduce their pension obligations or shed them altogether, a federal bankruptcy judge has ruled that US Airways must calculate its pilots' pensions according to existing regulations, rejecting the airline's argument for a new method more favorable to the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PURDY, THOMAS L. JR.
description: PURDY--Thomas L. Jr., at 94, died peacefully at home in Somers, NY on December 22, 2003. He was the sixth generation of his family to be actively involved in community service. He was first president of the North Salem Historical Society, and a WWII Air Force veteran. He had a passion for flying and woodworking. He leaves a son, Thomas III, and a daughter, Ellen Low Webster. The memorial service is scheduled for February 7, 1 PM, St. Luke's Church, Somers. Contributions in his memory may be made to St. Luke's Church, Somers, NY 10589 or North Salem Library Bldg Fund, North Salem, NY 10560.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Boy's Abuse Had Been Reported
description: The state Department of Children and Families said yesterday that it had received an emergency phone line report of neglect about the father of a boy whose body was discovered on Sunday stuffed into a suitcase in Watertown. A hospital employee phoned the agency in May 1998 to report that the father, Allen Lamont James, did not get his then 6-week-old son, Alquan White, proper care before bringing him to the hospital for mild pneumonia, according to an agency statement. On Tuesday, a spokesman for the department said no reports of abuse or neglect were associated with Alquan White at the time when Rhode Island child welfare authorities, investigating a matter related to Alquan's out-of-state siblings, asked their Connecticut counterpart to determine his whereabouts in 2001. A Connecticut social worker never saw the boy and relied on a report from Mr. James's lawyer that the child was fine. The state medical examiner determined this week that Alquan died from blunt trauma. Mr. James, 38, was charged with capital felony murder in his son's death and is being held in $1.25 million bond. The state child welfare agency is being monitored by Federal District Court for failing to adhere to improvements mandated by a 1991 court settlement. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: A Pound of Prevention
description: Mad cow disease, the popular name for bovine spongiform encephalopathy, belongs to a cluster of related diseases believed to derive from an aberrant form of a protein called a prion. These diseases, including scrapie in sheep and variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans, pose a number of scientific puzzles. Most of them concern how the disease moves, shifting forms as it does so, from animal to animal and human to human, and from an animal to a human.

title: A New University, Filling Apartheid's Gaps
description: There are more than 17,000 accountants registered in South Africa, but only 360 of them are black.

title: Writing In the New Year; A New Year's Child
description: He wants me to carry him.

title: Two Former City Detectives Discuss Pleas in Theft of Drug Cash
description: A Brooklyn federal prosecutor working on the investigation of two former police detectives charged with stealing $169,000 from a drug money courier said yesterday that his office was involved in plea negotiations with the two men.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If John Ashcroft wanted any favors on this one, he went to the wrong guy.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Parliament Backs Musharraf Deal
description: Parliament passed a constitutional amendment that effectively and retroactively legitimizes the rule of Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who took power in a military coup in 1999. The amendment formalizes a host of changes made unilaterally last year by General Musharraf that critics say further institutionalize military rule. Its approval comes after the general and a coalition of hard-line religious parties ended a yearlong stalemate last week, reaching a deal in which he has agreed to step down as army chief in a year. To legitimize the five-year term he won in a widely criticized referendum last year, he will face a vote of confidence tomorrow by the electoral college, comprising the Parliament and provincial assemblies. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: New SARS Tests Ordered for Chinese Man
description: Perplexed medical experts from China's Ministry of Health and the World Health Organization have ordered new rounds of tests for a man suspected of having SARS because previous results have been so contradictory that they cannot reach a diagnosis.

title: Off the Menu
description: There will be a New Year's celebration for children today from 4:30 to 7 p.m. at PLAYDINE at BIG CITY BAR AND GRILL, 1600 Third Avenue (90th Street). The fee, $25 a child, includes a meal, noisemakers and a countdown to 7 p.m. with an apple juice toast. PlayDine, one of two new restaurants that welcome youngsters, has a supervised play area on the lower level. It charges $10, not including food, for one child, $9 a child for two and $8 a child for three. The menu has sandwiches, salads and a few main dishes.

title: RADIAN PLANS TO CLOSE UNPROFITABLE ONLINE DIVISION
description: Radian Group, which insures mortgages and municipal bonds, will close its unprofitable RadianExpress.com unit and lay off 113 employees in Dayton, Ohio, a company spokeswoman said. RadianExpress.com is to close by March 1. The move will reduce fourth-quarter profit by 9 cents a share, the company said. Radian, which is based in Philadelphia, bought the business in October 2000, and it has never generated profit, a spokeswoman, Elizabeth Emmons, said. A decline in mortgage originations hurt RadianExpress.com, which helps lenders arrange mortgage closings, Ms. Emmons said.

title: South Asia Looks to Sign Free Trade Pact
description: Seven South Asian nations are expected to sign a free trade agreement at a regional summit to be held next week in Pakistan, according to government officials from around the region.

title: The Nets' Call to the Bench Is Answered by Scalabrine
description: Bright spots are hard to find when a team blows a 12-point lead in the fourth quarter against a team that had not won a road game all season. But it was difficult to miss Nets forward Brian Scalabrine providing a spark to a team that desperately needs more productivity from its bench.

title: An Operation to Ease Back Pain Bolsters the Bottom Line, Too
description: A complex operation called spinal fusion has emerged as the treatment of choice for many kinds of unrelenting back pain. A quarter million of the procedures, in which metal rods are screwed into the spine to stabilize it, were performed this year in the United States, three times as many as a decade ago.

title: Time to Put a Cork in '03 and Stick On a Label
description: THE year ending tonight was a good one for wine in America, and not just for the vintage, which, it so happens, wasn't bad. We will have drunk some 264 million cases of wine by midnight, about 14 million cases more than in 2002.

description: RUSSAK -- Adina. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the sister of its esteemed members Josh and Sanford Deutsch and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Restaurant To Reduce Hours
description: A major Japanese restaurant chain that serves American beef on bowls of rice, Yoshinoya D&C Company, will trim hours at some stores to conserve its stores of meat. The company, which said it has enough beef to last until late January, will temporarily close 174 of its 980 stores during late night hours. Yoshinoya's stock has fallen 8.2 percent since the first case of mad cow disease was discovered in the United States. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: John Gregory Dunne, Novelist, Screenwriter and Observer of Hollywood, Is Dead at 71
description: John Gregory Dunne, the brashly insightful novelist, journalist, and screenwriter who wrote novels and successful works of nonfiction crammed with pungent dialogue, lavish brutality and vivid glimpses of the Hollywood demimonde, died on Tuesday evening in his Manhattan apartment. He was 71.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Year of Triumphs for Women as Film Directors
description: ''Female Trouble'' is the title of John Waters's nasty, funny 1974 turn on Z-level-girls-gone-bad exploitation pictures; it's also a term that could be applied today to the world of women as directors, who still have such difficulties getting movies made, they must feel as if they're being treated like criminals.

description: The number of fire deaths in New York City jumped to 119 in 2003, an increase of 23 percent from the 97 who were killed by fire the previous year, city officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lawyers' Convictions Upheld
description: The federal appeals court in Manhattan this week approved the 1999 convictions of the name partners in Staten Island's largest law firm. The lawyers, Fredric Grae and Thomas Rybicki of Grae, Rybicki & Partners, were convicted in federal court in Brooklyn of paying kickbacks to insurance company employees to speed settlements of personal-injury cases. They were sentenced to a year and a day, but they were permitted to remain out of prison during the appeal. A defense lawyer, Ephraim Savitt, said yesterday that no decision had been made about whether to ask the Supreme Court to consider the case, which involved a challenge to the constitutionality of the federal mail-fraud law. William Glaberson (NYT)

description: The Raiders delayed making an official announcement on the job status of Coach Bill Callahan yesterday, but some players said he had been fired.
