description: For some who had still wondered whether Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the United States attorney here, would really be as aggressive as had been rumored when he arrived a few years ago from New York, the answer came this month.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a shift in strategies for feeding the poor as a result of growth in the number of working families seeking assistance misstated the name of a group that operates a soup kitchen and food pantry in Harlem. It is the Community Food Resource Center, not Resources Center.

title: Corporate Pensions Face Pressure Despite Stock Rally
description: This year's stock market rally has added more than $100 billion to corporate America's depleted pension funds, but even that has not been enough to offset forces that continue to weaken the funds.

title: MARRIOTT PAYS DEBT WITH WORLD TRADE CENTER SETTLEMENT
description: The Host Marriott Corporation, which leased a hotel destroyed in the attacks on the World Trade Center, said it would cut interest costs by repaying $295 million in debt with proceeds from an insurance settlement for the property. The repayment will include the redemption of $218 million in 8.45 percent notes due in 2008, a partial repayment of about $33 million in mortgage debt secured by four Canadian properties and a partial repayment of mortgage debt secured by two Ritz-Carlton hotels, the company said. The payments will reduce annual interest expenses by $24 million, Host Marriott said. The company, based in Bethesda, Md., received about $370 million in insurance proceeds after it gave up the right to rebuild its 820-room Marriott World Trade Center hotel.

title: Phillip Y. Goldman, 39, A Co-Founder of WebTV
description: Phillip Y. Goldman, a Silicon Valley engineer and entrepreneur who was a co-founder of the Internet service WebTV and more recently of a company that provides a service to block junk e-mail messages, died at his home in Los Altos Hills, Calif., on Dec. 26. He was 39.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Third Term Approved
description: The Constitutional Court of Ukraine ruled that President Leonid Kuchma could run for a third five-year term in 2004, angering opponents who called the ruling a dodge around the Constitution's two-term limit. The court ruled that because Mr. Kuchma was first elected in 1994, two years before the Constitution was enacted, his first term would not count against him if he wanted to hold on to office. Opposition members condemned the ruling. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NICHOLSON, JAMES J.
description: NICHOLSON--James J. The College of New Rochelle community records with sorrow the death of James J. Nicholson, cherished friend of long-standing, former member of the Board of Trustees and its Chair from 1985 to 1991. Ever the man of wit, warmth and compassion, he stood in the midst of this community for almost three decades as one who served. Wise counselor, guide and leader, he inspired us with a breadth of vision and boldness of action, always imprinted with his characteristic reverence for people. He contributed immeasurably to the advancement of this college, and his friendship has been a great gift. We celebrate his life. Stephen J. Sweeny, Ph.D. President Jean Baptiste Nicholson OSU Ohair, Board of Trustees

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Computer Sciences Awarded $405 Million In U.S. Orders
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, which is updating the Internal Revenue Service's computers, said yesterday that its government division had received $405 million in orders from federal public agencies since Oct. 5. The company won 58 Department of Defense Department contracts and subcontracts and 12 from civil agencies. They run from one month to five years and range in value from $15,000 to $60 million, Computer Sciences said. The company bought DynCorp for $950 million in March to win more government orders, which are rising as more money is spent on antiterrorism measures like computer network security. Second-quarter sales to the government almost doubled to $1.52 billion. Shares of Computer Sciences, which is based in El Segundo, Calif., rose 30 cents, to $44.61.

title: Filling In at Tourney Time
description: Backup goaltenders made rare starts. Third- and fourth-line forwards saw much more ice time. Holiday tournaments, held while 17 of college hockey's best United States-born players were competing in the world junior championships in Finland, unfolded with the help of some fill-ins. The highlights follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLEN, POLLY
description: ALLEN--Polly. In New York City, December 26, 2003. Retired executive with J. Walter Thompson and Grey Advertising. Sister of Patricia Sauter of Louisville, KY., Dee Conradie of New Canaan, CT., Janet Anderson of Westport, CT. and Edwin Allen of Cincinnati, OH. Services private. Memorial contributions, Humane Society of New York, 306 E. 59 St., N.Y., N.Y. 10022.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: UbiquiTel Raises Outlook
description: UbiquiTel Inc. raised its financial outlook for the fourth quarter yesterday as growth in net subscriptions was expected to be at the high end of a previous forecast. Shares of the wireless phone company, based in Conshohocken, Pa., rose 66 cents, or 33 percent, to $2.66. UbiquiTel said it now expected earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization in the quarter ending Dec. 31 to be in the range of $9 million to $11 million. It previously said it expected a range of $5 million to $7 million. The company also said it expected subscriber net additions, excluding resellers, to be 21,000 to 23,000, which is at the high end of the previous forecast of 15,000 to 25,000. UbiquiTel also said the new wireless number portability law, which allows consumers to switch operators but retain their number, is expected to have an ''immaterial impact'' on the company's operating performance this year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Suit Over Generic Medication
description: A British drug maker, Shire Pharmaceuticals Group, said it had filed a lawsuit against Impax Laboratories Inc. of the United States over its plans to introduce a generic version of Adderall XR, Shire's attention deficit and hyperactivity disorder drug. Shire said Adderall XR, its best selling product, is protected by two patents that expire in 2018. Shire filed the lawsuit in United States District Court in Delaware. Shire, which is based in Basingstoke, England, has also filed a lawsuit against Barr Laboratories Inc., which filed for permission to market a generic version of the drug earlier this year.

title: Mr. Deregulation's Regulations: Stuff of Politics, Mad Cows and Suspect Dietary Pills
description: The Bush administration's twin moves on Tuesday to ban the dietary supplement ephedra and the sale of meat from cows that appear to be sick on the way to the slaughterhouse underscores a simple White House maxim these days: with an election approaching, even a president who came to office assailing government regulation cannot do too much to protect consumers.

description: Democratic and Republican leaders of the Connecticut House of Representatives are examining whether to appoint a bipartisan committee of legislators to investigate the actions of Gov. John G. Rowland, with an eye toward deciding if an impeachment proceeding should be initiated.

title: Not Superwoman, Just Guidance Counselor
description: It is not yet 9 a.m. and Patricia Taylor, the head counselor at this well-to-do suburb's high school, has already attended a student community service program, met with a college representative, fielded a half-dozen calls and sifted through overnight e-mail when a telephone call comes in that requires her attention. She abandons her computer, spins around and greets the caller, an admissions officer at a highly selective liberal arts college.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Rally Called
description: Democracy activists are planning to hold their first big march tomorrow since a series of rallies in July forced the government to withdraw a stringent internal-security bill. The Civil Human Rights Front, a coalition of groups that brought 500,000 people into the streets on July 1, said marchers would call for the territory to allow the public to elect the next chief executive and legislature. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

description: LANDERS--Manfred, 99, formerly of Easthampton, NY on Tuesday, December 23, 2003 at his home in Ridgefield, CT. title: German Police Seal Off Hospital in Hamburg in Terror Alert
description: The police in Hamburg closed the streets around a military hospital on Tuesday and questioned everybody going in and out after receiving what they called ''concrete indications'' from American intelligence agencies that a terror attack was being planned against the hospital.

title: As Coach Dies Of Meningitis, People Seek Antibiotics
description: The death of a Newark high school wrestling coach from bacterial meningitis had parents and students lining up at hospitals and health centers for antibiotics this week to combat the infection, which experts say is fatal in about 15 percent of cases.

title: Pocketbook Issues at Top of Agenda as Democrats Swarm South Carolina
description: Calling himself a Vermont Yankee, Howard Dean pitched a populist economic message on Tuesday in this depressed coastal town where 563 jobs disappeared when a steel plant closed in October and where the county unemployment rate is 14.5 percent.

title: CremaLita Chain Accused of False Advertising
description: THE New York City Department of Consumer Affairs has cited the CremaLita chain of frozen-dessert stores for claiming falsely that its products are low-calorie and fat-free and, in some cases, cholesterol-free.

title: A New Agency Will Oversee Imports of Fuel For Use in Iraq
description: The Army Corps of Engineers, criticized for its management of a Halliburton contract to bring fuel to Iraq, will turn over its role managing those fuel imports to another Defense Department agency, which will then put in place new contracts, the Pentagon said Tuesday.

title: After 1,200 Meals, 'Check, Please'
description: NEW YORK, since the time it could truly be called a city, has been serious about food and not exactly shy about declaring itself to be the country's capital of fine dining. In 1828, when Delmonico's was still a rickety cafe selling pastries and coffee, a local guidebook assured visitors that ''New York abounds beyond all other places in the universe, not excepting Paris, in consummate institutions for cultivating the noble science of gastronomy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOOK, LUCYLE, PH.D.
description: HOOK--Lucyle, Ph.D. Peacefully, on December 30, 2003 in Pasadena, CA at age 102. Beloved wife of the late Fred Rathert. Graduate of the College of Industrial Arts (now Texas Woman's University), Columbia University (M.A.) and New York University (Ph.D.). Adored teacher of English literature and drama at Scarsdale High School and Barnard College; associate of the Huntington Library; survived by generations of devoted students, colleagues and friends. Memorial donations may be made to the Lucyle Hook Travel Scholarship, Barnard College, NYC, 10027, or to Texas Woman's University, Denton, TX, 76204.

title: Michael Jackson Is Said to Get $1 Million for CBS Interview
description: Michael Jackson struck a deal with CBS to be paid in effect an additional $1 million for both an entertainment special to be broadcast on Friday and his interview on ''60 Minutes'' this past Sunday, part of yearlong negotiations between CBS and Mr. Jackson, a business partner of his said on Tuesday.
